reviews.review: Palatine Hill. Alot of walking but well worth it.To make the most of it be sure to take an audio tour. Be sure to wear comfortable shoes and watch your footing! There is alot uneven walkways.
So much to see. There is so much to see here and lots of walking to do. Spend some time reading about the different ruins.

Fascinating Place. A pretty amazing place with stacks of history. I would have given it a 5 but at 14:30 they decided not to sell any more audio guides as the were closing! Instead we had to make do with a guide book and probably didn't experience and learn all about the place to the fullest extent.
Fascinating Area. We were with a tour guide. A guide is a must when touring any of the sites of ancient Rome. There is so much to see and so much that is still uncovered!

Great green area with terrific ancient Roman history. When visiting the Colosseum and the Roman Forum don't forget to leave time for a walk around this area. Its refreshing and doesn't seem as crowded as the other sights. A relaxing view of history - and no wonder the ancient Roman upper classes built their villas here.

What an amazing place!. We went to the Palatine Hill after seeing the Colosseum which is probably the best way to do it, it was a refreshing change after the crowds in the Colosseum to be able to wander freely around the site and in the comparative quiet to imagine how the buildings must have been when they were newly built. The scale of the remains is immense and covers a large area but there is a lot of greenery and it is a relaxing place to wander around. There is also a museum on the site which is worth a visit. We were slightly unlucky the day we visited as it rained quite heavily for part of the time but it didn't spoil the visit and when the sun came out it was beautiful.

beginning of the city of Rome. Palatine is one of the seven hills of Rome near ColosseumOn this hill, according the legend, was founded the city of Rome at ancient times by Romulus one of the twins, whom the she wolf took care of.Since then on it was build the palace of the rulers of Rome, where they had their own private theater and stadium for sport and horse race events.the size of the Palace must have been huge since it surrounded the stadium and theater area. from here there is just a short way to Forum Romanum

Roma2016. The Palatine Hills are my favorite in Rome. To step inside the hills and see the hones that used to once be palaces. There are still remnants of tile floors and even colored walls left intact. Most of these homes are from the emporers or even the rich folks. There are lemon and lime trees lining the streets. You can also see below the hills the Roman Forum were the senate used to hold meetings. A must see.

Excellent Way to Learn History. I recommend seeing this marvelous site with a guide. We hired a guide through Eyes of Rome and she was spectacular! We learned so much that we would have otherwise missed. It was a beautiful albeit hot day but we still enjoyed the Hill and seeing the Forum from above.

History Comes to Life. What an Architectural Gem Palatine Is to Behold!Layers of ancient history peel back to reveal themselves as you visit Palatine Hill. The origins of the Roman Empire are before you as you see how the Ancients lived. The site is wonderfully preserved and superbly lit by night.We happened to visit on a very rainy night, so best be advised to wear appropriate footwear as the cobblestones are slick.

Beautiful, Peaceful Historic Site!. Palatine Hill is the center-most hill of the 'Seven Hills of Rome'. It sits high above the surrounding area and affords spectacular views of the Colosseum and the Forum on one side and Circus Maximus on the other. I am not sure if we chose a good day to visit, but Palatine Hill was not at all crowded. It was beautiful, peaceful and serene! We spent a lovely few hours wandering the site and taking memorable, unobstructed photos!
Visit with the Forum. This is a wonderful attraction to see with the Forum. You just need to remember to put on your walking legs for this. Do not forget to see the insulae!

Beverly Hills of Ancient Rome. This is where the great and the good people of ancient Rome lived in their grand houses. Entry is included with Colosseum and Roman Forum so excellent value for money. If we had enough time I would have split these attractions over 2 days as the ticket allows you to do this. first tip - book online in advance. You will not escape the queues completely but it will help. At the moment it will cost you about 16 Euro. We had a voucher by e-mail that could be exchanged on the day of our visit (any time) by going to the reserved ticket desk at the forum. There was still a queue to get into the forum entrance as you went through security. It took us 20 minutes - I have been told since that if you go to the Palatine entrance further down the road you may get in quicker. It is very crowded at first, but thins out as you go round. The weather was wet, so spoiled our visit somewhat, as most of it is in the open. There is an excellent museum too with involving films

Brilliant views. The panoramic views from the top are amazing. The walk up is interesting with plenty of information boards along the way. This is a brilliant attraction that captures the real Rome. One important tip though: buy your 2 day/ site ticket, which includes the Colosseum as well, from the official site(€12) and NOT from the ticket sellers who charge €30 and make false promises of 'fast tracking' you!

Birthday visit! . We had a Canadian/Italian guide called Christian. Absolute star! Funny, informative, helpful! He made the tour so enjoyable. Interacted with the tourists very well and made everybody laugh and make what would've been a mediocre experience, so much better!

History ruined by idiotic exhibition . Ancient history and ruins in abundance and in the middle of it ridiculous modern art. Sorry but really annoyed me. Stop the stupidity and leave this historic site alone

Take the walk up the hill - Worth the quiet & church at the top. This was a 'find' as we walked from our Colosseo tour alongside the Roman Forum(just open-poles fence between) as well as excavation works still being done to enjoy the peace as you leave busier places behind and then discover the San Bonaventura at Panatino Church-1600's. A unique discovery and worth the walk.

Long weekend break . This was part of the coliseum entry. It is a huge site and takes hours to walk around. It was outside, but facinating and so varied. I found this really awesome and a must see along with the coliseum.
Where it all began. Fascinating historical significance. Loved the views of Rome and the Forum. We took a guided tour with Through Eternity Tours and that helped our understanding a lot.

Great history lesson. With the forum a must do visit in Rome , spent over 5 hours in this sight and felt we only skimmed the surface, lots of hills some quite steep , No water or drinks allowed in only water from a tap pipe accessible , no rest areas so can be a hard trip , but with a little imagination you can see were the great and the good of Roman life lived , the Caesars , vestal virgins etc inspiring venue

Roam where the Roman's roamed.. This place is breathtaking. Everywhere you turn there is amazing architecture. You can just imagine when walking through the grounds what it was like living there. I would suggest if it is sunny and hot go early or in the evening because there is no shade anywhere. I would also suggest going to the entrance near the Colosseum. No line up at all. We then walked through to the Roman Forum and did a loop and exited near the Colosseum where we went next. The ticket you purchase lets you enter to all three attractions.
This is where most walking comes into plY. This is the part of the Coloseium tour where all the walking is involved. But it really gives insight into centuries ago living and grandeur along the way

Visited along with Roman Forum. I visited the site as part of the ticket which gave me entry to the Roman Forum and the Colosseum. Note that if you have this ticket you cannot enter the Forum and Palatine Hill on separate visits; you have to visit both at the same time. Once you leave you can't go back in. My friend made this mistake and missed out on Palatine Hill. I entered the site at the entrance adjacent to the Colosseum. There are loads of ruins and partially intact buildings with plenty of helpful info in english to help understand what you're looking at. The view over the Forum is wonderful and the area that is purportedly the original settlement of Rome, where Romulus lived, was something I wasn't expecting to see. Pretty cool to see where is all started several hundred years before the advent of Roman society.

Summer of 1990s. Roman history 101. Make sure you have a good guide and good walking shoes . Must visit while In Rome. The remnants of the old 7 hills and the story of Romulus and Remus are captivating.

if you are into antiquity - visit a musuem. Well, from the hill you can have a really nice view on the Forum Romanum and the Colosseum, but what's really even more interesting is the musuem. If you have enough time, you should visit it.

Calling All History Buffs. The 7 hills of Rome are where the city began and thrived. This is one of them. A good guide will make the stories, people and events meaningful. Otherwise it's just rocks and columns. Great photo ops. Interesting stories. Not to be missed..
Take your time. It's a marathon to do it all but get the audio and start at 1 it's worth it so much to see and just try and absord

Interesting . A nice walk round with our guide and very interesting, the information we were given made the attraction otherwise I think we would have wondered the point ? Info and tour completed the best part of a day including coliseum which is next to it.

Huge area. This area is huge. A walk away from the colosseum and packed with tourists and students.. climbed the stairs to the top and the view is amazing with the colosseum to the right..loads of roman ruins scattered all over and this area was very important in those days
Good views from here.. We visited here as part of a tour of Rome and was pleased to visit here as well. It is worth the effort and there is plenty to see. All part of the story of Rome.
Excellent views. The views from the Palatine Hill are excellent. You can spend 1-2 hours in the afternoon soaking in the lovely sights.

Awesome view of Rome. The tour of the Palatine Hill was booked through Thomas cook and was part of a guided tour of the Colosseum. We climbed up the hill and our guide took us through the gardens and said that when we got to the top we would see the best view over Rome and Ancient Rome she was right this was an incredible experience. The view takes your breath away highly recommend that this part of the tour should be included as part of the colosseum package. Our guide was very knowledgable and enthusiastic and we were very privileged to have had her show us all the many points of interest. We will never forget the experience words cannot actually describe the feeling looking over Rome. Totally brilliant !!!
Not Much To See. When you first see Palantine Hill you are extremely impressed at the views. Upon walking the hill you realize that there is not much to see, just the views.
Central to all that is Rome . Not being an historian I had no idea how important this place is. Plan an a half day at least if you are properly guided in person or with audio.

Breath Taking View of Ancient Rome. Gorgeous view of the Roman Forum and learning about the ancient palace that once stood there was incredible. Remains of the original floor were still there! I highly recommend getting a tour guide, our guide Rachel from LivItaly was fantastic.

Of less interest to most than the Forum and Colosseum. The Palatine Hill, one of the famous seven hills of Rome, is included in your admission ticket to the Forum and Colosseum (the ticket office here, about 150 yards from the main ticket office is usually less crowded.)Of course, the Palatine Hill is a must for classical history buffs. According to legend, Palatine Hill was the location of the cave where Romulus and Remus were found by the she-wolf Lupa.But for the average visitor the Palatine Hill is probably of considerably less interest than the Roman Forum and the Colosseum. There is still active archeological excavation going on here, and it's interesting to meander up the hill before visiting the Forum.

Fabulous views. Visited here after the Colosseum as admittance was included with our tickets. There was quite a large queue because everyone went to the Colosseum first. Once in there was plenty to see and a lot of walking including slopes and steps. The view looking across to the Colosseum were well worth it.

So much to see but no real guidence. The Palentine Hill is collocated with the Roman Forum which I shall review separately, however our visit (wife being 6mths pregnant) was spoiled by a lack of toilets sign-posts and functioning.
old rome. Interesting step back in time! It's amazing walking in the footsteps of ancient Romans. Imagine the beginnings of the Roman Empire. A most see.
Nice view, but nothing much. There are some quite pretty views but that is about it. Great to take photos and spend about 1 hour should be fine.

Better than Roman forum. The Palatino is a real gem. We went here while waiting for queues to the Colosseum and Roman forum to ease. It was so historical, had beautiful views of Rome and was a beautiful place for an afternoon. Well worth a visit.

Beautiful place. Specially as part of the Colosseum experience, the Palatine Hill is definitely worth visiting.
The panorama over Rome, and specially the Colosseum quarter, is amazing
Awesome!. Really cool with so much to see. Worth climbing all the way to the top for good views. A nice way to spend your time before the Coluseum.
Must see. The view of Rome from the top makes worthwhile walking up there. You also look down on the Forum, this must have been an awesome sight 2000 years ago.

Here's where the word 'palace' derives from.. A palace on a very grand scale. One needs to know what one sees before appreciating what one sees.Try reading up on it before you go, it's worth the while. It is a pity that Rome allows lausy 'artists' to expose their trash amongst the structures. Luckily it is not as populated as the Coloseum, where you find yourself lost in a mass of people.

Less crowded than the Forum. Among the three central sights of ancient Roman heritage that you can access with one ticket (Colosseum, Forum, Palatine Hill), this one is the least crowded. With Augustus' palace it provides another breathtaking ride back in time as well as some great views onto the Forum and the city. However, explanation on the hill are quite scarce and I would recommend to bright a guidebook (I do not know about the audioguides which might be worth taking).

This is ancient Rome. This area can be toured on your own or with a guide. I did this on my own but studied it before walking around. I actually went twice since I wanted to make sure I understood and saw everything. These ruins show so much history such as where the city was actually located, below the current street level. There are many examples of Roman architecture and thoughtful planning.

Beautiful views. We had nice weather, so we enjoyed walking through this 'park'. On top of the hill there's a place where you can get a drink or some food (out of vending machines) and a nice sitting area with amazing views over the forum.

Great views and lovely walk. We walked up the Palatine from the Colosseum and then down to the Forum. I liked this sequence, and it was good to see the whole thing and then see the detail. On the other hand, we went up the Vittorio Emmanuel monument and saw over the whole thins some days later, and overviewing at the end added even more! The Palatine is quite an uphill walk if done in this sequence, but it wasn't too hot in early October. The views over the Forum were wonderful. We didn't have time to go into the structures within the Palatine, so can't comment on those. As with the Forum, the site is sufficiently big that you aren't swamped with crowds, except at the viewing platform. One tip: We got lost within the site and except that we knew that the platform was there, might not have found it.

great place to start your roman history tour. Our advice - buy your ticket which covers you for the Coliseum, Fourm and Palatine Hill from the Palatine Hill or Forum ticket office. Queues are much much shorter than the Coliseum. Tickets are valid for two days and if you are under 25 and an EU national you can get in at a reduced rate ( take id such as driving licence). However, it seems that you do have to pay by debtit or credit card not cash. The Palatine Hill is an amazing venue of, what feels like, never ending roman artefacts and architecture. The views from the top are stunning. A place which seems to exude atmosphere.

It's the Roman capital . Superb.
We didn't have a tour guide or anything and went of Trip Advisor and google for information.
Spent a good long morning waking around the gardens would take a few
More hours.
Superb.

Include this in your antiquity tour of Rome. Palatine Hill doesn't get as much attention as the other high-profile area in Rome, but it's worth a stroll. Number one, up on top of the hill you get great views of the surrounding city. If for no other reason, go to the overlook of the Forum and beyond. Bring a guidebook to help explain each area you pass through and take your time.
Must see when in Rome. Its really amazing how the Romans built this city. Imagine every detail on spent..amazing!! The photos speaks for itself..

Beautiful, full of History and in a very well conserved.. This attraction is really amazing!!! Is the size of a small villa, is a huge open air museum with pieces of art everywhere. I really feel like I was is an archeological field. Is just in front of the Colosseum and you can buy a combo ticket with this 2 attractions and the Forum Romano. It really worth a visit!

Roman History Lesson. We went early October, visiting the roman forum, palatine hill and the coliseum on the same day as you can purchase a ticket for all three, and palatine hill and the roman forum are within the same site. When getting your ticket and entering I strongly suggest going to the Palatine Hill entrance rather than the Roman Forum or Coliseum. When facing the Roman Forum entrance which is across from the Coliseums main entrance, Palatine Hill is to the left heading around the site. I guarantee the line will be much shorter and quicker. I would also recommend that if you don't have a guide, get an audio guide at the counter which is €5 from memory. Although most the ruins have information, there is so much more you can learn from the guide, even about the Emperors themselves. The only drawback from entering via Palatine Hill is you'll be listening to the audio guide's information in reverse order as it starts from Roman Forum, however I don't think this matters that much. If you really love your Roman history strap yourselves in for a long visit, we were there for 3 and a half hours and probably could've stayed even longer, there is a lot to see! The view from the top of Palatine Hill is especially good.

Hard to take it all in.. We visited after the Colosseum in the early afternoon. It was hot but worth it. Our tour guide gave us a light history lesson and pointed out which building was which and why they are important. I recommend getting a tour guide because this is a large hill with much to see. I'd like to visit again when I have fresh eyes and legs. I recommend taking a food break between the Colosseum and the hill.
So pretty. The views here of the ruins are pictuesque. There are performers here which are very similar to Covent Garden. Really nice to stroll along in the day.

Be prepared for a walk. Recommend getting a guide - this place is fascinating, it's probably worth visiting on a fine day as you are outside the whole time. Our guide was brilliant and made the whole experience really interesting.

Not enough information. Before I review this attraction I have to say that I love history and ancient ruins. But this was boring. We paid for audio guides but they were so complicated we stopped using them. My tip would be go on a group tour with a guide to explain the history to you.

Don't Miss While Visiting the Forum!. During my last trip, I had an excellent visit to both the Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum. The two attractions are combined under one ticket. You can also buy a ticket combined with the Coliseum, but I had been there before so I did not. If the line across from the Coliseum is too long, walk around the block to another gate. Doing that decreased the wait for admittance from 45 minutes to under 5 minutes.Upon entrance, the best way to cover the area is to tour the Palatine Hill first, and then cover the Forum. That assures that most of your walk will be level or downhill. The stairway from the Palatine Hill to the Forum is long and steep; you don't want to climb it.You should be sure to take pictures of the Forum from the viewing area on the Palatine Hill. The views from up top are spectacular. Then head down and go to the Forum entrance to get the full experience.Be sure to bring a water bottle or cup with you. Numerous fountains are available where you can refill the water. The water in the fountains is safe to drink.Access to this attraction is easy from the Coliseum subway station. You should be careful around the station entrance. We inadvertently walked into the middle of a PLO protest. Fortunately it had full police coverage and was peaceful.

Etymologically rewarding experience. Cuz, ya know, the word "palace" comes from "palatine." The most fun part about Palatine Hill / the Roman Forum is, IMO, closing your eyes and trying to imagine what this would have looked like hundreds of years ago.
Rome visit. This was part of our colosseum visit with a tour guide, who did a great job telling us about the history.

Amazing . Absolutely gobsmacked at the vastness of this place an ancient Roman palace overlooking the Roman forum can spend all day walking around this and the neighbouring forum just make sure you have something to eat before as only has vending machines although plenty of fountains to refill bottles. There's a very interesting museum and spectacular views and all included in your colosseum ticket. A must see
More old ruins. Interesting ruins next to the Colosseum. I would recommend having a guide or audio guide, as we didn't really know what we were looking at most of the time.
Hard work but well worth it. This is stunning and a must see for history lovers.You do need to wear good flat footwear as very uneven ground and lots of steps and walking to be done.
Great incite to Roman History . A very good walk in very old Roman history. Take a good guide. A walk in the gardens, a view of the Forum.

Spectacular views of Rome and important history today!. After visiting the Roman a Forum, my husband and I went above to Palantine Hill. This is where Romulus was said to have established Rome in 753 BC. Later, many of the Roman Emperors lived in luxury up here. There are ruins of the Domus Flavia (Imoerial Palace) and the stadium. Flowers gardens are also here, but the view of Rome from this site is spectacular. One can really see the vast Roman Forum below and comprehend better the importance and influence this had on the empire.

Amazing to walk into history but not too much information provided. With the help of some tenacious Googling, we rustled up some semblance of a clue what we were looking at, but without good data coverage you'll be lost! To see the skeletons of apartments, baths and gardens, monuments and royal houses was genuinely moving and awe-striking! Ancient Rome was just beyond belief.
Long walks and climbs. This is ancient palace still present as museum, surrounded by many destroyed courtyards atop a hill from where yo ucan see great view of circcus maximus.

Stunning scenary - Great value. The Colosseum ticket also combines Palatine Hill & The Roman Forum. This is great value for money and can easily get 5+ hours out of the ticket, even at a quick pace.Good amount of information boards.
The great Roman Empire. It is amazing how this place looks. and to look at the Roman Empire and imagine what the people were like back then this is a must-see destination if you come to Rome
Great Overlook of the Roman Forum. Are able to see the ruins and layout of the old roman city. It has a great overlook of the Roman Forum.

Good for views over the forum. We walked what seemed like miles to find the entrance to the Palatine Hills which had been reccomended by a dear friend. Unfortunately a huge deluge marred our visit there for which we were unprepared. There is an excellent viewing area, not easy to find, and the exit is even more difficult. There appear to be no signs for the exit until one is almost there!! We had to exit near the coliseum not the other side of the Hill which had been our intention.

Good Photostop. Gives you a general overview of the ancient Roman ruin. You can also see parts of the other monuments. Be careful of the beggars around this area and watch out for the street performers as they are quite awesome. Get a quick picture taken and thats all the time you will need.

Amazing!!!. I can't say enough how incredible this was. From the moment you walk up the ancient Roman road to enter until the moment I left I was in awe. So much history and so much to see. Make sure have plenty of space on your phone or camera for pictures. You can really take your time and enjoy this and you should. The line is much smaller than the Colosseum and if you get tickets for both, you can get into the Colosseum much faster. Avoid the guys trying to sell you a tour that tell you, you can skip the line. I've been told by reliable sources the tours are crap. This is a must see site!

Amazing Views. We did the tour of the Colosseum in the morning and the ticket we purchased had entry to the Roman Forum and the Paletine, which we chose to do the same afternoon. As they are so close this made a real full day as you could spend hours wandering around the forum. My criticism here is we didn't get a map with the booking and on times the attractions etc are not very well signposted and information signs are limited. When we visited there was a dreadful modern art exhibition in the Paletine, spoiling any photographs as the word LOSER appears in the middle of my photograph, made of shiny metal !! Use the water fountains to fill up your water bottles they are everywhere around the forum, the water is cold and safe to drink, we didn't pay for water all the time we were in Rome. There is no coffee shop only vending machines.
Nice attraction, need a book with information with you.. I had a guide book that saw how palatino was, it help me a lot. Prepare to walk a lot. There are a lot of things to picture.
worth it. so much stuff going on around there even if you're not into the history it's still pretty cool. especially as it's free.

Inspiring . . . .. When visiting Palatine Hill one is left with a sense of how the Roman emperors lived. From the top of the hill where the ancient palace stood, there is an expansive view of the Coloseum and the Forum as well. I participated with the Walks of Italy tour group and I recommend doing this because otherwise you will not have an explanation of the ruins you are viewing. The guidebooks just don't provide the insight that our guide did. I also ran through this area every morning that I was in Rome. It was inspiring to run the same paths as Emperors and, when in the vicinity of the Coloseum, the same paths as gladiators. Do not mis this.

Historic hills. You feel very small, when you walk around on Palatine Hill. You really feel the history of the place, and there is a fantastic view over Forum Romanum from there.What i don't like is, that right now there is several pieces of modern art blended in with the historic ruins. That's a shame.

Great walk . A great place to walk at your own pace and take in all the sites and history of ancient Rome. Large queue to get in but this went quick and the place is big enough not to be bothered by others.
Lots of water taps and toilets.

We toured this area ourselves and read the information provided on the signs.. We were very surprised at the size of this area. I never realized that the palace was this big, it's a wonder how many individuals lived here to keep the day to day activities that were required for this palace.
Amazing ... all of Rome . The walk through is great but in the summer avoid midday - so hot, little shade, no breeze! So much to take in, all just amazing

History surrounds you. What a wonderful place. Best views into the Roman Forum...you literally breathe in the atmosphere and imagine a world many years ago.
Look down over the place where Julius Caesar's funeral pyre burned...look at the Ruins of the Forum.
Wonderful.

Too much to take in at a quick glance. We really enjoyed just walking around and taking in the atmosphere after exiting the Colosseum. Weather was very hot but there are fountains to fill your water bottles.Surpprisingly easy walk from Centro storico.
Beautiful historic walk. A beautiful place, amazing walks. Can spend a whole afternoon/ day here easily. Tour guide is a must if you want to learn the history of the area without as much effort.
Amazing walk through history. All brick stone ruins but it takes little imagination of what was here 2.000 years ago... very impressive.
A first. Despite having been in Rome many many times over the years this site escaped our visits. It's a bit of a climb but so worth it for an overall view and great photo ops. Not to be missed Q

Full of History!. We visited Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum (really like one very large area) in four and a half hours. We could have easily spent longer there as we are both very interested in ancient history, but on a hot day there's not a lot of shade and there's a lot of area to cover. You can get a combined ticket that includes the Colosseum.We entered by the Via Sacra, near the Arch of Titus, which seemed to be the only place to grab an audio guide. Be aware that you must leave a form of ID and therefore have to come back to the same place before you leave. We arrived at open, 8:30am. There were no queues. The staff were nonchalant, almost to the point of rude but that is quite common at the tourist attractions in Italy. The audio guide was quite informative but tricky to use at times. It's like a little mobile phone and the map is on a different screen to the attractions so you're always switching around. There were also some errors and things that didn't match up, particularly in the Palatine Hill part. Also, it has a loud speaker, you don't really hold it to your ear like a lot of other audio guides, so you really only need one between two people. The highlight at Palatine Hill was the Domus Augustana and Hippodrome area. A wonderful place to visit, full of history.
WOW!. Walked passed a few times, never really thought to go in and had some time so I popped in. Well this was definitely worth it. The architecture and the history here is mind blowing!

Lovely Views. Palatine Hill is worth a visit when in Rome
There is a lot of History here and lots to see, some areas are still as they were thousands of years ago!

Only ruins. Palatine hill is near to Colosseum and also the entry ticket is the same of Colosseum. Visiting to that place means get ready for a long uphill walk :)Ruins tell a lot of story but before going there either arrange a guide or do little research as you will not understand anything about that place.It has a specific opening and closing time so make sure you reach before closing time and avoid it if the weather is hot.Enjoy :)

Away From the Crowds. This area overlooks the Forum and I found it most enjoyable. It was a nice break from the crowds of the Colosseum. The Palatine Museum is also worth a look. Gazing down on the Circus Maximus, it was fun to think of the chariot races actually held on the site...talk about history coming alive. I think if I had visited this site when still in grade school, I might have been a much better student of history. This site probably isn't for everyone. But for the discerning traveler and the student of history, it's worth your time. And to repeat, it's especially nice as an escape from the masses...as in crowds, not church.

Great views from up here - try to find them all!. We had a wonderful guide who took us up here and pointed out all the best spots to view the city or see archaeological sites of interest. They did not disappoint! It is not as busy up here as it is in the Forum so you are able to spend more leisure time and get more photos.

Very impressive. If you are interested in history and visiting Rom, you should visit the Palatin , which gives a good insight to the foundation and history of Rome. From the Palatin you have a great view to the Colloseum and the Forum Romanum, which you can reach by stairs. Entering from the Palatin saves a little waiting time, the ticket is valid for Forum Romanum and the Colloseum

Palatine. Such a beautiful place. You can spend hours there and just read up on everything! I would have done the guided or headset tour but I really wanted to see the Vatican too. I still spent 3 hours here!!

Wear comfy shoes! . Beautiful views of the city and so much history in this amazing place! Lots of walking, steep hills and uneven surfaces though so be carful and set aside enough time! Definitely worth it though :-) The ticket is joint with the colosseum and it is a 2 day ticket for a reason! I would not plan on doing both attractions in the same day unless you are uber fit!

Nightime is best. Walked here both daytime and in the evening. Nighttime is best and there are projectors casting images on the highlights and making everything more realistic. You can really imagine how things were back in those times. Fabulous

An amazing find . Palatine Hill is a true wonder of the world. Do your research before you go or I do recommend taking a tour. I have taken two tours now (one last year) and the information is well worth the cost.
Stunning Views. Great views of the City and the Forum below. Really enjoyed the walk to the top of the hill. Romantic as well

Great Views From Here. It would be foolish to avoid visiting the Palatine Hill as it is included in the ticket for the Colosseum and Forum. The reason being the fact that you get a magnificent view of both of those attractions and Rome generally. There are also some very interesting sites on the Palatine Hill
Lovely place. I liked the palatine hill more than colosseum. So much to see and such a beautiful place!! Will definately come back when in Rome-. Highly recommend!

Walk among the ruins. My husband and I visited Palatine Hill and the Forum directly after the Colosseum (your ticket to the Colosseum includes entry to the others). I thought walking through one nearly 2000 year old structure was cool, but Palatine Hill is even more amazing.This is an open archeological site allowing visitors to walk among the ruins of several ancient Roman structures. The imperial palace once stood on these grounds, as well as the homes of some of Rome's richest citizens. It is also the city's historical home, with tradition and archeological evidence placing Rome's oldest settlements here.Visiting Palatine Hill and the adjacent Forum was a breathtaking experience. It was impossible to imagine it as it was 2000 years ago, but moving to see it now in its state of disrepair. Perhaps there is something to the myth of Rome's founding, said to have occurred on this spot. The city's ancient roots are evident here, but it's spirit may reside amongst the ruins as well.

Just do it. We were so excited to be standing overlooking this incredible old forum village..I suggest you do it as part of a tour as there is so much to learn and understand, that I don't think you will have the same experience without it..
Great Views. Fabulous views across the city, you need to be in good shape to tackle the walking but it's worth it.

Wish we had a bit longer here!. We visited Palantine hill on a stopover in Rome recently. We were both so amazed by the sheer size of it. Definitely make sure to pay the museum a visit, as it does a great job of outlining what Palantine hill was like back in its "operational" days. As with the colosseum, I would recommend getting tickets in advance, to save you the line-up when you arrive!
must go. Do not forget to buy tickets online! In this way you can skip long waiting line and enjoy place, not crowds.

Good visit. A must do as part of the visit to the colosseum. Pleasant walk and interesting background to the history of Rome. Best to take a guided tour or a very good guide book. Some great pictures of the city , not ideal if you cannot walk far.

Part of the colosseum and forum ticket. You purchase a ticket for the colosseum and get the Forum and Palentine Hill included. There is so much history and architecture to see. There is a reson the ticket is for 2 days. Highly recommend purchasing the "skip the line" tickets. This way you do not waste time waiting in line for a long time.

Great views of Rome. Well worth the trek up the hill on a hot day to get great snaps of the city behind you. I'd like to see more interesting information signs around the area for when your visit doesn't coincide with a tour.

Unbelievable. It's hard to even describe this experience. Walking in the steps of ancient greats, seeing the awe-inspiring remains of what were once even more awe-inspiring giant structures, and hearing the related stories is a once-in-a-lifetime experience.
Pallitine hills. Great place right next to the Colleseum very picturesque and beautiful area can't miss it. East to walk around slot of area sights . Area is very nice at night.

Enjoyable but HOT visit. As with the other sites in the area, a visit to Palatine Hill is inspiring. All around you are places where early Romans worked and played over 2000 years ago. While mythology holds that it was on this hill that Romulus and Remus were found and raised by the she-wolf Lupa, excavations show the hill was in use by bronze age residents over 1000 years before Rome's founding. Additionally tradition holds that the hill was named for an early Greek city Pallantium located on the hill.While the hill had a reasonable number of explanatory signs and maps, we made several unsuccessful attempts to find places overlooking the Circus Maximus. We were more successful in finding a view overlooking the Forum. As I mentioned in the title, it was a very hot day. The northern side of the hill was shaded and there was a vending area at which we could buy cold water.

Great Ruins. Loved touring through Palatine Hill with our City Wonders Guide Maria. Seeing where Rome was once run and where the gavernment at the time resided was very cool.There is a lot of walking but it's well worth it.

You don't need to pay for a tour if you do a little research. How many buildings that we put up today will still be here in 2000 years? I find the whole Colosseum, Palatine Hill and Roman Forum fascinating. Just imagine what people would think visiting for the first time in its hey day, It must have really cemented the superiority of the Romans. Do a little research online and print out your guide and visit at your own speed.Hint: you can enter at either the Palatine Hill or the Colosseum. Lines are usually non-existent or very short at the Palatine Hill entrance and it is a short walk from there to the Colosseum if that is your preferred destination.

Awesome historical site. We hadn't really known what to expect as the site was included in our Colosseum ticket but it was incredible. You do need to walk carefully as many paths are uneven steps but it's with the walking around. The museum was very useful as it helped us understand more about the Roman Forum too which is next to the hill. It's best to visit the hill before walking around the Forum. There are plenty of information signs in English too. It's a good idea to take a drink with you as there isn't a cafe but I believe there is a vending machine.

Fantastic place to visit. Excellent place to visit. Some amazing archaeology and history. The audio guides are well worth the cost. Only downside was the very unfriendly and bad-mannered woman when we bought the entrance tickets - she really needs to get a job that she enjoys!

So much history. Stopped here just before the Colosseum as it was part of the ticket. It just leaves you in awe, thinking about what all this used to look like back in the day, how magnificent it was and well, still is!

Go by to Palatine Museum to Enhance This Visit. This was my favorite place to visit. If you want to get your steps in, be prepared for steep stairs but everything is well worth it. Not an ADA friendly area. Found a couple of city drinking water fountains, so bring an empty water bottle as there is no place to purchase food or beverages and you will need to hydrate.There is a bathroom near the garden area at the top of the hill. The buildings near the garden were under renovation when we visited = not even sure if they are open to the public if renovation is complete.You will notice the Fleur de Lis (French Cross) on some of the walls - interesting information on this shown in a film at the Palatine Museum. That film is about 15 minutes and is in English and Italian.View of the City, Colosseum, etc., is magnificent at the top of the hill. You will see a lot of lime trees there. Be sure to check out Augustus' house remains but budget the time for the Palatine Museum - it is incredible and educational. Would definitely make this entire area a go to place for sure.

A lovely walk through one of the most ancient parts of the city!. The Roman Forum and the Palatine Hill are adjacent to each other and you can walk freely between the two. Both the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill have separate entrances. The hill became a residential district attracting the nobility and the area gave way to imperial palaces. Although it is a picturesque setting and very green on the lower level, there are minimal ruins to be seen here and it was used more as a thorough fare through to the Roman Forum for us. Still a lovely walk though and has to be seen!!

The heart of ancient Rome. Forum Romanum and Palatine Hill are considered the center of ancient Rome, climing the hill you find the House of Vestal, Domus Flavia and the Romulus & remus Monument.From here you can see the Arc ot Titus, Temple of Saturn as far as the Bath of Caracalla, Pantheon, and Colosseum all the real and imposing show-case of the eternal city. The Palatone Hill is open for the public daily 9 a.m. till sunset. A must for any visitor when in Rome.

A lot of walking for not a lot of value.. We only went here because it was free with the Colosseum ticket. Having already been to Pompeii the day before and just having left the Colosseum, this place was pretty lack luster. Not to mention in the courtyard of an impressive ruins, was a sign with 3 foot high large block letters saying LOSER. Kinda kills the atmosphere.... Unless you have a lot of extra time on hand, I would give this place a skip. There are just so many better things to see in Rome with your time.

Steeped History and a view over old Rome. To stroll through the gardens and think of all that has happened in the past in this location, the people that have resided love lived and died is an amazing experience, To stand on the hillside and survey the city as emperors would have done two thousand year ago connects you to the past.

Fabulous historic views. Use your imagination and imagine the ancient Romans walking among these buildings. Although the ruins are not complete, they give a great insight into how life must have been.
part of the roman fourm. thus attraction is part of the roman forum. buy your tickets online with the collusisum in order to skip the ques

One of the must sees in Rome. Take a walk from the Palatine Hills down to the Colosseum on the original Roman road build before Christ. It will send shivers down your spine to know how far we have come and how amazing cultures were even in those years before technologies.
Majestic. Again the Gladiator Tour company was fantastic. Another must see if you're in Rome. Definitely should see again if I'm in Rome.

Palatine Hill tour. We had a wonderful tour of the Colosseum and Palatine Hill. I was so fascinated by the sights, I actually tripped & fell in front of the place where Julius Caesar was cremated. Should have been watching where I was going, but was in awe of the fact I was in front of such a historic place. Pretty memorable, even without the fall and the men of Rome being so wonderful to rush to help me up.
Very steep Hill with Stunning Views. It's a fair trek up on a hot day, but the views are really worth it. The gardens were slightly trampled looking in August.

great ruins to visit. palantine hill has some of the best ruins of temples and palaces and some great views of rome from the top a ticket gets you into the colosseum and palantine hill which are next to each other

A tough climb. The Palintine Hill is a must for great views & the ability to walk
from the top of the Roman Forum. Expect many steps which are very steep.

Vast Roman settlement. Better than ColosseumPart of three visit ticket package - Palatine Hill, Roman forum, and Palatine Hill. Allow full half day to visit all three. Start here and when crowds thin at Colosseum move there. Lots of walking and steps to see it all, but worth it. They continue to excavate the area and huge amounts of the rich old Roman city are now visible.

Allow half a day. Palintine Hill covers a very large area so be prepared to be on your feet for a very long time if you want to see it all. There are plenty of stairs to climb. Many people had small picnic lunches with them. The small museum is worth a quick stop and has free toilets.

History all around. Walked this hill twice. Once with a guide, but of course, that was the first time. Too much to say except, this walk is full of more history than you might be able to take in in one day so give it two if you can.

Looking at rocks. Was not provided with tour guides or sign boards that effectively shed light on the heritage and history of the place.So ended up was that I felt like I was looking at old ancient pompous rocks. Getting a tour guide however meant kaching so wasn't so attractive to me a budget traveller.

Enjoyed more then the coloseum . Been to Efes in Turkey. But this is far more beautiful. Best ruins I have ever seen. Literally waited for a ancient Romen to walk out the palace to greet us. In such great shape. Well preserved. Fantastic view of Rome. Fascinated by every building. Would like to revisit Rome just yo tour here once again.
Amazing history!. Do a guided tour of the Pallatine at least once. It will give you a much better understanding of Roman history which is absolutely fascinating.

Good Views. Again, read up before you go there. The views are very nice, especially of the temples across the street. It can be tiring on a hot day, the good thing is that there are no lines at the entrance.

Watch out for giant rabbits!. Did this with Colosseum. Really lovely views and very interesting. Was amazed to see 2 very large rabbits munching away in different areas. This certainly caused quite a stir amongst the tourists!

Nice scenery . The hills are beautiful after seeing the colluseum and the forum. There are not much to explore but it is a must see. Provides a perfect view from up there tonthe forum. The hiking in the nature is very relaxing. Visit the museum up there.

Walk where the ancient elite made their home.. Absolutely a must. Walk where Caesars have walked, you may expect to see a " Hollywood" sign close by. Palatine hill really gives you an experience of what the elite of the day looked down upon.

great visit. next to the coloseum and worth the visit, entry price is included with the coloseum, have a walk around and imagine as it was centuries ago, this place gives you a real feel for the ancient city, its a shame the Romans decided to run a road through the middle of it in 1933, however it would seem they are looking at this and exposing the original, well worth the visit both day and evening when projector screens are used to super impose how it was on the walls

Part of the whole picture that you must include. If part or all of your trip to Rome is to get a feel for the Roman Empire, then you must include Palatine Hill in your itinerary. There are certain standouts--the Flavian Palace Stadium, the view of what was Circus Maximus and of course the breathtaking view of the Roman Forum. However, our guide poured a little water on one of the old marble floors, and in the light, after all of these years out in the elements, the beauty is still striking---I can only imagine the stunning beauty and of these palaces in their heyday. I don't see how one could visit Palatine Hill without a guide--there is just too much that one would miss without a person that knows and understands the story--and can relay it. The high level of engineering and planning that was so far ahead of the rest of the world is amazing.

Wonderful piece of history. Visited as part of a group tour conducted by Walks of Italy. There is a lot to see but would highly recommend going with a guided tour to fully appreciated the historical buildings you are looking at.

Amazing place! Stunning ruins. Bizarre and distracting modern art whilst we were there. I visited in September 2016 with my best friend Doddy. We loved this site.But were distracted by the modern art, which we felt detracted from the stunning ruins. I would love the site to have clearer signage relating to the numbers on the map that the ticket office gives you, as the site is vast and it's not very clear to tell what you're seeing. We loved the video showing the ruins as they once would have been thanks to computer whizzardy. This site is VAST, so allow a full day. Well worth a visit. Yummy fruit stalls outside with fresh fruit, smoothies and slices of coconut to delight on before you go in.

Loved it . This place is huge and fascinating. Lots of information around to explain everything. There's loads to see, make sure you have drinks with you as couldn't find anywhere to buy any.Thoroughly enjoyed this. Excellent value!
Like stepping back in time. A definite must on everyone's visit to Rome. This is certainly one of Rome's many treasures and better seen in person.

Fantastic. A fantastic tour of palatine hill. Our tour guide Christian was fantastic full of facts but also had a great sense of humour. Need good foot wear as lots of walking but lots of lovely fresh cool water from the many water fountain.
breath taking. This view of the city is amazing and one of a kind. You can see so far and it's so beautiful. This is a must see just like everything else but this tops the charts.

Hidden treasures. You could easily spend 3 days just exploring this place. What a wonderful place, full of stories that are just fascinating. Our tour guide was incredible with such knowledge of the area. Every corner is a place of mystery and exciting tales.

A great view of the Roman Forum and tour of the Palaces of ancient Rome. Many visitors see this as a side trip to a tour of the Roman Forum, but it is an amazing place to get a real insight into how the ruling class of Rome actually lived. It is a fairly steep climb up the hill, but well worth it. There is also a museum up on the hill which describes the original inhabitants of the area prior to the establishment of Rome and thru the next 1000 years or so. The view is amazing and takes in the Forum, Circus maximus, the Collossium and much of modern day Rome
great views. fantastic views over rome, and lots of historic buildings or what is left of them, history lovers will enjoy walking around here

Peaceful,beautiful and amazing.. Anyone who knows the story of the History of Rome knows the importance of the Pallentine Hill.Not only is it the origin of Rome but it gives the name to what we call Palaces in modern times.The imperial palace at the top of the hill is amazing to see and the balcony over the circus maximus truly gives you a perceive of just how vast these structures and amphitheatres were.

Must visit. For this I would highly advise a tour guide. We didn't and missed a couple of bits.It was so hot when we visited but they have drinks available inside. Be sure to take lots of fluids. Beautiful views of the Colosseum

Great views. Did this as part of a guided tour. You get fantastic views of Rome and the colosseum from here and the buildings are numerous and very well preserved. To get the most out of the history would recommend doing as part of a tour. You can do here, the forum and colosseum as part of one tour as they are all next to each other and take about 3 hours to view them all.
What views!. You can see for miles. Fantastic to see the old and the new buildings and skyline of Rome, and you can sit and rest in the sun while doing it.

Very Atmospheric and interesting. The sense of history here is palpable. Luckily it is a very large site so is not unbearably crowded even in high season. The views over the city are sensational as well. This is far better than the Coliseum which is next door. We used the archaeology card to avoid queueing for tickets although in fact there was no queue at the ticket office - only at the security check.Sadly although still good this is not anything like as wonderful as it was 20 years ago as the security procedures are intrusive.

Amazing site, great value. We were advised to come to the Palatine Hill entrance to purchase our combined ticket to see this site, the Forum and the Coliseum, as the queues would be shorter, and that tip paid off after seeing the queues at the Coliseum (we only waited 15-20 minutes). We did intend to get the audio guide, but did not have our passports as security, so could not get this. Even so, we spent a great deal of time here and at the Forum (they flow from one to the other) and we were glad that we started at the top and worked our way down instead of having to go up at the end. The site was amazing, so interesting even without the guide, and such good value (12 euros) to see this site and the Coliseum. There is a small museum with a film show, which shows what the site would have looked like during Roman times - very good. We spent 2.5 hours here, stopped for lunch and then went to the Coliseum, another 1.5 hours, this time with an audio guide (did not need a passport for that one). Still had to queue to get through security - tip don't take water in with you, it is not allowed - take an empty bottle, you can fill it up in there.

Wonderful history. I saw this site on a The Roman Guy tour. It was very interesting to hear the history of the hill as well as see pictures of what it looked like in real life. I'm sure there are lots of other guides you can hire to walk you through it, I'm not sure if they have pictures though. It was definitely worth a visit. It's such a big area that the crowds don't seem nearly as oppressive here.

Great historical site. We visited palatine Hill as part of a guided tour (with Special Quality Rome Mircha) of the Colosseum, the whole experience was very good. We learned a great deal and were told who lived there, who worked there and why, while looking at the different areas.
Lovely views . Beautiful views from up here. We didn't have much time here but you could easily spend a good few hours here. Well worth a visit

Take the stairs for a Nice view. Enter the forum and keep on the left, you will see a building with stairs, go up and keep on climbing untill you reach Palatine Hill. It is worth it! The views you get over the city are a Nice plusAt one place you will see the Colosseum behind a part of the Forum.On a hot day take water and something to cover your head. Not much shade. There are a few vending machines were you can buy something or you can use the free drinking fountains.
Yet another pile of rocks.. There are pieces of Roman buildings all over Rome. If you are particularly interested in Roman history or archeology then this would be for you.

Fantastic views. Overall,this was a fascinating place.......lovely gardens to walk around but I found it quite sad and eerie in places.There was a modern art exhibition going on when we visited and,to be honest,I found it pointless and rather condescending..........

Everything you want in Rome. One of the most impressive historical places you could ever visit, right beside the forum. Get tickets for this and the Colosseum at the palatine hill to avoid queuing at the colosseum for what would have been hours in our case, although we went in summer.A Must see!!
A must!. You have to see it! It's so great and gives so many amazing views. Walk around at your leisure and you won't be disappointed

Suitable conclusion. We visited the Palatine Hill at the end of a four hour guided tour and enjoyed the relics of the Royal palaces, the hippodrome and the views across the Roman Forum and the modern city. Appropriate insights were provided by our guide Alessandro.

Views are fantastic . The views from the Paletine Hill are stunning with the Circus Maximus to the West and the Forum to the East.Lovely and cool as you walk around the hill and into Caesar Augustus private Palace.

Wonderful Views. This area is a lot larger than you might anticipate. Lots of stairs to climb to the viewpoint but the view over one of the most ancient parts of Rome is amazing.Not wheelchair accessible but parts of the ajoining Roman Forum are.

Fabulous View more history !. The Palatine hill is packed with great viewpoints particularly overlooking the Forum Great place for selfies and a great panorama It's worth going down both sides to get the different views etc A visit to the museum is a must it goes on forever and it has lots of art architecture and a great story You can get lost in time in there In particular It has some awe inspiring statues and bronzes and you will need to allow a few hours to give it justice Again the Roma pass gets you in so worth getting if you are visiting a number of attractions

Mind blowing. This is a stunner, with an off the charts view of the Collossueum.
It also looks down on the Forum.
Many wealthy Rimans lived up here, so there are plenty of places to see.
We did a combo tour of the Collosseum, here, and the Firum, and it was well worth the visit.
Wonderful. A though hill but really worth it, wonderful view of the forums, worth visiting although it's a bit of a steep hill

Ticket/ Queue advice. We tried to pre book but the payment page was in Itallian and couldnt get it translated. We paid 7.50 euro each (at the colosseum) as are EU citz and under 25, otherwise it is 12 euro , the ticket includes the colosseum and palatine hill & roman forum (hill and forum have two individual entrances but are all in one and connect at some point which no one told us so we had to pay all over again just to do the hill - worth it though it was my favourite part) Ticket wise I would buy first thing in the morning if buying from the Colosseum or from the Palatine Hill entrance which is always very quiet, Colosseum opens at 8.30 and is so busy from about 9.30 onwards,Palatine hill was my favourite place we visited in our 5 days in rome.

Roaming in Rome. I sent my girlfriend here and she is there right now! It's a fabulous Piazza full of people, shops, churches statues, so much history and beauty! You can sit and have a gelato or cappuccino and people watch, feed the pigeons or visit the shops. All good. A must see stop in your meandering in Rome!
Amazing! . I was so impressed with the Roman Forum! I could just imagine how it was in it's heyday. We took a tour of this along with the Colosseum and we weren't sad that we did. So cool.

Better than I could imagine.... The most amazing pls e to visit steeped in history and amazing stories of Roman times!! Our guide was amazing and went into great detail to help you imagine what life would have been like all those years ago!! A trip that you will never forget. Lots of walking and stairs so be prepared to walk for miles!!

Sightseeing. A must to see in rome you can see how the romans lived you can even see marble flooring where the excavators have unearthed and its beautiful its a long walk and not far from the colaseum so its a must
Must-visit place. If you have enough of time - visit Palantine Hill/ Great view on old Rome and especially - on Roman Forum
So much to see. There is so much to see here, many steps to climb and the views are fabulous. Again an explanation of History is given on the templates around the area. Good walking shoes are a must.
A very Physical climb. It's a long climb to the top especially in the heat, with only 1 toilet and 1 water tap when you get there, but beautiful views of the Roman Forum make it worthwhile.
Roman history. Another great historical site to visit if you love your history. So great to walk the cobbled streets that Ceaser once walked.
Excellent bit of history. Superb ruins and great history of the origin of Rome. Recommend a good tour guide to give you more info. Lots to see and some excellent views.

Colosseum and Vatican tours. Lumi, our guide could not have been better, and brought the complicated history to life with facts and a very dry humour! We loved it all, and well worth a visit - very highly recommended

Amazing Ruins. This is a must see while in Rome. All the architect is amazing. It feels like you are taking a step back in time. There is a lot of walking and stairs to climb to see this and I would suggest a tour guide if you want all the history behind it and what each building is and was used for.
worth the walk. best views over ancient Rome, worth the slightly steep walk, probably not best-suited to elderly or infirm

A must visit. Excellent place to visit.We went here as part of our colosseum tour.If you go in the summer wear a hat as there is no respite from the heat.book a tour with a guide its well worth the extra euros
Excellent views. Great day out, visiting this historic place. You transform yourself back to those early days imagining what it could have been like. A must when visiting Rome

Mind blowing!. Along with the forum (same entry ticket), this is a MUST do. It will show you how advanced Romans were compare to the rest of Europe. Explore the forum streets and climb the Palatine Hill for some amazing 360 views of Rome.

If you love history. We visited Palatine Hill after Colosseum. It involves a lot of walking and a couple of steps. It is full of history and have a great view over Rome, specially nice for great pics. It was a bit too much of info for me, but still enjoyed it.
Very nice. We had an amazing view of Palatine Hill and the Circus Max below! A very nice site at the end of our tour of Rome
Also part of the Colosseum "Roman Guy" Tour. Very impressive. Lots of walking, but well worth it. Our guide explained everything very well & you got to see much more than I had ever imagined

Incredible. Visited along with the a visit to the Forum without a tour guide as this allowed us to go at our own pace... the average tour lasts 2-3 hours and we needed almost twice that. If you do wish an audio guide you will need a form of ID which will be returned to you when you return he equipment. Take your own food as there is no on-site cafe.
Surprising. It was The most perfect experience for us (a family with 2 kids) at Rome. But you need to buy tickets before and need an áudio guide. You need at least 3 hours to see everything!!
Pretty cool. This is right by the Coleseum so it is is easy to visit and it gives you a glimpse of the Roman world.

Impressive!. My wife and I recently visited Palatine Hill with a tour from our cruise ship. There are some amazing ruins to see. Just be aware that the ground is very uneven and a little muddy in places. I would advise a tour or you may not have much of an idea what you are looking at.

Best site to visit. This is the most interesting and best site to visit. Loved it. You will need to get there early and buy your ticket, otherwise even in Sep the lines are long about 1.5 hours. Lots of guides offering you tours with instant access to the site at 35E a piece, not worth it. That is pretty expensive when you can just walk around yourself and use a audio guide which is 5E. I do strongly suggest getting there before 9am and lining up for tickets.

It was ok. I knew nothing about Rome really before coming here in July. My high school history of Rome was not existent. We did a 40 Euro tour which was not worth any of the money we spent. I would spend around 90 - 100 Euro next time and get a better tour guide. In July it's so hot walking around. Bring around 3 large cold or icy water bottles. You'll need it. You can buy water from vendors around the place. We did our tour at 1pm and it was too hot then. Early morning would've been a little bit better but not by much. Just pick a better month to go than July. Great photo opportunities throughout Palatine Hill and make sure you follow the tours if you choose to do it solo as they will take you to the good look out of Rome where you see how ridiculously big and grand this city is.

Visit whilst in Rome . After visiting the colosseum, we continued up to palatine hill, with the second part of the tour that we got, we went though and saw the sites, have to say the view from the hill of the colosseum at the start and once at the top of the hill the view over the roman forum we spectacular a must see
Amazing views. Another must-see in Rome. Allows an excellent view over the old Roman city and the old stadium. It is a very good way to see the place but it is not an easy walk to get there

Very good. Use a guide & get the full benefit of this tour. It was part of the Viator "Wonders of Rome" trip for us but there are very many other excellent guides. The history is endless. The talks & views are amazing. I suggest you read up about the tours before you go.

Good views of the Roman Forum. Some old marbles seen on the Palatine Hill but remains largely un excavated. The highlight of this would be the spectacular view of where Circus Maximus used to be, as well as the overhead view of the Roman Forums.

Absolutely amazing views over Rome.. Really worth the climb up the hill, amazing ruins at the top and absolutely stunning views over Rome (including the Colosseum). Great to see work in progress uncovering and stabilising even more ruins. Wear good shoes!

Oozing history . From Mussolinis house to the richest repository of Roman hierarchy this place is one for the history buffs. Lots of walking but worth every step, great as a tour coupled with the Colusseum, and the forum

Palatine Hill for Tourists. We recently visited Palatine Hill as part o a group tour and the history of and the buildings viewed were amazing. It would have even better if there was some shady areas to rest under, more drink fountains and/or stalls selling such items and more toilet facilities.
hot and humid. This should be taken in samll doses, a lot of rocks with a lot of history but I had to buy a book with an overlay page to appreciat what this 2000 years ago

Blew my mind. This was one of the best places to visit in Rome. Despite the scorching heat of the day it was fascinating to walk around these monuments, getting up close and really being able to appreciate their monumental (excuse the pun) size. I could have spent so long here...

Nothing Spectacular to See!. This is part of cosmos tour in Italy. Better have a local guide with you. Be prepared for a lot of learning, walking and a lot of rock sights.This way, you will add context to the tour and everything will be a lot more interesting! Comfortable shoes are a must and, even in the summer, a jacket might come in handy!

Best view in Rome. Incredible view on Palatine Hill with so much history with every direction you look. In the Roman Forum, we left Palatine Hill till last just before it was closing which was great as the platform was less busy. A must see if you are in Rome!

So much history in these ruins. Palatine Hill is the center most of the 7 hills of Rome. There are a number of legends about Romulus and Remus, the twins found by the she-wolf, that are part of Palatine Hill. This hill became the site of the Imperial Palace since it was the highest spot in Rome. Augustus, Tiberius, and Domitian all built there palaces here. It looks down on the Roman Forum on one side and the Circus Maximus on the other side. The ruins of the palaces are impressive in themselves. One of the most exciting discoveries was the discovery of the Lupercal cave. Because it is under the house of Augustus and partially collapsed, archeologists were only able to see mosaics in the grotto by scan. Even so, there is still so much to see and only one ticket is needed to see both Palatine Hill and the Forum.
Saw it from a distance. We were pushed for time and could not stop there. the line was long s well. It was so impressive from the bus. Next time we will stop for sure

The biggest of Rome's 7 hills (and that is not saying much). The Palatine Hill stands 131 feet higher than the Forum and it was one of the two hills that defined the Forum. Today, Palatine Hill is incorporated into the landscape; hotels, shops, bridged walkways, and (of course) historic relics dot the geography.
It is not a big hill (by American standards). The Hotel Palatine is located on Palatine Hill.

Remarkable. Was a quick trip as part of Coliseum & Forum, but great history and well worth seeing. The miraculous views there must of been in Roman times right to the seven hills of Rome.
Wish we visited more of it and spent more time

Worth it's weight in gold. We purchased a combined ticket (via the mobile site) with the Colosseum, and not only did we only have to wait just 5 minutes to get in there, but we saved on the price of entry for both sites! Couple this with the fact that the price of entry to the Palatine Hill alone would have been worth the visit, we were extremely pleased with the complete package! So much history, so much information and well presented. We were in Rome at Easter which meant one of the busiest times of the Roman Catholic year, but we were not rushed nor swamped by excessive numbers trying to get through the site. We would absolutely recommend this place for almost anyone except if you have serious mobility problems, in which case you will want to avoid it, sadly. Also make sure that you have plenty of water with you and have applied your suncream as its very open and exposed! (Even in April!!)

sightseeing. as with the roman forum there is a lot of walking and you need plenty of water as it is very hot. but enjoy taking in all the glory of what once was a beautiful place. appreciate the history.

First choice in the Forum area. For planning your trip to Rome, go during Italy Cultural Week, 9 days of free admission to all government operated sights of touristic interest. In the vicinity of the hotel, that means free admission to the Colosseum, the Forum, Trajans's Forum, the gladiator school, Nero's Golden House, Palatine Hill, and the Capitaline Museums. Figure on saving more than $100 in admissions, and, since it was free, we took a walk thru the Forum on several days.The colusem is great. The Forum is great. The Palatine Hill is better.
Great time. Enjoyed the visit and got some amazing photos with my husband. The hike to the top was not too difficult and there are lots of water fountains to fill your water bottles.
Amazing views of Ancient Rome. From this hill you can see so many of the ancient structures of Rome. We were absolutely wowed by the history here. It is an absolute must-see!

A Beautiful view--not crowded like so many other places. Our driver took us to see the Forum and Santa Maria Antiqua views from the Palatine Hill. It is just one impressive view--you get a real sense for the extent of the ruins that exist in Rome, and recognize how modern Rome has been built on top of most of them. It was the one place that was not crazy crowded and was a phenomenal way to end a long day of touring.

Must do on your Roman Trip. This is a must do on your trip to Rome, part of the history 101 part of the trip. There are several areas that are free but also a museum as part of this attraction. We did a simple view but if we had more time the museum would be a welcome addition.

More than you expect. There's a lot here, and you should really get a guide or an audio tour to experience it properly. I would not recommend doing this with young children, or if you can't walk. My boyfriend is a history buff and he said this passed his expectations. It's fun to walk around, but expect to WALK>
Great view. After a long walk enjoy view from top of the hill. Refresh yourself with coffee sold at automatic machines.

Very interesting. This is within the forum there is a museum which has a couple of toilets in it
Water fountains to refill your water bottles around the grounds
A really interest place
Quite challenging if you have mobility issues
You can buy your ticket here for the Collesium and forum joint entrance a really short queue
veiws really good. again as part of a tour and again the guide invaluable. Quite a lot of uphill walking but if you are able it is well worth the visit
Do with the Colosseum tour. Mind boggling, how did they do this. Do this tour with the Colosseum and before the Vatican to get perspectives of where the resources came from.

One of the world's most impressive pieces of history. I was on crutches for our trip to Palatine Hill due to a scooter wreck in Capri, but we still marveled at the small amount of the Palatine Hill that we saw. We took a tour of the House of Augustus, which I recommend. I was surprised to discover that the word "palace" derives from "Palantine."
Must Visit After The Colosium. We enjoyed the history. It is a great place to walk around freely and take pictures. Read some of the history before visiting Palatine Hill.
The views. This was a great spot to see the overall vistas of the Forum. Had a lot of walking to see all of this. So wear comfortable shoes.

Awesome . Like a best kept secret ... Make sure you climb up its well worth it and goes on for miles - it's incredible !
Buy tickets in advance online with forum and colosseum ....it's well worth it !

Lots of ruins. This is another site near the Colosseum that we were able to get in for free since it was the first Sunday of the month. A lot of walking in the hot sun but we brought our water bottles to be able to fill up from the fountains. We entered within the Roman Forum and was able to avoid the long line to get in. We were able to view the Palatine museum. There is also a pleasant garden where we had an overview of the Forum.
Great view. Another wonderful site and stunning views. Have a good pair of walking shoes though. You will appreciate the views and take your time looking round.
History fest!. With the right tour guide this place comes alive - we had Stefani from City Wonders who was amazing. We were all blown away by the stories and remains

Lovely. Very big hill! A lovely place to look at but it was a very long walk to the top, especially in the heat.
The forum is accessed in the same place and is also interesting

Strange modern art added. We bought tickets at this gate thinking it was for the Roman Forum, the tickets do both but the Roman Forum is on down a bit. I'd give it a skip and walk on through to the Roman Forum as I found it a little strange with the modern art of tv screenings, metal words placed randomly. Just not my cup of tea,
Magnificent views. Tag this onto your Forum tour, it is hard walking, and quite a climb, but the views of this part of Ancient Rome are worth every step

Amazing, but needs better signage. Amazing place, so much to see and learn and utterly iconic views. Better than the Colosseum IMHO, but wouldn't forfeit a visit to that in favour of this. Only criticisms would be signage for both the toilets and the exits, we were led on a wild goose chase and spent a good extra half hour trying to get out!Did find it mildly amusing that meticulous scanning searches are done on the way in, forcing you to queue for ages in the hot sun, but none on the way out. I guess it's about security rather than theft!
great views. We took a bike tour of the city and stopped to see the views. So much history and can just walk around and enjoy the sites

Exploring the Roman ruins. Area is still being excavated and restored, but you can walk among the ruins. Extensive history in this area (with the Forum). Tour guide is very helpful to understand the ruins and partial building histories. Alot of area to cover, good views of the stadium, Circus Maximum and the stadium if you climb up to the top and walk to the back edge of the hill.

Interesting Location. The Palatine Hill is packed with history which makes it fascinating. You often get a free tour of this area with a colosseum tour purchase and it is a great way to spend an hour or two, wandering through the ruins and looking at the spectacular views over the city from the top of the hill. It does require so walking uphill which may not suit some people. Some may not like the fact that sadly nearly of these once grand buildings are now a small pile of stones and a foundation. But because of the gravity of the place and the view it is one of my favourite places in old Rome.
Visit. Very beautiful and well worth the walk. The sites are beautiful. When you get to the top you can see the whole city. The tour guide was very patient in answering questions. Very good
Awe inspiring. Wonderful place to visit to understand how the upper classes of Rome lived. Made more enjoyable by Christian our tour guide from Crown Tours

Roman history at its best. Walk around the grounds, and look at it from multiple top-down perspectives. You can walk around the perimeter, and look down at Palatine Hill from different sites, without paying to go inside.

Take the Tour with Christian, the Hill become valuable. A tour guide named Christian is a must.He made history come alive and explained everything, he made this site fun and interesting. I lost his contact infor but he was outside the Colesseum stairs opposite this site,so we crossed the road and the fun began.Christian-a tall ,slim male originally from Canada but lived several places. He provides other tours. Review of the hill- full with details of people's lives and perspective - who they were ,potential reason for why they behaved a certain a way.Great views of other ruins

Worth visiting with Forum. We visited the Colosseum, Palatine Hill and the Forum as all one tour and definitely recommend all three together which takes about 3 hours if on a guided tour. There is a lovely view from the top where you can see where the chariot races used to be held as well as more ruins and a small museum.
Photo worthy!. A must stop to get all those amazing photos to show off to your friends. But really it's just a place so full of culture and interesting finds.
