Roma. OMG if you loved those old Roman movies then you will love this ! to see this in person is a must do and when you do ,you will be amazed at what you will see and what it must have looked like in days gone by

More enjoyable to come with a professional guide. Having a guide was well-worth the money. The guides in Italy are well-trained and know their material. It really helped to put this all in perspective!
Amazing history!. You can only see the ruins of what was an amazing site. A must do tour with a guide to understand and appreciate it. Without it it's imposible to see beyond what's there.

Phenomenal Historic Visit. We are so unbelievably happy we came to see this fantastic archaeological site! It offers so much and it truly inspires one's imagination to think what life was like during the ancient Roman Empire.Please take my advice and avoid visiting during the peak of the day when the sun is at it's zenith. The site offers little by way of shade and has such an amazing amount of history to offer. My wife and I made this mistake and it actually cut our visit short (I was fine... Honest). Make sure to get your tickets on the East side on Via Dei Fori Imperiali as the queues here are much shorter than by the Colloseum.

Amazing Site. Palatine Hill was included in our Roman Forum & Colosseum ticket, so glad we got the opportunity to see it a beautiful site & one that really leaves you thinking about the ancient times of Rome.
Palatine Hill. So much history its hard to take it all in.Difficult terrain if you find it difficult walking.My advice take a guide you see so much more than doing it on your own.

Great place to start. We started our Rome trip visiting Palatine Hill. A great introduction to Rome this proved. We did not have a guide but did read up before we went. Palatine Hill is the centermost of the Seven Hills of Rome and is one of the most ancient parts of the city.I believe it stands 40m above the Roman forum. We spent 2 hours here.

Must See !!. This is a beautiful place with a lot history. We spent about two hours here and that should be enough with young kids.Make sure you have water with you as it is hilly and the walk can be tough. There are water taps with super cold drinking water as well throughout.Tip: Take the tickets for the Colosseum and Palatine Hill from the ticket window here and that should save a lot of time as the ticket lines on the Colosseum side are very long.A must see attraction !

Nice views-some shady. It is definitely worth the hike up here to look down on the forum, and there are some nice plantings, some shady benches and a nice water fountain. There were even some nice breezes on a hot afternoon.

Well preserved area. It's a nice walk up from Colloseum to Palatine hill. Do not miss it.It would help much better of you are a history buff to get a guide. We had not taken. Just enjoyed strolling along ancient monuments.
Great views. Again, read about it first. Great views from there. Got some fantastic photos. It was hot so we were slow!

Really interesting. Did this as part of a 3 hour tour. We toured with Italyourus, I think it was about 50 euros per person. Our guide was incredible as far as knowledge, but he didn't speak loud enough, so many of us who weren't right up next to him at all times, had a very difficult time hearing him.
Great place, fantastic historic place. Amazing views can be had here, plenty of just fantastic things to see and experience. A must do for anyone visiting Rome
Part of Grand day tour with Avventure Bellissime. Made fabulous by our personal tour guide Franccesa. I wouldn't just visit and look without learning the story behind the ruins.

We drove by & took pictures!. Palatine Hill is the centermost of the Seven Hills of Rome and is one of the most ancient parts of the city. It stands 40 metres above the Roman Forum, looking down upon it on one side, and upon the Circus Maximus on the other.

Amazing.. We had a tour of the ancient area, and I'm glad that there was a guide to give us more history than the signs could give. The area is inspiring; it's difficult to imagine the age of the columns and structures that surround you.

Ancient Rome. When I visited some years ago, entrance was free. This year, a ticket was needed and there were X-ray scans before entry. The good news is that the ticket for the Colosseum is also valid. A fairly interesting stroll (though I'm ashamed to say that Roman ruins left me a bit cold...)
Great view of ancient rome. This is the place to gaze down into the heart of ancient Rome and thus gives a good feel for the layout of this part of the city.

The park was beautiful. I stumbled upon Palatine Hill after visiting the Colosseum (it was included the ticket). I hadn't planned to go initially, but what a nice surprise! The park was almost vacant (since it's not open to public). It was covered with wildflowers and butterflies, making it somewhat of a "secret garden" among a bustling city. I could spend a whole afternoon there; picnic-perfect. :)It's connected to the Roman Forum, which I liked less... only because it was over-crowded and packed with people ramming into the ruins. Not as pleasant as the garden itself. There's no excuse not to visit if you have a ticket to the Colosseum. It's beautiful!

Summer vacation. August seems to be high traffic and high temperature time. By getting a guided tour usually it includes the Colosseum and the Palatine Hill as well as the Forum all one price. If you do it by user self the ticket price will include all 3 attractions. The place the huge and there is a lot to see and the history behind it it amazing. Make sure to take water, there is a lot of walking and quite a few steps. We enjoyed our tour, the guide was well informed and even added things in history that most in the group did not know. Another must attraction if in Rome.
Amazing view!. Don't miss this view of the Roman Forum. Incredible! The photos wont do it justice, you can see 360 degrees for miles.

Take the time to see it . You can tour this on your own without a guide but obviously you get more information with guides. The ground is a bit uneven so watch your steps. Neat history of the city area.
Roman forum, the founders of Rome. Ruins for days, you cant spit in rome without covering some thing ancient and rare. This is also where Julius Ceaser was killed, and the body hid for a time

Free on the First Sunday of the Month. Wasn't one of my top things to do in Rome, but turned out to be a favourite.We visited first Sunday in May, and whilst had purchased skip the line tickets (with the Colosseum) decided to take a look whilst it was free. Queues weren't too bad early in the day, but did grow significantly later on.

Fantastic Tour of Palatine Hill, underground Colosseum & Forum. We had an amazing 5 hour tour of the underground Colosseum (including third tier), Forum and Palatine Hill with Eugenia D'Andrea with Through Eternity Tours. We only planned a couple of pricey "experiences" while in Europe and this one was definitely money well spent. I honestly felt that we would've missed out had we not had access to the underground areas of the Colosseum. If you can get a reservation to tour underground through the official Colosseum website, be sure to grab it. If not, book a tour with this company and use the promo code RICKSTEVES for a 10% discount. This was the best deal I found since we weren't able to get a tour through the official website (books up far in advance during summer months).Just be sure to bring lots of sunscreen (I'm not kidding-apply beforehand and bring it with you) and a water bottle for everyone. There are several refilling spots throughout the tour.

Amazing history. It was very hot and we became quite exhausted but going up there was a drink stop with cold Fanta and coke to sustain us. When you get to the top there are great views but the parkland is extensive and there is now a museum in the corner. Long queues for the loo so recommend you go at the bottom of the hill. In the end it was so hot we missed a small section and headed out via the Colosseum side. Again €12 gives an adult access to all three sites for two days and children up to 15 go free. I can't see the point in paying more so beware of the touts. Also don't buy a bus pass as the bus is very hot and the metro is air conditioned and very cheap just €1.5 for 100 minutes. After an exhausting hot tour over 3 hours we took the metro via termini close to our hotel in cool efficiency!There are plenty of signs to read in English and use the money saved to buy a book.
Better than the colosseum. Interesting and extensive site - visited at no extra cost to Colosseum visit. More guidance needed - why not offer a helpful route through to help tourists?

Worth a Visit. We visited this in conjunction with a tour of the colosseum. It made the entire tour a bit long and it was a lot of walking in the heat. There also weren't many places to sit down.It is very interesting and would be good to perhaps do it in cooler weather or on it's own. I'd say the guide is a must unless you know the history yourself.I also noticed they do outdoor concerts in an area of it. That would be cool to attend!

Center of ancient Roman Life. Therer is alot to see at this fantastic location. If at all possible do with a small tour group and a history based gide to max it out. Its a walk but not overly hard to do. The whole area will take at least 2 hours to do. However plenty of places to rest on route.

Best of the Best. We have visited Rome on many occasions and during our first visit we did everything in detail including walking the grounds of the forum..we were younger and were able to take the heat.Our most recent visit with family we walked up the Capitol towards the end of the Forum where we were able to view and absorb the the ruins and visualize the way it was.Certainly after taking a tour of the Colloseum and then walking up to this view of the forum our grandkids were overwhelmed with the grandeur and history of the place.

Vast amount of history. Here you can spend forever and a day soaking up the history . I recommend good footwear as I tripped over a large stone in flip flops ( not great ) bring plenty food and water as its very open and was very hot . ( there wasn't any water etc on the grounds ) a hat is always good and a good camera for photo opportunity's .

Skip this area. I love all the history. And this area is included in the Roma Pass with the Forum and Colosseum. And the view from the top is great of the Forum, however, it is not navigated well and the museum is just okay. The weird thing is on our visit there was a modern art exhibition within the area and it took away from the ancient ruins. Spend your time in the Forum and coliseum.
Great view of Roma!. Walk the stairs and enjoy the view of the Forum, it's a great place to get your photos from. You can get an inclusive ticket with the Forum/Coloseum
Loved out visit to Palantine Hill. Part of our three hour tour of the Colosseum and the Forum. Interesting place with beautiful views of Rome.

breathtaking. It takes a while to comprehend the size and scale of this site, but once you comprehend this and get a sample of the history and age of the site, it is quite something. Take the guided tour, but be careful.
nice. very beautiful area, very good to have a walk during the sunshine, the colors at this time are amazing and warm, i love rome!!olga

Yet another wow. Wow-- like most of the ruins in Rome. Try to not get overwhelmed by the crowds and the heat-- grab yourself a quiet spot and admire the beauty of these magnificent remnants of the Roman Empire.

Walking among 2000 year old building and roads. We went with a guide and it was excellent to learn of the history of the area. Really amazing to be among this much history - particularly for a guy from the USA, where we measure history differently
A must-see. I can't get my brains around the fact that the 'messy assembly of rocks and buildings' has been there for that long. It's just amazing. If in Rome, go and see and experience it.
Vast. Spend some time here. Don't be rushed. Take your time and soak it all up. Had a load of modern art 'messages' when we went, which rather spoils the historic effect. Please do not do this Rome!

Large garden area above The Forum, ruins to wander through - Excellent area for viewing. If for no other reason climb up to the Palatine Hill for the views of The Forum and Rome. Much history lies here - much of it yet to be uncovered. Access is part of the combined Forum/Collosseum ticket
Bundle Palatine hill visit with the Roman Forum and Colesseum. Bundle the visit to Palatine Hill with the Roman Forum and Colesseum, be sure to visit the sculptures onsite, they are remarkable.

A piece of history you should'nt miss. When you are visiting rome, you will surely visit the colosseum. What you might not know is that you can buy a combi ticket, where both palatine hill and colosseum is included. The price? 7.5 euro for students, 12 euro for adults and free entry for children 0-18. The ticket is valid for 2 consecutive days, but only one visit to each place. I did palatine hill the first day, and used probaby 5-6 hours to go through everything, it can surely be done quite alot faster, but there was so many amazing ruins and plaques with stories that kept me occupied for a long time. A hot tip, bring alot of water, there is water fountains inside palatine hill that people drink from, but these are crowded. I would recommend at least bringing 1.5L on a hot day. I cannot list everything inside palatine hill, because there is so much. I enjoyed palatine hill even more than I enjoyed colosseum.

rome holiday. we went here after the colossum about 2.00 it was hot and would have been better to leave it until later or go early next morning when you walk up the wide path there will be a que on your right join it(make sure you allready have your tickets) the que was fairly long but went quickly we took 25l rucksacks with water and food with us they do scan you and your rucksack but the water and food was no problem (they scan when you go into any major attraction) once in go were you wont and take your time.

Magnificent views. Palatine hill is probably one of the best vantage points to take those precious memories when visiting Rome. You will be surrounded by ancient history and you'll have the opportunity to take some of the best shots of the Roman Forum and Circus Maximums. There are several entrances. One of them is near the Colosseum (you'll see a track going from Arco di Constantino) and the other is about 100 meters after the new metro line works site in Via del Fori Imperiali. Plan ahead because the archaeological site is huuuge and it'll take you hours to visit all the temples and ruins around this area. Usually not a good idea to go before or after the Colosseum since, like I said, it'll probably take most of the day to go all over it.

Amazing. I am just amazed at how they have been able to keep some of these ruins intact! The site is quite big with lots to see. The area above the hill that overlooks many of the old ruined buildings was spectacular. Lots of hidden gems at this place with tons of history. Well worth the time going!

Nice Architecture to visit in Rome. We visited and looked from outside and it was worth visiting. There are lot of steps and walking to be done. This place if full of ruins and nice architecture. I would recommend this place for first time visitors.
History was made here.. This is one of the most ancient parts of the city. It stands above the Roman Forum on one side, and Circus Maximus on the other.

Still being dug up as we speak.. The ruins in this area are still being dug up from below. The way that new civilizations came in and built their own city over old ones is very interesting. It makes you realize how Rome really is rich in history and is literally layered with it. The ticket here also includes entrance to the Colosseum down the street so enjoy!

Brilliant - but prepare well!. This is a fantastic day out. We spent the best part of five hours walking around the ruins and learning all about the many dynasties that have occupied and rebuilt over each previous eras work.The audio tour was vey comprehensive and cost €7 each and the admission was part of our ticket to the Colosseum so that was a bargain.I suggest you plan for a hot day if you visit in July. It was 32° when we visited and we drank the free water like race horses. Water stops are scattered all over with plenty of shade for resting. Take a camera and if you are doing the audio tour take some comfy earphones with you as they will be in the entire time. It got a little crowed in the afternoon as most people visit the Colosseum first then head in here so be ready for plenty of people walking through your camera shots, it's completely manageable though and the place is absolutely massive so wear comfy shoes. Enjoy!!
Interesting. Mish-mash of buildings/ruins, make sure you take the tour otherwise it will make no sense! But it is one of those things you have to do when in Rome...

A view to the past and a museum. This is part of the coliseum and Roman forum ticket price. Once inside I suggest heading here first (in the left as you go in) visit the small museum and the walk back taking in the views of the Roman forum on the way before walking the ground level at Roman forum

Palatine Hill. It can be hard work walking up the steps to the Palatine Hill particularly in summer bit the views and grounds at the top are breathtaking. There is also a museum to explore and cool down in. Be sure to wear lots of suncream and a hat.

Beautiful and educational. Loved visiting palatine hill. Amazing to learn so much about it. The signs and displays were really informative and gave a lot of information. The site is very well maintained and kept clean.

I had a great lesson with a guide. I was very impressed by the architecture and what all this ment historically of course. So impressive and if your walking and come across some water stations, please fill your water bottle. It was the best water we tasted!

Travel back in time..... My family of four (with two teens) really enjoyed walking through Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum. If you purchase tickets to the Colosseum, these two sites are also included in the admission price. We went to the Colosseum on our first day and used the same ticket to get into Palatine/Forum on our second day. Splitting it up into two days worked out great! All you need to do is walk to the entrance... you do not need to wait in line again. Since we didn't wait in line, we didn't buy a headset. I do think that would have been helpful to learn more about what we were seeing, but the line was so long that we just decided to walk through at our own pace. Try to go back to this area at night to see the light show if you can. Very enjoyable...

Palatine Hill was an unexpected really great piece of history.. We toured Palatine with a wonderful tour guide from an English tour group. This tour requires a lot of walking and ALOT of steps but once you reach the top of the hill it is an amazing place chock full,of historical remnants of a palace that once covered most of the hilltop. There are some beautiful gardens, remnants of the guardsman quarters and one of the best hilltop views in Rome. There is also a museum that once was Mussulini's summer home. Well worth the walk and be sure to wear a hat & sunscreen on those summer days!

Spectacular . You can feel and touch the history walking from the forum up the hill like many emperors did. Unbelievable the size of the buildings and grounds and clearly they lived an opulent life. You also get great views of the circus

Great history to be learned here-if you have a guide. We went on a tour that began at the Colosseum and then took you to Palentine Hill-well worth the money. Our guide explained what we were seeing and the impressiveness of it all in a great way.

Historic. If you dont know your history, then this might just look like rocks on the ground. If you brush up on history before going; you can inmagine ancient romans walking around you and senator discussing politics.

Peaceful. With your Colisseum ticket, you can enter The Forum and Palatine Hill. Worth your time to glide through the gardens, and terrific photo opportunity over Rome.
Take water as hot, but there is an area where you can buy refreshments.

Interesting historical attraction. This is a great place to visit, but you need to be reasonably fit to be able to climb the steps and steep paths. It is worth paying for a guide if you can so that you can learn more during your visit.The ruins are so interesting, and it is incredible how many modern style conveniences (such as water features, heating, lighting and home comforts) they knew how to instal all that time ago.Be sure to take hats,sunscreen and water bottles if you go in summer as it can be very hot.Good view over the Circus Maximus area as well.Well worth a visit.

Lots of walking! . Great place, lots of walking, especially if you want to get up high and have views of the Forum and the Colosseum. This is ancient Rome and there is lots to read and take in. They have water fountains dotted around the place which is great as it can be very warm in the heat as it's all open.

Interesting place to visit. This is a superb place to visit and really interesting. We had a tour guide ( part of a package for the colosseum) and would recommend going with a guide unless your already a professor In Roman history . Being able to fully understand the importance of this place in Roman history is a must otherwise is just a mix of ruins and impressive buildings and gardens with some stunning views over Rome. This is not for anyone who struggles to walk any distance or climb stairs. Really well worth a visit. We would go back.

What a fantastic place!!!. What a place!!! We went to see the Palatine in the afternoon, right after the Coliseum. It is big, spacious and with a lot of history to see, read and feel. It is a bit of a climbing but nothing compared to the Vesuvio or the park in Trastevere (going to the Piazzale Giuseppe Garibaldi). From there you have an amazing view of the Circo Massimo, Rome and the Roman Forum. Don't forget your camera, water, suncream and conformable shoes.
Hot but awesome if you know your history. Very hot on the day we visited and it's quite dusty if rains haven't happened. Great views and great small musses on site.
Excellent views. Don't do this on a hot day:)...lots of walking but well worth it. Overseeing the Forum and just the splendor of the city is outstanding.

cool shade. After viewing the Colosseum, the arch of Constantine is only a few hundred feet beyond and if you then take a left up the hill it's a nice detour for a rest in the shade. There is a museum up there but we only walked through some attractive gardens and used this as a viewing spot to look down on the Forum--good perspective to see it in relation to the surrounding modern city. There are vending machines for soft drinks and water available.
Beautiful . What can I say... Rome has still awesome architecture left standing for us to see and admire. Brings a lot of pictures on your mind how Rome used to look back then. Bery beautiful indeed.
Just next to Colosseum . Another place with a lot of walking & climbing. Also, have someone to be your guide will be a better & more comprehensive experience.

Just amazing . The most impressive part of the Forum Romanun. You walk through history. This teaches you more than any history book will ever do. Take a good book or audio to guide you through the different parts...Just amazing and very impressive!
The view. Gorgeous view of the ruins, from this hill. Well worth the small effort to get the. You can see the people walking below.
Good fun. Here you an buy the ticket together with Roman Forum and Colosseum. It is very nice and can take great pictures.

A nice park with ruins . Very nice park containing old ruins and growing clementines on the trees. If you want to be naughty take one of the tree and you'll be able to taste the most succulent and luscious clementine! Many benches to sit down and relax on a hot day. Could take up to a few hours if you were to walk looking at everything. There's also a museum located on top of the hill, I cannot recall what it is or if you had to pay. But there is a toilet there!

What a place!. I was quite naive about Rome, lots of friends gave advice but none actually managed to convey the wow factor! We started with Palatine Hill because we'd walked down to the Circus Massimo and on the way back was a short queue so we sent in. We got ourselves happily lost in there for hours, so much to explore and read and see. We also had the added bonus of listening to Springsteen's sound check whilst we were there. We tried to go back on the same ticket the next day, not realising that the Palatine and the Roman forum was the same site...the man on the gate took pity and let us in if we promised not to go up the hill! Loved it all.
Great to go to see forum romanum from above. You go up Palatine to see foro romano up Above. Amazing experience. Don't Forgot to have a map of foro romano. We loved it.

Great view of the city!. Take a tour. You will learn more. Not that much to see up on the Hill. The museum was okay and a good break from the sun, but the views were probably the best part of going up the hill. Make time for it after the Colloseum.

amazing views. The View from the top was so cool to see you feel like your on top of Rome so amazing. It was a very Hot day so if you go in July or August make sure you bring a bottle of water, youll need it.
Beautiful ruins. If you can use the words beautiful and ruins in the same sentence, this is the place for it. It was very impressive.
Large and sprawling but good for a walk. This is a lovely area near the Colosseum. Hard to get a long view without a map/guide but worth visiting.

the best. That was my favourite activity in Rome. You can go there with your Coloseum ticket. I spent 2 or 3 hours there, walking on the steps of thousands of years old History and it was breath taking. Go as early as possible as it super hot and you can take the audio guide.

It's not the climb, it's the History. Having done the tour with private guide, she suggested doing Colosseum first. The reasoning was simple, it gets damn crowded after 9:30. Palatine Hill offers majestic views of the Downtown Roman Empire, you can see all from the top. Plus it's Nero's home which oversees the Circus Maxximus. ( This was a sick dude). For me the climb was a bit tiring and if you are even remotely disabled, there not facilities to help you. Wheel chairs, forget it. This is a great tour though.

wow what a site. We spent a long time wandering around this old site and it was so interesting. It is only a few minutes from colisseum but few people there when we went which made the wander that much more enjoyable - unlike the packed colisseum.
Do it!. Do a walking tour, you won't regret it! It was so awesome to learn about the ruins here, there was not enough time to see it all!

Do this as part of Ticket package. use the combo ticket that includes the Colosseum and the Roman Forum.there is a small museum with many artifacts at the top. the VIEW over the Roman Forum though is the supreme reason to go!!! Absolutely this gives a sweeping bird's eye view that is spectacular, one that stays with you. (much like looking at the Grand Canyon.)

Palatine Hill. What a history lesson! So much details, history and knowledge to take it. I think I need to visit this area a few times to retain the stories and see the detail of each building and site. Definitely worth visiting.Just remember sunscreen & water on a warm day!

Wonder how that city was. The best thing to do while you walk thru the Roman Forum and Palatino is to wonder how this piece of city used to be, what people used to do and so. If you like Roman History, you'll love it. If you don't like it, read about it before you go.
Must go. One of the most interesting places to visit in Rome if you want to have a brief of the ancient city.

Amazing ruins, hard to describe so get there & see it yourself. We visited first thing in the morning and there were no lines at all, highly recommend doing this as the lines can be really long and not so much fun standing around in the sun. The site opens at 8.30am and at this time there are very few people around so you have the chance to get lots of photos with no other people "photo bombing" them. The site itself is absolutely amazing, you could easily spend a day wandering around here. The ticket for Palatine Hill 12e includes entrance to the Colosseum and Foro Romano as well.

If you go early, you will be delighted with the view. Why is the Palatine of interest? Because it was the Beverly Hills of its ancient Roman times -- the elite tired quickly of NO AIR OR BREEZE down low in the streets, so sought the cooler heights. Hence, a) some great views, b) some great history, and c) a great, small museum recounting the past of the Palatine. We saved the museum for AFTER having already been down to the Forum, a nice move since the museum has AC!Too few people seem to know two tricks about going to the Palatine (as well as the Forum): 1) there is a third entrance to the Palatine/Forum, south of the one opposite the Colosseum, on Via di San Gregorio; and 2) if you go there early, like just when the attraction opens at 8:30 AM, you are likely to have the entire Palatine plateau to yourself and perhaps a handful of other tourists. We reached the beautiful belvedere overlooking the Forum WITHOUT ANYONE ELSE THERE. So my advice is: 3rd entrance AND Go Early. A third bit of advice: purchase your tickets for both the Colosseum and the Forum online BEFORE leaving on your trip. Just print out the forms and bring them with you. You can use them any time, but when you go to one (e.g. to the Forum/Palatine), you then will have to use the Colosseum entry by the next day at latest. We did the Palatine/Forum first, then the next morning were up early for the crazy scene at the Colosseum (for lining up, that is).
Very intresting, close to colosseum. Very beautiful ancient place to visit, close to the colosseum. There is little shade in this place, so bring hats!

Great history, amazing view. The hills bring you back to the historical place of the Roman Empire, the feeling of being there is great. I was amazed by all that marble and stone, statues, beautiful gardens ..everything.

Try to visit it in one day and Colosseum the other day. I visited these places before going to Colosseum, it´s the same tickets but a shorter line to the ticket office than in Colosseum and we can visited both places ( Palatine Hill/Roman fórum and Colosseum ) on two consecutive days.Ithink is better to visit Palatino hill and roman fórum in a afternoon because as we move from the hill to the fórum the sun is Always at our back so we take good pictures. there are many drinking water fountains and in hot days we is a good advice to drink plenty of water.In Palatine hill we find a good museum ( Museu Palatino ), from the end of Palatino hill we have the best view of roman fórum and at the end of roman fórum we have the best view of Colosseum.

Part of the colosseum tour. We visited Palatine hill & the Roman forum as part of the colosseum tour it was well worth the visit. The guide was very enthusiastic and animated which made the visit more interesting. One tip I would give you is make sure you have a hat or parasol as there is not a lot of shade and it can get really hot towards lunch time. I have been on this tour twice both morning and afternoon and didn't find much difference in the heat but the thought of going back to the hotel for a swim made us choose the morning tour.

Yes! Yes! Yes!. I think the title gives it away. Awesome place to visit. Good bit of walking to work off the oodles of pasta and pizza and well worth it. If anything we found Palatino more fascinating than the Colosseum. There is loads to see and majestic views for those camera moments...you'll get RSI - repetitive strain injury for the uninitiated - from trying to capture a pose in the never ending vistas...tip...take an actual bottle of water and fill up as you go if going mid July to mid August. It's kinda hot but worth the visit.
historical. Rome is a must see for anyone interested in the history of Europe and the Paletine Hills a necessary part of the experience
Amazing!!. Absolutely the best thing about this area!! There is so much to discover and see, it's incredible how open the whole area is!
so worth it!. We visited Palatine hill after our Colosseum tour. Its a climb to the top but so so worth it the views were beautiful

Amazing views of Roman Rome. It's a bit of a trek up from the Roman Forum, but well worth it. There's a viewing platform overlooking everything from the Colusseum, through the Roman Forum, backing up to the back of the museum. Quite amazing!
Palatine Hill. We were able to visit here right after the Colosseum. This is absolutely amazing. It was more than I expected.

All of the history!. Rome is so wonderful, you have to come here when in Rome and I highly recommend getting a guided tour! The history is so rich and a well informed tour guide can give you a completely different view on what you are seeing by simply telling stories.
Good place to see the Ruins. This place is next to Colessum and is included in the price of Colessum ticket. We enjoyed the walk through the area.

Ancient Rome. We visited this site before going to the Colosseum and found it to be very interesting . We had a tour guide who was able to explain the story of the Roman empire . Many ancient ruins to see . Don't miss this historical site when in Rome

Large site. Palatine Hill is a large site of ruins with not much explained. It is difficult to imagine what it was like when it was still in use. The line to get there is not too long.I grew up in Paris, I am very used to bag search and totally accept the process. My entire life I've had someone searching my bag and it was never a problem. But here at Palatine Hill it has been turned into an invasive process run in a very rude way. This completely unnecessary.

Don't forget comfortable shoes!. We visited the Palatine Hill and the Forum Romanum on a very hot day. The ruins and the view from the higher points are amazing, take shoes in which you feel comfortable climbing steps! Also take a lot of water with you, there aren't many benches to rest on. You can refill your bottles at water taps!

Average. Palatine Hill is basically a collection of Roman ruins. It's very interesting if you book a tour to get a bigger picture of what you're looking at. Otherwise you wouldn't fully appreciate it other than it is old and interesting.
History geek fun. Go up and see these ruins, its worth it, there is also a nice museum on the top that covers the history of the hill from Iron Age onward

combine with tour of colosseum for tremendous insight into ancient rome. you need tickets to Palatine Hill. can queue up for this or pay reasonable premium to join an english language tour of colosseum and palatine hill, including tickets for each, done routinely and efficiently with some "insider" bending of the rules. a highlight of Roma.

Unparalleled views of the glory that was Rome. This is a great place to visit along with the Colosseum and the Fora. I would even suggest you do this first before the Colosseum as the grounds are sprawling and the climb up the hill can be exhausting after a whole day of exploring other sites. When you do get up there, you can appreciate all the history and get unparalleled views of the glory that was Rome.

Ancient and Modern Works of Art Meet in the Best Value Ticket in Town . THIS is the best way to start your Roman holiday, hands down. It's a slow easing in from the modern world to the historical sites, featuring modern art installations interspersed with the ruins and once again, just so much to see - and that's only one third of the value of your ticket - the price also includes the Roman Forum and the Colosseum - and it's good for two consecutive days! There are many steps and stairs and ramps and nooks and crannies and it all ultimately leads to the Forum, and great views over the city and the Palatine ruins. It's a lot of walking but there's plenty of handy water fountains dotted around the site where you can refill your water bottles or take a drink for free.There is also a modern museum building on the site, featuring artefacts from ancient Rome we assume - we didn't go in as we were doing a speed-run of historical Rome that day, due to the short length of our stay.This is a great value ticket and one of the shortest queues we had to stand in in the whole time we were there; we would definitely return to this attraction and would recommend it to other travellers.
Very informative. Take a tour with a leader who can explain the story of the Roman Empire. If you don't have an insight of the history, you won't appreciate these ruins.

Did this tour with "Romearound"and Jill was our excellent guide. Well worth the skip the line fee to get this bonus tour with a very knowledgeable guide. Pay some extra money to skip the line and enjoy more of your holiday

Great complex to visit. Its a big area and make sure you have few hours to first stand in line and than walk around. Lots of history in here. We spend about 4 hours but not quite sure was able to see everything. Loved it.
Fascinating History. Worth going here after Colosseum, or doing tour that includes both. The history is fascinating, and it also helps you understand modern Rome better.
Rome. You cannot miss it if you are near Colosseum, I did not go down to see the ruins, but took some photos.
Breathtaking. We love everything about Italy. The history of the Palatine Hill and enthusiasm of the locals to preserve the area is wonderful. This is a must see.
Fabulous place to explore with time!. Not among the most iconic of sights in Rome, but a fabulous area to explore slowly. Domain of the emperors.... ruins and great views of the surrounding area.

Our Viator Tour took us to the Coloseum, Roman Forum, and Palatine Hill. We started our tour at 8:30am, so we beat most of the heat, but by the end when we were at Palatine Hill, we looked back and thought maybe we could research outdoor tours in Rome that start after 4pm. You can't go to Rome without checking out all this wonderful history. Make sure you get a professional guide that can add so much value on the trip.

WOW! Wish I had more time and energy when visiting.. It was included in our colosseum tickets, so I forced my husband to go. It was extremely hot and we walked up and down after visiting the colosseum. I suggest light clothes if visiting in the summer and water. It is so worth the visit. The walk is gorgeous and the views are stunning. The history is incredible. Do not miss!
Phenomenal view . The hill of the Emperors, great piece of history and the view itself is excellent. Try to go in the evening when it isn't crowded.

Historical Rome. You can't come to Rome and miss the place where it all began. Warning - take walking shoes, sun hats & plenty of water! Although there are water fountains everywhere - you sometimes have to queue for them!

Historic. Step back in time with tour of the past. Combined this site with a tour of the Colosseum and Forum and was one of the highlights of our trip.We took a tour with City Wonders who are recommended, our guide was Sara and she had such great depth of knowledge and delivered a view of ancient history in very good english.Make sure you see where Ceasar was cremated - easy to miss.

Good if you like History. This was an added on to our Colosseum tour. It was fine for those that love history. There is not a lot of shade so if it's hot then bring an umbrella. I wouldn't visit again as there is not much that I found interesting about it. But it was nice to see for the first time.

Beautiful . Absolutely fantastic views over the remnants of Ancient Rome. Scenic and breathtaking this is a great spot from one of romes famous hills. Great views of the forum so worth going up before or after a stroll through it so that you can catch your bearings and get a great overview. Lovely area.

History Galore!. Palatine Hill is very near the Colosseum. Because there are so many reviews, I would just repeat information already stated. Know that you will not be disappointed to stand on these grounds and hear stories of great times in history. The tour took about an hour and included a rest room break and an opportunity to fill water bottles with fresh water from a fountain. There is a lot of walking and it was a hot/sunny day when we were there, so the water and break were very welcomed.
Views of the Forum abound. If you want to have a bird's eye view of the Forum, this is the place to go. You can stand high above and see all of the famous landmarks!
Impressive. All the historical buildings and structures are a must see in Rome and this is one of them. Quite a view from there.

Time traveling.... Amazing architectural buildings and the knowledge oh how centuries before us lived, communed, worked and play. We walked through the area on a very hot (early) summer's day in June. Drink your water (there are two areas you can refill your bottles) and wear comfy shoes!

Beautiful Views of Ancient Rome. We saw Palatine Hill as part of a walking tour. I was amazed at the thought of the palace in its original splendor and you can still see some of the original marble floors of the palace. The views from the hill of Ancient Rome are spectacular!
Surprise for me. I really did not expect the forum and palatine hill to be as big as it is! Great surprise, and enjoy the day there.
Gorgeous. Beautiful scenery and gorgeous view with amazing landscapes and beautiful stories attached to every part of this place.. Walking around here definitely will blow your mind away

Palatine- What a view. History was in the making as you stroll around. What a view onto the old City and you are able to identify the Seven Hills. Do wear a hat and make sure to take water although it was refreshing changing your hot bottled water for safe cool spring water. Once again our tour guide from "I love Rome" was excellent and very knowledgeable.
Rome. Amazing history and amazing to see. We had a tour guide who had a book to show us what it would have looked like originally which was very helpful.

Hot. I love ruins and arqueological sites, but it was impossible to enjoy the place when it was so hot and there wasn't almost any place to drink water or rest from the sun a little. At least the line to get inside was going fast! Go when it's not so hot!
City break. Had a stroll around here after a visit to the colosseum and a lot to see. Pre booked colosseum tickets usually include entry so continue your history trip.
Beautiful. History and just amazing! Need to see near Colessieum. Have to queue but then security is high. Fantastic place
loads to see. avoid hot says as there is no where to hide from the sun, however an amazing site with lots of history

Extraordinary!. So much to see and the tour guide was so informative. However we didn't have tome to see everything in order to stay on the tour schedule. Definately worth a second trip after to get the rest

Loved these ruins. Loved visiting the Palatine Hill and the Forum (really one site). A few tips though, it can take quite a while. The site is large and has a number of small sites/museums you can spend time in. The ruins are extensive and amazing. Almost impossible to take a bad picture. Show up early if you can, especially during the summer/high seasons to reduce the crowds. When hot (30+ degrees), water is essential. There were no vendors inside the site that we saw. There were a few fountains if you have an empty bottle. Water would be a good idea, even when not hot. We'd skip the audio guide next time, as the numbers didn't sync with the map, so it was cumbersome and didn't add to our experience. Also, if you rent the audio you have to leave ID, which means you have to leave by the same gate you entered, cutting down your options. Plan to do the Coliseum right after (it is right there), unless the crowds are too big or you're two tired. The combined ticket works for the Coliseum if you buy it and is valid for two days, so you can come back the next day.

Great Views. Near the Colosseum and connected to the Roman Forum. Just buy one ticket and gains you entrance to all three sites. Not too steep and fairly easy going. Views are amazing and worth the climb. If it is warm you're better to go later in the afternoon/evening.
Speechless. A great part of history The Roman Forum is another amazing historical site a must visit and see. Take your time and enjoy!!
Best views. A guide is essential in order to understand the historic majesty of this place, but even without a guide the views are majestic. Prepare for the heat and be prepared to walk/climb.

Ancient Rome in all its glory. Once you tour the Coliseum, then tour Palatine Hill and ancient Rome. For us, first-time visitors, the ruins are impressive and in excellent condition given they are 2,000 years old. And you walk in the middle of everything to get a feel for what it was like in ancient times..

Nice views from the top of the hill. Situated beside the Colosseum and connected to the Roman Forum. The same ticket grants entrance to all three sites. The hill isn't too difficult to climb and there are great views of the ruins and Colosseum from the top. Some ruins towards the edge of the site that could be easily missed so be careful to explore every corner.
Lovely Views. Had an excellent sight seeing experience with great views. We didn't pay the €12 entrance fee as we were on a tight schedule. Next time we will.
Step up marine!!. Had a great tour here with Matt, a very energetic chap with a booming marine voice, very knowledgeable, witty and patient. Do it.

A gem in the midddleof the city.. Stunning place. We were there on a very hot day in July with a private your guide and we had am amazing time.It is well worth the money to have someone show your around.So much history and beautiful buildings.
Must see with Roman Forum and Colosseum. Walked up the hill after entering the Roman Forum to see the Palatine Hill. Great views and lots of history.

Bit too expensive. We only experienced this on the outside, would not have mind going in, but they are a bit to expensive. Rather see if you can't buy it online for cheaper. Also don't use hop-on-hop-off bus, the metro way better and cheaper.

Fantastic experience being amongst the ruins. I got this as part of a group ticket online for the Colosseum and The Forum, and it was one of the better options. I had no lines and was able to get in (arriving at opening time). This gives you plenty of time to explore and get lost whilst not having people falling all over you. It was quiet for the first 1-2 hours so you get a much better appreciation. In fact, there was absolutely no one in the museum whilst I was in here
A full day to do it justice if you can afford the time.. Fantastic part of our trip to Rome, so much to take in. Great views over the city from the top of the hill.

Historically interesting . The Church of San Bonaventura al Palatino is a small 17th century church in Rome built on the Palatine Hill. It is a Franciscan monastery church built by Francesco Barberini on the request of the Blessed Bonaventure of Barcelona and was completed in 1689The church offers a free tour of the monastery, garden and includes a full history...church has incredible original paintings.
So much history. Did only a quick visit as part of the colosseum tour but came away absorbed in the history of the place.Well recommended to spend a couple of hours to digest and soak up history.

Great, specially at night. The Roman Forums are great historical places, but to really get the most of them I recommend the night light shows at August and Cesar Forums...they are a must to understand the splendor of the Roman era.

Worth The Walk. Wear your walking shoes and make sure you buy your ticket in advance. The 3 way pass bought on the internet will save you some time, It includes the Colosseum , The Forum and Palatine Hill.
July. It is truly an amazing place to visit but at 10am & 35 degrees exhausting. All around is a vision to be seen and leaves you awed at history! Will revisit but not in the Summer!

Bridesmaid for Colosseum!!!. Palatine hill along with Roman Forum and Colosseum forms the troika of attractions and they are on the same site and have one entry ticket applicable for them. While this place is full of ruins from the Roman era with tons of history buried along, people are more inclined towards visiting the colosseum next door and this would not get more than a casual look around and so is the case with Roman Forum. The scorching sun in the summer months does not make this any better and all the more pushes the people to hurry up and end up at Colosseum.However, if you have ample time and keen historian, please take a guided tour and your plate will be full with historic facts!!!

Interesting ruins. Certainly worth a look around especially when visiting the forum area too. It's a bit of a climb up especially challenging on a hot day. Lots to look at but not very well sign posted so ended up missing quite a few buildings at the back. I think it's best to have a map or a guide.

Wonderful. Yet another wonderful area full of history. Nice place to walk and take in the beautiful views of Rome. Some modern art recently installed takes some of the magic away in my opinion but still a beautiful sight.

Worth the climb, well walk.. I believe Palatine Hill is the centremost of the Seven Hills and probably one of the most ancient. Stories advise that Romulus and Remus were brought up in a cave here, by Lupa the she wolf.Didn't see the cave but thoroughly enjoyed another step back in time.Our visit coinsided with a Contemporary art festival. Very unusual juxtaposition of old and new.

Impossible to describe in a review!. I had no idea of what to expect of Palatine Hill. It was breathtaking. I felt as though I was in some crazy Game of Thrones scene! Words really can't do it justice and this is a must see if you are in Rome.

Must see. The Palatine Hill is a must see to understand the character of this city. If you only have a couple of days in Rome, do Palatine Hill, Roma Forum, Colosseum, Fontana Di Trevi and Spanish steps. I visited all of these attractions today. It took 12hours but was definitely worth it.

great views. Best place to go and get your ticket to include the colosseum and forum, get it out of the way early as quite high and gets very hot. Buildings would of been very impressive in their day, quite a big sight. The views over Rome are amazing can see why they picked this spot. A small museum that has a picture of what it would have looked like and a few artifacts.

Great view overlooking the Colosseum. Located adjacent to the Colosseum. An amazing viewpoint for Photos. Awesome structure with deep history. Not easy for those with difficulty walking but well worth the effort.

Needs Imagination. Similar to the colloseum, this needs vivid imagination in order for you to understand and appreciate the grandeur of those structure. Nothing is left today, as all of this had damages due to the impact of time. Nothing is left today that is representative of the real structure, so you are just walking amongst ruins and pieces of history, trying to figure out what was where during its hey days.
Part of colosseum ticket. If you buy an online ticket for colosseum you can include Plantine Hill for additional couple of euros. You will feel that you are in an open air museum.

Underrated but Excellent. The views from here are stunning! You can see the entire city and imagine yourself looking down at the ancient Romans. There are spectacular photo ops of the Colosseum and the grounds are well kept and awe-inspiring.

Ruined by the curators. . A site filled with so much history has been completely destroyed by those meant to protect it. Constant construction, railings everywhere, dirty, vehicles driving over everything. It was enough to make someone sick. Areas where restorations were done, were done so poorly that I couldn't have been more disappointed.

Jaw droppingly beautiful . What an amazing place. A must see to soak up the history. Make sure you have a water bottle with you as there's not a lot of shade and it gets very hot. Lots of fountains to refill your bottles though. Visit the museum, it gives a clear vision of what the area would have looked like, and it's free.
What a view. No words to describe this, you simply just admire and process the view. Recommend getting a tour guide to give you a feel as they tell the story.

Lots going on. There is so much history in Rome and Palatine Hill was a major part of it. It is amazing to think that there are still so many buildings at least still partially standing after centuries.
Best. Love it and the love story told of Emperor Pius is magical, and also you get to see were Caesar was stabbed and burnt.

looks awesome. This time we just passed by because of the heat and lack of shadow there but next time I definitely will spend some time there.
It just looks awesome.

Amazing view and the history!. I would definitely hire a tour guide to help you better understand what happened at Palantine Hill (Unless you are a history buff and already know the key landmarks). It is amazing to think how Rome was such a dynasty in its day.

Interesting. On a very hot day in July, it was a sweaty trip here. We had a guide which made it a lot easier to understand the who, what and where, which, if left to our own devices would not have slotted into place. Great views of the Forum ruins and Coliseum.
See the Roman empire. We went on the "walking tours of italy" and the guide brought this fascinating sight to life. The highlight at the end was walking through the recently opened Caesar's Palace.

The first Rome! Don't miss it!. The palatine hill is the original Rome! The place where Romulus built the city, the hill is the heart of the ancient city that ruled the Mediterranean world. an absolute must see! The palatine was the home of the Roman republican aristocracy and later the sight of the imperial palace. Make sure you buy a ticket online and print at home to avoid long lines, especially in summer. The ticket is combined with a visit to the forum, can be paired with colosseum as well. I recommend to first climb and explore the palatine and then slowly descend into the forum. There are a number of Terraces with spectacular views of the entire forum and colosseum. Take some lovely pics and descend in the forum, walk the Via Sacra and explore the many remains of temples and churches. The latest site is the Santa Maria Antiqua, an imperial atrium which later became one of he first Christian churches. Beautifully restored wth some amazing early frescoes. At the foot of the hill it is connected with the emperor's ramp leading to the palace on the palatine. Fascinating!Palatine now also features the restored villa of Augustus and Livia, but special arrangements need to be made to visit. Hot, Exclusive tip: If you want to avoid the massive lines under the hot Roman sun, use the palatine hill entrance on Via di San Gregorio, which runs between the colosseum and the circus maximus. There's barely any people entering from that side. Be smart!

Great View of Roman Forum. There are some ruins on this hill and some nice park areas, but the main reason is to get the best view of the Roman Forums below. There is a museum on top of the hill, but we didn't visit. We found ti a bit confusing to find our way around. We came up from the Roman Forum (it is a bit of an uphill walk) but we realized a couple of days later that there was another entrance on the other side of Palantine Hill off the street. I wouldn't go here for itself, but if you are visiting the Roman Forums, definitely make the hike up the hill for the view. Plan to spend about an hour or less.
Beautiful gardens. Along with the ruins there is a beautiful garden here. Just the place to wander after walking through the colosseum

Superbe encore mieux avec un tour guidée / Superb but better Go with guided tour. Losqu'un site a plusieurs centaines d'années je recommande toujours une visites guidées qui fait le tour des anecdotes et points marquants de sa construction à Maintenant.When a site has hundreds of years I always recommend a guided tour that will provide you with stories and anecdotes from it's construction up to now.
Well worth the walk.. You get a great sense of history walking the cobbles, well worth doing even if it's very hot! You do need decent footwear.

Where Rome Began! Palatine Hill!. A visit to Palatine Hill is like hopping aboard a time machine to mingle with the prestigious locals of the Roman Empire. It is the official location where Rome was founded by brothers Romulus and Remus, who have an absolutely amazing story of their own! See the palaces and gardens where the Emperors of Rome once called home and don't forget to take in the fabulous view of the city from this vantage point! If you love history, this is the place to visit! Purchasing a ticket to Palatine Hill will also provide you access to the Colosseum...and the lines here are a lot shorter than waiting in line at the Colosseum!

Emperors view. Standing atop the Palatine hill provides wonderful vistas of the city below. The sheer utter size of the building and those below is incredible. The ruins are sufficient to provide a good view of where things stood. Certainly worthwhile if you are visiting the forum.

Study before you go. We started our tour at around 8:30 am. It lasted about 3 and a half hours. You should be familiar with the site before you go (read a travel guide book), even if you have a guide. With so many ruins to see, there were just too much information to process and remember. Start earlier to avoid the heat.

Palatine Hill. The Palatine Hill is one of the things that made a large impression on me when visiting Rome. It is literally a small city of ruins from ancient Rome.We visited without any form of guide, which may have been a mistake. I think we missed a lot of the history of the place, but it's very huge, and just walking through it taking pictures of the ruins there takes a lot of time.Be aware that in the summer this plase get very hot,and there is not much shade, so bring sunscreen and water.

It's full of historical ruins. This hillside is quite amazing with it's ruins and buildings. It is not free to go inside but the view from the streets are amazing. It brings you back to the Roman ages.

Back in time. Grwat views of the roman forum, Coloseum, Circo MassimoThis is were Romulus founded Rome, the ruins of his village are believed to be the ones founded on the top of the hillLots of fresh water fountains available which is a great relief during hot summer months
Marvelous View. Gorgeous panoramic views. Very interesting to see the once palace of Roman Kings. You can get beautiful photos from so many locations too.

Bring a good pair of shoes & water. It's amazing to walk through the ancient ruins of palaces and houses and soak up the history and grandeur that this place must have been in it's prime. It's much bigger than you think, so bring a good pair of shoes, lots of water, and expect to hike a bit to take in the best that Palatine Hill has to offer. It's a short walk from both the Colosseum and the Roman forum (and there's also a few spots to get some wonderful views of the forum) and if you're a history buff, you can't miss it! Lots of good information is posted on signs throughout, but it might be helpful to get a guide just because the place is so big.

Absolutely stunning. What an experience; it is certainly worth the effort to visit Palatine Hill and enjoy the stunning scenery and ponder on what the Romans did over a thousand years ago. Looking down at the Forum and seeing what was built and how it is withstood modern times is amazing

Impressive views of the Roman Forum. This is a very good spot to take in the views over the Roman Forum. I took really nice pictures,and viewing the forum from that vantage point was an added bonus.A stone throw from the colosseum, the Roma pass will count as a single entry if you choose to go there. This is a good place to visit if you like archeology .

Center of the 7 Hills of Rome!. This ancient area, it is said, had people residing there as long ago as 1,000 b.c. Also, it is from this word, Palatine, that we get the modern word, Palace. In Roman mythology, it is said that this is where Romulus and Remus were found by the she-wolf, Lupus, and kept alive. There is much rich history to this area, and should not be missed. Since there is a lot of walking to be done, it is best to go early in warmer weather.

No 1 site in Rome . We went to Palatine Hill as part of Walks of Italy Colosseum, Palatine Hill and forum 4 hr tour. 38 degree heat was no obstacle to enjoying our guide Michael Giovanni's ( archaeologist) insight descriptions and understanding of Rome from Romulus & Remus, Vestal Virgins, Nero as well as photos of reconstructions of the ruins. Having done Vatican it was a different yet just as magnificent tour. These 2 tours at Approx $127 were the highlight of our Roman holiday. A must to do with Walks of Italy to really understand Rome.
Sweet views. Palatine Hill is really cool fro the views. It was a scorching day, but seeing all the ruins made it bearable.

Very nice but really hot in summer. We enjoyed the views but there were too many spots without shade and in summer at 38 degrees Celsius, it was a real struggle. Probably best to do this when it is cooler and maybe later at night. We made the mistake of visiting it at 4 or 5 pm.
Must see. Ancient ruins, one of the 7 hills of Rome,walk around the ruins Discover Roman history and get the feel of great Rome.

historic site. We visited this site as part of our 3 hour tour of the colosseum and the Forum .. it was full of interesting history and our guide was very knowledgeable .. she was an archaeologist and spoke very good English .. well worth a visit.

Worth a visit but don't go too late in the day . Visited first thing in the morning before the temperature got too hot. Amazing site and well maintained with lots of information available. Lovely restaurant opposite as well.
Visit on a segway tour. I had no idea how amazing it was to see the ruins from up high. The view was spectacular and I can't wait to visit again and spend more time.
Amazing history!. It is amazing to walk around such history. Wear good walking shoes and go early in the day. We went as part of a tour...it is a don't miss place in Rome!

Palace!. This is where the word "palace" originates from! Go back in time and see how the locals lived in the 10th century BC. As with the Colosseum and Roman Forum, it is best visited with a guide - audio, book, or human.

Allow yourself some time. A wonderful place that you need to allow yourself adequate time (a couple of hours) to walk around. Please note that there is a lot of walking, some of which is not on very good surfaces. This is another place that I would recommend fast track tickets and it helps of you have a knowledgeable guide
Didn't realise how big this is. This place is huge there is quite a lot to take in the museum is worth visiting to it has marble sculptures found on the site.

How not to be impressed?. I have made two visits to this place and it is well worth spending an hour or two here. It is a quiet place in this otherwise busy city. There is almost too much to see in one location! One tip from me is to start by walking up the hill and then go to the lookout point. The view is amazing over the old forum. Another great bonus is that it is a lot shorter queue to Palatine hill/Forum than to Coliseum and the ticket is valid for both!
Skip the line tickets, good walking shoes and a hat are very much recommended.. Skip the line tickets, good walking shoes and a hat are very much recommended.Be prepare to see lots of people/groups.

Do this last after the Colosseum and Forum. It's ok but more like a park. Save the majority of your time and energy on the Forum and Colloseum under the same admission ticket but do get your tickets here to avoid the line at the colloseum.

Days Gone By.... I find it amazing that you can more or less, just clamber over what is ancient Roman history, in this place you really can. With some imagination, you can really feel what this place used to be like. Again, there is a lot of walking here and some pathways can be uneven and the stairs slippery if wet, so a good pair of shoes is a must as is a camera and perhaps a waterproof as the majority of this area is exposed to the elements. It's an incredible trip through history that you shouldn't miss on a visit to Rome. Keep small children close at hand as there are crowds and space and plenty places to fall or trip but after a trip round here they'll be sufficiently tired! For adults, the sheer scale of building and the way the Romans constructed will leave you breathless.
Beautiful. Pretty views. Worth a visit when in Rome. We went earlier in the day when it was less crowded, and much cooler.
fantastic views. best views in rome. wished i'd had the audio guide but this was not signposted well - would have been good to know exactly what we were looking at.

Favorite site in Rome. It was amazing to walk around these ruins. There were lots of people, but I never felt crowded like many of the other sites. Wear sunscreen and bring a hat. It is hot in the summer. There are a few water spouts around to fill up your water bottle. Give yourself 2 hours or more to really enjoy everything.

Palatine Hill / Palatino / Foro Roman. Thursday 7th July 2016You get access with the ticket to the Colosseum (€12 for an adult or €14 if you book online). Don't know if you can buy a ticket just for this.It's outside the Colosseum, to the north-west, approx' 1 minute walk if you exit at the right spot. Just past the Arco di Constantino. It's a large collection of a variety of statues, arches, gardens, pillars, relics, etc.There were vending machines within a small air conditioned building but these were nearly empty early/mid afternoon. Don't remember seeing any water taps so go prepared.Lots of steep inclines, steep steps, loosely cobbles paving so go in flat, sturdy shoes or trainers.Downside - there's very little shade.

Magical place, steeped in history, do not miss. If you are visiting Rome I would strongly recommend a visit to the Palatine Hill. To do it properly and make the most of the experience best to take a guided tour, there are many available. Access to the Palatine comes at a modest cost but also includes access to the Roman forum.From the palatine you get amazing views of the Circus Maximus and Roman Forum, your imagination can go wild here filling in the gaps, picturing the grandeur of ancient Rome.As with many of the other attractions in Rome I would strongly recommend wearing comfortable footwear. Visiting mid afternoon can be very hot and there is nowhere within to purchase drinks, you can however top-up bottles at many drinking fountains.
Impressive. We spent all day for walking and sightseeing. This place was very impressive and worth seeing. I definitely recommend it to anyone.
Bellisimo!. Well worth a visit! We loved everything and everywhere in Rome!What a city! Memories made to never be forgotten!

Brilliant!. So close to the colosseum it's definitely worth doing both in the same day.There is so much to see here and I actually enjoyed it more than the colosseum.There's a small museum on site with very clean toilets - the day we visited the hand dryer wasn't working though.We spent a few hours there and still didn't see all of it.
Viator tour. Part of a 3 hour package tour. Very interesting place with lots of history. Botanic Garden is nice as well.

Great site just make sure on a hot day stock up on water!. This was a great place to look around but not well sign post for information so take a tape or read up before hand on the history. Also because it very exposed take a lot of water as there is no drinking taps we could find and its very easy to get heat stroke here! Otherwise a great place to get an idea of what used to be in Rome. Book tickets before hand as it gets very busy, try and not go mid day as not only is it busy but the mid day sun is a nightmare.

Holy cow. Again what an amazing place If you have visited the Coloseum, the ticket you have just bought also gets you into the Roman Forum. Take water and lots of it and a good camera as you will be spell bounded with all the ruins dotted everywhere. Take a few hours out of your day to just walk around and feel the ora.Thumbs up

Why are Italians rude?. I thought it was just all the middle-aged men, doing jobs they've done for years and probably not going anywhere else, that were rude in Rome but it seems we met two women today who were also extraordinarily surly. Imagine my surprise when the lady in the tourist office said the entrance for the Palatine Hill was all the way back to the Colosseum and round the corner (not true - there was an entrance almost opposite on the other side of the street to that Tourist Office). And why, please, must a person with walking difficulties (ok maybe trying to do the Palatine was way too much for them) have to walk a lot further to the exit when the adapted ("disabled") was much handier and more convenient for a shorter hobble back to the Metro station. Oh no, there are rules and Italians can NOT break any sort of rule even if it makes more sense. Goodness me.
Must see. I missed this the last time, I made sure I went this time. This area is truly amazing, and it really shows how it was.

A great picture of Ancient Rome. Take the time to spend several hours exploring. With a good guide or guidebook you should be able to cover it all and get a really good idea of the layout and life in Ancient Rome. There are restrooms at the museum that you can use even if you choose not to enter the museum. Like the rest of Rome, and for that matter, Italy, walking can be uneven and there are not guardrails in some seemingly needed spots, so wear comfortable shoes and take your camera.

A Family Favorite. Loved exploring Palatine Hill! We started with a Walks of Italy tour that included Caesars Palace (a must-do) and ended up staying long after the tour ended, exploring this fascinating, amazing site on our own. One of our favorite moments in Rome!
Superb stroll around history. As the name implies its up a hill so not ideal for everyone. But if you make the effort on a sunny day it is a great place for a history walk. But take some water !
Ancient Rome at it's best. The cradle of European culture. A must for every visitor. Take a guided tour, as otherwise you miss out on too much information.

Awesome energy in this place. How can you not be amazed by the history of what went on here 2000 years ago. This was the centre of the world. Just trying to imagine the millions of people who lived and dies in Rome back then. So many things to see. A good guide or guidebook is a must.

Spectacular . Visited first with a guide then came back. There are amazing views of rome, and more history than can be digested in a visit. Be sure to wear sunscreen and bring a hat. There are springs to refill your water during your visit.

My Favourite.. This was by far my favourite thing to do whilst in Rome and all thanks to Greg from the Gladiator Tour Company. Make sure and book all your tours through them, they are fantastic at explaining everything thoroughly with added humour to make it more enjoyable.

Palatine Hill Rome . This is a must see after two days in Rome seeing the Vatican, Trevi, Sistine we were a little jaded 30 in the shade help with that. We went to see The Palatine Hill frankly better organised easier to follow as it has more understandable signs than them others. Rome from the start, the names you will know even with a modicum of Roman history. We went around 10am and it was not packed so unlike the Vatican you could actually spend time looking at the exhibits. We got a real sense of what time was like in Rome all those years ago and although the ruins were exactly that you could make out the various houses, Palaces with ease . There is also an excellent museum on site and although in modern building is absolutely worth a visit
Awesome view!!. We had a guide which spoke English really well which was great, and learning about the past of the palatine was awesome. The view at the end of the tour was amazing!!
amazing. This is absolutely amazing. The views are incredible and if you go in the morning, it is relaxing and peaceful.

Historic site, worth visiting. Palatine hill amazes with it's rich historic story, ruins and wonderful views over Rome. It takes time to wander around it but it's all worth it. there are nice areas with benches to take rest and toilettes free of charge. Also water points to fill your bottle.

Give yourself a lot of time, water, and sunscreen.. Buy your combo ticket (Colosseum, Roman Forum, Palantine Hill) at the Palantine Hill entrance down the street from the Colosseum- much shorter line. This was amazing too much to take in in a quick trip. The grounds are massive. With only two exits/entrances, you can spend almost as much time finding your way out as you spent touring the sights. Drop a pin with your phone at the entrance you use. It will save your tired feet when you're ready to go. Take a map when you enter. It's helpful. Bring lots of water and a few snacks. You'll want to take breaks in the shade when you find it. There's an indoor museum within an ancient church. Go in. It's a nice air conditioned break from the heat, and when you climb to the top observation deck, you have an amazing view of the entire complex. I think I enjoyed the Roman Forum and Palantine Hill more than the Colosseum.

Impressive Views. Once you have finished at the Colosseum, a short walk gets you to the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill. You can access Palatine Hill from the Forum - be warned, there are lots of steps to climb. The view from the top however is fantastic. Immediately in front of you is the Roman Forum but beyond, the skyline of Rome and not a single skyscraper in sight!!
WOW. Step back into time, take a tour and hear the stories of Palatine Hill but also what happened after the 15th century, why all the beauty was destroyed and where it is now...

A must see. You must go and see this, but please go with a tour guide. I would recommend City Wonders. They are by far the best talking to other people while we were in Rome. The guide will bring the place alive for you and make it an amazing experience.
Motherdaughter2016. If your into gardens this is a must, botanic gardens of the time, lots of stairs and views of the Roman Forum

Best with a tour. I had reserved tickets online and it was fairly easy to get the actual tickets from the office at the entrance. You can enter the hill anytime, but the Colosseum has to be visited at a set hour indicated on the ticket. The hill covers a big area of ancient Rome. There is a lot to see and to learn, and that is way I should have reserved a tour. The tour guarantees a skip-the-line entry for the Colosseum as well!

Great Tour. The views of the Palantine Hill from the top where the museums are is brilliant you get a real perspective of the whole place you do need a guide to get the best from this otherwise you have no real concept of exactly what is here

Mesmerizing walking through the Forum.. Recommend a guided tour of the Forum as it will enrich the experience and provide you with so much background and history. These guides are extremely knowledgeable and the perspective you gain from them is worth the time and money.
Take the time, go early. Walk thru here as part of the "Roman Forum". Go early, they open at 8:30. There was no line and the place was a pleasure to explore. However, by 10am, the crowds had arrived.
Palatine hill . We saw it at night. Wish we couldn't seen it during the day and taken a tour. My daughter couldn't fully appreciate it at night.

A must see but only with a guide. Palatine Hill on yourown may not seem like much other than a ruin. Palatine Hill with a guide is excellent because it comes to life with stories of Emperor Augustus and all those who followed. I really enjoyed the historic aspect and significance of Palatine Hill and recommend Palatine Hill as part of a tour that covers the Roman Forum and Colosseum as well.

Steeped in History, Stunning Views, Good with a Guided Tour. After Colosseum, this is a no-brainer stop. Again we elected to be part of a guided tour, and didn't regret that one bit. Our guide was humorous and witty, a student of art and archeology who was part timing. Along with our group, we trekked up the steps of Palatine Hill, the birthplace of Rome, and walked among its ancient ruins. History came alive among the ruins, with the blazing sun beating down upon us and a gentle breeze cooling down simultaneously. When we were thirsty, we refilled our bottles from the public fountains dotting the hill. The water was cool, clean and potable, so that even our 3 year old son drank his fill without any effect. We splashed the cool water on our overheated limbs and the feeling was out of the world. And finally from the top of Palatine Hill, we looked down upon the ancient ruins of Roman Forum and were awestruck. All in all, we relived the lives of the ancient emperors of Rome and imagined it come alive beneath us. It was an experience out of the world. This is a must visit stop for any visitor to Rome, and I would like to see it again.

Amazing ruins!. So, I see on trip-advisor all these pictures of the Roman Forum here on Palatine Hill attraction. You really need a full day to walk the Forum, Palatine Hill and the Colosseum. One ticket for 14 euros covers all three and the difference between Palatine Hill and the Forum is seamless, but they are different. Palatine is worth it because you can look down on the Forum. On the other side of Palatine Hill you can look down on Circus Maximus. This hill is the birth place of the Romans! Inhabited since the 10th century BC. Rich folks and emperors of Rome lived here throughout Roman dominance. The ruins of Augustus' palace, emperor Tiberius' palace and Domitian are still visible! 27 BC - 96 AD. I mean really, just think about that! Crazy! This is the least crowded of the three sites on the Colosseum combo ticket.

Emperors Palace. In your reading you will often come across references to the Palatine hill. Well this is it. Fairly long walk (1/2 + mile) , fairly steep and the vending machines at the top that sell water are problematical. When you get to the top you will see the private theater for the emperors, some attractive gardens(but certainly not spectacular). The views toward the Forum and ruins are quite interesting and make you wonder why someone didn't take it over as a private residence. Well worth the time and walk, but nothing spectacular.

A wonderful surprise. Your ticket to the Colosseum gets you into the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill. My daughter had done some research and insisted we go, and I'm so glad we did!
