You get a real sense of just how OLD this area is. Take the time to wander all over. Walk to the very top of the wall and look down onto the whole scene - it is a true old world wonder. One great thing: all over Rome (and most towns in Italy) you will find clean running water fountains to rinse your hands, fill your water bottle, and dunk your head on hot summer days. A life saver!
Nice View of the Forum and great selfie spot. Everyone in Rome is crazy for selfie sticks - the Palatine has a great view of the forum and a nice garden on top.

Fascinating Ancient Ruins... But Seeing From A Distance Is Just Fine!. My wife and I are seasoned world travelers and were driving by car throughout Italy during a month-long adventure. Happily, we had seen much of Rome years ago before it became a total money grab.Regrettably, like the Colosseum and the Forum, we found the Palatine Hill to be another Roman ruin of great historic significance that has been turned into an amusement park experience... complete with hucksters, scammers, gypsy tour guides, long lines of tourists and an 11 Euro entrance fee (or 20 Euros with a Roma Pass -- with all it's restrictions). We were happy to avoid the madness and simply used a telephoto lens for our photo memories.

Visiting with he Roman Gods. Spellbinding romantic molto Romano. You are in a virtual park where you are close to nature. Away from noise, cooler temperature by 10 degrees, birds galore if is late afternoon. Peace and quiet..
Well worth the visit. Spend the time and see the remains of Ancient Rome. Beautiful to see the architecture of the period and marvel at the engineering and expense of these structures.

A Must-See for History Buffs. Once you explore the Forum, go take a look at the Palatine Hill! Palaces of Roman emperors once stood upon the Palatine, and many are still extant. We took a tour of the Forum, Palatine, and Colosseum that was excellent.
Visit ancient Rome. Enjoy the views over Ancient Rome and beyond to Colosseum. By entrance ticket in advance or at the entrance on the day.

It's Just Ok.. Palatine Hill is a nice way to start your visit to the Roman Forum and Colosseum. In my opinion, it has plenty of history to see, but with a lack of placards and directions, it becomes difficult to know what you're viewing. We spent roughly 40 minutes traversing this area before moving on to the Roman Forum. Palatine Hill does provide very nice views of the Circus Maximus and other parts of Romes Centro Storico, but you don't need to spend your whole day here.
Make sure you have good walking shoes!. Beautiful but physically taxing in the heat. Well worth a visit. Buy iced water if you can, from sellers outside. (1 euro).

Good Place for a work with HISTORY!. This is absolutely a great place to visit with so much history, it is truly amazing, make sure you take a drink and some food because you spend hours there walking around taking pictures, taking it all, great day out

Only good if you have a good guide. Best way to see this is on a tour with a guide that covers the hill, the forum and the Colosseum. If you just wander around the hill, you will have no idea what you are looking at. You can go to the edge of it and look down over Circus Maximus which will save you the walk round to it and you get a better view.

Big and moving. Next to the Colloseum, lots of interesting ruins with a great story. Opens up a bit, so its nice after going to the Colloseum (very crowded), to walk around without the throngs of people. Hot however, not a lot of shade. Kind of awe inspiring
Perfect for a picnic on a sunny day!. Great experience and lots to be seen ! An impregnated with history site. Also lovely for a picnic on a sunny day!
Massive. I didn't relies the place was so big. It's easy to imagine what it must of been like in it's heyday.
Beautiful. Lovely area to walk around and experience the roman empire. Great view over rome. Very hot and uncovered so make sure you have water.

Incredible history!. If you are okay with just seeing ruins, you can walk all along the outside of the gates of Palatine hill and you will still be able to take great photos. Palatine hill is worth it with a guide, the guide will bring it to life that is rooted in deep Roman mythology. It has some really great view spots of the colosseum and more. Spent over an hour here.

blast to the past.. you leave the italian capital and enter the roman republic, this place is phenomenal and i think its more interesting than the Colosseum, you have to walk around the entire extent of the place and take everything in!

Lots of walking but with the effort. A ticket.to the Colosseum includes entrance to this area. Like the forum, it evokes wonderment about what Rome was like 2000 years ago. It requires a lot of walking on some dusty trails, but the views from the hill are spectacular.

Be prepared for a climb to the top.. The climb to the top is steep but once you get up there you are fine. there are ruins of homes and the palace of Ancient Romans. Not a whole lot to see but good views of the city and great history
A pick from ancient Rome. this is what ancient room looked like, its mostly destroyed but its still fascinating, you have to walk there a lot, don't forget the water.

Magnificent. Doing this after the Colosseum is a little energy sapping, but given it is next door, then they are invariably visited as a pairThe history has to be appreciated without question, magnificent grounds, wonderfully preserved to reflect their originality

So much remains and great views over Rome. This is a very big attraction, it is quite a walk, but is well worthy. It is part of the admission ticket for Colosseum and Roman Forum. It has so many artefacts, it is amazing. I would love to go again. There are quite a lot of drinking water fountains to top up your bottle if it is a summer visit, as it it really hot.

Forget the Colosseum and visit Palatine Hill. The guide books said to come here first in the morning so we did! No queue and straight in. This place is vast and we didn't even see all of it. It is simply breathtaking and the amount of things to see gets a bit overwhelming after a while. You just walk around with your mouth gaping saying 'wow' and 'look at that/this!' There is so much to see here definitely come here early in the morning and start here. Don't miss Palatine Museum while here, it has some amazing artefacts from AD and BC it really does blow your mind how old everything is. There is an amazing viewing platform that gives you a birds eye view of the Colosseum and the Forum below. Palatine Hill was undoubtedly a huge highlight. I visited the Colosseum 6 years ago and whilst it is incredible, don't miss a chance to visit Palatine Hill.

Stroll this historic site. Take your time to stroll around the ruins of this historic site, use your imagination and pretend you were a very rich person living in ancient Rome, especially if you were the Emperor. From here you can gaze down upon the Circus Maximus and imagine the charioteers. We suggest combining the Palatine Hill with the Roman Forum.

Must see!!!. If it is not the most is surely one of the most important places to visit in Rome. If you have not a deep knowledge of you are going to see it is strongly recommended to get a tour guide. The 12e ticket for the Colosseum covers also the entrance fee for the Palatine Hill within two days.

Palatine Hill. Doing this and Colosseum was very tiring. The day was very hot, However, the beauty was just magnificent. What a wonderful site. Only spent 2 hours here, should have spent 4 to 5. Too many things to see

Wonderful history unearthed. We had no idea the vast amount of structures that were excavated in the last few hundred years to show Palatine Hill until we arrived on the tour. This was a combo tour with the Colosseum and the Forum. All of it is outside, and you see the huge palatial areas and gardens of prior emperors - there are still walls and foundations left but not full structures. Frescoes are in there as well. This is helpful to have a tour guide or you really won't grasp what you are seeing to learn about the history here.

History! . Rome is just a fantastic place for anyone interested in history. Despite it being a very hot day we managed to do the full walk from the colosseum overlooking the Forum and Hill and then down around the bottom. We didn't have a guide for this but read the captions below each thing which was pretty informative. I do NOT recommend this for elderly or those with restricted mobility. I tripped about 4 times and watched a lady fall flat on her face. The path is very uneven and slippy.
Part of our tour of the colosseum. Was worth seeing, did enjoy the views. There was music on while we were there, but not sure if this was the norm.

Wow.... We took a tour including coleseum, forum and palatine hill. Well worth the money. Our guide was a font of knowledge and eager to share it. You can wander through on your own but is so much richer when things are explained.

The lesser visited, but fascinating. When you buy your ticket to the Coloseum and Roman Forum, it also includes the Palatine Hill. It may be a climb, and not as densely packed with historical sites, but it is well worth the visit. In fact, if you buy your tickets and enter through the gate at this address, you could save hours of waiting in line. It is a short five minute walk from the Circus Massimus Metro stop. The real value of this area is the palace and baths looking out over the Circus Massimus in the far back, but it is all interesting. After walking towards the Roman Forum, you first get a bird's eye view of the forum before descending the hill.
Palatine Hill. The tour guide on this trip was great, very knowlegeable and considerate to some of our parrty who were struggling on what was a very hot day with lots of steps to climb.

Free 1st Sunday of the month . Go here before you go to the Coliseum because your ticket includes Palatine Hill and the Coliseum and you might be able to skip the queue (line). Also, if you go on the first Sunday of the month you can get into both for free! Have fun and safe exploration!
Great Piece of History. Part of Full day tour, incredible archaeological find , well mapped out for tourists, found it very interesting & educational, enjoyed it immensely

Go and see our you will regret later. Standing amongst these buildings and the remains of the centre of the Roman Empire is a must. Perhaps do a little research before your visit to help understand what you are looking at.
Explore the ruins. Get a ticket in the forum for the ruins and the coloseum because the line is much shorter than in the coloseum. Wander around and take a tour for a more informative bisit

Every Tour takes you There.. Every tour of Rome - walking, open-top bus, bicycle, limo.... - will take you to the Palatine a Hill, from where you get a great view of the Forum. This brings out something of the history of the place, as you see so much more of the ancient city. Columns, arches, streets.... If in Rome, you'll go there!

Rome history. We found it difficult to know what we were looking at. It would be good to have images of what the buildings actually looked like. If you are into history then you will probably enjoy it.
Great views... It was a hot day and alot of walking, steps and hills, but once u get to the top the views of the entire Roman forums and the Coloseum were breathtaking.

A City with HISTORY. Stumbled upon Palatine Hill while touring the Colosseum. It's a massive plot of land with so much history you most certainly need a tour guide. It's amazing and at the same time overwhelming, but it one of the most beautiful places to take pics.

Really interesting. Amazing views across the city from the top. Ruins to look at in all directions. Can easily spend a few hours or more here. Wear comfortable shoes and avoid the hottest parts off the day as it's very open. We did find a sheltered oasis in the middle which was a godsend

Great views!. We did happen to get caught in a thunderstorm up here and there weren't too many places to shelter! But great views up here and worth coming up for a good walk around for an hour or two.

Fantastic Ancient Rome. The Palatine was the site of the palace of several ancient Roman emperors, high above the Forum on a hill.Now you can see the impressive ruins of the palace, which are surprisingly intact compared to the Forum or Colosseum, although sadly you cannot go down into them.You can however walk through the emperor's garden, and go into the Palatine museum to look at artifacts discovered at the site and to learn more about ancient Rome.Due to its lofty position, the views over the Forum to the Colosseum, and also to more modern monuments such as the Altar of the Fatherland and St Peter's Basilica is fantastic.A fairly recent and interesting surprise was the excavations of an even older settlement on the hill, believed to be the founding village inhabited by tribe who essentially started what has become modern western civilisation. And also where Romulus and Remus lived if you believe the legend.Thanks to the museum, and the partially reconstructed ornamental gardens on the Palatine, there is a lot more cover than on the Forum or Colosseum and drinking water taps appear regularly, so despite the climb it is a more comfortable visit on a hot day.Visited the Palatine on the same day as the Colosseum and Forum, and I would definitely say it is the best of the three.

Breathtaking view!. It was so beautiful! Sat there for a good while just taking in the view. Bring a water bottle as there are fountains in almost every corner. Also note, when you buy the tickets for the Palatine Hill, it's valid for the day itself and the day after to be used at the Colosseum and Roman Forum (both are places to check out!) And of course, wear running shoes.

This is old!. I feels strange walking along the remains of the streets that the ancient Romans used to go about their lives 2000 years ago. Why did they build such a massive legacy to their men and idols? There's the obvious reasons then you can go deeper if you like. I did and thoroughly enjoyed the whole experience.
Palatine Hil. One of the major attractions in Rome. A great deal of imagination is needed here when looking around and if it is hot take fluids. No shop or cafe in the hill.

Unmissable for visitors to Rome (See our review of the Colosseum).. See our review of the Colosseum. The Palatine Hill was part of a tour that included the Colosseum and the Forum. It is a most enjoyable way to spend a day in Rome, especially if you are interested in ancient history.
AMAZING. we did this after the Colosseum and it was amazing. Take water, and there are fountains were you can refill your bottles. Take a camera and enjoy!

Very climatic. I found this place to be more interesting than The Colloseum. You could easily imagine ancient Romans walking around, chatting and relaxing. It really gives you a feeling of the "eternal city". A def must see in Rome!

Astonishing antiquity. We were late to get tickets for entry but were pleased to be able to stroll up the hill and see a good deal of the ruins from the path through the fences. At the end of our climb, by the offical entrance, there was a lovely chapel. Ruins date to 800 BC. Will definitely plan to go back on a future trip.

Great views and a free museum. Well worth combining with the colosseum, on a hot day, leave this one till last, there's a great breeze on top of the hill near the flags which will cool you down after the low down heat of the forum
Palatine Hill. We had a tour guide that did a wonderful job explaining the ancient city. I'm generally not a history buff, but, this was very cool to see.

Exposed. To discover this attraction, one has to toughen up and get ready to be under the Roman searing sun. No choice but have to face the fear. It was well worth it to walk up the hill and discover the area and see the ancient Rome from the hill's perspective.
Jaw dropping. Even if not into the history, go up on to the hill and just take a few pictures. Its truly beautiful.
Another of Romes treasures. Every corner that you turn you will see fantastic historic buildings, you could spend weeks going from one to the other and it very memorable too
Must see in Rome . Must see at least once. . Always a good day nice good idea dto bring your own water and refill using any of the many fountains throughput the c655

A Must See!. This was one of the highlights of our visit to Rome. It is quite a large site and full of really interesting buildings. You get a real feel of how impressive Rome must have been in its hay day. The Colosseum ticket includes a visit to this site and you can pre-book on-line.
Not to miss. Just incredible to to walk around so much history. I would definitely encourage anyone to take a guided tour.

Left a little disappointed . Left a little disappointed after a visit here, not really that much to see or do, the best thing about it are the amazing views across the forum and colosseum, a few other nice sights but nothing compares to the forum itself, but worth a visit

Great insight into ancient Rome. Seeing the ruins was so interesting. Our tour guide Sylvia was incredible! The heat in Rome was intense, so we would have enjoyed this tour even more if it wasn't so hot; however, our entire group enjoyed seeing the ruins and getting insights into the ancient Romans.
Must See!!!. That is really a great place, for people who are interested in history it is a real paradise but I strongly recommend it to everybody

all starts to look the same. Nice to see but if your not that into the true history it all starts to look the same after a while. We did a semi-private tour with The Roman Guy and while it was good, it was very long, starting at the Coleseum and then here and to the Forum. Almost 5 hours in 95+ heat so it was a challenge keeping focused. I would think when cooler temps and less crowds it would be more pleasant. By all means, a site to see, but I think you can probably walk through it and be satisfied you saw in under 2 hours.
Must see with a guide. When seeing the "Hill" with a guide, you get the feel of the city - layer upon layer. We toured the area and moved to the Colosseum right after

Very cool site, rich history and views of Colosseum. Family liked this very much, an ancient Roman town (or remains thereof) with great history to it, view of the Colosseum, etc. You can get a combo ticket for the Palatine + Colosseum (purchase online to avoid the line at the Colosseum).
Must see!. I loved visiting it: if you go to Rome, take the time for a walk. Beautiful lookout perfect for taking pictures!
Excellent view . Excellent view just watch your step on the way up. We went through the Roman Forum first but next time we would do Palantine Hill first because the Forum is more intricate.

Historical, must visit. One of the seven hills of Rome and the most ancient part too. Apparently this area had the cave where Remus and Romulus were found. Later on they built their empire here.The hill has Roman Forum on one side and Circus Maximus on other. It is in total ruins now nut one does not have to stretch the imagination to think of the massive constructions that must have existed. Not all places here are accessible and you can use the same ticket as Colosseum.

Great Views and Interesting Ruins.. There is not a lot to see as far as the ruins go, you have to use your imagination or look at recreations of how it might have looked. The view from the top of Palatine Hill is nice overlooking the Forum. If you want the full history you should probably book a tour guide, the map they hand out is not very good.

Love the history behind it. I think it is advisable to go there on a guided tour as the guide will tell you the history behind it. If you just go there on your own, it is like having a stroll in the park with no information. But it is still lovely.

Well worth it!. Even at 90 degrees it was worth walking around. The views of the Colliseum and Forum are really amazing. There usually is no line so access is immediate and then you can access the Forum directly without waiting in its huge line.
Palatine Hill the birthplace of Rome. We were amazed at the importance of this site. The first cistern ever dug is here from when Rome was built. Worth the trip!
The heart of civilization. A must see, and thankfully Rome is preserving this great treasure. Plenty of room to roam and think about our collective world history.
Historic Sites. Toured the Palatine Hill as part of the Forum. Very nice views of the city. Do not miss it, while you are at the Forum.

Incredible views, don't miss it!. The views from the top of the hill are stunning, and we could have spent hours wandering through the ruins. Definitely leave time in your visit to spend a few hours here. There are no in and out privileges with your ticket, and the Palatine Hill and the Forum are considered the same area - so make sure you leave enough time to do both. We thought because the ticket was valid for two days we could go out for lunch and come back. Not the case (make sure to read the fine print!) Luckily, a kindly security guard let us back in anyway.
An amazing sigh!. This was part of our Colloseum tour and we couldn't believe the what remains from so many years ago. The history there was so interesting!

Worth the climb. Don't skip this part of the Colosseum / Forum / Palatine combo ticket. Incredible views. Make a stop in the museum to see the recreations to get your bearings while strolling the ruins.

Short trip of Palatine Hill. We took a tour guide on the palatine hill and think it was very interesting, We walked up the hill to see a great view of the Roman Forum. The guide was very informative, helpful and managed to make the tour fun at the same time. Palatine Hill was very quite compared to the Colosseum, and much more authentic than the Colosseum. Amazing.

Always Worth a Visit. We often come to Rome and try to never pass up a stroll though the glory which was Ancient Rome. One thing not to miss is a visit to Santa Maria Antiqua at the foot of the Palatine Hill. The frescos painted in the 700's are worth a look.
great views. Definitely worth the effort for the views although a fair amount of imagination is needed to picture what buildings would have been in place.

Understand the history else skip if you have limited time. If you buy the ticket to Colosseum, you can visit roman forum and palatine hill as they are in one package. The only building I appreciate is one of the basilica which is still complete, the rest of them are like abandoned stone. You cannot visually how it looks like without knowing the history behind. Hence if you have a guide that will helps a lot as you will be fed with some useful information which can help you imagine what you see. If you are someone that is really very passionate about the archaeology or if you have extra time, this is definitely a recommended place.
Just amazinf. If visiting Rome this is the place to be. It's much better than the coliseum and a lot more to see. Recently open a new sight the city. Please go you won't regret it. I loved it.
historical. Next to the Roman Colosseum. The place is shrouded in legend and steeped in history. For people who love history, this is a must place visit.

Mrs. We visited when temperatures were over 36 and blazing sun, lovely view all round and the museum is a nice sanctuary from the heat with the air-conditioning. Enjoyed the tour guide who kept us amused and interested about all the history and legends x
Great if you have a tour guide. Underwhelming if you don't understand what you are looking at. Use Chiara from Journeys to Italy- you won't regret it!

Amazing place, Ruins are great. Who could believe how these fantastic bldgs were made that long ago. Just great to see.lots of walking and stairs/uphill walking. If sunny at all wear hats and lots of sunscreen
Tour of the ruins of the early Kings and Empoers homes. Very interesting area, my visit was part of a tour through City tours and I highly recommend a guided tour to enhance the experience
The view. A photographers dream. This is a highlight view for those keen photographers to get the best shots. A bit of a climb but not too difficult and worth the effort.

A pearl midway Piazza Venezia and the Colosseum. You could spend morning till noon easily there
Apart from beautiful archaeology, you could enjoy one of the best view points of Rome

Rome's history laid out in magnificent rubble. This was part of our Colosseum Tour and I enjoyed it very much. Our guide wa interesting as she told us stories of the buildings built here and the history beneath the more famous spots. It was a very hot day while we were visiting, I think it was the official first day of summer in Europe so it was a scorcher. Keep hydrated and bring an umbrella or anything to shade yourself when it gets too hot. This is a must to do in Rome.

Interesting. Buy a combined ticket for Palatine, Forum and the Colosseum at 12 Euros. Buy and start in Palatine (shortest queue). You can use at least 3 hours walking around Palatine and Forum, which is very interesting and the views from the hill are great. With your ticket its quicker to get into the Colosseum, but not much inside ( 20 mins) enough.

Part of the Forum, Colosseum tour package.. Great views of the Forum from the hill. This is where the elite’ lived 2000 year ago. In some place you can stand on 2000 year old marble, and if you splash a little water on it, get a sense of its original color.

Unmissable Views. It was a hot day but it didn't stop us venturing up the Palatine Hill. The views from the top are beautiful, overlooking the forum and seeing the Coliseum from a different perspective was very rewarding. The area is well managed and there are clear walkways and plenty of fountains to refill water bottles which was a godsend in 35 degree heat.

See it by MoonLight. Any of the ruins viewed by moonlight are even more enchanting than when seen in the daylight. You can almost imagine yourself being there when it was a vibrant place full of people and activity.
Part of Colosseum tour. We did this as part of a great Colosseum tour. Alot of great history although it was so hot out were worn out by the end.

Part of History. Once you are in the Forum, there are signs directing visitors to Palatine Hill. It is easy to understand how this location was selected as the business hub for Rome. It's not a hard walk and there is a water station and bathroom near the top. Read about it before you go because there is not a lot of signage.

Fascinating, must-do walk. Very interesting walk that must be done if you're in Rome. Probably best with a guide to learn and appreciate the "field of rocks" as our little travel group called it. (I reviewed our tour guide separately). With a little imagination you can picture life here all those years ago. Time well spent.

Amazing but hot. Get your tickets in advance and you still need to que. biggest challenge is lots and lots of walking and extremely hot. Bring water and some snacks and an umbrella you will appreciate all.

Amazing ruins. Even avid history buffs will be overwhelmed. So many layers of history and the shear magnitude of what must have been, judging by the foundations and remaining walls, is stunning. Plan on at least 4 hours and do a little research first. You will be richly rewarded

So Much History!. This was an amazing place to visit with so many ruins (e.g. Roman Forum, House of Augustus, Arch of Titus, Temple of Saturn, overlook of Circus Maximus). It was cool to see so many things in such a confined area. There are at least two places where you can view things inside -- a small museum and a basilica. Plan to spend at least two hours here. Water is available from various fountains throughout the area.

Awe Inspiring. As part of the Colosseum and Roman Forum "skip the lines" tour by Viator, we found this really great. Our guide was very informative and gave us descriptions and had pictures of what the structures would have looked like. Could almost see it in your mind. Worth the price and visit.
Stunning. The views here are stunning, breath taking. Gorgeous photo opportunities here. What history in this area easily walkable.

Im never gonna get enough of this place. I just love the fact, that you can walk around there... sit there and watch, eat your snack.. go up to the hill and see the view. Just amazing place! All what you can see, the history, the architecture - or what is left of it.. It once must have been incredible!

Fantastic for a history lover.. It's best to mark the down for a couple of hours when going. There is a decent amount to see and lots of photo opportunities, especially for those whole love roman history.

Truly historic. Could have easily spent a week here, however the heat/sun is horrid. Also the audio guide is trite and banal.History like this needs narration, not reading out of facts. Without the context this place loses its impact.

A big area to cover. We visited here after the Colosseum and the Forum. It covers a large area and isn't so clearly signposted. It was around midday, so even for May it was quite hot. The views overlooking the Forum and Circus Maximus are splendid but it is quite a long walk between the two. If you're over 60 like me, avoid midday!
Worth a visit. Nice views of Rome, queues to get in though . Pricey if you don't get combined ticket.You can see best view of the remains on the hill for free at the Circus Maiximus.

Great views and history. Do this on the same day as visiting the colosseum and forum. You get some fantastic views up here so definitely worth going up to see how Rome has evolved over the years. We didnt have a guide but there are lots of signs with information on so it isnt a necessity.
Amazing historical architecture. Amazing historical architecture, great to walk around and check it out after visiting the Colosseum. A must see!

Amazing. Huge, and stunning. Such a big place, so many things to see and it's a lovely walk around all of the grounds, from ruins to gardens. Nice fountain in the middle to refill your water bottles. Definitely worth the time.
Palatine Hill Tour. Best to do this with the combo tour of the Colosseum, the Forum and Palatine Hill. Prices are better, a tour guide is virtually a necessity and more more informative and fun
Good views of the Colosseum and Forum. If you leave the Colosseum and go to the Forum via this hill, you will have glorious views. Going with a guide is helpful for the most information.
Best overall view. Best overview of the city. See the contrast and blending of the ancient city and the current one. Best picture opportunity!
Very peaceful. Great to hang out for a couple of hours. Hard to believe you are in centre of Rome. Take a water bottle and enjoy endless free refills from the cool fountain waters that taste great.
Too unreal. Happy to say I've been here, didn't have to wait in line for too long and you really felt free to walk among the ruins.

Great and Epic Location to Visit. We visited Palatine Hill with a tour guide. This was probably my favorite site in Rome especially when the details are explained. It is beautiful and historical with many surprises and vistas.

Beautiful views and plenty to see. Again thanks have to go to Barbara from City Tours she pointed out many things that could easily be missed, a wonderful way to finish a tour as the views are amazing and not to be missed.
Part of the Forum. The Forum grounds are so vast, that this is an attraction within an attraction. This should be a scheduled stop in your Forum visit.
more histoy. use one of the walking tour guides and you will get the palatine Hill, colloseum, and Rome forum all in one.
Most worthwhile. After having toured the Colosseum and the Forum, it was wonderful to see all these sites again from a perspective. The view from there is just breathtaking. A definite must!
A can't miss!!!. was part of our Colosseum tour. a lot of walking but well work the time, bring comfortable shoes is a must and bottled water is a backpack.

Amazing views. Great place to walk around and explore. The viewing platform over the forum is a must. There are plenty of water fountains to refill bottles. Do this in he morning to avoid the heat then have some lunch and do the coliseum late afternoon to avoid the queues.

Best views of the Forum, less crowds!. Out of the three big attractions in Ancient Rome, this was our favorite. A great way to see all of the old city and the forum, but with less crowds. It's up a bit of a hill obviously but the views were stunning. Lots of photo opps and a great pause in a day of sightseeing.
Stunning. A testament to the Roman empire, it is incredible to think that some of their buildings are still standing almost 3000 years later. Wear comfy shoes!
The home of the Emperors of Rome.. A quiet refuge in bustling Rome. It really helps to have a knowledgeable guide unlock the hidden details.

Naturally Part of Forum & Colosseum Visit. We spent a morning visiting the Colosseum, Palatine Hill and the Forum...would suggest you have a guide in order to truly understand where you are. Otherwise, so much would be lost...very educational! We used WekaTravel.

Interesting site. We first started off at the Colosseum and then our tour guide took us over to Palantine Hill. This is such an interesting site that wont be understood without a knowledgeable guide. The site is very wrll preserved and is really worth a visit. I would recommend earlier in the day if you going in summer as it gets very hot.
History. Fantastic views over Rome and the colosseum and the forum, worth the walk up, just for the views, not as much to see as down at the forum, but it has to be done!
Who knew??. Did not know there is so much packed in here. You can wander for days. So much history here, just enjoy the walk and explore.

Wow!. Palatine Hill is simply gorgeous due to its beautiful ruins and old building and extremely old traces of places and shops.We booked a tour guide to bring us through and we saw everything!It was very well explained by our tour guide and we enjoyed every moment up there!

Done it with 7 and 10 y/o must do. Amazing as everything around the old Rome! As I mentioned in my review of Colosseum we had a guided tour for the main objectives. It is well worth the money in my opinion. The kids were not bored but very interested and with the guide you can see all 3 main attractions in 3-4 hours. Indeed you can spend days in the ruins but...

Didnt even know it existed! amazing!. We visited Palatine Hill as part of a trip to the Colosseum. We thought we would see a few Roman ruins on a hill - how wrong were we? The site is HUGE!! There is a museum you can walk around too. It is a must see place for visiting Rome.We spent just over 3 hours doing the Colosseum, Palatine Hill and Roman Forum.You can use your tickets for the Colosseum to gain entry.

Must see. Large site. Take your time on a cool day. Go inside the church to see the remains of frescoes. My daughters climbed to the top for the best view. You can't get out of the back end of the site.
Lots of stairs. Did this in addition to the Colosseum but for 70+ year olds was really hard going with all the steps. However w did enjoy it and it was a good sunny day.

Interesting. Entry is included with the Forum and Colosseum and so it's worth seeing this part, not least for the view you get. You need a guide book etc as visitors are mainly left to just find their own way round. Plenty of interesting history to see.

Simply astonishing..... This is a must see, bucket-list, don't miss it attraction in the very heart of Rome... This is literally ancient Rome... still here for you to see and experience.... simply mind-blowing for a history lover.
Worth a visit. A must to visit when at the Colosseum. Great views of the city and perhaps a little lacking in information for those who don't have a guide book

Book a tour for this.. Palatine Hill isn't easy to appreciate if you don't know the history. Either read a guide book, or book a tour (usually comes with a Coliseum tour). As with everything in Rome, there are a lot of stairs/steps, so wear comfortable walking shoes. You will be rewarded with the best view of the Forum ever!

A nice and relaxing walk trough ancient Rome. We had a relaxed guided tour with a small group of 8 people and it was great. When we got the story about each site on the way and even saw some renderings on how it once looked it made it a great tour.
Interesting. Go nice and early to avoid the queues and to be able to take it all in before it gets super busy with tourists later on! Buy tickets in advance
Good overview of some of the Roman Ruins. one gets an excellent perspective across an area of historical interest from this hill and hence can take more in than being amongst them all...

walking in history's footsteps. As a fan of novels and histories of ancient Rome, this was a real treat. We spent 6 hours here and in the Forum. The first dynastic palace built by Domitian is wonderful and I hope that one day they will make the lower level ( Domitian's private area) open for public viewing.

Reconiasance in Rome. On the second day we took a cab to the coleseum Palatine Hill in Rome, saw the ruins of Demitian's palace and the arch he erected to his brother Titus to celebrate his victory in Palestine.

Fantastic to walk through history. This is a short walk from the colleseum and has so much to offer. The whole thing is spread over quite a large area. So if you want to take you time then plan your root and take plenty of breaks. There is some stunning and iconic architecture to see so take your time. Take plenty of water as a lot of the site is in the open air.

Relaxing in Rome. We went to the Palatine Hill directly after our visit to the Colosseum. It was not busy yet so we could stroll around, enjoy the beautiful views and ruines. Our walk ended with the view on the Forum. Here, we started our own app with the audiotour, so we could see it from above! Again a view you will never forget!

Long but amazing trip. Very amazing to see. We did not plan well as it takes some time to visit this area. Be sure you allow 3-4 hours and eat prior to going. No place to eat there of course. Lots of walking but definite must see area!
Wonderful panoramic view of Rome. We visited with Walks of Italy and were very impressed with this area. Our guide was able to help us imagine what it might have looked like so many years ago.
W/ Guide. Our guide was great but not sure if you'd get much without one? We didn't bother to check for free map/guide as it was already taken care of. Take your time, catch the views.

A good walk through after the Colosseum. A good walk through after the Colosseum on your way to Piazza Navona for lunch but don't make a day of it unless you are real history buff. FYI it's included in the Colosseum/Forum tickets available at coopculture.it

Palatine. We spent 5 hours in this area and didn't see everything, we opted for the video tour, it wasn't brilliant as some of the building works caused us to miss the location for the playback. Make sure you visit the ancient village over towards the river, one tip, buy a twin ticket for Palatine and Coleseum, visit Palatine first then go to Coleseum about 4.30pm, the crowds have diminished and we walked straight in.
Lesser known ruins. We went just because it is included with the ticket for the Forum and Colosseum. I think we were just really tired at that point so we were not impressed.

Next to the Colosseum . Palatine hill is within a very short walk from the Colosseum. Many ruins are accessible by purchasing an entrance ticket. It's gardens overlook the Roman Forum and can be reached by a path leading down to it. Very historic and well worth the visit. If your able book a tour guide that can relay all the info.
Ancient Roman Ruins. A step back in time, but it is wasted unless you make sure you read up on the history of the area so it makes the trip worth it.
Beautiful Tour. We went to the Palatine Hill as part of a tour of the Collesium and it was a great visit. Definitely look at bundling this with the main tour although it took most of the day.

Good view of Forum and millenia of history in front of you. Excellent point to see the forum and play of history in front of your eyes.
Better to go with a guide to understand the story the stones narrate

A different world. It is unbelievable to see Ancient Rome and get a great real feel despite the 200o years that have gone by. You need to have read a little before you travel to fully appreciate, unless you have a guide. Amazing place to visit.
Amazing. So much more to see now than when I last visited Rome some ten years ago. Well worth a visit as so much history unveiled.

Beautiful views of Rome, worth the walk. Excellent views of this beautiful city from the top of the hill. Worth the effort of walking in the heat and gives you a sense of how impressive the city of Rome is.

A lot of history to digest !. The monuments are all very old and nearly in ruins. Be sensible about booking tours ... too much walking to do. Might as well give it a skip and go straight to the Colloseum which as unimpressive.

Not to be missed. Our half day city wonders tour took us through the ruins and brought them to life. The before and after book is great to have when you see these to appreciate what once was here. The teens loved it and were interested the whole tour.

History come alive. Please see reviews for roman forum, colosseum and also colosseum and Vatican tours. This was a very enjoyable day on a guided tour with the above company that took in the colosseum, the forum and palatine hill. Our guide made the day extra special.

Beautiful scenary. This is certainly a historic location which requires a high amount of walking (including stairs, if you wish to seek the highest points where you will get beautiful views of the forum and surrounding sights). A lot of informative boards which you can pause and read whilst strolling around. Wouldn't really recommend visiting here when rainy, as it is mostly outdoors. Can purchase tickets here which allow entrance to the Colosseum too, and allow you to skip the longest queue.
Gotta see. Absolutely unbelievable. The sheer mass of history in Roma boggles the mind. Palatine is archeological lasagna. You have to see it if you're in the city.

Steps are closed! Boo!. Saturday is no doubt the busiest day at the Spanish steps. They've been closed for some time which is too bad. The shopping area near is exquisite. There could be more places to sit please.

Must see, must go! A continuation of the Colosseum visit. After visiting the Colosseum, must go on to visit the Roman Forum. Both are from the same epoch. I suggest getting a guide so as to truly understand and grasp the meaning of the buildings and monuments. Our guide from Quo Vadis, Francesca, was fantastic.
Amazing. this place would have to be one of the most interesting and fascinating places you could see so much history in one spot

Better than the coloseum. Not too crowded, but it should be since this and the Forum are the essence of what Rome rose from. So much history is cannot be done justice in a tripadvisor review. Lots of walking, some stairs, hilly, and worth it. Easily could spend 4 hours here. Try to go on a cooler day. It can get toasty out on these rocks. Start here and work toward the forum. A little easier way to tour it as you get more tired as the day goes on.
Walk in the past.. Like strolling around an expensive Roman settlement. Information boards again helpful. A bit of a push uphill but well worth the effort.

Abode of the Imperials. The historic Palatine Hill in Rome, known for its ruins of ancient imperial palaces.The birthplace of Romulus and Remus who were reared by a she wolf is now more like an open air museum
Wonderful City View!. This place isnt crowded at all, very surprised! Its unique and interesting to see and you can get some wonderful views of the city from here.

An 'oasis' of calm in the middle of bustling Rome. Walked up the hill as part of the Forum visit. It is green and pleasant and an easy steady climb. There are natural watering places on the way and at the top. Get nice views over Rome. It's more walking to do but well worth the effort.

Very good tour purchased through Viatour.. Fantastic experience along with The Forum grounds and the underground tour of the Colusseum. Totally recommend this but go early as possible to avoid the crowds. You MUST BE ABLE to climb many stairs to appreciate these sites
Nice hike. Nice hike I would say. Also more grand at night as the Colosseum. Less lines compared to the Colosseum so you might want to go here first.
Nice hike. Nice hike I would say. Also more grand at night as the Colosseum. Less lines compared to the Colosseum so you might want to go here first.

Near the Forum and the Colosseum. It's been said that this is the area where Rome was truly founded, as this was the place where Romulus and Remus were raised by wolves. For now, it's a beautiful area with lots of ruins (where in Rome isn't?) and a great view overlooking the forum and the city.

Great sites. Worth seeing the place just from a size point of view however don't pay for the confusing and rubbish audio guides.
Lots of stairs and walking so wear good shoes!! But very beautiful.

Worth the trip. We had a tour guide (The Roman Guy) which definitely made a difference. We booked the tour with the Colosseum and Roman Forum. Learning about the history really made a difference when exploring this place.
Tip: bring sunglasses as it can get dusty with the wind.
Walk up for a good view. Here, you can have a good view of both the Roman Forum and the Colosseum. Make sure to carry plenty of water on a hot day!
Beautiful hill. Go prepared to walk a lot with comfortable shoes. Beautiful views of the city, the coliseum and roman forum.
How it was. If you like your history this is this place to go. It has everything, especially after a trip to the Colleseum this truly shows how the Romans lived

Worth a visit. I really enjoyed it here, cause I personally find it so interesting, and I like trying to imagine what it used to look like, even if you aren't overly interested in it but have gone to the Colosseum this is included in your ticket so you may as well go and have a wander. Near the top there is a little museum that I went in and liked the top floor is all statues and the bottom is about the buildings, there is a room with a video which alternates languages on each loop
Interesting place to visit. We saw this place a part of a third party tour that included the colosseum and Roman forum. The tour operator with My City Wonders was awesome!
Panoramic views.. Just one of Rome's many outstanding sites. A favorite place to stroll and enjoy panoramic views of Rome.
Breathtaking . This was part of our colosseum tour and it's awesome but I would definitely recommend you get a guide and don't just go it alone
Wow. You can see this as part of the Colosseum ticket. I can not stress how amazing this site is. We walked around looking in wonder at the buildings and the vast size of the site.

Excellent views. Beautiful views from Palantine hill over the Forum and all the way the way to St. Peters. We did it with a guide on the tour of the Forum and Palatine Hill. This best way to do it to get all the historical details makes it much more meaningful. Many steps and walking, bring a water bottle and hat for the summer sun.

Old palace grounds. This is part of the Roman Forum visit. Do yourself a favor and get a Roma Pass. You'll get 3 full days of public transit and free entry to 2 main attractions (I used mine for Colosseum/Roman Forum and the Castel de St. Angelo). You also don't have to stand in line for tickets!The Hill is really neat to see and full of old ruins. Supposedly the place where Romulus and Remus were suckled by the wolf.
Great views!. Obvious statement. Fascinating to stand on top of this much history. This is simply a must for any tourist. Certain you will enjoy!

Must see, right next to the Colosseum - Same ticket too.. Palatine Hill is one of the coolest things we saw in Rome. We bought our ticket here for 3 attractions- Colosseum, Roman Forum and Palatine Hill. There was NO line. I think it was 12 euros each for all 3 attractions. It is a BIG MISTAKE to buy your ticket at the Colosseum as you will wait in line for hours! What a waste of time when there is so much to see. Start at Palatine Hill, make your way to the roman Forum and end at the Colosseum. Palatine Hill is so lush and green and its amazing to see the ruins of the ancient Roman civilization overtaken by nature. Definitely see this if you are in Rome!

The place where Rome began. The place has more of a historical significance than sheer beauty. From the place, the view of Rome is beautiful and if one does not wish to pay to enter, they can go to a nearby view point for a similar view of the city.

Incredible. This is a must see when in Rome. One admission gets you into Palatine Hill and to the Roman Forum. The sites are well preserved and easy to walk around. It is a nice reprieve from the crowds after you see the Colosseum. The ticket for the Colosseum will work for this as well, or you can use your Roma Pass.

Amazing!. We took a skip-the-line tour through viator for Colloseum, Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum. The Palatine Hill is definitely worth a visit especially if you will be going to the Colloseum as it is right beside it! There were some great photo taking spots there.
A must do in Rome. We did this with the Colosseum and were so glad we did. It's an iconic view and worth all the steps.
amazing!. It is amazing to see how romans used to live. You will see a lot of ruins, most of the things are almost destroyed but you could perfectly understand what is what.

Very Large Area, Commanding Views, Steep Stairs. if you access the Palatine Hill from Piazza Venezia, you go stand facing the incredible facade on the Piazza, then go to your right, around the huge sculptures, to the enormous stairs leading to the top. It is a steep climb, but the views of much of Rome are stunning. The Piazza is kind of the centre of "all roads lead to Rome...", as the various major thoroughfares converge here. From here to go to the Colosseum, the major shopping areas, Trevi Fountain, the Pantheon and Piazza Navona. It's incredible views, but also a good place from which to orient yourself.

Another beautifull evidence of the power of the Roman Empire. Here you can find the ruins - but these ruins are greater than some modern architecture actually. I bet half of the todays` buildings won`t leave half of the material for the history )))Ave Cesar :)
Rome at its best. At the Palatine hill you get an amazing view over the city! Tou can also see loads of ruins from ancient times. It is a long, but very nice walk

Fabulous City Views - be prepared to walk. This is a must see attraction in Rome and the effortless walking will be rewarded with a fabulous city view. The other attractions like Imperial Forum and Roman Forum can be all done on the same day. Take an audio guide for 7 Euros for all attractions. Only drawback is that you have to return in 3 hours. So you may have to speed up a bit.

speechless. Nothing could prepare us for this visit, we did it at the same time as the Roman Forum and was so interesting to see all the different areas, i would recommend going with a guide to get the most out of it

Great adventure. Great adventure. If you have the ticket for both the Roman forum and the coliseum, I'd recommend doing the forum and palatine hill last. This takes a lot of time to see it all but worth having your other activities out of the way so you are not rushing. It can get very warm in here so have water and careful not to get burned as not much shelter. Impressive views of the forum and out over Rome

You need a guide for this one.. The area is quite large and although there are markers in front of structures to tell you what they were, there's little background available without a guide. Quite a bit of walking but worth the effort

Great to Visit on a Tour. The Palatine is another stand out when visiting the ancient part of Rome. It is a great option to do this with a tour as it means so much more when you can get historical education as you go along. We went with Gladiator tours and they were great. A real highlight was to see where the Circus Maximus used to be from up on the hill. A stadium that could sit 250,000 people must have been an unbelievable sight.
Fantastic. We went in the afternoon and it wasn't that busy, we were able to wander where we liked. The view to the Colosseum from here was great.

Beautiful walk.... It's a beautiful place to walk to sigh so many sights to see. They have a horse track in the back that will give you an idea of what the circus maximus might have looked like if it was still standing.

You'll need a guide to get the most out of it. Like Pompeii, Palatine Hill is more about learning what was there than seeing anything left. Much of the structure is gone, but with a good guide you'll get a good picture of what once was.

Family trip to Italy with adult children . This is a must see destination in Rome. It's a short walk with a lovely view of the city! You could take a taxi...but I loved the walk to & from our hotel. (This walk does have a few steep hills)

Quite a hike. We took a Gladiator Tour that included this with the tour of the Colosseum. It's a bit of a hike to get up to the top but once you get there, you are treated to an amazing view of the city, the Roman Forum, the Arch of Constantine, ruins, just to name a few. Our tour guide gave us so much information about the Flavian Palace, an extensive residential complex of the Roman emperors that was built on this spot in 92 AD. (He also pointed out Mussolini's summer house to us on the way.) He also explained to us why there is basically little trace of this huge palace there today.

Great walking - great history. Wonderful family venue to experience the history of the Romans. This is adjacent to the Roman Forum, so be sure to enjoy that in the same visit. Bring your water bottle - water is available to refill those bottles.Note that the exit to the Coliseum is closed due to enhanced security measures, so one needs to exit in another direction.
Don't overlook these palace remains overlooking the forum. These ruins reflect the opulent lifestyle of the privileged emperors of this era. This was one of my favorite sites in Rome!

Beautiful walk with lots to see. A little quieter than the crazed hussle and bustle of the Colosseum or Pantheon, but equally as interesting in many ways. It's probably not going to be the highlight of your trip, but you'll certainly enjoy it.

Lots of history, Easy tour. Did a quick tour of the forum. It's an easy walk around the ruins with obviously lots of history. This is an amazing place to return at night and take photos!!! The lighting is perfect!!

Palatine was good but best used a good view of the city and Forum. Palatine was good but best used a good view of the city and Forum. Would recommend visiting the Circus Maximus and also using this to photo the Forum and the rest of the City. Most interesting part of this was the facts about the central heating system the ancient Romans used to heat their homes.

Be sure to get a guided tour. We would not have know the wonder surrounding these ruins without a good guide, plus with a tour you get to enter into the house of Augustus, which is worth the price alone.

Heart of Rome. Hugely enjoyed the climb up the Palatine Hill. Take your time and definitely visit the museum at the summit to try and put the incredibly confusing history of this important hill in some context. There are many little side areas, away from the crowds, that really allow the opportunity to enjoy the wild flowers and reflect on the deep history of what became the heart of Rome.

Don't miss this fascinating look into ancient Roman history!. The line into the coliseum was soooo long that we decided to start with the Forum and Palatine Hill. We spent a good couple of hours just exploring and enjoying the relative peace away from the crowds. The little museum (included in the ticket) was interesting and the views from the hill breathtaking. A truly magnificent area to visit. Bring your walking shoes!
Part of the Coloseum Skip the Line Tour. This part of the skip the line Coloseum tour. Our guide Chira was very informative from City Wonders Tours.

Don't Miss the Museum!. If you do the forum and the Palatine on the same day, as we did, you may find the slog up the hill a little daunting - but its worth every step. It is also covered in your 48 hour ticket for both plus the Colosseum. Be sure to get tickets ahead! If we did it again, I would rent or download an audio tour, but we did it without, and it was fine. There's a lot you cannot see - there are frescoes described at Livia's house that have to be preserved from sunlight, so they cannot be viewed - but the foundations of all of the Augustan stuff is fascinating, and the museum is truly amazing, though very small. Domitian's palace and some of the Flavian is also worth the walk and the views of the city below are pretty darned good ones. Exit for Gelato through Titus's Arch but do NOT miss the interior engravings there. For fans of Indiana Jones, the famous bas relief of the Romans carrying off the menorah with the Ark is right above your head -! It may be "lost" now, but it wasn't to Titus, who stole it.

Nice walk. Went round here as part of the package that you get when you buy a ticket for the Colosseum. Despite the crowds around the Colosseum , this place is big enough to hold thousands without getting too busy. You could spend hours in here as there is so much to see, but an hour and half was enough as we needed to be in the queue for the Colosseum. Be prepared for the gladiator at the end who will charge you for a picture with him ( and he didn't really look the part lacking the size and muscles to carry it off ).

Old Rome as it use to be. I am a history nut and especially an archaeology geek, and this site was just absolutely fabulous. It may be the most authentic location in Rome, and there an amazing thing around every corner. It is simply amazing how much of the area is still intact, almost as if the ancient Romans simply packed up and left yesterday, perhaps for a nice little raiding trip in the British isles. The spot where Julius Ceasar was killed and then cremated especially gave me the chills. I would recommend getting an auto-guide or guide, so you can truly get the scope of the history here. Don't miss this spot!!!
Must see. You really need a few days to explore everything if you have the time. Your ticket gives you 2 days I think. Make sure you visit the church, the paintings on the walls are amazing

Such history and architecture. A fascinating place to walk around.Definitely take the time to read all the information as it really adds to the awe of the area being able to understand the goings on as well as just take in visually the sights.Some beautiful phot ops and a great place to walk and enjoy your time in ancient Rome.

wear comfortable shoes. pleasantly suprised when we visited here as we werent aware colosseum tickets automatically granted you free entry into here. the place is massive a, you could easily get lost. the ground is rough in some parts so definatley sensible foot wear would be advisable.get a guided tour or audio from here though or you wont know what anything is.
GREAT Views. Worth the time! Be sure to bring water and wear sunscreen and walking shoes. Lots of amazing photo opportunities!
Historical . This was visited after our tour of the colosseum and it's nice to see. It's gorgeous with some lovely views of surrounding places.

The truly ancient Rome. The centermost of the seven hills in Rome. Located between rhe forum romano and the circus Maximus. The original and ancient romans lived here among other important people like Tiberius.

Wonderful history - a very real destination that oozes the past. Spend some time and do not hurry your visit.. If you can spend the time this is worth a visit as it brings all those dusty history books to life. Banish the thought of all those B grade Hollywood films as Rome is far more interesting in reality.

A view to see . Palestine Hill is one of the most ancient parts of the city. It sits above the Forum Romanum, looking down upon it on one side. The Palatine Hill, and the Roman Forum beneath it, is now a large open-air museum that can be visited on the same ticket as the Colosseum-- meaning when you pay for one ticket you get to go to both (3)places: Forum /Hill & Colosseum.

Take the time - it's worth it.. The Palatine Hill - located overlooking the Roman Forum, next to the Colosseum, and overlooking the Circus Maximus - is the most important of the seven hills of Rome, and the most ancient. The site is covered with excavated ruins and amazing vistas of the city. It is an area that is difficult to understand without a local guide - we tried that on a previous visit. This time we used a company, "Through Eternity", that specializes in small groups (8 participants) - they are terrific! Be warned, though, that this is a somewhat challenging tour due to the amount of walking and often uneven surfaces, but REALLY worthwhile.

Views to die for. A must for getting an overview of the Forum. The entrance price for the coliseum includes the fee for this. In fact you could save yourself a queue and get your ticket from here to visit both places. Fabulous views of the Forum.
Place full of history in the center of rome. Interesting archeological side for anyone who studied latin in school. Helps to get history alive and understand the history of that antique town

Wonderful to see. We busted this site using our Roma pass and spent a good 1-2 hours exploring around, may be a good idea to join a small tour or audio guide in order to understand more of what is there

Another must see when in Rome. The ruins are a wonderful step back in time. They are awe inspiring to look at and imagine this time in history. I would recommend a guided tour to get the full experience and complete understanding about what each area within is all about. Do expect a lot of walking to reach the top and get a great view over Circus Maximus. Bring a water bottle and fill up at the spring fountains along the way! I highly recommend this for anyone visiting Rome.

This image is of the Forum, not the hill. Palatine Hill over looks the Forum, there are two ways to access it, through the Forum, or directly, either way and you will have a climb a head of you. Once at the top, you can look at over the Forum, or the Circus Maximums. There is not much left to see, but with a guide there is more to be learnt. The ruins are just that, you can see them outside of this area for free, what access to Palatine hill and Forum allows is, here you can still touch the same surfaces once seen and felt in Roman times.

Beautiful heart of the Empire. If you have visited other Roman ruins around the world, this is the center of where that all came from. A lot to see around this area so take your time & embrace thousands of years of heritage.
Great views and history. Nice way to spend a few hours but a guide is handy. Lots of ruins which would be better explained. I would suggest a good afternoon for this and the collesium
Hill. Must see when in rome. Very good with lots of shade and water fountains. Would recommend for all who are in the area.

Simply Beautiful. We visited the Palantine Hill after passing through the Colosseum, and it was lovely! There are so may remnants of the ancient city, everywhere you look there is either a wall, pillar, column, arch, or something to remind you that that was once a great civilization, the central hub of Rome! It is unfortunate though that so much of it was destroyed or taken down, but it is a privilege to be able to see, even if just a fraction, of what Rome once used to be.

Worth the cisit. This as well as the Roman forum are included if you buy your coliseum tickets online. Really nice was up Palatine hill. When walking up though, turn to your right and walk towards two big garden houses. Them go left and you will have a cracking view over the forum and Rome.

Bigger than expected. We visited the Palatine Hill after seeing the Colosseum. The architecture (what's left) is amazing and this place is huge. Not much of a queue to get in but wouldn't recommend for the disabled as very rocky in places

Like looking at the history of Rome in one place.. Palatine hill is the remains of former emperors palaces, basilicas, forums and the temple of the vestle Virgins. We went on a Friday at midday and didn't have to queue.Walk up the hill through the gardens to stand on the emperor's huge balcony to see the numerous and amazing buildings, arches and columns which span the early history of the emperors.At the top of the hill see the ruins of the old palace.A must see.
Imperial Views. The view from this hill was almost overwhelming. You could not only see all the Forum from up there but could understand why the emperors of Rome choose this location for the palaces.

First hand history.. We visited the Colosseum, the Forum and the Palatine Hill is one morning. We had booked an early entry time because there is not much shade and it gets hot later in the day. The sheer scale of the place is overwhelming. It was busy but not crowded and we wandered at leisure. The same ticket gives access to all three and they are interconnected so no rushing from place to place. The atmosphere is lovely and the wild flowers beautiful.Book a time on-line to avoid standing in a queue. This can be done in advance of your visit from your own home anywhere in the world.

Incredible Experience. Archaeology and history on display. Set high above the forum, this, one of the seven hills of Rome, gives you the opportunity to visualize the scale and scope of the opulence of ancient Rome. Plenty of walking but very worthwhile.

Anniversary trip of a lifetime . To stand here you will stand in awe! This is nothing short of spectacular! The views, the history, the connection to a past that is still very present because of the care taken to preserve these fascinating ruins. In all of Italy this is what reduced me to tears. You must see this. Simply breathtaking. Tours are available or buy a book or an audio guide headset and take your time.
Fantastic views. Lovely site to wander round with lots to see and great views over The Forum. Buy a joint ticket from here for the Colosseum and you will only have a short wait to get in there.

gasp!. The gardens here are so lovely! There is a nice shady area where people sit and chill. My husband and I almost missed this because we were so tired and hungry, but I'm so glad we climbed and saw the gardens. Also, there is a vending machine area so we bought some snacks and had a small vending machine picnic under some trees. It was beautiful. Also, don't forget to take your water bottle as there are water spouts all over the place. The water is good to drink and so cold!

Book a guide or take a guide book. Probably best visited with a guide or at least a guide book to really appreciate what you are looking at as is mostly ruins so takes some imagination and knowledge to really grasp what was there. Still amazing to see and walk around and definitely worth the visit.
My 50th. Steeped in Roman history as was the Forum, its worth going just for the spectaculer views over the city we were lucky to have a clear blue sky even in later dec
I always wanted to visit this.. FANTASTIC!!! I have always wanted to visit the old city and I know a lot about it but to be standing there was an awesome experience
MUST SEE PALATINE HILL AND ROMAN FORUM!. Do this tour. Went with our group of 13 and this is excellent history lesson. Don't miss these ruins!

Very nice place. The temples and ruines are beautiful! I have enjoyed the exploration! We enjoyed listening to the history of this place and its not free you have to pay for the tickets and try to get the tickets online to avoid queues!

Spectacular. Wear comfortable shoes we going to this attraction as you will be doing a lot of walking and going up hills. The history was very well explained for by our tour guide and we were intrigued by the ruins.
Roman history. Good impression of the grandeur of the Roman high society at the beginning of our century. The palaces were really big.

A tour in history. Even if you're not a history/architecture buff, strolling through the Palatine Hill is like taking a tour in history. We came in the late afternoon just before the last entry, and spent about 1 hour there until they closed the place. Lovely view of the ancient city.

Brings even more history to life. A great place to visit at the same time as the Forums. Not only is the whole complex connected, but you get great views of Rome in all directions and it adds to sense of the activity and living arrangements of successive Roman nobles and the temples that they were obsessed with building. Whether you pay and take the handheld audio tour or not, the information boards at different locations around the hill help you to piece together some of the historical development of the Palatine. You can even just get up on the hill for some piece and quiet, away from the chaos going on below!
A magical snapshot of Ancient Rome.. Thank goodness Rome treasures these ruins and preserves them as well as humanly possible. If you are at all interested in History, you must visit.

Great place but requires some imagination . The palace is almost entirely ruins now, so without a good guide it's difficult to appreciate the depth of the history - but with a guide, and imagination, it's a very impressive and important site. Go as part of a tour if you can.

Must see places in Rome. When looking at the ruins on Palatine Hill and realizing the size that this palace one was back around 2000 years ago, it doesn't take much of am imagination to understand how truly spectacular the palace once was. I must see when in Rome. You can visit for free but I recommend go as part of a tour, because it will give you a greater understanding regards what you are seeing.

Another view of Rome. The ruins of the palaces and temples on the Palatine Hill fill out the picture of the the Roman Empire and the lifestyle of the emperors. Easy to walk around and less busy than the Forum and Colosseum leave time for this in your visit.Good views over Rome and the Circus Maximus are available. The Palatine Museum is small but worth a short visit.
Amazing. So very difficult to imagine the length of time all of these structures have been around. Enjoyed wandering around, exploring, in the pouring rain - worth it.

Definitely do this with the Colosseum. We took a 2:30 pm tour of Palatine Hill before the Colosseum. This tour took in the King's Palace, Vestal Palace, Roman Senate and surrounding ruins which put the whole area into perspective. Touring the Hill with a guide is absolutely necessary to understand the history of the place and The Hill is excellent and just as important to see as the Colosseum.

Amazing place. Wow!. My hubby wanted to visit Palatine Hill after we visited the colosseum and Forum on the first Sunday of the month for free. We would have stayed longer that day but we had no food or drink with us, and although there are a couple of vending points and plenty of water spouts, we wanted a cafe break! So the next day we went again (forum, colosseum and palatine hill all one ticket) and paid for an audio guide also. We went prepared this time with take away sandwiches and refillable water bottles, and plenty of time. We headed straight into the Palatino area totally avoiding the Forum except to pick up our audio guide. The palatino area is a lot prettier, greener, than the Forum. The audio guide was brilliant for navigating our way around, a blue marker dot shows you where you are on the map, whist toilets, water spouts and points of interest are all instantly displayed at the touch of the screen. This all makes the visit a lot more enjoyable. The markers at listening posts all have numbers, so rather than going around in a particular order, we strolled around in a very leisurely fashion, listening at the corresponding post as we desired. The museum has an interesting array of antiquities, the most striking, are the wings of victory. The real breath taking moment for us was looking at Augustus's Palace, the sheer scale of the place needs to be seen to be believed. We managed to find a sheltered bench behind the palace where the hillside drops away , and you can view the remains of the aqueduct arches to enjoy our packed lunch, and while away some chill time to rejuvenate our weary legs!

Amazing history. Which a whole Rome is a amazing. The Palatine Hill is the centermost of the Seven Hills of Rome and is one of the most ancient parts of the city. It stands 40 metres above the Forum Romanum, looking down upon it on one side, and upon the Circus Maximus on the other. Roman myth holds that Romulus established Rome on the Palatino after he'd killed his twin Remus in a fit of anger. Archaeological evidence clearly can't prove this, but it has dated human habitation here to the 8th century BC.Enjoy after Colosseum the incredible history. Ticket from Colosseum valid for Palatine Hill and Roman Forum too. Was been valid, last year.
Historical Perspective on Rome through the centuries. The Palatine Hill in Rome is a fantastic place to see monuments and buildings that speak to the long and diverse history of Rome.
Loved our tour guide. Toured with Through Eternity tours. Our guide was Mario Baas. He was exceptional! Very knowledgeable, engaging, and just plain fun! Loved every minute!

Indescribable. . Just an incredible place. Totally unmissable when in Rome. It's a large site so allow for plenty of time. The museum gives great context and the modern art scattered around the area is fitting. The views are also amazing. It's free on the first Sunday of every month.

Interesting, but see the Forum and Coliseum First!. Palatine Hill was interesting, but of the three big Roman sites – Coliseum, Forum and Palatine Hill – it is the least exciting of the three. You do not get that feeling of walking in the footsteps of the Romans and the ability to visual their daily lives at Palatine Hill as you do at the other two sites. Still, being the site of the palaces of the emperors and other nobles of Roman society, it is worth seeing.One of the most exciting views is the view of the Circus Maximus that you get from Palatine Hill. Also seeing the emperor’s private area for races, etc. was interesting.Most tours of the Forum also take you through the Palatine Hill sites, so why not go! I am glad we went, it just was not as exciting as the other two major Roman sites. Our tour was of all three sites and was through OverRome. The guide did an excellent job in explaining, giving enough information to keep the history buffs happy, but not overwhelming or boring those less interested in history. It was a good balance.

Amazing but do a tour or read up first. I found this place amazing but to understand it you need to read up on it or get a tour. We did this along with the coliseum and did it on the first Sunday of the month when all museums are free in Rome. So it was on 20euros to do both the coliseum and Palatine hill with a tour guide. Well worth it we used gladiator tours who where great. The views from the top are great but the story of the palace that it used to be is equally staggering.

History to make you proud to visit.. Breathtaking sights that keep on going, the heat was 29 degrees which made it uncomfortable to a scots woman but I had shade with my umbrella haha.This place keeps on giving with its history, ruins and sheer beauty, no-one expects to see such a vast amount in this place so you will not be disappointed at all.

Great views of Rome. Palatine Hill is where the early Emperors of Rome had their palaces. It overlooks the Forum and Circus Maximus.This was one of the most interesting tours we took. It was in conjunction with the Colosseum tour we had.

Open space offering best view of the Colosseum & Rome. The Colosseum is impressive but we preferred wandering the Palatine Hill. Here, nature flourishes, wild flowers exploded among the ruins, offering a soothing contrast between the past and the present. On top of the hill is a beautiful rose garden and a panoramic view of Rome and the Roman Forum.

Great walk and incredible views!. Prepare yourself to walk, mister! It's wide, it's good, it's a romantic and historic walk... Went with my girlfriend and both of us loved the atmosphere, because it's located in an natural enviroment...

The walk is worth the view. As part of a walking tour of the Coloseum and Ancient Forum, we walked up to Palatine Hill, a challenge for anyone with limited mobility. It was worth the effort to experience that amazing view and the gardens. Do it if you can!

Start early!. Visited on day 2 of our Coliseum/Forum ticket. Went early and started at the entrance away from the Coliseum (Via Gregorio?) which means you start at the ruins of the palace. The two of us were the only people to be seen for a good 45 minutes or so which was excellent. There is also a small museum at this end of the site (free) which is worth seeing. Another plus on using this entrance is that it is a downhill walk to the Forum area, which is always a bonus! Happily spent a good 4-5 hours exploring both this area and the forum.
Fantastic views. Best place to go to get amazing photos across Rome we would never have found this without the help of max from Rex tours

A huge palace worth exploring. Palatine Hill is basically the remains of what was an ancient palace. As what you see there now are just excavations of what remains of it, it requires some imagination to visualize what the palace actually looked like in ancient times. I would recommend a tour guide or audio guide to properly understand and experience the palace.
Go early. Arrived 8.30 am and had the place to ourselves with about 8 others until 10.30 when the tour guides begin.
Sunset. We did a package tour of the Coliseum and the Palatine Hill. We started late but this allowed us to see the Palatine hill at sunset just before close. The view over the forum was magnificent.
Great view of the ruins. It's a slight trek up, but you get a great view of Rome and the Roman Forum. Definitely worth the time and enjoyed seeing Augustus's home and ruins of ancient Rome.

Walking back in time. A perfect day in Rome includes a visit to the Colesseum, the Forum and Palatine Hill. The ruins are spectacular. The views are incredible and the photo ops are more than plentiful. Going with a guide is important because the history and extra information they provide help in appreciating the site. Comfortable shoes are a must as the terrain and steps are uneven. On a hot day water is a must, too -- and you can refill it along the way. I felt badly for folks who were trying to navigate strollers -- hard to do here but if you have an extra set of hands that helps. Take a moment and sit - you might need to break and there is something special about gazing about this incredible lasting slice of history.
