A lovely afternoon in ancient Rome. You can easily spend a few hours here wandering around the ancient ruins. Get your ticket online before heading to Rome - 14 Euro (incl 2 Euro booking fee) to avoid lengthy queues - we went into the Colosseum first. Palatine would be the best place to buy the combined ticket if you haven't already got one.
Imagine how it was. Walking through this roman site, you can imagine how it was and what splendor it could have been, it is an amazing place to discover for around 2 hours.

A must visit. Really attractive Roman Ruin that shows off the wealth of the Roman Rulers in bygone days. Hill overlooks Circus Massimo (Ben Hur fame). Vast complex in tranquil surroundings. Spend time if you can.

Fascinating place. We visited this as part of the Forum ticket entrance and to be honest you really could spend a whole day here and not see everything. One comment I would make for anyone intending to spend more than a few hours here, take something to eat and drink because there are not facilities to buy anything and once you've entered you cannot leave to eat and then return without paying again. Definitely worth a visit
Ancient Rome. Set aside a good few hours to explore! Fascinating area full of ancient wonders and history. Well worth a trip.

A walk around History in the city. I did not realise the Palatine hill expanded so much over the whole hill. This is a vast expanse of ruins that is worth the visit to understand the grandeur of Ancient Rome.

A walk back in time. I toured this location along with the Colosseum ( they are less than 1 mile apart). It was amazing to walk along the same path as others 2000 years before. The area is not that big but still amazing to see and hear what the area looked like over the years. Best to have tour guide and it takes about an hour or so. If I were to do it again I would print out a drawing of what the area looked like when it was built (can get of Internet) to fully appreciate the scale and details of the surroundings.

Rich in history. The visit to palatine hill was very interesting, it was very easy to imagine the roman soldiers and emperors that inhabited the area and walked down the streets. It was like stepping back in time.

Day trip to the antique. Sunny day and there is a little shade. Foods and drinks are not sold here, which is a good thing. It would have been an easier day if we had some salty snacks with us. There are lovely views and you really can feel the history. This is a wast place and at least today it was not too grouded.

Plan lots of time for this great sight!. We spent almost a whole day at Palantine Hill and Roman Forum. Our 2.5 year old son also loved the place, he could climb old marble stones and explore the park. Not so easy to navigate with strolley but worth the effort. Go to the top!
beautiful historic site. Palatine Hill is a garden full of history as well as a kind of adventure. The climbs and the gardens are spectacular as well as the view.

Full of History but use a guide. This was one of the most interesting places we visited but would have had no idea what it was about without our guide. It is rich in history but again only with a guide. I would not visit on my own because without the history, it is just some old ruins.
A must see. It is a must see place , these are ruins and are unimaginably huge , architect is amazing little tiring but must see .

Amazing. This is an amazing site that you could spend a whole day exploring just so much to see and absorb . Check on times as some areas close during the day and you don't want to miss anything . Take a water bottle and a snack with you and wear sensible shoes as the paths are very uneven . You can get the Colosseum and Palatine Hill on one ticket there is also an Audio guide available . Go early to avoid the crowd
Very Interesting. The view from the hill is unbelievable. Everything you see looks like it's from a movie. Great if you love to see pieces of history.

Under appreciated!. Palatine hill is amazing. Not to be over shadowed by the colosseum! It's under rated and under appreciated but so worth visiting! The place is amazing especially if you love your history and culture.
Wow..this place was amazing. To see the whole thing you have to do some serious walking but it's so well worth it. Give yourself a few hours to take it all in and you won't be disappointed.

Quite an extensive site. This is actually the first time I visited the Palatine Hill--I visite Rome before many years ago. There is quite a lot of history just in this area--Cesar is buried here and you can even see it and take a picture. We were with a guide so she explained a lot of the history, building, and the cultural atmosphere of the time. It's worth having a guide with you, otherwise enjoy the ruins and the surroundings.

A lot of walking, bring change or drinks. There is a lot of walking if you want to enjoy the entirety of Palatine Hill but its all well worth it. We made the mistake of not having any drinks/drinks bottles and no change. Imagine my disappointment when we found vending machines and had no change to buy a drink.There are water fountains which you can use and the views are stunning across the entire city. Plenty of history and get in early to enjoy it without all of the crowds about.

Beautiful views. This is a nice place to visit and provides some amazing views to the city and the colosseum below. This requires lots of walking and could be difficult for anyone with mobility issues, as the hill is fairly steep. As a bonus, this entry is included with your entrance ticket to the Colosseum.

Better than I expected. I really had no idea what to expect, but our tour started with the Colosseum, came to Palatine Hill and ended in the Forum. Our guide was an expert and skillfully showed us everything there was to know about this area. I had no idea that this was a major palace. Who could tell, since there was practically nothing left, but between the ruins that were there and our guide, we were showed incredible insight into the area and the life of the residents of this once great palace.Don't try to go here without a skilled guide. Otherwise it will look like a bunch of old ruins that are barely visible.

Imperial History all around. to see the very beginning of rome to the remains of the homes of the emporers, the paletine hill has it all. its a wealth of layers of Romes past covering Millennia. Its adjoining the Colosseum so if ou visit one-you must visit the other!!
Good addition to Roman Forum.... Ruins there are sketchy, but interesting. Did as part of the Colosseum and Roman Forum tour. The view from there is very good.

So much to see, to savour and to experience. What an oasis of calm and interest in the centre of this busy and rather frantic capital city. Enter by the gate beyond the Arch of Constantine to gain quicker access. Walk as slowly as you like through shady wooded areas and try and imagine just how life as lived some 2000 years ago. A few more signs and perhaps a marked route would help. A place not to be missed
Excellent views of Rome. Well worth a visit so much to see here and using a guide made it even better would highly recommend can't go to Rome without seeing it
Great views,Beautiful place. There is a fair bit of walking up hill but well worth it for the fantastic views. It is part of the Colosseum guided tour. This tour is a must see for the history alone.

Breathtaking, and calm to wander around (went on the free 1st sunday of the month). Go to the Palantine Hill entrance (no queue) which gains you a ticket and entry to the colosseum as well (so you don't have to queue there either!). A real surprise at how empty it was (start of May) and very calm to walk around after bustle of the city streets - allow a whole day
Almost too much to see. Well worth a visit, get there early before the crowds to enjoy amazing views of colluseum and forum below.
Beautiful ruins. Entrance tickets can be purchased with Colosseum tickets online to save money and cue times. The ruins were breathtaking.

Interesting but not a must . This is something for those interested in history. It is not something to bring smaller children or children to since they obviously got very bored - very fast.
If you have the time it is a nice way to spend time in Rome!

Amazing view all the way to the top!. We just finished visiting the colosseum and to our surprise, our admission included Palantine Hill and the Roman Forum. We walked up the pathway into an incredible space! We moved our way up the path thru gardens and structures to an amazing top view of the city and colosseum. We ended up staying an extra 2 hours!
True Surprise. Included in your ticket to the colosseum this was truly one of the reat surprises of our visit. Emperor's Palace was awesome. Enjoyed the museum and views from the top of the Hill

Can not go to rome with seeing it.. An amazing place to see, as this is where Rome began the ancient buildings are a must to see. Be prepared for some steep hill walking. Free water form fountain when you enter.
Lack of toilets though only 1 at the top of the hill with a massive q.
Beautiful. It comes as part of the colosseum tour, nice day trip especially with a guided tour. Beautiful views of the city.
Wonderful. We took VIP tour with Walks Italy....excellent! Colossuem included which is a must! Stunning viewing points for many, many photos!

Probably the most impressive historical site. The Palatine, taken with the Forum, was probably the most interesting part of Rome we visited. One gets a real sense of what it would have been like in its prime. Breathtaking to think how it was planned and built. Architectural vision, skill, and probably lots of slaves!

Ancient Rome right infront of your eyes..!!. This is a place with a great history. You can witness the ancient Roman way of living and their arts and culture through the ruins of their massive buildings and the artifacts at the museum. It will take a whole lot of walking and time to cover the whole area, but I assure you won't regret it. Single ticket is valid for the Palatine hills, Roman forum and the Colosseum. My best advise is to purchase the tickets from the Roman forum/ Palatine hill entry point and you can avoid the long queue at the Colosseum entrance to purchase tickets.

Favorite place to visit in Rome!. We take time out of each trip to Rome to visit Palatine Hill. Fortunately, now you can access it directly from the Forum. I am continuously amazed at this place. You are walking on and over Roman palaces. With all the hustle and bustle of Rome, our day at the Forum and Palatine is a welcome quiet break. Make sure you wander all around. There is a great view of the entire Circus Maximus from the back of the Hill. If you look off to the left you an also see the baths of Caracala. You get a real sense of what Roman life was like and how beautiful it would have been. On the flip side, you also get a real idea of the differences between the classes and how they lived. Our 10 year old has visited a few times with us and also says it is his favorite place. He gets to run around, take photos on his own and play amongst the ruins.

Ancient Rome in person.. Do it! Emmersion time warp, Historical brain strain!! Loved the creative force these Romans put into building an architectural rich civilisation that we still marvel at today.

Palatine Hill - Next to Roman Forum. Intersting and beautiful area with gardens and ruins from the Roman era. Sits above the Roman Forum so views are great. You can get a combination ticket to Palatine Hill, Roman Forum and the Colesseum. The ticket costs 12 Euro per person and is good for one entry to the Roman Forum/palatine Hill and one entry to the Colesseum. Ticket good for two days.

Excellent. I had never been here before and what a lovely surprise it was! It's so green and luxurious. The museum at the top is brilliant but there were no staff! We needed to use the wheelchair lift but couldn't do it without staff and although we searched and waited a long time, no one came. The rest of us enjoyed the museum visit - it is excellent, but the person in the wheelchair sadly had to miss out.The views were amazing. A really nice place to visit.

Large Attraction. You really need a couple of hours to visit this attraction because of the area it is spread over.There was a downpour on the day of our visit which put a bit of a dampener on it and we were not able to appreciate iy in its full glory. WE did however have a great guide from the Gray line tour we were on and he gave us masses of information and brought the attraction to life. Well worth a visit

A must see experience. This is an area that we hadn't visited on previous visits to Rome and were astounded by the history and condition of the site. I strongly recommend this as a place to see. We visited the Colosseum, then Palatine and then the Forum, with a private guide. This allowed us the opportunity to take our time while discussing the history etc of this site.
Nice view. There is a very nice view. The best is to buy a ticket to this, forum and coleseum and the price is 12 euro.

Great views and interesting history. We arrived late in the afternoon and also purchased the audio guide. It was a wonderful place to wander and wonder. Note, there are bathrooms in a couple places. We stayed about 3 hours and could easily have spent more time but it got cold. Even in high summer you should be able to find a quiet place to view the ruins.

Great sights poor tour guide. We went with a company called GLT that took us to Colosseum, St Peter in Vincoli and the Palatine. The tour was supposedly in English the tour guide had great German and Italian but his English was only so so. He may have been a new guide and was a bit disorganised and unsure of himself.

Lots of walking. This is great to just walk around and take in your surroundings, you kind of have to use your imagination as to how the place would have looked thousands of years ago. But make sure you have the most comfortable shoes as there is a LOT of walking! You can take some lovely views from the top of the hill.

Requires time!. To do this write, you need time, and a guide. Otherwise without a guide, it is a great place for a stroll. The architecture and history is great, they have boards at each site you can read... however it takes time. It is fun for small kids, if you don't mind them running about... may however distract other tourists.

Feel yourself at 27 BC. This place is good for nature lovers and history enthusiasts. Once you walk through the hill you could see the ruins of the monuments and more like walking in a garden. Probably the best time to visit this place is in the evening when sunlight goes down and man made lights come alive. This place is not free. The Colosseum ticket includes the entry to this place along with Roman Forums. Also if you have a Roma pass you can access this place without buying a separate ticket. We went with our little one (12 months) with a stroller. But we had difficulty in pushing the stroller as the paths in the hill are not stroller friendly. So I would advice carry your baby with a carrier or sling or a baby backpack carrier. In fact entire Rome was not very stroller friendly, but we managed. Without stroller as you roam around the city entire day its difficult for the baby during nap time. So we had to carry the stroller around.

That's unforgettable . We are not a first time in Rome it becomes a best place all over the world, and I can say that Rome is for everyone you can do not pay to visit everything and to see and find out about Rome more than sbd from touristic group. There are a lot of view points to watch forum, coliseum or something else. And it much more fully emotions to go another road of tourist
wow..... again.... so much history in the city of Rome, be sure to take a tour of Palatine Hill on your way to the Colosseum.

Peaceful Palatine. Believe a guided tour is needed to fully appreciate this area. We had Chas from Romaround tours who did a great job. It's otherwise difficult to spot racists the ruins in their full context.
Great views. Excellent place to visit to see ancient Rome. Included in Colosseum ticket. Great for photos & allow about an hour or more.
Great views. We did this as part of guided tour of colosseum. The history we learned was really interesting and you got some great views from up there, especially over the forum.
Must see place. A really nice experience, we did Colosseum first than Forum Romanum and Palatine Hill, devote a few hours for the sigh seeing.
Fabulous views over old Rome. Walking in history is thought provoking. The views over the Forum, Colosium and other beautiful buildings are fabulous.

Interesting addition to my forum tour. I had never seen this entrance to the Forum before. It's a little hidden, so fewer tourists and no line. I got more history than just what I learned at the forum. I will always go in this entrance from now on.

How did the emperors live?. After the crowds at Colosseum, when you climb the Palatine Hill, you are engulfed in silence and tranquility. There are not too many architectural remains to see, but, luckily, we had our guide with us to tell us the history of this once grand place. The most stunning thing was when, faced with several columns and arches, our guide flipped open a picture how this same place did look at the height of Roman Empire. Overlooking the Circus Maximus, the grand palace of several stories in opulence and splendour... There is a great position on the Palatine Hill to look down on Roman Forum, and you can rest in the garden under orange trees. If you go, make sure to have a guide or a guide book to really see behind the fallen stones and bricks.

takes you back to an era you never dared to imgaine. The palace ruins takes you back to a thriving, prosperous civilization. I couldn't avoid feeling envious about the grandeur and the luxury that was experienced by the people then! the view from the top are breathtaking too.

Another on your "I'm in Rome and Must Do" list. I have been fortunate to watch the renovation and restoration of this site over the last decade plus. This last visit allowed us to stay within walking distance. Nice stroll. Use the alternative entrance for quick access if not part of a tour group.
History galore!. This is part of the Roman Forum / Colosseum ticket and is an extension of the Forum (up the hill). Really nice to walk around and take in all the history and has a great museum.

Great views, wonderful buildings. Don't be tempted to skip the Palentine Hill in your rush to get to the Forum - there is so much to see on the Palentine Hill which gives you the background to the area. Also see the 9th century postholes of an early hutted camp on the hill.
wow its breathtakingly huge. worth taking the time to walk up from the top to get the best views over palatine hill. Just incredible

A very interesting historical site. We enjoyed visiting here with a full written guide and information to help us know more about what we were looking at. I think with the right tour guide, and a small group, this could be an even more engaging experience. We downloaded RS audio guide to use with his guidebook for the tour. Whatever you do, don't go without any guide at all or its just a pile of partial buildings and rocks without info plaques and feels like a waste of time and money.

Huge site. There is not much in terms of information available to tourists to explain the Palatine Hill. You would be well advised to pick up one of the audio tour kits which incorporate both the Forum and the Palatine Hill and take it at your own pace rather than racing around on one of the expensive guided tours.The views from the hill down over the Forum and out across Rome are stunning and worth the many steps or the long slope to reach them. When we visited in April there were lots of tourists about, but as the site is so vast, we were able to wander around in comfort. There are a few shady areas, but if you are going in the heat of summer it is going to be very very hot.We discovered a very convenient (unsignposted) w.c. adjacent to the Rose Garden which was a relief in many ways. One thing we learned on the tourist trail was that if you see a loo without a queue, then use it!Now I’m going to say a few words about being a tourist in Rome, and I will include it with reviews of all the places we visited because I wish I had known prior to my visit and maybe it will help you on yours!Firstly, Rome is an elegant city. Tourists in shorts, crop-tops and mini-skirts stand out like a very sore thumb. This attire will mean you are unwelcome in churches, (especially the Vatican and the Vatican Museums) where it is regarded as disrespectful. Expect to be turned away if you are dressed like this. We witnessed from one lady in microshorts and a strappy top and her partner in vest top, Bermudas and tattoos, being politely asked to cover up or leave St Peter’s which did not go down well after waiting for hours in a queue.If you dress smartly you are less likely to be bothered by hawkers, tables materialise in apparently packed restaurants, and you are treated with respect. It’s worth going for ‘smart casual’ if you want to get the best from Rome.Secondly, footwear. Roman streets are mainly cobbled and very gappy. Stiletto or kitten heels are going to be mighty uncomfortable. Wear block heels, wedges or flat shoes and you won’t go far wrong. Most Roman ladies seem to run around in loafers or boots. Another thing to consider is that there is A LOT of walking involved wherever you go. Walk your shoes in thoroughly before you get there and you will save yourself a lot of pain and blisters. Nevertheless, it might be a good idea to pack some plasters in your handbag so you don’t limp yourself out of action. I don’t suppose I’m the first person to lose a toenail after three days walking around the city.Be polite, smile, say hello, please and thank you in Italian and you will be appreciated as much as you appreciate the Eternal City.
Rome in Mid April. We visited this area with a personal guide (Maria from Bruno Tours). It made our visit to Rome just perfect!

Worth a visit. You can visit Colosseo, Foro Romano and Palatino with the same ticket. They are all right next to eachother so it's easy to visit them all during the same day. The view overlooking Foro Romano and The city from Palatino is fabulous. And ofcourse it's great to see the remains of the ancient palazzos of the emperors
Must Visit. Definitely a must visit. One of the attractions that you just cannot miss on your trip to Rome. Couple it with your visit to Colosseum.

Must See Place !. An history to explore, an ancient Rome ruins just opposite Colosseum. The most exciting place for me was a Temple of Caesar (as stated...Caesar was cremated here after the assassination)
Huge. Your ticket for the Colosseum is usually entry to both venues and valid for two days. If you have visited the Colosseum and don't have hours left - leave the Palantine Hill for another day.

Fascinating to see how people lived so long ago. I found it fascinating to see how people lived so long ago. Much remains, even though it is in ruins. It is handy to have a guidebook/ tourguide who can explain everything that you are seeing. It should be noted that you only need one ticket to gain access to the Roman Forum, Palatine Hill and the Colosseum. A must see for those interested in Roman history!
Amazing!. The size is amazing when you think of when it was built and what tools they had at the time, all of Rome is incredible!

Speechless!!. I am coming from a city full of ancients parts around. But Palantine Hill can not compare with anything I have seen before. The remainings made me realise the actual size of the palaces which is amazing. Moreover, the thought that I was walking in an real ancient city was thrilling
AWESOME!!. Part of the Roman Forum this was very nice and full of photogenic landscapes and different paths you can take whether you are a fully-abled person or disabled!

Incredible Palatine Hill. Definitely worthwhile seeing this area with the relics of Roman times so prolific and in some cases, breathtaking making you wonder what happened and who had gone before thee!
10/10. A full day is necessary to visit Colosseo and Fori Romani. If the weather is ok, it is a must. different viewpoints are accessible.

The central hill. The central of the famous seven hills of Rome lies forty meters above the Forum Romanum on one side and upon the Circus Maximus on the other. According to the legend, it was at the foot of the hill's south side where the cave, known as Lupercal was located, the one where she-wolf kept alive Romulus and Remus until a shepherd Faustulus found them.
Fantastic guide.. Great guide with front of the line experience. Very educational and so worth going! Would book them again.

Visit only after preparation and only after Forum. It's good idea to visit both Forum and Palatine Hill after some preparation, so that on spot you have understanding on what's in front of you. It's almost worthless to go there without any knowledge and/or any guidance.I would suggest taking a guided tour or preparing beforehand, as audio guide is not very informative and somewhat impractical in usage.I also suggest to allocate the whole day for Forum - Palatine Hill tour, so that you wouldn't rush and take you time to enjoy both, thinking of eternity on the way (the atmosphere there fully corresponds to the mood).If possible, go to Colosseum the other day.If you are in a hurry, go to Forum first, as it's more impressive than Palatine Hill (although the views from the latter are superb).
Excellent view over Rome and the Roman Forum. Very good views over the city, Roman Forum and Colosseum. Its part of the Roman Forum which you need a ticket for.
Huge amount of Roman history. This site offers a vast amount of ruins from the Roman era. It is a huge area that you should take the time to wonder round.

Un real !!. Felt culture overload at this point. The proportions are impossible to comprehend before seeing with your own eyes. I am so pleased to have been, even though I am sadly lacking in historical knowledge, that can come later. Take the time to wander and be amazed.
Long walk. It is a long walk around the site. It is better to go in the afternoon because it is not that crowded.

Walking tour. Once you reach Palatine hill, go for a guided tour as it is the easiest way to learn about it and to get number of historical facts. Interesting architecture, amazing views, a lot of history.
Well worth a visit!. We enjoyed visiting Palatine Hill as the views are magnificent. The history is awesome and you feel a real sense of the past. Do visit here if you have the opportunity.

So much to see. Palatine Hill is right next to the Colosseum and definitely worth seeing - make sure you walk to the top of the Hill - amazing view of the City - couldn't help but think it was a bit like a salvage yard though ...
Early morning views. Amazing views in a very quiet walk around the hill. We looked round the villas and ruins on the top and down onto Circus Maximus and The Roman Forums below.
Great views. Great views over the city and Roman forum. It's included in the price of the colosseum ticket which on the first Sunday of the month is free.

Intersting Walk through history. We visited Palatine Hill after our tour of the Colleseum, it was a beautiful warm day and the walk through the grounds admiring the ruins and hearing the story behind the buildings was a great addition to the tour.

Extremely huge area and full of artifacts. I went this April with my fiancé and we enjoyed going to the Palatine Hill. It's a wide area and thus require a lot of walking. It wasn't as crowded as the Colosseum when we went on a weekend (Saturday). So we enjoyed the place. Throughout our walk, we were just in awe because the same cobblestone that we were walking on was also where the Roman emperors were walking about 2000 years ago, I thought that its very impressive. Expect to see a lot of artifacts, expect the sun (it can really burn you. I'm tan/light brown and I got burned), and expect walking long distances. Make sure to go to the gardens and enjoy the view (of the gardens and also the view of the city since the gardens are on a higher elevation). I highly recommend.

Wonderful extensive ruins - need good walking shoes!. This was in many ways, the highlight of our Rome trip. We spend a long time exploring these ruins, set in a lovely area of parkland, near to the Colosseum. There is so much to see and marvel at, and it is great for photography. There are boards in English and Italian to explain the history behind the various parts. Well worth a visit and your joint ticket will get you into the colosseum as well.
Interesting and great views. Definitely worth getting a guided tour to cover the main historic facts. It was an interesting mix of architecture, gardens and views,

Amazing wish I had a magic wand. one day will will be offered some kind pf virtual reality gadget to put on before we walk around here and I for one will be up front in the queue on that . Just walk around here and let the old imagination flow no more to say here it is all in the eye and mind of the beholder and I just can't get enough .

Amazing views over roman remains. The gardens up on the hill are gorgeous and the roses smell divine. The view from the terrace out over the colesseum and the roman forum is well worth climbing up for.
Fascinating. Enjoyed a warm day to explore the hill on a Walks of Italy tour. A welcome breeze too whilst viewing the top. A must and recommended for anyone visiting Rome.

Worth the visit. I suggest reading up on the area before walking through it to get the most out of the visit. The history behind the Roman forum is quite interesting and worth the read...I like walking in the rain so even if it is raining and your visit to Rome is not very long, I would suggest to continue to visit it...I am from the NW so rain does not stop me in seeing as much as I can when I travel.

First time visit - last time we ran out of time!. Palatine Hill and the Palatine Hill Museums were on our Must See list for this trip. Rome is such an amazing place and holds so many layers. The Palatine is one such place...
Surprisingly enjoyable. I only went because it was included in the Colosseum ticket, but we ended up wandering around for some time. It was pleasant and interesting.

A historical treasure. I'm just back from my second trip to Rome I'm surprised to see you now pay to visit the hill. A guided tour make sense of it all, so if your going to see the ruins on the hill a guide is worthwhile.
It Just keeps going and going. This place is huge. I walked around for almost three hours. You think it's just small ruins and then you see more and more. Amazing how large the buildings were.
Great views!. Don't miss out on this place in Rome. There are great views from here of the Forum so don't forget your camera!

Palatine Hill in Ruins. We arrived here quite by accident after leaving the Colosseum. It was a beautiful warm day and I would suggest if it looks like being rather warm to take an umbrella with you for shade, or make sure you have a hat. I still cannot believe how old these ruins are. It was very interesting wandering around the ruins and finding out how things worked all those years ago.

Take the time to visit - dry weather activity!. We got a combined ticket giving access to The Forum, The Colosseum and Palatine valid for access 2 CONSECUTIVE days and it was well worth it. You could spend hours walking around, amazing history and great views of the city. Definitely a dry day activity though as its all outside! I'm not sure where The Forum starts/finished and the same with the Palatine! The whole area is just amazing. There are lots of levels and some steep steps in places but there are different entrances so if your not overly steady on your feet please don't feel like you have to miss out there is plenty to see at all levels.

Go with a guide to know the history. I bought the tickets to enter the colosseum and had free acres to both the roman forum and palatine hill. The place is basically the place where the rich stayed in the past. To know more about the structures I highly suggest a guide to explain the rich history if not you be clueless throughout. Was lucky to hear parts of the existence due to guides at diff points that I visited. Definitely need to go to the top of the palatine hall to get a good view of the roman forum.Suggest that u visit the colosseum, exit and head pass the arc de Constantine, go up to the palatine hill entrance which has few people and is accessable by a gentle slope and walk downhill to the roman forum. Most seamless route I reckon.

Include With the Forum. Again this is good to do with a Scholar as you do the Forum. Usually it includes Palatine and Colosseum. Context Travel is a good company as they take small groups not more than 5-6 people so you get the full history of the Forum, Palatine and Colosseum.

Impressive historic site. Walked around the Forum Romanum and the Palatine Hill with a guide. Highly recommendable to do this site with a guide, otherwise you'll just be walking around between lots of buildings and remains of buildings. At the end of the tour we climbed the Palatine Hill. This is a rather steep trip so good shoes are recommended. Not for those who are not very mobile. The way down again in also very steep.

:-). We got to see the palletine free with our colosseum tour. We wouldn't have known about it otherwise. Our tour guide was fab and shared some amazingly interesting information otherwise we would've thought it was just a pile of bricks lol :-)

If you have been to stately homes in the UK or toured Europe, you will see where a lot of the ideas came from!. We took a long leisurely stroll through this are after visiting the Colloseum. There is so much to see. Make sure you have a map and printed guide to enable you to make sense of what is there.

A must if you love ancient history. It seems obvious, but it was still surprising how hilly Rome is. The views from Palatine Hill are remarkable and help put everything into context. An audio guide is helpful here to put the ruins into perspective.

A wonderful trip back in time. It is worth paying the extra to have a guide. Our guide stopped several times along the way to explain the history of what we were seeing and it almost made you feel you were experiencing a step back in history. It is beautiful in itself but the history adds to the experience. It is well worth all the steps!

Very interesting. This takes a few hours but is very interesting and enjoyable on a sunny day, very easy to get lost and miss things while seeing others multiple times! More interesting than its more glamorous neighbour - the colosseum
Very interesting. Beautiful site, a walk through the ruins. Amazing views of Rome,the forum and the colosseum. No queues to buy ticket at this entrance.
When in Rome.... Amazing. Walking around these magnificent ruins is an experience I will never forget. Just visited in April and the weather could not have been more perfect.

Incredible!. This building is huge...no I think huge is not big enough! Totally dwarfs any memorial in the US. Must is the elevator to the top! I believe it was 6 Euro's. Totally worth it! Amazing views

Nothing Exciting. Its basically a big area of roman ruins, there is nothing overly exciting or special and nothing to really explain what you are looking at. You can get good views if you go nearer the top but other than that, we were quite bored to be honest.

Simply wonderful. We visited Palentine Hill after we found the queues for the Colosseum were excessive. Palentine Hill is impressive and we enjoyed the walking and the views a the top are fabulous and well worth the effort

Give yourself plenty of time to explore. Your ticket to the Palatine Hill/ Roman Forum comes with your ticket to the Colosseum. The hill and the forum are in the same area, so once in, you can't come back. I highly recommend booking some sort of tour, as there is so much to see, but it won't make any sense without someone telling you what you are looking at. I downloaded the Rick Steve's audio tour, which was good, but there was still so much more to the attraction that wasn't on the audio tour. (This is free though). I do not understand how people said that they walked through in 5 minutes. There is a whole part of the area that many people simply don't go to, up on the hills. We toured the area for a little over 2.5 hours and still didn't see everything. I can imagine that it's extremely crowded during the summer months, so just keep that in mind. I went in April so the air was cool and the crowds weren't too bad. Also, there are multiple entrances to this. Go to the one to the left of the Arch/ Colosseum, no one knows about it and there is hardly a line there. Everyone only knows about the other two entrances and you will wait forever in line to buy your ticket, then again to get through security. (Again, if you bought your ticket for the Colosseum, then you only have to wait in the security line). I do not recommend this activity if you have trouble walking or have little children.

Not to be missed!. Perhaps one of Rome's most ancient sites. Close to the Colosseum and next to the Wedding Cake ( as Italians like to call it) Gives a real sense of what Ancient Rome must have been like. Oozing atmosphere from a bygone age.
Wear your walking shoes. Although there was a lot of walking... this was a highly enjoyable trek. Get yourself a guide and learn the history of this beautiful area of Rome!!

My husbands new favorite place. We took a tour so we had explanations as we went and it was well worth it. Beautiful, incredible vistas of history brought to life through her words. It would have been amazing to just wander ourselves as well, but with the guide it had an extra touch.
Must Visit. We had a tour that took us through the colosseum and to the palatine hill, we both preferred our visit here, so much history and a very beautiful view!
Nice views from the hill. Lots of neat things to see inside the grounds, but there is a few spots which offer great places to view the colosseum from as well.

500 years of History. We found Palatine Hill more interesting than the Forum itself. It was the seat of power for all the known western world for almost 500 years. You can stand where the emperor sat when he ruled the world. It has better feel of ancient Rome than the Forum. There is also a great view of Circus Maximus. Get your tickets in advance!!!! The ticket covers the Coliseum, the Forum and Palatine Hill. A guide makes it easier to understand and although more expensive a private guide for a couple is very enjoyable.

So much to see and so little time. This was a mind blowing piece of history. Allow a whole day for this one site if you want to see the whole thing and read all the history. We didn't get the audio guides which we should have. Took four hours just o visit half the ruins. Entrance queue wasn't bad if you got there early enough. Truly amazing like the rest of rome.

Must see - Toilet tip, Guide Tip. Go on your own. Tip 1...the toilets at the museum are long lined since they are the first. 5 min from there, at the oversight near the labirant... there are NO LINES.Tip 2 - Take an audio or just read the signs. You do not need a guide here. It is well organized. Do not waste time on guides. Bring a book and take your time. Compared to the colesseum ... this is much more impressive.
Get here with your lens!. The hubs and I wandered all of Rome, pounding cobbles for several days. Palatine Hill and its ruins have a big chunk of our most recent photo book. Get there, snap away.

What It Was... We visited as part of a City Wonders tour and had an incredible guide teaching us about its history and showing us pictures of how it probably looked. It was incredible. To walk in the same footsteps as emperors...literally.

Nice View of the Forum but be Ready to Climb Some Stairs. As part of the combo ticket with the Colosseum, we visited Palatine Hill and the Forum in 1 day. It was fairly warm during the day and there was a not a lot of shade available for visitors. There were not many water closets available either. We happened to overhear a tour guide and we were able to close our eyes and imagine what an amazing place this was during its prime time.
nice place. my humble advice bring your best walking shoes and enjoy the view and let your imagination run wild.

Worth the walk!. An excellent part of our tour that we enjoyed a great deal. Excellent views... excellent condition of the ruins. Lots of great information scattered about (in English) which offered amazing details of what life would have been like in ancient times. Don't pass this up .. lots to see on a beautiful walk

Palatine Hill. You read about it in history class. You've seen pictures and movies about it. Now see the home of emperors, Palatine Hill.. It's worth it. Be prepared to stand in line even if you have bought your tickets on line. DO buy on line because your line is a lot smaller. When you buy your Palatine Hill ticket also buy the ticket for the Colosseum. They are in the same area and your ticket will get you in to both places if you buy it early. Expect to spend the whole day.

Walking in the footsteps of the ancient romans. This place is magical. For a moment I thought I am standing where Nero and Julius Ceasar walked. There is so much to see and take in this area that it is well worth a visit. At least two hours to take in the tour. I really enjoyed it but you do need strong shoes or trainers as the ground underfoot isn't,t always smooth. A tour guide or guide book is a must. Well worth the money.
excellent. amazing-well worth the visit. A true essence of rome. a must do. Located within is a little museum .
Ancient miracle. You'll need comfy shoes and a big memory card :D beautiful view, huge spaces, must see, It's amazing.

Worth climbing to the top. Now this place is a must because once you are off the main axis of the Forum, there is a bit more room to breath. The best part, I find is the Farenese Garden which is a gem of cool and quiet that you'll probably need but also, if you go over to the corner, it is the BEST view of the Forum from above and worth a couple of pictures! It is poorly labeled so you don't really understand what you are looking at without a guide
Nice day. Really lovely, however another busy place in Rome. Great place to get some idilic holiday photos and some nice pics of the colosseum.

Fabulous. Another must see. Do a private tour as there is so much to know and this gets you all the information you need. Not an easy place for wheelchairs and prams. Reasonable fitness helpful. Loved it.

Allow 6 hrs.. Enter by the side entrance away from the Colosseum, on Via di San Gregorio it is usually a lot less crowded. Get a map or lay out there is a lot to see and a lot you will miss if you do not get some direction.

You'll never find your way out of here!. There are no signs for the exit and this is vast place! If you find yourself in this predicament, it's a very small path leading upwards next to the temple on the right with a big bronze door - good luck!

A great view over the Roman Forum. Stunning views over the city of Rome with beautiful gardens and roses that actually have a perfume. Didn't spend too much time here as had so much else to see and only had 2 days to see it. Will definately return to give it the attention it deserves.
Roman History. Saw sights that I had only read in history books. Never imagined that I would set foot to see a part of ancient Rome.

Fantastic. This is a must visit if you have time to after the crazy ques in the Colosseum. The views of the city are fantastic and the history is amazing, this is one of the nicest things to see in Rome. Must visit, 10/10 stars. Enjoy

User your imagination.... We really enjoyed our tour of Palatine Hill. It's easy to imagine what it may have been like to live there and what every day life may have been like in that time. There is an amazing view over looking Circus Maximus. Definitely worth the time!
Palatine Hill. Enjoyed the views from the top. Enjoyed the whole tour and the walking. The orchard was interesting as well as viewing the forum ruins below.

Get a guide (Greg from Gladiator Tours) and hear the stories. Don't hurry past this - there are some incredible stories and great information to be learnt. It also gives you some great views of the ancient city. Lovely on a sunny day.
Prime address for Romans. Another good place to imagine what life was like for the Roman rulers - information in English which is helpful!

The real history before your your eyes. Such a lot to see and take in, it helps to have some sort of guide with details as this gives you so much more than just reading the signs. lots of walking and steps and could be very hot in the summer with no shade.

Wonderful historic site and a beautiful park!. Well worth a visit; there is not very much information without a guide or an audio guide. So if you're into the history I would recommend doing that. However, it's a beautiful place to visit anyway - in April when we visited, the roses and orange blossom were out and the scent, and views (of Roman temples and bulldings, and over the whole city) are divine!

Truly Magnificent!. Stunning, Spectacular, Memorable and Worth seeing (ahead of many other sites).Wear really sensible walking shoes - no sandals/flip-flops and explore history 'at its best'.Ensure you give yourself a minimum of 2-3 hours to explore and if possible, book ahead to gain the insights and understanding of a trained guide - don't pick one up at entry as most haven't a clue what they're talking about, they're simply scamming tourists to 'make a quick buck'.

How did I miss this last time?. I was last in Rome 25 years ago and went to the Colosseum, not realising what was on the other side of the road. Given the choice, I'd take Palatine Hill every time - less manic, great views, and you still get to look down on the Colosseum. The Palatine Hill has the ruins of many of the main buildings from Roman Empire days - temples, houses of the emperors, triumph arches, bits of viaducts - and it's a lovely walk if the day is not too hot. Well worth the €12.

What a nice day out this was. We visited the Palatine Hill after the Colloseum, this was organised by realrometours. Its amazing how so much of this was buried tens of meters under ground after earthquakes and floods.
Immense. Really enjoyed our few hrs wondering here before dinner. Warm but cloudy, easy to view guidebook probably sufficient unless you're a history buff/archaeologist
Stunning views of Rome. Go in the afternoon after the Colosseum and you will be lucky enough to see sunset over Rome. It is breathtaking and exceedingly romantic. Excellent pictures. Lovely Walks
nothing to see. its a garden with really nothing to see.just to take a walk and have a coffee from the machines......

Plan for at least half a day.. There is so much to see here. Magnificent views and its well worth the time to walk to the extended corners of this complex.Take a guide or a detailed guidebook that will explain all the sites as you walk through. There is little relief from the sunshine, so wear sunscreen and a hat! And there are limited public bathrooms on Palatine Hill - the little bathroom in the historical museum was crazy crowded. So, if you can use facilities at the Colosseum or elsewhere - go preemptively like your mother probably taught you!

Recommend you visit Palatine Hilll with the Colloseum. Historic home of Caesar Augustus and other emperors, Impressive site. Recommend you have a tour guide for it, so you know what you are looking at. Really enjoyed it....

A good place to start. Important site, since it is the location of the birthplace of Rome. We found the site itself less impressive than expected, since not much of the palaces which used to stand here actually remained. Nice views of the Circus Maximus, the Forum and the Colosseum. Good place to start the tour of ancient Rome
Interesting. Good views across the forum and around Rome. Museum inside the Palantine to see artifacts and how it developed as a palace

Wow. Didn't expect there to be so much to do and was very happy after discovering we can get in for half price as I'm under 25 WOOOO. Got the joint ticket so saw the colosseum too all of it was very good. Would recommend going

Put on your Walking Shoes. Walking through Palatine Hill offers the chance to see how the Romans lived in antiquity. Wear walking shoes and don't forget your money belt or fanny pack to dissuade the pick pockets. The water from the outdoor Roman fountains is safe for drinking and cold, so re-fill that water bottle often.

An awesome sight : go with time to spare : and a guide. Go with a guide first. This allows you to understand all the buildings/ruins properly. Then, I would honestly recommend lazing around the area for a bit because there really is a lot to see and 'take in'. If you are not interested in history, then it is only a bunch of ruins : but if you are like me, and fascinated with ancient civilisations this really is a gold mine. Read up before you go - and seeing it in person truly is a delight !
Great place to view the city!. One of the seven (or ten depending who you ask) major hills in Rome where you can view the city below. Worth the trip up the hill for the view!

A vast area above the forum.. Your ticket to the Coloseum will cover the Palatine and the Forum. May be better because of queues if you need a ticket to enter here before the Coloseum. The hill is vast and contains ruins of the Imperial palace and early temples and a museum. Allow plenty of time and take water. Gardens were laid out here and there are wonderful places to walk, sit, smell the roses and the orange blossom. Great views of the forum. A must to see.

Yet another must see. We coupled this with our Dark Tours organised trip to the Colleseum. I'm glad we did as we had the same guide (Luciana) who was a font of knowledge for both these sites.Like most historical sites in this beautiful city it has to be visited.

Amazing views. The views over Rome and the Forum from the Palatine Hill are super special, so make your way slowly up there (especially on a sunny day) and enjoy. Clean loos & an ice-cold drinking water fountains.

Lovely views. Well worth the walk after visiting the Collseum for the stunning views. The gardens are beautiful especially the orange trees. Needs to be better sign posted so visitors can understand what it is they are looking at.

Nice relaxing stroll. If you want a nice stroll in the sun this is the place to go. It was beautiful weather when we went, perfect to take loads of pictures. The grounds are huge, with different levels allowing you to look over Rome. You could spend a good few hours here and bask in the city that once was!

Had a half day tour, including colosseum, excellent. So much bigger than I expected. Saw it from the perimeter in a previous visit, this time did a walking tour. Guide was brilliant, and helped us picture every aspect of the people who built it, lived here and recycled it. Wear comfy shoes/ clothes, not much shelter in the sun.
One to see. See how the Romans used to live... Civilised 2000 plus years ago .. spectacular.. One better for a dry day..

Enthralling. This is way more interesting than the tourist infested colloseum across the road, and a lot less busy! But please don't bother to ask the typically arrogant Roman staff who skulk inside their "information" booths anything - you'll most probably be ignored like I was! However, I can't deny that the actual site was absolutely enthralling and well worth a visit.

Amazing!!!!. This was my favorite attraction in Rome! So much beautiful history - you can really imagine life 2000 years ago. It would have been much better with a guided tour and it got hot in the sun (even in April). Wander around and enjoy!
part of a tour - but amazing views. We went up to the top of Palatine Hill as part of a tour. Amazing views all over Rome - not for the faint hearted - but also not that difficult.
Best view in Rome. Wow, the scale of the Roman building work here is breath taking. Give yourself a few hours to fully appreciate the ancient wonders
Beautiful and a must see. Beautiful and breathtaking views.Need to use your imagination as you need to think back how it was like before the ruins. Simply wonderful experience.

Palantine Hill - part of the Colosseum tour. We were able to include a tour of Palantine Hill as part of our Colosseum tour price. Our guide was super knowledgeable about the history of this area which made for a very fun tour. I recommend taking water with you and as with most of Rome, comfortable walking shoes.

Magnificent area with plenty of stories to tell.. Roman Forum + Palatine Hill and Colosseum are usually sold in a 2 day ticket so if you opted for these tickets, come only to the Hill after the Colloseum as it is a huge area and queues are less. There are so much to see and each angle offers a different perspective. If you are financially able, book a guide with reputable company instead of just walking around sightseeing as you will apprecate the place better. I enjoyed my visit here and it is suitable for long walks with family.

Not to be missed - if reasonably fit!. So much to take in over this vast historical site. Indeed, almost too much. Small information boards provide some help for individual items / structures, but much improved interpretation boards should really be considered, which provide better context. Great views over the Circo Massimo, the Forum and the wider city.Needs more than a spare hour to do this site justice. Needs reasonable fitness and surefootedness over some uneven ground, particularly if extending your visit to include the Forum (recommended).

Beautiful and awe inspiring if you knew where anything is. This really was an amazing part of the trip. COMFY SHOES ESSENTIAL!!! I saw some women tripping about the place in their high heels, ladies dont do it to yourselves!! lots of gravely slopes and grassy areas.The only thing that really really disappointed me was that there were no signposts anywhere! Luckily as a complete history nerd I had my trusty Lonely planet guide with me but I still for the most part had no idea what I was looking at! For the love of god please put up some signposts in this amazing place so people can actually appreciate what they're looking at!!!!

does get repetitive and boring but you must see the GARDENS at the top, with orange trees!. after doing the Colliseo we visited this place and it was a little overwhelming as it went on and on, ruin after ruin, the dust on the paths on a windy day meant there were spots were sand flew in our face, be warned. Do not wear white or short skirts, and wear sunglasses at all times.My personal highlights and very welcome break was when we reached steps that let to the top gardens where the smell of orange trees hit us and that was priceless, the trees were in bloom with oranges on them, first time I see orange trees. Lovely views from there too, and much more quiet.

Julius Caesar's Ashes!!!. It's surreal to walk where so many great emperors called home. I highly recommend everyone to walk through with a smart phone to see images of what the grounds would look like when the Roman Empire ruled this land. It's incredible to think that these are still here for us to enjoy after so much time and historical events like wars, the birth of crist and so many rulers. Make sure you pay for a guided tour or have a book that lays it out for you... if you don't have either you won't know how cool everything is.
Fascinating. See how the emperors lived high on their hill palaces. A lovely stroll through the trees. Good museum and Roman relics. See where Rome is thought to have begun.
Breathe history. Try to avoid having your photo taken by swarthy gladiators...but otherwise this is an absolute MUST. It is best to avoid the hottest months of the year to visit it.
Do not miss. A must see. We listened to an audio guide but over heard some tours and if we could go back we would definitely get a private tour guide.
Absolutely favourite place. My absolutely favourite place in Rome, amazing! The view from one of the terraces is stunning! Don't think twice, a must see
Ruins outside the Colosseum. We covered Palatine Hill as part of Colosseum trip since it was right in front it. Good place to cover.

Back in time. If you go to Rome, you need to go to the Palatine Hill, in special with a guide, that will give all the insides about this beautiful place.
Visit the Palatine hill after the Coliseum.

With the Forum. The Forum and Palatine Hill go together. I have been there several times and the tour guide can really make a difference. This last time was with Walks of Italy on the VIP Caesar's Palace tour with Fernando. I highly recommend this.
Palaces galore. this is visited via the Forum and is on the same ticket as the Forum and Coleseum. We had a limited number tour of Augustus' and Livia's Villas which was well worth the effort

Wow!. If you like Roman ruins, this is a must!!!The place must have been immense 2000 years ago. Be prepared to walk up lots of steps, but well worth it when you get to the top. I would not rate this place as disabled friendly. We made the mistake of exiting to find a toilet, then had to pay again to get back in. Please do not make our mistake. Toilets are available in the grounds, but don't expect them to be clean!The admission price includes the Forum. Now that part is truly amazing!!!

Often overlooked by time-pressed tourists. This is worth some quality time.. The 'heart' of ancient Rome. It is evocative more than instructive, simply because there are relatively few undamaged buildings. The open vistas are good and Octavian's house is truly special. Wander, sit, think.
Huge area - must see. Did not really give this enough time as site is so large - at least half a day if not more - a time capsule of time long gone - amazing

It's part of Forum. Palatine hill was once upon a time center of Roman power. Today it has office of Mayor of Rome. However, old empire buildings were destroyed and only ruins remains. It's pity his try got destroyed. Without audio guide you will not enjoy it. It's better not to take guide.

Allow Time - Impessive. Huge area to cover. Some information panels around if you don't want the full guided tour thing. You need at least an hour to see it all. To get out was a bit tricky! The exit isn't sign posted very well. Felt a bit trapped. No where to eat or drink. Take snack. They do have the water fountains though. Need to sit and imagine how it must have been back in its day. Massive. Extravagant. Must pre book your ticket! DONT que! We didn't come across anyone who looked like a pick pocket. HUGE police presence everywhere, which made us feel quite safe.

A must see! . Absolutely incredible!! A must see to fully understand Roman history! I highly recommend paying extra for the guided tour. They sell tickets outside the colosseum. At first I though it was a scam but it was well worth the money!!

Beautiful Views. One of the 7 Hills of Rome. Palatine Hill is where the nobility of Roman society lived. There is an excellent museum on the hill which has good exhibits. You can visit the House of the Emperor Augustus. Great views of both the Forum and the Circus Maximus from the Hill.

A visit to remember. If you enjoy history and have a very good imagination then a visit to the Palatine Hill is to be recommended. It can be tiring on a hot day so take plenty of water. A guide book is handy to make sense of the ancient ruins and the museum on site should not be missed. I suspect that there is plenty underground of interest but sadly not open to the general public.

Impressive ruins. If you can combine a tour of the Palatine with the Forum then you will have a wonderful experience. Great views from atop the Palatine Hill and very extensive ruins - palaces of the Caesars that you have heard of. There are panels explaining the site and also a museum.

Fantastic place steeped in history. This is a large area (with the Roman Forum) and we spent up to 6 hours walking around. It could do with an audio guide. Tickets are cheap and include the Forum and Colosseum valid for 2 days. Cannot do all in one day.
Great walk. Relaxing stroll through history which I enjoyed very much. If it is hot take water with you. There are fountains you can top up with once you are inside.
Nice place. No words to describe how amazing this place, It's the old town of Rome, where this wonderful city started.You should visit it when you go to Rome.

14Euro bargain. Visited the two Museums on the last day of our break glad to say didn't disappoint. I have never seen so many statues in such excellent condition. Overall I think it took us two hours to walk around both parts and as an added bonus you get a superb photographic view of the Forum. 14 euro's each we didn't bother paying an extra 5 fir the audio guide. Well worth a visit if you have time to kill.
Euro Honeymoon . Have your good walking shoes on! I used a tour guide for a Colosseum and Palatine Hill tour. It was very good. Informative and the scenery is just spectacular.

Amazing, must see.. What a beautiful place, we really enjoyed it the views were amazing and obviously all the history and the old ruins. There was alot of trees and quite few olive trees. Its best to wtart with Palatine Hill then go down to the Form, as it will be tiring to clim up all those stairs.

Emperor's view & Ancient Rome. This is the heart of the Rome of the Emperors. We wandered along the multiple path of this beautiful park filled with ancient ruins and extraordinary traces of the past. Columns, sculptures, triumph arch, even the traces of an ancient prehistoric village that probably was once home to the legendary Romulo and Remo. Once up on the hill you can have a beautiful view all over the capital of the ancient world. The walk is not hard, the walk on the hill is mostly in the shade (thanks to the pine trees). Bring with you some water, and most of all take your time, no one wins a medal when reach the top. Pay attention to the the ground once wondering in the upper plane, sometimes beautiful marble patterns arise from the ruins!

Beautiful view. Wonderful view of Roman forum and Colosseum from Palatine hill. There is a small garden/park, where it is nice to sit, relax and have a cup of coffee. It's really worth to visit this place. I think, I loved the most Palatine hill in Rome.

The essence of ancient Rome. What a difference a few decades makes! The last time that I was here, the Palatine was almost unvisitable, with just a few paths meandering among chunks of bricks sticking out of the ground. The excavations have turned this into a wonderland of Roman palatial architecture, giving the visitor a sense of awe at how these Roman leaders lived! The Museum has some excellent exhibits, and should not be missed. The houses of Augustus and Livia were particularly interesting, compared to the palaces of the later Emporers. It's a bit of a tough visit, with lots of stairs and hills, but well worth it to see the heart of Roman power.

Layers of history. Amazing place, layers of Roman history built on top of each other. Easy to access even with security checks. A very interesting few hours. Also, good value if you buy the ticket online as its included in the colosseum entry.

Quite a steep climb but worth it. The Palatine Hill is included in the ticket for the Colosseum. It overlooks The Forum on one side and Circus Maximus on the other. It is a bit of an uphill climb to the top but it is worth it.

Heart of the ancient world. Take a tour to fully appreciate not only how important this once was but how impressive. It looks great now but only a small fraction of it remains. A 'must do' if you truly want to appreciate the vast and varied history of Rome.
Cool but tired. This is included with your colosseum entry ticket. It's cool to wander through and look at but I felt it was more of the same rather than anything spectacular

Great views of Ancient Rome. We were taken to the Palatine Hill at the end of our tour which had shown us the Colosseum and the Forum. You get fantastic views of the city from up here. I stopped for a while and thought how, 2000 years ago nearly, many of the buildings in view had stood, as part of a civilisation, while we in England were, (I am led to believe) comparative savages!

Gorgeous views, worth the trek!. Palatine Hill goes along with the Colloseum and Forum, and is worth the walk up the hill. You get incredible views of Rome, and there aren't too many people up there with you, so you can enjoy it in relative peace.

Amazing history and amazing views of acient Rome. This area is all part of ancient Rome (Roman Forum, Colosseum) and must be experienced. There is a tremendous amount of walking for all of this so be prepared. Read about the area before you go so that you have an idea of what you are looking at. Well worth the time.

Wish I'd made more time to explore. It's a vast site and you should leave at least an afternoon to do Palatine and Colosseum justice. We left it till 4pm and 3 hours just didn't do it justice. I wish the hill had more images. Some pictures around the buildings of how it could have looked.But otherwise a super place for children to roam, and what an incredible place.Other reviewers do the site more justice.Go, even if it's just for the view looking down on the Colosseum.And if you didn't read before for some reason, decent shoes. Which applies to Rome central regardless.

Probably my favourite place. This was a more than pleasant surprise! I went to the Forum first, in an entrance further away from the colosseum, off the main road. No queue at all and they didn't even ask to look inside my small bag. The queue at the entrance by the colosseum was huge and lots of security checks. As it was the second place I went to after getting my Roma Pass I was able to walk straight in without any queue for tickets either. The Palatine Hill is part of the same area and you can just walk between the two. This entire area I absolutely loved. So many different parts and things to see. I spent hours here. Even on a boiling, busy afternoon there were areas that were quiet and peaceful. It was hard to believe you were in the middle of Rome!I'm so glad I came here by myself and NOT as part of a tour for my first visit. I just had all the time I wanted to explore and appreciate things. There's no way I would have had such a wonderful experience on a tour, even with a good one. I actually came back for a second visit with a tour, which was interesting and I learnt more about the areas, but it didn't compare to my first solo visit. There are toilets around and drinks machines, although I'd suggest just filling up a bottle with water from the free drinking fountains that are around. You could easily spend a LOT of time here so take comfortable shoes! I can't recommend this place highly enough.
Great History. Took a tour and found out a lot of histroy about this place that I didnt know before, this place is where Rome started .. you must book a tour to understand how did it start

Historic oasis in the Roman hustle and bustle . We went through the Forum to the Palantino on a day ticker cover dying the Colloseo and after the over hyped latter the older ruins were a calm and beatific delight.

This should be your first stop when coming for Colosseum and Roman Forum. First of all this place is packed with history as the rest of the area, well as the rest of Rome to be precise. Having this as a starting point for Colosseum and Roman Forum is for two reasons. First of all there usually is a smaller queue here, we had none. Secondly, by working yourself to the top of the Palatine hill will give you a great overview of the Roman Forum and you can end up by the exit close to Colosseum afterwards. Palatine is green and filled with connecting historical sites linked to the rest of the area. A few challenges with a baby stroller, but not to much as to put us off.

Worth your time for the views alone!. I recommend going with one of the tour groups that will accost you when you leave the metro station. We had a fantastic guide who really helped us understand the history and archaeological processes of what we were seeing. Without that, the hill is just another pile of old Roman rubble. The views from up top are tremendous. Although the site has several ramps for wheelchairs and strollers, I saw people really struggling with both and would not recommend the place for anyone with wheels.

Not a short trip!. This historic sight is worth several smaller trips. In order to really absorb and appreciate these ruins, see it from many angles. And make sure you bring snacks! Don't be talked into a "30min tour" by a local. What a disservice to your senses!

History,History,History.. We had an American guide called Matt. He was absolutely fantastic! In the previous reviews, I forgot to mention, if you paid 5 Euros for the guides to each place. It is so worth it. As mentioned we did the colosseum, and the Palatine hill and the Roman Forum with the guides 15 Euros altogether. Palatine hill has a museum and wonderful ruins at the top. Still surviving, the Architecture is stunning. The top of Palatine as said, there is a museum, but during the 1930s, Mussolini actually lived in the house. Well worth a guide and the visit.
Don't miss it!. You can't visit Rome without visiting the place the city started. Again a guided tour is recommended and don't go on a rainy day as you'll miss so much. Terrific.

Palatine Hill. Palatine Hill is a great place to explore. We went in the spring when the weather was perfect for strolling the grounds. There is a nice breeze up there as well. The ruins are interesting. Remains of an upper class neighborhood, with fountains, columns, frescoes, patches of marble floors, and a museum. There was also plenty of green space for kids to run around or relax from all the walking.
A chance to experience Ancient Rome. A chance to experience Ancient Rome. With our guide giving us insights into the what, where, when and why, he really made it come alive.

So much to see. I always enjoy Palatine hill. It has so much to walk around and see. And every bit is fascinating to a history buff like myself. The still standing architecture is interesting and to picture the places major decisions were made is amazing.

Ancient Rome in all it's glory. Part of the Forum Area. Walk on roads and paths trod by the emperors from Caesar onwards. Best views of the Forum itself are from the Palatine Hill.
Beware that it can be very hot at times so bring water with you as it taks some time to fully explore

very atmospheric. managed to spend quite a while here on a lovely sunny day. Quite crowded but because of the amount of space it did not feel too bad. There are signs dotted around telling you what is what but it probably helps to have a basic understanding of what the area was used for before you go otherwise you are just looking at a pile of stones.It was very good value as the ticket we had purchased for the Colosseum also gave us entry here and the Forum avoiding further queues.We entered at the farthest gate along the street beside the Colosseum and this then flowed into the Forum when we had finished.It's amazing to think you are walking in the exact foot steps of the ancient Romans.

love Palantine Hill. If you ever travel to Rome , Palantine Hill is a must see. So many ruins left standing of a city of such grandeur. Just the size of it is unbelievable. Walking through this area of so much history of past Roman times. Would have loved to have seen it hundreds of years ago, just amazing.

Ancient museum under the open sky. Palantine Hill is a unique place as it it so well saved and spread out on a large territory. I hope you will have a good guide, who will dive you in all the historical legends connected with this place, but our guide was not the best one, unfortunately. However, this place is definitely worth visiting.

Amazing ruins. Went as port of a fairly large group, but still had excellent explanation of history. This and the Forum are almost unbelievable in their expansiveness and complex structures. Worth the considerable walking that is required if one is to see everything!

Great Views. It helps if you do your research before visiting this attraction or take a tour as not much is self explanatory. The signage has very brief descriptions. Irregardless it is a beautiful location and is a tour that is complementary to the standard Coliseum experience. There are great views but be cautious towards closing time as the custodians begin closing off sections and you can have a little trouble finding an exit that gets you were you want to end up.
Awesome. Easy to imagine what it was like in ancient Roman times as some of the building and structures are still standing. We spent quite a bit of time exploring.

Fragrant gardens. The roses and wisteria add a pleasant fragrance on the Hill as you walk towards the expansive platform that offers the best views of the Forum below. The Palatine ruins are not nearly as impressive as those of The Forum but they are worth a stroll. The museum of artifacts from the site is rather boring (excepting an exhibit which shows the layers of pottery shards discovered at the site, each representing a different era of civilization).

Worth a visit. I must say that I didn't know a great deal about Palatine Hill until my visit (embarrassing to admit) but it is obviously a very important historical site. There are some great things to see here and it also offers amazing views in some parts. There is a bit of walking to do to get around the site but it was worth it.
Great. Spent a lovely day here. Really blows your mind the sheer scale of things! No ques and nice and easy to just wander at your own pace as long as you like
wonderful. this was a great place to tour for several hours. the views were wonderful. It was very sunny, so were sunscreen.

Peaceful. If you are doing the Forum and Palatine in one day make sure you dedicate enough time so you aren't rushed. This area is so peaceful with benches placed throughout to sit down and take it all in. Be sure to wear comfortable shoes as it is a little bit of a trek to the top.

Interesting. We had a guide take us around in a large group, a multi lingual guy, full of fantastic stories, he was great from 'Gladiatours'. Its an amazing place, but you need a guide, otherwise your just walking around ruins not knowing what anything is, the history makes a huge difference
Amazing!!!!. Went with a tour to Palatine HIll (The Roman Guide) and was amazed by the beauty of the area. Loved the architecture and learning so much about Rome. Do not miss this site!!!!

Palatine Hill - Interesting history lesson. Enjoyed this area very much. There is a lot to see. It is much bigger than you would expect. Save enough time to see this along with the Colosseum. More history but more of a variety.
So amazing. It's a great place to go. Go late afternoon, it was pretty empty and we had lots of time to explore and not full of crowds.

Huge Historic Value. The home of the Roman emperors - this is an amazing tour taking in all the ruins and the orange garden on Palatine Hill. The tour guide (and I would recommend taking a guided tour) was not only very knowledgable but fun too. There is plenty to see and loads of photo opportunities so make sure you have enough battery life in your camera - I didn't!
Beautiful views, a must do. If you're in the area this is a must do. It's free with a colosseum ticket as well, great views to sit and watch the world go by.

Roman History and Architecture with amazing views. The views sitting atop Palatine Hill are amazing. One can see the Collosseum, the Roman Forum and the Vatican all atop this breathtaking point in history.

Very interesting. As others have stated, go with a tour to really get the most from your visit. Do the forum, colosseum, and palatine tour as it really fills in the picture through both Roman mythology and archaeological findings.
good visit. this is very close to the colosseum. it gives a fair view of the colosseum and surrounding area. it is also near the roman forum. its a good to visit place

Bring COMFY shoes. This place is MASSIVE! bring comfy shoes as the cobblestones all over made my feet really hurt. Interesting ruins that are completely different from the other buildings one usually sees in european cities.

Great place to wonder around. The hill overlooks the Forum and you need to buy an entrance ticket to the Forum to be able to get here.The hill is actually quite expansive: more than it looks on the map. It's a great place to wander around, with so many old ruins all around and nice paths to explore. We visited in early April, and therefore caught some nice flowers and blossom in the trees. There is actually an interesting museum tucked away in part of the hill which has toilets too. If you wanted to explore the Palatine Hill in depth, you could easily spend three hours wandering around. The highlight for me was the wonderful view of the Forum.

the views here and history are devine. This was part of the Colosseum tour ($25 euros) where after the tour we passed by the Constantine arch, on to Palatine Hill and Roman forum... fantastic history lessons; Palatine Hill is surrounded by endless ruins, centuries old pillars, what look like part of a huge open piazza (patio)... wonderful if you're a history lover and can see what this place was like centuries ago... Tour guides were wonderful too!
Fascinating. Fascinating look at the ruins of what used to be a town including apartments Go with a tour (that includes other sights ) so you know what you're looking at

All part of the Roman experienced!. You can't visit the forum without also doing the ruins of the palatine hill. On entry we got an audio guide but signage not too clear and we certainly didn't do things in order. My audio guide was clearly faulty and kept going off. My son's was fine and actually you can get by sharing so don't buy two! Info prob too much for our needs so not suitable for young children. Remains are amazing in places so plenty to see. I enjoyed forum better on balance.

Intriguing. Because so much was lost over the years, I think it would greatly benefit this site to have a 3D reconstruction shown somewhere. The views from the top are amazing, and the museum is nice.

City inside City. Get yourself prepared if you want to really enjoy this tour. Alternative is to get some guided tour. There are so many interesting details all spread around a big area. You can finish the tour either very short or very long. Roman Civilization is so close to you if you really want to discover.

Nice place after the Colesseum. Virtually next door to the Colosseum the Palatine Hill was one of the must see sights of Rome and how the Romans lived. Lots of picture opportunities wherever you turned
Amazing place. A must visit place, great views. Just leave enough time as there is plenty to see. Bring a hat for the sun and some water as you won't be able to get any inside
