Cannot be missed, but bring you imagination (and a mobile/tablet with a guide).. These are the bones of Ancient Rome at its heyday; one of the most impressive civilizations at its time. The ruins are rich with history, the arches tell the stories of conquest, oppression and plunder, the doorways hint at stories both known and unknown.If you have any interest in Ancient Rome, this attraction absolutely cannot be missed. The more you know about Rome beforehand, the richer your experience will be. I downloaded a guide before visiting, and together with Google, had a wonderful experience.If bringing small children, I would NOT recommend a stroller. A baby carrier will be much easier, as there are broken and stony paths. There will be a fair amount of walking here, and it is mostly uncovered.

Amazing! So much history!. Don't miss it - you'll have a fantastic view from the top onto the Foro Romano & the Vatican. Also, the ruins of what was once a powerful empire will impress you, but you need to read some history before visiting the place.

A Must See Tour Along with Roman Forum!. Toured with Dark Rome (City Wonders) and was treated to the Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum. Without the wonderful guides provided by City Wonders, we would have missed out on much of the background that these sites offer. This is a must do for all tourists.
Worth a Visit. Used this option as one of our free options to visit on the Roma Pass. Looks better than the Colosseum to be honest, more to see and took us half a day to get round.
History Buff's Dream. Sit down, close your eyes and imagine what it would have been like when it was in use. It makes you feel quite insignificant, putting your life into perspective.
Wonderful views of Rome. Well worth the climb to the top to experience the wonderful views. Take your time and have a good look around. You will not be disappointed.

History buffs dream! . Palatine hill is out of this world... The amount of history, culture and ruins are astonishing. I would highly recommend a guided tour here as there are not enough signs or information to take it all in properly. If you want to get a sense of Ancient Rome you need to visit here! It's beautiful and interesting and just a must do on your list if visiting.

The best view of Ancient Rome. I visited Palatine Hill as part of my Colosseum and Ancient Rome Tour which is a great way to see the site as the different aspects of it are explained.Upon Palatine Hill were the orange trees are gives you the best view across the Roman Forum and looking right towards the Colosseum - give yourself time up here to admire and appreciate what lies beneath you.
amazing sight. you can see all this by strolling along the streets about without paying - fantastic sight - if you wish you can pay and walk amongst the buildings

Absolutely knackering!. Enjoyed a warm march afternoon on the hill, amazing views worth climbing the hill for, theres some strange folks on rooftops though! Museum up top was bit disappointing, but bottom stuff was more impressive
Rome 2016. Well worth seeing- so much history, the guide was included in the Colleseum tour but you needed it to explain the history surrounding it all- amazing place
Worth the time if you have it...but not a must see. Depending which gate is open to the Forum, the Palatine Hill comes into play more than not. Personally, its overrated!

So much history!. Worth walking up the hill to see the Palatino - many structures to look at and the view of Rome is exceptional! There are some information boards around. The main parts of the Palatino are major Roman buildings from 2000 years ago, but if you walk far enough around you come across buildings from 600bc and older, which makes you realise Rome was once just a small village of farmers.

Absolutely amazing. There is so much to see here you really need a guide to make the most of it. Luckily we had booked a private tour which included The Roman Forum & The Colossuem. It was torrential rain when we went but we still managed to enjoy it. A fascinating day!

More views and a chance to touch an amazing civilization long ago. Palatine hill is a nice walk up through gardens to visit remains of expansive structures and the arena. Spending time here provides a bit of a window into what life might have been for the ancient Romans. There are inside exhibits that are quite nice and we would recommend taking the time to see them. However most of the things to see are outside, good walking shoes are a must.
Well worth climbing 150 or so steps. Interesting, worth doing a guided tours that you what everything is. Amazing to think what you see is so olf

Probably need a guide of some sort. I won’t be at all surprised if some disagree, but if I had to cut something out of my itinerary, this would be one of the things. The plaques weren’t very informative or interesting. I imagine that an interesting tour guide might be worth the investment, or at least an audio guide. Sadly, Rick Steves didn’t make an audio guide for this place!
A wee gem. Only went here to buy a ticket to get me to avoid the queues at The Colliseum, glad I did though. Cracking place, views amazing

Extraordinary view. The place is amazing, the ruins and a fairly good weather will make the trip something to remember. Prepare for a couple of hours to view everything, and make sure to have an umbrella and good walking shoes, as the terrain can get rough and if you catch heavy rain (like i did), you wont get out of there smooth and dry :) Dont forget to reach the highest point on the hill for a good panoramic photo, and you;ll get yourself some great memoriesYou have free entry if you already purchased the Colosseum ticket, so make sure you visit the ruins after checking out the Colosseum; it would be a shame to miss it

A hill with a view.... The hill above the Forum Romanum on one side, and the Circus Maximus on the other side and beside the Colosseum. On top of Palatine Hill you can find the remains of the House of Agustus, Tiberius and Domitian.

Very interesting.... but wear walking boots. the whole site is really interesting - it's amazing what has been preserved and what is known about it. It is spread over a large area and is hilly - we went on a rainy day and would have benefitted from wearing walking boots. It was really hard to find the toilets- right in the middle of the site in the museum- and not the cleanest of places. Well worth the money though and recommend the ticket also covering the Colosseum
Simply beautiful. We were taken away by the history and the beauty of this place. It is just breathtaking surrounding. Great location to take some wide shoots of the city

Roman Ruins in the heart of the city. We were walking along Da Vinci Museum when i stumbled upon this site and i was weak to my knees, i never see that coming in the midst of the busy cars and buses. This is an amazing site needed to be tend by the tourist board since it says a lot about the history and any ruin is always an attraction.

Simply Amazing. Was not sure what to expect when visiting and we were blown away with what we found.The ruins are so extensive its hard to describe. This has to be one of the best places to visit in Rome

It's a hike but if I can do it anyone can!. Amazing walks through history and the views from the top are fantastic, top tip for travellers, entry to the Palatine Hill and the Forum is free the first Sunday of the month. However, I would not mind paying for this anyday, we were just fortunate that we were there the first Sunday.

Walking in History. What an amazing place to visit! Reading about ancient Rome all through school is one thing, but seeing the ruins of what was once a powerful empire is a once-in-a-lifetime experience! We went on the first Sunday, so admission was free (still need a ticket; we got ours across from the Colosseum, and it was good for the Hill, Forum, and Colosseo).It may not be the greatest place to visit in the rain, as it had rained the previous night, and there were still quite a few puddles despite the sunny skies. But in all honesty I would still trek through it, because it's a sight not to be missed!
Bring water!. Nice walk with beautiful views and a lot of history. Be prepared to walk in rough terrain. Bring some water and a nice camera.

A great sense of history. A load of old ruins on a hill? No once you start to walk around this site you get a feeling of the thousands of years of history that you are treading on. We had a guide book and you can see how the elite would have been living before crossing the road to the Colosseum for what ever was on that day.How each Caesar added his own touch and how it grew and in the words of Python what did the Romans ever do for us!All I kept thinking was how much of the architecture is still so similar to today but I suppose if it's not broke don't fix it.A great way to pass a couple of hours walking in the footsteps of all the famous people in history have trodden

History spirit with lack of information. Place is wonderful but it could be better if it was well organised. Maps, directions, anything.... We weren't told that area will be closed in about one hour. And one hour is not much. You must know that there opening hours depens on sunset but to be honest - who checks what time sun goes down.When they are closing you should go pretty fast and don't look around because men with whistlels gonna whistle at you ;/

Step into the past. What a great place to see a ton of Roman ruins, see some great views and see how Romans lived many years ago. Be sure to take in the sites, read the material and have good walking shoes. It is well worth the entrance fee. We were there in Feb. and the line didn't take long to get through.
Needs a guide. It is defenately a place you should visit with a good guide only, otherwise it is just a bunch of stones. Same, maybe even more so, goes for forum romanum
Amazing place to see. This is a place I would definitely recommend great walk to see all inside again a roma pass gives you free access.

The best. Place to see, place to be! Really, if you are looking for history, a place that breaths humanity go there! Walk at the bottom and wander around the statues - it is just an incredible experience!
A beautiful vantage point. The very heart of Roman civilization - a must see location. Museums, government buildings, church and an incredible view of the Roman Forum.
A view into Roman history. This place even in ruins portrays the majestic structures that would have been in all splendor at the center of the Roman empire.

Cremation Site of Julius Ceasar. It was a challenge trying to imagine all that happened here. There was the Roman Senate, the Square, shopping, eternal flame, and the cremation site of Julius Ceasar. Yes, Ceasar was cremated and his ashes scattered about in front of the little temple erected in his honor . Many of the structures have given way to time and the elements, but our tour guide did an excellent job helping us understand the history and glory of the Hill.
Get a guide and go. This was brought to life by our wonderful tour guide. Go here and then the Coliseum or vice versa. Its just a short walk between both.

Very interesting! Included with entry into Colosseum. After touring the Colosseum, we ventured to Paletine Hill. Commanding panoramic view of the Colosseum, Capitoline Hill and the Roman Forum. Citrus trees burdened with fruit, wild parrots and many tourists add to the intrigue here.
A lot of history. We took a tour around Rome and it took us here as well, so much history that I still cannot comprehend. A worthy visit to all those who visit Rome.

No exits!. Well worth the experience. Need to get the head set tour, we didn't. No everything is marked. Place is huge, and one bathroom found, one exit found. Felt like a rat in a cage. Need more exits, bathroom, signage and maps.

My favourite place in Rome. You would have to be clinically dead or have no imagination not to enjoy the Palatine Hill, which was the home to the Roman elite and emperors for hundreds of years and the view down to the forum is just magic. Shut your eyes and you are back in ancient Rome. It is also quite quiet and peaceful.

Lovely walk and museum. Lovely walk over Palatine Hill with tremendous views of the Forum and central Rome. Great to soak up the ancient history, visit the ruins and visit the museum. When we went the entrance wasn't very well-signposted from the Colosseum and lots of people headed up a hill in the wrong direction and had to re-trace their steps, so it may be worth double-checking the directions to the entrance when buying a ticket.

Part of the Rome experience.. Peaceful and nice to hear birdsong whilst imagining how Romes rich lived.I must admit that I was underwhelmed initially as it wasn't until we walked down to the Roman forum that I realised that I had actually been walking "on it" and could see it properly.Magnificent.

Amazing lots to look at get your Colosseum tickets here. Get your tickets at here for Colosseum and Palatine hills as all 3 sites are included in the price of 12 euros and the queue is much shorter here about 20 minutes than at the Colosseum which even in March I think was at least 300 people long! The Palatine hills area is fantastic I didn't know what to expect but it was full of history walking in the steps of the Romans and views from the top were great across Rome and Colosseum. March was a nice time to visit less crowds and plenty of time to walk about the ruins we were very lucky with weather blue sky's and warm for March. The Colosseum is a 5 minute walk from here and I actually enjoyed this more than the Colosseum.
Guided tour with Matt. Huge amount of space and facts to absorb but brought to life with wit and care by taking this tour. Thank you!

great for light sunny days, not so much for hotter days. An arena of history ! Things happened here, and famous rulers and common people walked these very paths. The historical complex of buildings (most of them ruins now) offers exciting itineraries for visitors of all interest levels: casual selfiers to history buffs. Also contains an interesting museum housing interactive exhibits on the evolution of Rome from prehistoric to modern times.

Palatine Hill. We did a combination tour of the Colosseum along with the Palatine hill. The company we used was Dark Rome Tours. They were excellent. I would recommend you tour Palatine Hill in combination with the Colosseum
Amazing Views. You overlook the whole city from this vantage point. The views are spectacular Don't forget your camera

Fascinating . Went to the Palatine hill on an organised trip and it was great. Such a huge fascinating place with lots of history. I would recommend going with one of the tour guides ( we used Real Rome tours) and the in formation the guides give you is superb. Walk from the Coliseum end up and over hill and down to the forum at the end would be the best way to see it .

Take a walk. While you are at the coliseum take a nice walk up the Palatine hills ruins area. This area of town offers some of the oldest ruins of Rome. Majestic columns that once supported buildings now stand alone in solitude of what once was. Grave yards adjoin the area as well for those who may want to adventure in. The area to the south is visible from atop to what was Circus Maximus, site of chariot races immortalized in the movie Ben-Hur.
Vito tour guide fantastic. we went on walking tour of palatine hill and augustus caesar house.vito was our guide. he was extremely informed and interested. he customized to tour to our interests.

Included in the cost of the ticket otherwise would not have gone. It was included in the cost of the ticket for the Colloseum. Very old ruins, just not my cup of tea. Very little information as to what it is you are looking at.
Huge. We bought tickets here for both the colliseum and palatine. It was great value as there was so much to see. We had a great day and we're impressed by the Roman's engineering skills
Fascinating. A fantastic view from the top onto the Foro Romano and the Vatican - well worth the climb. Lots of shaded areas to sit in the shade.

A fabulous place of history that should not be missed by a visitor to Rome. We had visited the Palatine in 2009, but without sufficient pre-reading about it and the Forum at the bottom of the hill. This time we had done our research, the weather was better and we covered parts that we hadn't seen previously or identified on our earlier visit. We started at the entrance near the Colosseum, walking past the Aqua Claudius to the remains of the Palaces of Domitian, Septimus Severus and Augustus, including part of his garden. It is also the best place for a view of Circus Maximus which is quite disappointing from ground level. A highlight is the Palatine Museum which house many artifacts, including frescos from Nero's Golden House. We didn't take a tour as most areas are well sign posted and this just built on our pre-reading.

The Coliseum's ignored but much superior sister.. It's one ticket entry for both, and the line to get tickets to Palatine Hill tends to be much shorter than the Coliseum. You should budget more time here than next door, at least twice as long to really wonder around the hill and see the incredible palaces. The ruins on the hill are in better shape than the Forum below, but it's all really incredible. I wish I had taken a sandwich or something, we eventually left because we were hungry but I would have loved to have just had a quick picnic and continued exploring the area for longer (the tickets only allow single entry unfortunately, but I guess that's necessary given the crowds).
Difficult to find the entrance. Worth the visit, but entrances are not well marked with the old ruins. Make sure you have a map! Otherwise you may get turned around.

WOW WOW WOW. You just cannot appreciate the sheer scale and interest of this place. No photo or film will ever do it justice. It was pouring with rain the day we spent there but still didn´t dampen the impact and enjoyment of the place. Whether you´re a lover of history or architecture or not you cannot fail to be impressed. We could have spent a week there and still not taken everything in.

amazing views over the forum and coloseum. fair bit of walking uphill but well worth the effort make sure you have water, the view over the forum is fantastic and definitely gives you a perspective of the amazing structures built by the ancient romans

So much history. travel back in time with a guided tour which is what we did as part of the Colosseum tour. You learn so much about the history, the lives of the people which bring the ruins to life. Well worth it.

For History lovers. If you are a history lover this is an amazing activity. We did it on a tour but you can do without but it seems like you get so much information while on the tour. The ruins are really amazing. If you have mobility problems this is not a good activity for you since you are mostly climbing the hill. I would do this again if I ever get back to Rome.
Some fabulous views. Feels a little cluttered with randomly placed artefacts but we'll worth a visit. Fantastic views from the top of the hill.
History in the making. Worth visiting while in rome it was part of our Omni pass and we were not disappointed would visit there again
Neat old ruin. We found this while walking around looking for the Coliseum and it was very interesting. We d don't go in, not sure how f you can buy it is clearly a very old ruin and very big.

A view from the top. We booked ahead and missed both the queues and were able to get onto a tour with just a handful of people - a worthwhile action. The guide was very informative and multilingual but definitely knew her topic for as we ascended the hill through its many terraces the whole area was put into perspective. I would certainly like a plot like that! The highlight though had to be the view looking down across the ruins and across to the Trajan Market where we had been just hours earlier and wondered how we got to such a view point.

Quintessential View of Ancient Rome. No where is there a more breathtaking view of Rome. The Palatine was the center of Ancient Rome. While standing there and gazing at the sights, just think of the history that took place there
Fascinating area. It does not look much from the road but once you get up there it is amazing. Don't worry if you don't like steps, there is also a slope which is a bit longer but not so tough
Amazing. I was memorable visit to Palentine Hills. I was amazed to go back in history by thousand years! One can spend a whole day here

So peaceful. The grounds are massive so wear comfy shoes! The main entrance was pretty busy but once you get past that it's so quiet and peaceful, you can take your time wandering around the grounds and they are truly fascinating. Definately worth a visit, just to get away from the busy streets.

Totally bizarre to think how long this has been here.. After beating the que's and visiting the colossium we rambled around this area and up the Palatine Hill. So many places where temples, waterfalls, once where which I didn't know about until reading the scattered information boards around the place. I do think there could of been better signage for a route to take as we seemed to just walk about all over the place. Breathtaking to stand and think of what things used to be like.

Vast!. We really enjoyed Palatine Hill,which is included in the combined ticket for the Colosseum and Roma Forum as it is really vast and gives you great views.There is lots to see and some very informative boards to help understand the ruins and areas!

Wow!. So much to see! We had a tour guide (part of a Colosseum tour) and it was definitely worth it to understand everything we needed to about historical Rome! The site is huge and there is plenty to see! Leave a good couple of hours to visit this and read all the info on offer - such an interesting place!
Weather makes a difference. We tried to do this with the Colosseum but weather was poor. Found ourselves skipping parts in order to seek shelter and food

A good walk up a hill. Heading towards the colosseum we decided, due to the rain to leave that to a nicer day. Do we headed up Palatine Hill. It's a good climb and you see some very historical sites. We did not enter the chapel at the top as it was a Sunday, but it would probably be worth doing if you find the time.

Another part of Rome that's worth a visit!. There is plenty to take in when visiting Rome, and this is another area that I think is worth a visit. It's worth buying a guide book that gives you an idea of what the place was like when it was built, and then use your imagination! Just amazing.It's a great area to walk around, there is plenty to explore. It will give you some some good views over the City and loads of photo opportunities! Worth a mooch.

Not for everyone. Great if you learn some history before. The site isn't so clear, and visiting it is actually a waste of time if you don't learn the history before. I would recommend on reading some of the history at the flight to Rome (takes about 30-45 minutes), at least by one of the party, and that would make the site very very interesting. Worth the effort. Not a site for children or shopping animals, but very romantic and pleasant.

Wonderful!. We loved this place ! It was a beautiful sunny day; it seemed the whole hill was alive with light and history. Not to be missed. Get a Roma Pass to avoid the waiting line and get straight in.

Must see. Incredible architecture and shows many phases of builds across a long period. Wonderful to wander up slowly by foot and gradually hear the noise of the city fade.Take your time to wander around the whole area and its a must to visit the small museum at the top
Must see. Go with a guide so he can show you how it look like before it is very sad that the whole place is in ruins. It's a very big place and interesting aswell

Ancient world. It's amazing what people 2000 years ago achieved in here. There's an app called Roman Forum what gives you a virtual reality peak in how the place looked like 2000 years ago - pretty impressive.

A Walk Through the Cradle of Civilization. Preserved structures that are freely accessible to visitors allowing your imagination to run freely as to what it might have been like in historic Rome. The view from the top of Palatine Hill is one of the BEST of Rome and the Roman Forum. It is definitely worth a few hours of hiking and discovery!

So much to see. First visit the Colosseum and then come here, if you're with kids, that is. This is where the emperors lived and loved and worshipped. There are old foundations and ruins, great views and huge monuments. We were there in the winter and there were oranges on the trees and silly seagulls posing for photos. There's plenty to keep kids amused, lots of places to run and hide. It's safe and clean. I wish there were more signs to show the way and to give information, but with a good guide book you can bring the place alive for the little ones. We loved it.
The new old world . Palatine hill plus roman forum plus colosseum , the best experience u can have there, big history small prices

stunning. loved this place, theres so much to see and loads of hidden little bits. its opposite the colleseum and i would have happily spent all my time around here. a few bits weren't open i guess because of the time of year but its fantastic. theres food and drink dispensers on top of the hill too which was quite refreshing! theres a stunning view of the city from the top also
Wonderful!. It was a lovely afternoon we went there the first day we got to Rome, lots of beautiful pictures. We really enjoyed the walk and exploration.
Great. Simply amazing must go and see to actually get a clear idea of what it's like even if you don't like history still worth a look.February 2015.

A perfect place from which to put the other wonders of Rome in perspective .... As you wander around these amazing ruins you can, in turn, see wonderful views of the Coliseum, the Forum and and the Circus Maximus. Standing atop the walls of the now ruined palace it's not hard to imagine yourself in the Rome of old cheering on the charioteers as they raced. The sheer scale of this amazing place is quite overwhelming and it's very well worth a visit. Not being quite so celebrated as the sights you can view from it, the Palantine Hill isn't quite so packed with tourists and is all the better for it. Quite possibly my favourite place to visit in a city full of so much beauty.

Start your visit to the Forum here. The combined Forum/Palatine ticket is excellent value. Go up the Palatine before you visit the Forum as there are magnificent views. Also a very handy "self-bar" in a discreet corner dispensing chocolate bars and little cups of coffee for 1 euro. Very civilised

Make time to visit. We hadn't planned on visiting here during our stay but with free admission with colosseum tickets we wandered up. Thank god we did, it's truly amazing and breathtaking. We were blessed with sunshine so made it even more beautiful. Definitely take an hour or so to visit, it's just unbelievable some of the ruins to see.

Takes some imagination to see the city that Rome used to be. This was near the top of the bucket list for Rome and I wasn't disappointed. It does take some imagination to see what this area was like that was so important in forming Europe.The cost of entry is included if you take the our must see the coliseum. The trail leads down the hill to the imperial forum with buildings and places that are world famous.It would be best to take refreshments with you and spend time soaking in the atmosphere.
loved it. this place is amazing, seriously, the amount of monuments and historical buildings and ruins in there are breathtaking, i loved exploring that place so much

Started at the coliseum . Sign posts to the entry point poor but once found entered at the bottom of the palatine hill. There are no recommendations where or what way to walk so we went left to the furthest point and worked around. It would have been very easy to have followed the signs back to the exit but luckily we found ourselves overlooking the forum and the route down. Covering both palatine hill and the forum took a few hours but for us a not to be missed visit. Luckily we did find a couple of cold drinks machines but be warned if visiting with children there are no other amenities such as toilets.

History overload!. Palatine Hill is fabulous, I really didn't expect it to be so awe inspiring! With so much to look at and experience you could spend hours and hours here then some amazing spots to take photos with a backdrop of the colosseum!

Full of history. Visited here as part of a guided tour which was brilliant, lots of history in this area and found our tour guide was very knowledable on the area and spoke very passionatley about the history which was great.

Do not miss!. Get the RomaPass (at any local Tobacco shop- they are everywhere like a convenience store- look for the large T in front) and enter here for virtually no wait. Breathtaking, as expected. Not overly crowded either, so if there are too many people where you want to be, head here first.

Amazing & huge. This is the most amazing place & included in the cost of the colosseum, so much bigger than you think & you could spend all day here, free to roam at your leisure, drinks machines & toilets do you really can take your time. Signs everywhere so you really can soak u the history

Requires Stamina. It's quite a walk and double check where you should enter. We had to go all the way up after coming out of the Colosseum but the entrance at the top was closed. Allocate half a day to enjoy the Colosseum, the Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum.
Good couple of hours out. A lovely wander round the ruins for a couple of hours, also enjoyed the little museum area. Buy your ticket here rather than at the colosseum and you'll save loads of time.

So much history!. Make sure you do some sort of tour for this! You will want the background information that they provide. Our Coliseum tour included the hill and that worked perfectly. Plan a couple of hours to explore if you interested in history, artifacts or general random statues.

Superb views over the Forum and Rome.. One has to visit the Palatine Hill to see the superb views over the Forum.The whole place just oozes history and it's not long before one is back in imaginary time in this spot where the emperors had their royal palaces and buildings.It's great to wander over the hill and see the ancient ruins and look over the magnificent Forum and other parts of the Eternal City.

Amazing view from the Forum. You can see one of the seven hills of Rome, full still of magnificent buildings. You can go up from behind the Forum, there are stairs that take you up surrounding the hill to your left. You can see the "wedding cake" as Romans call it, the monument to Vittorio Emmanuel and go to the museum and the Church above. Really nice walk. Take the elevator above the Monument to see everything from above.

Pack a lunch. The ticket to get in was but 12 Euros and gets you access to both Palatine Hill (Augustus's home and a great musuem of roman era tiling and sculpture) and the Forum. But there is a plethora to see and as a special present not just in surface area as the Romans continue built over structures. Give yourself 4 hours minimum and that is moving at a pretty brisk clip. Super bonus. Giant roman bunnies. It's funny when you think thru the whole Romulus Remus Wolf legend that there are big sassy rabbits loving it up all over the Palatine hill.
Amazing. Amazing place that will take you back more than 2000 years ago. You will walk a lot, so my suggestion is to use soft clothes and snickers.

A step back in time. This is truly an amazing site to see. Get a tour guide to show you around and explain the entire place to you. It really is very interesting and a wonderful part of any Italian trip. The history is unreal.
Bring a guidebook. We forgot our guidebook so couldn't appreciate the full experience and the sense of history so well :/

Great look over the OLD ROME. You can overlook the old Rome and with a bit of imaginnation you feel if you are really there. Read the signs and the city of ancient Rome and his rich citizens will com eto life
Stunning. A must see while in Rome fabulous trip made great by our guide Maria she was very help ful and knowledgeable we had a great day
Expect to be throwback in time. Ruins of ancient Times well preserved. As you go from one spot to another, you can see and imagine the grandeur of each structure.

A schoolboy's dream come true. Ever since I was a school kid reading Livy and Tacitus I have wanted to visit Rome - although it has taken me quite a while to get there. When the opportunity came up, as part of a rugby trip, I jumped at it - and made a b-line to the Palatine Hill. I was not disappointed - far from it....The Palatine is much bigger than I had expected, with far more ruins to wander through.I could easily have spent a whole day just on the hill, exploring the many ancient palace ruins.I was also incredibly impressed by the price to access the Palatine (with access to the Forum and Colosseum too) - incredibly cheap, especially when compared to prices for historical attractions in the UK.

So much history!. Everywhere you look there's something amazing to see. From the huge buildings, columns and arches to statues and remnants of decoration it is humbling to see what they were capable of building.

Really Impressive. We visited the Palatine Hill from the main road and even we're meters away from the proper place by itself it was really beautiful, you can see all the remains from the main road next to the Palatine Hill route in site and still enjoy the view. If you really love the Ancient Rome history you really need to spend your money for a guided tour, if you are in Rome to have just nice picture, just have a look from the main road as you will still enjoy it.

Great in the sun. Visited the palatine hill as part of the joint entry ticket to the forum and colosseum. Great views and lovely day out when it's sunny. I recommend visiting this attraction 1st as there are no queues to buy tickets at the palatine hill whereas the queues for the forum and colosseum are quite lengthy.

A Step Back in History. This site is covered by your Colosseum entry ticket and is only a short walk away. Ideal to for a quiet stroll around the grounds to take in the ruins and city views after the full on tour of its more famous neighbour.

Bit more signage required!. This is really interesting and amazing that so much has been found/survived and there's still so much more to find I suspect. It could do with a bit more signage to give information. We went in February school holiday and it was quite busy although we only had to queue about 10 minutes to get in and but our ticket but in peak season I imagine that unless you book in advance queues can be quite horrendous! The ticket is combined with Coliseum entry and you can go through a gate into the Coliseum area but you still have to queue for security checks before going into the Coliseum - that is quicker than the ticket queue though!

Historic pleasure. Along with the colosseum this is one of the main attractions for Ancient Rome exploring. A great attraction and value for money. Paid for Colosseum and price included Palatine Hill as ticket was usable for 2 consecutive days. No need for tour guide if you would prefer to just stroll at your own leisure and it is a great place on a nice day. Be prepared for a lot of walking this is a Palace but more the size of a small town. Views are amazing across most of Rome.

Walk, walk and take ancient Rome in. Such a lovely walk in mid-February. The ticket is included in the Colosseum ticket, but also in the Roma Pass (combined with the Colosseum). We never expected to take such a long walk on the Palatine Hill and discover so much history in one place. It's impressive and worth the rather long walk up and down and so on. We could have spend so much more time here, because there was still so much more to discover and explore. Take some water with you. At some point I was craving water like crazy. Towards the end of our walk we found some vending machines and they were a blessing. Don't miss the Palatine Hill. I wish I could go back some day.
beautifull. This is my favorite spot in Ancient Rome. From the top you can see the Forum, which is so beautiful!

Day in Rome. So much to see here it's hard to take it all in sit for awhile. It's a busy place, take a drink and if you happen to need a coffee all the better there are NO rest rooms anywhere you have to use restaurants but they won't let you in unless you are a customer. Other than that set back it's a wonderful city full of history.
Very enjoyable. We really enjoyed wandering around here. Bought our Roman Pass here and used it at all three sites. Exciting to be at the spot where Romulus and Remus were brought up by a wolf.
A Must See. Palatine Hill overlooks the Colosseum and The Circus Maximus area. You can almost feel the history as you walk around the park and take in the views.

A stroll through Ancient Rome. This was the second part of our guided tour, the homes of the Caesars and Senate. Our guide was very informative of the history of how the Palatine had developed over time from the early settlement of Romulus through to the rule of the Domitian. The site of the Palatine Hill and Forum are so large that a good half a day is required to allow enough time to spend walking around. I would suggest that visitors take a bottle of water and perhaps snacks as there are not many hostelries around this ancient Roman area. It is easily accessible from the Colosseo station on the Metro B Line. Wear appropriate footwear.

Great historic site.. Was pleasantly surprised to find that this site is also included on the Colosseum visit. It's only a short walk from the colosseum and well worth the visit. Don't forget to include a visit to the museum.
Surreal. Ancient history is what this is. If you visit the Coliseum you should walk across the street and visit this.

Take your camera. This is a wonderful place to immerse yourself in the history of Rome. We didn't have a guide but used an online app to tell us about Palatine Hill. If your a photographer this is an excellent place to take photos and try different shots. It's not really wheelchair or buggy friendly. A pair of comfortable shoes are a must.

Do not miss this place. Go to the Forum and then up the hill as it is well worth the climb. The views from up here are some of the best in Rome. Also wander around the ruins of the palaces here as they are enormous! One side overlooks the Circus Maximus and you can imagine how frantic it once must have been.

Not to be missed!. We could have spent days wandering around Palatine Hill and the Forum - it's an amazing place. It's €12 for a ticket, including entrance to the Colosseum and it gives you two days to visit both. Absolutely not to be missed.The major problem we encountered was that that unlike most big attractions they wont let you go out to get food and then come back inside after lunch. There's no food inside - just a few vending machines and some water fountains - so you have to either take food in with you or restrict yourself to a short visit. I imagine this would be particularly problematic for people with children. Having said that, they wont let you in with big rucksacks either so taking a picnic might be a bit tricky too.We visited in February so the weather was mild and dry which is definitely the best sort of weather to visit in if possible. It wound't be much fun in the rain and I suspect that in the summer it is fairly unbearable because there's very little shade. The Palatine Hill entrance on Via di San Gregorio is probably the shortest of the three queues but we'd recommend buying a ticket online or using the Roma Pass to jump the queues, especially at peak times. Make sure you have some sort of guide (there's tour guides and audio guides available, but we used a book to guide us round which was quite suitable for what we wanted) because there are very few signs or information boards to tell you what you are looking at.Overall an incredible visit and one of the most enjoyable parts of our stay in Rome. So long as you're prepared for the lack of food and information boards you cant fail to enjoy and we would recommend to everyone.
A must. Joined Angel tour. Small group tour of the historical site. Good guide. The sites are so interesting and full of history.

DON'T BRING A BUGGY. We got the tour from Gladiator tours and our tour guide was Greg. He was very funny and did apologise that we had to go up 144 steps. But we picked up that buggy and we soldiered on and it was worth every step..........AWESOME!!There is no way anyone can go to Rome visit the Forum and not step on the top of this HIll.

So much more than you think. . This is one of the three attractions included with you 12 euro entrance fee for the coliseum. It is massive and you can see great views of the city. The houses are cool to look at. The gardens are pretty and if your lucky you can enjoy the view on a clear day. I was very impressed with this stop.
Spectacular. This place simply showcases the scale at which the Roman kings lived their lives and also helps us laud the roman architectural brilliance
Not to be missed!. Palatine Hill was included in our Colosseum ticket. You need the tour guide...they have so much knowledge and there is so much history. It really is amazing!

the whole thing was underwater. underwater millennia ago...you can see the water lines on some of the buildings and this basin is full of so many fascinating architectural features and monuments. I could have spent the whole day here. Its right next to the Colosseum so if you have a whole day I'd see those two things and have lunch in the area.

Loved this!. Disclaimer: I'm a huge tangible history fan, and that's the main attraction here. We booked a skip-the-line tour of the colosseum and Palatine Hill / Roman Forum. It's a long walking tour, but to be in the middle of some of the most famous Roman landmarks was a treat not to be missed. The Hippodrome (along with it's history), views, Temple of Saturn, and various arches were amazing. Don't miss this, but make sure you have a narrator or guide to help explain the history. It's well worth it. Also, I can't say enough how great the skip-the-line feature is. The line was probably 1 hour to Palatine Hill the day we went, and we walked right in.
Ancient Modernity. I really loved to get to the Palatin with my friend. Near Piazza Venezia, this place is wonderful both day and evening ti spend some time in the middle of Rome.

Looked impressive!. We saw this from other vantage points but having duly bought our ticket - from the ticket offices opposite the huge queue to get into the colosseum and buy your ticket at the entrance which is just stupid- go to the ticket office then literally just walk in- well anyway I digress - it looked great but the Roman people have a weird way with queue! If you go to the colosseum first then walk down to the hills entrance it is a huge queue of people WITH tickets you will join! With this it is better not to have a ticket and join the queue to the left of the entrance which consisted of about ten people!!!If you'd I get in it should be fantastic!!!

Fabulous. We went round the side of the park and queued for 20 minutes to get in - much quicker here than other entrances for this, the Forum and the Colosseum. One ticket costs 12 Euro and covers all three things for 2 days. Dont forget walking boots/shoes as there is a lot of it. It follows on to the Forum below (Palantine is on a small hill) with even more ruins.
Wasn't blown away. My least favourite attraction that we seen. I much preferred the Vatican area of Rome and the Museums and churches
Bigger than anticipated!. The land is huge...so much walking to do but seeing the ruins was amazing. You can get a great view of the city at the very top.

How much history can a Koala bear?. The Palatine Hill is an historical assault on your senses, as if the Colossuem was not enough, to walk through this area that is littered with the ruins of so many historical buildings was something I shall remember for the rest of my life an absolute must do for lovers of history.

Amazing. The tickets to the Roman forum and palatine hill were included in the price of the tickets for the colosseum. It's amazing to see what the Romans achieved! The variety of buildings the created for various uses. Could have spent much longer here, but my family were too hungry to see anymore! Definitely worth a visit!
For me the best part of roman history . Absolutely blown away by how much there is here. History galore. Stunning ruins that are endless. For me it outshines the Colosseum

Amazing, especially for history and architecture lovers!. I'd highly recommend buying a combined ticket for the Palatine Hill & Roman Forum (they are on the same site) and for the Colosseum. Settlement of Rome started on the Palatine Hill, so it's a great introduction to Ancient Rome before walking down to the Roman Imperial Forums. Take your time when visiting, and take a good guidebook to fully appreciate the history!

Great views of ancient Rome. Palatine Hill gives you a brilliant idea of how the ancient Romans used to live and the enormity of the building they used to live in. You also get great views of the Roman Forum and Collosseum

History, history everywhere!. Amazing ruins to walk among, and so much history in one place you won't know where to start. Beautiful and magnificent monuments and eerie ruins to walk amogst. It's also spacious so does not feel cramped walking around with all the many other people. Amazing place to visit, with a lot of information on the Ancient city of Rome. There are also fantastic views from here of the Colosseum. This is included in the Colosseum ticket, so it you go to the former, definitely visit this gem too.

Be prepared for lots of walking and a great time.. So my husband and I had a fantastic time here and in the Roman Forum, but I recommend going on a day with good weather, and bringing snacks, but no need to bring extra large water bottles, because there are places to refill your water bottles all over the place. The pines! The pines of Rome! They are so incredibly beautiful. We didn't purchase a guide to the area, just followed along with the page or two in our guide to Rome, but that was fine for us. It was part of one of our nicest days in Rome. We spent all morning here and in the Roman Forum, had lunch, went to the Colosseum, and then went to a small museum after that. All of the activities were paid for together on the Archeology card, and it was fantastic.
Rome visit. This was beyond amazing. To see ruins dating back to Christ was beyond comprehension. I never thought I would see where Caesar was cremated .
Ancient Rome at its finest!. Stroll around the ruins of ancient Rome, with the palaces and temples on the hilltop overlooking the forum and the "Circus Maximus" racetrack.

Walking into history. Walking into this place from a strange feeling , it is a place where you can feel the past history of the origins of the old continent . the only thing that I find unpleasant fake Roman centurions who are of Romanian origin are really pushy and unpleasant but otherwise it 's fine Rome is a city that offers so much for those who love history and culture with me

A good place to begin exploring Ancient Rome. Wonderful views from above, looking down on the Forum and Colosseum which really helps you appreciate and make sense of what was founded here over 2000 years ago. The size of the palace complex is mind-boggling and it's a good place to begin exploring.

Excellent. This is an amazing well preserved piece of ancient Rome and is really one of the birthplace of civilization as we know it.There's so much to see words can't really do it justice.The tickets for this come with the Colosseum and you get two days to get around both which is good.
Ancient Rome. Fascinating to see how big things were built over 1500 years ago.A well preserved area that is quite awe-inspiring!

Must see! But with a guide.. The view you get from here of the Forum and the city is breath taking but I thoroughly recommend you do it within a guided tour. Our walking tour included the Colosseum, Palantine Hill and the Forum and our guide was incredible. We learnt so much from this fantastic history lesson. The only way to see this.

A trip in history. Such an interesting trip back in time, bring your imagination and love of history and you have a full day of activity...bring your walking shoes (and water too if it's a warm day!) as this is quite the hike around the grounds - not very stroller, wheelchair friendly...be prepared to walk but it is certainly worth it!

History, history, history.. We wandered the Palatine while we carried out our objective of seeing the Forum. It is amazing to see so much history in the middle of a city. Having been to a couple of the entrances near the Colosseum, we ended up going in through the entrance near the Wedding Cake - the queue was nowhere near as long, and, once one of the rather slow staff was replaced by someone a bit quicker, we soon got in. There are very good audio guides for this place - although we didn't take the one for Palatine, as we were more interested in the Forum. This area is a must for anyone visiting Rome.

My favourite part of the city. Take plenty of time to walk around. There might not be a lot of information to explain what you're looking at, but I don't think you need it. There's a very nicely made museum at the top that tells more about the most ancient part of the city. Lovely.

Real history. The ruins tell the real story of Ancient Rome in a much more detailed and authentic way than many other attractions.Would recommend a guide or detailed guide book to accompany this visit to make sure you get the most from it.
Interesting History. Take a tour, there is too much to see without someone to explain what everything is. Our Tour guide, Rafa gave us wonderful history lessons.

A great view of Ancient Rome. This was our first trip to Rome and visiting Palatine Hill was certainly on our to-do list. We heard about the long lines and how you can spend a lot of time waiting so we booked a Colosseum Tour with Special Access to Underground & Arena Floor through Expedia. The tour was conducted by City Wonders and the whole tour was AWESOME!!! It started with a guided tour of the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill and ended with an incredible tour of the Colosseum. This tour allowed us to bypass all of the lines tied to all three of these sites and our guide gave us a very comprehensive tour of each site and provided us with so much incredible back story to really help our group really understand what we were seeing. It's easy to kind of lump Palatine Hill in with the Roman Forum as they're very close to each other. If I had to vote for which I like more, I'd vote for the Forum but Palatine Hill is a site worth visiting too. The ruins there aren't as complete as they are at the Forum, but definitely worth the visit. The guide that accompanied us throughout our tour was awesome and really helped bring it all to life for us. So much better than an average audio tour. The entire tour (Roman Forum/Palatine Hill/Colosseum) was awesome! I'm so glad we paid the extra money for that very unique and enjoyable experience and would recommend others to do the same.

My Favorite attraction in Rome. I am embarrassed to say that I somehow missed this attraction on my first trip to Rome. I honestly don't know how that could have happened. I have since been to Rome on two more occasions and this is my absolute favorite place. To see and actually TOUCH things from 495 BC is almost unbelievable! Prior to my most recent visit I did my homework to learn all I could about each ruin. I spent two days here and could have spent more. You will absolutely want to wear comfortable shoes with non slip bottoms. People with strollers have a difficult time and sometimes end up parking them and carrying small children. Check the website for hours as they change from day to day. Also, pack a small lunch, there is a charming shaded area with benches near the garden at the top that is very picturesque. Do your homework, it makes the experience so much better. An absolute must for history buffs!
Nice afternoon walk. A great place to wander away from the crowd at the forum, palatine hill was relaxing and more quiet than the crowded forum.
Use a tour guide . Because the info they give you just puts such a different slant on your sight seeing trip. So much to see here it's amazing .
Impresive ruins.. You could spend over a day just walking around this huge area of ruins. You can also get impressive views of other areas of ancient Rome from here.

Ancient history at its best. The palatine hill and Roman forum are well preserved buildings and streets of areas when senators and important Romans lived and worked. The more you see and discover gets you into the way they were,and you want to discover more and more. You can spend the whole day just wandering around visualising yours self as some person in Rome going about there business. Fascinating area to be explored.
A breath from the Colosseum. There was not as much people in here as the Colosseum. Plus, the site is large and more beautiful.Would recommend this over its neighbor, the Colosseum.

Great site - but need to bring a detailed guide book with you!. Amazing site - but little effort has been made to bring it to life. If you want to make the most of the visit, choose the right guide book carefully before you travel. We purchased on on site, but it wasn't great
Relaxing. I enjoyed the garden setting as it was a nice change from the city buildings and buzziness. It was interesting and the audioguide useful aswell.

breathtaking. it takes quite some time waiting in line to buy tickets, but this is a must-see anyway. Magical view of the Roman ruins and Rome on the hill and it can take you a long while exploring around.

Amazing place. This is attached to the Forum (my review for there is more extensive but covers both areas).This is a must visit if you're in Rome - if you like history/romans/architecture/old things etc etc then you have to visit and requires a long time! We spent about 5 hours here over two days. Buy joint Colosseum/Palatine/Forum ticket from the Palatine/Forum ticket office as Colosseum queue is always huge and forum queue is small.
Fascinating. We did this as part of a tour led by an archaeologist from "Walking Italy" and we are glad we did because we got so much more out of the visit!

A Stunning Palast. This palast is located on a hill overlooking Circus Maximus and is not only interesting to look at and imagine how it was to live here in ancient Rome, but has gorgeous views over the city of Rome as well.

try to imaging yourself being there during Roman times. A great insight into life during the Roman times, walk the streets and look at the old houses and walls, try to see yourself there - the hustle and bustle. Wasn't too busy in Feb when we went but I would guess that during the height of the season it would be pretty busy and hot.Not too interesting for young kids though and a lot of walking.

Pleasantly surprised. This attraction was included in Colosseum ticket and to be honest wasn't that interested in going but as it was such a great day and I'd nothing else to do... What a turn up for the books...enjoyed this more then the Colosseum. The views of the city are fantastic...go see for yourself.
great to see and fab views of Rome from top of hill. Great picture setting of the colosseum and breathtaking views of rome are amazing from top of the Palatine hill
Fantastic. You must visit when in Rome, opposite the Colossuem. Wished we had more thime to spend at locality, but so much to doe in Rome...Sensible footwear advised. Perfect for views over Rome
not really my thing.. free entry on the first of the month. was very beautiful. spent a few hrs walking round it. was a nice thing to do on a sunny day.

Behold the Might of Rome. A must for anyone visiting Rome. A remarkable collection of ancient monuments in such a concentrated area - many of them have seen better days but it's amazing that so much remains standing after such a long time. Much of the structure of our modern day democracy began here, before being exported to the UK by the all conquering Roman Empire. Well worth the visit and better still if part of one of the excellent, informative guided tours.

The history of our society. Much of our western society is based on things we adopted from some part of ancient Rome. Some things have changed; some not so much. There's a fair amount of walking and stairs involved in this, but interesting and awe-inspiring archeology. With a little pre-reading and some imagination, teens were quite engaged.

Wonderful place to Visit. We did this on the same day as the Colosseum and we thought this attraction had so much more about it. We got really good weather so we were lucky. Definitely best to do this on a dry day. We were there for around 3-4 hours and was worth every minuet.
Amazing history. Gorgeous setting adjacent to the Forum and Colosseum. Group ticket is very well priced at 12 euros. Under 18s are free if you can show id. Great views would thoroughly recommend.

Ancient Roman ruins. "free" if you bought the tickets to see the column right across from this entrance. Huge area to walk around and explore to see how the Romans lived. There are different paths depending on how you are on your feet so dont' worry about not being physically fit.

Must see. A great Tour, very informative and totally worth the money. Pre booking is a good idea as there are dozens of touts all vying for tour business. We had no idea and found the Gladiator rep purely by chance.

Cool place to walk, bring water. It can get sweltering in the middle of the summer in Rome and there's not a lot of shade so bring water and sunscreen. This was a nice walk, although we got a bit lost and couldn't figure out what we had/hadn't seen.

Well worth the entrance fee. Too see it is to understand it. We spent an entire day here and just loved it. It is well laid out and the audio is great. To see the level of civilisation 1500 to 2000 years ago is mind-blowing

Great place to see over the site of the forum. A gentle climb up lots of steps but worth it..This is the best place.to get an idea of the layout of the Roman foirum. You must pay to walk around in the ruins of the forum but its free from the top of the hill to look down on it all.

A must during your Coloseum visit. Ruined antique roman palaces and temples, lots of walking and a visit that could take you 1h or a full morning/afternoon. You could feel as you lived during the roman empire.
Nice walk. Very nice walk and found a nice small church at the end of the path. Great views from the top and its free!!
Near Colosseum must to be seen. Very nice attraction. You can feel the history when walking here. If you were learning latin in school this will bring up old memories.

Another Must Do in Rome. Definitely consider booking a tour via City Wonders, Viator or the like so that you can fully appreciate this historical area. Not only does entering with a tour group allow you to skip the line, you are also able to get SO MUCH MORE out of your visit.

Astounding. I've noticed that the majority of visitors of the archeological area focus on the Roman forum and coliseum.I have a passion for the palatine hill that's one of the most simbolical and beautiful sites in Rome.I always include the palatine in my tours and at the end I notice that my guests love the history of the Roman forum but are amazed by the remains of the imperial palaces.They're able to visualize it, with my help, and at the end they love it the most.Everyone wish to live like an emperor!!!The site is majestic but not very easy to comprehend....Nevertheless it's worth the visit also to see the mixture of ruins and natura that has inspired the poets of the last 2 centuries.

Free viait. Having purchased a tour to the coliseum this was added on as a freebee - in fact it was better than the coliseum tour. The guide spoke perfect English, had a great sense of humour and an in-depth knowledge of his subject (Gladiator Tours). The tour is physically challenging at times and is not suitable for the unfit (steep slopes and slippery when wet) however if you've looked after yourself you'll be rewarded with a great visit

A hill full of ruined roman palaces. There is an entrance very near to the Coliseum, which generally is less crowded than the entrance to the Roman Forum, and both are connected with 1 ticket for both, or a combined ticket with the coliseum. Note that in winter it closes, like the coliseum, already at 4:30 pm. However, it is much less crowded than the coliseum, and out of season pleasantly busy. Of some palaces and aqueducts quite substantial and impressive parts remain, so less imagination is necessary than for the Roman forum, where little remains except some columns. There are explanatory boards, but as my partner remarked, the information given is rather lousy, certainly if one compares to the presentation and information given at archaeological sites in Peru and other countries across Europe. Here, certainly a guidebook is necessary to fully appreciate what you are seeing. There is a small museum of which especially the 2nd floor is well worth a visit.
Must see. When in Rome you must visit here for fantastic views of Rome. Free entry but the 7 euros to take the lift up to the roof is well worth it.

Worth the time to explore. While many visitors skip Palatine Hill, it is well worth your time to explore. Be prepared for some hill climbing and lots of walking. Read up on the site before visiting or take a good guide book with you as posted signs are few. Look for the place where the emperors used to sit and imagine what it must have been like when this was the seat of the entire Roman empire. Beautiful views of Rome including the Forum and Colosseum, from various places on the hill as well.
more then you think. This place is amazing they have just found Julius Ceaser town, not for the faint heart has there is a lot of walking but again steeped in history

Relaxing walk through history . Three hours just flew by as we wandered around the site. There are many areas to explore with plenty of places for you to just sit and wonder at the many ancient buildings. We ate lunch purchased from the local supermarket just behind the Colosseum before entering the site as there isn't anywhere to buy food except for a few vending machines. You can then walk through to the Forum. We had purchased a combined Colosseum, Forum and Palatine Hill ticket online did our tour of the Colosseum the previous day which we thought was sensible as you can get historyed out!

Palatine Hill. We had a guided tour of Palatine Hill with Gladiator Tours. Our tour guide was called Greg and was superb. The cost was €25 each but did include The Colosseum and Forum. You need to wear supportive footwear as a little uneven under foot.

Unbelievable!. It was incredible, so amazing. We walked around it but never went inside but still got to see enough of it to appreciate the history behind it all. You felt like you were taken back in time.
Enjoyable stroll during the day. Great thing to do, especially since it's connected to the Roman Forum. Was fun to get to walk around and see all the ancient artifacts.

Lovely. The walk through the shady area of the Palatine was most enjoyable. Buildings of ancient Rome were everywhere, all were labelled with a potted history and explanation. However, take a guide book as sometimes it is confusing as to what you are looking at. The area is no where near as crowded as the Forum area and the shade of the plane trees makes it a most pleasant excursion in the heat of summer. The buildings are just as spectacular as those in the Forum and is easier to navigate around. Even my husband who is no great lover of history was fascinated. The Palatine is well worth a visit and depending on how thorough you are can take anywhere between a quick hour to 3. Enjoy!!!

Great for history lovers. Located right next to the colosseum, why wouldn't you want to take this in as well. If you're in Rome to visit the sights, this a must do, some tours of the colosseum also include this

So glad we went. I enjoyed Palatine Hill more than the Colosseum, wish we had booked the audio tour for this part two, we were there all afternoon and did not see it all, a second visit will be needed, the tour is not for young children or the elderly or people with mobility issues.

See Rome where it all started. We didn't really know what to expect but we are so glad that we decided to visit the site. You literally see Rome from its foundation through to its rise as the most powerful nation on earth.Take plenty of water if it's hot, there were a few water stations but these are vending machines as opposed to cafe, so some change is also advisable. Facilities are also quite spread out so be prepared.If you are uneasy on your feet or not so good with climbs or steps then this may not be the best site to visit as it's a quite large site and does involve some steep climbs.

Worth the walk on the Palatine Hill!. We took a long stroll around the Palatine Hill and totally loved it! lots of history, ancient city (more like ruins, but i like to call it a city) to discover, excavations, a museum and a great city view we got during our time!
Wow . This is also another must if in rome also recommend with a tour guide to get the best experience and knowledge. Amazing structures and sites
All the old things. Loads of old pillars and statues and all sorts. This is where romulus or remus did something. Really nice views. Very impressive

Disappointing . Sad to say the Attraction was a let down. I appreciate the history of this place however it was poorly maintained, loads of overgrown ruins covered in weeds and lots of litter. Very limited facilities, one small dirty smelly toilet block when you enter through the turnstiles with unhelpful uninterested staff. No drinking facilities available as the fountain was unclean. Very limited information available and signage was poor. Nice to say you've seen it but came away knowing little more than I did before I went.
A wonderful surprise . A lot of walking involved here but really worth the views once you get to higher ground. Really beautiful historical peices to admire here

Amazing journey to the past. The forum is big area of ancient buidings located in the center of Rome, close to the Colosseum. You can walk and admire paved roads and buildings. The ticket to Colosseum gives you acess to the Forum. Don't miss it!

Great area to visit! . Me and my girlfriend got this place included onto our coliseum tickets, great value for money! The ancient ruins are spectacular and there's a free to enter museum on site. You can walk here in about 5 mins from the coliseum, walk through Palatine Hill and into central Rome which is just beautiful! The hill provides amazing elevation for the panoramic views also! Highly recommended for all!

Walking in Centurions' footsteps. If you don't get a sense of history walking through here then check you still have a pulse.I could almost hear the legionnaires marching on the cobbles and see the Senators arguing over taxes.We thought this was even better than the Colosseum, go if you can.

Great views and museum. This gives a great sense of perspective to the wealth and sophistication of the Roman era, as well as the city with views over the Aventine and the centre. We spent 4 hours exploring and still know there is more to see. Put your sturdy shoes on to wander around.

Very interesting. Tour combined with Colosseum.. We booked a tour and this was one of the included site visits. For someone who likes history, these sites cannot be beaten. It was very helpful on a tour, as we learned so much information that we would have never known on our own.

Allot Enough Time. If you're limited in the amount of time you are in Rome, bypass this and do the Forum only; if you have enough time, do both! Great excavations; so much history! Spectacular view of the city! Can get crowded, and some tourists can be rude, but don't let that deter you. Well worth the walk if the weather allows.
A day in ancient Rome--amazing. A must see while visiting Rome. Walk and relive the lifestyle of ancient Romans. If you're visiting in the summer, bring a hat, sunscreen and water.

Delight to the Eyes!. My family and I really enjoyed this excursion. You can see how in Bible times the need to show the hospitality of washing the feet of your guest was important. Walking in sandals here your feet will quickly become dusty! It was just amazing to see buildings of this caliber still standing in 2015. And the brain power and manual labor it took to create it...it just reaffirms creation for and not evolution.

Do not miss this if you are in Rome!. It was an absolutely great place to visit, and we were thinking of just going back to the hotel, so thankful that we decided to go in, the place delightful with lovely views and was a great walk, kept us fit anyway ;) There weather was extremely hot though so we could not stay as long as I had hoped, may return at a point when the weather is slightly cooler so to enjoy the place better! :)
Get your walking boots on. Fantastic place to visit but your walking. Steeped in history and fantastic photo opportunities everywhere. Take plenty of water.

touring tips. We visited the Colosseum, Forum & Palatine hill in one day. Honestly it was way too much for one day as this is a lot of touring combined with lots of walking ( we walked there from our hotel- the Metro was having problems that day our hotel told us). So by the time we got here after touring the Colosseum and Forum, we were beat.We spent 1.5 each in the Colosseum, Forum and about an hour here. To really see the Forum, allow for 1.5 hours.If short on time, this can definitely be missed. Or do this separately when you have more energy. Another option is to see the Colosseum, have lunch in the Monti section of Rome right near the Colosseum and then tackle the Forum and Palatine Hill together. This way you won’t be as tired.I found it OK but it was a lot of walking inside here. Plus they were doing lots of excavation which impacted the view. Had I been less tired, I would have enjoyed it more.If you like my review, I hope you'll click the 'helpful' button; those of us who write reviews live for those and it motivates us to do more.
Best ruins in Rome. Great place. Awesome views all over the city. The ruins were great, and it was a quiet place after visiting the busy colosseum.

History overload!!. We used a tour guide for palatine hill and had we not we would not have known anything about what we were looking at. From the eyes of an amatuer they just looked like beautiful gardens however with a tour guide you are mentally as well as visiually stimulated. Ancient Rome was beautiful to see and the historty we learnt was something that would entertain adults and children and we have every intention of returning when our little girl is older.

Worth the hike . Palatine Hill is accessible through the Forum which requires an admission fee. The ground/walkways here are very uneven and the whole site is on hilly ground so expect to take your time and exert yourself. I recommend very comfy shoes and bringing water or a picnic (we found no refreshments inside the site aside from an ancient fountain -which was drinkable- though we did find restrooms). We thought it was very impressive and worth the effort, but do go with your guidebook, or get an audio guide to help you bring it all to life - otherwise it may just feel like a pile of photogenic ruins to you.
Historical place. Wonderful views and date with history. Anyone looking for nice views and some historical experience should visit it.

Great - if you like ruins. Lots of bits of Roman architecture standing around here so great if you are into that sort of thing. Quite a lot of the access was shut when we visited so we ended up being funneled up the hill to a not-very-interesting church and then had to retrace our steps

Great Place to Visit. Pick a audio-guide and just wonder off into history..................it is a great experience. We opted to spend a few hours in the area which is in a strategic place in Rome and enjoys lovely breathtaking views of Rome.

Far more spectacular than I imagined. The Palatine Hill is definitely the place to start your visit to Rome. There is just so much to see, the upper level with the gardens and the views across the Colosseum. Was just spectacular with the hippodrome and other great ruins, just wanted to see it built up!
Do not miss. Excavated since my last visit to Rome, the magnificence of Palatine Hill makes the Forum look tiny. Prepare to spend hours wandering and the views of Ancient Rome are amazing.

Palatine hill. This whole area is sari undead by history . If you get a good tour guid you would have a fantastic visit . There are plenty of thigs to see so I would say get a good guide or guide book

Visit together with Colosseum and Forum. The Palatine Hill, Forum and Colosseum are locatednext to each other and can be visited with one ticket. (Roma Pass). These three places give a really great impression of ancient Rome.

A walking museum. Get on no 64 from termini station...stop at piazza venezia...walk up to altare della patria and along via dei fori imperiali. It felt like living in the past. Could actually imagine the roman senate walking up and down the place. Impressive ruins. Can't be missed.
Another must see in Rome. Especially if you like your Roman history. Even if you don't you'll be impressed by the sheer scale of the palace complex. The views from the top are the best in Rome
Palatine Hill. After the Collesseo, went up the hill slowly. There are not so many tourists visiting the area and can see some recent excavations or perhaps renovations going around.

Part of the package for the Colosseum visit.. As I said in my review of the Colosseum, this place is free with a visit to the Colosseum every first Sunday of the month. Allow for at least 3 hours for the Colosseum, the Palatine and the Forum. Worth the visit.
History at your finger tips. Being able to physically touch living history, and wonder at the magnificent architecture is overwhelming.

Awesome. Once visiting the Palatino, Foro Romano & Colosseum make sure you start in the morning, so you do not have to rush through the sites. Note that on site the purchase of tickets must be paid with a credit card. The lines were not long in January, wish I had hired a guide.

A lot of construction work, so limited access.. Although third visit to Rome, first visit to the hill. The views were good, but as there is a lot of maintenance/preservation construction taking place, some of the views were spoilt.
Not as interesting as the Colliseum. Our ticket gave us entry to this area as well but we found the Coliseum far more interesting as there was a lot more information available.

Underrated. I knew that the old imperial palace sat above the Circus Maximus, but I had no idea how much of it is still standing (in ruins) or how much else was up on the Palatine Hill. We were running a little late and realized that seeing both the Palatine and the Colosseum was probably going to be a stretch, but once we got inside the old palace, everyone agreed that we would have to fit the Colosseum in on another day (we did, but that's another review).If you don't know much of the history, you would be well advised to hire a guide because there isn't very much interpretive information posted. On the other hand, the views require very little explanation, and they are outstanding. This was perhaps not the best part of the trip, but it was the biggest (positive) surprise.
Plenty to see. A very large area with a lot to see right in the centre of the city. A great place to sit and chill out too.

Place to overlook old rome, free at 1st sunday in every monday. We could overlook Poro Romano, Colosseo, Crico Massimo. Especially in overlook poro Romano is great. When you go there, move from left to right.Enjoy free at 1st Sunday in every month. After this I recommend move to Mouth of Truth.

Historical Spot. It is a good place to see what kind of architecture was in ancient time during Rome empire,, you can explore a big area filled with the ruinsSome people who likes history and old architecture will like it, but some others might just feel this spot just so - so
DO it!. A lovely walk and amazing relics to peer from off the sidewalk above. Some amazing cafes nearby. Follow the locals.
Amazing. Had a guided tour of Palantine Hill, The Roman Forum and the Colosseum and to see all the ancient structures , albeit slightly weathered, is amazing. A must see.
Very impressive. A beautiful area, very nice to walk in the park on a nice day, the museum gives you a very goodd idea of what the hill must have looked like back in the day.

Part of the Colosseum and Forum Ticket. Explore these ruins on your way from the colosseum to the forum. They're included in the price. You get excellent views of the forum from the Palatine Hill. Plus there is a nice little museum on the top that's worth a visit.

Try to get in to see the Casa of Augustus. Palatine Hill is awesome.... although it's mostly a pile of rocks. But again, try to imagine yourself back in Ancient Rome. See how life was built and how it was really genius and not really different from our times. Ok, we don't build with columns like that anymore, or huge circus in our back yards, but it's not that different from now.But if you can be at the Hill before 12:45 (or check the site to get on one of the guided tours on the weekend), splurge the 4euros to get in to see the Casa di Augustus. It's a well guarded secret and the only place that sells the ticket is the Palatine Hill entrance. Even then, the ticket guy tried to tell me it was closed. Fortunately, there was a paper on the window that gave the visiting time (it's good if you can speak and read Italian) and after a few insisting moments, he finally sold us the tickets.The House is restored to it's grandeur and the frescoes are amazing! The 12:45 visit is only accompanied by one of the employees, so there is no narration or story telling. But it was amazing nonetheless! I am NOT an art connoisseur, nor a history buff, but I can see beauty when it's in front of me. To walk in what was once his private quarters and to imagine day to day life is really something else.I'm not sure how long it will be opened to visitors given that the Emperor's ramp was closed only 10 days after being opened, but if you can get to see this rare gem and you like to see things that are off the beaten path, then go. It's not easy to find the tickets, but when you do, you really feel you've found the hidden gem. Alternatively, you can book this visit through one of the tour agencies before you leave the country. I'd say that this would be worth the expense. Check Tripadvisor to know which company is more reputable than the others.
