Go ffor it !. Just go after the colosseum!..it helps to make you get the feel of the Roman empire splendour..anyway comes with the ticket with the colosseum so its really worth going..just give about 2hours or more
Birthday visit . We went on a very windy day but still lots of fun lots to see , make sure you spend as much time as you can here as I have been here 3 times and still have missed bits each time
Interesting. Little plaques along the way to educate on the significance of various facets of Palatine Hill. Great for history buffs and plebs alike:)
No good for disabled people!. Although this is historical I was unable to access the Hill so my husband went instead. He found it very interesting.

History in its glory. You can take a guided tour but we preferred to amble around, the modern statues are a little incongruous beside the centuries old building. Use your imagination and you are swept back to the times of the togas
Palatine Hill. The view from the top of Palatine Hill is great and the ruins but once you make it down to the bottom, it seems to be a lot of ruins just thrown together and hard to follow.
Lovely step back into History. This place is breath taking if you enjoy history. We took a tour guide and learned all the history of old Rome... would def recommend...

Interesting. We did not have enough time to see this when doing it with Roman Forum as you need several hours to see the full extent and soak in the history of it and we didn't have any food with us. We should have taken a packed lunch as there is a vending machine which only sells a few snacks.Directional sign posts would be useful as we were not sure which way to go and missed quite a bit of it out.

a walk through the past. We went to the hill as part of Colosseum tour, and we can imagine how it looked like in the ancient time, as the tour guide explained to us the details and the story that happened in this area. It is not easy to bring the stroller, although it is not prohibited. You have to step some stairs, and walk on the ancient road with uneven surface.

Great place to view the city and ruins.. It is wonderful to be able to stand on Palatine Hill and peruse so many historic landsites and ruins that have made up my collective consciousness over years of high school education, literature and visits. Never fails to thrill me.

Don't miss it. If you're able to take the walk up the hill, this is not to be missed. It's worth 20 euros to take a guided tour unless you're a serious scholar of Roman history, since we learned many things on this walk that we would not have known otherwise. The views are excellent, and the expanse of history displayed here is impressive.

A birds eye view . Palatine hill overlooks a magnificent view of the forum. If you only have time for one then take the gentle route up to the hill.The entrance for palatine hill and both the forum is about a 5 to 8 min walk away from the colosseum. From the entrance, ( remember to show your colosseum tickets) it is about roughly about a 20 min to 35 min stroll to the top.The route up is gentle but rocky. Hence wear comfy walking shoes. The Elderly will require some assistance and those with baby prams might want to leave those behind as there are steep, cobbled, uneven ground which will make you do twice the work. ( dont forget u have to go up and then down!)At the top, you will find it adorned with lovely orange trees, fountains and aqueducts which you can quench your thirst with. While tje view is magnificent. Becareful of the short railings. I peered down on the ledge and realised that some tourists have lost their hats, bottles and other valuables to the height. So keep ur stuff close and secure any loose items before going selfie crazy.The view is magnificent. And going there before noon will gurantee you enough sunshine for great photography and also less people to fight space with.To exit, you can either come down the same way, or proceed to the forum and explore the ruins further.Ps: beware of huge seagulls (i think) who are not afraid of tourists and will comfortably perch on the railings while you take your pictures.
Worth visiting. Lots of ancient ruins and things to see here. Was not as busy as the last time we visited. Worth getting the combination ticket.
So much beauty. An awesome sight to see up close.My only wish is that i saw it in summer when it was not so nippy, but do not take this away from the beauty that was on show

A quiet corner of history. Palentine Hill deserves to be separated from the Forum site as in nature they are two very separate sites. Entrance is included in the Colosseum ticket. I would recommend to try and use the entrance to the left and down the street from the forum entrance. If this is not possible I would bear left from the forum entrance and follow the trail to the remains of the aqueduct. From here you can take a steady walk with a much gentler incline. There are water fountains dotted around and plenty of seating to rest and drink in your surroundings. It is a beautifully maintained area and every so often you are treated to some stunning glimpses of Roman ruins. At its peak the views across the city are unbelievable. There is a Palentine museum which is free. It is worth following every nook and cranny to discover some unexpected delights such as the underground fountain room. The views across the forum site and amazing and will serve to wet the appetite further. This is as must see as any site in this amazing city.
Well worth a walk. It was scorching hot throughout the week we visited, but it was worth the walk up the Palatine Hill to see the magnificent views over the Eternal City. Highly recommended!

Interesting walk through. Plenty of Roman history here, a person could spend hours exploring the ruins. Some of the attractions were well preserved, others little more than rumble. But than what can you expect for ancient buildings, I am was very glad to see what I did. Feb 2013
Just "Rome at a glance" visit. Fabulous, great whether during a daytime, a bit freezing during night (+5-7C), not that many tourists like in other time of the year.

Excellent, included with colliseo. Huge area, check map as some routes up the hill do not allow one to come down to the forum (you have to return). We didnt get a self guide but recommend as worth it.

A Day in the Past. If you are doing this in the summer you must take water.Day tours are highly recommended to see all of the best spots as you can get lost.Amazing the history, I would suggest a little history reading before going as it makes it so much more interesting. A must do if you are in Rome with a heap of other places

A must if you are in Rome . Just stunning! History at it best. Worth a tour and if the weather is nice you will get some great pics. Take some water with you if it's hot. Soak up the history. Fantastic

Beautiful. Best to get a combo ticket for Colosseum, Forum and Palatine. Beautiful display and preservation of imperial Rome palace and grounds. Right next door to the Colosseum! Would not recommend for a rainy day as there is much walking outdoors, however, there is a museum on-site.

Must take a tour. There is an amazing amount of history on this hill - and it's worth a tour guide to explore it. Gardens, ruins, and an unmatched view from the top is not to be missed! Not very handicapped-friendly though..so wear your walking shoes.

Amazing Views. I spent so much time to get around this area, which was rather big for a rainy day, but it was totally worth it cause you get to see amazing views, take amazing pictures and learn so much about the Italian history!!
Unexpectedly good.. Lovely archeological site of Rome right across from the colosseum (include in ticket price). Security long can be a little long but also then leads in to Roman Forum.

Breathtaking. If you are interested in history or architecture...or just the beauty and magnificence of the human race...then this is for you. Amazing place, I personally preferred it to Athens or Olympia
Interesting place. Worth a visit if you are going to the collesium as they are right next to each other. The tube stops right outside and it's beautiful .
Worth seeing. If you are into antient history go and see it. Some others might think "ruins, ruins, ruins". Interesing if you are into the history of all emperors and popes.

Don't Miss This View!. Palatine Hill overlooks the Roman Forum. The views of the Forum and the Colosseum from here are just amazing. You can only imagine what it was like back in the day. There is also a Palatine Museum that was very interesting as well. Our tour guide brought us up and explained so much. I would definitely recommend.
Living history. There is some space in the furthest corners away from crowds. Museum is excellent. Gives a feel for ancient times.

Don't miss this. I think a lot of people miss this area as it is above the main attractions and a bit of a walk, it is not crowded but tranquil and full of the most fantastic buildings in a good state of repair, water features and gardens.

A must see but easily missed. The Palatine Hill abuts the Roman Forum in Rome. While you can access the "Hill" separately, most visitors walk up from the Forum. The gardens at the top are tranquil and much cooler than the Forum below. the views are spectacular. You really get a feel for the "Villas" of the rich and famous of ancient Rome up here. Perfect real estate! It is easy to miss out on a visit to the Hill. Don't. It is worth another hour to walk around and chill in the gardens, soaking up the views.
Amazing remnants of Roman history. This requires lots of walking, it is amazing that this is open to public for free, original ruins untouched, definitely do guided tour if not in a hurry.

The power of Ancient Rome can still be felt here. The Palantine Hill cannot be missed when in Rome. The ancient ruins of the center of Rome will leave you in awe. You will literally feel the past as you stroll by the Temples and home of the Vestal Virgins. I was speechless...
Amazing!. Beautiful grounds - covers a large area - be prepared to walk a lot! We did not have a tour guide, but there are plenty of plaques around to explain what you are looking at.

A lot of walking involved!. I loved the olive trees and discovered some orange trees along the way. The museum at the top hosts some amazing sculptures and artefacts. But does require imagination and a lot of peddle power. They do have automated drinks machines at the top but I would have prefered if they could have installed a nice cafe just because you do need time to take break with a huge site like that. So do take drinks and snacks. Oh the same ticket to the colloseum will also give you access to this.

Strole through history. We paid a private guide we happened to meet on another tour;Leisurely afternoon stroll with a walking encyclopedia. One of our best days in Rome. If it is hot take water and a hat!
Wonderful.. So interesting for those who love history. Have read so much about Rome and to visit the Palatine and Colloseum was a lifetime's ambition. It did not disappoint!
Must see!!. You really have to see the Palatine Hill when visiting Rome. I think is the best way to understand how ancient Rome and Roman lived and what their city looked like.
you must see this. wonderful place took a long time to walk around but if you enjo history you will enjoy this given free access due to disability

Spectacular . From looking at maps and tourist guides etc it is hard to grasp the sheer scale of the ruins of the forum and the palentine hill (they are the same place as far as planing a visit goes) do not go the same day as the collaceam visit if you get a combined ticket unless you go to the collaceam early. It is a good 3 hours at least to see the the forum/palentine ruins
Lovely for a stroll. Full of history and wonderful sights. The gardens are quite high up but there are easy paths to walk on. Lovely and peaceful, nice to get away from the hustle and bustle

Wonderful for history buffs. Wonderful for history buffs and any one wanting to understand ancient Rome. It is really a two or three day job to cover it properly. Be prepared to do a lot of walking and you will be rewarded.Actually travelled in 2012

Beautiful views. Another amazing location in Rome and so significant to Roman history. Incredible archaeology sight. The day was awesome touring the Forum, Pallantine Hill and the Colesium. A definite must to see when in Rome and definitely worth purchasing the tour and skip the line up tickets. We would have stood in lines for hours if not and we went in the slow season.
Prepare to walk!. Wonderful to see all the ruins. We did the coliseum first...so we were tired by the tie we got here. Nice to see the ruins and take pictures. It's an expansive area..

Rome just keeps on giving!. We visited the Palatine Hill and Roman Forum after touring the Colosseum and entry for all three was included in the one ticket price which made it quite a reasonable cost and also avoided queuing for tickets at each location. Take your time and just soak in the sights as, yet again, they are amazing. It was quite busy on the day we visited but not uncomfortably so. Keep an eye on your belongings as we were advised about pickpockets being in the area but I guess that is commonsense. Enjoy!

Interesting tour for a Roman history buff. You should only do this tour with a guide unless you are an expert on ancient Roman history. Time well spent. Keep your camera ready ... there are LOTS of Kodak moments just waiting for you!

Part of Ancient Rome Tour. Wie Walker over Here After Leavin The Colosseum and in spite of The rain we were art of quite group of sightseers. The only negative note is the horde of men who follow you around shoving cheap umbrellas in your face or trying to sell you terrible plastic ponchos. If the weather was better it would have been even more of them. Quite disturbing to the scenery.

Well worth a visit but this does require some time. Unless you have at least an hour, skip this one. It's much better with 2 hours or more. All of the sites from the Forum to Pompei add up to a better understanding and appreciation of Roman life. You should bring some water with you and there are washrooms but there can be line-ups. A fair bit of walking and climbing is involved to see the site so not so easy if you have a mobility problem.

Breathtaking!!. Spend your time visiting all the ancient sites of Rome. The architecture is beautiful. You can see the the Roman Forum and Circus Maximus from the top. It is one of Romes's seven hills and truly a great view of the ancient city of Rome

Wow so much history !. We had this as an add on to our Colosseum tour and it was skip the line so we didn't have to wait in the heat for entry.So much history in one place ! There was just story after story of the different civilisations that have lived here. Not just the Romans.

Great View Over Forum. Although there is a decent little museum in this area, it's worth the 'climb' just for the view over the Forum and Jewish Ghetto areas of Rome. Because there is quite a bit of walking about involved, we did this early in the day in conjunction with the Forum so we could have a good long lunch break before hitting the overcrowded Colosseum. Not as ruin dense as the Forum area below, there are several partial excavation areas of interest that provide insight into the importance of the area during the height of the Roman Empire. Again, well worth the hike for the views!
History. Similar to my review on the Roman Forum. We did this tour with City Wonders and really enjoyed it.Great to see such history.
Historic. . Again one of those places that I've just walked past on my last visits. Stupid! I took some time this time and admired all that was there.

I would have been a great Roman. I'm not going to lie walking up Palatine hills one of the 7 hills in Rome is a task in itself, but I have to say the views are actually quite epic. the weather turned out beautifully so the walk was amazing, just make sure you bring a drink, if not they actually have vending machines. which was lucky for me, I parked a pue and soaked in the view.

It's the view..... The Palatine is a hill overlooking the main body of the Forum. Inevitably it involves a longish upwards walk but the ground isn't too rough and the steps are manageable. If you have breathing or heart problems you might wanna take a minute to think about it.Terrific view of the Forum and if you don't get thrown out before sunset the light on the buildings is, photographically speaking, beautiful.Nice, small, formal gardens at the top with fruiting orange trees. For those of you with bladder issues, there is a toilet at the top :)

A place to breath. A must go place thought not so much is standing up compare with the forum. But an amazing view on the south part of the site like the Massimo ''s circus. Very green lots of vegetation that give you a chance for a fresh break. Also every one rushes to the forum which is right in front of the coliseum and queue up for an hour or more even with Roma pass. Instead you better after the coliseum head left towards massimi circus and there you have the palatine entrance with no one waiting. Then from the palatine you walk down and join the forum a way... Much more relax this way...
Amazing tour. Over 2000 years old and amazing to see how advanced and opulent the Romans lived. We had a private tour guide which made the experience even more educational

The must visit in Rome. Destroed columns, ruines, rest of walls... Sounds boring? Not in this case. Because you'll the ruines and rests from Roman empire and even fell the spirit of that times. And also times of Roman republic. And times of integration of Itlay (Vittorio Emmanuele monumet is visible fron Palatine).
Rich history. We took a tour of Palatine Hill and the history here is amazing, we learned so much on this trip can't wait to go back

Simply historic. Firstly, if you intend to see everything, without necessarily reading everything, you will need at least five hours! This site covers a huge area so a lot of active walking is required. All for €12 an adult. It is a hill so expect some steep slopes and uneven surfaces. There are self-service snack and drink machines on site. Also a neat small museum within. The views are spectatular across the site, as well as parts of Rome. Naturally open area so could be less interesting if raining. You certainly feel how it may have been in years gone by...

Walk through and imagine the splendor the wealthy lived in here!. Recommend reading up on the site so you can understand what you're seeing or go on a tour. We went with Through Eternity's Underground Coloseum & Roman Forum/Palatine tour. Worth it.
Astounding history, truly unique place. We visited as part of a tour which included the Colosseum and the Imperial Forum. Definitely take a guide or you'll miss 90% of the story.

Well worth the a visit. Palatine Hill is included with the Colosseum ticket, so go ahead and visit! It is packed with history--the huts of Romulus & Remus, the Imperial Palace ruins, a view of the Circus Maximus, and a museum. Palatine Hill is great for anyone who wants to get away from the crowds.There are audio guides available, but we used Rick Steves' tour from his guide book to Rome.

Very fun to see but go with a guide. We saw the palatine hill while on a tour of the Forum. While I really enjoyed seeing it I don't think I would have gotten a lot out of it if I weren't with a guide. The palatine hill is much more in ruins than most of the forum and requires more imagination to be appreciated.

Great views. I enjoyed so much this part of Rome. Less crowded than you'd expect, besides the ruins and all the amazing history, the Palatine Hill also offers great views over the city, above the Roman Forum. My advice is to visit the Colosseum first and then the Palatine Hill.
Unbelievable. Allow plenty of time so that you can view all the buildings and take time to take it all in. Thoroughly recommend it.
Great view. This was part of our tour which included the Roman forum and colosseum it was a bit of a walk but well worth it.
Fantastic views. Amazing views of the city, alot of things to see and big, wasn't expecting there too be so much. A lovely little museum inside and vending machines. Leads straight into the forum
Fascinating. Recent excavations show that people have lived there since approximately 1000 B.C. It is a must see while visiting ROme

Ancient history. This is a ascending walk which takes you top of a hill with full of excavations of the archaeological sites. From top of the hill you could see the entire site full of ruins from ancient Rome. On a Rainy day please take umbrella with you as there are no place to seek shelter. A museum is there though but it would require a ticket.
Beautiful views. The Palatine Hill has some amazing views of Rome, as well as some rich history too. I wish I could see it in the spring or summer when things are in bloom.

Not to be missed. I have been to Rome several times and of course to the Forum..but never to Palatine Hill...this is not to be missed . If you should only have a day a Rome this must be first on your list..it was moving and inspirational all at the same time.

Another must see. Great to spend some time wandering around and lovely views of the Forum and Circus Maximus. It would have been lovely to find a nice cafe or something here to sit and enjoy awhile rather than the automated machines for snacks and drinks

Don't Miss This!. A visit to the Palatine Hill, which is the lowest of the 7 hills of Rome, will not disappoint. Walking amongst the majestic remains of statues and the columns of temples, one senses the beauty of this Eternal City. But nothing lasts forever and I felt very privileged to be able to experience this first hand.

Truly beautiful . You're in Roma! What to do? This!! So get your legs over there and experience a genuine feeling of going back to what Rome was before. When buying the ticket, get the bundles. Colosseum - Forum - Palatine.

Must do. This is part of the Forum area and highly recommend when you visit you start here, it is a large area with many old buildings and spectacular views. It has one of the earliest settlements in Rome.

Open air history lesson. There was something very enchanting about the afternoon we spent wandering the Palatine hill and Roman forum . It was a rainy day, but that added to the charm in a strange way. Remember to take your umbrella.

Take your time. This place is huge! Take your time and stroll through the ruins, its def worth it. The museum is superb, giving you an exact step by step timeline of how the whole place changed throughout the centuries. P.s. buy the roma pass as it includes many extras.

Incredible to Imagine. This stop had my imagination running wild at the hints of grandeur. The ruins pointing towards some very grans and lavish lifestyles. The grounds were beautiful and it was a nice bit if green space i the middle of a busy city.

Worth a visit. We started our tour of Palatine Hill, the Forum and the Colloseum here. This is the place to start, no queues for tickets and a downhill walk. Not much to see but worth a visit nonetheless for a sense of the history.

Superb!. We could spend the entire day here if we had some more time! Reserve atleast 5 hours and explore the ruins at length! The Circus Maximus and the Forum are stunning! Explore the ruins on a sunny day and dont forget your hat! Totally worth the visit!

Scenic and Historical Architecture. We viewed Palatine Hill as we walked around the outside of the Coliseum. Just seeing the structures and their remains gave an impression of how magnificent Rome must have been in the heyday of the Empire. Just amazing and impressive so much of it has been preserved.

WOW... most beautiful spot in Rome. Entered Palatine Hill with our Colosseum tickets, quite a climb, but so worth it! The gardens up there are breath taking, tranquil, lined with orange trees. With the sun shining, you could see why Emperor Augustus wanted to build his home on top of there!You will see the oldest relic in Rome up there, a piece of "wall art" Augustus had in his home, and the ruins of the palace. Try to go up there with a guide, as they have a lot of stories and information to give about the old palace, and why it is now in ruin.A great view of circus maximus (what is left of it) and a breath taking view of the Roman Forum, make sure you visit here!!!!

Enjoyable, but not as good as Pompeii or Herculaneum. The price for entry to this was included in the ticket to the Colleseum and the Roman Forum. It was greta to get a view of the Roman Form from above and the view of Rome. The museum had a really good film on the founding of Rome, which we sat down to watch, but I can imagine for most other people it is just a good place to shelter for the rain. As we had been to Pompeii or Herculaneum, we didn't learn that much more or see anything that blew our mind. However, if you are staying in Rome, would recommend.
Good views from top.. Fascinating history. Walking in the footsteps of the rich citizens of Ancient Rome. Well laid out and informative signing.
City Wonders Tour. This tour opens up areas normally closed to the public including additional fresco's and walking on original Roman cobbled floors. Great new attraction which is vast in size.

Beautiful and must visit. If you have some imagination, you can see the ancient Romans taking their baths here. What a work of art! Be sure to visit the museum too, where you can see some busts and some nice art. Oh, and also pick an orange from one of the trees along the road, they are lovely :-)

it's a hill of ruins. We visited the colosseum end with the same ticket (12€) the palatine hill although not all of time due to rain. It's was ok, nothing really special if you consider how many monuments rome offers.

Good place to visit. We ended up on Palatine Hill as part of a group tour we did...It was OKAY... I didn't find the ruins that impressively well preserved as other attractions.The information was interesting but I have to admit that I wasn't as excited as other parts. Actually I wished I would have seen other attractions / ruins instead of this one. It is purely a question of preference but I do believe that there is so much more to see in Rome; if I had to look at it again, I would have spent maybe 30 to 40 minutes there instead of an hour and 15 minutes, and I would have spent more time at the colosseum. That is simply my personal opinion...

Walk in the ruins of the Emperor's home. Explore the Palatine Hill to appreciate the grandeur of Rome's past and of course, its rulers. A guided tour or audio-guide enrich the experience and can draw your attention to interesting artefacts and archaeology.

Enjoy the emperor's view. We enjoyed our private tour of the Palatine Hill with our guide through Dark Rome tours. It was amazing to see the view which ancient emperors once enjoyed and the opulence they once enjoyed. The Circus Maximus is below toward the freeway; the view on the other side is the Forum.

Old and new. I was lucky to visit on a sunny day even though it was November but it wouldn't matter if it was a rainy day because there is so much to see that you can still enjoy the ambience of the place whatever the weather. Old Roman soldiers stand around looking splendid in their colourful uniforms and love to have their photo taken with you, however this cost money but if you want some fun it is well worth it makes for an even better visit. It makes you appreciate the old and new and realise that some of the ruins have been their for some 400-500 years old and still resemble the buildings that they once were, and you can image the chariots and the romans walking around in their togas etc. Well worth the visit.

Go for the view, stay for the history. Do not miss. The views of Rome are stunning, but closer up the views of the Colosseum and Forum are beyond belief. And when you listen to the history of how Rome was founded on this hill you will be more impressed.
A bit boring. Closer to colloseum. this can be sjipped considering the numerous places in Rome. More of ruins and bit boring

Full of character. This was part of a tour we did and was definitely worth looking around full of character, history and amazing buildings. As long as you have a good guide your experience should be a good 1, we did this as part of the coliseum tour through city wonders formally dark rome tours.

So much history to see. Palatine Hill is one of the 7 hills of Rome, and the place is just packed with history. It's great to see how well the Italians have preserved their history. Do give yourself a few hours here to enjoy it well.
Get fit whilst you view in wonder. Great place to overlook the Roman forum and ruins and also other parts of rome including accessing the national museum if you so wish

Get your Colosseum combo ticket here. A great way to avoid the ticket line at the Colosseum is to buy your combo ticket here. The line is sighificantly less and it is a great site. I really enjoyed walking your Palatine hill. Also great views of the city, Roman Forum and Colosseum.
Fantastic. Loved it, so much history! We had a tour guide and it was great as they explained everything. It could be quite confusing without a tour guide. Remember to take water in with you!
Full of history. Make sure you give yourself time to go through the whole area. It's amazing to walk through these historical sites. I tried getting lost so that to find new things!

Lovely and even Peaceful. Its sometimes hard to imagine what you're looking at and how it looked when it was complete, but this is a chance to have a leisurely stroll. Find the ruins of the church of St Sebastian and enjoy the peace and tranquility. The Palatine Hill is as understated as the Colloseum is overstated

Whole day activity. Take your time. Go through whole Foro Romano before starting with this (top of the hill).
There is a lot to see and explore. Only this upper area takes about 4 hours to go through approx.
There is a candy machine in the right corner towards st peters church.
Stunning! full of history and was fantastic to see. Stunning and really breath taking. Its so great to see and you could spend hours wandering around! The ruins are so well kept

Palatine Hill. This is an amazing tour of history. We did a small tour and it was well worth the extra money. There was so much information provided by the tour guide that we would not have known and would have missed. A must see.

I spent a whole day here then did the tour. I was totally amazed by this place with all the history and beauty. Thits is the best day of my holiday so far. I first walked around the top parameterfor about an hour then made my way down to get a ticket to go inside. I had to queue for about 40mins in Nov which isn't too bad. The ticket is € 9 and gives you access to the ruins and the Colosseum which is good value and valid for 2 days. I think you need the 2 days.There aren't a lot of descriptions in English so I recommend using an audio guide which you can borrow there or take a guided tour which will go into the history in depth. There is a lot to see and different areas of the hill to see. There is also an interesting museum in there that I think was opened by Mussolini in the 30s.Please note there is a lot of walking and climbing stairs so you need to have reasonable fitness levels. Also, don't be fooled into buying fake tickets outside of the venue, I have seen this end badly.Must see.

A must see while in Rome. The history at this location is amazing. The guides explain to you in every detail the history. It is awesome to see such great structures of the history of the world so well preserved.

Walking through I felt I was in ancient Rome. It's a must see, even sometimes there are no signs what you are looking at, but walking there among the ruins is unbelievable, give yourself plenty of time to enjoy it.

Relaxing. There are two entrances- one from Via Sacra, other from Via di San Gregorio - if you want to enjoy a little bit of the quiet nature, take this one. I recommend to visit Palatine Hill as early as possible, it has a different atmosphere. You can just sit down and enjoy either sights or beautifull views. There are small fountains with water there as well so no problem if you feel thirsty. In the small museum on the hill there is a fine bathroom as well.
spectacular. Signage and maps could be better so resign yourself to getting lost, but the exploration is part of the fun.

A must see!. Palentine Hill is a must see in Rome. If you don't have a tour guide booked, use an audio guide to help understand what you are looking at. This area should be done before you go to the Forum. Give yourself plenty of time and enjoy the views!

Amazing. Really amazing but it could be far better signed so you know what you're looking at. Also we tried to get an audioguide at 230pm and were told it was "too late" - what's the deal with that? Still amazingly huge - allow some hours.
Probably the best view of Rome !. No kidding, it is probably the best view of Rome. I won't want to leave there for a while. Roman Forum, Colosseum and rest of Rome. If you have time, don't miss it.

My favorite Roman site in Rome. This hill (1 of the 7 on which the city was built) is somewhat overlooked by the tourist hordes, and that's a good thing. It is large and sprawling and serves as somewhat of an oasis in a day of sights, crowds and traffic in Rome. The ruins are impressive enough but the views are the best part, Most noteworthy is the view from the edge of the gardens in the NW corner, looking out over the forum. You can see all that the forum has to offer much better from this vantage, than from walking through the forum itself

Good experience of ancient history. As other people have mentioned, this place is only 1/2 as cool if you do not have a guide, book or some way to learn more about the history as you walk through. The signs posted around the area just don't do it justice. I downloaded Rick Steve's audio guide before going and it was perfect. It walks you through all the major areas explaining all the history along the way. When i wasn't listening I would overhear the other tour guides saying the same history/facts but my knowledge was free. I would highly recommend!

Feel the magnificence. Do some research before or join a guided tour to get the most out of it, otherwise you only see stones scatered around. :) In the Colosseum's bookshop you can check books picturing the buildings and temples in their original beauty which are now ruins. Walking on Via Sacra and looking at the Arch of Titus and the rest of the remains you have a feeling of a great empire. The view from the Palatinus provides an overview of the historic centre of Rome. There are vendor machines for snacks, coffee and water on the site, marked 'self bar' on the signs. There is a combined ticket for Palatinus, Forum Romanum and Colosseum. The closest entrance to the Colosseum is temporarely closed.

Really good views!. As part of the tour of the coliseum, we also went to the Roman Forum and the Palatine Hill. It is a bit of an uphill walk ( but only a few mins) however, the effort is worth it. Gorgeous views from the top of the looking onto the Roman Forum directly below, coliseum to one of the sides and the rest of the city to the other side. Good location for decent panoramic photos (and selfies)
A very large place. Awesome architecture from many many years back. Lots of walking needed, can also be like a mini-hike.

Must visit.. for beautiful view of Rome City... You have to walk and walk to check out every beautiful corner of the hill. At the top of the hill was Beautiful Palatine Museum.. as per our guide it was supposed to be once residence of Mussolini. Don't miss the balcony, from where you can have beautiful view of complete Rome. Please keep your ticket safe as you can also visit Colosseum with the same ticket (and vice versa).

A must do.... We did this as part of a package with the coliseum. When you visit Rome you must go and see this. It's a good idea to get a guide (which there is plenty outside hanging around) so you know what you're looking at. There's lots of history here and could spend an easy half a day. Be prepared to walk a lot.

It is a must see though better in the fall or spring. Make sure you have really read up or have a good downloaded audio guide.Otherwise you wont get much out of it. We also managed to tag along with a university group for some of it .

Perfect visit in autumn sunshine. At first I thought it was sparse and with little information but we had only walked a little way into the actual interesting areas, lots to see both on top of the hill and down below at the Forum. Wild rabbits around to add interest.
Beautiful!. Put your walking boots on for this one!!! And get you cameras out! Beautiful......Scenic.....Historic.......Wow! Has to be done if in Rome!.....Awesome! :) x
Nice view and a lot of things to see. There is nice small park and lots of the remains of buildings from ancient times. From every corner of Palatine Hill you can see another famous monument.

Could be better . Great place to have a walk on nice day,unfortunately staff are terible,went to buy ticket asked for id if im under 25,if i am €7.50 if no ID then €12. Including collosoeum ticket which we didnt want but had to pay anyway.just be careful when buying of them make surre have a ID if under 25,i dont get it whats the difference over or under its same hill same walk
Amazing. Palatine Hill is one of those places that you must make time to visit, I was amazed at the place as were the whole party we went with. A must
Beautiful. Better to have a tour guide as the history here is very interesting, bit of a walk but well worth the effort.

Breathtaking, full of history - it's a must!. With spectacular views it is in my opinion one of the best places in Rome. The hill is overlooking historical Forum Romanum side as well as area of where Circus Maximus was. Such a great spot to be at, you can either spend a romantic day or afternoon there with your loved one or just sit down and learn all the amazing history of Rome while being surrounded by history itself.
Good to round out. When you see thr colosseum and forum this is good to round out you visit in the area for a more complete visit

Center of the Seven Hills. This is the center of the Seven Hills of Rome and one of the most ancient parts of the city by the Colosseum and the Forum. The tour was included in our admission to the Colosseum. Lots of ancient ruins - we had a great guide who told us a lot of very interesting stories about the areas we were visiting.
Roman Ruins. So there are a lot of Rome ruins with history plates saying what used to be there. Very little remains. But it is a nice walk for the imagination...
Magnificent. long climb up and wonderful views and history . We had a guide...always good to know the history and what you are looking at

A place of emperors overlooking the place of the people. We were undecided whether to visit the Palatine Hill, but I am so glad that we did as it was one of my favourite places of our entire trip. There is quite a walk up around 100 or so steps, but once you reach the plateau, it is worth it.We had a tour guide who took us from the Colosseum up to the Palatine Hill who was exceptional. Her name was Antonia and she was brilliant. She was incredibly knowledgeable and yes sassy and amusing at the same time meaning that we took more in than you may otherwise when information is delivered in a monotone. Antonia showed us around the Hill then led us to a terrace that overlooked the Forum, making it the perfect vantage point to see the important areas from above and so get a sense of the perspective and sheer size of the area. An excellent way to first get to trips with the Forum below.

Before Colosseum, come here. Not only you need more energy for this place but usually Colosseum is very busy and you wait a long time for a combined ticket. Before you climb up the Palatine Hill, there is little office which is usually not too busy and you can buy ticket for all the sites here for reasonable price.History is waiting for you on every step you take forward, so be ready with snack and drink. You an spend a whole day here wondering how did they manage to build this and how did it manage to stay here up till today. Just impressive!

Must see in Rome. This was our first visit to Rome and we went to Palantine hill as it is part of the area available to visit when you purchase a ticket to Colosseum. Historically fascinating; be prepared to walk...........would be a killer in summer with heat/humidity as we went in late Oct. and it was still very warm

History everywhere. We went on a walking tour around this area and it was fascinating. The history of the area was just incredible and gave you a real sense of how the Roman people lived hundred of years ago.
Impressive. Beautiful Place, Impressive History! Going around the palatine is very interesting and information boards are very useful. The museum is nice and informative.
Great for sport/history buffs. My boyfriend and I are both really into sports snd exercise so found these ruins really interesting. Bring a bottle of water and great walking shoes

history was made here... Just amazing to learn and see with your own eyes what happen many century ago!
Palatine hill is a beautiful place full of remembrance of the past long gone..
The place is easy to access and not too big to explore.. Close to other major sites in Rome.

Don't miss this walk thru the past. You must be a history and art lover to visit Roma! You can't miss the short walk from the Coliseum to the Palatine Hill. Use your imagination to walk these streets 1500 years ago or buy a little book sold by vendors that fills in the missing parts of the ruins you walk by. Take a drink from the public fountain Romans have used for 100's of years. I loved it.

Place for History Lovers. Although you must use your imagination to see the splendour of these imperial ruins, this place absolutely worth seeing anyway. There is a small museum of antiquities as well and artifacts are amazing. The entrance to Palatino is combined with the Forum and Colosseum and it is the best option to buy your tickets here to avoid queues at the Colosseum. Honestly, among Palatine, Forum and Colosseum, Palatine hill was my favourite although I expected the least.

Fantastic view, amazing ruins, use your imagination. Echoing sentiments about the Forum and Colosseum (it's the same ticket to enter all 3 anyway) - wonderful historical pieces but seriously lacking in terms of content provided on site - who built what, when and how. Not even a site map with information given at the ticket booth.PS - start your trip here - there is usually no line or a very short line at the ticket booth here, rather than lining up for a ticket at the colosseum - get the ticket here, then go to the Forum then the Colosseum
Interesting. Had a great time looking around palatine hill there is a lot to see and it got very tiring towards the end but keep going it worthwhile
Amazing!. So much history here. Awe inspiring to say the least to stand and walk through such an historic place that has been built on and built on over the decades.
Breathtaking. Since the tour guide gave as all the information about the buildings and the background of the history it is great to see this

Mid week break . Well worth it even though the climb up the steps from the ancient roman ruins burnt the legs out of me. There are some lovely statues on top of capital hill as well as a good view of the city. There is also a small stature on a pillar of Romulus and Remulus on the left side of the hill
Historically fun!. The structures are interesting but doesn't have much explanation. So, go with a tour guide for more info.
A walk in the History. One of the greatest sights in Rome , feels like you're walking the history of the great roman empire . Just a minute away from the colosseum

Palatine Hill. The hill overlooks the Forum, and is the best place to get an overview of the site. Buy your tickets at the Forum (NOT the Colosseum) and you can visit the Colosseum, Forum and Palatine Hill for one price
Beautiful Views. The entire Roman ruins area is fantastic and the views from Palatine Hill are fantastic looking down on Via Sacra.
Inspiring. Some of the best views over the city only beaten by the view from the roof of the Imperial Palace neraby

Palatin Hill. From the Pallatine hill you arrive by the hill of Vellia and the Via Sacra. it's amazing all the more as 2000 years old ruins; There was the house of Augustus and Livia also from the emperor Tiberius, coming after Augustus; Many parks and gardens; A legend said: here were found Romolus and Remus in a grotto.
lovely view. everything about this historical site is amazing... from the beautiful scenic view to the ancient yet partially preserved sites.

We wandered here for hours !!!. We booked combi-tickets for this and the Colosseum in advance, which turned out to be a great investment. The Forum and Palatine Hill are huge, so you can really spend hours here. The views from the top platforms are wonderful, as are the many little corners where you can sit and take a break. For me, the highlight was the triumph arch which shows the Romans sacking the Jewish Temple in Jerusalem - an act which still has ramifications today! ... One piece of advice: take food and drink with you. Once they've got your money and have pushed you through the gate, there's virtually nothing for you to buy.

From the Iron Age to present. This is included in your entry to the colosseum but go early. It is an incredible feeling walking through the ruins. The museum is small but there are many artifacts and it tells the story dating back to the Iron Age. Absolutely incredible but it is a long day to see the sights and the lines are long if you don't get there early. We did the colosseum one day and arrived at the opening of the hill the next.
Ancient Rome. Very interesting area of very old Roman building remains and great views around the city. Great photo opportunities.

Another must see attraction in Rome. Palatine Hill is located a couple of blocks west of the Colosseum (a very short walk) near the center of Rome. It is the centermost hill of the Seven Hills of Rome. It is also located north of Circus Maximus and south of the Roman Forum. According to an old myth, this is the hill where Romulus and Remus were found and eventually founded Rome. The city was named after Romulus after he killed his brother. During an early period of Roman history several Emperors built palaces on the hill (you can still see the ruins) and the word palace comes from these buildings on Palatine Hill.I visited this amazing historical hill and the remains of an ancient palace (or palaces) with my wife and daughter on a Monday morning in mid-March and really enjoyed it. We hired a tour guide who seemed to know everything about this area and pointed out every important spot and ruin. Without his help it would have been a little confusing since most of the structures were only partially standing. I highly recommend that you tour this area with an experienced guide. I enjoyed the great views of Rome at the top and also enjoyed learning about the massive palace that was here.We bought a combination ticket for about 12 Euros which allowed us to visit the Colosseum, Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum. It was easier purchasing the ticket in the morning at the Palatine Hill location since there was no line at all. Make sure you keep track of your ticket as you will need to show it a second time when you get to the Colosseum (I just jammed it into my pocket and thought I had lost it).Overall I thought Palatine Hill was amazing and think it is another must see attraction in Rome. Go early to avoid the crowds.

Bad guide makes bad visit. Unfortunatly, we've got a real bad guide to visit the palatine. Her french was OK but she was not abble to bring us feeling the past life of this place. For sure I will do it again, to be sure this place is the best of past Romain's life.

A must see. The glory of Rom all started here. IT's mostly ruins so you need an imagination to appreciate it. I highly recommend getting a tour guide - there is so much history that the guide books don't fully capture.

Its like travelling back in time.. This is probably the largest and oldest historical preservation site I have visited so far. Take a day and spend time here. If you can may be get the audio guide or an actual guide if you can afford it.
Very interesting site. This was a great deal of walking on uneven terrain. The history of the site was very interesting. Would recommend if you are fit.

Amazing - Probably my favourite part of Rome. Amazingly beautiful! So much to see & take in we could have spent the whole day there. The ruins & views are breathtaking, it is a must see if you visit Rome but give yourself a good half a day to really appreciate the place & not to miss any of it.

Wow. History history and more history, In a beautiful setting after seeing the colosseum a walk around this stunning array of ruins is just the right way to wind down and let your imagination run free. But make sure you have good walking shoes on and plenty of water with you, If you are not able to walk it would be very hard going.
So much to see. Bear in mind when much of this was built most of the rest of the world at that time were still living in huts. Wonderful remains of buildings to look at.

Domus Romani. First off, it's WAY bigger than you think and it's much harder and more tiring to walk it. That said, it's spectacular. Our tour was the one tour that day allowed in the Houses of Augustus and Livia, and I am so glad to have seen this fantastic imperial residences. Gorgeous frescoes, but the rooms much smaller and humbler than you expect: Augustus was that kind of man and even though an emperor chose to live in a humble fashion. The rest of the Palatino was lovely also, but that was the best. Don't forget to fill up your water bottle with the cold, fresh, clean water available at a spring tap.
Great. Together with the Colloseum a great experience. A hands on look at the great Empire. Amazing! What a place. Rome is our favourite place in the world! All roads lead to.....
A must see for any visit to Rome.. This is the heart of this great city. Its ancient city. October is a great time to visit when it isn't so hot.
2000 + years of history in a small, compact area. The Palatine Hill, hoe to the Roman Emperors is a place where you can glimpses of the glorious past of Rome at the time of Romans

What to Expect and How to See It. My wife and I visited the Palatine Hill and the Forum (the two are contiguous) in late October. They are major Rome attractions and well worth visiting. The two form a large, North-South oriented rectangle with the Palatine covering the bottom (South) three quarters, the Forum on the North. There are entrances (with ticket booths) at the bottom of the Palatine from Via di San Gregorio and to the Forum on the North from the Via dei Fori Imperiali. These are served by different bus lines. Tickets, which cost 12 Euros each, include the Palatine, the Forum, and the Colloseum, and are good for entrance on two successive days.The Palatine has ruins of the large buildings that housed emperors and other high-ranking Romans, a small Fascist-era museum with displays that exhibit discoveries made during excavations, and excellent views over the city. The Forum, in turn, was the political, religious, and commercial center of ancient Rome. The remains of the early buildings, plus the Arch of Titus, give a good idea of what a thriving and important place this once was. The Colosseum is separate and a short distance to the East of the Forum. Since Palatine paths can be steep, and surfaces rough, this is not a place for anyone whose walking is impaired. Restrooms are available.On our first day we took Bus #80 from Largo Argentina to the Palatine in the morning, bought our tickets, and spent two to three hours exploring before leaving for lunch. On the second day, we came back to see the rest of the Palatine... we had covered the southern two-thirds ... and the Forum. Sorry, we were told at the entrance, but our tickets were good for only one entrance to the Palatine/Forum and only one to the Colosseum. There were no signs at the entrance or indication on the tickets that this was the case. Gotcha! Since we did not want to ruin a precious day in Rome, we paid another 24 Euros for a second entrance and then saw the rest of the Palatine and the Forum.With the benefit of hindsight, we would have planned our Palatine/Forum trip differently. (We were not interested in seeing the Colloseum). Since the two are open from early morning (8:30 a.m.) to dusk, we would have brought food and something to drink, started earlier in the morning, entered by the same Palatine entrance, had lunch at the other end of the Palatine before descending to the Forum, and left by the Forum entrance/exit which is a fifteen-twenty minute walk to the Large Argentina and closer to the center of Rome and our hotel.

Exceeded expectation. Definitely worth a visit. We enjoyed it more than The Forum. You could get a feel of how the wealthy lived. Lovely peaceful gardens and great views of Rome. We were there around 9.30 - 10.00 am and it was fairly tourist free. Entrance is only available through the V Di San Gregorio as the one nearest the Colosseum is temporarily closed.

Where the Movers and Shakers of ancient Rome lived. After the mayhem of The Colosseum this was a welcome green space and relatively quiet although we visited in November. Extensive remaining ruins give a real feeling of how it might have been

Wow..... Visited here as part of the Colloseum ticket. Amazing views, ruins and the weather was fantastic. We didn't take a tour guide but walked around at our leisure absorbing the sights. Comfy shoes is a must and take water bottle, there are water fountains to fill up with on the way round. There are drink and snack stations at various places. Loved it here

So much to see, so little time. A must see when in Rome. I laze around the area, stopping once in a while to snap pictures and admire the view. Some of the areas were so secluded, it made me feel like I was in ancient Rome. I recommend planning your time properly as 2 hours wasn't enough for me to explore the whole area Please wear comfortable shoes as the walkways are rough and uneven. I entered using a roma pass and skipped through the lines.
Monument!. Is just right next to Colosseum. Worth seeing it though. Advisable to get the ticket prior to the visit to avoid long queue.
More than I thought. The museum building seems to be the only toilet and it had huge lines! The site is very big and you can walk about at leisure. Many signs provide info in English.
Really fascinating site. This was good and was included in our fast track Colosseum ticket. Lots of archaeological ruins in what was the centre of ancient Rome. Good site.

Fabulous History!. We were amazed by the history of the Palatine Hill. We did a guided tour that included the Coloseum, Roman Forum and concluded at Palatine Hill. The tour pointed out so much more than we'd have discovered on our own. You got a true feel for how rulers lived in those days.

Take a guide. Take a guide who can show you the place in perspective. The place is on a hill and probably the most ancient part of Rome. Of course Mussolini built an ugly structure there but then it is also about the hills history! You can visit the Roman from from this place and one ticket takes care of the Palatine hill and Roman Forum.

Roma è qui. Here Rome was born, here you can feel all its past present and future, here you can see the magnificence of emperors palaces and the wide overview of who first built the city on this hill. If you wanto to visit Rome you have to start from Palatin hill because all began here!!!

Best tour guide made for an incredible experience!. Were stroke luck with our tour guide Jonathan Silvestri, He was absolutely amazing! He made the tour so memorable and was definitely one of my holiday highlights! If you luck out too.. I definitely recommend his underground tour of Rome... its unbelievable! :)
Soo much history. This place is fantastic for those wanting to know about the history. We got the audio guided tour and it was very useful. Be prepared to walk a lot and wear sturdy shoes.
Wow. I have waited half a lifetime to see this. Lots of restoration needed but you can close your eyes and feel the bustling city it was. Such beautiful architecture and attention to detail.

Palatine Hill, Roman Forum, and Colosseum. We bought tickets for the three events and were told that we had 2 days with which to see them. Previous reviews that I read recommended to start at Palatine Hill which takes you up to a beautiful overlook of the Roman Forum. The tour was amazing and way better than thought it would be. The only problem was that by the time we got down to the Forum, we (especially our kids) were really hungry so we left to get lunch without spending anywhere near the amount of time I wanted to spend in the Forum which was the best part. We went to our scheduled tour of Colosseum and by the time we were done it was evening and planned to go back to the Forum next day. Unfortunately, they told us that you could only do the Colosseum one day and Palatine Hill/Forum the other day, but can't go to same place twice. I was thoroughly disgusted since the Forum was basically what I traveled across the world to see and only saw 15 minutes of it! My recommendation is to start your day at the Forum FIRST, and then make your way up Palatine Hill, because there is no food unless you leave the gates. You might find yourself spending more time on Palatine Hill than you realize since a lot to see and very spread out, whereas the Forum is not as large with better preserved buildings so see it when your fresh!
A full day's outing!. Wonderful location, loads of walking around. Keep a watch out for pickpockets! Amazing architecture well worth a visit

Got some extra space? Build something amazing!. You must see this! the area around the Forum is amazing, the views are stunning, and you will make memories you will never forget. Wear comfortable shoes, and don't forget to eat gelato before and after you see this sight!
WOW again!. WOW again! Awesome to view the ruins of the eternal city. I've read about this all my life and I'm amazed to really view this ancient place.

I didn't even know.... What a story behind this area! The architecture of Rome simply cannot be appreciated unless visited in person. We purchased an Omnia Pass that gave us access to transportation, the Vatican, Colosseum and a few other perks and it was well worth it. I'd also highly advise paying the extra 15 EUR for combined guided tour of the Colosseum and Palatine Hill. You will learn so much more from the guides than the audio or books! We had no idea of the history and story behind Palatine Hill.

Yes Go. The hill is huge with trails for wandering. We visited Rome 11 years ago and the hill was still being excavated then. There is a small museum there that is worth visiting. Take a day for the Hill, the Forum and the Colusium.

Beautiful in the evening as the sun is setting. After visiting the colosseum we strolled over to Palatine Hill just as the sun was setting. It was beautiful. The birds were flying around by the thousands and chirping wildly. The views were awesome.

Interesting, but with a guide. Unless you do a lot of homework this site should be seen with a guide otherwise the significance of the remains will be lost on the viewer. There's a ton to see and it's all very interesting. Splurge on a guide!

Okay for a quick visit. This place was okay for a quick stop on out guided bus tour, could have taken it or left it to be honest. However I suspect that this may be down to the fact that I was a bit overloaded with historical information in one day. I would recommend that if you have time to kill then you should pay this place a visit, if you are short of time then leave it off and spend the time elsewhere
Amazing. Couple a trip hear with the Coliseum and its a fantastic day spent. Not only all the history but stunning views of Rome also.

Just amazing!. We have wandered here for a couple of hours and taken our time to admire the ruins and beautiful architectural constructions. We were also blessed with such beautiful weather that we were able to take amazing pictures of quite everything. We visited just after three o'clock in the afternoon on a Saturday and it proved to be worth it, since it was less crowded and you needn't to be crushed to take a decent picture.
Too good. The Roman Fort and the Palatine Hill are clubbed together. The ticket for the Collossium can be used for the entry to this place. Just Walk down the road and spend your time with leisure.

awesome! must see and walk all the ruins.. The colloseum was great but palatine hill was excellant. The history and the views are just fantastic. Get your ticket at pallentine hill for colloseum and forum, walk the colloseum first and then enjoy pallentine hill, well worth the visit.

Included in our tout of the Colosseum-great views from up here. Wonderful views,and walking down on the Sacred Road and imagining what it would have looked like at the time..not too crowded either. Well worth the time

Another stunning area of Roman architecture. You could spend days just wandering round all the ruins a X looking at the architecture in this area of Rome, there are a collection of places all very near to each their, the Palatine Hill, Circus Maximus, The Forum and the Colosseum, all truly amazing experiences for any age. Wonderful
Vast Complex. Quieter in November, would expect it to be very hot in summer. Good walking shoes needed here. Toilets at entrance and the museum.

Fascinating. Leave plenty of time to explore!. So much to see, and just awe-inspiring. A real highlight of our trip. Recommend getting the ticket which allows you into the Forum, Paletine Hill and Colloseum - and ideally do it over 2 days rather than rushing around in one go. We didn't get a guide, so we just wandered around and took our time taking it all in. Spectacular.

Great views over the Forum. This was part of our Colosseum visit, but ensure that you have on comfortable walking shoes and a bottle of water. We spent about 45 minutes walking through the ruins, the views are spectacular, so pleased that we had a guide with us to explain ruins, a must visit during any trip to Rome
Great views. If you must conserve you energy, then you could probably miss, quite a climb up and once on top just more ruins, but great overview of forum.
Lots of walking. A good tour guide makes this site come alive. We had an excellent tour guide. For obvious reasons it's a ruin and leaves a bit for the imagination.

Both places are marvelous!. True and actual ruins of the Roman empire and where the emperors lived; in front of Coliseum, you can see and walk around the old city, where there was houses and commerce, some places still being discovered.

Lovely views, interesting history. A great place to walk around with some lovely views of the city and down to the Forum. There's a lot to see up here and it can be easy to miss things - you can spend quite a while up here if you want to read all the information signs and spend time enjoying the views.
History. A great spot to revel in all the history that surrounds Rome. We went with a tour group and enjoyed the commentary.

Lots of walking with great results. This site is part of the Forum and you see both together but make sure you wear your walking shoes. I love walking around these type of sites and just think you could be walking in Julius Caesar foot steps.

The Layers of Rome. This was such an interesting area to see. From on top of the Palatine Hill to the Roman Forum there is history around every corner. We started on the Palatine Hill and worked our way down.

Well worth the walk. Palatine hill is a very nice place to visit on sunny day (avoid at rain) and (TIP!) offers the opportunity to skip all the ticket lines for Colosseum as ticket for Palatine Hill also includes Colosseum!You can start to get the feeling for ancient Rome once in there as there really are some beautiful carvings on some of the remains. Also very impressive columns and Arches.Once very famous people walked on those stones and now here you are walking on the same path!

Fascinating. You need a full day for this site,12 euros gets both Palatine Hill and Colosseum, 2 day consecutive ticket, Get the ticket from Palatine as the line is shorter and no need to que again at the Colosseum,Lots to see, they've uncovered an impressive amount in the last 10 years. beautifully lit and well worth finding a good vantage point to view at night No food so eat before you go
Lovely. A must if you visit Rome.A combined ticket gives you entry to the Colosseum, the Forum and Palatine Hill
What you come to Rome for. It is ruins like this which brings people to Rome, it is so historically amazing to find ruins like this, worth a visit
Brilliant views over the Forum and Rome. Palatine Hill has so much to offer. From the history of the grounds to views over the Forum and Rome it is a must. We visited with Dark Rome Tours.

The Most Breathtaking View of The Eternal City. Palatine Hill beholds, honestly, the most beautiful view of Rome. I suggest climbing up at Golden Hour (sunset) to view and ponder The Colosseum and The Roman Forum.
Simply amazing. Lots to see and wonderful experience. Amazing that's it's all still around. Feels so serine and peaceful

Excellent view of the Roman Forum. From here you can see the whole forum and get your bearings before walking down into the ruins. The site of the Vestal Virgins is clear from here otherwise there's a chance you could miss it if you were to just explore at ground level.

lots of ruins. well you ceratinly need your imagination how the place looked like in it's time-otherwise it's just lots of ancient bricks.on top can see the circus maximus when Ben Hur was racing-again imagination is the key issue hereand don't do this in the summer unless you are a masochist!

It's true about Rome, it is an outdoor museum!. Wow so much to see and it goes on and on. Don't bother with the tour guides, I used Viator and they rushed me through with very little historical information and no time for pictures and trust me this is a place you will want to take pictures!
Majesterial. A lovely place to spend an afternoon wandering around. It is so close to other sites you can pop in a few must sees to this visit.

Enjoyable day. We visited 8yrs ago with limited time, so this time we made sure we saw everything we possibly could,visit the museum about Palitine Hill and watch the film (with subtitles) and then go and explore. Be prepared to walk on very uneven surfaces and explore every nook and cranny. A very informative day out on how Rome came about.
A day is not enough. Went here after the Colloseum and honestly could have spent another 2 hours there that day. More than worth the 12eur for this and Colloseum.
Fantastic Views across the city and down into the Forum. Combined ticket with the Forum and the Colosseum. Fantastic views down into the Forum, so fascinating to be part of antiquity

et tu, Brute. Fascinating to visit the site of so much history learned in school! To fully appreciate it, its best to have a good guide who can answer questions, otherwise it could appear just a pile of old stones. For me to visit the ruins of the actual Roman Senate and the spot where Julius Caesar, Augustus Caesar, Mark Anthony et al walked and spoke was awe inspiring

Hurry up, the Emperor's road is open. You can get here once you visit the Roman Foro. So, if you are going to the Foro, make a point of climbing up to the Hill or taking the Emperor's road- opened until January 20th, 2016 only. It is on the same ticket, that is, no separate ticket needed.
Beautiful view . Crossroads, a Hill and excellent point of view towards the Roman Forum, a convenient place to stop for a snack and rest on the steps. Wonderful views and more art like all over Rome.

Same area of Colosseum!! . Colosseum, Palatine Hill and other attractions are close to each other. Just walking there make you feel the greatness of Rome's history... Amazing !!From the Wikipedia: The Palatine Hill (Latin: Collis Palatium or Mons Palatinus; Italian: Palatino, IPA: [päläˈt̪iːno]) is the centermost of the Seven Hills of Rome and is one of the most ancient parts of the city. It stands 40 meters above the Forum Romanum, looking down upon it on one side, and upon the Circus Maximus on the other.It is the etymological origin of the word "palace" and its cognates in other languages (Italian "Palazzo", French "Palais", German "Palast", etc.).

A quiet stroll. When we stay in Rome, we always visit the Palatine hill. The view is superb and even with many tourists around, it's so quiet. I get a special feeling when I walk around here where Emperor Augustus and Livia once lived.
A walk through ancient Rome. Palatine Hill has to be the best place to visit in all of Rome. As you walk through the streets you can really imagine you are walking in ancient Rome.
Not to be missed. Visited on a sunny day. Loved the histor attached to venue. Great views of the city. Highly recommended

Very tranquil . We walked through the Palatine Hill after visiting the Roman Forum.. It was very peaceful and was as though you were somewhere else despite being in the middle of the city.. Would recommend going at sunset to get some fantastic pictures
Loved it. I was never so close to any ruins except in Mexico. this place makes you feel part of it, tons of history in every piece and corner.
Great views. Not too expensive at all to get ticket for roman forum/palatine hill/ colosseum. Beautiful views when you get to top of palatine hill! Pretty walk up.
So much to see. Great place to visit when in Rome as so much to see. There are people working very hard to preserve this fantastic site.

Archaeological site. You may explore this site by taking the main road leading to the Colosseum from piazza venezia.
No need to book for a tour with the Colosseum like many travel agents propose.
It is an open air archaeological site...
Very nice & well explained by the briefing panel boards they displayed next each of the ruins.
Ancient Rome. Its good to get a guide to get familiar with the soul of this ancient place. Have a detail stroll around Farnese gardens, ancient ruins and Domus Flavia.
Great view over the city!. A really nice place to take a breath and enjoy the city and the view. Lots of shade and a nice place to relax
Historically interesting, but... . It's little more than rubble. Only interesting if you know what you're looking at. Reading the descriptions barely helps visualise what the structures used to be.
Wonderful collection of history. Particularly enjoyed the House of the Vestal Virgins and their adjoining Temple. There is so much to take in at Palatine Hill you really need a full day.

Delightful fragrances & fabulous views await!. Get your three stop ticket at the Forum then walk up to see Palatine Hill. Lastly stop in at the Colosseum. Less lines if you do them in this order. TIP: Download a free audio tour beforehand. That way you can enjoy Free Info without needing WIFI.

Refreshing place. We have visited Palatine Hill after Colosseum and it was refreshing here. Less people, a lot of trees and benches to sit and quietly soak up the atmosphere. Really nice to see the place where the highest representatives of an ancient Roman empire lived. We spent 1.5 hours here just visiting some quiet places and terrace with famous view down to Roman Forum.

History Histroy amazing. The times our ancestors lived in were amazing and being here made you really feel part of the past. One codul just imagine the what it was like to live in those times with the beautiful architecture a

A must visit!!. Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum are a must visit! Make sure you wear flat walking shoes as the terrain is uneven! It is breathtaking to see all the remains. Take a walk up Palatine hill and look down over the archaeological site! I would recommend you buy a guide book than use a living guide as they can make it an expensive day out and they rush you through the site at 90 miles an hour!! So beware of that fact! Queues were about 10 minutes long max.
A must see. A great place to visit. Go to the top of the hill first and look down on the Forum.Leave a couple of hours to walk around. So many photo opportunities and areas to keep you interested.

Another great place. Next to the coliseum. I can only repeat what I have said about the other sites we visited. Very historical and educational.We only had a limited time. You definitely need to spend a few hours here.

A Historical Hike in Palatine Hill. Palatine Hill is a normal tourist destination in Rome. One can spend half a day exploring the hilly area and marvel at all the historical landmarks within walking distance from each other. The Colisseum with is undergoing restoration is the most massive structure and will take hours to get in due to the long lines. It was a hot summer day with nearly 100 degrees fahrenheit. Despite wearing comfortable clothes of blue denims and tees, one can feel the scorching heat of the sun. However, we covered most of the landmarks including the Arc of Constantinope and the ruins of the Roman Forum

View Rome from the Palatine Hill ..... From atop one of the most famous hills in Rome you'll have grand vistas of the eternal city below you - the forum, coliseum and more. Plenty of interesting historical sights up on the hill to visit as well. Lots of perfect photo op views. ...

A good introduction to Rome.. We visited this large area before the Colosseum.The ticket was included with the Colosseum ticket and you are allowed two days for your visits.It is a large area, and you can roam around freely.On the hilltop is a small museum with handy loos.The best part was a short slide show which shows how the area may have looked with all the fabulous homes.It really brought it to life.It rained a lot on our first visit.We managed to visit again as it is free the first Sunday of each month ,as are other places.

Beautiful Views and Amazing History. Fabulous. Get tickets at your hotel so you don't have to stand in line. You can enjoy the Hill and the Colosseum on the same ticket. Get there early in the day because it is less crowded.

Beautiful and Peaceful. Gorgeous views of the rest of the city, amazing ancient buildings, amazingly not over crowded. We went right after the Colosseum and got there at about 2:30, definitely needed more time as they closed at 4:30 thus time of the year. We should also probably go the walking audio so we don't need to stop and read so frequently.

Huge area. Some of the photos from other reviewers are actually the Forum rather than Palatine Hill. It is confusing as one leads to the other. The hill is littered with huge ruins of Roman Palaces and wonderful views. There is a rather uninspiring museum and very poor toilets (Rome doesn't seem to bother with toilet seats). We wished we had bought food with us as there is none to buy and there is lots to see. Not quite as impressive as the Forum but still worth a visit.

Massive Roman ruins. Site closes early, not suitable for wheelchairs. Very limited sign posts to show route. As a ruin it is huge and you can easily make out the forums and main buildings.no shelter if it rains.As for all tourist attractions lots of annoying hawkers.

Where Rome Started. We were on a tour with Walks of Italy, which I highly recommend. The archaeologist guide told us about the history beginning in 753 B.C. Just amazing. Wish we had more time to spend exploring the building. Maybe next trip.

Top place - but come prepared!. A magnificent place to be. So full of history. Walking can be tough if you're not fit enough, particularly in heat, but worth every drop of sweat. It's a layered cake of so many history periods, so well worth doing some homework beforehand and reading up on it so you can truly appreciate what it is that you see and walk on. I come there every time I visit Rome.

Disappointment. I had high expectations of Palatine Hill and it has such potential. I rented the audio guide, which I always enjoy, but this audio guide was horrible. Disjointed, poorly organized and not well done at all left me confused at what I was seeing. This is a shame because with a good audio guide Palatine Hill would be a top draw.

Photographer's Dream!. Took advantage of this attraction as entry was included in The Colosseum ticket. A fantastic size allowing you to roam freely and absorb the wonderful views over The Eternal City. A little uneven in areas so flat shoes required. Tours and audio available if required but after a long day sightseeing we just enjoyed wandering around letting our imaginations wander back in time. A great area too for children to explore and roam around safely - a haven from the crowded and noisy city!

Allow a day. There is an enormous area here, and you will need time to get your bearings. Allow the best part of a day to even try to do justice to this site. Well worth the ticket price to get up close and personal with the remains of Ancient Rome. Just remember to see all you want before leaving the site as they don't do re-entries. There are WCs but nothing much in the way of places to eat and drink. Might be worth taking something with you.
Good Views. A lot of walking but a lot less crowded the further in you walk! The views are stunning, and there's some interesting ruins to see along the way.
Interesting. We bought fast track tickets which helped miss the long lines. We hired the audio tour guide which are very informative and allows you to go at your own pace.

If you like history this is a must. My family and I visited the area and were awed by the monuments and the history that accompanied them. There are audio guides that can be purchased. These are very helpful. We spent too much time higher up on the hill and really should have spent much more time lower down...where closer examination of inscriptions seems easier. We didn't get a guided tour but that might be a good idea...as we over heard guides once in a while and they certainly seemed to know their stuff. Will do that on a return visit. All in all worthwhile.
Holiday visit. This place is amazing, step back in time and appreciate the technology that the Romans had to construct these buildings, walk where the Romans walked a must to visit.
Time travel!. To see, to touch, to envision the daily lives of the ancient Romans is as close to time travel as I am likely to get and I loved it!
Breathtaking views. Absolutely breathtaking views. Beautiful park setting with fountains and views of the city. Ceasars palace

Don't miss this! Easy to combine with a trip to the Colosseum. This place is a must see place. It is easy to combine it with a trip to the Colosseum.
We did use a tour guide at this place and we think it was worth it because otherwise it would be hard to imagine what these ruins were like in ancient times.
