Great!!!!. We really enjoyed this attraction, it was clean, spacious and well worth a visit. It was great to walk around without being squashed and pushed along. It is spacious enough to accommodate everyone comfortably. The views are wonderful and dont forget camera!!
So impressive. Palatine HIll is so impressive with its size, and history. considering this was a residence the size is amazing. And so is the surrounding area.

A historic stroll near the Colosseum. My husband and I visited Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum after the Colosseum - all neighboring attractions in the ancient part of the City. You can view the Roman Forum from this open air museum, and it's a great vantage point to take photos. It's a great place to visit on a nice, sunny day - don't bother visiting if it's raining. Wear comfortable walking shoes and expect to stay for under an hour if you're traveling without a guide.

After Colosseum must go!. After the Colosseum this is somewhere you have to go! Very large area for the price, learn all the history with a guided tour or audio guide pre downloaded! You learn all about the history of the area and see all the ruins very cultural a must see if your in Rome!

Even the clouds look heavenly from up here.. One of the most ancient parts of the city and where Romulus directed the first settlers to build their huts. The views of the Forum at its feet and the Circus Maximus on the opposite side are stunning. Excellent perspectives for all budding Landscape Photographers.

Lovely walk through time with great views. We did Palatine Hill, Forum and Colosseum in half a day covered by the Roma Pass. Great views from the rose garden at the top over the whole of Rome. Wandered around taking photos and enjoying the views. Takes you back in time.
Where the Emperors lived. this was the 2nd part of our Colosseum tour and it was very interesting. Got to learn about various emperors and how they lived.

Gorgeous. went here because a ticket to the colloseum also lets you visit here. we went just before sunset (when it closes) which was a great time to visit - less crowded and cooler. great site for photographs

Nice view. We had a great day with Our tour guide, sightseeing Palatine hill and the Colosseum.Lots of great first hand information,and no que lines on all locations.You can try to go alone just for the view,but i really recomend a guided tour for more insights.

Nice walk . We arrived in Rome late Sunday and decided to walk up Palatine Hill as the forum was closed. Quite a steep hill but great views beware once you get to tge top it leads to a dead end and you have to walk back down but worth it for grest views
Is near Colosseum. Great for historical view and photos. Take wather with you, in summer is quite hot. On one ticket can be seen all site, covered by RomaPass

It's a lot.... We did the Colosseum, the Forum and Palatine Hill all in a three hour tour. I believe this place deserves some time to itself to just wander around and take it all in. It would be a great place to just have a picnic in and I for one would love to paint or draw while there trying to capture the antiquity of it all. Very cool place in the heart of a somewhat modern city.

impressive and inspiring!. In the heat of the day, this place frees the imagination to consider what life had been like in ancient days. Spectacular views and being able to 'CONNECT' the different areas... circus massive with the grand palace on the hill was amazing.

Great if its dry ;-). We should have visited the day before or after as the day we went it was raining so we rushed round and missed a lot. Its amazing to walk round and see the different ruins, you get a real feel of how Rome was thousands of years ago.
Luxury of the old romans. Really worth visiting to see how rich these people were. Tour is well indicated and the site is very large, so you still breath while visiting it.
Majestic!. This place takes you back in time and the rich history surrounding you will definitely make you want to go back too! A must visit to everyone

Great Views of the Forum and Colloseum. Any view i can have of ancient Rome is worth a visit. You have great views while here and a great place to take some pictures. We were here as part of night tour we took to get into the colloseum and i am glad we took this walk too becuase the views and information from the tour guide are well worth it. This part was done before our entrance into the collseum so it was done while it was still light out. Many people doing it on their own were trying to listen in to our guide to get information. If you do it on your own, download Rick Steves walking tour and you should get plenty of infomraiton while you are walking through.
2 days in Rome . Beautiful and more enjoyable than ruins. Picnic lunch if you can as it really deserves an afternoon to wander about.

Wonderful Walk Through Time. Our tickets to the Colosseum included entry to the Roman Forum and the Palatine Hill; also got a small map in Italian and English. It was a cold day in December and had rained heavily the night before, so we had to dodge puddles and mud. But even with the rain and cold, this was a wonderful walk through time. According to Roman mythology, the Palatine Hill was the location of the cave where Romulus and Remus were found by a she-wolf. The Palatine is one of the seven hills of Rome and stands 40 meters above the Forum. You will see beautiful views of the city from here. I recommend that you google this site before a visit and read up on what you will be seeing; this may enhance your enjoyment.

Great entryway into the Colosseum & Forum. The residential district for the elite of Republican and Imperial Rome. Home to Nero's Palace where he watched Rome burn, it still provides fantastic views over the ruins of Rome's glory days.The paths and steps are worn and uneven in places so be careful and wear sensible footwear. There are many resources available to aid in understanding the area for people from a variety of language backgrounds including guide books, audio guides and guided tours. My wife and I chose to go at our own pace and make use of the information displays that were in both English & Italian. The Farnese Gardens were a treat providing a green oasis of shade on a warm day.Get your tickets either at the entrance to the Forum or the Palantine and it also includes the Colesseum. If you miss any of the 3 attractions listed on the ticket you can see it the following day but you can't return to one you've already entered. We did the Forum & Palantine and gave our feet a rest before skipping the line at the Colosseum the next morning. (We actually snuck up to St Peter in Chains to see Michelangelo's Moses first as it's very close when getting off the Metro.)

A Pleasant Place to Walk. This is an ideal place to find a look up for photos of the city of Rome. Make sure you visit all the nooks and cranies. There is a free Museum here in the building where Mussolini once live. It is small but worth a visit.

Lovely and peacful with impressive views.. Start here with a €12 ticket for the big three. Palatine Hill, Roman Forum and Coliseum. Reduced prices available for some categories ofEU citizen. Free to all on first Sunday of each month.
Astonishing moments. very impressive to see the old city of Rome. You feel like being set back in time. It is huge!I can only recommend to visit this nice pace. Take some water with you.

Amazing. This area including the Forum just blew me away. The size of the areas combined are huge and the ruins are plentiful. We spent hours walking around. Well worth it. Comfortable shoes, water and maybe a hat if it's hot.

A secret delight. We came on this jewel by accident. At the top of the hill is a small church and monastery. We went on a tour of both. The view from the monastery's garden down on the coliseum was incredible.
Spectacular!. No visit to Rome is complete without touring the Palatine Hill. Suggest going with a tour guide to really enhance the experience and to understand what you are seeing.

Great value . I used this as a quick way to jump the queue to the colessum. I was surprised how good palatine hill and the roman forum was. I would suggest that you do not use this as a short cut and save 3 hours for the worth while wander.
1.Take water
2.Take fruit.
3.Wear walking shoes.

Great view of ancient Rome. I enjoyed this portion of Rome, seeing many of the different ruins and the location of where emperors would speak to the people. This is another self guided tour that you do not need to pay extra for.
Amazing!. Walking through ancient ruins, where the emperors walked, amazing pictures from a terrace! That's what i really wanted to do, and so worth it!
Beautiful historical site. We loved exploring this site. We had booked a guide, so that added to the experience, but absolutely, a must site to visit while in Rome.
Awesome view from ancient hills. After a Roman forum trip, go to the top of the hills and see the awesome view of Rome. You will be fascinated.
Crowded. Our ticket to the Colosseum included the Palatine Hill. After visiting the Forum first, we were quite tired and it was nice to find somewhere to sit. This would be a good place for a picnic.

A good way to beat the queue for Colosseum tickets. Some interesting ruins set in a pleasant park. It takes such a long time to walk around, we gave up half way. BONUS - If you buy a ticket here (where the queues are smaller) it also allows access to the Colosseum.

Great views of the Roman Forum and Rome below. If you have the time this is a great place to visit directly from the Roman Forum. Climb up the hill and wander around the ruins. There are great views of Rome and the forum below. Some nice gardens and places to sit and ponder ancient Rome. Well worth the visit if you have the time.
Walk through ancient history. You will be walking on the same hill where Romulus and Remus were found by the she-wolf, on the stones as Augustus and Tiberius

An impressive Roman ruin. Part of the joint ticket with the Forum and Colosseum, this is perhaps the least busy, but as impressive in its scale.Toured along with the Forum you might spend 2 to 4 hours in both. Keep in mind then that the toilets are very limited and are a disgrace (no flush when we were there) and there are no refreshments other than water fountains. Go prepared!

Must see!. Hard to believe this is in the middle of Roma! Yes, history in the middle of Roma. Very close to other places of interest you can walk to the collesium or Vitoria. Plan on spending the day in this area. do some homework or hire a private guide to go through this area. There is so much to see you will be hard pressed to see it all reading all of the signs! Do not hire a guide for the collesium it is a waste of money! Walk the streets in this area and just take in the sights!

A lot of history here. Palatine Hill was the palace of the emperors. There is a ticket available that allows you to walk through this area and the Roman Forum. The history of Rome itself - Romulus and Remus - some of the old remains of their dwellings are here. I wasn't that impressed with the remains of the palace, etc. But it might be for you.
Amazing place. To visit this amazing place with so much history is an experience like no other. Being there and imagining how it was in those days, is just awsome.
Amazing to stand on the hill overlooking ancient Rome!. Although it's quite a walk up to the top of the hill, it's worth it . . . an amazing view of ancient Rome!

Stunning!. It is connected to the Roman forum, so for one price you see the roman forum and palatine hill. Walking through it all is so cool. It is amazing that it is still around after all these years. At the top you get a cool view of the city and you get to see Augustus' house.

In awe!!. There are not enough words to describe this place! It is huge! It is an architectural marvel! It is history! and it is worth a visit. But be warned- huge!!! veeery little shade and it gets hot! The tours are worth a go as well to get insider information on the site but don't be surprised if it takes you two trips to see everything. It's that big!! But very very worth it.

Prepare for some walking. If you're into ancient ruins and nice gardens, this is immensely enjoyable. If not...you'll get to the top and wonder why you bothered to climb this urban mountain. It's actually not too strenuous a walk, but my mother, who's fifty, struggled with all the stairs and inclines.Fantastic location to spend an afternoon and I'd highly recommend that you bring a picnic lunch or, at the very least, your own bottle of water (supplies get scarce up there).

Pretty spot, not enough information. A lovely viewpoint for looking at many parts of Rome from a height. But a lack of signage means you end up walking in circles and the maps available are very worn out. Some of the ruins were shut when they look like they are normally open. Overall looks like it needs some tlc. However, if you had a good guidebook or tour guide I'm sure the experience would be much more enlightening. You can certainly appreciate the spectacle of the forums beneath you and how the modern city has grown.

Loved it. A two day entrance tickets cost 12 euros and you can use the ticket to enter the Colosseum on day two. Plan plenty of time for the Palatine hill, it is worth it. Make sure you have eaten before entering, no food or terraces inside. Absolutely worth every penny.
Must see. One of my favorite places in Rome is Palatine Hill. I would strongly suggest the visit to all of those who favor the ancient Rome's history.

The must see thing before you leave Roma!. This is known as the most ancient area of Rome, with some residences estimated to be over 3,000 years old. You can really let your imagination run wild with glimpses of what ancient Roma used to feel like - the ecstatic bustle, the humming of crowds gossiping about Imperial business and worship, to the very residence of past Emperors in their might. It simply is a must see in Rome. I would highly recommend seeing the Colosseum and afterwards heading to the hill. Entry is covered with the Roma pass if you have one. Be sure to bring water if your travelling on a warm day and plan to budget at least 2 hours here.

Palatine Hill Grand Roman ruins reduced to weeds, rust and lack of information. . Rome is a weird place. It's monuments are amazing. The history. The cultural heritage. The grime. The grafetti. The lack of investment. The ruined ruins. The palatine offers amazing views of the city. It is a must for that. Its offers stunning views of the forum. It possesses a amazing collection of palaces, gardens. It is so Rome. In how it is so badly maintained. It is unkepted. Rusty fences. Badly maintained paths. Inadequate signage. A great collection of construction fences. Disused bins left behind enclosed fences. There is now a direct link into the forum that must be done within the same day, despite the misleading information at stating you have two days. And the security staff are just rude and bullish.

Beautiful. Beautiful day on the hill. Many people but ok. The only issue we had that it should be marked the line is closed in the end since many times we had to return back. Otherwise nice place to see.

Just amazing. Its a steep hill from the Colosseum up some dry stone paths that are a bit uneven in places but the wow factor is there for sure . How so much history has remained intact over the centuries is one of the wonders of the place !

Get there early. Worth seeing whilst in Rome. I would definitely advise on booking a guided tour as soon as you know your travel dates because they sell out well in advance and it is kind of hard to tell what you are looking at without assistance. If you choose to get the audio guide instead I would still recommend booking your entry ticket online (combined with colosseum) and getting there early as it gets very crowded on weekends and during peak seasons.

Old rome ... We did the roman forum and palatine hill and colesseum as a super saver tour..much better..we went thru everything with running commentary..audio earphones so u can hear well..the palace at top of hill was a big surprise. .didnt know it was there..take a snack and water..quite a long tour..recommended

What a view!. Climbing the Palatine Hill from the Forum could be a bit of a hike for some people, but it is magnificent from the top! The ruins of the palace, other buildings, racetrack and gardens cover the entire hill. There are views in every direction. It is also a good place to see the Forum at a different angle. Looks like there is a new snack building at the top if you forget your water.
Beautiful . Such a fantastic way to see Rome from the brilliant balcony vantage point. Definitely include this on your visit to Rome.
Palatine Hill. Not to be missed in Rome. Over looks the Foro Romano on one side and the Circus Maximus on the other. There are some fantastic restaurants (but out of the way nearby)

A step back in history. I had to see the Palatine after seeing Mary Beard talk about it on TV. Amazing place steeped with history and has the added bonus of fantastic views over Rome. There are several entrances, so you can avoid the main one marked and the queues, although with a Romapass we got through quickly. My only criticism is that there wasn't enough information to know what things were (a map would have helped) and facilities were too limited to cater for the crowds. As the site is so large, you can see the remains in relative comfort and wear suitable shoes as there is a lot of walking.

This was my favourite site in Rome. Beautiful ruins, fabulous gardens, a great way to spend an afternoon, if I had known how lovely it was I'd have done a picnic! again lots of walking, but the views from the top were worth it, even at this time of year (End of October) it was warm and the vending machines were a reasonable price €1 for a bottle of water, also there were spring water fountains about. There are lime trees and gardens, definitely would go back.

Ancient Rome. There are ruins everywhere in old Rome area. Palestine hill is very pretty and if you are into very ancient history than Palatine hill is a must see. You are surrounded by history. No matter which way you look, you see old.
Immersed in history.. This was one of our favourite spots during our trip to Rome. Fascinating to walk around the ruins imagining the life in Ancient Rome going on around you. Well worth a visit.
Not to be missed. This is amazing to walk through, especially on a dry day, lots to take in. Uneven under foot, so not wheel chair friendly.

Not to be missed for history buffs. One of the best ancient sites for history buffs...Spend at least 1/2 day walking through this ancient site....get a guide if possible or bring a travel book with explanations.....wear comfortable walking shoes and enjoy this marvelous place

Lost potential. Worth to visit since you can enter it on the Colosseum ticket and it is valid for 2 days. Otherwise, if you didn't buy the book with explanation what was where and how it looked like it is just stones lying around, with some structures remained quite intact. The biggest issue is lack of signs and some posters presenting how these buildings looked like before collapsing. It will be nice to also have some kind of model presenting how the site looked like at different historical periods. Summarizing, the place has unused potential that can lift this site to be the best attraction in Rome.
Roman History. Wow, just so overwhelming. It is hard to get your head around what you are seeing and the dates they were built.

History comes alive. When in Rome do not miss to visit the Palatine Hill and Forum Romanum complex of historic ruins. The shear scale and the idea of the size and power of the Roman empire becomes clear to you when walk trough the left overs of these magnificent buildings.

Where the other half lived. The Palatine is one of Rome's famed seven hills. It was where Rome's rulers had their palaces from its earliest days but especially after the Roman Republic became the Roman Empire.The ruins of several palaces and palatial homes are well preserved and worthy of a visit. From the top levels of the Palatine splendid views over ancient and modern Rome are to be found. Looking south, the Circus Maximus of Ben Hur fame is 100 or so metres away. Looking eastwards one sees the Colisseum and Constantine the Great's Arch. Looking north, the modern city lies beyong Trajan's column. To the west is the Capitoline Hill, the seat of Rome's government for the past 2,500 years. Off in the northwest distance, the great dome of St Peters dominates the distant skyline.

Away from the bustle of the forum. A place where the emperor and roman elite used to live. Seems like a quite place away from the bustle of the forum and streets of Rome. I was there in 2012. Palatine Hill is part of the Roman Forum. I took a tour and we were able to skip the line and go in quickly. Also, the tour I took included the Colosseum and the Forum as well.

Incredible views, lots of climbing required, accessible via metro. This venue has incredible vistas so bring your camera, I suggest taking a group tour or getting an iPhone App that tells all the history of this site. Many different civilizations built one on top of the other here, so getting some background either before or during a tour is a must to fully understand all the ruins that are present.

Beautiful . It's a huge and beautiful place, we spent about 3 hours there. Great ruins, nice views and rabbits everywhere! Do not know how but at least a whole rabbit family lives on the hill among the rocks:)

Beautiful. I could of easily spent all day exploring and sitting in the gardens, the views from rooftops over the Romun forums were also beautiful. While the sun was setting i didnt want to leave. Highly reccomend!

Wish I'd Had More Time. Got a high level look as part of a tour but I would have enjoyed a tour on this location as a separate activity. This is where the emperors lived and I would have enjoyed looking at more of their homes.

A Day I will Never Forget.. From the moment that you walk through the entrance, you simply do not know what to look at first. This is true history, right in front, back, below and above your every move.

Be Guided. Visited as part of skip the line tour to Colosseum, Palatine Hill and Roman Forum. An extremely knowledgeable guide brought the Palatine Hill to life and made the visit great value for money.
Perfect spot to see over a large part pf ancient Rome.. Another must see in Rome. The views over the archeological site is wonderful and there are very interesting things to see here too.

Take your time if you can. Don't do a guided tour, get an audio tour so that you can look around at your own speed. We were route marched through this ancient site with a guide with seconds to take photos it was awful.

A sense of distilled history. Hours of walking through history, reading and absorbing the incredible sights.I came away with almost a full 8GB of digital photographs and could easily have taken more photographs and video.The mass of stone absorbs the heat and radiates it back out. Make sure you cover up and take water on a hot day.Give yourself plenty of time to wander around.

Ancient Rome. Well you need a day to make the most of all this area has to offer,not really necessary to pay for quick access as que not that long and you still get searched by one guy which slows you down anyway.If you love the story of Rome this is a must it brings it all to life and is just amazing how so long ago they did so much.

Best of Ancient Rome. Among the major sights of ancient Rome (Colosseum, Forum, Pantheon, Circus Maximus, etc.), this is arguably the best -- not for historical significance but for enjoyability in the midst of Rome's busy tourism season. While in the Forum and the Colosseum you'll be pushed and shoved and jostled by hoards of other people, Palatine Hill offers enough empty space to take a moment to relax and enjoy the shaded pathways among crumbling ruins. It's easy to spend 2-3 hours exploring this surprisingly large site. Make sure to bring a snack to eat if you think you'll get hungry.The Forum, Colosseum, and Palatine Hill share a common entrance ticket, and both when we entered and exited Palatine Hill, there was no line to purchase the ticket, so if you plan on visiting all three sights, this is a good place to start (the ticket is good for one entry into each of the sights and is valid for two consecutive days). We didn't get an audio guide and instead relied on a pocket guidebook, but the signage is rather poor, so it might be worthwhile to pay the additional fee for the audio guide if you're interested in ancient Roman history. I would also recommend visiting without a tour guide -- we actually saw it twice (once on our own and a second time as part of a walking tour) and enjoyed it much more when we could set our own pace and route. There are so many different paths and interesting angles that you don't get to see if you're just part of a pack of people following behind a tour guide.
Unexpected treasure!. Loved discovering this on my own and at my own pace. Incredible views of the city and the ruins. The gardens were stunning and it was easy to envision it at its prime.

Breath Taking . You need a tour guide for this part of Rome. It is where the history of Rome began. There is so much to know, it will enhance your experience. Without a guide, it's beautiful ruins and a lovely view.

Like a trip in the Wayback Machine. Wandering around the ruins of the imperial palaces( palatine is the source of the word palace), one can not help but think of a the historical figures that trod upon these grounds. Augustus, Tiberius, Nero, Claudius and others may have stood upon this spot and looked down upon the Forum or Circus Maximus. I still get the shivers thinking about it. It is best to buy the Roma Pass which allows you entry into the Colosseum, Palatine Hill and The Roman Forum. You skip the ticket line at the Colosseum and gain fast entry, but at the Forum and Palatine you only skip the ticket line. There is no special line for Pass holders.
Forums. Not to be missed! I enjoyed visiting Roman Forums and Palatine Hill just as much as Colosseum and Vatican. It's part of an overall experience of visiting Rome not to be missed at any cost!

Stunning Views! Do Not Miss!. Rome offers some beautiful views from multiple locations, but don't miss the ones from atop Palatine Hill. You could easily spend 3-4 hours exploring (and if you're a photo fiend, taking beautiful pictures).

The heart of ancient Rome. The sense of history is almost overwhelming and takes you back to the heart of the Roman Empire. Through careful and ongoing conservation the architectural and building skill of the Romans are clear to see.

Do this along with the Forum. By getting a guide, seeing the Forum and Palatine Hill together, we developed a wonderful sense of the history of this area. Our guide explained the rise and fall of the various inhabitants, the society in which they lived, and made the area come alive.
amazing. everyone should do this before they die. take a long tour with a guide but be prepared for a long hard day of walking through eternity tour guide very good

A Must When in Rome. I cannot begin to describe and name all that can be seen at Palantine Hill. It was so awe striking to be there and take in the ancient Roman beauty. If you are in Rome it is a must see tourist attraction!

If you are into history. We spent a beautiful sunny afternoon here. Again the sense of history was palpable. You need to experience it to understand and appreciate the atmosphere. It's so close to the Colosseum and the Roman Forum and a €12 tickets gains you access to all three. There were no queues and no-one hustle you along, you could just take your time to soak it all in.
Visit to Palatine Hill. Great day. Recommend if visiting Rome. This is walking distance to the Colosseum and the Roman Forum. We did these all on the same day.

Free Entry with Colosseum. Visited because we had free entry with Colosseum ticket. Spent the whole morning at Colosseum on a tour then had lunch break in Monti neighbourhood and visited this after. Everyone was a bit tired of walking around by this stage - maybe better to do it on the 2nd day as ticket valid for 2 days.

Wonderful!. I always wanted to go here after reading so much about the Palatine and seeing shows on TV. The ticket is good for the Palatine, Forum and Coloseum. In the late morning (around 10:30) there was no line for tickets at the Palatine gate. Also, when you're done there it is directly linked to the Forum so there is not a wait to get in there.It is green, lots of trees and very historic. Note: read LOTS before you go and bring a guidebook to tell what each building is. There are signs but they're not very informative.There is a museum at the far end near the Circus Maximus. If it is warm, bring a water bottle in with you. There was no water for sale anywhere inside the Palatine.

A much quieter part of the antique Rome to discover.. Buy your ticket online and print it out at home before you go. That saves you a lot of time at the boots. The ticket will be valid for two consecutive days. The Palatine and Forum are one attraction and the Colosseo is the other one. Bring your own drinks and food, for there is only a vending machine at the site with nothing but cookies and drinks. The Palatine Hill will show you Augustus' and Lydia's house, now only from the outside, and the hut village where Romulus is supposed to having lived. OK, the cradle of Jesus in Bethlehem or Snowwhite are other nice stories one can belief, or not.The museum shows artifacts and gives in models and a movie good information about the situations in the old times. Be stunned about the huge palace and enjoy the view over the Circus Maximus.
Trip in time. Get a guide book or pay for the head phones. It is impossible to appreciate this site without having the info to hand. You could easily spend 3 to 4 hours wandering around

Top of the Hill and the best of all. It is so easy to miss it. Do not. That is the place were rich and powerful used to live in the ancient Rome. There is a breeze of fresh air, nice gardens, good views and the most important a sense of seclusion: both from the splendid ruins below and the thousands or tourists marching to the drum of guides. The Palatine Hill is an unique to separate you from triviality and gives you a feeling of the past long gone. Enjoy it!Note that there is an easy accessible toilet as well if you need it.
Good tour. Worth a visit, wear good comfortable shoes and bring a drink, as it is long. Not for people not good on their feet.
AMAZING historical site. This is a must see in Rome. Take a few hours to walk around and imagine all the great things which happened right here.
Lots to see. I would recommend nice walking shoes. Lots to see and take photos and bring some water. There are many paths within the Roman Forum leading to Colosseum, Spanish Steps, and Palatino.

Great visit - much quieter than the Forum or Colosseum.. Firstly, I should point out that many of the pictures shown are of the forum not the Palatine, though the ticket covers both and they are on the same site. Secondly, I'd suggest if you wish to go to the Colosseum to buy the ticket here where queues are much shorter and you then get to skip the queue at the entrance to the Colosseum. The hill where the Emperors lived and where Romulus is rumoured to have lived is a maze of paths and ruins with much still being excavated. You get a view from the far end of the site of the Circus Maximus (just empty ground but you can see the shape). There is a museum up here with toilets. There are also huge rabbits. Seriously - they are massive and gave more than one tourist a fright!! Don't miss the view of Rome from the top or the grottos with spring water bubbling through.

Palatine Hill. A wonderful place to walk around on a sunny day. There is lots to see and lots of walking to do. Good idea to purchase a map beforehand or hire a guide although we did this on our own and found most things like Augustu's wife's house. Take water with you as there is no food outlets.

Probably better appreciated by history enthusiasts. Rome has its origins on the Palatine, and people have lived there since approximately 1000 BC. Many affluent Romans and even several emperors built their residences there. It definitely has historical importance to Rome and worth a visit.I didn't buy tickets to enter and walk among the ruins, but there was some sort of viewing balcony from the main road and I was able to view it from above. To me, it really just looks like a collection of ruins (which is what it is). A guided tour would likely make the visit more meaningful.

Another historical spot. As I walked around the old buildings, I wondered "Will our structures still be standing in hundreds of years to come?". Probably not is the answer, so it's clear that the wealthy of Rome in ancient times were onto something given their places are still (partially) standing. Well worth the visit.
Great History!. This is a must see in Rome! The history is awesome! We had a wonderful tour and learned so much! I would have hated to miss this!

Unique site. Be prepared to walk.. We visited Palatine Hill in the afternoon, as part of a guided tour package with the Colosseum, which we did in the morning. The guided tours are absolutely necessary and well worth it if you are to gain any sense of what you are looking at. There a very few places to use a bathroom so consider this before setting off on your walk. So much to see and I found it to be quite calming despite the number of visitors. It's an enormous space so you won't be on top of each other. Must see in Rome!

A Word to the Wise! Don't make the same mistake we did!. The Palatine Hill is a must-see while in Rome as that is where legend has it that twin brothers Romulus and Remus--the founders of Rome--resided. Be careful when buying a combo ticket for the Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum! After visiting the Colosseum, my friend and I viewed the first building complex at the base of the Palatine, when my friend looked down below at the Roman Forum and decided he wanted to visit that first. Down the hill we went, to see the Forum; then, we walked back up the hill where we were stopped by the ticket taker who informed us that we could not go back. Even after lengthy explanations of why we actually had not seen the Palatine yet, the ticket taker did not budge. He said, No, and stuck by it!

Where it all began. One of the seven hills of Rome, and where it was founded. The legend says Romulus and Remus, co-founders (with Aeneas) of Rome, were deposited there as babies, to be suckled by the she-wolf they called "mom." Overlooks the Forum and is often visited as a joint ticket with the Forum. Seems as though one can purchase tickets for other attractions (the Forum and Colosseum) without the long waits here.
A maze without signage.. Yes it is special but so packed with tourists walking far and little obvious signage. Where are we and where is a bathroom and how do I get out? Not my favorite.

Touching History. On a beautiful sunny day, this is a perfect place to spend time walking around the ruins of Rome. If you have an informative tour book, take that and wonder at your own pace. Each site also has a brief description posted to help guide you.
first sunday in the month free entry. we enjoyed the visit and free on first Sunday of the month.Take A INFORMATION BOOK to gain maximum experience as not much labelled

Wonderful place to see. During my trip to Italy (Dec/2014), we were able to see many wonderful places. This was one of them. A must see to appreciate the culture and understand the local history. It was busy during my visit so leave enough time to see everything. Wear comfortable shoes and take a jacket. Even though sunny, we needed our jackets.
Amazing. It's definitely a must see in Rome. Amazing sights, full of history. It's a trip back in time to a place where emperors and high society walked on the same stones you step on
Historical. Nice place to visit and learn more about the history. It's located about 10mins walk from the colleoseum

Dont miss this attraction when you visit Rome. A must see on your trip to Rome. Take a guided tour so that you know what you are looking at. This was my second time but I still found out lots of new facts. There are quite a few stairs and steps so if you are not too good at climbing stairs then be prepared to take your time getting to the top of the hill. It is worth it. Once your guided tour is over you can wander about and enjoy the area at your leisure. Brilliant part of the city. Go on Sunday as the whole area is for pedestrians only. This makes it even more special as you don't have to dodge the traffic and tour buses. Lovely way to spend the day.
Ancient Rome!!. After Coliseum, stop by here at Roman Forum. It is covered by the same ticket. If is a must see. It was a lot of fun and very interesting
Palatine hill. Absolutely stunning, unbelievable that these structures are still standing after all this time. Well documented when walking by to give you some insight to the ruins.

A must see in Rome! A travel back in time.. A must see in Rome! A travel back in time. Well worth the 12 euros per person to visit (which also include the visite of the Colosseum and the Roman Forum).

Must be maitenance improved. The site is necessery step in Rome due its historical importance. Despite the fact this attraction you must pay an entrance ticket, which I do agree, the administration should offer better toillete structure , signs are missing every where and cleanning is failing.

Get a tour guide. Everything in this city is beautiful to see, but I would suggest to get a tour guide, you can walk past so many things, and with a tour guide you get a in depth story of everything, and lots of them are very funny and have a lot of character. We found someone called Chad, he was very funny and we honestly learnt a lot. The Palatine hill has many stories.

Buy your tickets online. Palatine Hill is inside the Roman Forum, so if you have a ticket for Colosseum/Forum this will also take you to the hill. It provides fantastic views of the Roman Forum so highly recommended, turn left as you enter the Forum and climb up, on you reach the museum you need to go right which will take you to the view points.

Great architecture and historical value.. Palatine Hill is an exciting and engaging site. So much history involved and a mirror of a great civilization. To visit the Palatine is to visit our heritage.

See how the rich of Amcient Rome lived. As Palatine hill is free entry along with the Roman Forum when you purchase tickets for the Colosseum, it is worth a visit.Walk through the ruins of old palaces and grand homes, imagine how rich the families must have been to own homes so grand. Observe their stadium & see the recovered marble columns laid out on the ground.We treated it as a walk in the park, not stopping to read too many signs, just soaking up the atmosphere. It's worth doing if you have a spare hour.

Amazing view!!!. This part of the tour was also included with the Colosseum part. The views from here are just amazing. You can see the Colloseum, Roman Forum and most of the City great for picture taking. This is a must do, but with a tour guide otherwise you will miss out on the historical part.

Great views. Part of the same area as the Roman forum this is a great area to explore. Views over both the city & the forum are wonderful. Signs are informative although there seem to be some areas you have to pre-book (although we weren't sure about that).
Read up before you go. Palatine Hill was once an incredible palace... The problem is that so little of it is left that it is hard to imagine what was there with what is left.

Awesome views.. So interesting to see ruins throughout Italy that have so much history associated with them. You can also get an audio device to get more information as you go along. Your ticket to Palatine Hill also give you admission to the Roman Forum and the Colleseum. Don't miss these three areas.
Nice surprise!. We visited here after the Colosseum & it didn't disappoint. Wear some decent shoes as it is quite sandy/uneven! Fantastic views!
Bring comfy shoes. Went with a guide who gave us a thorough history lesson. Lots of steps up so not suitable for anyone with walking difficulties Million dollar views from the top.
Wander at will. The complexity of this excavation is mind-blowing. Take your time and absorb all that is around you and within your thoughts.

Wear a hat and take it easy!. Amazing place for history lovers and quite an impressive site for everyone else. The hill offers a lot of ruins to explore (with audio guide if not personal guided tour) as well as amazing views of Rome and the ancient forum. Also a nice park to relax in.

Get your trainers on!. Much bigger than I expected and free with your coliseum entry so keep your ticket. Takes a couple of hours to get round properly but timed correctly you can leave and go right back to the coliseum for the night time shots. Plenty nearby restaurants.
Amazing. The views from here are just amazing. You can see the Colloseum, Roman Forum and most of the City - do not miss this when in Rome
Take a tour. Take a tour for best understanding of this piece of Roman History, quite a lot of walking involved so not for people with limited mobility.

Amazing Views from Palatine Hill. Although it is a walk UPHILL along dirt tracks, cobblestones, steps and uneven walkways, once you get to the top of the hill, you realize it was definitely worth it. The overview of the Forum and imagining what the town was once like is something to experience. We were on a guided tour and wish we had longer to linger. There are areas to sit in park-like settings, olive trees, flowers, shade trees, etc. Bring a bottle of water and if it is warm weather, you may want a hat and sunscreen. You could easily spend a few hours up there walking around and looking at all the views below. Glad we took the time to visit it!

Must see!. You have to drop by here when you get the chance, preferably with a tour other wise you will not know the history of this spot, even though I didn't have a tour I really enjoyed this spot, I took great pics but would've enjoyed it more to learn the history.
a step back in time. when walking around the forum, it feels like you are away from the city environment. again. a good half a day can be spent wondering the sights of the forum and hill
Always mind blowing .... ... what the Romans achieved. Recommend taking a tour along with Colosseum to get full explanation. You could easily spend the whole day here, getting lost in ruins!

Don't leave Rome without going there!!. Located at the same site than Colosseum. Spend around 5h to visit all of them (Colosseum, Palatino Hill and Roman Forum). It's hard to describe in words the emotion you fill when you visit this site wchich tells us about milleniums of Humanity history!!The price if you buy on line is 14,00 euros (including the 3 attractions). I highly recommend you doing this, otherwise you will have long queues. Use confortable shoes!! The Roman Forum floor is all made of big and small stones. Check the wheater forecast, because it's not very nice if it's rainning.
Near The Colosseum. Walking distance from the Colosseum. Can combine the visit along with the Colosseum. Audio guides would be helpful.

Walk back in time. This is an amazing experience not to be missed. History in stone. We have seen this attraction several times during past visits to Rome but there are always new things being uncovered, reconstructed and displayed to add to the story. Good walking shoes, a hat and water a must. Find a good guide it will bring the site alive. We did the first time and we would have missed so much if we had not done so.
Take a travel book with you. First visit to the Palatine Hill. Having Rick Steve's book (with a walking tour to read) was very helpful.

ANCIENT ROME'S ELITE PRESERVED. Viewing an attraction that is more than two millenia old still thrills me. Possibly my 12th visit here, and I am still mesmerized by this piece of ancient Rome. No visit to the "eternal city" is complete without viewing this attraction.

A must see to complete your visit of the Colloseum. Really important site if you love history! We took the skip the line tour of the Coolseum with Viator. They have the best guides and with their listening device you are so well informe. The infos are very well presented. Really with it!

Stones are mostly damaged. Deeply historical place. Stones are mostly damaged.Even somewhere its not possible to understand original shape of stones. If you know the story before you come it is more possible to understand and appreciate its story.

Strolling back in time. a great place to visit on a dry day. we went as part of a ticket that included the Colosseum and together they took all day. good information boards around and great views of the city from the top. i would think it would be quite hard work for a person who cannot walk far but if they have got all day it is well worth the effort. there are plenty of places to sit and if you take a picnic you can imagine yourself in ancient Rome.

That View.... It is so worth the ticket to see these incredible views. Go early to give yourself plenty of time to explore. From the base of the hill to the wonderful view could be done in half an hour but you could invest 2+ hours just exploring. That view is one in a million so definitely go all the way to the top.
Amazing. This is realy a place you need to walk trough for an afternoon. It is amazing and beautiful, bring enough water with you during hot days.

Excellent view. I love this viewpoint. It overlooks directly roman forum so you have great photo opportunities here. One of nicest viewpoints ever. It was pretty crowded when we get there but still was enough room for anyone to stop and do photo. Beautiful must do when you around.

One of my favorite spots definitely!. Being in the Palatine Hill and Foro Romano was one of the greatest experiences of my life! It is unbelievably full of a history vibe. I loved it! There is history happening everywhere. amazing!

Plan ahead for bathrooms.. There is a lot of walking here. We did not have a map so here so we walked into many dead ends and had to turn around. SOOO much walking. You really could spend all day here if you wanted. Limited signs for bathrooms. There was one bathroom in the small museum in the back of the property with only two stalls. There were sinks inside the stall so people would wash their hands in the stall even though there was a sink outside in the main bathroom area. This held up the line and some people really needed to go.There was another bathroom in a less traveled area toward the Colosseum side near the back. There were about four stalls in there and one sink near the door. No line here when we went.The actual property was mostly a lot of very old structures and there was almost as much construction fencing as there was bricks/rocks from the original build. Some of the pictures posted on here are actually the Forum not Palatine Hill although you can take pictures of the Forum from Palatine Hill.
Beautiful. A lot of history. It is worth seeing. Breathe taking. The history is very interesting. You won't be disappointed.
Beautiful. You can feel a sense of the greatness of the empire in these ruins. Beautiful buildings that stood the test of time.

Underrated. Well worth a visit. We had visited most of the tourist attractions in Rome on previous visits and were searching for somewhere we hadn't been before. We didn't expect much but were quite blown away by the Palatine Hill. It wasn't overcrowded and so we were able to relax and take it all in. We thought the museum was a bit expensive but after our visit, we thought it had been worth every cent of the 10 euros we had paid. It was amazing.

"Sharp contrast from the modern streets below". This was walked through a little on our own, and so I as other people have suggested also think that a guide is needed to begin to touch the surface of this very historical area. We did take some great pictures of the surrounding area, Colosseum and Forum,etc. because of the high ground. Views of the area are very picturesque, and have a stark contrast with the modern streets you take to get there.
get a joint ticket. This c an be included with a visit to the coliseum ticket but will mean a awful lot of walking to see both so beware
Amazing. Put this one on our 'Bucket List'. It's amazing home much history is displayed in such a small arena.

Nice outdoor walk!. We got the combo pass at the Palatine Hill ticket booth, which saved time in lines! It was a nice park like walk around the ruins and seeing the "circus" area was amazing! It was an easy transition into the Forum from here.
a nice uphill walk!. Located next to the Colosseum, it is interesting in it's own right. I would recommend seeing both of these by a guided tour as the history is as interesting as the architecture.
Go back in time. This was part of our tour of the Colosseum. It brought goosebumps to all of us. Wear comfortable shoes.

Looking down on history. The Palatine hill gives superb views down over the Forum. Can be a little dusty but the breeze can be a welcome relief from the heat of the Forum area.
Slight climb up to the Palatine but well worth it for a taste of where the emporers lived.

Long visit!. It's a cool sight, with a lot of history. This was part of the colosseum tour that we took. Honestly, I got a little bored after a while b/c it was hot, it's all outdoors, and it is a bit too much history. However, it was still cool to see the history of the place. On a cooler day it wouldn't be a bad visit.

How The Other Half Lived. Palatine Hill is a great tour to learn how the elite of the day lived in Rome. It is amazing to learn about some of the ingenuity that was involved in the architectural and land management of the time. Well worth the visit.

Fascinating. Better than the Colosseum and Forum Romanum as it is not that overcrowded and you can walk around and get more into the ancient age. The museum is also worth a visit, very well arranged exhibition.
Take a tour. There is so much to see and take in that I would defiantly recommend a fully guided tour! So pleased we made time to visit x
Well worth visit to view. Well worth the effort to visit top of site as it will reward you with great views. Definitely one of the top sites along with the colesseum.

Great views. It’s quite a walk up, but it is worth it! Palatine Hill is the centermost of the Seven Hills of Rome and is one of the most ancient parts of the city.There are lots of panoramic views for pictures – especially over the Roman Forum obviously.
Definitely Worth Ten Euros. Unearthed ancient roman streets and buildings with monuments and artifacts that you can just walk through however you want and touch. Great place to explore.

Feel the history. TIPs:Set aside a few hours for thisWear comfortable shoesListen to a guide before you go or purchase oneI did Palatine Hill in conjunction with my tickets from the Colosseum - they definitely go hand in hand. I listened to the Rick Steve's Palatine Hill tour on his iphone app as I walked through. Leave a few hours open to walk through - while it looks to be a small area - it is not!There are some amazing spaces to look down into the Roman Forums - great photos!
Next to the Colloseum. It was in this area that there were magnificent homes, offices and meeting places. As you walk within this area you'll also come across Caesar's resting place.
A Must .. This is the place to go with a guide to learn about the history of this place. Do not go on a Sunday as very very crowded and difficult to get to the edge to take photos of the forum below.
Fantastic. This is free with the collusium and a must see in Rome. Alot of walking though so not good if your not able

too much to see, too little time. We visited Palatine Hill after the Colosseum, the ticket is valid for both. It's a very large sight, with a lot to see. There are wells all around the sight to get fresh water (which is needed during the summer months). We didn't see all of it because we visited Palatine Hill at noon when it was too hot to do much.

Views that take you back. The best views of the ruins are from here. It is said that people have lived here from 1000 BC. The place will immediately transport anyone back in time. From here one can see many monuments spread over a large area and its probably the closest I got to see an ancient city anywhere in the world.
Amazing History. There are so many things to do in Rome but this was worth seeing. The history is whoa! Worth taking a tour or looking down on the sites from the hill.

Fascinating . Bought the joint ticket for The Colloseum, Palatine hill and The Forum. Absolute bargain for a day strolling through ancient Rome. The hill is so much bigger than I imagined and the views are spectacular. The museum is great and you get a great feel of the time and looking down on the forum was so good.
Feel like your stepping back in time.. I went with a guide and they were able to tell me the history behind this area and the important events that happened here. It really brought the place alive.

Best Spot to View Ancient Rome. This is the area of the palace of the Caesars in ancient times. When visiting the Coliseum, etc. this is a must view. Just walk up the hill. Might be a little tough for those physically challenged.
pagan mixed romanesque history. Great location with lots of fascinating history, well worth a visit and alot of other big landmarks based close by so worth checking whats around and make a day of it

Brilliant day out. Cant wait to go back again, best bit of Roman history to see in the city!Amazing things to see related to the best known emperors, and you can cut straight through to the Forum and Coliseum. Also much easier to get your tickets there than queue at the coliseum. Really atmospheric!

unreal. This is such an amazing place, on of the few places in the world you can walk through a whole city that is thousand of years old.So much history and so much beauty. Good to do a tour to learn about what you're looking at. However would recommend good shoes, bottled water and an over cast day. We were dying out there in the heat wearing jeans was also a bad idea in the summer. :/
Beautiful views. It was worth the walk. It was amazing to hear about the history of the gardens. We were able to see an active archeology site
There is not another place like this on Earth!. Situated in the heart of Rome (modern and ancient), the Palatine Hill is a MUST for all who visit Rome. Don't miss it, you'll never forget it.

Get a sense of grandeur of old Rome. Nice areas to walk around, the museum is worth a visit with an AV show on the history of Rome. You get a sense of how grand the area must have been and some of the artefacts in the museum are beautiful.
excercise for fit people. If you are fit enough go climb to Palatine Hill. Your reward will be excellent view from the top you will enjoy just don't go there in bright sunny day
Fantastic. We did a small group ancient Rome and Palatine Hill our guide was Richard he is a retired history and art teacher he bought the ancient city of Rome to life he made our tour so interesting

A Must-see in Rome. The Roman Forum, Palatine Hill and the Colosseum are must see attractions in Rome.The historical greatness is magical.The monuments take you back in time, they vibrate roman energy.Aprox 17 euros per ticket, including the Colosseum.

A time travel experience!. I'll never forget this experience. I could not stop looking and pondering and thinking and admiring. It is just unbelievable. Probably is bet if I do not tell you anymore, just go.Go and see it if you can.
very little info at this site!!. This place would of been massive back in the day. But when we found it not interesting as there was not much to no info on some ruin sights quite disappointing..

My Favorite Place in Rome. I can't get enough of the Palatine Hill. Every time I visit, more has been excavated and revealed. If you are interested in the Caesars or ancient Rome, the Palatine Hill is a fascinating afternoon of exploration. You'll get to see the ruins of the palace of Augustus, the House of Livia, temples, cisterns, etc. It has a ton of history to offer and is a wonderful way to spend an afternoon.
Wow. One of the most fascinating places i've ever visited, you could amost picture life in ancient Rome. Visit the gardens on the upper level, well worth the walk and great view of the the colloseum
Amazing. Breath taking - the view from the top of the hill over the ruins is just incredible. Great photo opportunities
See it. Don't don't don't leave Rome without experience of visiting Palatine hill it's spectacular and amazing

OK place, visit only if you have some extra time left in your trip or if you are a history buff. Nothing great about this place. The history might be engaging for some. However, this is an ok place with nothing much to see.

Wonderful walk thru Romas history. The forum and Palatine Hill was about a 3-4 hour excursion thru Roman political history. It was a long walk with much to see. Take a good map of the area or use Rick Steve's guide on the Roman forum to get the most from your visit. Wear good walking shoes and bring water. There are some water fountains available inside to refill your water bottles, but no place to buy water inside.
Fantastic Ruins. Of course you're going to see this. It's rubble but it's the 2,000 year old remains of one of the greatest Empires in western civilization.

Amazing. This is one of my favorite places in Rome. The plot is big enough so there aren't crowded tourists everywhere like in the Colosseum. I went in late April once and the weather was amazing, the site was amazing and the experience couldn't have been better. November gets a little cold, but still workable. Do your homework ahead of time and research the ruins. It will make the experience more worthwhile and you don't have to pay for a tour guide.
Very Good. Lots to see and some fantastic views across the city from here. Not to be missed. The climb from The Forum could be a bit tough for the more elderly visitor.

Lots to see, allow plenty of time for this attraction. Worth spending a good half day exploring this and the Roman Forum below. Your ticket allows two day access to this area including the Roman Forum and also the Colosseum but you can only visit each area once during the two days of the tickets validity.
Rome Trip. The best parts of our trip was visiting the Colosseum, Palatine Hill and the Forum. It can be a little crowded so a skip the line tour is recommended.

An absolute must. No visit to Rome is complete without a visit to the hill of the Kings ad Emperors. On one side it overlooks the Forum, to another the Colisseum, to another the Circus Maximus and then to the Tiber. Now all ruins, there are important archaeological sites to visit in what was the real centre of power. This is the Palace of Augustus, the House of Livia,and much more.

Palatine hill,you will need your walking boots. The palatine hill is amazing and yes it is on a hill so wear senible shoes/trainers.The whole site is a slice of history and when you get to the top and look out over Rome you will say it is worth the climb.
recommended. Good tour Not as "colourful" as other sights,I suppose it;'s still a "must-see" sight since Rome was founded there...
Enjoying. The entrance fee also includes the Colosseum and is good for two consecutive days. There is so much to see here. Take your time it is amazing.
Palentine Hill. Brilliant, you have to go, it's amazing, tour guides are very informative and when it's hot it's glorious!

Worth it!. I was not at all prepared for how much time the Forum and Palantine Hill would take. We seemed to be walking forever!! Thankfully there are a few places with vending machines with water. Once we were on the Hill it was kind of hard to tell how long it was going to take for us to find our way out. Everytime we thought we must be close to an exit we were wrong, so plan accordingly! But it was beautiful and the view was amazing!

Worthy visit. Unfortunately we visited here on a day it didn't stop raining so unable to make the most of it. What I did see was a large area of different infrastructure and architecture to see. Crowding not an issue as with most other attractions.
Ancient city. It was great to see what was left of ancient Rome. Its difficult to recognize any of the old buildings without a guide.
Must must must see. If you're in Rome, you must see this site or you're cheating yourself! Breathtaking views and so many massive ruins it will make your head spin.
You Don't See Sites Like This In The US. It is hard to understand how long ago these structures where built and the views from the hill overlooking the Coliseum and Roman Forum were breathtaking.
Palatine Hill. Ruins of the emperor's house, but there's not much left, so I recommend a guide or an audio tour so you know what you're seeing. Great view of the Circus Maximus.

Top of The Hill. So amazing to walk through the area where legends have been made. We had an excellent tour that began at the Colosseum, top to bottom, then Palantine Hill and the Forum. Our heads were filled with facts and stories by the time we were finished, but a full picture had been made.

Nice views of Colosseum area. Beautiful views! Not very crowded in the morning hours, which was great for taking photos of the scenery. Easy to access and audio-guides are available for decent price in many languages.

What a trek!. It is a trek but you won't be disappointed. Once at the top you over look the Forum and can only imagine if this is where Nero watched Rome burn! Put on your walking shoes and climb to the top of the forum. Great back drop for selfies!

The true Roman.. This is old, old Rome with the huge remains of Emperor Tiberius' palace dominating the area. The ruins surrounding this area speak to the building skills and architectural sense of beauty the Romans employed in all their construction. This is a good location to get a picture of the Coliseum without paying. The Palatine Hill cannot be accessed without buying a ticket and the line-ups are significant.
Great views. Great views of the old city. Plenty to see - don't miss it. A lot of paths to wander around, some are quite steep and rough. Good to get a perspective of old Rome.
Great historical visit. A stunning area of Rome, steeped in history. Well worth a visit, although probably not on a very hot day.
Great views.. Best to get here early to get the best views of the surrounding area. An audio guide lets you get the best out of the area.
A Walk Back in Time. We visited right after the Colosseum and enjoyed a couple of hours walking through the ancient ruins. Where good shoes and bring an umbrella for shade on a hot day.
Enter from forum near colosseum . We walked out the entrance near Capitolini and it is a LONG hike ftom there (maybe 3 miles). Great view of the forum from up there.

Fantastic Views. You will probably spend 2-3 hours here in conjunction with the Roman Forum. You will near to wear sturdy footwear; there is nowhere to shelter from the sun or rain so make sure you are prepared.

Amazing site . My personal favourite of the three linked ancient sites (along with the forum and Colosseum) in central Rome. Worth the 12 Euro entry price alone let alone with the other two thrown in - just get the official tickets from the usually queue-free Palatine entrance and ignore the predatory touts. On a fine day you can really take your time wandering the site soaking up the ancient ambiance and the amazing views across the city. The recovered statues in the museum section are also a must-see for their craftsmanship.
Beautiful. After the Colosseum. This is just a few steps away. The view is amazing. This is more for grown ups than kids. None the less it is part of Roman History.

Good shoes required. This was my second visit to Palatine Hill as part of a tour including the Roman Forum and The Colosseum- this tour was a good as the first, it was with the same company as I had used before but the whole visit was completely different. So much to see, luckily the weather was fantastic. It is very hilly and ensure you have water with you, that way you can refill your bottle as many times as you want from the Roman Fountains all around, lovely fresh water.So much history to absorb :).
Great feeling. Seen this place from outside since I was on a guided city tour package. You will not get much on your own so hire a guide.

Palatine Hill, amazing place. We decided to take a guided tour of this place and glad we did. The Platine Hill is so old it has virtually layers of buildings and history upon history. A guide can help you understand everything. It cost around $150 and seems a lot but was well worth it, It was about 3 hours. You can book online but not sure if they run all year. There is quite a bit of walking and remember to take some water. The views are amazing...The Palatine is the centre of the seven hills of Rome and has a history dating back to Romulus and Remus...awesome stuff. Especially coming from a country that is barely 200 years old..

I Underestimated How Long We Would Be Here. We spent 4 hours between Palatine Hill and The Roman Forum and we still did not see everything. Everywhere you look there is something beautiful/significant. Great views of the city. Beautiful picture opportunities.Just remember to wear comfy shoes and give yourself plenty of time.

Can't miss....literally. Palatine Hill is directly opposite the Coliseum and near the Roman Forum. You can't miss it. Interesting to walk where Emperor's walked. It's like taking a step back in time. Beautiful view. Opt for a guided tour of the area to get the most out of everything.

A walk through time. It's an awesome experience for someone from a country where our oldest buildings are only a couple of hundred years old but get a guidebook or join a tour to get the most from your experience.

If you are an archaeological fan, don't miss this!,. Just drove by a few times but luckily had hired a tour guide!! Highly recommended! Ours happened to be a historian, which for me, could not get any better, except wanting to hire him much longer! If I can give any good advice...........I highly, highly recommend hiring a guide to answer all of your questions, give great advice of what is important to see, plus always pay extra & make reservations for sites!!! I cannot tell you what a relieve to walk right in to these places verses seeing people having to wait in lines for 3 hours and longer!! Especially having disabled folks in our group.

Roman Forum . We've been here before some years ago but new excavations have opened up new areas in the Palatine and the entire site including the areas outside of the paid entrance areas was much more excavated and accessible for visitors. Overall, I would consider this a "must see" in Rome.
A Historic Site. A lot of monuments here that are self exploratory and mystique. Stroll through the site and one will feel that he/she is not in the present time.

Interesting but overcrowded. Palatine Hill is an amazing look at an ancient world. I would recommend attaching yourself to a guide walking round - they usually offer tours for free in return for tips at the end. I completely underestimated how long I would spend wandering around here.There are great views over the Baths of Caracalla and Circus Maximus. I just wish it had been less crowded.

Must see part of history of Rome. You get a sense of what it was like.. I loved this. Although a lot of it has disappered over time you still get a sense of what it was like. It is definately something you must see. I did not go down to the ruins. I viewed it from above, from behind Capitoline Hill.
Roman Forum and Palentine Hill. Took my breath away. Loved it!!!!It was like an 'outdoors' museum. Made me feel like I was there with the ancient Romans...
Visit. History coming to life through hard work and care taking of the area and must do and visit on your trip to Rome.

Fun but long. Was a fun area to tour. Took a long time and we were pretty tired of walking around by the time we got here. Lots of interesting things to look at. Only one way in and the way out is on the complete opposite side of the attraction. Can see plenty of it by just walking around town, so if going to skip one thing, I would probably say this is the one to skip.

WELL WORTH A VISIT. A good place to visit to see all the architecture from the Roman Times, so bring your camera with you and a good pair of shoes or decent trainers. Its a short visit but time spent there could be from 1 - 2 hours or longer if you desired. Its cheap to go in but as we had an Omni card it was free.

Sightseeing in Rome. We stopped here a couple of times. Each time learning a bit more about the hill, (one of seven) that make up Rome. So much to see and so much to take in. During the time of the Czars and the Republic this must have been awesome to behold

Place of history. After visiting the Colisseo, you just need to climb the Via Sacra to get there. Once Inside the Forum you will be fullfield by history, the ruins are full of it. Starting by the Tito's Arch, you will after see the ruins of multiple temples of the acient Rome, as well the descriptions of what each one means. After that you should climb to the Palatin Hill, where you can take amazing photos of the Forum from above. In the Palatin Hill the most impressive structure is doubtless the stadium.

A historical must see.. A short walk from the Colosseum, Palantine Hill has everything significant from ancient Rome. It can be hot so bring water. There are water vending machines on site for a euro if needed. Kids and tired adults can get bored seeing so many structures that have been lost through time. It is significant, but maybe view on another day from Colosseum.
Lovely relics of old ro,me/. We just walked up the hill at the side of this as it was way too busy and hot really to go in and do the full tour,

Well worth the visit.full of great photo. We did a small group tour of ancient Rome, including Palatine Hill. This was very inspiring and full of great photos. After touring the Forum, etc., be sure to walk up the hill. There is so much more there than you can imagine. As long as it's not raining, the weather doesn't make any difference. We went on a very dark day, but it still made for some very interesting photographs. Recommend a guide; ours had much to share that brought what we saw to life. One of my favorite days!

What a Palace!!!!. I think I enjoyed this site more than the Colosseum but toured both utilizing a combo ticket. These grounds are varied and impressive. The variety of structures and examples of Roman architecture are a fantastic. Start here where lines were minimal and make you way around to finish with the Colosseum in 4-5 hours. A lot of walking, sometimes on rough surfaces and so wear comfortable shoes that have a tread
Remains of an ancient city. Palatine hill is less impressive as compared to its neighbor, Roman Forum. However, whatever that remains is still magnificent!
Beautiful Views and History!. Worth the walk! Lots of panoramic views for pictures. You can also view some of the most ancient living quarters believed to be about 730 BC. Do this!!

Emperors residence. Remainings of an era where emperors live and conquer. Ruins of the palaces, gardens and a life of pleasure at it's time. Need more than four hours to walk it all and feel the atmosfere.
Palatine Hill . Amazing to see and the views are fantastic. Makes sure you can make plans to visit this area. Good walking shoes Will help.

This is where the Emperor's Palace was in Ancient Rome. Don't miss this folks! If possible, take a private guided tour. Don't miss standing on the veranda where the Emperor would be to watch the chariot races in Circus Maximus. This is a must see, but take a guide book or a tour to know what you are looking at and appreciate the site.

Ruins are Farther Apart Here--A Great Way to Walk and Explore Ancient Rome. If I only had one day in Rome I'd go here again. There's a lot of history here. If that's not your thing so much, there are still gorgeous views and beautiful ruins.Your ticket for Palatine Hill is good for the Forum and the Colosseum also. (Remember you can use them for two days, but can ONLY ENTER EACH SITE ONCE. It's almost three days worth of sights, but it seems easier to break it up into one day at the Colosseum and one at the Forum and Palatine.)This is the place where you can see Augustus' and Livia's palaces, Circus Maximus, and roam a museum with some of the art removed from the sites in Palatine and the Forum. It's a park-like setting and a comfortable and easy walk (albeit long).Like all places in Rome watch for pick-pockets. I don't know how they operate in the open spaces like Palatine without getting seriously up close and personal--but it was a repeated warning over loud-speaker the days I went. My goal touring Palatine was to see the murals at Livia's palace--but you need to book that tour separately and I didn't realize that and missed it. So heads up if you want to see anything special, investigate ahead of time. Now I just have one more reason to return to Rome.One of the days I toured was in the rain--which was fun if you have the proper gear and an umbrella. There are vending machines on Palatine with snacks.
worth the walk. What a beautiful view of the Forum and Circus Maximus. The ruins are very good to. Not to be missed.
Flat shoes a must!. Lovely way to spend an afternoon. Take a picnic and find a place high on the hill. The views are amazing.

Interesting.. Visited this after a visit to the colosseum. The day qe went was heavy rain all day and I was soaked through so I don't think I fully appreciated it. However it is a wonderful and interesting place to visit and I would highly recommend it, but maybe best to leave it until dry weather!

A must see when in Rome. While ruins it does not take much of an imagination to see this as the once center of Western Civilization. You can pay and walk thru the Palatine Hill and Forum but one can get a wonderful view from the souranding streets without the crowds or cost.

While at the Colosseum and Forum, don't miss this. While buying passes for the other attractions get the deal and get all 3 at once. Colosseum, Forum and Palatine Hill. Plan several hours to give the hill it's deserved attention as there a many wonderful sites and a museum to see. Will you not only see the site of the Hut Village and the origins of Rome, you'll get wonderful vistas of the Forum and Rome. There is a self guided audio tour, cash only and you'll need to leave a form of ID with the attendant.
History and culture. History and culture, near to the coliseum,walking in that structure we can imagine the great people are the Romans, with a enormous empire and big buildings for that time.
Family vacation. Rome tops everything! Once you go there, not much else compares in my opinion. Stand in the middle of Palatine Hill and close your eyes.

Most can be seen from outside without paying to go in.. Most can be seen from outside without paying to go in. Again this is something that can be seen for free from outside the fenced off area. Mind you it was raining when we went and walking round ruins in this weather was quite off putting.
Nice view. A perfect way to end a long day at the Colosseum and Roman Forum. The view from the top is truly amazing and well worth it to get up there.

Walking in history.. Best to use a tour guide (City Wonders), very informative and pointing out all the little things that we probably would have missed had we just gone independently. Same tour as the Colosseum and a wonderful time in the sunshine. Shown a worn lump of rock behind a marble sarcophagus but it was where the body of Julius Caesar was cremated. The stone cobbled street we walked was the original from Roman Empire times and the billions of people that had walked it through the ages was mind boggling.
Interesting. whilst interesting, I did enjoy other Rome sites more than palatine hill. But it's still worth a visit as the views across the city are stunning.
Great views. Get a sense of Roman grandeur. See how diverse and vast their vision was. Views from up top allow you to see this beauty.

Wow, wow and more wow.. First time I've ever reviewed a sight seeing activity, but this place is mind boggling. You've all seen the coliseum, but this is amazing, just trying to get your head round the Roman ability of 2000 years ago. A must see on any trip to Rome.
Great experience to be here.. Love this place. We were brought back in time seeing all the ruins. It's a good place too for great pictures. Just next to Colossuem so you can't miss this.

For history buffs and walkers. Theres a LOT of walking involved with this site. ..its a full day trip in itself. (Bit of a line of people to get in). So much to see if you love your Roman history you are steeped in it here. Helps to have some sort of guide/map - even if you print one of the internet. If you don't then it can all get a bit much theres so much ground to cover. Otherwise you could miss so much detail. On the plus size you really get the feel of ancient Rome, its size and splendour even if every bit has been sacked to decorate all the zillions of Churches in Rome. If you've seen all that ecclesiastical use of marble and stone use your imagination and add it to all you see in Palatine Hill and you'll be in awe of what ancient Rome must have been in all its Glory.BIG MINUS - Theres NO cafe or drink stops here so if its a hot day take something. I was here for 4 hours and with nothing even in this area of Rome except the odd street vendor ended up dizzy with dehydration. Even the toilets are spread out so plan and work out where these are in case they are at the other end of the site when you need one…it can be a long way to cross your legs!

Beautiful ancient views. This place is very beautiful and must do in Rome. One of my very favorite spot in Rome. Very ideal to have sightseeing here, and you can learn historical stories from local people here.

Good Views From Top Of The Hill. Very hot during our visit so take plenty of water. Our group had a guide who gave us the background of all the archeological buildings and ruins. 360 degree views from the top of the hill are outstanding. Fairly crowded at the time of our visit but enjoyable none the less. Recommended.
Nice . My husband and I visited the forum and the palatine hill and it was nice and interesting, it has a very nice view from there

Vast Grounds and Filled Mounds. This was an afternoon affair. With the audio guide in check we set off. You could really spend 3 days here getting your head around things. Some fantastic views of the eternal city and the oldest room I've ever been in. What a place!

Part of Roman Forum. This is part of the Roman Forum an elevated area closer to the back of Piazza Venezia. You can reach the Forum by the Piazza Venezia or the Coloseum.
