Remember this is all an open area and no protection from the weather so plans accordingly. But by all means do not miss the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill.

Magical. Ancient magical environment. I recommend coming early to avoid the line, better yet pre-order the tickets online to avoid the line altogether and just scan them at the entrance.
We were during a cloudy slightly rainy day it was perfect, not too hot. Hot cold and windy at the top spots.

Arm yourself with caps, water and a guide if you can. It was quite extenuating this visit but at the end it was worth it.If you go in the summer it is very hot. Do not forget to take water and a caps because the sun goes hard on you here.Normally you will visit these 3 places when you are in this area: The colloseum, the forums and the Palatine. We started the day here because there is almost not any lines to buy the tickets and they will work for the three places named, so instead of throwing out your times standing in lines on the Colloseum, come and buy the tickets at Palatine.I would have maybe taken a guided tour because you cannot enjoy the full experience without it. What happened is that we had an audio guide (Tutta Roma) that was quite good but it was difficult to locate the places inside the area so at the end we decided to just do the tour by ourselves.There is a lot of interesting archeologic findings here and the museum inside is also interesting.

Palatino the Idea of Representing Power. The Palatino is a Roman hill on which the Imperial Palace of Emperor Augustus was conceived and as consequence left the name to the home of power, which became an example all over the world. The fascination stays in the domesticity of the ruins and the sense of comfort. Obviously the view is still heartbreaking, but too imagine at the time it must have been really unbelievable.
fantastic view & buildings. there are so many great photography spot, very ideal to have sightseeing here, and you can learn historical stories from local people here.
Incredible piece of history. If you come to Rome this is simply a mandatory stop. It is incredible to see the ruins of the Forum and the Palatine offers nice views from the city.

Excellent day out. Loved walking the ruins of the old center of Rome and walking the hill at sunset was a site to see. I recommend a walking tour to get detail and perspective and then finish on your own up on top of the hill.

Must visit place in Rome. This place is very beautiful and must do in Rome. The place can be visited both during the day and night and is very beautiful at both times. Book in advance with one of the guided tours for understanding a lot about the Roman civilization. There are a lot of other attractions near by too and umpteen number of restaurants to eat.
Walking through history.. My very favorite spot in Rome. As I walked among the ruins I could feel the aura of the past. History is alive in the Roman Forum. It was awesome!

Very interesting!. Combo ticket with the Colosseum and also part of the Roma Pass, literally right across the street. Interesting to see sketches of what the area used to look like and then to go view the ruins. Could easily spend 2-3 hours or more just walking around.

So much to see in one visit. This is a much bigger site than I realised. In hindsight I wish we had a guide to help make sense of all the things going on here. Hopefully I will return and make more discoveries.
Beautiful views. You really must do this on the joint ticket with The Roman Forum and The Coliseum. The views at the top are fantastic and it is a really quiet and beautiful place to spend an hour.

Greggos Roman facts.. Another great experience of Roman history and the capacity of the Romans to build such structures in a city like manner but dating back to the times when you would think impossible to do. Just like the Coloseum a must to see.

The sentae steps where Julius Caesar was stabbed to death and Caesar Augustus's home on Palantine hill are the highlight. Palatine hill is a hidden attraction within the Roman Forum. I say hidden because if we had not explored by oursielves we would not have discovered the fully in tact home of Caesar Augustus on this hill. His home with it's underground escape tunnel is fascinating.

A great place to see history. Going to Palatine Hill was exciting. We walked around and saw the houses where the Roman aristocrats and their families lived and had their parties. Looking at the architecture of the buildings that were made of marble was a sight to see and just imagine the many man hours that it took to build those enormous monuments was just stunning to see. This is one sight that should not be missed..

Never can see enough. I loved this whole location and went back and back and back. Never tiring of it, nor the surrounding streets and always saw something I had not seen before. This is not one off visit.
A very nice day. Take the time to stroll this place, it's so calming. Beautiful images that will stay with you for a long time.

Stellar view of the city. Palatine Hill is kind of hidden until you get inside and climb. You can take breaks for great photo ops along the way, but the top is worth it. Gorgeous view of the city and helpful birds eye view of the Roman Forum. I skipped paying for the Roman Forum after this view. It gives you a great perspective from the highest level with the gardens.
Nice place to walk around & enjoy the history. Beautiful place to enjoy the views! Give yourself enough time to really take it all in, so you don't miss anything.

The Palintine hill is wonderful but a large area. So glad we walked up onto the hill, so much history and a real insight into the rich suburbs of old. It is a long walk though, and very little cover on a hot day - be prepared. the views of the Forum and on other sides of the City in general are spectacular and worth it just for that.
Stunning. Amazing. Allow yourselves a good few hours to look round this place and take photos. Stunning views of major landmarks

posted info would help. Well, we all know Rome is in ruins, but I would've learned more about its history if the ruins at the Roman forum and Forum Imperiale were marked with placards telling what the ruins used to be. There was also no map of the rather large area, so finding our way around was impossible. I really wanted to see the frescoes at the house of Livia (Augustus's wife), but there was no indication of its location. The museum itself was very crowded and disappointing. Rome needs a big upgrade in terms of signage.

Leave this off your bucket list.. Without a guide, this is just too random a collection of broken buildings to take in. Our teenage children were thoroughly bored and, with too little shade, too little water and more spectacular things nearby, it's okay as an interesting way to elsewhere, but not a main event. No doubt archeologists will make more of this place, but to the average tourist with the usualaselection of travel guides, it's not one for your bucket list.

The Palatine. The Palatine, built on the site of Nero's ornamental lake, this was a massive venture which included an indoor race track which could seat 30,000?. It demonstrated the might and power of Rome and of course covers many more acres that the original lake did. The guide will tell you that a lot of the stonework and statues here were taken for the building of Vatican City, the land upon which, incadently was given to the Papacy by Musolini, el Duce! From the high point within the Palatine, much of Ancient Rome can be seen

A highlight of our trip!. Buy your tickets at the Palatine Hill entrance...no lines...and get a walking tour hand set. one will serve 2-3 people. you can tour both the Forum and Palatine Hill from there. Then exit, and use the same ticket to visit the Coliseum.  Their maps are a bit confusing so study in advance online. The forum was packed with monuments, relics of antiquity, and tourists. Up on Palatine Hill things are more spread out and serene...and it is cooler and offers more opportunity to sit and take in the incredible architectural skills of ancient Roman builders.

Rome's Origins. The Palatine Hill is located in between attractions such as Circus Maximus, the Colosseum and the Roman Forum. It was on this hill that the Roman Empire began. It is vast, you should have enough time to visit this attraction. A guided tour is recommended.
Very good, very nice view, go back into history.. There is an excellent view of Rome and the Roman Forum. It's very pleasant to walk along, very nice gardens, very beautiful.

So much to see! Buy the Roma Pass and Omni Tour. We saw this after the Colesseum. Its one of the stops on the hop on Bus tour. Worth every penny.Be prepared to walk everywhere there is a lot to see here. We spent a full morning at the Colesseum then we came here for the full afternoon. Bring a water bottle and you can refill it as you go.
Lots to see. Huge array of interesting buildings. Worth having a guide book/tour to get the most out of it as there is limited information on site.

book a tour of Augustus' and Livia's houses!. We really enjoyed the informative tour we had today that took us into otherwise unaccessible areas of these structures on the Palatine. Our guide (Mihaela [sp?]) was friendly and expert, revealing a great deal about the history of the construction and excavations of these special places. Great photo ops too! Well worth the additional cost to our entry ticket.  We booked a couple of months in advance for the English tour.

Stunning views . Excellent. This is where Rome began and where the palace was invented. One does not really appreciate the scale of the buildings until you stand in them. The musem is small but interesting - watch out for pickpockets in the confined and crowded spaces.Excellent views across the city from the top of the hill.We hired two audio tours and whilst they were full of information and detail as well as showing location by GPS, it became easier to look rsther than rely on the technology. Probably necessary gor the forum to understand the buildings and where you are.

Lack of info. We had a nice walk among the hill but we were exhausted by the end of the visit. It is a nice place to visit but not so special. We walked to reach the hill for 30 minutes but weren't impressed when we reached our destination. Great place for taking pictures though
Worth seeing. . View from palatine hill is great overlooking the fora romana and colloseum. Circus maximus is a wonderful sight

Nice to walk around but no good information. There are very little signs with information (a lot of things you just dont know what you are looking at) and no pictures at all of how the area looked like back then. We missed that. Its just soms ruins without any meaning because of the lack of information.

Nice spot. Firstly great place to buy your ticket for the 3 big sights (Palatine, Forum and Colosseum) as we had about 1 person in front of us in the queue.We decided to get the audio-guide as well which was €7. To be honest I wouldn't bother getting this. A lot of the time the bloke would be waffling on about things that either didn't seam relevant or didn't seam to be at that particular place and the thing kept crashing on us.In hindsight we would have gone on one of the tours. €5pp and from previous experience you get to know a lot more details.All in all a very important part of Roman history an worth a visit. Just don't get the audio guide.

Just go. Wandered round here in the late afternoon to kill some time after realising entrance was included in the price of the Coliseum (which is a another must!) Turns out this was a good time to visit as it was very quiet and not too hot. beautiful views over the city.

Well worth a visit. We bought a two day ticket to cover both here and the colluseum and this worked out a lot cheaper. There was plenty to do and see here and the view from the top was well worth the steps.
With a guide . Definitely a must see but with a guide as the place completely lacks of any explanation or directions. A pity. It is not really well maintained but still magic.
Loved it! History lesson was amazing.. Lots of walking, but much to learn of early Roman days.Recommend to take this tour after the colosseum tour.

Walking tour. Best to take in the Palatine Hill, Forum, and Colosseum on a walking tour. You get inside the buildings, you don't wait in lines, and the guides have some really interesting things to tell you.

What a view. The palatine hill is accessed via the roman forum and holds the remains of the world's first palace. The palace itself is in ruins so there is not much to see, but it would have been quite grand when it was built. The palace is quite massive in area so there is quite a bit to walk around. But the best part of the hill is the view. There is a balcony which provides stunning views of the forum and with distant views of the Vatican. The hill is definitely worth it.

A beautiful view of the city. I would highly recommend walking through palatine hill. The view from the top of the hill is amazing (bring your long lens for your camera). It talks about an hour to two hours walk through if you take the time to take in the magnificence and read all the signage. Bring bottles of water because they charge you a fortune for drinks around the major sights.

Great View. This place has great views and it's nicely connected to the forum. I wish I would've gotten and audio book so I could understand a little more about the site and what I was seeing. Be prepared to walk a bit.
Historic rome. Most interesting. Use the services of a tour guide to help you fully understand the buildings and the grandeur of the area
a must see. we walked there for almost 2 hours, and we were WOW'ed at almost every scene, it should be on your schedule when you are in Rome.

A nice respite from the Roman Forum. This is a pretty area south of the main Roman Forum area. The paths wind about the umbrella pines and grassy areas. There are some ruins to ponder. I imagine this was perhaps at one time 'suburban' Rome. In any case not as compelling as the Forum but there is a lot more shade. The Forum and Palatine Hill are in the same area and one admission provides access to both.
What a view. The hill full of history. Its worth the walk to view. The best way to see it is with a audio guide or a guided tour. Its a must see while in Rome.

Astounding. If you are a history lover, Palantine Hill and the Roman Forum must be on your bucket list. Walking in the footsteps of Ceasar and using your imagination to conjure up the people of Rome congregating here thousands of years ago takes your breath away.

It has changed a lot in 10 years. Just come back after a gap of 10 years you used to just be able to wander freely round here but now it is linked to the colosseum still very very interesting and worth a visit

What a life if you were rich. Palatine Hill has amazing history predating Jesus and after. The work to preserve the buildings is a worthwhile effort. And the views over Rome are stunning. Worth a visit as there are so many different sections to explore.

Amazing HIstory. One of the MUST-SEE things in Rome. SO much history to absorb, it is amazing. We wondered around ourselves, but if I go back I will get a tour guide, or a guide book to learn more. The colors in the late afternoon made for some great photographs. We got our tickets online as part of the Colosseum ticket package, well worth it.
Majestic Views . See the entire Forum laid out in front of you ending up at the Colosseum. Slightly less crowded and definitely worth the walk.
Great exposure to history. So much to see here. An incredible amount of history happened here. Yet another place where you expose yourself to history. Close to the Coliseum.

Amazing! Must-see!. We did Palatine Hill as part of our Colosseum tour via Carrani (our tour was called a Colosseum and Eternal Rome Walk). It was just as amazing and worthwhile as the Colosseum and it was amazing to see places like where Emperor Nero had once lived. Definitely wear suitable walking shoes as you do a lot of walking (but worth it!).

Get your walking shoes on and go there. Now.. We headed here thinking it would be a quick trip after hitting the Colosseum. How wrong we were. Hours later and still not having seen everything, we walked out. Tired but delighted to have spent time here. The history is amazing, the archaeological sites varied and covering multiple centuries. Very worth visiting, but give yourself plenty of time.
Impressive with a guide. We were lucky to have a guided tour of the palatine hill included with our collesseum tour. Without it we would have had no clue what we were looking at.

Humbling. Kind of bunching this review in with the Roman Forum, but it's fantastic to walk around this place in quiet awe of the ruins. From temples to palaces, 'houses' to gazebos, there's so much to see – and even more to imagine. Plus, there are loads of opportunities to take in the fantastic views over the complex, which makes you appreciate the scale of it even more. We overheard a tour guide saying that one of the large-stone roads we were walking on had survived since 1BC!It was my second trip here and I'm hoping that, in the future, they can show illustrations/videos of what the place would have looked like in its heyday.
Unsurpassable!. No matter how many time one does this walk, from any angle, from above or below, it is always awesome. An avenue into the past.
what a panorama. Do you want to see whole Rome and don't have enough time to do so? Do not miss this spot then. Just get there on the top and enjoy the view.

Amazing views. We used one audio guide between two of us and this was sufficient for our needs. We walked through some amazing trees and a few ruins to the top of the hill - the central one of seven Rome is built on. Palatine Hill has magnificent views across the city and down into the Roman Forum. If you do all three (Palatine Hill, Forum, Colosseum) it is a lot of walking so be aware. None is overly steep but there is not a lot of shade. However, there are plenty of drinking water taps to fill up bottles in all three areas.
Antique Rome!. My second visit to see Palatine Hill, spend time just using your imagination at this historic place. A must see!

A great walk among the ruins and the gardens of the old imperial palace. The Palatino (shared ticket with the Colosseum and the Roman Forum) is a lovely walk among the gigantic ruins of the Roman Imperial palace and in great gardens over looking the centre of Rome and the ruins of the forum. Don't forget to visit the small, but interesting museum on the hill.I'd recommend that you start with the Palatine Hill, then go to the forum and finish your visit in the afternoon with the Colosseum. Wear a hat and have water with you in the summer as it gets very hot and people often pass out from the heat (I saw at least three ambulances being called when I visited).Also wear some good walking shoes.
Need Tour. This is something you would do after the Coliseum Again I recommend the Rick Steves audio tour other wise you will see rocks and have no clue.

When in Rome.... Part of a wider guided tour but a great site. Evereywhere in Rome there is a site but this is close to the Colossem and the Forum so makes sense to see all 2 in one go. Need a good afternoon to cover all. It is open and so a dry day is best. In August it was very hot so keep refreesments with you. Impressive to imagine what had been achieved.

|Ancient Roman City Ruins ~ Walks of Italy Tours. History buffs will absolutely LOVE this tour !!!As you descend the walkway you are transported in time back to ancient roman times !!!Each step is another period in time as the guide explains what the ruins left before you once were. Temples, houses, markets etc.A MUST SEE !!!!
Amazing. Step back in time a stroll amount and savour the history of this amazing collection of Roman artefacts in the shadow of the Colosseum

Wow old rome. Old Rome is next to the colosseum and is another must see event and best to do with a tour guide to get the true historic value of this area. It is truly amazing to walk around areas where others roamed 100s of years ago. The old buildings that have been dug up is truly amazing

Great views of Rome. Bought our tickets to the Colosseum here to avoid the hordes, and found the site to be nice and quiet. You can explore it and have parts to yourself, the signage is a bit hit and miss but enough is explained for you to get an overall picture. Great for views over the Forum and towards the Colosseum.

Takes Time to Really Appreciate. We have avoided the challenge of touring the Palatine Hill during previous visits to Rome but this time we had the luxury of making our way through the layers of rich rich history at our own pace. It is helpful to download a travel guide to your phone or bring along a printed guide, as their official audio guides are frequently sold out, even during non peak tourist times. The pathways are some of the most challenging in all of Rome (they even offer printed warnings) so wear your most comfortable footwear. All this may seem like deterrents but it is totally worth the efforts and time to walk through this treasure trove of artifacts and amazing samples of early Roman ingenuity. There are also many beautiful views from the higher points and amazingly preserved art in the buildings. The ticket package also covers the Colisseum. Thoroughly exploring both sites would surely be enough for one day.

Must see site in Rome. Palatine Hill is an amazing area to discover, you can spend hours walking through the ruins, though having a knowledgable guide is very helpful to explain what everything looked like originally.

a walk but worth it. the history in this city just drips into you and you just need to know more and why not just walk on the old streets themselves and touch the boulders that used to be important buildings and sketch the architectural marvels that are still standing and drink from the same fresh cold water fountains as the ancients

Spectacular view of the Forum and the Colosseum. The Hill is beautiful and has sweeping views of the Colosseum and the Forum. The Gardens are a nice change from the ruins and even has wonderful shady spots to stop and take a break.

Lots of walking and hours to spend. This is an absolute must with excellent history, views and nice for a photographer. There are nice little water fountains where you can drink fresh water and refill your water bottle. The scenery is out of this world. It will be a good idea to take some snacks with because you spend a lot of time inside with no restaurants close by.

Spend a lovely day here. We spent hours here! A lot longer than anticipated but it was so good and there was so much to see. We have a beautiful day for it too which helped. The vastness of this area was completely underestimated by us so make sure, like the rest of Rome really, that you wear your walking shoes!

Great views, more history. Palatine Hill is right next to the Roman Forum and the site of ancient emperor's palaces. It is a combined ticket with the Forum, so you can visit both. We saw the Forum and then Palatine Hill, which was convenient although a lot of walking on a hot day. Like the Forum, the sights are mostly ruins with few signs. We had a guidebook that helped to explain what we were seeing; that our a tour group or guide is I think a necessity to get much out of the experience. There is a museum at the top of the hill which we visited for a short time. We also enjoyed the views from the top of the hill - to the west over the Circus Maximus, and to the north/east over the Forum. We were glad that we visited.
Interesting add-on to Collosseum. We went after touring the Collosseum. It is worth a look around for the chance to see yet more of the history of Rome, but not a highlight in truth.

Worth a quick visit. Interesting visit with great views. A lot of imagination is required whilst visiting both here and the Forum as it is mostly ruins. I would think about 1hr here is more than enough for most other than the serious historian
Took a tour. The founds and the tour were great. There is so much history in just one spot to see. The enormous columns and buildings leave you in awe of the abilities to build in the old days.

Surreal - A must see in Rome.. I have spent hours soaking up the atmosphere of these ruins. It's an incredible experience and it opens the imagination as to what it was like in that era. Take a book on Rome, soak up the sun and enjoy!

Amazing. Visited the Palatine Hill and Forum after a visit to the Colosseum, what an amazing place so much to see certainly gives you an insight to the history of RomeAt the highest point you can see all of Rome, the views were amazing.This is definitely worth a visit

Fabulous views right across Rome, great spot to chill out.. Entry is included in the forum and Colosseum ticket. The views are great and it's on of few nice green spaces in Rome to chill out, have a nap etc. Very pleasant.

Feel ancient Rome in your bones here. We feel history here more than in a museum. Walk and be astounded. Good to go with a small group with a guide 1x if you have the time. Let your imagination take you back in history.

History happened here. You cannot visit Rome and not see the Palatine Hill. It's where it all started. Most impressive are the palaces of Augustus and the Foro Romano. It's amazing to see the building skills of the Romans.

Great visit! . We started out at the Palatine Hill early morning before the heat became unbearable. The ruins were beautiful and somewhat close to one another. There were a few fountains with ice cold water which was great to refill your water bottle or wet your head. Don't bother with the audio guide as it's difficult to follow the map. Also there is a lot of walking and steps - not good for elderly folks. My in-laws couldn't do the whole fire do they sat for a bit while my husband and I went around.

Huge area.... Its quite a lot to see here. We spend more than 3hours in that place and that wasnt enough. So if do Colosseo + Palatino, have lunch between and take a loooot of time and comfy shoes ;)View from the hill is breathtaking...And with Roma-Pass we had free entry.

Fab tour back in time. Had a guided tour around Palatine Hill yesterday. Sun shining but not too hot. Definitely better with a guide who told us all the history of the buildings etc. well worth a visit. Might 80 year old mum loved it.
First time in Rome . Quite a spectacular place. Amazing views over Rome and although busy didn't feel overly crowded. Tickets easily purchased at the roman forum
Centre of the world. Wow!!! Feel the Rome of old and bask in the history of the centre of the old world. Imagine the engineering to construct these walls, temples and entire city if old.

Never ending maxe. This place is huge - bigger than expected, right down the street from the Colosseum. Your ticket to the Colosseum covers the cost of visiting this site as well, so it's worth it to see both. The views from the top are wonderful - great for pictures.

The ruined palaces of ancient Rome. The cheap as chips ticket also includes entry to the Roman Forum and the Colosseum. The Roma pass is also usable here giving you either free or discounted entry. This hill situated next to the Roman forum is where the rich used to build their huge palaces. The word palace actually comes from the word Palatine and you can well see why. Although there are notice boards around giving descriptions on what the ruins used to be, i would say that a tour or audio guide is probably useful to gain a better insight into the area. From the ruins you can imagine the size and beauty the palaces must once have looked like. It is incredible to think these palaces (one for the Emperors of Rome) existed so long ago. The area has a bit more shade that the Forums and has great views of the Forum on one side and the Baths of Septimius Severus and the remnants of a chariot arena (Circus Maximus). There is a museum here too which has a collection of Pottery and statues.
A must visit. They say the visit takes about two hours, but reserve more than that. It took us almost four and still we believe we haven't seen everything. The hole complex is just amazing!

Preferred this to the coliseum but requires some time. Palatine hill or roman forum. Buy ticket here for euro 12 skip the crowds as this covers both the roman forum and the coliseum. The roman forum or palatine hill is huge and open air so go in morning when not too hot. Or free from walking around the outside.Preferred this to coliseum. Better value too although ticket covers both. But requires some time.

Very nice views.. Nice views and amazing history. Be sure to book an official guide that can tell you everything you need to know! It is truly amazing to hear what buildings stood on the hill 2000 years ago. Nice view over Forum Romanun from the hill

Utterly amazing. So many excellent things on this site. Just utterly overwhelming in the artifacts and history present. If you want to see ancient Rome, this is the place. €12 for a two day pass, gets you in to the Colosseum too!
Love the history!. Love this place! Amazing history everywhere you walk. Spend the afternoon here after visiting the colosseum.
Amazing visit. If you understand how important the old city of Rome has in our lives, you need to visit this place.This is a open sky museum.You can take nice pics in this place.

Part of the colosseum, Roman forum trio. We visited as part of colosseum and Roman guided tour. The guide really gave us a feel for what went on and the sheer magnitude of the site. Although not as magnificent as it once obviously was still worth th visit.
The glory that was Rome. Jam packed full of Ancient Rome , temple ruins and the forum wander along feeling the history and watching the cats that now reside there...not far from the Colloseum nearby

Excellent views of Ancient Rome. The colisuem, Roman forum and palatine hill are all one ticket. Don't miss out on Palantine hill. It is of great interest and the views are stunning. You can relax after the me lee of the coliseum and enjoy walks through the gardens and ruins of where the Roman aristocracy lived. We loved it.

Awesome! Take your time!!. Awesome! Be sure to get a good guide book so you will know what you are looking at, or take a guided tour. It's amazing to think that you can walk the same paths and steps that Caesar and others did! You MUST have a good guide book or you will miss a lot. Plan to give this site lots of time so you can explore and just absorb everything around you.

Pieces of Roman history. We visited Palatine hill as part of a tour of the Roman forum and Colosseum.I found it interesting to see the ruins compared to what they used to look like as our guide had a book which made it a bit easier to imagine.There is so much history to see and read about I really enjoyed my visit again as I've stated in other reviews about Rome this is a must.

A wonderful historical respite from the hordes. I loved the Palatine Hill! Surprisingly, even though it is part of the ticket to see the Colosseum and the Roman Forum, most people skip it and instead focus their time on the other two sites. If you are short on time, then I would recommend this approach. However, if you have the energy and the time, I would very much encourage you to spend time here. It is rich with history and the ruins are quite interesting. It is also not very crowded, which is simply wonderful! It is also shady in many areas and is just overall a very nice respite from the tourist hordes. You also have a great view over the Forum from the gardens. A definite must!

Palatine Hill is Interesting, but in the 97 degree Heat Next Time I Would Pass. If you are into ancient ruins, Palatine Hill would be very interesting. And if it was a lovely summer day (70 - 80 degrees F) I might be game for exploring. But in the August heat I was not happy. We spent 2 hours at the Colisseum, and that is enough ruins for me in one day. The most precious commodity of the day is cool drinking water, so plan ahead. Admission to Palatine Hill is often included with an admission package to The Colisseum, so check the details when purchasing tickets. I think Palatine Hill admission adds very little (or no) value to a Colisseum ticket. Plan for weather and wear REALLY comfortable shoes.

Stunning visit . After visiting Colosseum went and climbed up Palatine Hill and thought it was fantastic included in the price of Colosseum it's worth the effort to walk up to Palatine Hill.I was unaware that Palatine Hill was actually their and decided to stroll around the area, a bit of a walk up the hill but not that exhausting even though it was a really hot day when I visited.Views are stunning and you can see how the Romans lived in that time as I believe this is the area that the emperor presided.I real treat after visiting Colosseum.

Wouldn't go back. I know it's the historical heart of Rome and you still can get a sense of how powerful it was when the rest of the worlds population was still living in mud huts. But it's huge and after an hour or so looking a rocks and bits of houses I was only focused on getting out. Tony Robinson and the time team would love because it's what they always seem to find....... A series of small walls.

Amazing!. Across from the Colosseum you will find Palatine hill. It was included in our Rome Pass. The ruins are quite a sight. I would suggest not visiting on the same day as the Colosseum because it's a killer on your feet. There is so much climbing and walking.

Amazing. Buy your combined ticket here.12 euros and it gives access to Palantine Hill, Roman Forum and the Colosseum. This ticket allows you to bypass the queues at the Colosseum.At Palantine hill visit the museum first to get an idea of the grandeur and scale of this site. This is an incredible site with the Circus Maximus on one side and the Colosseum on the other.The 12 Euro ticket is the best thing you will buy in this part of Rome and you can ignore the expensive touts.

A wonderful place to the feel of ancient Rome. Once you have finished at the Coliseum just go across the road to this amazing place. The feeling of living history is all around you. Great views overlooking the Coliseum. Amazing when you think of the people that have walked in the same place. The ruins are fantastic. Amazing.

Stroll through ancient Rome. Next to the Colloseum, buy a Roma Pass and have both attractions included and skip the lines. This site takes at least two hours to visit and you will not be bored ! You can walk through an entire city with some buildings well preserved, others in ruins. The visit of the house of Augustus is limited, so expect a line, and comes at an extra charge. Check the hours of operation in advance. If I am not mistaken, the house is only open in the afternoon, but if you book a group tour with a guide you have direct access. This attraction is not suited for wheelchairs.

Amazing!. Loved it here! Wasn't at the top of our list but we had time to kill and it was free to get in with our colosseum ticket so thought why not! Ended up being one the highlights of our day! It is a lot bigger than you think and there is so much to see! Highly recommended!

Great View!!. The Palatine Hill is quite a climb after you have done the Colosseum and is not for those who have any walking difficulties, once the site of the Imperial Palace of Rome it is a vast area, the Palace itself was once 40,000 sq m. However from the ruins that are left it is very difficult to imagine the Palace in it's heyday unlike the Colosseum.The views of Rome from here are however breath taking and from here you also get to view the Roman Forum and the Circus Maximus which is an added bonus.It would be great if the authorities could create a model of how the Palace once looked to give the public a better idea of what they are actually looking at, that said, once you see the site you realise the power that the Roman Empire once commanded and how the Romans managed to influence the known world in so many ways.
Walking in the steps of Emperors. So much to see, Plan your trip for viewing before you go. There is alot to see, walking in steps of emperors is an experience.

Simply Beautiful. Like everything in Rome, this place is breathtaking. It's behind the Colosseum, and you can visit both the same day. My advice is to buy tickets online, in order to avoid waiting in queues. The ticket for Colosseum, The Roman Forum and Palatine Hill costs 15 euros, and you can use it in two days in a row, if you get tired of watching so many rocks in one day:-). Make sure you put on sneakers or some comfy shoes, because it's pretty dusty and rocky.
Walking Tour. Sign up for a walking tour of the Colosseum, Forum, and Palatine Hill. Tours in all languages. Lots of walking, but worth it. History is fascinating.

Beautiful and lovely atmosphere. Relied on guidebook for info about the Palatine and Romulus & Remus - as with the Colosseo, printed info is sparse once you're in and wandering around. However it is beautiful and the atmosphere is incredible. Definitely recommended!

Another Great Example of Roman Architecture.. Included in the ticket to the Collosseum and highly recommended Palatine Hill is a vast area, very hilly and not for the faint hearted, allow 2-3hrs and Make sure you have refreshments and headgear as there is no shelter and very few toilets. Although it was very interesting I do wish the guides would show the buildings as they would have been as it is difficult to imagine. Having said that I wouldn't have missed this fantastic collection of Roman architecture.
Amazing experience! . Had an amazing tour with Sev Borzak via Viator. Highly recommend. Sev took us back in time through the lasagne levels of Roman architecture and history

Lovely views over Rome. We visited here after going to the colosseum as the ticket cover entrance to all three sites (colosseum, roman forum & palatine hill) all for a reduced rate if under 25 with valid id! The entrance is just across from the colosseum it is the same as the entrance for the roman forum! The view from the top of the hill is breathtaking. It is also a lot less crowded than the surrounding sites.

A piece of hIstory!. You can visit this place with the same ticket for Colloseum and Roman ForumIs something that you must see,it had an impressive view, you can see the Colloseum, the Vittorio Emanuele attraction, the Roman Forum and the other places ..
History before your eyes. Visited Palatine Hill after the Colosseum as it is nearby. Well worth the visit. Amazingly preserved ruins.

Another one which you should not miss. Walking distance from the Collosseum, included in the same ticket if you have Roma pass. Highly recommended, allow at least three hours, possibly more. Impressive history. If you are going in summer, take plenty of drinking water.

The large Castle that has dropped. This story is amazing now this was apart of the tour we bought at the collessium which I highly recommend. The tour guide is amazing funny and very informative. Is able to really bring out the best of the history. You can do this yourself but if you don't get the tour guide you will not know the history which is the most interesting thing.

In the middle of history . If you like history you will love the roman forum. It is like you would be replaced 2000 years back in time. Just walk around and enjoy. Don't forget to bring something to protect yourself from the sun in Summer because there is not much shade in some areas.

A break from the city. Great place to relax a bit. And very interesting in terms of ruins. Connected to the roman forums and most hoponhopoff buses stop right infront of it. So it would be wise to go there using them, then buy a ticket (much much less crowded than the colosseum) then exit from the other side near the colosseum and enter without waiting. (Standard ticket includes all 3 places)
Great feeling of history.... Visited last year on a 5 day trip to Rome and was part of a tour with Dark Rome that included the Colosseum. Another must see location if you're visiting Rome.
Beautiful Area of Rome. Palatine Hill is a classic area of Rome. It is full of history and stories and beautiful buildings. Well worth seeing if you are in Rome.

excellent - but do this with a tour guide. fantastic ruins to see - a must do when in Rome. Do this with a tour guide who can give you the history of what you are seeing - I would recommend City Wonders tours for this site. Amazing!

A walk through history. Over 2000 yrs of history on the Palestine hill starting with the legend of Romulus and Remus. We had a guided tour and I would thoroughly recommend that, otherwise you will be staring at a few old stones and bushes. The guide brought the history to life and it was truly humbling to be amongst such history. A wonderful couple of hours!

Beautiful historic spot. An absolutely stunning view of roman architecture which includes the coliseum- the best photos I took on my trip. The beauty is awe inspiring and the spot easy to access although some stairs to navigate.

A very interesting look at the oldest part of one of the greates cities of the world. Did you ever want to walk down the pathways that Caeser himself walked? Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum is a peek into what's left of the centre of one of the greatest empire's heart. Looking at the ruins and imagining the grandiosity of the temples and buzzing piazza and imagining senators debating laws and rules for the first ever democracy is a great way to start or end your Colosseum tour. I'd highly recommend a guide if you can afford it, as seeing the place itself doesn't do it's rich history justice and you'll just be staring at some ruins.
Great History. Very nice but by the time we got there on a hot day, we were somewhat overwhelmed with so much to see. Lots of walking.
Palatine Hill. Amazing history in every direction you look. It's worth the time to visit. Not like the tourist sites in Rome. May take a few hours to go through it b

Excellent view and a piece of history. We were a little rushed here by the tour guide. There isn't much to actually see on the Hill, but you get an amazing view of the Forum and what once was Nero's palace. Definitely a must see, but expect more ruins than actual sites or buildings.
A trip back in time.. Visiting Palatine Hill is like taking a trip back in time. The mind is boggled by the sense of history.

Another must see in Rome. Yet another glimpse into the splendor that was Rome. Even from the ruins you can the the magnificence of the architecture and get an appreciation of what it took to create these structures. Would love to go back and spend more time, but never again in August. Too hot and crowded.

Long queues. Visit early in the day as you need plenty of time to see everything lots of walking involved, just take it easy and take your water, it's very uneven in places. Lots of fountains in Rome to refill your water bottle, so need to keep buying from the sellers as lots around the Coliseum.
One good walk. From the Roman Forum, just beside the Coloseum, you can see the hill and the walkstairs to the Piaza Veneza

take your time. you feel the Roman imprint! it took us 2 hours to stroll through the ruins feeling the atmosphere. Looks much smaller than what you see on movies though! the arc of triumph through which the victorious roman legions would march looks really small too!
Stunning. A must-see place with all the stairs, the view, great shooting areas. Pictures on the stairs, with the view behind, next to the lions or next to the Romulus and Remus statue!

Amazing. If you book a guided tour to Colosseum and the the Forum, Palatine hill is inluded. (We used Walks of Italy). The fact that was the oldest Roman hill to be inhabited makes you wanna know more and more about it.

Beautiful and restful. Palatine hill was a welcome place of beauty, history and shade on a very hot august day. The views were wonderful and there were many points from which to gaze over Rome. There were interesting information boards and a museum which helped us to make sense of our surroundings and the history behind them without a guide. We got our tickets at the forum entrance where the queues were minimal and came to the hill from there. As is common in Rome there was a water fountain available to top up our bottles and cool off. Well worth a visit.
Incredible!. Stepping into history. This place is wonderful! The whole area in which it is situated is amazing. It is hard not to feel amazed at what the Romans were able to achieve.

Palatine Hill. you must be in good shape to walk around. Be sure to have comfortable shoes, a hat and water, mainly if going in a hot day. It worth more for the view in the horizon and to learn a little of its history. That is where the word PALACE came from - the big houses build over that hill.

A must see!. From the Colosseum our tour guide took us to Palatine Hill (one of the 7 hills of Rome and the oldest to be inhabited). We meanderd up and down and around the hill taking in the beautiful scenery. From the ruins of the homes of great Ceasers to ancient churches to the Circus Maximus (where the chariots ran) to the Forum it was all amazingly! We stood on a ridge at the Ruins of the palace from the Flavian period and looked down on the place where St. Paul addressed the Romans...wow...I still get chills picturing it! Go see the Palatine Hill!

The Roman Empire began on this hill!. It is believed to be where Romulus and Remus where found in the Lupercal Cave. The homes of Augustus, Cicero, and Marcus Antonius were all built here. At one point the hill was covered with palaces; the Emperors lived here too. Today the hill is an excavation site littered with ruins. On top is the Palatine Antiquarian Museum. Inside one will find ceramics, frescoes, mosaics, inscriptions, and portrait heads found on the site. Wear good walking shoes, bring water, and prepare to spend a few hours here at least. As well, have your camera ready; you are up high enough to get great shots.
Amazing!. You will at least half a day to check out this place. Lots of interesting information about this hill can be found inside. You can use the same ticket to enter the Colosseum, too.

Centuries old city in the middle of modern Rome.. Fascinating ruins that are right in the middle of modern Rome. It was such a joy to imagine how life was before electricity, automobiles or air conditioning. The history that eminates from Palatine Hill is incredible.
Beautiful. Walking and climb up in the Palatien hill will bring you amazing atmosphere and view. i had amazing experience from some histories and some things remain around here. very exciting!

Amazing views. This was incorporated in our tour of the Colosseum, the views alone from here are amazing. The history of the hill is engaging, would be just as nice as somewhere to wander around and absorb everything around you.

Provides a great view of ancient Rome. The Palatine hill provide us with a great panoramic view of ancient Rome. The gardens are also lovely. We feel it is a definite must see but the climb can be taxing for people who are not in good shape.

Love it. The place was not in her best shape, of course, but lots were remained and you could imagine how it was before. Love it. Worth every penny to visit. Wear good shoes, bring water, hat and some snacks to relax and enjoy the view.
Must see in Rome. One of the must see main attractions in Rome, what else can you say? There is a lot of hills to negotiate if you are not keen on walking just be aware.

So much to see. It never seemed to end! I had no idea there was so much to this place. It was fascinating to see it all, knowing what a great history it had. Climbing the hill also gives you some fantastic views, specifically of the Forum and its surroundings.Informative signs are few and far between, which had us wishing we'd done some research beforehand, or downloaded some sort of audioguide to get the most out of what we were seeing. A tour would probably be beneficial as well, if you're willing to spend some more money. Also, make sure to give yourself plenty of time to see everything! We had no idea how much time could be spent in there, and I'm sure we were there for the better part of 3-4 hours. Your ticket is only good for one admission, so make sure to eat prior to your visit, and/or bring some snacks- we were wishing we had, as we felt a little light-headed and pretty exhausted by the time we finally called it quits.All in all, this is a must-see in our book! It's an amazing experience to walk the same ground as the ancient Romans, and get a glimpse into how things would have looked and felt many years ago.
Great veiws. Well worth the walk up the hill, some beautiful views, and lovely garden areas. You can really get a feel for how many Layers of ruins there are in Rome.

Amazing view! . Nice short walk which rewards you with a simply awesome view of the Forum and the city! Would have loved to have had a picnic with us and just sat under a tree enjoying the atmosphere.

History unfolding. Felt a bit like an emperor looking back to the glory days and somewhat proud that it is still there for so many people to visit and admire. Makes it even more worthwhile if you do some research before your visit. We had purchased tickets online (tip!) at ticketitaly.com for the Colosseum and Palatine Hill incl downloadable audioguides, 2 weeks before for Euro 18,50 p/adult and 14,50 p/student. After visiting the Colosseum we entered Palatine Hill. The Colosseum is doable within 1 or 2 hrs while Palatine Hill has much 'more' to offer (and see). During the summer months the heat will have a tiring influence so be rested and take your time. Worth a visit!

History Buff Bucket item. From all the history and fiction books you've read to all the movie or TV shows you've seen prepare to be awed. Yes it is just a bunch of knocked down stone blocks. But before, this was Rome. You'll walk the same steps the ancients trod. Close your eyes and imagine.

Amazing and not crowded!. First of all - start here, not at the Colosseum. There's virtually no ticket line, so you breeze right in, and you'll be able to skip the terrible line at the Colosseum. This was my favorite of the three locations on the ticket. Hardly anyone was there, and we were able to take some amazing pictures. The ruins are incredibly well-preserved, and it was humbling to see how huge they were. It was also very shaded and breezy, which was a welcome relief in the August heat. This was my favorite thing we visited in Rome - a definite don't-miss! Check out my blog post on Rome tips for more details: http://sousmonparapluie.weebly.com/home/eurotips-rome
Get a tour. So much history that you need a tour. Highly recommend Through Eternity tour company. Ask for Katia as your guide.
Beautiful. A joy to behold! Wonders right there to see and enjoy amidst the hustle and bustle of everyday life. The view from further up is beautiful. A must see.

Given its location quite a view and you can sense the scale of the area below.. Overshadowed by the Colosseum perhaps and on a hot day you might want to limit the time to sufficient to give the overview and add the perspective to the Forum and the Colloseum. You can only go up and down on one route although you can see some of the older stairs which would have connected this to the Forum's buildings. It is part of the ticket for the Colloseum and the Forum so it's a pity not to do it. Didn't go into the museum there so can't comment on that .

Well worth doing. . After the Colosseum you can move onto this area and you'll find it much more interesting. Lots to see and some quite jumbled up history to unpick.
Whereas the Colosseum takes at most an hour. This site along with the Forum can take the rest of the day to fully enjoy.
History comes alive. A good tour guide will make history come alive. This is an important area to see, often it is done with the Coliseum tour. Wear good walking shoes, and take a bottle of water.

Palantine Hill. Palantine Hill is best seen if you go with a guided tour (3 in 1 for coliseum, Palantine hill and Roman Forum )The guide will tell you more about the place and you'll also enjoy the company of fell I was tourist. After your tour guide lives you you can enjoy roaming the site on your own.If you just want to go directly inside on your own or with your family you can do so . climbing the hill is a bit strenuous one coupled with the heat, but at the end it's a good one for 2 reasons:> if you're a history lover you'll really enjoy the place .it's really full of ruins what's really will strike you is how these structures stood the test of times and how they were built just imagine their impliments on that day and yet they were able to withstood time to tell us something about them .(now they're trying to preserve and restore some areas)> if you're a nature lover parts of the green areas are really pleasing to the eyes and there's also nice resting shaded areas. At one/some of its vantage point /view decks you can watch and see the roman skyline and the blending of old and newer architecture.

Must do for a walkabout but be sure to have a guide or guidebook!. This is the original "mansion on a hill". No comparison. Visualize the way it must have seemed 1800 years earlier - there are some great tour books that give you the before and after views of many Roman Ruins - try and bring one. Look at how the Romans were living back then and realize how advanced they were...and appreciate the preservation work that is ongoing to save this for future generations. Magnificent history lesson as well...from the bones and stones of the past.

Love it!. Have no idea why I did not see it the last time I was in Rome, so this was the highlight of this trip to Rome. Though not so reach in monuments as Forum, the buildings are better preserved and you really get the feeling about the size of the old Rome.I only wish it's not included in the same entry as Forum, since I needed a break between those 2 and there are no refreshments on the site.

Ticket for retrofit I thought, beside colosseum. As I feel, ticket required here is used for retrofit for it. Popose should be present Roma glorious. That's good for Roma I absolutely agree, but be honestly say, visitors' ticket could only help very very little about that... You can get the info of how original Roma build up from a small museum internal; but really confusing about many routes even there have map... From entrance besides colosseum(noted only from this entrance, there have others exit), basically says, left side is palatine hill, right side is Roma forum Nice view on the top, there have 2 'terrace'

Ruins of Ancient Rome - A Must See. Palatine Hill is near the Coliseum. The views are amazing and the historical relevance is surreal. It always amazes me that one can turn a corner or walk down a street and suddenly come face to face with the structures or in this case, mostly ruins, from the ancient past.

If you are into history that's a jackpot. Pallatine Hill its basically ruins, its a very large ground full of ruins of what it was in the past.As at the time I visited it was middle of july and nearly 40 degrees it was exhausting to visit it. I went only to walk around quickly enough and took me more than an hour to go out...it is really big grounds.
Great views. Great ruins. Best to walk over to the corner of the property and get an amazing view over the Roman Forum below.

A must so in Rome. Easily my favourite place to visit along with the Roman Forum.The views from the hill are incredible. There are so many amazing ruins to see along with the Colleseum and also Rome.Wear your walking shoes and bring some water. Cannot recommend enough and photos just do not do it justice.

Panoramic views from Palatine Hill. An excellent viewpoint overlooking the Roman Forum and beyond. We spent 2.5 hours exploring the roman forum and Palatine Hill. The audio guide was blandly informative. It was a hot day - I had hat and parasol envy- luckily there were enough spots of shade to listen to the audio and a couple of water fountains to refill water bottles. Learn about the Vestal virgins and the follies of Nero and a whole lot more.
Great views. Beautiful views and lovely to walk around after visiting the Roman forums and learning about all the history. Visit early if you can to avoid the heat is visiting in the summer

Good place to take a wander and a break. Beautiful calming area with plenty of ruins and views of the city. Lots of seats to take a break and soak up the history. At times, quite repetitive as such a huge area, but worth the wander.

Nice to see ancient rome from Upside. the palatine hill ticket is already included in the Colosseum ticket and its entrance is the same for the roman fourm. the palce is very big and you need to have good fitness to climb the stairs to the top and catch the nice vie and weather upside.

A Must See. One of the seven hills of Rome, it overlooks the Roman Forum, and overlooks the Roman Forumum. The view of the forum was outstanding, and the proximity to the Forum and Colloseum was really convenient. The Metro is right opposite the Colloseum.According to tradition, Romulus founded Rome here. It became the residential district of the Roman aristocracy and the remnants of the early founding structures (huts) are evident and this site has serious historical significance.

Palatine Hill Stirs the Imagination. As these ruins were close to where we were staying while in Rome we decided to wander over and see the sights...imagine our surprise when we discovered a set of ruins we had never heard of...not as complete or impressive as Pompeii ofcourse but enough to stir the imagination

Before you book. This place is incredible and requires quite a bit of walking. The price to go in without a guide is 12.50 Euros. This price includes the Colosseum. I highly recommend that you first visit this place and then the Colosseum. The line to get tickets in the Colosseum could be upwards of two or more hours. While the line for this is as little as ten minutes. Take an umbrella, frozen water and some sandwiches so you can take a nice break under the trees if you go during the hot months. Remember the ticket you buy here will get you into the Colosseum as well.

Awesome. Had a great time here. Amazing to be able to visualise the enormity of the place. Signs have been put up around the sight this year explaining what each area would have been used for which provided valuable additional information. We had a guide to show us round. He was great, so knowledgeable and interesting to listen to and gave information we would never have known about otherwise. Well worth the visit.

Large area of what once stood. Very neat to walk around see all of the ruins and buildings. We went freely without a guide and spent a little over an hour exploring. The size of what used to be was massive and quite extensive. We had a bit of rain while exploring so the heat had diminished and it was nice outside. This requires a lot of walking and climbing stairs. It's spread out over a large area and you could spend several hours exploring.

Best view of Roman architecture & old city. Palatine Hill undoubtedly gives the best view of Roman Forum, Colosseum and other parts of old city. You can also see the beautiful Piazza Venezia from a distance. I got my best Rome pictures from this place. Don't forget to take your camera. Also, during summer it may be hot so carry ample liquid, although you will get that in Hill.

The Beginning Of Rome. Palatine Hill is included with the admission to the Colosseum and Roman Forum, but prepared to spend many hours. We stared walking the place thinking that it was going to take us a hour or so; we were so wrong. The more we walked up the more we found more to walk and it was a big puzzle that was a bit confusing at times. There is so much history in the place that I order to really appreciate it one need to dedicate a good 4 hours to see it all. After a while my wife and I go so tired of the walking that we weren't sure if it was worth it. Luckily once we got to the top of the hill and we saw the breathtaking views it kind of made up for all the walking. There were a couple of museum buildings which were very interesting and it kept us away from the heat for a while.

One of my favorite places!. This is the center of ancient Rome where all the action took place! A copy of the great Marcus Aurelius on his horse guards the great museums nearby and could spend day there easily! Many great ancient statues in museums so never bored! Views are great too and you know this place is special! Enjoy!
History before your eyes. My teens really enjoyed this. Go to the top of the hill above the museums for great view. Tour guide had book of photos showing full layout of the structures, helpful.

Going back in time. We really enjoyed visiting Palatine hill. It is a bit of a trek to the top but it is well worth it. The ticket for the Colosseum includes this and the Roman forum. The ruins are quite intact and you can get a good feel for the place. There is also a museum at the top which has some interesting artefacts.
Must see. It was breathtaking experience when we arrived at Palatine Hill. Like you are back in the past again. There is so many things to see and to walk through.

Loved the amazing histor of this place. A must visit while in Rome is a trip to Palatine hill. The history of this place is fantastic. Suggest you read up the history before visiting and try and get a guided walk to take in as much as you can.

Worth going to for a pic of Ancient Rome. Not much to say on this apart from the fact that it's worth climbing to the top to get a pic of the surrounding area, including the Roman Forum. I found it a nicer experience than the Forum itself.
Just like historic movies. It s near colosseum , you dont wanna miss this historic part of rome with too many ancient stories and full of tourists, music and street performances
History at it's finest. Amazing to be able to stand in history and let your imagination run, putting yourself back in the day....

Fascinating. Well worth a visit. This is the very heart of Rome where it all began. I do recommend a tour guide though so that you can understand how significant this relic was to life as we know it.Apparently, only 2% of this enormous palace remains now but it is obvious how gigantic and important it was. This city once housed over 1.5 million Romans. A population that was only equaled in the 1800's in London!Definitely worth a visit!

Walk Amongst History. We did this as part of a tour with Walks of Italy (who were fantastic), if we had gone by ourselves I think we would have just wandered around not really knowing what we were looking at but our guide gave us excellent history and background and this made it come alive for us. Highly recommend you visit here but not without a guide. Wear good walking shoes and bring water which you can replenish with lovely fresh chilled water at lots of spots.

Incredible! . A fantastic way to see palatine hill is simply to buy a €12 ticket, it ladwts for 2 consecutive days and also gets you entry into the coliseum, no need for guides or expensive 'multicards' the best value €12 you will spend in Rome. You can walk around Palatine Hill snd the Roman Forum all day with incredible views of the ruins and of the city as well, all breathtaking, however be aware that there are no concessions inside, there are toilets in the museum and water fountains but thats it, you may want to bring snacks with you especially if you have kids, its the perfect setting for a picnic depending on the weather of course, also there is a lot of walking involving steps and inclines not a great idea for the very old or young. No doubt anout the views though, it is absolutely stunning, we loved every moment.
Amazing!. Beautiful architecture of Rome! It's very interesting to see ancient buildings. There are a lot of points of interest. High recommend!

Incredible . Just returned from Rome! We discovered this on a walk during our last day. I must say that the sites and views are incredible. You can see far out!! It is very hilly but the name kind of gives that away haha!! Serious recommendation!!!

It was amazing.. The Palatine Hill is within striking range of many other Roman sites, so it's no inconvenience to visit. Unfortunately, as others have noted, walking can be difficult. I don't recommend it for the mobility challenged/disabled/elderly. I recommend you book a tour through City Wonders FKA Dark Rome to bypass lines for this and the Roman Forum/Colosseum. It is a fantastic site, but you would miss quite a bit without a tour guide, which adds a cost to doing it right.

Worth a visit! . Definitely worth going here before the collessium and buy your tickets for both. You get to see the ruins of the forum but climb up and you get to see beautiful site of the ruins. Not much information boards around but well worth visiting for the sites and cheap seeing as our ticket also covered collessium for the next day!

Great unexpected history. I didn't know of this place until I arrived in rome and im glad we went! Some much history to see here and feels bigger than the roman forum. You can really sense how big the buildings were built.

Beautiful, but be prepared to walk. If you didn't buy your ticket in advance, we recommend you to start your visit by those attractions before going to the Colosseo (the three are included in the same ticket) to avoid its huge lines. Take your water bottle to fill at the fountains and be prepared to walk: we took around 4 hours to get to know everything. If you don't want to pay more for a tour or audioguide, take your guide from nome for a more enriching experience.

Badly organised and frustrating. Site is fantastic BUT it's very difficult to get around. Lots of walking and little in the way of signposts. Audioguide does not have good directions so you spend a lot of time retracing steps trying to find what you need to look at. This may be fine in some circumstances it's not when you are in heat of around 40 degrees with little shade. To make matters worse one of our audioguides didn't work and had to be returned but this can only be done at the site you have bought it - even though there are other areas where they can be hired on the site you can't swap it there so it's another long walk there and back to sort this one out. The excavations here are fabulous but be prepared for a lengthy visit and best to go very early morning before the main heat of the day arrives

Brilliant and helps beat the queues for colluseum. A wonderful glimpse into the past... Best enjoyed with a guide or guide book.Get your combined ticket for here, the Roman forum and the Colosseum and beat the massive queues at the Colluseum entrance. I had no queue to wait at here unlike at the Colluseum and you'll want to see all three anyway.Be careful though, the ticket is only valid once so don't leave until you are sure you won't want to come back.

A giant puzzle.. I think that the view of Palatine Hill it is kind of a 3D Giant Puzzle. You can saty there for ours and try to figure out what was left of the buildings.
The place could and should have more information for visitors. è very uninformative. A pity.
But, as many things in Rome it is a good visit.
Excellent with colosseum . If you've been or going to the colosseum then you have to go up palatine hill!! The remains are fascinating and a perfect add on to an Ancient Rome day out

Avoid a queue. Even though it was very hot this is well worth the time. A lot to see and it includes the Forum. Ticket includes entry to the Closseum and there is a much shorter queue if you go to Palatine first and then go to the Closseum after and avoid along wait at busy times.

Awesome view of Forum. Go to Palatine Hill for the best view of the Forum. It's lovely to walk around there, but the sight of the Forum from the top is breathtaking. We didn't take the Colloseum tour, and went directly to Palatine instead.

Unreal Views Of Ancient Rome. This area boasts fantastic views of ancient architecture and views of Rome. The Palatine is a significant area to visit as it has so many ancient ruins and great photo opportunities. My recommendation would be to check out at night and during the day. The only con is Rome gets humid mid day and it's extremely hot especially in summer months.

Give your eyes a change in imagery. After a couple of days in Rome, everything starts to more or less look the same. Huge stone and marble statues and carvings or elegantly painted murals in golds, blues and reds. At Palatine hills, images change up a little because the greenery of nature breaks the monotonous ancient grays that your eyes have become accustomed to seeing. Being on higher ground, the air is much cooler and refreshing there also. There are great views from above. The incline is not a stressful walk but the larger stones and the haphazard way they are laid may make it difficult for some people with knee, hip problems to navigate. You must place your feet carefully when walking.

Amazing . Visiting Palatine Hill was absolutely amazing. The history of ancient Rome was tangible.This is a must see for any traveller traveling to Rome who is interested in ancient Roman civilization.

Breathtaking. Well worth the visit, take your time and enjoy all the ancient ruins, the site is vast. Don’t forget to make sure you have plenty of water, there are many fountains to refill your bottle if you run out. I had a fantastic time and would return again. Pre book your tickets online and save time, the queue's can be huge and in the sunOne of Rome’s must see sites!!

a must see. Well worth the climb, take time and enjoy all the ancient ruins, make sure you have a hat on a hot day and plenty of water is a must.i do photography it was amazing looking down on the ancient sites. I had a fantastic time and would return again, taking a picnic is a great idea lots of places to sit and enjoy and make a day of it.

Have spent many hours here and could spend many more. Over the years I have visited Rome many times and at the top of my list of most amazing sites is Palatine Hill. Sometimes I've wandered around with a travel book in hand, others times I have joined a tour (be sure to arrange tours with official Rome tour companies). Ancient, engrossing.

Must see!!. The area of Palatine hill is very wide..If you are fan of History you should come here so you'll see the ruins and the ticket can be avail at the ticket Booth inside the Colosseum..it's a package.U can visit Colosseum first or the other way round.The ticket is only good for 2 days visit/entry..Was lovely to see all these places in the center of Italy..I Learned a lot in speak of the Romans time.

Ancient Rome. Well worth the effort of getting there. Certainly there is a sense of atmosphere = particularly if you manage to visit in the evening when there is a definite aura about the ruins . This is a must for anyone with an interest in the classical world, its art and architecture. In the day expect crowds but still worth it.

Way better than the Colosseum. Yes, you heard it. The place is so big so theres variety youll see. That also means you can go 'treasure hunting' and try to see the less obvious sights from the place. Considering its a historical ruin, youll probably find some gems. Great place for the curious and interested.

A must on the way to the colessum. Palatine hill is a truly beautiful area.. Worth taking your time to walk around it and be amazed by the beauty and power of the Roman Empire.. A must while in Rome!!
Worth a visit. It's worth the effort to climb up the Hill. Everyone visits the Roman Forum so It's not that crowdy.
Huge site. Only 12 euros to enter and this included entry to the Colosseum.You can walk amongst the extensive ruins and with the hill views over the while forum and Circus Maximus. Great

Visit ancient Rome. We enjoyed the amazing history walking in ancient Rome on our visit to Palatine hill. It is a bit of a relief to get away from the hustlers on the streets as the site is available only by ticket or tour. We enjoyed the self guided tour and found it all very interesting.
Palatine Hill. A full or half day and you can see ancient Rome by foot. Lots of walking and ruins. Discover how Romans use to live and the advanced culture they really were.

Take your time, be amazed. Walk it through slowly and with time, the most unthinkable things can amaze you, it's not only about the arcs or the Colosseum, the Vestal's temple, the Isis temple, the churches along the main road, or the path to Liva's house are among the most incredible and time-travelling experiences in the inmortal city.

Fantastic history and great views. This is definitely worth a visit, like most places in Rome expect lots of tourists but the ruins are incredible and amazingly designed. It is an inspirational piece of history so take the time to walk there, relax and take it all in! Please note you do not need a tour; it's a good free attraction if you've brought a Colleoseum ticket!

A must do!. Be ready for some walking, but don't miss out on this. We booked a Colosseum tour with Viator that included Palatine Hill and the surrounding area. I"m SO glad we did. It was a long, tiring, and hot day (July) but it was worth every minute spent. Our tour guide was fabulous, can't remember her name now but she was really good and very knowledgeable. Just walking through some of the paths was breathtaking. To think how old the area is and what it used to look like, what it was all used for, etc. Overall cool place for anyone, history buffs or not. Palatine Hill also makes for some amazing photos, if you're into photography.

Beautiful . We saved visiting here til the end of trip. And it was worth the wait. We went early in the morning and it was so peaceful and beautiful. On the high points you get some beautiful photos. The ruins were amazing to look it. We didn't book a tour we just just our time and strolled through it. Plenty fountains for filling up your water bottle.
Well worth a visit. This is right beside the Colosseum and a ticket for this will also get you into the Colosseum (but without an enormous queue to buy the ticket)

One of the Highlights. I enjoyed our tour of the Palantine Hill very much. It was extremely interresting from both an historic and a cultural perspectiev. The geography of Rome is so much a part of its history and this is one of the most interesting and strategic areas.
Interesting. Very interesting, you can great views of Rome and you can't really go wrong.... Enjoy I'm sure you will.

Great views on the hill. Palatine Hill is situated on a hill in "ancient" Rome. It offers great views of the side of the Coliseum and over the expanse of the Forum.Palatine Hill was the place of government in ancient Rome and building are still there to prove it. Buildings are still being uncovered, and archaeologists believe that they have discovered the birthplace of Romes first emperor, Augustus.For those in shape, it's no problem getting up and down. For those out of shape or those with knee/joint problems, it can be a challenge getting up and down the hill.You can spend anything from an hour to 2-3 depending on how much you want to dig into history. If you're on an abbreviated trip like I was, my recommendation is to climb up to the overlooks, take some pictures, enjoy the views, and come back down.

Interesting Site. Viewed this after the Colosseum (part of the same ticket for all 3 together with Roman Forum for €12). Is a 'sister' sight so is only a short stroll away. This has drinking points to refill water bottles if very hot. Gives a feel for how the higher class Romans lived overlooking the rest of the city. Would recommend.

Amazing Views. The Palatine Hill is situated in the Roman Forum, it has some Roman architecture and great views over Rome. But there is no water and little shade so try to avoid visiting in the mid day heat as it quickly becomes unpleasant!
Amazing place. You must visit it and let your imagination go back in time,so you will understand the importance of this place.

Trip Back in time. This was so AMAZING!!!! To be able to see so many ancient remains of buildings and imagine what life was like. (To be rich and live on ground floor apartment and have a fire and heat or less afluent and live in a higher floor apartment). See Temple of Vestal Virgins, Caesar's buriel site, Colesium, and Arch of Titus in one place And walk where men have walked for thousands of year. Yes, AMAZING!!!

Wouldn't miss it . Really nice to see roman ruins and walk amongst them if you like or else the ancient city from above from various view points
The architecture is grand and breathtaking
Worth a walk and you'll get a few great pictures
An amazing experience. Don't leave Rome without visiting this incredible experience of Roman history. Every corner you turn has something to see. Allow up to 2 hours.

Good views - lots of pollen!. A nice walk up and great views of the forum - gardens were lovely too but must be honest couldn't see much for sneezing and eyes streaming!
Views of the colosseum were great too - good photo opportunities :)

Historica Fantastica!! . Amazing walk on history's past. I recommend hiring a private tour guide but the walking tour seemed free (with admittance ticket) and the interpretive signage is in Italian and English and offered a lot of information! Wear STURDY shoes and bring water - you can refill bottles from potable fountains! Take tons of photos! No discernible restrooms. Worth the time and exploration!

Great views but be prepared to walk lots and you'll need a good imagination. Our ticket was included in the Colosseum tour otherwise we wouldn't have come here. I'm glad we did though. There's a lot of walking to be done and in the heat it was exhausting. Wear comfortable shoes as it's quite difficult to walk on stones, gravel and uneven paths The views of the Colosseum, the forum and Capitoline are really good. We walked aimlessly as the signage is not good at all. We relied on our guidebook for information and followed tour groups for directions. If you love history then you might be better off joining a tour group for detailed facts. We took refuge from the heat and visited the museum which has statues and artefacts from the Palatine which was interesting. This place was once dwellings for the rich and noble back in the day but you have to use your imagination when walking around as it's now ruins. This place was OK but I prefer the Colosseum.

One of the highlights of the Rome for me. This is a yourney back in time and with some imagination you can feel people rushing there form one place to another those centiries ago.You should read about this place before and reserve hours for it!

Picturesque and Lovely. We probably wouldn't have done the Palatine hill if it wasn't included in our tour of the coliseum. You don't want to miss it. Fantastic views of the city and the forum. The gardens are beautiful. And it's pretty spectacular to walk on the grounds that Rome's first emperors inhabited.

Breathtaking feats of engineering dating back 2000 years.. An excellent place to visit with great views of the Forum below giving a clear picture of the structure of the place.
