The engineering of aqueducts to bring water into the town and to this hill are incredible. Arts clearly flourished and some good examples in the museum on the hill which is part of the entrance fee. Get a combined ticket with the Colosseum for 12 euros each a very good deal.
A must do walk. Walking through these ruins helps you really understand what the real Rome might have been like. Along with the Colosseum it should be one of the first things to do in Rome.
Very good example of Roman ruins. I saw this at sunset, and was impressed with the architectural details present on the ruins. There is a real prescence of history in this area.

Imagine the history of Rome. Rome: "La cita etrna". In the Palatine Hill I run straight from the airport when I first visited Rome. If you like antiquites and have a good travel guide, you can shape in your mind how life was during ancient years and revive the spirit of Roman Empire. I wish Athens arheological sites were also unified that way so as the visitor to have a complete picture of our civilization..
Amazing !!!. Lots of Roman architecture still standing after all the centuries when it was built its truly amazing to see and you can really imagine how they lived

Classic! (duh). A classic, literally. I really enjoyed my visit here. But make sure you've got enough time, the area is HUGE, a lot bigger than I had anticipated! Also get hold of one of those maps that show you what buildings were where, and how they once looked. You can purchase one from the gift shop at the entrance, I think.

Fab views. We got to the top of the hill and all I can say is wow, the view was fab!You can see so much from high up and can see some of the other sights to visit from the hill.Booked tickets for the Roman Forum/ Palatine Hill and Colosseum well in advance to save waiting in queues.
Time travel into the Roman era. I have been to this place thrice and still feel the time wasn't justified. We used Rick Steve's audio guide to help navigate ourselves and it was a great experience.

Enormous. It's absolutely beautiful. There is so much history, so much to see. overwhelming history and breathtaking views. I did a great tour with Through Eternity walking through the Forum and up Palatine Hill. Amazing place, just layered with history and stories. It was very hot when I was there, take a frozen bottle of water and a big hat, flat walking shoes.

A trip through history. Waundering through both the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill was quite an experience. Such rich history. In the Palatine Hill Museum they had a wonderful little movie presentation that gave a but of history about the Palatine Hill and reign of Augustus. Very informative.
Wow!. A stroll through time. As a massive history geek I was in awe at every turn.Wear comfy shoes, take your time, take it in..if you can!!!

127 lyn. Again like so many things in Rome rpthis is another piece of history that you ought to see while you are their we had a guide take us round and give us the history he was excellent he was a old guy not very tall and is name was Jonny well worth the money we paid him

Ancient and quiet. Except its enormus historical meaning here is very nice park for walking and take a break...
Perfect place to walking and imagination...

Get a guide if you really want to experience this. There are lots of treasures here but without a guide, it just looks like crumbling ruins. Relics of old columns tell stories. There's the apartments of the Vestal Virgins. Or stroll over to view the Circus Maximus. You would be hard pressed otherwise to get all this without a guide. Ours was through Cris Giannichi. Her contact is in Rick Steve's book.
Beautiful views over Ancient Rome. The views over the Forum is amazing it you really get a sense of how grand the whole Roman Forum was in its hey day.
The fall of Rome.. Wear sneakers and knee pads and try not to fall over these pieces of broken history,else you'll come home on crutches. pieces of broken history

World's First Fashionable Neighborhoods/. Here lived Rome's wealthiest and influential citizens. Sadly none of its once magnificent palatial homes have survived the last two millenniums. But with a little imagination they can be envisioned in one's mind eye.It overlooks the heart of the Ancient City.
Wonderful to see the center of Rome. This is the center of Rome although confusing without a guide I found it to be fascinating nonetheless. A bit of a trek be prepared for some up hill walking.

The views from the top are worth the walk!!. We visited here as part of a tour that included the Roman Forum and the Colosseum, and it's a pity that we didn't have more time to spend here. The hill itself is quite steep, and we were warned that there are usually lots of pick pockets here as there are lots of people slowing making their way to the top of the hill. Fantastic. We went late afternoon and entered at the entrance away from the Colusseum entrance as there were reporrs that there were little queues. We were not dissapointed. An amazi g spectacle.

Amazing Roman history. It is such an amazing site with so much to look at. There are multiple entrances. The one closest to the Coloseum is the most crowded. The Roma pass does save some time though I might save it for another more crowded site. There are numerous areas to take pictures from. Just have to be patient with all the tourists running around. Again it was hot since it was July. There were numerous places to fill up your water bottles so I would be prepared since the vendors are more than willing to sell you a bottle from 2-3 euro. I would recommend starting at the top and working your way down. You get the tougher hill out of the way and you can exit from the lower level where it is far less crowded. We spent about a hour wandering around and loved it.
My favorite place in Rome.. Fantastic views over the city, Roman Forum and Colosseum. Had a great feel to the place. My favorite spot in Rome. Got in for free first Sunday in the month.

The Palatinr hill gives the forum and the ancient city context - the views alone are stunning. If you are interested in the history of Imperial Rome the Palatine Hill is very interesting. There are extensive ruins including the Houses of Augustus and Livia and the Flavian Palace. The sheer scale of these ruins (esp. the Flavian Palace) are a demonstration of the power once wielded from this place. From the palatine hill you can walk down to the old forum, it is easy to imagine the 'great men' of Rome walking with there followers down to the forum to conduct business as was the norm in the days of the Repuplic. If you visit this site be sure to carry water and wear comfortable shoes - the climb up the hill in heat is tiring.
Excellent on a private tour!. This was included in our private tour of the Colosseum. Do not miss going up to Palatine Hill! The history and views are simply amazing.

Such a great day!. After visiting the colosseum we decided to spend the afternoon exploring palatine hill. Such a beautiful place enriched with history. Many places to just sit down and soak up the ambiance! Would recommend to anyone was by far our favourite place to visit!

Fantastic!. A must do in Rome, and next to the Colosseum so perfect to do in one day! Make sure you go in the morning or afternoon while it is still cool if planning to go in Summer. I happened to go to Palatine Hill on a 36 degree (plus humidity) day in Rome, so fill that water bottle up! I spent just under 3 hours here which was ample time to see most things. A wonderful experience and fascinating history.

Surprising history. To be honest, I didn't know much about palatine hill so it was quite an amazing surprise to learn that is where the Roman Empire was born! The entrance is the same one for the Colosseum so you can go to Palatine Hill and Roman Forum one day and to the Colosseum the next day, it's a two days ticket, so worth it.

History in Rome. What a great place to see and learn about the history of Rome. There is a fair amount of walking, but not physically demanding. Take a small or group tour to learn as much as possible.

Palatine Hill 2015. We considered this possibly the best day out in Rome, it's very extensive with great views over Rome. The food in Italy is fantastic...and the gelato, wow, on every corner, history all around. Near the coliseum and chuck full of old roman buildings and ruins, something to see. Easy walking with some uphill, wear appropriate sightseenig shoes.
Unique. Historical site with many buildings, gardens and temples from ancient Rome. If you are found of history, it is easy to spend hours walking in this place. Don't forget the sunscreen.

Amazing views. Take a deep look at the ancient Rome. Perfect spot to appreciate the Roman Forum. From up there is really nice to watch over the ancient city of Rome.

Very old and beautiful.. If you want to see old rome then you should must visit this place , so rich on archalogy that you wont realise how your entire day is spent.

THIS is ancient Rome. Oh wonders! is the centermost of the Seven Hills of Rome and is one of the most ancient parts of the city. It stands 40 metres above the Forum Romanum. The Palatine Hills is where the Patricians and the emperors resided. You can still visit Augustus' house and his wife Livias' house, though only if you buy a special ticket.If you are interested in Roman history in the making, this is the spot for you!

If you aren't an expert in Roman history.... I have some basic knowledge of Roman history, but I would not have known the significance of most of the structures, and in some cases, piles of rock located on the Palatine Hill without a local tour guide. I chose Through Eternity tours because their guides have a history or art background and the tours are MUCH smaller than is typical. Wear comfortable shoes and be prepared to climb a lot of hills and stairs.

Birthplace of Rome. After my tour of the Colosseum, I passed the Arch of Constantine, and went up the Palatine Hill, which overlooks the Roman Forum. At that time, I did not appreciate its importance. Now I do. The Colosseum may be the symbol of today’s Rome, but it was merely a place of entertainment in the good old days. By contrast, the Palatine Hill may not be best-known in our time, but it occupied a unique place in Roman history. The city had its origin on the Palatine. Romulus and Remus were found to live here, and Augusta, the first roman emperor, was said to be born here. Many rich and powerful called this hill home. Many sites have been excavated and well-preserved. For example, a hippodrome still looked impressive, and a museum exhibits many precious artifacts. Just as Tsar, Kaiser, and Shah derived from Caesar, the word “palace” originated from the word “Palatine.”There were reasons for its historical role. The hill was the centermost one among Rome’s seven hills. Living at the top of the hill provided people with physical safety and beautiful views. When I am writing this review, an analogy came to my mind. What the Palatine Hill was to the Roman Forum was what the Acropolis was to the ancient Agora. Having stayed here for several hours, I walked down to the forum.

Good view of Rome and it's past history in natural environment.. Me and my family were driven up towards Palatine Hill as part of our private tour of Rome for 3 days. The view from the top provides a great feeling of what the Italian Capital City was like back in time of the Roman Empire many years ago. The unique architectural structure although ruined following past earthquakes, wars and development are very well preserved and there are places that are still slowly being uncovered releasing many hidden gems. The area can be very hot on the sunny day, so it is best to bring plenty of water and put on sun-screen as they is very little shade. Always a great position and place for photo opportunities. You can also observe other historical building from Rome at a distance from Palatine Hill such as the Colosseum for example. We liked what we had seen and it was no wonder that it is one of a few most explored places in Rome. The only downside will be a lot of walking involved so if it is going to be a problem, always ask your guide for advice or if you are on a private car tour, ask your driver for help and assistance. Apart from that, it is the most wonderful places to see in Rome and no tour would be complete without it.
Very Large. It was very large and I was tired after going to the colosseum so spent most of the time finding places to sit down. The ruins were very nice though.

A perfect way to explore history. spent more than 5 hours exploring around. our guide took us to all the important historical sites. was a really nice experience. I think the best way to explore is to purchase the multi ticket. If you are an history explorer, you definitely need to do this.

Great collection of actual period bluildings. This site is sooooo full of ancient bldgs from a variety of periods that it looks almost like a Hollywood set! Great fun to imagine yourself part of the scene. . . Excellent signage. I easily spent half a day there. You can also buy the "multi-ticket" there which will also get you into the Colosseum later, without having to stand in those god-awful lines.

Amazing History. What an amazing step back into history! The only thing we didn't like was how hot it was the day we visited. We were hot and miserable, but luckily there were a few places with shade to stop and rest and water fountains handy.

Interesting Stop. Interesting Ruins. We enjoyed the view as our guide was able to point out interesting parts. At first glance I did not realize just how many layers there are to Palatine Hill architure and ruins. The admission to Palatine hill is typically included with the Colosseum admission. It is well worth the stop.

Beautiful views of Roman Forum from Palatine Hill and a nice garden to relax under shade on a hot day.. Palatine Hill we visited along with Roman Forum. Palatine Hill gives great views of Roman Forum and the City of Rome. It also has a nice garden and big trees which provide shade on a hot day. Interesting antiquities to see. Please note if you bought a ticket for Colosseum this also includes Roman Forum and Palatine Hill. No need to buy additional tickets. We made a mistake of buying additional tickets seeing a queue there without realizing that our Colosseum tickets are valid here as well.

Great Historical place.. Great experience. I would recommend listening to Rick Steve's walking tour while visiting. The park is very well preserved and taken care of. It is clean and the employees were courtious.
amazing. Amazing antique hill next to the forum, where the history becomes alive. One of the must see places in Rome.

Amazing old Roma .... . Take half-day for visit, it is an impressive time travel. For those who like to understand what you see in the various layers of ruins is critical a guide or a good book on the spot.Regrettable not have more information on local and / or suggestion of routes according to different times of the ruins....it's like a generous salad of monuments.

Amazing object. I don't have the words to describe how wonderful this object is. You can't describe the feeling when you are standing on the place where Roman civilization started. The ruins are impressive but they miss the magic of the other two. The best part of the tour was the view of the city from the top. Worth the walk. Palatine Hill is directly across from the Coliseum so I just crossed the street. I entered through the Via Sacra entrance. Don't miss the Palatine Museum, it's got some excellent examples of statues and other things they found dug up from around the area. Also, it is air conditioned. So after walking around the forum and the hills, it's an excellent place to catch your breath and enjoy some beautiful antiquities. Walk behind the museum and look at the rest of the ruins and continue to the far end where you can get a nice view of the Circus Maximus. I walked back down and took the exit by the Temple of Antoninus & Faustina and it took me out to the Via Imperiali.

Amazing History to See. must see in Rome. a must see in Rome, especially the view inside building to the back yard. All monuments compacted together

Simply immersed and enjoy the ruins.... 1) walking shoes... real comfy shoes as the stones and cobbles are not heels-friendly... tho' i see ladies with heels strutting all the way up. Well...2) self reflection seeing the ruins and how great the human kind were.once upon a time... 3) carry bottles of water (at least)... no stalls or kiosks selling food... families with small children to take note! Amazing . The view from palatine hill is absolutely incredible as you look down on the Roman forum! Would definitely recommend visiting here. Especially as palatine hill, the Roman forum and the colosseum are all under the same ticket so you may as well get your moneys worth!

Excellent....wear walking shoes..... I found Palatine Hill to be fascinating. Seeing all of the ruins, thinking about how they lived so long ago. Please note the sidewalks are not flat and at Palatine Hill you walk on some stone from ancient Rome. It is slippery, hilly and uneven. Wear a sturdy shoe! I saw several people with sprained ankles.

Far cooler than I thought it would be. I thought this was going to be similar to the Roman Forum, but it’s not ruins itself. It’s a garden overlooking the ruins with wonderful views in all directions. Very worth a treck up to that hill. Great views of the Forum.

The original of the Seven Hills.. Beautifully preserved and totally enchanting. Here's where Rome bag an! The ruins are highly accessible, clearly marked and steeped in history. There are public restroom, snack carts and water fountains nearby. A great way to spend them afternoon with the Circus Maximus and the Colosseum nearby.

Excellent place to visit, great ruins... a guide makes it even better!. We loved Palatine Hill. It was included with our Colosseum Tour from Overome tours and I loved it. I think you really need a guide to fully enjoy the area as there is not much signage or explanations around the ruins. Our guide was fantastic and we were traveling with 4 kids ages 7-12 years old so having a guide there to answer all of their millions of questions was priceless. Rome was my favorite European city that we visited because the history is incredible. Exploring Palatine Hill where it supposedly all started with Romulus and Remus was an awesome experience.

The 'burbs for the Roman leaders. The Palantine Hill, of course, was the living area for many Roman leaders, Senators, and even Emperors. Hence simply walking around gives one a great feeling of history. The PH is best experienced with a great guide book.The ruins are impressive. The history behind them is incredible.
Simply wonderful. Very nice collection of sculptures!.So many great pieces in one place. Make sure you get the audio guide.a definite "must see" when in Rome.

The Founding Place of Rome. Rome was founded on this hill's slopes. There are huts of a small village here as old as the the 10th century BC. In ancient times the 'huts of Romulus and Remus' were ceremonially refurbished here each year. Most politically and culturally prominent Romans resided here during the Roman Republic, and it was only natural that the imperial families and their emperors establish their residences (palaces) on the Palatine. Unfortunately, the Palitine is a poor third when it comes to touring the 'Big Three' of Colosseum, Roman Forum and Palatine. Why is that? I have a theory. Perhaps this happens because of the impressive and historic nature of both the Colosseum and Corum. Maybe too the geography plays a part. The summit of the Palatine is a steep climb up,fro either the Forum or the Colosseom. That 140-150 foot vertical ascent is pretty steep, and that means that tourists - after walking around, up,and down both the Colosseum and the Forum - they don't look forward enthusiastically to having to climb up that slope to the top of the Palatine and then walk around a third time looking at all of the imperial-era remains. But if you want to see the places where 'Romulus lived and founded Rome, if you want to see the remains of the House of Augustus, if you want to see the ruined Palaces of Augustus, Tiberius, Domitian and other emperors, and if you want to see fabulous views from this height of Rome, you simply must make the climb. Rest at the hilltop Museum, or alongside the octagonal,fountain amid the ruins, or in the Farnese Gardens. There is a lot to see here, but a bit difficult to find an easily readable map of the place (most are complicated and scholarly, and many in Latin), Rick Steves supplies a solution with a convenient, readable, hand drawn map in English. It is published by the authors of a travel blog called 'Those Crazy Schuberts'. You can also Google 'Rick Steves Palatine Map' and it will be among the first images that appear in Google Images. Regardless of where you obtain a copy, print it out and take it with you. It is very readable, in English and will point out all the major sites. The ancient 'athletic area' or 'garden' is also of interest, being sunken. Of course there are only ruins left. No marble, wood, iron or bronze. But that can be said of almost all ancient monuments around the city. The point is that people interested in this History of Rome should also cherish the opportunity to walk where the people who made that history lived and walked. And that 'where' is atop the Palatine Hill. Enjoy!

Great views but massive. Do not be fooled by the size of this from the outside.. It is massive!, we thought it would be a quick stroll, however it took forever and seemed to go on for miles!.. worth it though for the views.
Amazing maze of ancient Roman apartments. The Palantine Hill is one of my favorite sections of Rome, as it shows where people would have lived, and it's less crowded than the main attractions.
Add to your itinerary if you have time. Nice to see if you have time after visiting the Colosseum. This is part of the ticket we got for €12 from coopculture.it. Enjoy!

Amazing Historic Location. Taking in the views of Palatine Hill were a highlight, as the amount of history that took place on the very path we were taking was hard to fully grasp. We opted for a guided tour as it helped us to understand the full significance of the area. Palatine Hill was an unexpected highlight for me and I am so glad we took the time to walk through.

Long But Not Boring. Very intriguing to say the least. So much to see and learn. Seeing everything and reading all the signs that go along with it can be rather tedious. I'd recommend getting an audio guide so you can listen while you walk around.

Like taken out of movie!. This part of Rome is a must see for traveller who love architecture. In contrast to all the amazing buildings all around Rome these ruins tell a different story. The tour among the ruins itself is scenic and worth it even if you're not utterly interested in cultural stuff.

Lovely -Beautiful views. The best part of this place is the surrounding views of Roman hillsides and other parts of the city. Go early (8am-10am) and you will the place to yourself before all the tourist groups start packing in and before it gets hot. Also it was fun to imagine yourself living in Ancient Roman while walking around the ruins.
Great views just alongside Forum. Located right alongside the Collosseum and the Forum, I didn't expect much but it was lovely! Beautiful views.

Excellent View !. Palatine Hill is easily accessible from the Forum. The elevation gives you many great view of the entire city of Rome, the monuments in the Forum and the Colosseum.
Their museum presents a great history of the previous people that occupied the hill.

Worth a look & Free entry with Colosseum ticket. It must of been fantastic in its day but very little remains now, it is a good walk around but they should put some pictures around the place so you can see what you are looking at because it is hard to visualize what some of the structures would of been like. If your visiting the Colosseum you get free entry to this place so you can't not check it out while your there being as it is located next door.

Ancient Beauty Never Dies. I absolutely love the Roman Forums and cannot wait til the next time I return! The ticket for the Forums, which includes Palatine Hill is included in the Colosseum ticket purchase. There is an amazing view of the city from here. There is a lot to explore and lots of walking so be ready for a long day!

My favorite place in Rome. Palatine Hill is definitely a must see when visiting Rome. It covers a fairly large area on a hill and there's a lot to see. If you visit during the summer you will also appreciate the museum where you can cool down a bit while looking at exhibits from different periods in Roman history. Palatine Hill is also a lot less crowded than the Colosseum.

A fairy tale place!. The Palatine looks down on the Forum, and what a place to have a mid-day meal! Beautiful botantical gardens, plus the ruins of spas, and athletic venues used in ancient times. Quiet settings, grassy areas abound to stretch out on and sip some wine, have some bread & cheese and just relax!

Palatine Hill. Palatine Hill lays on one of the 7 hills of Rome and is located between Forum Romanum and the Colosseum area. It cost nothing to view and you cant miss it on your way from Forum Romanum to Colosseum. You should read a bit about it prior to visiting, as there is not a lot of information about it at the area. Some signs and historic information but not much. A guided tour might be your best option.

Wow. The Forum and all the ruins around the Palatine Hill should be on everyones list of places to visit, WITH comfortable shoes!!! The walking is on cobble and can be very uneven, with that said, take your time and enjoy the history before your eyes and under your feet. Be prepared for ticket sellers, tour salesman, selfie stick sellers and just a bunch of other street salesman who have nothing better to do but try and separate you from every euro you might have hidden in your secret travel wallet. Although kinda pushy, most street salesmen will back off if you ignore them completely, as soon as you acknowledge them, they are on you like vultures on a roadkill. The sights are usually very busy and you can have a tough time if you traveled around the world and think you deserve to have these places to yourself, but if you keep an open mind and realize that nearly everyone else in the world wants to see these places just like you do, and accept the fact that the ruins are on everyone else's list of things to see, it just makes it that much more cool that you are actually there doing it. I was near a couple who complained about the "horrible uneven walking surfaces" and all the people there who were crowding all the sights they had planned for months to see.... Comfortable shoes and an open mind will go a long ways towards making your sightseeing more enjoyable.

Got Lost Outside Of Palantine Hill .... We were on our way to a a Colosseum Dungeon Tour (after a very long day) and got lost along the way ... Palantine Hill (interior) was closed but you can fully appreciate these vast ruins from outside the gate. Not to mention the quaint neighborhoods and bars surrounding Palantine. If you enjoy Palantine check out the Jewish Ghetto. Such an interesting, escape from Roma, place. Much more impressive than the Colosseum itself in my opinion.
Wonderful. I cannot express for me how wonderful this place is. Far better than the coliseum . Walking the street up the hill was breathtaking .
Beautiful view of a historic place!. The views were incredible. So much to see! Just be aware of the temperature in July. It was hard to enjoy when it was scorching hot!

Well worth your time. This crux of Roman culture is a must in your visit to Rome. The area is a large and expansive wash of history, and gives some of the best views in the whole of Rome. Definitely worth your time.

How the wealthiest Romans lived. Fascinating to see how the Romans lived, great views from the top. Make sure to bring plenty of water,a hat or umbrella if going in July, even with a hat my wife got heatstroke and collapsed on the bus on the way home. We got back to hotel eventually and a cool shower sorted everything
good to buy tickets for colluisim. buy tickets here and save a long wait ,tickets valid two days for all 3 attractions save a long wait at colllosuim this ticket hut is only 100 meters away

spectacular. this place is amazing especially from the streets up above, we where on an ebike seeing the sights, it is so interesting and might I say old it is just pure history it is what you see in the old movies these amazing buildings, it is down in a valley as rome was built up on itself over the years, and it is a haven for cats there are hundreds of them among the ruins, it is really worth viewing from ground level and up to the viewing points above

History, a beautiful view, and nature in one spot. Just a must see when you visit Rome. You walk up Palatine hill from the Forum and you can't help but struck by the history. You can see where Caesar Augustus lived and how the city of Rome first took shape. On top of the hill there are hundreds of wild poppies in bloom (in May when we visited). Don't miss it when you're in Rome!

Well worth a visit and plenty to see. I used my Roma pass to gain entry and was so glad I visited this fantastic place. Firstly there were no crap sellers and beggars around so you could enjoy the sights in piece. Given the queues and crowds at some other sights this was a more pleasant place to visit.The area is fairly large and the history is obvious. Some of the views over Rome are stunning and to be able to stand where some of the famous Roman emperors lived is in itself an experience. The area has maps and descriptions of written in English and there are water fonts to be able to rehydrate on a hot day.You could easily spend the good morning or afternoon exploring so definitely good value.

Hat & Water is a must!. Don’t forget that you can see the Palatine Hill, the Roman Forum and the Colosseo with one ticket. The ticket is good for two days. To see the Palatine Hill, you need at least 2-3 hours. It can also get very hot at Palatine Hill, during the summer. Therefore, take your hats, sunglasses and water bottle with you. (There are some fountains with drinkable water available around the Palatine Hill. You don’t need to buy water.) If you don’t like historical places, you may skip the Palantine Hill, because it is guaranteed that you will get very tired after your visit, especially if the weather is around 40 degres.

Forum romano - veja do lado de fora. Palatino - passeio. Opportunity to walk around in the gardens where the romans did. It worth go to Palatino if you have time - a very big garden. My recommendation is to start in the Via Claudia - the highest point - and walk.

A hike to the top but the views are worth it. We only scratched the surface here as we visited in summer when the hike to the top was a little too much. It was worth it though, the views are spectacular and you can get some fantastic panoramas.
Amazing view of archeological sites in Rome. Amazing view of archeological sites in Rome.. good location to take pictures and get a overall view on Rome city.
The history wows!. Another not to miss attraction in Rome. The structures left behind for us to explore are fantastic. The Museum here holds wonderful remnants and historical evidence.
Interesting. We were on the hop on hop off bus tour and alighted here to have a look around. The site is amazing and well worth a look.

A nice view of the forum. The Palatino Hill is a nice detour to see the Roman Forum from above. There are some ruins to see, but nothing to brag about. On the day we were there, the line up was long and hot. The ticket is included in the Colosseo ticket.
Hot but worth it. It was really hot the day we went so take a water bottle and fill up from the cold water springs. Pretty good experience even without a guide
Roman streets... So amazing to walk down the very cobbled streets that Julius Ceasar walked down. I was puzzled to see people still bring flowers here in his memory..

History, history and more history!. Lots of nooks and crannies to find layers upon layers of history. Everywhere you turned there was more to see. The museum helped to set everything in context and you also got some great views of the city.
Amazing. Despite the heat it was quite astounding wandering amongst the ruins and the birthplace of Rome. Words really can't describe the works and architecture.

The epicenter of the beginning of ancient Rome. The Palatine Hill is the center most of the Seven Hills of Rome and is one of the most ancient parts of the city. It stands above the Forum Romanum, looking down upon it on one side, and upon the Circus Maximus on the other.It is believed that on Palatine Hill, the twins Romulus and Remus were found in the Lupercal Cave by their four-legged shepherd mother, who raised them. Ultimately, this is where Romulus decided to build the city.

Peaceful, Ancient Oasis of Bustling Rome. We came here in October 2014 and June 2015. The ground is uneven and cobbled - so make sure you wear sensible footwear. There are all sorts of wonderful sights around the hill such as remains of imperial palaces, Farnese gardens etc. However if you want to see Livia's house - tours are timed and you must prebook tickets. I have been left disappointed to have not gone on both occasions. The top lush and green with trees, with beautiful views over Italy and I find it much quieter up there. They also have fountains with potable water. However if you want to see Livia's house - tours are timed and you must prebook tickets. I have been left disappointed to have not gone on both occasions. The most frustrating aspect of the Palantine Hill is the lack of signposts and availability of maps to get to everywhere on the hill. Despite visiting twice, I have really struggled to get to all of the sites on the hill.

Amazing ruins and views over Rome. I found the Palatine Hill and Roman Forums absolutely fascinating. It is a true testament to the incredible ability and advanced civilisation of the ancient Romans that so many of the buildings can still be viewed and admired. The ruins of the Emperor's palace on top of the hill are spectacular.It is a pity that a map of the area wasn't supplied with the tickets as this would really help to make the most of a visit. I did see people with audio guides though. I would recommend taking a handbook or audioguide as the signs are fairly sparse and there didn't seem to be a set route..It is quite a steep walk on uneven ground but on a nice day is a lovely place for a picnic. The tickets we bought here covered the Colosseum as well and were valid for one visit each to the Colosseum/Forum and Palatine Hill over 2 days, which is handy as there is a lot to see. The views from the top of the hill are really stunning.

Views over the colosseum and roman forum are the real highlight. The Palatine Hill is located adjacent next to the colosseum and towers over the Roman forum – it is covered in the 12 euro ‘ancient rome’ pass which encapsulates these three key famous attractions. It was ancient romes most exclusive neighbourhood and a famous site where Romulus supposedly killed his twin brother Remus and founded the city in 753BC. Unfortunately time and medieval re-development has been cruel to this area and its present structures require a bit of imagination, as well as a decent guide to actually get much out of a visit. I would recommend downloading the FREE ‘Rick Steve’s Europe’ audio guide on your smartdevice (ie iphone or ipad) and listening to it via earphones. It will allow you to get more out of your experience and is free. A real highlight of palantine hill is its viewing platform over the roman forum – this is a great spot for photos – particularly if you zoom in on the colosseum. It’s also good for getting orientated if you plan to visit the forum later in the afternoon. A common approach to a visit to palantine hill is to combine it with its 2 adjacent attractions (they are even included in the same ticket) in the same day and this is sensible. Just beware that the colosseum should be visited 1st up, as the queues will build up during the day (less of an issue for the roman forum). You need a bit of time out between this is and the forum and there are a surprising amount of large open green spaces so pack a lunch and relax before taking on the forum in the afternoon. Bring water as there is none on sale in palatine hill. There’s also only a couple of sets of bathrooms – one in the small museum.

Really Fascinating Place. The Palentine Hill is a part of the Roman Forum which is bang opposite to the majestic Colloseum. This place is filled with fascinating archaleogical artifacts. The temple of venus is at the right hand side of the entrance. A quick tip for travellers. In case you see a long queue for tickets in the Colloseum, just hop to the ticket counter at Palentine Hill. The same ticket is valid for Colloseum and Palentine Hill. Generally ticket queue is very less at the Palentine Hill.

Very nice. Palatine Hill is right next to the Roman Forum and overlooks it. Walk up for a better view of the Forum and Colosseum. It is worth the short walk and will give you a different perspective in which to look at both structures.
Iconic Rome. Step back in time and feel like you're in Ancient Rome. There are several "Roman soldiers" around for photo ops.

Walk up Palantine Hill. the Palatine Hill area was quite impressive and though my health made the walk a bit difficult, it was worth the effort. The view of the Forum, colosseum and the area in general from on top of the hill was very inviting.

A Stroll through Royal Ruins. It comes along with your Colosseum ticket purchase. It's a nice shortcut to and from the Colosseum. You just need to walk through it properly. Otherwise, you'll get stuck at various dead end areas.
Impressive!. After walking around the whole day, I was kinda of tired and rushed through the Palatine Hill. However it is definitely worth going!

SO hot but so amazing. Like many things about Rome, it was amazing to see these ancient ruins. Access is included in your Colosseum ticket, and it's really close by, so there's no reason not to go. We actually took a lunch break between the Colosseum and the Palatine Hill, and that was a good way to go. There's very little respite from the sun, so if you can avoid the hottest part of the day, you should.

Must see piece of Roman history. Visiting the Palantine Hill was a great break from walking around in 35 C weather in Rome. There are trees to hide under and look at the terrific ruins that make up this important part of Roman history. Also, the ticket gets you into the Coloseum, so you can skip the lines. (neat trick!)

Roman emperors' luxury villas. The villas scattered on top of the hillside overlooking the forum were des res mansions. It's a bit confusing to understand exactly what you are looking at and it can get very hot on the hill. There is a small museum with a few well preserved statues. Part of the entrance ticket to the Colliseum and worth a look
Historic Place. A historical place. Every building (it's remnants) were beautiful. Wonderful for a visit. Should take time to be here at Rome.
Great history lesson.. Loved this part of our ancient Rome your with Sylvia of Walking tours in Rome. It really allowed us to see how ancient Romans loved.

A Step Back in Time. Even on the scolding hot day we visited there was so much to see in this beautiful park area. There was something awe inspiring about the untouched nature of this ancient hill!
A must do!

Only for Photos. Included in the Colosseum/Forum ticket but a bit of a treck on a hot day. Only thing left is a section of the planted garden buy really good visa from the platform to look down on the Forum and to take photos

Must See for the Historic Architecture Afficionado. The ruins strewn about Palatine Hill and the Forum area were a highlight of one of our evening walks of Rome. For lovers of ancient architecture, these fields of ruins are an awesome study. The area around Palatine Hill is also a great place to enjoy the evening activity of tourists and Romans walking, driving and speeding about on their Vespas to take in the culture and atmosphere of Rome.

One of Rome's must-see places!. You should put on good shoes and get around the area as widely as possible. The hill has good prospects to Roma Forum and on the other side you will see the Circo Massimo. Between these there is a lot of interesting things to see.
Amazing. We didn't actually get to visit directly but the view from the road was awesome. We will certainly be back to Rome and make it a "must do" visit.

Unexpected treasure. I came to Palatine Hill because I'd read up that it's sometimes better to get to your Coliseum entry ticket here to save queueing at the Coliseum! I decided that as I had the whole day ahead of me that I would spend the morning on the hill and look at the Roman Forum before going to the Coliseum at lunchtime. First of all it's true that you don't have to queue very much to get in which is a bonus. Secondly everywhere you look, and there is so much to see, you are greeted with picture postcard views and historical gems. There is a great little museum that you can look around. There are also fantastic vantage points over the Forum, Coliseum, Circus Maximus, over towards the Vatican, over Rome.. The ruins of the various palaces are inspiring. The site leads directly into the Forum which was also fascinating. I spent so much of the day up on the hill that by the time I'd looked around the Forum I actually decided to finish for the day and return to the Coliseum the following day. The great thing is that your ticket is valid for two days across the three sites. Originally, if my ticket haven't included Palatine Hill I would have only visited the Forum and the Coliseum. I'm so glad I saw Palatine Hill, it's definitely a place worth visiting, and somewhere I hope to return when next in Rome.

Must go better than Coloseum. The first time I went in 2010 I didnt go in due to time constraint, also I didnt do research so I thought just bunch ruins on the hill.This time we joined a private tour outside coloseum for $30 Euro per person, we got the skip the line access and a guide for ColosseumIt turns out the regular ticket for colosseum also includes entrance for Palatine Hill, and the $30 we paid also include a guide waiting for us at 2PM.The guide Gregory explained a really good story about the development of the Hill over time, how magnificient it was with 5 floor temple and palace, he also explained the ruins are due to human force of the Vatican instead of natural disaster.Overall very good view on top of the hill.

Incredible views . I'd say that the Palatine Hill was actually one of my favourite places to visit in Rome, purely for the breathtaking views over the city. The entrance was included with the ticket for the colosseum, and in some ways I preferred the Palatine because it was much less crowded and so it felt more relaxing. A truly beautiful place.

Have to do It!. So this is where it all began. Romulus killed Remus and then there was Rome? Excellent!We had no idea what we were looking at. We did some research before hand and then just enjoyed strolling through while all the flocks of tourists with frowns stared in different directions with earphones glued to their heads. I remained oblivious. Ruins are not my thing as I am a gardener and need desperately to see Green before I am happy. There were plenty of grasses and wild meadow flowers, or more accurately 'weeds', for me to frame my pictures so I was happy. You have to go see this purely because you are in Rome and very little else in the world is this old. Join the rest of the crowds and get with the spirit! I read online to buy our tickets here and not at the Colosseum where the queues are ridiculous. So we kept walking till we found a little office, but I think it was the ticket office for the Forum. No queues there. And the ticket worked for all three entries with skip the line access. Wonderful!

Rome's past revealed. I'm a fan of history so this stroll around the ruins of Rome was informative and interesting. The ticket came as an add on to our family coliseum visit but the kids had had enough so I ventured on my own. The Palantine hill gardens were a nice stroll and you could sit and have a drink in the shade. ( remember some insect repellent here). The rest of the ruins were impressive to me and its nice to see Italy taking care of its past.

Beautiful beautiful Rome. What an amazing place. I've seen pictures but nothing compares to seeing it and walking through it. Took my elderly parents to Rome and they loved it too. They liked the Sunday walk down the boulevard with everyone dressed for church.

Expansive views, relaxing gardens, and massive ruins all overlooking the Roman Forum. Summary: Hill overlooking the Forum with stunning views, unbelievably good museum, and hidden treasures.The pros:-Entrance is included in ticket to Forum and Colosseum-Some of the only shaded places in the Forum-See remains of Domus Augustus, Palatine Stadium, Domus Flavia, Caligula's palace, hut of Romus and Remulus, House of Livia, noble gardens, and the ancient art collection at the Palatine Museum-This area is much less crowded than the Forum below, so you can take your time to enjoy leisurely -Shady spots to relax throughoutGood to know:-Get there from the southern end of Forum, by taking path up from Arc of Titus-There are public drinking fountains (nasoni) throughout Palatine Hill, including one near the top of the staircase to the gardens, so bring a water bottle-Read ahead to know about the ruins you're seeing-Palatine Museum has incredible collection of statues, paintings, mosaics: Small, but mighty-Palatine Museum WC often has a line-There are 2 terraces for views, 1 at the northwest corner, 1 at northeast corner overlooking Forum-Just like everything you'll visit in Rome, it's bigger than you expect

Interesting and great views of Rome. We did a tour of the hill as part of the Colosseum guided tour tickets we purchased outside. Definitely recommend a tour guide (we had Chad from California) as there are no descriptions or information on the hill so a guide would be your only source of information and history.

This plus the Colosseum are a must see. We started here before the Colosseum. Be prepared to do a lot of walking over uneven cobblestones. Other than that it's an amazing place. There's a lot of information available as you stroll through that really helps to explain what you are looking. A good guidebook is a must.

Travel back in history. I could not get enough of this place...so much history and yes you can make this area a one day trip. the hill offers not only the stunning view of the streets and an imagination to believe those Romans are still walking but there is a museum that offer impressive artifact from the time.Walk the steps to the top of the hill watch the grand statue that is magistic outside the museum then walk inside and enjoy your time seeing histroy.

Amazing!. There's an entrance fee but is included in the Colosseum's ticket. It's amazing to walk around all those ruins!! You've read it in your history books and now you're there!!! Is extraordinary!!! We went in June, the weather was hot and sunny, dress accordingly. If you can bring an umbrella since there are very few shady spots.

No Palatino, No Party. The visit on Palatino Hill is higly reccomended when you visit Rome,With the same ticket the Colosseum visit is included.Your visit will be very enhanced with a good guide, in order to understand who, what , when and why, of all that.Palatino=Palagio=Palazzo=Palace this is the first thing to know: that should explains more than thousands words how kind of history comes from there.The area is wide, you need time to visit everything, beginning from the paleo-romans houses that was already ancient when the romans built Palatino and that romans considered as theirs roots. For that reason those ruins has been preserved by romans like we do for Colosseo today. The famous Emperor Augusto lived there in very small rooms. Today is still possible to see some frescos from 2000 years ago. The big horses' stadium, columns, mosaics, a little casino built in midage full of stunnings frescos (you need a special permission to see inside it) and the view of Rome all around are the topics of the visit.Enjoy it.Aldo

Remarkable visit to the past. Tthe gardens of Palantine Hill gives a great view and lots of photo opportunities of Ancient Rome including the colosseum and Roman Forum. It is advised to purchase a combo ticket for entry into the colosseum, Palantine Hill and Roman Forum. Better to enter from Palantine Hill to avoid long queue from colosseum.
our history. not to be missed, too many of our origins as civilization happened here, but a good guide is needed and avoid hot hours, crowded

Eerie and Breathtaking. The vast array of ruins, remains of ancient Roman buildings and structures, some of which has been excavated is both awesome as well as eerie since one gets surrounded by the memorable scenes from various History programs and movies standing there atop the Palatine Hill, one gets overwhelmed that the various majestic and some not so majestic characters had once wined, dined, supped and danced in these very places. The view especially of the Colosseum and Circo Massimo is breathtaking. Palatine Hill itself is not as high as I had imagined but nevertheless a great experience.Since the entry ticket to the Colosseum and Palatine Hill is common, to avoid the great rush at the Colosseum, one may purchase it at the Palatine Hill, where the ticket booth does not have long queues. Walking shoes or joggers are recommended since the ruins are spread over a vast area. Drinking water is recommended because there are water fountains but too few and far apart. Umbrellas are recommended to avoid the sun or inclement weather.

It is a part of Colosseum.. This is locate closer to Colosseum . Once the ticket is purchased for the colosseum it includes this also. Since we could not purchase online tickets had to be on a line to purchase tickets. So I recommend to purchase online tickets. Also can purchase tickets from the City sighting tour bus.
Breakthtaking. We visited Palatine Hill as part of a private guided tour of ancient Rome. Incredible views and sweeping sense of history.

How much history can be in one place? Start here and find out. They have books that show what it looked like before and then now. Without it, it would be difficult to fully grasp what you are seeing. It's one book worth buying from the vendors on the street. That, and the coliseum books!

History all around you. Firstly, go here and the Forum as well as the Colloseum. All next to each other and 1 ticket anyway. Free on 1st Sunday of month, when we went.There is a small museum at the top of the hill which is well worth a visit, including for a bit of a break while watching a short arty film which covers a little of the history.The Palatine hill was basically the Emperors and wealthy palaces (Forum was shops and temples) so on the hill you have for example remains of Nero's palace. Often things were built on top of each other, so look out for the places you can see the multi level buildings, often 4 of 5 levels deep...

WOW!. There is so much old stuff here in Rome. I suggest reading up before you leave home. Take in the Coliseum while you are right next door. OLD!!!!! You need about an hour to go though the site. Across the street and a bit down the road are other ruins you can view from the roadway, but can't go down into. It looks like a work in progress.
Wow. It is next to the colosseum & be prepared to do a lot of walking. We had a guided tour that helps put yourself in that place during its glorious period.

Transportative!. One of those places that will take you back in time and leave you awestruck. There are lots of tours here. Try Dolce Vita tours. You simply have to know what it is you are looking at.
Intriguing. Far more interesting and intriguing than the colloseum, would definitely recommend a guided tour of both sites

Interesting. Had a guided tour which included palatine hill. Certainly worth it as they had pictures of how it looked in the past which really helped you get a feel for the place. Lovely to be at such an old historic place
A must see.. Well worth an exploration. Put your walking shoes on and preferably take a guided tour. Another must see in this amazing city.

Great views. A lovely walk through the gardens of Palantine Hill giving you an excellent view and photo opportunities of Ancient Rome including the colosseum, Circus Maximus and Roman Forum. Useful tip: Purchase a combined ticket for entry into the colosseum, Palantine Hill and Roman Forum at either Palantine Hill or Roman Forum entrances to avoid lengthy queues at the Colosseum (reduced rates are offered for 18-25 year olds, under 18's go free)

Walk through history. One of most ancient areas in Rome, Palatine Hill is center of Roman legend and lore.. People have lived here since about 1000 BC, and legend holds that Rome derived its name from brothers Romulus and Remus, who lived in a cave here at Palatine Hill. When the boys grew up they decided to build a new city of their own on the banks of the Tiber, then had a violent argument resulting in Romulus killing brother Remus. Rome got its name from brother Romulus. Nearby is the Hippodrome, Piazza Navona, and Palatine Museum and Palatine House, which was only recently discovered in 2006. The entire Palatine Hill area holds an amazing part of Roman legend, lore, history, and architecture.

Thanks Rick!. The entry was part of a Colosseum tour package. The guided tour was for the Colosseum only. We downloaded Rick Steves audio guide to my phone. Thanks to Rick this pile or ruble came to life!

A beautiful place, but beware of pickpockets, we got robbed. We visited Palatine Hill in the end of September. We bought combination ticket in Forum for all: the Roman Forum, Palatine Hill and for the Coliseum. Line was only ~15-20 min. We saved a lot of time compare to the lines in the Coliseum.It is beautiful place and full of history, we used Rick Steve’s book as a guide. We spent a lot of time in both Forum and Palatine Hill and honestly could spend even more, but we left because we also wanted spend some time in the Coliseum as well and we were not sure how much time we would need. You need more time for Forum & Palatine Hill than for the ColiseumRoman Forum is pretty crowded. It was also hot because it's all open space. There are a few places with water fountains, where you can drink or refill your bottle. There are no places to eat inside the Palatine Hill and not so many bathrooms. It’s huge; you need to be on foot for long time.We liked the place, but one person in our party was robbed on Caesar’s Tomb. Pickpocketing - wallet disappeared from pocket of our friend pants in blink of an eye. Some man asked to take a picture of him on Caesar’s Tomb and after this our friend's wallet was gone. He didn’t feel a thing. Beware! We read about pickpockets and thieves before the trip and tried to be careful, but it happened anyway. After this case we were afraid to carry all our money and documents with us. A couple days later we left Rome and went to Tuscany for a week. On our 2nd day in Tuscany our villa got robbed... We lost much of our money, credit cards, jewelry, documents including passport, driver's licenses, etc. Instead of enjoying Tuscany we were spending time in police and US Embassy. It really helped that we had copies of our passports, because we didn’t have any other documents left with our name on it. It took 3 weeks to restore all our documents after coming home. We will remember this trip for a long time. We travel extensively and it never happened to us before. Just be careful.

A Must Stop in Rome. My wife and I recently visited Rome with our daughters and their husbands. We splurged on a private guided tour of the Colosseum and other ancient sites including Palatine Hill. On a previous trip about ten years ago we were self guided and we missed a great deal about what we were seeing and the history behind the artifacts. Don't miss it.

Beautiful, breathtaking, busy!. There is history where ever you look. It is a beautiful place but as with the Colosseum (of which the entrance ticket is the same) get their early if you're not into crowds1
Loved exploring Palatine Hill. There were many old historical buildings and beautiful scenery. This is a great place to visit for any history buff.

Must vist along with the Colosseum.. A must visit with the Colosseum. Its like going into a city of the past. The spot where Julius Caeser's body was cremated is also there. Just an awesome place to soak in rich history!

Get a map!. It's bigger than you think! Get a map and allow plenty of time, especially if you have the combination ticket and want to see the Colosseum too. We were not able to get to the Colosseum because it closed before the Palatine Hill and we went in the wrong order. They are not connected so once you enter one you have to finish that visit before you go to the other and you only get one entrance.

A beautiful place in Rome. We started early enough in the day that we were able to visit the Forum of Augustus, Palatine Hill, then the Colosseum. I was given the advice to buy the tickets for all three places at Palatine Hill. That was great advice because we didn't have to stand in additional lines at the Colosseum.

Historical place. This place is a part of the Colloseum and Roman Forum area so you can visit all at once. Yes i agree its some Climbing and in the heat it can be a bit hard but its worth it. You find alot of historical buildings, houses here and you get beautiful views once you are on top. Theres a small park where you can take a rest in the shade and a nice garden with fountain. Worth the effort thats for sure.

Impressive site!. Fascinating site in the middle of the city between the Collosseum and the Circo Massimo. Walk. if it is summer, make sure you have lots of water with you. Watch for the green parakeets!

Wow - great views. We tied this in with a trip to the Forum. A tour guide makes all the difference. Difficult to understand how old everything is and how much still exists. The view from the top is nothing short of wonderful.

Palatine Hill. Definately worth getting a guide. You can pay for a guide that will take around the Colusseum and Palatine Hill. It cost us 25€ but was well worth it, they really bring the ruins to life and build a picture of Roman life. Amazing place.

A must see. You have to walk up Palatine Hill to see what Rome looked like in the past and they still have remnants of the castles that were there. Mosiac floors that were not destroyed and parts of buildings also.

Impressive views. During our Forum visit you were always aware of the massive buildings on the hill high above. This was Palatine Hill which gives us the word for palaces today. While we did not visit directly we did see both from the ground as well as driving around. The foundations of the palaces on this hill were impressive and they offered great views over the Forum below.

Ruins. Wear good shoes as you will be tired. It's unfortunately mostly ruins and rubble with a few interesting historical sights. Knowing a lot of history or having information / tour guide could have made it more interesting as there isn't much to see. The visit will eat up quite a large chunk of your time due to walking so plan accordingly.
A must see. if you are already in the Colesseum and Forum, this is a short walk and definitely worth visiting. We highly recommend it bundled with Forum and Colesseum.

Tour Guide Needed. I so loved this tour. Rich in history. I can't believe how far back some of this stuff dates back. Having a tour guide was much better than just walking around on our own. He had so much extra to share. And the tour guides have degrees in History. They go thru a ton of training before that can get certified. They know their stuff!

Needs to be viewed on its own. Viewed this as part of a combined tour of the Colosseum. Was at the end of the tour. After walking for a few hours, you start to lose interest. We were ready to be done. Everything is out in the wide open with little shade. Tough for anyone who has any difficulty walking. It is a nice place to visit and here about the history of the ruins. Guide did a good job leading us around and informing us of the historical significance. Amazing that part is still in use today.

A Rome Must See Place. This area was the heart of the Roman Empire. There is layer upon layer of history there going back to the days when Rome was a tiny village. You will want to go up the hill when in Rome to see what remains of the old palaces, to see the post holes of the original village, walk among the ruins and take in the views. Like most of Rome this area was looted and mined for building material over the centuries, but there is still wonder in what remains.

A view from the top. This area near the Colosseum is often overlooked in favor of its iconic neighbor. It is a beautiful and somewhat mysterious place to visit. One can imagine the day to day living of it's former inhabitants. To fully appreciate what you are seeing either take a very good guide book or better still have a tour guide, hired in advance, help you understand what you are looking at. It can be very, very warm walking around the area so wear comfortable shoes and have a bottle or two of water with you. If you are short on time and don't want to actually go through the Palatine Hill, We found the best view of it was from a terrace located above, behind the Victor Emmanuel monument, and next to the Palozzo Senatorio. Our expert tour guide, Cristiano with Easitalytours.com navigated through narrow, winding streets to show us this great view!

Take the time to explore..... We visited Palatine Hill after our Coliseum tour and we're as equally impressed and happy to visit and learn about the historical significance.Not to be missed and if like us you invested in a private tour you can learn so much about this marvelous place.Our recommendation go early or late to avoid the huge crowds and summer heat so you can explore this marvelous historical site...

Wonderful, but lot of climbing hills. We did Palatine Hill as part of a tour that included the Forum and Colosseum. The Hill had a lot of steps involved but the views and the peacefulness was worth it. So much to see but it must be explained by a guide or a very good book.
Wonderful history. Beautiful place to visit. It is great seeing all of the historical sites. We went here on a Globus tour of Italy.

Incredible to see!. So much to see here! What incredible ruins! Lots of walking so wear comfortable shoes. Very hot the day we visited with no shade and I didn't see any place to purchase water so come prepared.

Amazing History. I enjoyed the combined trip to here and the Colosseum and the Roman Forum although this hill was my least favourite of the three but I would still recommend doing this tour to experience the true history of Rome.
Palatine Hill. The first to be lived on. Worth visiting on a guided tour to learn the importance of the Palatine Hill and history of Romulus and Remus. Beautiful views over Rome from the top.

Amazing amazing amazing . We had decided to go to the colosseum first but the queue was massive so we came here first. I am so pleased we did, the whole place is amazing the views the areas. You are walking history and yet whilst it's busy it is still possible to get some time where you are just on your own. The marbles and the statue's it's everywhere you just don't know where to look. We were here for hours and I could have stayed longer. Water available plus loos and I would say wear a hat and sunscreen, the breeze is there and it's easy to forget the heat.Amazing views of the colosseum and rome itself. If this was the only thing I could have done in rome I can honestly say I would not have been disappointed
Audio guide to be avoided. Another amazing Roman attraction, but the audio guide was very confusing and took out of the pleasure of a perfect visit.

birthday treat. Every body visits the coliseum, but few walk across the road and visit Palatine hill where mussolinis house, caesars funeral pyre and home of the celestial virgins which gave rise to the phrase Life Begins at Forty. Marvel at the church door halfway up a tower because Rome was once covered in metres of mud from flooding. Tip look for an american university student tourist guide and they will explain all in detail for just a few euro and get you into the collliseum ahead of all the queues , well worth 5 euro for a days fascinating info

Just Ok. This one is ok, not a must see, since you are in the area for the Colosseum and the Forum, you can do so if you choose. If you are on a bit of a tight time schedule, I would pass on Palatine, the museum at the top of the hill is fairly interesting, but there are many others in Rome much better, a Must See is National Museum of Rome near Termini station, is absolutely great.
history at its best.. Yes the Romans could buid stright roads...... i did enjoy this tour. the history and age of the place has you in awe ruins yes but the best .

Definitely book and come here before the colossuem. We booked tickets the night before and the photo shows how short the queue was at about 11 in the morning. We walked past a huge line who hadn't booked online so definitely recommend pre- booking. Also, it's a good idea to come here before the Colosseum as when we went in the afternoon it wasn't too busy. Palantine Hill had great views - this was my favourite part of the three.Btw, if you want to catch a bus back into the city, make sure you pre-purchase return tickets. We wanted to buy a bus ticket back and all the local shops had run out of bus tickets so had to find a taxi instead.

A trip back in time. It was amazing to walk through the former centre of the known world. Using a map of interpretations of what buildings used to look like, it was amazing to see where decisions were made regarding the entire Roman empire. Worth the price and time.

Incredible ruins, tough to navigate. Not much in the way of help for a lone tourist trying to take in the site. Confusing - could use a path that directs you around the hill and some more signs to bring the rich ruins to life. Museum is a gem, not to be missed.
Pleasant and charming. Amazing view, excellent picture of Rome, agreeable and really---reallly wonderful. It worth it. You will nor regret it

Great site, but a lot to see after the forum. The best part about visiting Palatine Hill is that your ticket is already covered with the forum/Colosseum purchase. The bad part is that it can make for a very tiring day. While there is a lot to see, especially great views, make sure to pace yourself.

Takes your breath away. My daughter and I visited the Colosseum, Palatine Hill and Roman Forum as part of a 3hr audio walking tour. The Coloseum takes your breath away to be a part of so much history! The vastness and sheer size is incredible. Palatine Hill and forum were very interesting and our guide gave us so much history and made it interesting. The tour was booked through Dark Rome and well worth booking in advance when short of time in Rome.

Awesome place to take pictures of the ancient city - Skip the Colosseum Lines, Get Tickets Here. We got our tickets for the Colosseum here at the Palatine Hill museum ticket office so we wouldn't have to stand in line at the Colosseum. Our son is under 18, so he was free. If you have kids, have them bring their student IDs for many of the museums are free. Great over view of the ancient city area.

Fantastic View, Lots to See, Beautiful in Spring. So much history and such a field to explore. Bring water and snacks you will be there a while! Fortunately and without realizing it our online Colosseum ticket purchase included a visit here.

Must view. Free tickets for u18 12 € tickets ( colosseo and palatine hill)Spent 3 hours there , could have spent more : aqueduct , temples , ruins , arc , view over the city ... very nice place, walked there for over 3 hours It would have been better if there were audioguides to rent

Amazing. This place is incredible if you're in Rome you must visit! You'll be amazed at how much of Ancient Rome is still left! Also visit the forum too! Although we found the chariot racing arena to be a bit of disappointment compared to the forum and Palatine hill! So if your short for time stick to these two and the colosseum for an Ancient Rome fix!
Another Must See While In Rome. Rome has plenty of places of historic interest and this is one of the must see places when visiting Rome
Great place. Super views , highly recommended to go there before the Colosseum Since you purchase there ticket with no lines to Palatine hill and Colosseum

Uncovered Ancient Ruins. Rome is one of the cities you can walk and explore all day without getting disinterested, always something exciting to see and the "Hill" is no exception ....... Walk where the Romans walked many many centuries ago, where Julius Caesar was when he was killed, then walk thru to the Parthenon ....... You could spend 2 whole days here and still not see it all
Special. A special place to visit; this is the perfect end to a visit including the Colosseum and Roman Forum.

Best place to start your tour of the forum and colleseo.. Queues for the combined pallantine, forum and colleseum tickets are very much shorter here, just as the guide books stated. So take the metro to the stop after colleseo and take the short walk down the hill, passing the circus maximus on your way and enter via the pallantine gate.Loos available at this entrance and pallantine museum inside the site and in the forum area. There were at least 6 free drinking water points to fill up bottles, but the queues get longer the closer you get to the forum.The site/complex is very impressive and it's a marvel so much survived the centuries.

Great views, but make sure to pay for a guide. This probably would not have been as good if you just walk through it yourself. We ended up paying an extra 13 euro each(25 each total) outside of the Colleseo and getting a guided tour for both the Colleseo and Palatine Hill. We were told the story of all the buildings, the rulers from 1 AD, and some local tips. Honestly could not tell you the name of the tour company, but they were outside the Colleseo offering to skip the line and the two marketing the tour were two english females.

Journey to Ancient Rome. If you're looking for the remainings of the Ancient Rome's grandour, this is what is left of them. And there is plenty of ruins, outlining a great civilization of the past. There is also a freat panorama of the city, which you will certainly appreciate. You definitely should not miss it!

History on your doorstep!. If you love history, Rome is the place to be. Around every corner is a reminder of the past. This attraction wasn't far from our hotel and enjoyed looking at all these reminders of the past.

Palace on top of a hill. Get your good walking foot wear ready as this place you will be needing it.Lovely place,awesome gardens mixed with the old ruins and plenty to learn from your guide. It's a place were you can see most of Roman old ruins with every corner a story to tell. Enjoy :)

Rome ..... Relax, ake in the views !. Rome' s Palatine Hill ..... Just great ! Rome the Eternal City, is preety safe, do take the usual precautions, learn a little Italian, The Palatine Hill itself !........ yep its just great, very well worth a visit,

Wonderful Views. This was my favorite part of the combined ticket that includes the Roman Forum and the Colosseum. Palatine Hill offered a wonderful view of Rome and over the Roman Forum. It was not overly strenuous to walk and the trees provided some shade. The orchard around the pond was in full bloom when I visited which was lovely. There was also no queue entering at the Palatine Hill entrance where you could buy the combined ticket.
Pretty Place. If the weather wasn't plus 30c the entire time this is a lovely place to walk. Picturesque with some great views of the rest of Rome, worth it if its not as hot as when I went!
Just get melt under the sun. Rome is so much of history and cloture and lights and statue, you can spend a whole day to just look and let yourself be amazed by antic constructors..

Awe inspiring. The origin of Rome and the site of the home of the royalty, this hill (which is not bad to walk up) is itself filled with ruins to explore and offers a gorgeous view of the Roman Forum and the spread of modern Rome beyond. Definitely plan to visit.

Exploring ancient Rome. Our guide took us through a quite side entrance up the Palatine Hill. Home to a number of emperors with some ruins telling the story. The highlight was the view over the Roman Forum. Splendid!
A must !. A must in Rome with the Coliseum. Very very impressive ! I felt like I was part of history. Bring some water with you, sunglasses and a hat, because it's hot and sunny !

Ancient Rome..... This is part of the combo ticket, with the Forum and Colosseum. Forum and proceeded through it, seeing wonderful historical sites. Palatine Hill is one of the oldest parts of Rome. March up the hill, and see lots of ruins such as the Palatine, and the view from the top of the Flavian Palace overlooking the Roman Forum, with the Colosseum to the right and the centre of modern Rome just beyond. Enjoy.
Enjoy the coffee!. An integral part of any stroll around the Forum or Colesseo area. Just grab a great cup of coffee and enjoy all the lovely views Rome has to offer. Don't rush, you're on vacation!

Amazing history. Amazing to walk the same streets as a Roman emperor or general and look out over the forum and the passage of time written in the various buildings.Would definitely recommend a guide to really understand the place

Feel the history seep into your pores . . .. because you can almost feel it! This is a must site; you can see much from here, the Colosseum and the Forum and just over a little further is Circus Maximus. Feel the breeze on the hill.Drink from the many fountains throughout the city and fill your water bottles; its spring fed.We took a Segway tour through and around these sites; its a great way to cover a lot of ground in 3-4 hours!

Good Views. The Palatine Hill is one of the oldest parts of Rome. Once you've trekked up the hill, there are several very old ruins such as the Palatine, some newer buildings such as the 17th century aviary (no birds) and most impressive for me was the elevated view from the top of the Flavian Palace overlooking the Roman Forum, with the Colosseum to the right and the centre of modern Rome just beyond. Also, it is quite peaceful up there. Entry is included in the Colosseum/Forum/Palatine Hill multi-ticket.

Unable to get in. We bought our combined tickets for this, the Forum and Colosseum (valid for 2 days) at the Roman Forum and proceeded through it, seeing wonderful historical sites. There were no clearly marked signs to Palatine Hill, and the exit took us back onto the streets.We returned the next day after visiting the Colosseum only to be refused access - it appears that although its a combined ticket, you cannot visit all three attractions, or perhaps you must visit Palatine at the same time as the Forum - the lady on security was more interested in shooing us away than explain as to why we couldn't get in. We were not alone in being turned away at the gate - there were several other tourists also finding the same issue.
One of the top sights in Rome. One of the top sights in Rome (the ticket to the Colosseum gives you access to this, and vice versa). Can get very hot in summer, but fabulous. Don't miss it.

Get a real feel for how the wealthy Romans lived. The entrance to the Palatine Hill is just around the corner from the Colosseum and Forum Romanum. We visited all in one day (with our ticket that gave access to all three attractions). There were plenty of remains from the Roman houses (more like palaces) to see and all was set in a nice park. Excellent view from the Hill onto the Forum Romanum and all over Rome. For me, this was one of the highlights of our visit to Rome.
The Forum is inside of the Palatine Hill. If you like The Colosseum, you'll love the Forum on Palatine Hill. It's hard to explain so I will attach a few photos. It's a must see

Do a Vulcan Mind Meld & EXPERIENCE this unique locale!. This site is so amazing! Art History students, History students, Lovers of Beauty and those with any imagination: Go here and BE a citizen of Rome! DISCLAIMER: TripAdvisor does not allow a visit date earlier than 2014. I was here 1998/99 but I can't imagine the site has changed dramatically. Just put on your "history pants" and have fun!

Dont' miss this on your visit to Rome!!!!!. There is nothing like this! To actually walk among the stones and ruins of what was once the center of civilization in ancient times was thrilling!!!! And it's right in the middle of bustling modern Rome!!! It is awe inspiring and worth visiting!!!!!

Great history. Great place to see some serious history. Seeing the ruins and the old structures sights was inspiring. Especially when you walk in the footsteps of millions of others through thousands of years.

Definitely worth getting a guide here!. There are lots of ruins located here, and stories to go with each. It really takes you back in history and makes it come alive! Lots of stairs and hills to see the whole area, so I recommend early morning.. You'll be more comfortable!

Palatine Hill, Colosseum, and Roman Forum. I did this review for the Colosseum, but also wanted to share it here:There is not much I can add to this incredible piece of history than what is already out there. However, I am writing this review to give tips to travelers going there for the first time. YOU DO NOT NEED TO BOOK A SKIP THE LINE TOUR if you follow these tips.Tips:1. DO NOT START AT THE COLOSSEUM. It's by far the longest lines and there is not point on standing in line when you dont have too. Instead, go in thru the Palatine Hill entrance. If you are taking the metro in, do not get off at the Colosseum exit. Instead go to the Circo Massimo and exit there. Then walk up the Via d. San Greggorio and you will see the entrance on the left. We had a two minute wait while the Colosseum entrance had a 1 hour wait. The same ticket, which cost 12 Euros (and its free for 18 and under), gets you into Palatine Hill and the Roman forum (which are attached) and the Colosseum (separate). To go into the colosseum, all you have to do is get on the "have ticket line" which is the same the tour companies use for their "skip the line" tours.2. It is going to take you 4-6 hours to see all three places, so get plenty of water and eat if you have kids with you. You cannot buy drinks or food once inside.
