Rome is hot, and this place is huge and hilly, so be ready for a good workout.3. Watch out for pickpockets. A lady tried to pick pocket my brother.4. Take the time. This is really an amazing place. Schedule plenty of time to really see it all.
Brilliant. Probably the most iconic historical site in Rome. It is a must see. Make sure you have a guide as they make it feel real.
palatine hill. huge Place walk around, definitely take a whole day to soak up what Roman life would have been like back then.....

Where the Posh People Once Lived. The Palatine Hill was where the posh people once lived. A great place for kids to let off steam and worth climbing the hill to see. You will be rewarded by breathtaking views of the City. Here you can appreciate how each Roman Emperor wanted to leave his mark on the city by new building. A prime piece of real estate, the guides will relate how Emperor Nero is suspected of evicting the residents by burning their property and seizing the land for himself.

Palantine Hill. Our teens loved this. A must see with a guide who can explain what you are seeing. Our guide really brought it to life. Also purchase one of the books that shows you how it looked in its splendor. Take some time before you go to read about what you are seeing.

Unreal!!. My wife and I spent quite a whole morning touring over the Hill and Forum. It's simply breathtaking to see that these ruins are more than a 1000 years old and how on earth people at that time can built something like this. We recommend this to anyone who is visiting Rome for the the first time.

Really fun!. Breathtaking views from the top! Interesting to hear the legend that goes along with this hill so id recommend foing a tour! If you pay for the Colosseum tour the Palantime Hill is included!! Do it! Great for pictures too and to learn how to distinguish between the old and modern architecture in Rome

Real history under your feet. Being a bit of a history buff in my young days I remembered much of the history however I admit that I may have just stylized it a little that was until now. This magnificent place spanning some much historical time and carrying so many stories put a lot of what I remembered back into shape. The probability that Romulus lived here and made his plans for the Rome to come and the fact that good old Caligula bbbb bought it in the aaaa alley outside his bbbb backdoor really made it for me. A splendid time and an absolute must see.
Learning experience. Your best bet is to do this with a tour guide. It is absolutely magnificent and definitely worth the time.
A must see location. Overlooking the Colosseum, on Palatine Hill you walk the streets and pass the architecture that the returning legions walked. A magic experience

Another must see location while visiting Rome. A visit to the ancient ruins on Palatine Hill are another must see place to see while on a Roman Holiday. The history and architectural combine to make this a truly memorable place to visit. I would advise people to investigate the history of the ancient ruins prior to the visit. I believe it would have been very beneficial to me if I had done that. It was really hard to imagine that I was walking the same streets that victorious Roman legions returned to the city on. A truly remarkable place.

Essential part of Ancient Rome visit. If you allow your imagination to work, walking through Palatine Hill is an enjoyable and thoughtful experience. We used a downloaded audio guide which helped us get a better feel for what things looked like back in the day.

This is an all day hike and read into the past!. Amazing that earlier times covered up such history. Amazing how large the grounds and history are. You must take your time and a water bottle! The bathroom lines can be long so don't wait until the last minute else you'll dance in line! We didn't buy any audio set and I saw one young lady with her family and an app for this location.... dang it! Wish I had found the app!

Must visit in rome. I would recommend everyone to visit the palatine hill in Rome. We were on a guided tour starting with colusseum in the morning and to palatine hill and ending in the roman forums. It is recommended that you go on guided tour with audio guide or a guide leading you if you have not studied history. Its easy to miss some interesting points without a great guide!

Historical place. A real insight into the history of Italy. A really wonderful experience to see all these buildings being preserved and it's a magical feeling. A must-go for all who appreciate history and culture.

For archeological and history buff. It was super hot that day and it was not a pleasant time to tour the place. Luckily there's some trees to shelter you from the direct sunlight. It's bit of a climb so good walking shoes are needed. Do bring along bottled water along as you need to keep hydrated during the long walk.

Hire a Guide! It's So Worth It!. My biggest recommendation when visiting is to hire a guide to take you around. If you don't, you'll just be wandering around looking at everything and will miss out on all the history and information that a guide could provide! In addition, the terrain is not for the faint of heart. Uneven and broken stone, dirt and sand, slippery marble. Always watch your step and wear good walking shoes!
amazing. there were so much to see and the views are stunning.make sure you wear suitable footwear as some areas are very uneven
A Great Walk. Great walking around. You have to be early if you want to avoid too many crowds. I found the ruins at the far end most enjoyable.

Get a guide. Though you can explore the hill on your own, it is much more interesting to hire a pro to tell you of the rich history here. You might casually walk by the memorial to Julius Caesar and never learn of the temples and buildings. It can be very hot in summer, be sure to carry water and consider a hat or paper fan.

Toured it Again. Having seen this several years back decided to see it again. Went with a guide book which described the entire area. Really need to imagine and read as you are there to get an accurate idea of the once grandeur
Breathtaking. So much to see, really well preserved site, today's builders could take some tips, make sure you have suitable foot ware I can confirm flip flops are not that great !!

My favourite bit. the story of Romulus and Remus, the first kings, the Sabine women. WonderfulThis was the place Rome (named after Romulus!) started with a bunch of shepherdsSuch a humble start to the wonderful city

Walk through history. This hill changes from barren parkland to gravelly ruins. There are amazing ancient sculptures over a large area. It leans through to further ruins nearer the city centre. It is uneven underfoot but incredibly interesting. We stopped to eat our picnic at one of the high areas and just sat trying to soak up the atmosphere. A good but hot and dusty day out.

Nice place to be covered with Roman Forum..!!. Its a huge place to walk around the gardens and ruins and appreciate the Roman ruins. Romun Forum and Palatine Hill have different entrances but I think its actually the same place. While walking you won't realise whether you are at Romun Forum or Palatine Hill. You can cover both together but give it a good amount of time of at-least 3-4 hours if you want to visit both together.

Good way to enter the Forum area. We were in Rome on a very hot day and also a very busy "free to see the Colosseum" day so we took Rick Steves advice and entered thru the Palatine Hill entrance. We were glad we did as this is a very calm, cool place to enter a very busy and hot Colosseum and Forum area. We took our time and wondered thru seeing ruins of the buildings that remain in this area before heading into the Forum. If you want a break from the crowds, head here.
Re-visit. Simply brilliant. The history, buildings, atmosphere are unbelievable. No place like it. So much to see you could come back day after day.

Awesome Ruins. The ruins do not do justice to the scope of the palace as detail in historical documents. One can get a feel of the immensity but I do not believe that imagination can fill in to the extent that historical accounts describe the palace.

Full of history to be enjoyed. This is a place full of history. Every stone there carries the memory of this ancient city that was once full of power and mother of an empire. It is a place to be appreciated. So if you don't like history or the silence, maybe this is not a good place for you to visit. But if you are a life and knowledge appreciator, than this is a must do. It is quiet, peaceful and if feels like even the wind tells you secrets about it. Don't rush when walking around. Let the place guide you and be attentive to the details. Oh, and wear confortable clothes and shoes!

Wonderful Views!. We visited the Palantine Hill as part of a walking tour. The view is amazing and the ruins are very interesting. Its above the Forum and is an uphill walk - it was very hot the day we visited, so the breezes at the top of the hill were very refreshing.

Top of the World. At one time, when Augustus lived there, he ruled the world form the top of this hill. You can see excavations that reveal the original hut that pre-date Rome. You can enter the grounds of Augustus' palace. Museum is good, don't miss it. Do not miss the signs. They explain much about what you see, even if you take a guide book.

A DEFINITE TO PUT ON YOUR TO DO LIST. The best part about this site is the view once you reach the top! The view of Rome from way up there was breathtaking. It was one of our top 3 spots we visited. To look down on all the history is mind blowing. There are lots of stairs to climb so be prepared.
Ugly place. I really didnt like. It looks like an cemetery. You cant understand the buildings because there are just pieces or bricks and columns on the ground.
Beautiful views!. Wow! Walking through the ruins is mind-blowing. Realizing how these people lived is really cool! A must see while in Rome!
Very Historical but not much explained. Great area of ruins but they tend to blend into one without too many signed explanations which would help significantly

Historical. Very close to collosium which is famous for heritage and history.
Metro station is closeby and easily reacheable
Take good hat or umbrella with if hot.
Sweet water and other facilities are available for entire 3-4hours

Don't leave Palatine Hill off your visits. We finished our tour of the Colosseum at Palatine Hill. It was not crowded at all. We first walked along the leafy areas stopping to refill our water bottles from the natural fountain. Cold and tasty! Looked out over Circus Maximus, great views over the city and to the main gate entrance and Colosseum. Then walked across to the Roman Forum. This open air museum tells much about the ancient civilisation of Rome. Be prepared for lots of walking but it is worth it. Also worthwhile is a guide. they have so much knowledge about the area.
Step back in time.... Like walking through history, this place is inspiring. It reminds me of all man has done and all we can accomplish. We enjoyed walking around here on our walking history tour.

What a view!. Wow the views are amazing from here and we were very fortunate as they have been closed for renovations and only just opened up again! I would advise booking a guided tour through City Wonders as there is so much info as it's such an important site and so to really appreciate the area you in!That's what we did and they were awesome!

So wonderful!!. One you are in Italy. This is so full of history and the guides who were American students for us were terrific and knowledgeable. Love it here could have stayed the entire day listening to our wonderful guide.

Incredible. We started our exploration of ancient Rome at the Palatine Hill, as advised by other reviews. Absolutely no queue whatsoever here. This place is amazing. We didn't use an audio tour for this, we found that the information signs provided enough information. There's also a little museum tucked away in the middle with lots more artefacts as well as a little computerised model thing demonstrating how the area developed and changed throughout its history.As a bonus: Amazing views over Rome, and you can stop by the Circus Maximus on your way here.

Phenomenal royal palace overlooking the colosseum. Loved the position under trees and benefiting from the cool breezes. The gardens etc must have been a delight and the temples etc must have made the Romans feel they really had conquered the world.The museum romana has the frescoes, mosaics etc from the villa and they are mind blowing, even after all these thousand of years.

Staggering. We spent quite a few hours touring over the Hill and Forum on our last morning in Rome. I would suggest entering via the entrance that is down the road to the left as you look at the Via Sacra from the Colosseum. It was not crowded and set us up for an easier walk overall. Enter and turn left, this took us along leafy areas, and up to the Imperial Palace, overlooking the Circus Maximus. We wound our way up to the upper levels and got some great views down to the main gate entrance, Colosseum and to the military monument. We then descended slowly and could view the main gate and down the avenue of the Forum to complete the rest of our walk.

FLANKS THE ROMAN FORUM AND THE CIRCUS MAXIMUS--GOOD VANTAGE POINT FOR BOTH. Palatine Hill is one of the seven hills of Rome. It is the legendary site where Romulus and Remus were rescued leading to the founding of Rome. Romulus became Rome. The Palatine Hill overlooks and is flanked by two significant historic sites, the Roman Forum and the Circus Maximus (the Ben Hur legend). The Palatine Hill is also the site of the Palatine Hill Museum which features antiquities found from the hill. The antiquities date back nearly 2500 years and were found on location.

Ancient Rome at its best. The history is incredible and the site defies explanation. It is best to book a tour guide (City Wonders is a good one) who will take you around the Colosseum, The Roman Forum and Palatine hill (they are next to each other). The guides provide details of the history of the area, the monuments and are also available to answer any question you may have. Our tour took about 3 hours. NOTE-There are many, many "vendors" in the area. Be careful. Most of these vendors are on the streets illegally. We were cautious and did not have any problems. They mostly sell Selfie-sticks, hats, scarfs and bottled water. If you need to buy any of these items please stick to the gift and souvenir shops. Your guide can direct you. Also, DO NOT ACCEPT any flowers or roses which are handed to you for being a "beautiful lady". They are not free. If you take the flower they will chase you down for money - usually 5 Euros. The vendor kiosks in front of the attractions are mostly OK, but be sure that what you are paying for is what is being placed in the bag. Get a look before handing over you money. A little caution goes a long way. Stay safe and enjoy!

Go first thing in the morning!. We went to the colosseum the first day in Rome. We were on our way to follow the crowds into the Roman forum and palatine hill, but since tickets are good for two days we decided to come back the next day. I'm thankful we did. When we arrived at 9:00 there was no line, and only a few people inside. This place is vast, beautiful, so much to see! Without the crowds it was perfect. We stayed 3 1/2 hours and we still didn't see everything, but it was getting packed (and we were hungry and tired). Bring snacks and water bottles. There are several water fountains inside to fill your bottles. Go early!

go early and enjoy the views. A lot has been improved since my last visit here... I recommend a guided tour for the first visit, coming back enjoy exploring the vast area at your own pace.Dare to walk away from the crowded areas and you will be rewarded.

Everyone must see this site when in Rome. We enjoyed several hours wandering around, amazed at the relics and how well preserved they are. The scale cannot be imagined. Well worth taking one's time to appreciate it all

Must see. I booked my ticket for the Colosseum, the Palatine and the Forum online, so jumped the queue at the Colosseum and spent the afternoon strolling around the Palatine. The most impressive and atmospheric archeological site I have ever been too. My back was aching but there's so much of interest to see I didn't care! The signs are helpful

Make sure you do all of it!. I have been to the Roman Forum and Colosseum twice, yet the first time I completely skipped the majority of Palatine Hill. Give time to explore it in it's entirety, because it is just breathtaking. You do not have to book a tour as there are helpful signs that offer enough information for you to do the exploring yourself. It is also much less busy than the Forum.

Be Prepared to Walk!!!!. Mostly in ruins I would suggest that one arrives early and on a cooler than normal day, as you will be going up and down hills and over the many ruins of the Palatine Hills. Great views of the city and surrounding landmarks from many of the lookouts throughout the area which is large. One needs to use their imagination to see the sites. There is a good, but always crowded museum that is worth seeing, and if you can pick up a guide near the entrance it would be worthwhile as the signs are few and while informative a guide could give a better overview of the area,Tickets are required you can get a ticket that will give you entry to the Palatine Hills, the Roman Forum and the Colosseum for a reasonable price. Note the first Sunday of each month is free for all the above mentioned sites, but they can be crowded.

Love the Palantine Hill. We got our tickets to the Forum, Colosseum, and Palantine Hill here. There is no line compared to a very long line if you get them at the Colosseum. It gets hot here if you go in the summer, so go early.

Stunning history. Hard to believe that they are still excavating in Rome but here you see it first hand. Amazing to think you are looking at artifacts that are centuries old. Looks like they will be at it for the next 100.

Well worth the walk. We took the 87 bus to get to the Colosseum, the Forum, and Palantine Hill. After seeing the Colosseum first, we climbed the Hill. It is one of the original 7 hills of Rome, and thought to be the one where the earliest part of the city was founded. In contrast to the throngs of people at the Forum and Colosseum, we had a leisurely and private walk up the hill. We are 60, but it was not too strenuous. I would recommend going in the morning, before the heat of mid day. There are several noteable stops, including a fountain/former aviary, gardens with roses and fruit trees, and tremendous overlooks/vista points for the whole city of Rome. It gave us a nice respite before we tackled the Forum, where again, there were bigger crowds. Highly recommend.

Great historical area. I am a bit of a history buff, so anything having to do with the ancients fascinates me. Hindsight being 20/20, I might have gotten a guide (if available) to walk me around and add a little more knowledge to my surrounds (had a little guide book). If I could make a useful recommendation, it would be to wear comfortable shows.

Better with a tour guide. Our family with teenaged sons visited this with Through Eternity tours. It included the Colosseum and the Forum, and was 3 1/2 hours long, which felt about right to see it all. We loved seeing the architecture of the ancient structures. I think without a tour guide to give us all the stories, facts, and background, it would not have been as fascinating. This was one of only 2 tours we bought in our 11 days in Italy, and I would definitely do it again. We did listen to some Rick Steves audio guides at a couple of other places though, and that might be an option if you didn't want to pay for a guide.

Great to see ancient Rome. Well worth walking through to see ancient Rome still in Rome city itself, walked here from the main city, to Colosseum and then through the ruins afterward, excellent to see

Must see. The most incredible place, mind blowing to walk about such an amazing area. This is one of the most interesting places I have ever been, just so informative and it is amazing to walk amounts such important buildings - imaginging how it must have been in Ancient Rome really is just spectacular.

Like being in a history book !. At the summit of the Palatine Hill there is an amazing collection of ruins and the remains of the Farnese Gardens and an amazing view. You can see the remains of what was once the Circus Maximus and the Roman Forum from various vantage points. Its an amazing view and well worth seeing. would recommend that you take food with you as there isn't anything to buy and it is makes an ideal spot for a picnic.

My favorite attraction in Rome. Just incredible views! Walking through the ruins, one could really get a feeling of how the Emperors lived in the city. We spent a few hours here in the afternoon after covering much of the Coliseum and Roman Forum on an earlier visit in the week

Just fab !!!!. The start of this reveiw is the same as my colosseum review as how we got our tickets for people to try .For some people when they think of Rome they think of the food and the shopping. Me i think of the history . We purchased an omnia card for 89 euros each normal price 98 we got ten percent of as a promotion was on this gave us 3 days free transport on metro busses and the open top tour bus . Free entry at the colosseom , palantine hill and a rome museum and then discounted price on other museum, free entry at sisteen chapple and vatican museum with also free entry at st peters basilica and st peters prison ( all fast track entry thank god ) I LOVE history and you will find no finer example of it than Rome ! On the hill you get a real glimps of the real old Rome how magnificent these ruins have stood to the test of time. Everyone dont miss this opertunity yes there is a steep hill to climb but the garden at the top that overlooks the roof tops of rome is awesome again guided tours with headsets are available if you like to have everything explained to you in detail. Me i use a book and imagination ( cause i am apparently a big kid for roman history :-)

A wonderful addition to a Colosseum tour!. My husband and I had finished our VIP access Colosseum tour when our guide advised he was going to take us to the top of the Palatine Hill. Whilst I had heard of it before to be honest I had no idea what to expect.As we made a slow leisurely walk up the long pathway that brings you to the top of the Palatine Hill (one of the Seven Hills of Rome), our guide told us that according to Greek mythology the Palatine Hill was the birthplace of Romulus and Remus the twin brothers, who were suckled and raised by a she-wolf and later became the founders of Rome.At the summit of the Palatine Hill there is an amazing collection of ruins, a museum, the remains of the Farnese Gardens and a view you cannot believe. From various vantage points throughout the area you can see the remains of what was once the Circus Maximus and the Roman Forum - incredible!!!I would highly recommend to anyone visiting the Colosseum, Roman Forum to take the time to walk to the summit of the Palatine Hill, you will not be disappointed.

Historical but would've preferred a guide. I enjoy historical sights, and there's not many cities better than Rome to experience more than ever!We visited Palatine Hill directly after the Colosseum, and although I enjoyed walking through the site and admiring the ruins, I was slightly disappointed, but possibly due to our being alone, and not fully understanding the historical significance.Would still suggest this as a must-see, especially if included in the ticket with the Colosseum - an opportunity to see something different, and maybe join a guide or read up on this site beforehand to fully experience it!Visited in November, so not as crowded as in the summer.
palatine hill. enjoyed this and the roman forum - would be better with a guide as I think I missed lots of the history - but still an interesting visit.

Do not miss this expierence. Amazing Views......you can take photos of the Coloseum from here, you can see the Vatican and Castel Sant Angelo, it overlooks part of the city of Rome, their are gardens to have a picnic or just have a nap under the shade of a tree, a very nice place for a relaxing walk with many things to see...
Memorable Trip to Rome. Awesome place to visit and learn about the Roman culture and history, ensure you have a guide or you can also find the electronic guide pocket transistor which is very handy!

Palatine hill tour. We did our tour of Palatine Hill with the tour group Through Eternity. Very good - especially for our 2 kids. Vanessa helped them remember what was there, what was going on at the time and made it interesting for them. Well worth the time to see this beautiful area, but I would highly recommend visiting with the tour group!

Don't miss. This is a must see - get there early in the morning to beat the crowds - at 12 euro you also get enterance into the Forum and Colosseum it is a very good idea to hire a guide as there is much to understand and it would be a shame not to experience this important historical site

Historic. This is a part of your itinerary for Colosseum. Your ticket covers the entry to Colosseum, Palatine hill and the Roman forum. So, if you enter the Colosseum first, ensure that you don't lose the ticket. You will have to show it again for making an entry to Palatine hill.The hills oversees the Roman forum on one side and the Circus Maximus on the other. We went there on an extremely hot day. So the climb was really uncomfortable. But the view from the top takes away the effort of the climb.Carry a lot of water, and ensure you are dressed for outdoor activity. No ramp walk this...
Must see!. Offering the combination of beautiful views, historic landmarks and lovely trees and vegetation this was a pleasant and educational experience.

MIND BOGGLING. Combined with a visit to the Forum, Colosseum, & the other Rome wonders, The Palatine Hill is a must.A tip is to splash out and get a personal guide... visit Viator.com we were very impressed with the service, & this is definitely not an advertising scam!!!!

Don't miss this historical part of Rome. The history and architecture of the Palatine Hill is amazing. It was much larger than we expected and we happily spent a couple of hours wandering around and reading the plaques. We didn't take a guided tour but we did read as many plaques as possible. Up on top of the hill the views are great, including some nice views of the Colosseum, the Circus Maximus and other parts of the city. We really enjoyed looking at how they built things. The stonework and columns and thick walls must have taken a lot of work.Here's a tip. Go to the Palatine Hills first and buy a joint ticket for the Palatine Hills and the Colosseum. Visit the Palatine Hills and then exit by the gate overlooking the Colosseum. At the Colosseum there were two lineups. A short one for those who already had tickets and a really, really long one for people wanting to buy tickets. It only took us five minutes to get inside and we saved a lot of time by have tickets in hand.

Amazing site,history and views. Visited after Colosuem spent three plus hours. Take water and snacks there are no opportunities for refreshments and few toilets. Well worth the walk around the entire site I suggest you do a little homework before so you have a basic understanding of the history. The views are great.
This is the real Rome. What a fantastic site to visit, you will not be disappointed.If you are in Rome for its history this place is a must visit

Must-See Views of Rome. Palatine Hill is a must-see view of ancient Rome. I highly suggest taking a guided tour that includes the Colosseum, the Forum, and Palatine Hill (we took a tour with Simone from "Joy of Rome" tours and it was a highlight of our trip). An experienced tour guide will make ancient Rome come to life and is worth every penny. Without a guide, you will be totally lost, hot, and confused.
Great views. Not only does Palatine hill offer a look back to Ancient Rome, it offers stunning views over Rome, the colosseum and the forum. Well worth a visit.

Beautiful. I wouldn't worry about seeming 'touristy' Wear tennis shoes! There is a lot of standing/walking on hard and uneven stones for an extended period of time if you want to go all over and take everything in. It's not worth being sore or aching if you're on a trip. Buy the pass that gets you into the Colosseum, Roman Forum and Palatine Hill. It is good for use over two days so if you really want to look around at everything I personally would recommend doing the Forum and the Hill one day and then the Colosseum the next even though they are all in the same area. It will make it more enjoyable to get out of the sun and off of your feet to split things up. Read up on the Forum first so you can really appreciate what you are seeing.

Thank god for our tour guide bringing us through here...... Thank god for our tour guide as I'm not sure we would know what we were looking at - it was ALL breathtaking and historical. The views alone are incredible. This is a MUST see for your Rome visit - bring water and a hat because when the sun hits it's hot, humid and the crowds make it even more so.
Beautiful views. Just 1min walk from colosseum..Info-With rome pass,entry to colosseum & palatine hill is counted as one entryHad beautiful views from the top...a must watch

A historical treasure trove. Our group of four hired a private guide for the Coliseum and Palatine Hill, and it was definitely the way to go. No waiting in lines. No straining to hear the tour guide.It was fascinating to form a picture of the way the people lived and worshiped, including the rulers. The architecture was extraordinary. In Rome we used Viator Tours. In Sorrento we used Tours by Locals. Both groups provided excellent English-speaking guides.

Great climb and awesome view. Been there before and it is amazing, of course. But now that the panoramic view is open you have one of the most spectacular views of the city from one area. Don't miss it. It is a substantial climb but a few seniors were doing it and didn't seem deterred at all. Overlooking the Forum and with the Colosseum and City it is amazing!

Palatine Hill. This is a must visit place and we went late afternoon. Quite a trek up hill but worth it. We had been up since 3 am flying in from London. There was thunder and lightning but no rain which added to the views over Rome. I liked the boards offering information about the site. Take plenty of water to drink and there are many places to have a sit down. We are in our 60's. We had no problems with the street sellers, just say no thankyou. Water from the vendor stalls are 2 Euros for a small bottle, buy from a supermarket or fill from one of the taps, quite safe to drink.
So much history to take in. Having spent a fantastic couple of hours in the coliseum went over to the forum and palatine hill.Totally breath taking area -and so much to see.

Less crowded must-see. Another must-see - feels much better after being crowded in Colosseum, especially with small children. Nice to realise that the excursion and entrance is included in the excursion bought to enter the Colosseum.
Palatine Hill. It is an amazing area with bits and pieces (some large and some small) of the old Roman Empire. It is within waling distance of the Colosseum and a must see place to visit.

ancient rome. We booked one of the combination tours through CitySightseeing. The staff appeared a little unorganized at the beginning however overall it was still a good tour. You buy your ticket for a certain day but not a certain time. So for the day you want to go on the tour, you purchase your ticket and you may join any tour group they have throughout the day which start every 30minutes. I would suggest catching the earliest tour possible (9am) as the tour groups can become quite large in the afternoons. We first toured to Coliseum- our guide was very nice, made sure we all stayed together in the crowds at the coliseum and gave great information and history about it. We were able to skip the very long line of people trying to get into the coliseum without a tour which was nice. We did not have any headsets for this tour so you did have to stay close to the guide to ensure that you could hear-which she did a good job of projecting. The tour group was small (about 10) so asking questions etc was very easy. You were given plenty of time after the tour to look around the coliseum and take pictures. The tour was approximately one hour.  The tour then continued with a tour of Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum. We joined up with a different tour guide for this portion and ended up part of a very large tour group consisting of about 50 people which at times made it a bit difficult to hear (there were no headsets for this tour either) but our tour guide was very diligent to be sure everyone was keeping up, could hear, and got all of the information. She would repeat herself whenever needed. We got a lot of good information and history about the area and after the tour (which was about an hour) we were given free reign to look and wander around wherever we wanted in the very large area. I know there is no possible way of giving an entire history lesson on a 1 hour tour but from overhearing some of the other tour guides from other companies, I do feel like we may have missed out on some key historical facts. There are multiple stairs at each location so I would not recommend bringing strollers unless they are small and light as you will have to carry them at times (remember, its an ancient city—they were not very handicapped accessible in those times).
Beautiful Walk and Lots of History. Palatine hill was one of my favourite landmarks in all of Rome if you add the Forum as well. Lots to see and it's not too busy.

Palatine hills walk. A walk through history. To think I have walked in the footsteps of those Roman warriors. Makes my body tingle. The whole experience was something that will live me always. History teachers ...Please teach and show the real history of our world.

Lovely, Fairly Easy Walking. Wonderful area full of bits and pieces of the Roman Empire's heyday. Visits to this place are usually included in a trifecta tour package (Colosseum, Forum, and this place). The site offers a look and touch of interesting artefacts; prime for picture-posing and getting really hands-on with some of Rome's history. However, to the seasoned Roman ruins expert, this is not the best I have seen.Also, be sure to bring some sort of sun protection, there was very little shade to seek refuge in during the tour.

Palatine Hill. Last time I visited the forum, I only explored the market at the bottome of the hill. this year I was determined to visit the Palatine Hill. I was not disappointed. Although I didn't go into any of the villas, I trekked to the back and far side of the ruins to see some great architectural angles, and ruins of smaller structures, mostly open to the weather. I caught site of lots of original marble mosaic floors, just open to get close to. Although it was pouring rain, it was a welcome releif to the oppressive Roman heat which had been dogging us. We wandered, thouroughly soaked and happy. The fee to the forum and Palatine hill was included in our Colosseum tickets, which we purchased with our Roma Pass.

You just have to!. This is absolutely on the must see list when visiting Rome along with the Colosseum and the Forum. Get the Roma Pass and visit all three. You will not be disappointed. It is incredible to be living in the 21st century and be able to walk through a single area containing THOUSANDS of years of history spanning the millennia! Ridiculous!
Lots of histor. A short walk from the Colosseum and included in the Colosseum ticket, along with the Forum. Covers a lot of ground, so leave time to explore.

Roman History Buffs Will Love This With a Guide. Interesting history of Roman government and it's workings. Do go with a guide as this was struck by an earthquake years ago and a good portion of it is in pieces that you will not understand, no signage available. It is uneven and a little of walking so if you can not handle being on your feet a long time it's not for you. There is not handicap accessibility so if you are in a wheelchair, walker, or other handicap aides enjoy it from the top, you will only be able to see a small portion and not much of the architectural detail.

Stunning Second Visit. This was the second time I visited Rome and the Palatine. It's worth going here first and getting the 12 euro ticket which includes the Forum and the Colosseum as the line is shorter. The Palatine is in the same grounds as the Forum and is quite simply incredible. In fact, this time I realised that actually I hadn't seen all of the site on my last visit and was stunned by some of the ruins. There are information boards to read which are really interesting and the museum also has some cool artefacts. A must do in the historical centre.

Mandatory visit. There is a short list of must see sites for any tourist's first time in Rome. Amongst these is a visit to the palantine hill. Overlooking the forum on one side and the Circus Maximus on the other the site is excellent for providing a sense of history as you get a sense if what the rulers of the greatest empire of Europe would have seen as they surveyed their capital. As you walk around the grounds you come to appreciate the number of centuries that have marked this site as one of d most important ruins for world history. I strongly encourage you to time your visit to allow you to join one of the group tours or arrange one of the private tours of the site since the information provided on plaques throughout the monument won't provide a full appreciation of the area's history.
Magnificent. Truly a magnificent and culturally-rich area that shouldn't be missed. When in Rome, you must see how the Romans lived.

Palatine Hill and Roman Forum, a must see.. Palatine Hill, Roman Forum and the Colosseum may be seen with a single ticket for two consecutive days. I would recommend to buy the ticket at the Palatine Hill entrance booth on Via Di San Gregorio. A bus stop is located at the entrance. 12 Euros (May 2015). The advantage of doing so is the fact that the queues are shorter then on the other two attractions and after you have seen the Palatine Hill you stroll down to the Forum rather then climbing up the steep hill. The site itself is very interesting and there is a museum which shows the archaeological findings and the past glory of this place. I also recommend to take a guide book with you. When going to the Roman Forum, you still stay in the closed boundary of the site.The first Monument on the Forum is the Titus Arch. The whole tour will take about 4-6 hours. Make it early morning to avoid the heat and take a battle of water with you.

It could be so much better. Palantine Hill itself is obviously 5 stars, it is Palantine Hill after all.The only staff you will see, will be at the entrance, when taking money off you or scanning your Roma pass. They did not acknowledge us, but continued to talk amongst themselves.Information panels are limited throughout the site; there are audio guide panels, but we weren't offered an audio guide, so of no use to us.Site was heavily littered.NO STAFF ON SITE AT ALL.Exiting the site can be a bit tricky too, a few dead ends and no signs to tell you this; we did see a few people struggling.Whoever is running this site should be ashamed of themselves!!!

When in Rome you HAVE to visi IL PALATINO. Just over a week ago, on my way to the Termini train station, I had to ask my taxi driver to stop and let me walk on the streets of Roma Antica. I grew up here and it is still moving to step where Emperors and the citizens of Rome lived their lives. The Market place, the Senate, the place of woship dedicated to Athena ,the Campo Marziowhere war victories were celebrated, The Temple to Vesta, the Arch of Emperor Tito where the returning heroes were hailed...it seems we can hear the crowds almost. It is so solemn, so powerful to be there ! And yet, I , We cannot but admire all these building still standing, in spite of the 2000 years, the endless invasions, the wars and the desecrations, Then ,impressive and moving at the sametime, is to note all around the Roman pines grand umbrellas, the wild flowers all growing at the Palatino. Nature is there making all human, gentler, attractive, pleasing to the eye, even romantic. Then it comes to my mind the movie Roman Holidays and please, watch that classic before you visit the Palatino, it will make it so much more personal..." just you and those grandiose ruins"

Bargain trip back in time. Got the tickets at the Palatine Hill & The Roman Forum because the queue's at the Colosseum were very long (about 10am). we queued for about 20 minutes to get the tickets then joined another queue to actually go in for about another 20 minutes. The tickets were 12 euro's each and include admission for the Colosseum as well, so it's an absolute bargain compared to The National Trust in England. You can quite easily spend all day in the Forum and Palatine Hill if ancient history is you thing and the tickets were valid for 2 days anyway. we spent about 3.5 hours wandering round the Palatine Hill & Roman Forum before we exited onto Via dei fori imperiali to get some refreshments. Walking back down towards the Colosseum the queue's had all but disappeared (about 3pm) and we were able to go straight in & queue for the ladies toilets inside instead. The Colosseum was a good experience too well worth an hour of anybody's time. I think the three attractions combined are just right for a good day out but be prepared to queue at some point.
Beautiful . Love it here, was a beautiful place to visit. Great views and a wonderful garden makes it like you are out of Rome.Visit to see something wonderful

Awe inspiring. Rome is amazing, such wonderful places to visit, Palatine Hill is stunning, so much history, its so wonderful to walk in the footsteps of ancient Romans, close your eyes to imagine what it muct have been like back then.

Walk back in time. I thoroughly enjoyed wandering amongst the ruins on Palatine Hill. There are good views of the Forum and Colosseum from the top. Ticket queues are much shorter than those at the Colosseum and your ticket covers entry to both sites (the Forum can be accessed from Palatine). Beware of the 'Centurions' outside the sites as they will expect payment for the photos.If you enjoy this type of attraction I would recommend a visit to Ostia Antica if you have the time.

more for archeology buffs. for me it was just above average place but for those interested in archeology i'm sure its a treasure trove. still shouldn't be missed. since this visit is combined with the colosseum would suggest this to be done first early in the morning followed by visit to the coliseum. also ticket lines are much shorter here so get the tickets at the counter here.
Beautiful views.. Everything looks really nice from up there. Great panorama of Rome and you even can see Vatican. Very good price for all three attractions, specially if you are under 25.
Beautiful Grounds. Beautiful grounds full of ancient history. It is very well looked after and a very affordable price. Staff willing to assist if needed.

Great for kids. After a long and crowded visit to the Colosseum, this was a welcome change for our kids. They could run around freely and have more space. While there isn't as much to see here (as compared to Colosseum and Roman Forum), it still has exhilarating history and stories behind it. We had used a guide (common for Colosseum, Palatine Hill - at 13 Euros per person - outside the Colosseum). His English was decent - so we enjoyed this more than the Colosseum (where our guide's English was too accented for us to understand)

Fantastic. Definitely a must see attraction when in Rome. Spent 4 hours exploring Palatine Hill & The Roman Forum with my 12 year old who thoroughly enjoyed this also. Some magnificent features and history throughout......make sure to wear comfortable flat shoes as there are lots of steps, hills and uneven surfaces.

Ancient Rome Experience Needs a Guide. Get a guide like we did to thoroughly enjoy the meaning of all of the sites in ancient Rome. Ours was very informative and we learned a great deal about all of the sites. It is really amazing to get the feel of the small city we now call Rome and the Coliseum, the Forum and Palatine Hill!

The heart of ancient Rome. This is the largest collection of Roman ruins in a compact area you will ever find. Unfortunately it is becoming more and more restricted in access.There is a new multimedia light show that is projected onto the forum ruins. It is well worth the 15 Euro price.

Amazing couple of hours spent exploring. A must see attraction in Rome. We got the combined ticket from the Palatine Hill ticket office ( much quieter than the huge queues at the colosseum ticket office ) you have to use the Palatine Hill and the the Roman Forum on the same day as the Palatine Hill, they lead on from one another so makes sense. The Colosseum can be visited separately ( we did it next day ). There are plenty of steps so lots of climbing required, take comfy shoes...The scope and scale of the temples and buildings is amazing, if you have any imagination at all you can get a great idea of what it was like to be there all those years ago.take plenty of sunscreen if its hot as there arent many places to get out the sun for the time you are in there

Two in one - buy your Colosseum ticket here too!!!. Queue up on the left to buy your ticket for here and the Colosseum to save the huge queues.Queue up on the right if you already have a ticket. This place is enormous! Take a drink and some food. We were craving everyone else's pre-bought apples and waters, there was nothing be sold inside here. Consult maps every now and then as it's easy to get lost.Once you're in, you can't leave and come back which we made the mistake of. So do what you want/as much as you can in your one visit (unless you buy another ticket of course).The place has a truly magnificent feel to it. It's well preserved and you can really picture Ancient Rome. Most areas/ruins have information about them. Just standing and observing is enough for me. It's a nice break from beggars and sellers. There are plenty of seats and also a WC. A must see in Rome and awe-inspiring.
Roman history on your own.. Plan to spend a day here if you want to see everything. Beautiful and peaceful. No guides but you do get a map.

The ultimate site . When in Rome outside the forum the palatine hill, just above it, is a must visit in the city. The ruins of the imperial palace, the houses of octavian and his wife livia are the principal spots. There is breathtaking view over the forum and beyond from there. A place that trully captures the imagination.

get the right guide. did this as part of a three element tour with the Colosseum and the Forum, our guide from Premier Italy Tours was Chad a Californian studying for his PHD in Roman & Greek history, his tour presented in a laconic and sarcastic way was perfect, his knowledge needless to say was excellent but it imparted an enthusiasm in me to look up books when I got home on the history of Rome ( I haven't read or previously felt the need to read a history book since I was 16 (i'm 60!) very very enjoyable who brought he history to life.
Splendid Panorama's. Palatine Hill is today an open air museum There are some fantastic panorama's to be had whilst touring this area. Well worth it.
Wow. It's called a hill for a reason but will give you some great sights. Take a tour guide to get a true understanding of the ruins before you

If you like Ancient Rome, don't miss. When we arrived in Rome we took a tour that walked us from the Colosseum through the Forum up to the Pantheon. From the Forum area you can see some ruins on the Palatine Hill, but you have no sense of the scale of the place, or its place in the history of Ancient Rome. I had read a couple of historical novels by Robert Harris about the Roman senator and consul Cicero, and knew that even during the Republic, so pre-Empire, the Palatine was the place to live. So we went to the Palatine Hill entrance where lines were very short, and embarked on touring the sites. It was great. The area is now very park-like, so lots of shade. Near the entrance was a map which we took a picture of with our iPad and used as we toured. Don't miss the overlooks of the Forum area and the Colosseum. The one suggestion I would offer is to pack a lunch, as no food is sold (there is water available, and restrooms). Also note that your ticket covers all 3 sites of the Colosseum, Forum, and Palatine Hill; you get only one entry per site, but you can visit over a couple of days, so plan ahead.

A Walk in the Footsteps of Augustus and Livia. A stroll among the ruins here offers some spectacular views of the Forum, Circus Maximus and the Colosseum. There are peristyles, temples, royal apartments, gardens and a hippodrome. If you sit and imagine you can almost see the Caesars walking and/or the children of the royal household playing along the pathways. In the hot weather it is also a great place to catch any prevailing breeze. Water fountains are everywhere to refresh the traveller and public toilets are available but not plentiful.
Feel the history!. Feel the history. Mostly ruins but when you are up there you can have a glimpse of the life of the rulers of the world.
Great views of the ruins. Very close to the Colosseum, we walk up this hill that has a nice garden and admire the views of the Roman ruins
Staning monuments.. Very nice point of view from up the hill , just all the entrance for historical monuments in Rome toghether seems to be expensive for a familly with 4 and more members.

Another 'must see'. Another must see attraction in Rome. Do your research or take a guide otherwise you'll miss out on the significance of certain aspects.Note that the combined ticket with the Roman Forum must be used on the same day as the Palatine Hill visit as it is a common entrance. The Colosseum can be visited separately.Lots of climbing required - naturally as it is a hill but lots of places to sit, rest and admire the view.Ample free toilets and water fountains to top up your water bottles.
Offers great views of the old city of Rome. Excellent place. It s full of history. One can see the old city of Rome with its monuments, art work pillars gates, temples.

Roman ruins!!. I would definately recommend a guide so they can explain what you are looking at otherwise all the ruins will look the same! This was definately very intetesting and is part of the colloseum ticket

Historical Walk in the Park. Located very close to the Colosseum, we decided to take a walk through the park of Palatine Hill! It was extremely special with mounds of ancient buildings everywhere. Walking through Rome, it was easy to see ruins where ever you went! Being a ancient history enthusiast I loved every minute! Its a very big part so expect lots to see!
wow. what an amazing place we spent over two and half hours walking around the site and we still missed parts of it, so much history enjoyed it here more than the colosseum.

A visit to the Palatine Hill should be on everyone's list of places to see. A visit to the Palatine Hill should be on everyone's list of places to see, My top tip is that whilst you can visit the Palatine Hill using your joint ticket for the Colosseum, I would strongly recommend using one of the private tour companies (Hint:see my other reviews). The reason is that without an expert, you will miss out on the importance of the Palatine Hill. In particular, you're expert will be able to show you what was on the Palatine Hill, who built what and how the Palatine Hill was arranged. Without this, you maybe forgiven for thinking that this is just a collection of Roman walls, Roman pillars and a few trees.
Loved it!. A great way to spend an afternoon wandering through the Forum and Palatine Hill. Lots to see! Top tip, take a drink in with you as we had to come out as was gasping for a drink!
Worth visiting. Best to go with a guide so you get the history. Very interesting and great views from the top. A must see.

Spectacular views. The walk going up was very short and we were completely taken with the view of the forum and a lot of rome. It alsi wasn't too crowded and we were able to take a lot of nice photos. The entrance was a little hard to find but just see where others are going up and it should be fine.

Walk through History. So many of those epic movies you have seen, and history documentaries you have watched happened here. This is truly a stroll through history, and is a must see while in Rome. Take your time, and get there early in the morning to avoid crowds.

Walk the hill. We joined the tour that encompassed the Colloseum and the Palantine Hill with a group. The hill walk was great as the bloke who ran it had studied Roman history. He had a great sense of humour and cleverly put the ancient politics into an amusingly modern context. Well worthwhile.

Awesome part of history. This is a must see attraction. It is amazing to walk through history. If you book your tickets before you go to Rome you don't have to wait in line. I booked the Colosseum ticket along with Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum together. All is a must see.

Great Start. Went to the Palatine first based on guide book reccomendations and was not disappointed. No lines whatsoever early in the morning and it was a nice walk. Seeing the earliest part of Rome was great and starting here does help orient you for visiting the Forum and the Colosseum later in the day.

Shammmmmaze Ruins!. Its like Disneyland for ruins. I haven't seen this many ruins packed in such a small area in my life. Or if I had then I have just doubled the amount of ruins I have seen just by visiting this place.

History. I visited this prior to the Collesium and got a favourable price on a joint ticket, this place gives you a feel for how Italy would have been in Roman times.its teeming with history and information but is also nice to just walk round and take in the scenery. It's well worth climbing to the top of the hill as great views of the area and the Collesium await at the top
wonderful views. just take your time and wonder around and enjoy the views. No amenities but just a wonderful atmosphere

The Heart of Rome....Don't Miss!. I'm such a lover of history that to visit this archeological gem was a no brainer. To be here is to almost literally, physically step back in time. One can palpably feel the beat of generations of other humans having been here prior to that moment when YOU are standing on the same soil.

Buy your colosseum tickets here. You can skip the line at the colosseum by buying your colosseum tickets here. It saved us so much time and we only happened to stumble across it by chance. If you want to visit this place you need the full day to properly appreciate it. Make sure you bring you hat, sunscreen, sunnies, lots of water and some really go walking shoes. There are kilometers here to explore if you want to do it properly. It's well worth it. We didn't get a guide, we just overheard others but I would probably recommend a guided tour so you get the full experience and knowledge of what each area was. There are also free toilets here but they aren't the nicest or very clean.

Awesome part of historical Rome. We visited the Palatine Hill while on a highschool field trip. Our tour guide gave a detailed historical explanation of the sites we visited. If you were on your own, you may not know what you are seeing without a tour book or guided tour. Everyone enjoyed this quick visit during our day in Rome.
WOW. Be sure to get a good guide or find a Rick Steves tour group going through. The history of the world is in this valley and on the way to the Pantheon.

A beautiful way to the scale of Ancient Rome. Almost an aside while we waited for the coliseum queue to shrink, Palatine Hill was wonderful. Sweeping views of Rome and the Colosseum, areas of shade and relaxation. Like a combination tourist attraction, archeological site, and city park.Do not get so hot and tired waiting to enter the Colosseum that you miss Palatine Hill.Note: a long hot climb up and back down. Not recommended for strollers, wheelchairs or those in poor health.Also same ticket for Palatine, Forum and Colosseum.

Worth the walk. Did this as part of a Colleseum tour. Was not that interested when I bid it but changed my mind once we started touring. Wonderful views, pretty gardens and lots of history. What's not too like

The Home of Rome. Overlooks the City, the Forum and Circus Maximus. It is touted as the beginning building site of Rome. It is a climb up from the Forum, so wear great walking shoes, bring water and an umbrella and a shade hat. There was a line to get into the site, but not bad for early in the day. We bought the Rome Archaeological Pass through the Tourist Bureau, and it saved us a ton of money and time getting into many sites such at this one.

Need a full tour or you'll lose interest quickly. The palatine hill is a good place to visit but with the area just being ruins and small ruins eg mainly small rocks, it's easy to only get bored within an hour of being here. I would say go and it would be really good if your on a tour and they explain everything to you, otherwise it's a bit meaning less just seeing rocks on the floor without the story behind it. Would go, but don't expect to spend more than an hour here, the best place is at the top of the hill to take photos and is lovely there.

Stunning and hidden part of Rome. i have been to Rome several times, and somehow never been to the palatine hill before. I was on a guided tour with a school group, and was disappointed when the guide said we would be going to the palatine hill and not into the forum as it was so hot.However once we got up there, I was so not disappointed anymore! This whole area is stunning, and opened up a whole new section of Rome's history I knew nothing about. And the views...breathtaking! The best view of the colosseum, and down onto the forum as well.From what I understand, you can easily go into the forum as well, but on a hot day with 32 sweltering teenagers, this was a great way to get out of the heat and learn a bit of history as well.

Beautiful. You can follow the Roman Forum to get around to this. Just as amazing the the forum lots of history to be found. Amazing views over Rome. I recommend you take plenty of water and sensible shoes.My review of the Forum covers this attraction :) message me if you need details
Great History. Wonderful place with many wow moments. Find a guide if you can or carry your Rick Steves book for reference. Plan to spend a couple of hours at least at the site.

Refreshing relief from the bustle and traffic of Rome. Because one has to enter this wooded hill through a guarded gate and have bags searched, it seemed that the vast majority of tourists vied away from entering. Once in, however, one is in an oasis of peaceful ancient palace ruins (Palatine - palazzo - palace, yes, the origin of the word). This was where the ancient aristocracy would escape from the chaos of the city and it is as true today as it was 2000 years ago. They are still excavating up here but still there is a wealth of fascinating buildings. The view from the hill down onto the forum area is the best way to appreciate the ancient city.

Great views but must be visited with the Forum on same day. Interesting hill with great views of Rome and of the life of rich ancient Romans. There are already thousands of reviews of Palatine Hill, so I won't repeat them. I just wanted to add that the ticket to Palatine Hill is in conjunction with the Roman Forum. So although the ticket is valid for 24 hours, you can't go in the forum one day and then to the hill the next day. You must go to both on the same visit. If you buy the combo ticket with the Colosseum, then you can go to the Colosseum one day and then Palatine/Forum the next, if you can't finish all three sites in one day. I'm mentioning this because I learned the hard way. I had visited the Colosseum and the forum, hoping to see Palatine the next day, since it was almost closing time. However, the guard informed us that once the ticket is used to enter the Forum, we couldn't use it again the next day for Palatine. Hope this little piece of advice helps someone enjoy their visit to Rome better!

Spectacular. Not to be missed.. Just up from the Colosseum, you should count on spending 1/2 day on the Palatine Hill. After the Forum and Colosseum, you may be tired and the gentle hills, the benches and the beauty are just what you need to recharge. It's a beautiful place. Wander an afternoon away. You'll love it.

Great History and Good Views. This is such an underrated part of Rome but with a good guidebook or plan from the internet it comes alive. I spent a whole morining here just walking around and taking in the buildings and the fabulous views of the Forum below and the surrounding city. So many people head straight for the Colesseum and overlook this important part of Roman history. Good tip though ... this is the quieter entrance so buy your ticket here (i queued for all of five minues) and it also includes the Colesseum and Forum and is valid for two days! Wear comfortable shoes and a sun hat in hot weather, There;s a lot to look at!

Great Views. The ticket you buy for colosseum includes palatine hill and roman forum. It gets really hot in the summer so be prepared to walk with lots of water and comfortable shoes, umbrella. The views are great of the roman forum and colosseum from the top of the hill.

Very enjoyable. How could anything that is this old, and this intact relatively speaking, be anything other than cool. Lots of picture opportunities and views to be had, and all within a manageable area of other historic attractions to minimize the inconvenience of having to maneuvering a family all over.Lots of food vendors and not too far from restaurants in this area either.

Great place with fantastic views. Went to Palatine Hill and Roman Forum as one of the attractions on our Omnia Pass and they were great to see. We just wandered around the ruins and imagined how life used to be and read all the signs of what the ruins were and it was very interesting and you get some fantastic views for photos too

Interesting. If you have never been to Rome I think you will want to see the Palatine Hill, however, you may be disappointed since it is mostly in a state of ruin. You do get a sense of history however. Be warned that there is little shade and it can get very hot during the warmer months.

Great place to spend 1/2 a day along with visit to Colosseo and the Roman Forum. An important collection of residential palace ruins can be seen at Palatine Hill. This is where Roman Emperors and other important families resided during ancient Roman times. You can enter and view the ruins here as part of a combined visit to see the Colosseum and Roman Forum. Entry (€12 per person). Sadly, the palace grounds, gardens and houses found at Palatine Hill have been in a state of ruins for many centuries, leaving only a glimpse of the grandeur that would have adorned this famous hillside many during the height of ancient Rome. What does fortunately remain include some lovely wall frescoes at Domus Augustus and the House of Livia, if they are open at the time of your visit. You can see some nice artefacts at the Palatine Museum (free to enter at Palatine Hill). These were mostly unearthed here during previous excavations. There is also interesting display in the museum for the Iron Age period Huts of Romulus which you can also see at the southwest corner of Palatine. Another neat place to visit at Palatine Hill is the 16th century Farnese Garden. This was the first private botanical garden in Europe. Then make your way to the viewing area overlooking the Roman Forum. If you have a guidebook, you can study the building below and identify what they are before/after walking through the Forum. Tip: To get the most of your visit to Palatine Hill, it is advisable to purchase a good guidebook and to spend some time going over the ruins found here before you visit. This will help prepare you for what to look for when wandering the Forum grounds. Tip: The grounds around the Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum can be uneven. Do bare this in mind when thinking about footwear. Tennis or hiking shoes are most suitable for exploring the grounds. Overall, we'd suggest first seeing Colosseo and the Roman Forum, if time is limited. These are higher impact areas that you will likely better remember after your trip is finished. However, if you have time, it is well worth also visiting Palatine Hill to see the ancient structures, ruins and museum here as well.
Amazed. Well worth a visit, so much to see and take in, ticket also gets you into the coloseum.Best to go early to avoid the crowds
Brilliant Guide. Gladiator Tours - we had a male guide who was very informative and made the tour really interesting and fun, I would thoroughly recommend this guide to add to your holiday in Rome.
Not to be missed!. The history just surrounds you! Walking those streets on Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum gives you just a glimpse of what it was so long ago.
For amazing views. If you want an amazing view of The Forum.....just go there, little walk....but well worth an effort....

Great visit- recommend getting a guide or audio guide. great place - one thing we didnt do was get a guide (real or audio) and this would have enriched our experience and made it more meaningful, so worth it to get a guide :)
Great open space. Visited as part of an organised tour. It was great to hear about the history of the place. The immense size of the palace that used to be here is amazing.
A walk through history. This is an amazing walk into the past. The buildings are well presented and the areas surrounding them full of history. The past comes alive in this site.

Squeeze It In If You Can.. Palatine Hill, along withe the ubiquitous Colosseum and the Roman Forum, is included in the two day admission ticket. It is worth spending some time and the energy to walk up this hill. The views of the Forum, the Vittorio Emanuele Monument and the Circus Maximus are nice. There is also a small museum up top. Pose for an angel photo shot in front of a set of stone wings.If you don't have the time or energy, I would suggest choosing the Colosseum and Forum over Palatine Hill.
Stunning history. Breathtaking, awe inspiring, a definite must see around this beautiful city. The view from the top overlooking all this history is stunning.
Worth checking out.. Very cool. Amazing view at the top of the hill. We almost didn't go but I am so glad we did. Lots to see

Amazing views and sense of history. We pre booked our tickets before we went to Rome ( combined ticket for the colosseum ,roman forum and palatine hill combined 14€) and this ensured a quick admission. The whole experience has an amazing sense of history and grandeur . The views over Rome are amazing and it's easy to see why the palaces were built there. We were there at around lunchtime, just before the crowds arrived, which added to the sense of calm. You need good walking shoes as some of the paths are steep and uneven.

Well worth seeing. This is one of the sites that can be pre-booked on the Internet in combination with the Coliseum. Palatine Hill is on the same site as The Forum & will take you many hours to tour the 2 sites but well worth it & dont rush round , check out all possible nooks & crannies.

History alive. I strongly recommend it when in Rome. However, if you don't want to book a tour you should read about first to understand what you see. I encourage you also to visit the palatine hill museum to get a more insightful idea about what it.Buy the combined ticket coliseum + palatine ,they are 10 minutes away from each other and both worth seing.

Interesting. Similar to Roman Forum, just a different story. But, its must visit. We hired a guide, so it was good for us. And the tickets were combined with Roman forum and Colosseum. Plus, it was valid fro 2 days. When we went there it was raining, so we could not enjoy it as much.

Beautiful ruins with fabulous views. Once we had located the place to purchase tickets (near the colosseum), it was a short 5 minute queue to get tickets & get in.They have security so expect to have your bag checked.We were not able to determine whether there was a cost for children or not as the asian couple in front of us had to pay for there young daughter. However only the adults were charged in our family, but just not sure if the ticket lady just assumed that we were from the EU as we look European. (from NZ) Tickets have combined entry for the roman forum/palatine hill & the coloseum. This is definately the fastest way to get tickets to see them all.Anyway plenty to see and entertain yourself with here and also some great photo ops including great views of the colosseum.Uneven walking surfaces, wear proper shoes.

Another amazing experience. We visited Palatine Hill and the Colosseum on the same day. You can purchase one ticket for eu14 per person, and it includes entrance to both Palatine Hill and Colosseum (its a two day ticket). I loved walking around the ruins at Palatine Hill, it gives great insight into the early days of Rome. You can also see some of the areas that are still being excavated.I would strongly encourage a visit to Palatine Hill, especially if you are visiting the Colosseum.

An image of the past. Visiting Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum was very interesting, but I think it is very helpful to have an idea of what it might have looked like during it's peak. By visiting the Palatine Hill Museum, you get an idea of what the ruins represent in the exhibits, so it is important to visit it when you go there.Another thing that is very helpful to put the ruins into perspective is to check out the books all of the museum book stores have with overlays of the glory days of the buildings showing the structures in their Heyday over the ruins you see today. Then you get a very vivid picture of the magnificent and colorful city this once was.Be sure to note, a ticket for the Colosseum is good for two days and gets you into the Palatine Hill and Roman Forum Site as well. The ticket is good only for one entrance into each site. The Palatine Hill and Roman Forum is one attraction, one entrance.

You need a good guide.. The Palatine Hill, though being the most ancient part of the Colosseum/Roman Forum/Capitoline Hill complex (the theory is that's where the first Roman settlers picked their residence) is also the least interesting, in our opinion. It is significantly less preserved, the remaining vestiges of the past Roman glory are not that striking neither they are evident for a non-Rome scholar. Add to that the area that takes up a huge stretch above the Roman Forum along with continuous climbing, and you get a modest 4-star rating. The panoramic view of Rome, or rather its south-western part is quite impressive though. But again, without a good tour guide, even the Circus Maximus doesn't look like much. House of Augustus and Stadium of Domitian surprise with their enormous scale but the state of preservation is minimal. If you are limited in time and are facing an option of what sites to choose - pick the Capitoline Hill instead or spend more time at length at the Roman Forum.

A nice relaxing walk in a busy city. When you enter through the gate beside the Colosseum, turn left and head up the slope for unrivalled views of the surrounding sites including the Roman Forum and Circus Maximus. These will make all the uphill work worth it and the ruins throughout the site are amazing.

Visit the Church on the hill. Big walk up a steep slope but worth it.The ruins are of interest but the church & convent make the climb worthwhile.The Franciscans & the Youth of St Francis make visiting the small church a true religious event ( better than the Vatican, even )We were offered a prayer, we went to a free trading table & received free hugs from the youth.Thank you all. Made our trip to Rome so great.

Palatine Hill, Colosseum and Roman Forum Tour!. We had a tour that included Palatine Hill along with the Colosseum and the Roman Forum. It was definitely worth the price. The tour was cheaper than purchasing all entries separately and it was very informative. There is so much to see on Palatine Hill that a guide is definitely recommended. There is a lot of walking up and down hills so if you have any issues walking, be prepared.

Worth a visit. If you purchase the ticket through the official channels it allows you to the colosseum as well as roman forum and palatine hill. All are within minutes of each other. Worth spending 1/2 a day minimum there.

Steeped in Roman history. This was part of a 2 ticket purchase which included the Colosseum and allowed us to skip the normal long queuing arrangements that so frustrate the visiting of monuments and museums. This place is worth a visit, how anyway could disagree is is beyond me. You can stroll around as long as you like and you see just how vast the Roman Forum was 2000 years ago. Lots to take in with audio tours available as well but also there are many information boards that give you the gist of relics and so on if you don't fancy spending your time listening to commentaries.
Must visit along with the forum. What a fascinating place to visit and so much remaining from over 2,000 years of history.Be warned toilet facilities inadequate though and paths often very uneven.

Palatine Hill ruins. It was quite a long walk around these ruins, and there were a lot of them. Nice grassed areas where you could sit, and there were not many people around there at all. There is a museum in the middle which was pretty interesting. There is a good view of the Roman Forum and the Colosseum from here. It was interesting to see, but not something I would have paid for separately (ticket was free with Colosseum ticket).

A guide made all the difference.. Julieta from Walks of Italy, explained what Palatine Hill was like in its heyday. She used illustrations to show us what historians believe the area and buildings used to look like, and explained the lives of those who lived there. She was an enthusiastic tour guide whose passion for history made our tour very informative and enjoyable.

Love the history!. Our tour guide explained what we were seeing & we found it very interesting. We highly recommend a tour guide for Rome. It's well worth the price if you really want to know the history of Rome.
A must see!. A must see but see it with a guide and be prepared to walk and walk some more. Seniors you may just want to look from afar.
Great experience. Well worth going here as an extended visit to the colosseum. We were guided by Chad... From California - he had a great 'take' on the history and made the tour very interesting
Great views. Lots of things to see, which really need explaining, but if you are not into tour guides, you will still enjoy walking around this area, taking in all of the great views and the ruins.

Go with a good guide. It's a privilege to tour Palatine Hill, but it requires imagination and the help of a good guide. If you were just to run through the site, I'm not sure it would have much meaning. We visited with a private guide and were so pleased with the experience. This is one of the big reasons to visit Rome and it lives up to expectations if you do it right.

See together with Colosseum and Forum. Buy tickets ahead to save time. Eat before or after your visit. Totally worth and doable together with Colosseum and Forum. Read ahead or hire a guide since there are almost no signs to tell you what you are looking at.

Nice Historical Site. I did not pay to enter, but they looked beautiful from the Colosseum. They would definitely be fun to walk through, but I was too tired to make it through that site. You can access it easily by getting off at the Colosseo stop on the Blue Metro Line.

Intresting. Roman Empire , what can you say , though only ruins are left but English guide explained us all very well, visiting this area does give some idea in those days how rulers were ruling from such massive place
Loads of history from a hill top view, a view that the wealthy enjoyed!. Amazing architecture for the time! History is so amazing. Tour bought at Colosseum allowed entrance and tour of Palatine Hill.

Interesting not to be missed. An essential attraction when in Rome and especially when buying a ticket taking in the colosseum tooWe visited on a busy last weekend and strolled the site for a couple of hours - amazing history, a special site

A hilltop view of Rome.. On our tour of the Roman Forum ruins we were told that Palantine Hill was optional. When our tour ended we went back and climbed the hill, we thought it was just a view point for photographs, however, it was so much more. We spent two more hours there taking panoramas, walking through the ruins and just enjoying the sunshine. If you take a trip to the amazing ruins of the Forum, a walk up Palantine hill is a must.

Another amazing part of amazing rome. A walk to remember.... Combining the amazing weather of Italy and one of the most beautiful historical parts of Rome... Best time to visit is the spring time April and May

Very intresting place. It was very interesting walk around the roman town ' Palatine Hill ' We spend between 3 to 4 Hrs walking there and there are a lot of things to see. Also in certain parts of the Palatine you have to use a bit of imagination so you can get a imagine of that time.Next to the Palatine Hill also we saw the horse race which used to use the roman at that time.I really recommended to see it.
A Different View. With a tour that included the Roman Forum, and Colosseum, it's worth the climb for the visual perspective.

Fascinating. Took to Palatine Hill with a tour guide who was very knowledgeable and funny. Walked around the ruins and over the forum. Although most of the structures and statues were gone you just knew you were in the birthplace of Rome itself.

A breath of fresh air in the heart of Rome. More people are visiting the Palatine Hill now that it is included in the same ticket as the Colosseum and the Forum. It is a delightful place to stroll round and admire what is left of the magnificent buildings in which the great and the good of ancient Rome lived away from the smells of the people down in the city. There is an excellent small museum, and a wonderful viewing platform. It is perhaps the best spot from which to take in the whole of the Forum and helps to put its buildings into perspective. Plenty of benches in the shade and fountains where you can fill up your water bottles. Very much worth a visit.
Ruins . Plan to spend several hours enjoying this spectacular group of ruins. Great views of Circus Maximus, Roman Forum and the Colosseum

Perfect Overlook.
