The Palatine Hill overlooks the Circus Maximus and has a great view of the Roman Forum, which I think gives you a better feel for the size and intricacies of the Forum as opposed to walking the entire Forum site. Getting to the top of the Hill is a strenuous walk, winding and steep. Our taxi took us right up to the top overlook, where we got out for a good look and photos. Very impressive view.

Go early and skip the audioguide rental. We went early in the day (right around opening time), and there was no line. As the mornign continued, the hill got more crowded, so we really appreciated starting early before it was filled up with people. A tip is to download the audioguide to your smartphone before heading here. You save money, and skip waiting in line to return the audioguide at the end of your visit.

Gorgeous & breathtaking. A must see, it is a bit of a hike but worth sit for spectacular views!The little maze garden is lovely and the views are amazing, be sure to bring you camera & extra data card!!
Great view. From the palatine hill you have a grat view on the forum romanum and the circus maximus. Further you can see very nice gardens.

Wonder of Rome. This place has so much to see. Be sure contemplate every area. Incredible architecture and well kept gardens. Minimal areas to sit under a shad and enjoy the view but if your early u might just grab a seat. Enjoy and marvel at the antiquities preserved here.
Excellent visit!!. Allow 2-3 hours for this. Definitely worth a visit and pick up a package deal with Colosseum. I enjoyed it and children enjoyed it. Your must visit place if you are going to Rome.
A View with a Difference. Magnificent view of the Roman Forum especially from the vantage point next to the gardens. Well worth the climb.

a walk through the empire. As a student of the classics and someone fascinated by the history of the world this was a highlight for me. Knowing the historical Roman emperors that graced the hill made the experience incredible. The architecture that the ancients were capable of is fascinating!!

History filled site. We had an excellent guide for this visit - enthusiastic and full of interesting facts. Sad that so much of this historic site has been plundered to add to the Vatican. It must have been such an impressive place in it's day! Even though so much has been removed it is still possible to imagine what it must have been like.

Interesting to explore. We used Rick Steve's walking tour to assist to make sense of the ruins here and later down in the Forum. The guide also proved useful in directing us along the paths in a logical order. We started at the ruins of the imperial palace where we viewed the stadium, fountain remains, and various buildings. We could see the Circus Maximus from one viewpoint where there was activity due to Rome's birthday celebrations. We headed downhill from here, getting a marvellous view of Forum from above, before going down to explore it.

Surprise, this is fun!. Been to Rome twice and always passed this tour up because it did not look interesting. Big mistake. I recommend taking the combo Colosseum/Palatine Hill tour they offer at the Colosseum for 12 Euro. It may seem sketchy when they walk up and offer the tour but not only does their Colosseum tour knock the socks off the "Skip the Line" on-line offer, but our Palatine Hill tour was with native English speaker who had a PhD in European Studies. He had the scoop on all the Romans. Pretty cool.
Beautiful and historic. Definitely recommend visiting Palatine Hill, it's beautiful!!! I would suggest going early morning or late afternoon. We were there from 11-2pm and it was incredibly hot!

Historic and beautiful. I did this with the Walks of Italy tour company along with the Coloseum and the Roman Forum. To hear the stories on how Rome was founded is amazing and definitely worth paying for the tour!! You can also enter without a tour, its stunning and so much to see. Well worth a visit

It was good, but expect to walk forever. You're trapped..looking to escape.. Be prepared to walk forever. Once we got to the top of the hill, we kept looking for the exit out. We felt we were trapped and there was no way escaping. If you're in a rush and you have plans later, make sure you plan your time carefully. Also, no food or water to buy on the hill. Make sure you're prepared, but there is an open fountain and bathroom at the top by the gardens. Last but not least, they're very disorganized at the gate. If you have online tickets and didn't print it out, they will tell you that you can't get in and won't print off tickets for you. This is stupid because the online tickets clearly state that you can bring it to be scanned, that's why they're call "online tickets". What it really is, is the fact that they're lazy and their scanners do not work, nor will the ticket office give you a ticket. Kick up a fuss and make a big deal of it and you should get in...I did. Go harass them at the ticket office and ask to speak to a manager. We had the same issue at the Colosseum, but they knew what to do and they used another ticket to get the turnstile working for us, because their scanners weren't reading properly (the Colosseum tickets will also get you into the Palestine Hill and Forums....you have 2 or 3 days to use the ticket for the other venues. See the Colosseum first though). No fuss was kicked or needed at the Colosseum.

Nice Stroll through history. This was a highlight of our stay in Rome. The views of the area and strolling through some unique sights was breathtaking. I would suggest going later in the afternoon because it can get very hot and the sun can feel like its baking you. Find a shady bench and enjoy.

Ancient Rome. I knew nothing about Palatine Hill before planning our trip to Italy, but it ended up being one of the highlights of our day in Ancient Rome. Up on a hill above the Forum and Coliseum, it's far less crowded (both with artifacts and tourists) than the other sites, and is blessed with lovely breezes. It's easy to see why this was the area chosen by the earliest settlers. From here you also have great views of the rest of Rome. It's also the best place to buy your ticket to see the Ancient Rome sites, as the lines are infinitely shorter than at the Coliseum. Do not skip a stop here.

Impressive. Mad to know what happened here 2000 years ago - seems unbelievable!So good that the people (and counsel/government) are willing to allow everybody to see this so easily, would be very fenced off and expensive to see something like this in England.

Enthralling. An enthralling scope of the beginnings of Rome. We didn't have a guide, just walked around on our own. Beautiful, peaceful, not as crowded as some of the other sites since it was spread out.

Amazing architecture. A step back to history. Definitely, I must go to Rome again. There are so many places to visit, I'm amazed for all the the city offers. This is one of those examples. My first recommendation: bring a bottle of water since you will walk at least one hour. There is a drinking water fountain outside of the metro station that you can refill your bottle, very convenient. My second recommendation is don't wear your brand new white tennis shoes for this visit. You will walk through sandy alleys all over the place. One good thing about this place, it's that the queue is short and you can buy the ticket for this place AND the Colosseum as well. The stroll begins with a big gate entrance beautifully carved. You will find descriptions of every building and the ones that were once there. In my personal opinion, it's better to read ahead before the visit rather than take a tour. I forget very easy the information from the tours, that's why I prefer the books. The descriptions explain the particular building and don't give you the overall explanation of the place. Wear something comfy. I didn't see bathrooms but I saw people selling water bottles. There is a hill facing the Colosseum that you can take the best photos for the Colosseum.If this review was helpful, please click below. Probably I can help you in something else, shoot me a message.

Great views and sights, less crowds. We visited the site before our official tour began so we didnt have the benefit of commentary but the place was beautiful and even peaceful in certain spots. Its large enough to spend a few hrs especially including the museum. Only downside - bathroom was closed at the end of the visit (go ahead of time).

Read Your Guide Book. Of the Forum, Colosseum and Palatine HIll, the latter is the place to start your three-site ticket entrance. The entrance line is not as long as the one for the Colosseum. You will, however, need the book sold by tour guides in front of the Colosseum that shows the sites as they now are but with overlay pages showing what they looked like originally. This will make sense of what your are seeing. I'd use the Rick Steeves audio guides rather than buying the audio tour sold at the sites.

Steeped in history. Just walking through these ruins it was easy to imagine what it must have looked like in Romulus and. Rimus time. There is also a great view of the Colosseum from here. This is old Rome and worth going to see.

Back in time of Roman Empire. Absolutely amazing space filed with best of Roman Architecture. It is very big landscape of different terraces with spectacular pieces which are so well preserved over the thousands of year it as actually fascinating. Even if you are not a fan of ruins and marbles or statues there are so many fascinating structures which tell the story and you start to feel a bit like Roman Aristocrat walking around. A defended must experiance.Just keep in mind that there is a huge land scape which is a lot of walking and you will need very comfortable foot wear and refreshments to take you true the Roman Empire walks.

Absolutely Loved It!. We had downloaded the Omnia app on our phones and were able to get some decent information BUT, next time I will hire a guide as I feel we missed some important facts and information. I was amazed that you could just reach out and touch something so ancient and see the beautiful colours of the marble. I highly recommend going and make sure you have time to wander.

The best bit of Rome. I didn't expect to be so entranced by Palantine Hill. We didn't have a guide and just roamed over the extensive site. It felt just as it must have done hundreds of years ago. The gardens, the vineyard and the views were so evocative of a bygone age. I'm sure we would have learned lots more with a guide, but we wouldn't have got the feel of the place. And it was the feel of the place that was so magical.The Forum was also worth just wandering around. Some of the carvings on the pillars, whether they were upright or had fallen over, were amazing. There was one on a gate by one of entrances of a full sized man, holding a baby. Who had carved that, and why?Of all the places that we visited in Rome, this was the one that took me back to another age.
Great stories. Enjoyed the historical sites of ancient Rome, how they came to be and the amazing stories behind the scenery.

A step back in time. When you set your eyes on this beautiful expanse beside the colosseum, dotted with ruins and lovely stone pines, you can't help but be drawn toward it. We took a combined guided tour of the colosseum and Palatine Hill, and it was an amazing, educative and entertaining experience. The view of the Roman forum and other parts of the enchanting city that Rome is, were breathtaking.There are a lot of places to sit around too, so you can spend hours just reveling in this magical historical place. I would rate it a must see in Rome, especially if you love to learn about culture and history!

Fantastic experience, but beware.... Pro tip - beware of the taxis which congregate outside the entrance to the ticket office. I asked how much the fare back to Vaticano would be, was told by the driver it was on a meter so he couldn't say for sure. Slightly naively we jumped in and all seemed fine until we got going and noticed the meter wasn't turned on, and was then told that we had to go 'the long way around' as there was a protest going on in the city centre (I checked the web when I got back - there wasn't!). I reluctantly didn't kick off with the driver as I was with my elderly mother who wasn't feeling too well, so didn't want to turn it into a more stressful situation than it needed to be. Anyway, got charged €32 for a €15 trip. In summary, dodgy cabbies who rip-off tourist operate in this area. Save yourself the frustration and find the nearest taxi rank instead!

You HAVE TO have a guide. More than other main attractions in Rome, this one requires a guide to be worthwhile. It's just a sparse collection of not very interesting ruins unless you have someone giving you the history of how people used the space when it was the main area of political and business action in the ancient past. With a good guide, it's a short course in major buildings and marketplace activities of those ancient times.

Have a picnic where Rome began. This is an interesting part of Roman history and there is much to see. The Palantine Hill is one of seven of the Roman hills and it is from here that the city was established.The view from the top is beautiful and it is well worth making the trek up. There are also various lawned areas where you could rest and have a little picnic.There is no mapped out tour of the place for you. The various parts are labelled though and you can read a little about what each is. You can combine this one with a tour of the Colosseum on one ticket and you must see both places within two days. It's best to see one on one day and see the other the following day as each involves a lot of walking.

2000 years of History. I have wanted to come to Rome for years and finally had the chance. If you are into Roman History then this and the Coloseum are for you....from Spartacus to Gladiator....this is what it's all about. Book a tour ahead of time, we did, with City Wonders, our guide Marco is a Archeaology student so knew his stuff , this your was included in the Coloseum tour so well worth the money.

Climbing required. This is a great way to understand the wonder that is Rome. Layer after layer of civilizations painstakingly revealed in excavations by experts. Go with a guided tour or guide program on your phone. You will walk right by some of the most fascinating stories in mankind's history if you don't have help understanding this place. This is not for the faint of heart. The hill is just that...a long walk. Well worth the effort.

Very interesting site. Palatine Hill is very interesting and a pretty way to spend a day. I do wish that the site was marked better as it would help understand the history and what everything was used for and why.While I did enjoy this, if strapped for time it would go a bit lower on my priority list. It is nice that it is included in the ticket for the Colosseum.

Give yourself a whole day at least to immerse yourself in history.. Even in a day, the area is so large and there is so much history that you will not give everything the attention it deserves. The history here pre dates Christ and is even more impressive as a result. If you can cope it is one place where a guide would certainly be useful to put it all in context. Practical advice is to take drinks with you and that your ticket is included with entry to the Colosseum - and the crucial advice for the Colosseum is to book the ticket on line, the queues are insane! Luckily the Palatine Hill and Forum are quite straight forward to get in comparatively.

Good views. Admission included with colosseum entry, so why not?! Impressive ruins, and great views of the colosseum and the forum. Huge historical significance, but make sure you have something to read or listen to to learn about it, as there are few informational plaques.

Ancient history everywhere you look. We came here after our Colosseum tour. This involves lots of walking up and down steep hills paved with cry uneven stones, so sensible footwear everyone.Between the incredible arches, columns, temple ruins, emporer's residence ruins there is history truly everywhere. The Roman Forum gives you a central location surrounded by all this. Lots of good spots for photos all around.

Worth a visit. Roman Forum and Palantine hill is worth a visit to understand how the city used to work dating back to the Roman empire time. A guided tour would be helpful to understand the different aspects of this place - the churches, prisoner cells, government buildings, etc.,

Magnificent way to see many ruins. The climb up the hill can be a strain, particularly if its near the end of the day. But it is worth it.The view over the Forum is magnificent and the skyline views are just as good. A wander about the top of the hill will place you in more ruins of Rome. A good spot to have a shady rest on the grass before continuing if only to regain some strength for more touring Rome

History at it's finest!. We visited Palatine Hill on a tour through City Wonders, which also included The Colosseum and the Roman Forums. Our guide Amber is an Archeologist so I took advantage of her vast knowledge of the Roman Empire. The Roman Forums and Palatine Hill were the highlight of the tour for me. There is so much history in the buildings and our guide Amber did an amazing job explaining everything to us. My advice is do all three on a tour or you'll never get all the great information we did. Go early in the morning! Our tour ended at 1pm on Palatine Hill and I was glad because it was so hot! I couldn't imagine just starting the tour at that time. You cannot say you've seen Rome if you haven't seen where it all began!

Soaking in the History. I loved this walk. It was so cool to walk up the hill and look in at the Roman Forum and see the sites where the emperors once did their thing. Just take a few minutes and let the history soak in. An absolute must-do for anyone with any interest in ancient history.

A must visit. Situated beside the Colosseum, you could easily pass a full morning or afternoon here.Ideally you could visit both attractions in one day, however if I had to choose I would choose Palatine Hill. Great views of the Colosseum, to take pictures etc.Got great input into early roman times.Tip : No restaurants here once inside, if a good day bring a picnic or some food & drink.

rome at it's finest. it's all there today like you read about it in school.as you walk around you can't stop but think of who's foot steps you might be walking in.there is a lot of walking involved but it's fun.you just go from one famous site to another.it's worth it to take a hoop on off bus and to sit on the top right side to see it too.

The Scale is Amazing. The Palatine Hill really takes a guide to appreciate. The scale is tremendous but you really wouldn't know it without a guide. We used the same guide, Greg from Romania, who was great. Greg also does Vatican tours which I also recommend.
Better the the Colosseum!. Lots to see - It was amazing - could see/feel what it would have been like in Roman times. Prepare to be amazed this is better than the Colosseum (and that was good!)

In the footsteps of the Ancients. We visited this remarkable hill as part of a tour that included the magnificent Colosseum. Our excellent guide, Alessandria, gave us a fascinating insight into the various buildings and their chronology so we could better appreciate the gradual evolution of the area and its culture. The temple of Vesta, Julius Caesar's cremation place and, at the very summit overlooking the Circus where the chariot races took place, the Imperial palace. Alessandria described the gorgeous rooms and all their astounding 'mod cons' so well that we could almost see them. A fine complement to the Colosseum tour that together gave us an unforgettable sample of Roman life.

Palantine hill where it all starts. his is a reaaly interesting place which we highly recommend. You will get pieces of the history all the way back to the Days of Romulus and Remus. A nice and shady park, Beautiful views. If you don´have pre-ordered your tickets, no woories buy the, the day Before at the travel Agency. We used the on Close to the bridge Ponte San Angelo which is easy to find. It is opposite the river from Castel Sant Angelo on the corner of the streets via Banco and Pada. When we visited there were actually no Cues at the entrabce from Via di San Gregorio, but I would´nt take the chance.

So peaceful. The entrance fee to this site was covered by our ticket into the colusseum. I have to say, I actually preferred the walk around this amazing site than the overcrowded rush of our colusseum tour.Most parts of the site were accessible with a few undergoing restoration works. We were provided with a self guided recording which we used a bit but there are information points at almost all of the main ruins so we felt we didn't actually need the recording. Although, on it there were some very interesting back stories about parts of the site thar we wouldn't have learned otherwise!The colusseum is an obvious must do while in Rome but do make sure to visit this site too, it's an easy walk from the colusseum.
Armstrong. Give yourself plenty of time to look around, so much to take in . Beautiful place to enjoy at your leisure

Breathtaking. We spent over 3 hours walking around the ruins and every time we thought we were done, we turned a corner and somethig else surprised us. It was amazing and words cannot do justice to such a historical place.Go, see and prepare to be amazed.It was way better than the Colosseum

Walking Through History!. Getting into Palatine Hill & Roman Forum is free with the Roma Pass and certainly one to be taken advantage of. Walking around Palatine Hill really does give some perspective of the way the city used to be.Definitely pack a sun hat and some sun cream if its a hot day as it does get hot! Also remember to pack a water bottle and some food, there are plenty of fountains to refill your water bottle but there is nowhere to purchase food!Decent walking shoes / trainers required as there are plenty of occasions they are traditional Roman (cobbled and very uneven) roads.

Palatine Hill. the ticket to Colosseum include entry to Palatine Hill and it's a short walk between the two sites. There are a lot of very interesting ruins spread out over a large area, almost park like. Read up on your Roman history before you go or just follow the map you get at the entrance. Well worth a visit.
Lovely and peacful. An opportunity to get away from the hustle and bustle and relax. This area is beautiful and very uncrowded. We went after the Colosseum.

Walking back in time.. The whole scale of the Palatine hill complex is hard to take in. So much of the city has survived over 1500 years after the Romans were routed. A great amount has been removed by different tribes, cultures etc over time but you can still walk down the streets where Cleopatra, JC, Nero & the rest walked! You can walk through the the rooms of their palaces (some imagination required) and see where they played !, look down on and decided on the outcome of millions if distant peoples lives.A full day is required to absorb the hill and its superb history. Bring a packed lunch and water (bottles can be freely refilled at the many fountains around the complex but food is not available), if its hot wear a hat and good walking shoes are essential.The shop at the entrance has a supply of books and paraphernalia but they could do with selling a single sheet plan of the complex to help plan your route. There are plenty of spots around the hill where you can shelter from the sun but down in the forum area it is open to the elements with very few shade spots.A superb day out.

Wonderful views. I always love walking around this place, there are a couple of spots with spectacular views over the whole Forum and Rome.
It can get very hot so take water and sunglasses and you need good walking shoes.

Fun in the sun.. but hot too. Great ruins, beautiful views of Rome and the Colosseum! Theres not much shade though and nowhere to buy water from, take a bottle of water and you can keep filling it up at the many taps dotted around the gardens and Rome in general. Gorgeous place though, would love to go back!

Makes me want to invent a time machine. I loved to walk around and look at the old ruins. Wish I could have seen it back then. It's amazing to just walk around a try to picture how it could have looked like. I could have used more information from signs etc. on the site.

A relative bit of quiet in ancient Rome. I really enjoyed just wandering around the Palatine Hills. I visited here after going to the Colosseum. By comparison, it was much less crowded and less noisy. You can walk around at your own pace reading about the history of ancient Rome. The views from the top were stunning!
Worth a visit. We visited here has it was included in the Coliseum tour,no guide for this part though . It was an enjoyable place to walk around and learn roman history ,fab views of the city .

Why is there no MAP!?. This is a fabulous site, really not to be missed. But unless you have a map of the (very large) area in a guide book you bring, you are out of luck. Its'a mystery to me why they do not provide one, even one we could pay for. I'd happily pay a few Euros for a useful map!

Could do with more signs. Could do with more signs. You tend to wander around following everyone else to find the viewpoints. Great view of the Roman Forum, and the Circus Maximus. Nowhere for food, so take your own. Museum on the hill was small but good.

A must see in Rome!. We visited on the 1st Sunday of the month, making it free to enter, along with the Colosseum and the Roman Forum. This place is beautiful to see and to imagine how it was like. Would definitely recommend having a few hours for this place and take water with you, which you can fill up when at a water fountain. Don't forget to wear comfortable shoes while walking around, as it will be much more easier and safer than some heels!

Great tour guide. Gregory from Gladiator Tours gave us a wonderful, humorous, knowledgeable tour of Palatine hill and information on the Forum below. Gladiator tours offers a combo ticket for a Colosseum tour, which was also very good, and Palatine hill. They can be found near the entrance to the Colosseum. Recommend having a tour guide. Much more personal, the facts and tidbits of information are amazing. Such historical, beautiful parts of Rome, not to be missed.

History, history, history.... Visited here first Sunday of May which meant entrance free ( covers Forum and Colosseum too). Walked from Piazza Navona, along river to Circo Massimo, then up to entrance to Palatine hill. Despite having read about large queues on free Sunday's, we got in within 10 minutes. It is hard to imagine the scale of this area and the buildings that once covered the hill without visiting. Information is limited so a good guide book would be useful. Forum is at same site so you just follow the path downhill (a good reason to start at the Palatine entrance) to see this. You can then exit here over the road from the Colosseum ( beware people offering to get you in quickly for 20 euros) as it only took us 10 mins again to get into Colosseum despite huge looking queues (using same free tickets).

Another thing you must see. The Palatine Hill is next to the Roman Forum and the Colosseum. Your entry ticket from the Colosseum allows you entry. We entered at the Roman Forum and you can walk between the two. It is a large site and you can just wander around. This area is where the first settlers went, so a lot of history. It is good to read up on the history before you go so you can appreciate it more.

Try to go on the First Sunday of the month. This was on our to do list for our second day in Rome using our OMNIA Vatican & Rome card (its one of many extras you can choose as part of two extra spaces) but we stumbled across it while looking for St. Peter's Prison on our first day.Lucky for us it was the first Sunday of the Month and they had Free Tickets (hence my title) so we didn't have to use up a space on our card.An interesting part of history with beautiful nooks here and there, I suggest wearing sneakers though as the paths are odd stones and I saw many people struggling with inappropriate shoes on. If you're thirsty they have fresh water springs inside to top up your bottle (as does Rome all over) and plenty of places to sit and take in the atmosphere. We didnt use a guide but just looked at the signs which we thought were informative enough.

You really need a guide to truly appreciate. We generally visit sites on our own, but for this and the Forum, a guide will help you understand. So much history, plan on reading guidebooks if you don't have a guide to explain everything. Otherwise it is a park with ruins.

Amazing. My husband and I visited Palatine Hill as part of a trip to Rome, and this was on our 'must see' list. My husband loves history (hence the trip) and we visited Palatine Hill as part of an organised walking tour (see review for Walking Tours of Rome). The hill was busy and yet there was still space to relax. The views are so beautiful it's hard not to be moved. You get a sense of the grandeur that was once there. If you get chance, try to spend some time there, relax, and watch the parrots flying through the trees.

Only for the amazing view. By itself this garden complex is not that fancy. Nowhere near Versailles or anything like that. But the reason you should visit is that if you go to the Colosseum you have a joint ticket. The outlook to the forum is great, it really gives you an authentic and majestic feeling.There are some additional ruins to the Forum which you can enjoy. But chances are by the time you get there you already seen one too many of them.

A test of the ancient Rome. This is one of the best places I been to. Not a historic nerd but this was fascinating. A guide is recommended. Walking around the Palatine gave an excellent feel about how the ancient Rome was organized. After the guide left us on the top you where able to stroll around al over this place.

Immersion.... Surrounded by history, surrounded by beauty, and if you're lucky, surrounded by not too many people!We had an upcoming tour of this area combined with our colosseum tour, so we weren't too desperate to know what significance each building had. It was beautiful just to wander around it.The next day, our archaeologist-tour guide pointed out so many things as we walked around with him, that we'll be heading back by ourselves again to truly appreciate it and take it all in.

Fascinating. Absolutely worth the visit but best done with a guide. Sure, we all read the guide books but a decent guide (about €10-€14) brings loads of incidental information that really brings it alive. TAKE YOUR TIME, there's so much to see here.
a historical place. one of the places to visit in roma. a good thing to do is to take the tickets in the forum to avoid the queu in the colisium.

History. It's great to take the time and enjoy looking at history. To see the work that Rome has done in restoring some of these ruins so we can better see and understand some of the world's greatest history. Walk about and get up close to many current projects.

Wonderful experience to explore and see ancient ruins. We spent the better part of the day exploring Palentine Hill and the Roman Forum. Seeing the different ruins of Roman structures up front and personally is quite an experience. I would highly recommend it for anyone who has not been there. We started the day early, which helped avoid the crowds, and in the spring, which kept temperatures moderate.

Must see this. At the heart of Rome is the remains of the palaces built by the Roman Emperors, on top of the Palatine Hill, which overlooked the forum on one side, and happily gave prime seats to watch the Circus Maximus chariot racing. The remains of marble tiles and frescos gives us an idea of the glory of this empire, the remains clearly showing us the centre of the known universe at this time. Hire a well versed ancient history guide to give in depth details of this glorious place when in Rome. You will need half a day at least
a lot of things to see, but a guide is necessary. there are a lot of monuments to see, but you need a guide to understand what they are. The hill dominates the Roman forum, and is truly impressive.

It's OK. We had bought the ticket that gives us access to the Colosseum, Forum, and Palatine Hill. We were most underwhelmed by Palatine Hill. While impressive to see the footprint of some of the edifices, and of what life was like back during the Roman Empire. There aren't many "attractions" per se, but it's wide open & you're free to roam as you please.
..........and Forum. All in one grounds - and ticket to Colesso covers you for one entry. Plan to spend a good half day here as the grounds are extensive and so much to see and taken in.

Fascinating. I love Roman history, and this place was amazing. We bought a ticket that got us into here, the fora and the colosseum - well worth it. I was fascinated by seeing where the Roman aristocrats used to live, and being able to just wander around and poke my nose into places where people were living hundreds and hundreds of years ago was amazing. You must go if you have any interest at all in Rome and the emperors of this time.

Very interesting, only a short walk from Collisseum. Went here right after the Collisseum - you get good views of it from upstairs at the former, and as well as visiting here if you walk to the right of the entrance there are also some great statues and sights leading up to the square. Recommend.

Single entry with Roman Forum. Beware that despite being listed as separate attractions, the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill are really one site and so only one entry is permitted on the ticket. There is a lot to see, although the information boards are quite dull, and we regretted not having taken a picnic with us as we were there for hours. Lots of walking.

Great views and refreshing air overlooking the Forum. Unexpected pleasure in the Forum/Colosseum area. The forum can be hot and crowded, but the Palantine was relaxing. We didn't have time to explore it all, but it is definitely on the list to revisit should be fortunate to return to Rome. Great views overlooking both the Forum and the Colosseum, orange trees and grass to relax.

Loved it for the history. We was here midday, it was hot, the ruins were fascinating / fantastic, you could visualize how it must have looked back in time, some of the descriptions were a little strange in wording, however it is Italy, it was a little crowded.One word of warning, watch out for the pick pockets out on the roads where the big crowds are.
Gorgeous history. Such a great walk through history. The relics there are amazing as the civilization is from so long ago. it's beauty is astounding and the views from the top are breathtaking.

Beautifull. If I'm honest, I only wanted to see The Colosseum and didn't even know about Palatine Hill (we only had 5 hours in Rome).However, I am extremely glad that we chose to see both. Palatine Hill is a lovely peacefull place to walk around in the midst of the city with some amazing views to offer.Will definately come back if we return with more time to spend in Rome.

Roman ruins. A number of ancient Roman ruins which were uncovered a few centuries ago.You do need a guide (or a good guide book) to explain these, so just be careful who you choose as a guide as their prices vary greatly.You can save money by buying a combined Colloseum and Palatine Hill entry ticket.

Surprise!. We hadn't investigated the Palatine and just decided to take a look as it included with the Colosseum ticket, as usual we wandered contrary to the crowd and found a quiet path through the 'park' only as we climbed up to the Palatine did we start to discover it's riches. Wow! We were in for over 2hrs wandering here and there and would probably have stayed longer had we been able to find some refreshment but none seemed to be available anywhere within the bounds of the Palatine or the Roman Forum, had we know this before entering we would have taken something with us and had a bit of a picnic whilst appreciating the ancient monuments. This really was one of our highlights of a 3 day visit and we would rate it above the Sistine chapel!

Buy your ticket for Palatine Hill then go to Colleseum. You should go and buy your ticket for the Pallentine Hill/Colleseum at the entrance to the Palentine Hill. This way you dont have to wait in line for the enormous Colleseum line up.Palentine hill is worth seeining. There is also the museum you should tske in.

WITH BEAUTIFUL VIEWS OVER THE ROMAN FORUM AND COLISSEO!. Don´t miss it! You can walk and walk learning more about the ancient Rome civilization, (there´s also a litle museum). It´s also a nice place to rest a little bit, before entering the Colisseo.And you have astonishing views over the Roman Forum and the Colisseo. Ideal to take great photos!

Nice stroll through time. Get your ticket for the forum and colosseum at the Palatine hill entrance to avoid long lines. Then walk the hill, enjoy the views and small interesting museum. Well explained signage in English. Bring Roman history to life
history. If you enjoy history this is a must see. Due to time we only had 1 1/2 hours here but could have stayed longer.

A wee bit of peace and quiet. God but it was good to get away from shouting kids and slow witted tourists !! The forum was an horrendous entrance and the crowds make it very difficult yo make sense of what you see. The short walk up the hill brought a new dimension to the Forum with great views and a different perspective on what the whole area was about -- and yes the silence !!

A lovely park with plenty to do and great views. You can hire segways, bikes, go-cart, rowing boats, 4 person bikes, so plenty to do. Lots of sculptures to look at and great views of Rome. There is a also a beautiful looking restaurant there which is fine dining so we didn't stop. If you've got the money I would say this restaurant would be top of the list. Nice to have some peace and quiet after a busy few days sightseeing.
It's a hill. Viewed the forum which is amazing, then walked up this erm hill. It's ok, part of the rome experience, but once you've seen the forum this is nothing but a hill.

Fantastic views. Obviously where the rich people lived, overlooking the Forum, and you see this hill from various aspects within the Colosseum too, so you have some great photo opportunities. Lovely quiet areas to walk around with obviously fabulous views from all areas.

Nice for a walk. This area was nice for a walk but not much else.
There are some sites which have a rich history but no where near as good as the Roman Form which is connected.
I would still go again, but if I was pushed for time there are more impressive sights to see.
Amazing. It is a must see.Breathtakingly beautiful.Rome is one of the most amazing cities in the world and you cannot die without seeing it.

A must see! Absolutely beautiful and very relaxing!. We visited Palatine Hill at about 11ish in April and there was only a small queue, only about 10 people in front of us. And we bought our ticket the day before from when we visited the Colosseum - €12 for the Colosseum, The Forum and Palatine Hill! You can use your ticket for 24 hours which is brilliant!It was quite quiet, considering the amount of tour groups we walked past, but it is quite a big space so didn't feel full! Palatine Hill was extremely beautiful and we enjoyed looking at all of the ruins left and the old pieces of marble flooring, overall a very quiet and relaxing morning with all of the blossom, orange trees and views from the top. I would suggest taking a water bottle with you - there are fountains around so you can keep filling up - as you get very hot in the sun but there are shady spots too! The view from the top is stunning and you can see over The Forum, see the Colosseum and the basilicas across the city! Gorgeous!

Allegedly the best views in Rome.... From what I gathered the Palatine Hill is at the peak of the area including the Roman Forums - those you have to see, it was great to literally walk through a piece of ancient history, and many photos were taken. Only thing is when we tried to find the Palatine Hill in order to peruse the amazing views of the city we were unsuccessful, we ended up exiting the barrier thinking there was a separate entrance but apparently we missed the entrance somewhere inside. Either the hill isn't very well signposted or we were just bad at orienting ourselves here!
Worth a visit. Was a lovely view from the top, lots of ruins to see. Was a beautiful day and we had a iconic. Worth a visit.

Must see. It is a climb after spending time in the Forums. We also nearly took the exit from the forum as there were no clear guided paths. The view from the top and amazing Orange trees on the top is a must see. You will spend atleast 3-4 hours in the forum and on the hill as they are next to each other.

Beautiful. I would definitely recommend this. You should allow about half a day for the whole experience and definitely see it with a guided tour. There is so much to learn and the view at the top is simply breathtaking. We went with our little girl in a stroller/push chair and managed just fine. Also nice grass areas of kids to play.

Must see. As mentioned in my review of colosseum, we purchased a three day omnia pass. We were allowed free access to this amazing site but unfortunately no fast track entry but we didn't have to wait too long to gain entry but glad we didn't have to queue to buy a ticket!There is so much to see so allow a couple of hours. There are sign posts which not very clear we exited the site without seeing everything.

Don't miss this when you go to the Forum!. Palatine Hill was actually more fun to wander about and explore than the Forum, which I never would have expected. There's less people up there, and the palatial ruins are for the most part still-standing; you get a much better sense of scale and purpose than from the rubble in the Forum! And there's a very long, very cool tunnel to walk through if you get too hot. ;) The views from Palatine Hill are amazing - there's a corner overlooking the Colosseum that does not seem well-known, the corner looking over the Forum that everyone goes to (and for good reason - don't miss that view!), and then on the back side, a view over Circus Maximus and Aventine Hill in the distance, which is really quite special and gives you a sense of what it would have been like to be standing in the palace overlooking Circo Massimo. :) I think Palatine Hill is underrated. I wasn't expecting anything much, based on the reviews, and it turned out that I enjoyed it more than the Forum, which I never would have guessed. It also has large enough open stretches that would allow kids to run amok in, which might be a good tip for parents trying to expend some energy in their children. :) (Not tested, just a hunch).
Amazing architecture of very old Rome. Was an amazing view on our Segway tour. It takes you back hundreds of year for a real feel of Rome. Lots of history and pictures to take here.

Wonderful Sight. Palatine Hill is the middle hill among the famous seven hills...it is a very nice place to visit as it is them oldest among the all seven. This hill is also important as the history of Rome begins on this. Rome got its existence and name from Palatine Hill only

Huge site. We visited the Palatine Hill after having been to the Colosseum. We thought that we had seen everything there was when we saw that there was much more. The signs were not very clear so we almost exited the site without having seen nearly half of it. You should plan to spend at least two hours here if not more. Afterwards you exit into the Roman Forum. Ticket is a combined ticket for the Colosseum, Palatino and the Roman Forum.Wear good comfortable shoes

So much to see. We booked online the triple ticket to the Coliseum, Palatine Hill and Forum. They kindly give you 48 hours to visit but there is something you may not realize. Once you use the ticket for a particular place, you may not return. We knew that. However, we did not know that the Palatine Hill and Forum are considered one place! We returned the next day and were told we already used the ticket. We explained that we saw a separate way leading to the Forum and thought it was a third entry. (I am a senior and partially disabled and could walk no more after the Coliseum and Palatine Hill.) The ticket entry young woman was sympathetic but could do nothing. This was a "once in a lifetime trip" for us for so I told her I understood but it was a disappointment. As we readied to leave, I saw the ticket booth empty(a very rare occurrence I believe) and decided to ask the ticket woman if there was anything we could do. She allowed us entry and I could have hugged her! Never will I forget her kindness. HOWEVER, do not let this happen to you. Palatine Hill and Forum are one.  Do go and wander and soak in the beauty, the history and the views from everywhere. Do some pre research to enjoy the most and do not skip the little museum inside the Palatine.  We did not realize how much there was to see. Plan to stay a while, so bring a snack and water. Use the available WC's when you can because there are few and sometimes long lines(the out of the way ones are a better bet).  Try to go in the morning if visiting in the warmer months. It got very hot in the afternoons. It is also less crowded early.

Spectacular view from the top. Take the time and effort to get to the top of the hill and you will be rewarded with an awesome panorama of the surrounding area. The view will make you appreciate the unique blending and melding of the ancient and the modern that has earned Rome its nickname, "The Eternal City."

A view into the heart and soul of Ancient Rome.. This is the one "hill" not to miss. Walking the two thousand year old paving stones gives one a real sense of how glorious Rome must have been. A definite must see.

My favourite place in Rome!!!. Please please please allow yourself the whole day at this beautiful location....my only regret about my trip to Rome was that we only allowed a few hours here but yet there is so much to see! When you see it from the outside is very underwhelming because you can't see much and the travel guides don't quite explain what a great place this is. Its full of goodies, from huge dried up Roman baths, to mammoth pillars and vast grounds that you can just casually walk around. I would suggest that you not only spend a whole day here but also take some sort of picnic and enjoy the splendid views that behold you. I can't find the words to describe how great this place is, its like to get to walk around what a true Roman village would be like. All I can say is just GO and visit it!!!

Very interesting, worth the visit. This is included in the Roma Pass, and kids are free (you just have to get free ticket for the kids from the ticket window). Roma pass and free tickets are scanned to open the turnstile. To our pleasant surprise, we found out that there is a less congested "other" entrance (left of the boulevard leading to the big arc before reaching the colisseum ) to Palatine hill. There is lots of history in this place, also a nice respite after our Colisseum visit. Don't forget to check-out its three-storey museum.

Must see. The great place which is well worth of seeing and showing the kids. Very teaching. Order the tickets in advance and be ready that there is a long line to replace the vouchers ordered by the actual tickets.

Words are too little to describe. Awe inspiring. The best part of our trip to Rome. Allow a full day to explore this and the forum. It brought back all the intrigue and fighting for power from the Robert graves book 'I Claudius'. I think this is my best part of my visit to rome

Palantine hill. We took this as part of the colosseum tour and it was a great day. Lots of walking but a great experience. With the tour guide you get a great understanding of the history and artifacts. This truely is a fantastic area for the history buffs.

Magical time . We went to the Palatine hill in April and had a magical experience. You can walk around it in about and two hour. I would recommend a tour for this or staying around to absorb the environment afterwards. Great site with fantastic views of Rome !

Honeymoon first trip to Rome. Beautiful location right beside Colosseum. The sights this area presented took our breath away and we were totally in awe! Highly recommended for anyone visiting Rome - this is a must see!

Very relaxing to walk around. Went here after visiting the Colosseum, and found it very relaxing to walk around - there aren't as many visitors as other major attractions and there is very little background noise from cars etc. Really enjoyed this as it was nice to just relax and 'bimble' around, taking in all the old ruins and buildings.

Get a map. This is such a LARGE area! Be sure to bring a map and guide with you for this place. So much to see and no directional signs. The info signs are translated from Italian and not very helpful. We loved this place and could have wandered all day, but wished we had more info!

relaxing with lovely views. I loved just wandering around and looking at all the ruins as well as stopping when you get to the top of the hill to appreciate the lovely views of the city.Buying a combo ticket here also means you get to go in a much shorter queue to enter the coliseum.Theres plenty of benches and places to sit so if you have the time bring a picnic and have a relax.

My favourite! Dont Miss the Museum. Even Though it was raining cats and dogs on the day i visited, Palatine Hill was my favorite attraction of all Rome. Take your time and make sure to read about the place before if you are not planning to get a tour guide. If you are going to visit Colosseum and the Romans Forum on the same day I suggest buying your ticket from here. It is far less crowded comparing to Colosseum entrance and you get a very nice view from the hill to the Colosseum too before going inside, also great city views. The Museum is a great compliment to the old castle. But you have to pay separately for it.Like all other attractions I recommend being there the hour it opens up if you are a traveler and not an average tourist.

So peaceful at your own pace. Visited this immediately after the colosseum and the views from the hill give you a sense of what ancient rome would have been like all the ruins of basillicas and temples including that if Romulus.A great place to just take a step back away from all the busy traffic and just embrace Rome for what it is a place of endless culture

A must do. It is probably best to start the tour of the area with Palantine Hill as the first as not only Is the ticket counter much easier to tackle from this point but also gives you a good view of the forum and then you could take the colosseum exit and finishing your entire tour by stopping at colosseum. There is a whole lot of walking and climbing so be prepared for the same.
Lovely. This was one of the easier sites to visit in Rome. The ticket line moved quickly and was a nice casual walk throughout the area.

So much to see. We had a ticket for the Coloseum which was a timed entry. That ticket gave us entry into Palatine Hill. We could have done with more than 2 hours. The views across Rome are spectacular and it's much better organised than the Coloseum.
So much to see and take in. Good information boards around too.

Great history and view. I really enjoyed the tour we did of palatine hill; the history you receive with a good guided tour is amazing, and the views are stunning. Definitely a sight I'd recommend. But be warned! Lots of walking is involved, so if you're with children, or elderly people, just keep in mind that it can really take it out of you at times.

Dont miss it - better than the forum. I actually enjoyed this area more than the forum. Audio guide really worth having. Entrance has no queues, and can then walk down into forum. Best views of forum are from terrace near gardens on hill. Excellent!

Lovely quiet walk, with amazing history. Make sure you visit this, as it is a welcomed break from all the hustle and noise of the main streets. The runs and history are simply amazing and will make you stay for hours.

Spend half a day here. Absolutely worth the walk!!!! You'd be silly to miss this in your itinerary. Much to see and admire. I would advise the guided tour since it's very easy to get lost.Even if you are not a history buff there is a lot of architecture to soak up. It's a botanical garden and ancient ruin hybrid that works.

Some tips to share. To avoid the long line, enter the Palatine from Via dei Fori Imperiale entrance and exit it near the Coliseum. The ticket also includes visiting Coliseum, so later you can go straight to the Coliseum ticket's holders line.

Lovely walk with amazing views. This was a wonderful walk which gave a great insight into how life was then. The remains provide a sense of scale as the site is huge and you could spend a lot of time here if there wasn't so much else to see! Museum is worth a visit

Great place for a picnic. The palatine hill is a good visit. The ruins are interesting. I suupose that being on a hill there was less plunder. the views over rome are the best in rome. The view over the forum is so good that you don't really need to visit it. Also the area where you can see the forum is a great place for a picnic.

Make sure you take a walk around Palatine Hill. We didn't have much time in Rome so elected to just take an unguided walk around Palatine Hill and observe the Roman Forum and Circus Maximus from the perimeter.As a family of four we saved 90 euros doing it this way an we were satisfied that we had seen enough for our level of interest.If you are keen on the full entry option I will emphasise the frequent suggestion to buy your ticket from the palatine hill entrance - this gets you into the colosseum also and the queue is negligible! Just walk past the colosseum entrance past the arch of Constatine and it is on your right.

Worth the Uphill Climb. We happened on a tour that combined with the Colosseum. Fascinating history and overview (pun) of Roman history. The balcony area gives a look over the Roman forum and numerous significant places in Rome. Do know that it is a long trek up stairs to the palace area and a treacherous trip down over ankle threatening stone path. I would not recommend this for infirm, those with breathing problems and those inclined to klutziness. One wrong step could easily mean a twisted ankle.

Lots to see here so good walking shoes needed. This is quite a large area to walk round so make sure you have some good foot ware. I would recommend a guide on a pre booked tour. The queue was over two hours if you just turn up on the day. A guided tour lets you jump the queue and the guide will give you an informed view of what you are looking at whist walking round. And good half day tour.

Going back in a time machine. Amazing place. For everyone, not just history fans. take your time, reserve at least 3 hours for that. If it is sunny be careful as you will be under the Sun and wont even notice. The place is big and there is no cafeteria inside. There are beautiful green spaces so if I go back I would take a sandwich with me and make a pic nic in the middle of the visit. Beautiful views of Rome, incredible place.

PHENOMENAL!. A definite must see! Your ticket to the hill covers 2 days and you should definitely make the most of it as there is LOADS to see if you take your time and soak it all in! An absolute must do! We only spent one day there and I regret that we didnt have longer there. We did however, get a tour that covered the Colosseum and the hill and it was great, it was all day and a great guide who knew SO MUCH about the hill and was an obvious enthusiast for Roman history, it was great.

A must see-preferably on one of your first days in Rome. The Palatine Hill and forum area are what Rome is all about. I urge anyone visiting to make time to walk about this area and soak in the wonderful culture in this location. The ruins are simply breathtaking. It gives a great beginning to the historic core of the city. I am a history teacher back in the US and loved this.

History!!. Enter Palantine hill from west entrance which is less crowded and then walk down towards roman forum. Also, I recommend buying the audio guide . Do visit the palantine meusuem and watch the rome movie which shows reconstructed rome,

A must while seeing the Colosseum and Roman Forum. This is one of the most wonderful and peaceful parts of my journey to Rome. Seeing the sights, the different palaces/residences, and the breathtaking views of the Colosseum and Roman Forum is an absolute must!! Additionally--you will get some great exercise walking around (and up and down the hills).

Truly amazing . Must do. Get a Guide. It's a must do and spend a lot of time in. The ticket is combined with the Colosseum so do both together . Enough place to sit and relax with toilets etc for the breaks and place to lunch in. But definitely get a guide

Eye opening experience. We bought a skip the line ticket which worked well. When we were standing outside the Coleseum we were approached by someone offering a place in s guided tour for €13 each, also including Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum. Bargain! I'm so glad we went for it. It made our day, and helped us to realise what we were looking at.

Great way to have a look at the ancient past of Rome. If the weather is good and the ground is not muddy, the Palatine Hill is a must visit! The area is huge and there are ruins everywhere, reminding us the great past of Rome. The hill offers a great view of the city too. Better take a guided tour to skip the line and learn interesting facts
Ancient and amazing landscape. The Roman Forum it´s a beautiful attraction in Rome, one of the most impressive to see. Totally loved it.

So much history!. We loved climbing up there and seeing the ruins from above. I always research the places I visit so I can impart a little knowledge on my kids and so they walk away knowing what they just looked at. This was no different. And it was well worth it.

Definitely worth having a guide. A great place to explore and immerse yourself in the history of Rome and its politics.
I would highly recommend having a guide as much of Palatine Hill is now ruins. Our guide told us about each building and its importance, which made the trip much more worthwhile. The views from the top are breathtaking.

SEE HOW WELL THEY LIVED 2000 YEARS AGO. The Palantine or Palace is located next to and up the hill from the coliseum is very large area to see. There were many places that we were not allowed to go into because of new underground excavations, but you get a good idea of the size of the palace and how well they lived

Amazing! A must see while in rome!. We were not planning on going here but it was part of the ticket we had to visit the colosseum and I am so glad we did. There was so much to see and the views from the top of the hill were breath taking! I did not know so much of the ancient Roman ruins were still there to see! The kids enjoyed exploring and the little museum was very interesting too.

Take a guide!. Not alot of information around up there, so a guide, or a good downloaded guide book or something would be a great help to understand what everything is and a bit of the history behind it. Having said that, we really enjoyed it, and also took our lunch in and sat on the grass under a tree and enjoyed the peace and quiet away from all the annoying people trying to sell you selfie sticks!

Wonderful to Explore. This is a great place to explore, we didn't do a guided tour just strolled round at our own pace. Marked it down slightly as there was nowhere to get refreshments and the place is so big it takes a good hour or so to walk round - we were there almost 3 hours. So if you plan to go for a stroll round, bring plenty of water.

Must See While In Rome. This is a must for visitors to Rome. Palatine Hill IS Ancient Rome and is located next to the Collesseum and Roman Forum. This is a beautiful experience so take time to let your imagination fill in the blanks. So much to see as this is where the emperors lived. We found a bathroom just at the entrance. Excellent attraction that is well kept and monitored for security.

Multiple historical structures or ruins collectively seen here, but important settlement location as per history. This is one of the most important places of historical Rome. As per history the Roman settlement happened here in the early years. Accordingly you will find all the important buildings around this place starting from the temples where they used to worship to important government buildings where the major discussions were held. Also small wars had been fought here based on enmity between rival rulers. You need to visualize the settings here 2000 years ago and you could feel those people still walking around you or the perfect structures still standing in front of you with the advanced architecture. Make sure you follow some documentaries on this place before you visit and you will love this place more. With Roma Pass you do not need to buy ticket and can go straight inside.

My favorite attraction in Rome!!. This was my favorite attraction that we visited in Rome. It was so beautiful and historical. Walking through the ruins was such a unique experience and it was so hard to imagine what it was like back in the day. There is a beautiful view of the city from the top of the Hill. There is also a beautiful garden up there, which we did not expect to see while roaming the ruins. This is a big location and takes up a good portion of the day. We stayed for over 2.5 hours (combined with Roman Forum). Most of the buildings have a plaque on them to tell you what they were used for. A MUST see in Rome!

Yet another must see in Rome. I really can't imagine visiting Rome without the Palatine Hill, one simply needs to see the ruins it to better realize the astonishing history of the ancient Rome. The view on the city from the hill is also great, definitely worth seeing.

enormous, so much to see. allow a lot of time to roam around this site, so much history and beauty to see, buy combo ticket. We did Colosseum, Roman Forum on same day as right next to each other. Pace yourself to enjoy the experience

So many vantage points. There are so many ways to see the ruins here. From on high you get amazing views and vistas that capture your imagination. Then you can walk around and be dwarfed by the magnificence of it all. Remembering that people walked here over 2000 years ago

Another Top Ten of Rome to see. Enter with a fee not far from the Colosseum. Linger and stroll all day until closing. Photos opportunities everywhere and up on the hill, a great view of ancient Rome.
Nice gardens and exquisite ruins.

Breathtaking but.... ... A battle to get there - every where you turn someone is trying to sell you a selfie stick or some other crap, and they won't leave you alone until you shout at them. Very disappointing seeing as this is supposed to be the most romantic city in the world - how can you be romantic when your being hounded by an illegal immigrant every couple of minutes?In most places my girlfriend pronounced things in Italian which most staff didn't seem to care for. I personally avoided doing that, but the one time I did try I was made to fell very small by an inbred looking waiter in Travestre (avoid that place as well), as he leant over my table in his vile restaurant and tried to make me pronounce every syllable as if I was a child. Such a shame what this beautiful city is - full of hawkers and locals who don't appreciate what tourism does for the city they let go to ruin.

Palatine Hill. The visit was great with good views and interesting information. The only problem a strike by workers who locked the gates for about a hour and no one could enter. They tend to do this on Fridays, so avoid Fridays to visit.

3 in one. Roman Forum, Palatine Hill and Colosseum are covered under the same ticket. Palatine Hill is over twice the size of the Roman Forum, and I would recommend you allow twice the time to explore.We went to the colosseum first (8.30am) doing the underground tour. We then entered vis the Palatine Hill entrance, about 11am, Q of only 15 people, there are also toilets at this entrance.There were no maps for sale, fortunately we used our phone to get maps, so would recommend looking for a map before going.We spent a quick 90 mins and only saw 75% of what could be seen, we could have spent another 90 mins there.I would recommend going here before the Roman Forum as you are above, looking down and get a better idea of scale when you descend.Look out for the first houses (huts) to start Rome, plenty information boards everywhere, plenty drinking fountains also so carry a bottle to fill up along the way.

Beautifull!!. The Palatino is the best to do in Rome! It is far less crowded then the Forum Romanum, but much more beautifull, with great views over the city, and à lot of space. When you go during the day it is smart to take some food and drinks along. There are a lot places for a nice picknick.
Absolutely loved it.. This and the forum were my highlights of Rome. So much cool architecture to see. Took so many amazing pictures. Definitely a can't miss place to visit when in the city.

A nice place to wander around. A nice place to escape the bussle of Rome for a few hours. Audio guides are offered at the entrance for an additional fee, but is very factual and uninspiring. Good for school parties who are studying Rome, but not engaging for the holiday visitor. As with the Colosseum, there is minimal signage and nearly no information available about what you are looking at, except for the hired audio guide, or if you are part of a tour. It is a large area and takes a good 2-3 hours to see, if you want to take it all in. The worst part is that there is absolutely NO catering offered within the site! If you are with small children who need to eat, then you will be forced to cut your visit short. We asked nicely, and the security allowed my wife to exit briefly to purchase snacks from the over-priced burger van outside and we picnicked in the grounds. It was unclear whether picnics were allowed. I feel like the gardeners tolerated picnics from the few people who had food with them, but I can imagine that it can quickly get out of hand and this is probably why they do not offer food for sale within the site. Overall, and nice visit, but I would take some food and plan to spend the whole day there if you want to see it properly.

One of the BEST Photo Opportunities in all of Rome!. What a wonderful place to take pictures. After climbing to the top of the hill you can see much of the center of Rome from the Coliseum to the Roman Forum. This is a must-see attraction in Rome and the ticket for the Coliseum gets you into the Palatine Hill at no additional charge.

Very interesting place. Totally recommend Palatine Hill. It's so rich in history and has beautiful views of Rome.
I definitely would recommend that you buy a ticket that gives you access to the Roman Forum, Palatine Hill plus Colosseum that cost €12 which is great value for money
Amazing. Stunning place makes you realise what a beautiful place this was as even today it's stunning to us it was mind boggling and really enjoyed it.

Palatine Hill. Nice view of the surrounding city and lots of interesting information. We had an amazing guide through Viator.com, and did enjoy this site. If you have the time, it's worth it, but I personally would spend more time at the Colosseum or Roman Forum.

Don't miss Palatine Hill Museum. When wandering around Palatine Hill, make sure to go to the museum. It's included in the price of entry so it doesn't cost you anything extra. The museum is very modern with beautiful art, but it's a little small and the layout doesn't flow very well-- so if there are throngs of people it would be difficult to see the exhibits. Don't miss the beautiful angel's wings. If you stand in front of it you can get a really cool photo.

Boring. This place was fantastic however it really left a lot to the imagination as to the significance of this place I feel that some interactive electronic displays as well as some models to show how the place was originally build and the scale of it would go along way to helping us understand better

Palatine Hill. Part of the tour we booked with the colosseum helped to skip the line, again, nice to have background information of the lives of people who lived there to put things in perspective. we appreciated the opportunity to walk around and see what we wanted to see following the tour overview.

Mind boggling. . To imagine that this palace rose to nearly twice the height of the Colosseum from these foundations is incredible. The form and construction is so perfect that it looks as if it is a modern design. I wish we had pictures of it in all its beauty.

Must see when you visit Colosseum. It is fairly close to Colosseum, and it is a must see the day that you go to Colosseum.Remember to bring water if it is a hot day, it is a nice long walk, but always better to be hydrated, because there are not so many shadows.

Okay but not much to see. The area was nice to walk around and the view of the city is nice but not amazing. We paid the 'three in one' pass so we saw the forum and Colosseum as well. Worth it for the price of all three but these are more "see it because everyone will ask" than because it's that wonderful to see.

Aweseome. You should already know that one ticket gets you into the Colosseum, Forum and Palatine. Be aware that the last two are physically connected, so once you are in, you are in for the long haul. I didn't realize that until we were at the gate, and it was almost lunchtime. We did enter at Palatine where the iine was much shorter than the Forum line. There is a LOT to see on Palatine which I didn't realize. It's really amazing and you have to have a decent city guide to help you out. I got Rick Steves from the library and it is TERRIBLE. Anyway, the views are great and the history is mind-boggling. Down the hill, you then are in the Forum area. Properly seen, these will take at least a few hours.
Interesting ruins.... If history is your thing,then plenty is here. Though you often wish thieves,churches, vandals and barbarians had left us more to look at.. Take plenty of water.

Enjoy the walk... and take in the wonderful views of Rome and the Ruins, we did it without a guide and just enjoyed the ambience. I would also suggest doing the Colosseum first then take time to walk the grounds.
Peaceful, interesting and worth a visit. We visited after the colloseum and spent a very pleasant couple of hours exploring. Wonderful views of the city

Awesome and historical. Part of the forum, used to be the center of government, just an awesome place to walk to and to overlook the colliseum and the forum. As with most of Rome, have a guidebook to tell you what you are looking at and the historical significance of it. That will make it extra special.

Amazing place to visit. Entry is included with your ticket to the Colosseum and the Forum an it's well worth a visit. We did it without a guide which means you don't know exactly what you are looking at half the time, however it's lovely and relaxing walking around the hill and you get some great views.

A must see. Although i am not a history expert, this place is just amaamazing. Take some time with you, the area is huge.And if you have some good weather, you can als take a nap. This place is also great if you search for a quieter place...than go on the side with the palace.

An amazing sight to behold. Tip, if seeing the colosseum buy a ticket online (Roma pass I think) to allow access to Palantine hill too. Do the colosseum first and upon exit walk towards the back of the colosseum to palatine hill near the old viaduct ruins. This is a shorter, shallower climb to the top of the hill where you look over the remaining ruins and Rome. It's amazing what they built and how they lived and the infrastructure in place 2000 years ago. My husband and my 4 year old found it fascinating too. If you don't like crowds or extreme heat then mid season is ideal to visit.

What an experience!. We visited Rome on our honeymoon and Palatine Hill and the Roman forum were second on our list (Vatican City was #1) of great places to visit. The history of this area is so rich an deep that could literally spend 2 or 3 days walking about there soaking in everything. We did it briskly in about 6 hours. We ordered our tickets in advance (I strongly recommend this) and it was a bundle that included access to the Colosseum and the Roman Forum.

Lovely place. Allow for time, should be enjoyed slowly. Such a relaxing experience walking around the ruins, although I wasn't there for romantic reasons, I would suggest it to be a wonderful place to spend time with your nearest and dearest.

Walk as the Romans once did.. A guided tour is a must. There is very little information around. Allow at least 2 hours around here. Lots of steps and bumpy roads to navigate. Some really nice ruins to see and a great view from the top.
Ancient and historical. Make sure you have enough time to visit, very interesting spot, a great smell of ancient roman civilization and history, worth the whole walk.
Nice Photo Ops. Worth the walk and the hike to get the nice photo ops of the hill, and the sites, and the Forum! Early in the morning has less people crowding around the area.

Underwhelming. We had read good things about Palentine Hill, but when we got up there, it didn't seem like there was much to see, and we were on a guided tour. Also there was no good view, which is something we expected.

Ancient Hostiry Buff???????. If you are and have read up on this then it's quite the area to walk around and use your imagination about what went on there. If you're not then I think you'll have a quick look and keep on walking...So many of these old monuments are great to see and admire BUT you have to be a History buff of Ancient Rome. Otherwise, you'll see lots of brick walls, ceilings, half destroyed marble statues and columns and most likely will get bored. Hit the museums instead. HOWEVER, for fans of Ancient History, ROME is a must see and study, walk around and TAKE YOUR TIME to admire their building skills for palaces, meeting rooms, temples, statues, baths etc etc etc.
How the half? lived. Have not been since they opened the new museum.Everything clearly marked and fascinating.New museum excellent.

Roman Sites Outdoor Walking. Bring your Camera!. We walked in this area for hours. Fascinating and thrilling. Open air. Great views and vistas. Lots of picutres were taken here. Safe and secure walking at the time which was one day in early March 2015 and few tourists compared to the hordes in summer months. I highly recommend off-season touring in Rome.

Do you have good imagination? :). Do you have good imagination? :)It is a bit confusing but if you could get one of that maps from the suposed original forum and palatine maybe you can get an idea where and how buildings were.I would say that it is a mandatory place in Rome to visit but get some comfortable shoes first. :)
Palatine my favorite!!!. visit Rome , the best way to start is the Palatine Hill and relax viewing what you see in front of you, the Coliseum , the Forum, is the best way to start....

Favourite Part of Rome!. This was my favourite site to visit in Rome and probable could have been even better with a guide or better guide book. I bought a guide book from the Colosseum bookshop but could have picked a better one with more pictures. Mine was informative enough to get me through and it wasn't expensive either. We spent about 4 hours (easy) touring all the different ruins trying to figure out the palace and what it would have looked like. I'm a huge ancient history lover so it was tons of fun for me. There were a decent amount of signs around the palace area which was nice. Best part had to be the water fountains that were everywhere, which were so convenient to fill your water bottles up. We went in December so it wasn't too hot, but I could see how in the summer months you could want lots of water and good clothes since you'll be exposed to the sun for most of the day. It never felt crowded since the hill is so big which was nice. There are bathrooms around the hill and maps all around to point you in the right direction. For non history buffs, a couple of hours should be enough to get a good idea of the hill and its importance in Roman History. The price in included with your Colosseum ticket!

Gorgeous vistas . Palatine hill is connected to the roman forum and is right outside the colosseum. It's the site of the ancient palaces of the roman emperors. The ruins of the place are beautiful, and there are lots of gardens. There are some great spots with views of the forum and the surrounding parts of the city. There is also a free museum of artifacts found on the site. A couple of pieces of advice. Try and get a map; we didn't, and it was confusing to get around because it's so extensive and there are a lot of twists and turns. Also wear comfy shoes, because it's all cobblestone paths and it's a lot of walking.

Try one of the guided tours if offered while in line!. Obviously this is a must see if you are in Rome, but I thought Id share our experience to maybe help save some time. We showed up around 9 am and there was already a long line that we were not able to skip, even with our Roma Pass. A young American asked us if we wanted to take a tour for $10 that would allow us to skip the line, his company was called Royal Crown tours. The tour was informative and we learned a lot about both Palatine Hill, the Coliseum and the Forum that I feel we wouldn't have learned had we not taken the tour. It isn't very long but its only $10 a person so you get what you pay for. A warning, we were taking the stairs up to Palatine Hill when two men tried to pick pocket my wife and I. I suppose they are all over but keep your head on a swivel.

Disappointing . I love sightseeing and learning ancient history. All the hype about people recommending to see these structures made me go and see them for myself. After waiting in line for a bit. I was disappointed. Just ruins. At least Venice and Florence had proper complete structures worth taking pictures and imagine to live in the moment. Here just big rocks and gravel. Next time I think people should check pictures on the internet and than decide if this is something they want to see.
great views. We spent about an hour and a half here. It is worth the time to go through and enjoy the scenery. good place to take photos.
So nice!. For me, one of the better things to do/see when in rome. It was nice, calm and quiet. Some great things to see and gives a nice view over the forum
