Not to be missed on any trip to Rome!. What more can be said. The eternal heart of the eternal city lies in the Colosseum and old Rome. Hugh crowds, any day of the year. If you are short on time, pass on the Colosseum (it is really more grand from the outside) and spend time walking through the Roman forum area and Palatine hill. The memories will last a lifetime. And watch the cheesy "gladiators" - they tend to be friendly when you are called to have your pics taken with them... but get testy if you only offer 1 or 2 euros. They want 4 or 5! But between them and the guys selling smartphone "selfie sticks" will drive you nuts!

great 3 hour tour. A very interesting historical tour led by an enthusiastic and knowledgeable guide. 3 hours outside walk so may not be so good on a rainy day but as we had good weather it was wonderful. not suitable for wheelchairs, buggies or the infirm.
Full Access!. We had full access to the main floor, including the second floor. This was not included on our last trip here We had a great time.
Stunning. This place is absolutely stunning and would recommend anyone coming to Rome to visit this beautiful place!

Introducing a 5 yr old to the Romans. My son is not a history buff, but by having a child's history book that explained the life of the Romans while walking around, it came to life for him and he was very interested.
Ancient Rome. My favorite part of our trip. I love the stories behind the ancient ruins. Can almost imagine wandering through the magnificent era.
great. very interesting, followed round rick steves guide full of info and made it exciting. Go to Palatine hill to make sure you miss the queues (when getting a ticket)

Brilliant. Book your tickets online before you visit as the queues are HUGE, well worth seeing, we loved it here as its steeped in history. Watch the men dressed as gladiators outside touting for photos, yes the pics are funny but ended up costing us 20 quid!

History lessons live!. Your feet would hurt, your body would ache, but this part of Ancient Rome is definitely a must see. You need to read up on Ancient history to understand why these buildings are as it is now and what it was during those times when it was built and used by Ancient Romans.

Historical excellence. Great visits to these sites, learning lots and seeing history come to life. Thoroughly enjoyed our visit to these landmarks, and learnt so much more than history books have taught us in the past.

How about a map or something guys?. This is our second visit in 18 months, first with a guide this time on our own with Rick Steves audio app to guide us.Negatives...12.50€ with no little guide or pamphlet...nope nothing is a little rich.For crying out loud put up a few more signs up saying what's what. I saw a lot people looking a bit bewildered.Leave your nice shoes at home ladies because this is a pretty hard place for heels I can tell you. Large gaps in the paving stones, I'm suprised no one has snapped an ankle. Time for some maintenance on the walk ways!Tips...Palatine Hill is the best part I reckon, along with the museum hiddened at the back.You need 3 hours here to take the whole place in.Make sure you visit the Musei Capitolini to get the full picture.

Fantastic. The Roman authorities have done a fantastic job in controlling the access to the Foro Romano and using the proceeds from ticket sales to improve the signage, information and pedestrian routes. Visiting this area is a fantastic experience and not to be missed.
Great place to visit. So much history here. Very nice experience. Booked the tickets online and skipped the line which was hugeeeeee.

Great Sight. Well the point of any visitor in Rome...ancient history and culture in front of you. Great start to beggin explore the Rome. Nice point near to metro station. Early the morning is better to see or to photo this monument...

Avoid the Goofy Gladiators. We visited with children and our pal Rick Steves (in pocket guidebook form) - love the self guided tour for the highlights of the sites. Steer clear of the goofy gladiators, they can be fun but charge a high ransom for your camera! You can purchase a combo ticket for both the colosseum and the forum.

Must see - representative of Rome & the Romans!. You can pick up a guided tour in different languages on the outside if you want to avoid the queue (pay around 25 euros which includes entrance to Colosseum and Palatine Hill. Approx 3 hour tour). Fascinating place with lots of photo opportunities!

An amazing Full day experience in Central Rome. A visit to Italy must include the visit to the Roman forum and the colosseum. Make sure to buy your tickets in advance online or in the Forum entrance - you would save dear time in that - instead of waiting hours in the entrance to the colosseum. Begin in the Colloseum - finish early, and go to the Forum - where you can enjoy all day long (at least 1 day ).

Awe inspiring. To state the obvious this is one of the most important historical sites in the world. I found it very interesting but it was also very hot on a July day and my teens were ready to go after a couple of hours or so. Strongly recommend either a guide, purchasing the audio tour or downloading a tour before you arrive. As others have mentioned some of the building sites are basically a pile of rocks that do not have much meaning until you hear the story behind what you are witnessing (other buildings, however, are in very good shape considering their age) so some type of guidance will greatly enhance the experience.We went in high season and this was part of the two day advance combo ticket that also provided entrance to the Colosseum. STRONGLY suggest the advance pass as you will avoid very long lines.If in Rome...be sure to visit.

WOW!. You need to give yourself enough time when visiting these attractions. I was amazed by it's history. I wished I had read about it prior to visiting the place as there is so much to take in after listening to our tour guide, who was excellent and very knowledgeable at what she did.There was a lot of walking, stopping, looking, photo-taking but not enough time for toilet breaks. Get the first-hand experience and relive what once was the centre of Rome.

Three is a crowd. To look at these places in half a day is too much and exhausting. In order to appreciate what you see and remember the highlights of these places, one needs to take the time when visiting all three. These are the icons of Rome and therefore one of a kind.

Visit in the morning and don't rush. We went with a tour group and this was one of the sites that was covered by the tour. We started with the Colosseum, then the Roman Forum and had the Palatine Hill last. By the time we reached this place, we were exhausted and therefore were no longer able to concentrate on what was said and shown to us. It was also getting too hot in the afternoon which made it worse. The place is truly magnificent. Try to picture the hill how it was once before. Read about it beforehand. This will help you understand more about the history and the old remains of the sites you are visiting. We had a great guide but sometimes when the 4-hour tour can be very exhausting. Take lots of photos. Make sure you bring water and wear comfortable shoes as you go through the old Roman roads and climb steps can wear you down. A visit to the toilet is very handy before you enter the Palatine Hill.

A favorite from our week in Rome. The forum is really amazing and Palatine Hill is beautiful. The history here speaks for itself? It must-because as a "museum" it is lacking! A tour book is absolutely necessary if you want to really learn or appreciate the history. The signage could be so much better! The history is there, museum execution so sad. Late November-wow, no crowds, great views, perfect temperatures.
GREAT. This area housed old big palaces.You need sometime to spend here walking around enjoying them.Spend enough time.here.
Ancient Rome. Seemed crowded even in October, but weather was perfect. Can't imagine the crowds in summer. Must ride a 2 deck bus on the top deck for a great tour easy on the feet.

A definite must see!. Our family booked a tour outside of the colosseum for the colosseum and the Roman Forum and Palentine Hill was included "free" with a student from the US working on his degree...what an amazing area! I had visited the area before and never knew what those hills were hiding! There is so much to see in that area and the history is unbelievable!! I would highly recommend finding a tour guide to help navigate through this area....fabulous!

Gives you a real impression of the scale and grandeur of ancient Rome. None of the pictures in guide books etc give you any idea of the massive size of this site. We walked across the Circus Maximus, looking up to the Palatine hill from which the emporers could look down onto the chariot races. Although the palaces were denuded of their marble by the papal architects in the 1500s and left to rot you can still get an idea of their splendour and size, particularly after seeing the exhibitions inside the excellent little museum inside the site. We continued past the outline of the original Romulus hut and down towards the forum and the Senate. Wow. To see where Cicero spoke....well you get the picture. Such a great place to visit. One word of warning, as they don't have any cafe etc inside the site we came out a bit in need of nourishment and almost fell onto the first van as you exit....don't! He didn't have an easily visible price list and was a rip off, although backed down on being challenged.

Historic !!. History of Rome echoes here, its a must see place in Rome of course but I must say if you read colosseum history before going you ll enjoy/feel more when visitng. As for a sight seeing its a boring place but if you want to feel the history then its good place to be. So a bit knowledge about the place is highly recommended .

Awesome. We had a private tour with the best guide, Francesca. She was quite knowledgeable and had a book and photos to accompany her stories. She spent 3 ½ hours showing us all 3 areas, plus Circus Maximus.
Do the underground tour worth the money. In my The underground, Palatine and Roman forum is the tour to take. you get to go into areas you won't see on any other tours.

Most beautiful place I've ever visited. Been to Berlin, Paris and Rome. I visited all the main attractions and this was definitely the most beautiful of them all. If you are lucky to go on a beautiful blue sky day you are going to feel like you are in a dream inside this place, especially on the top of the Palatine Hill... very wonderful.
History on tap. History everywhere but a lot of walking. Obviously the Palatine Hill is a hill so be prepared for a climb!

Must visit. Again, no introduction needed for this site, now combined in a single entrance fee. Yes, for the clarification, Roman Forum is no longer free. Since, most people visited Colosseum and you already paid for other two sites, why not visit. In my opinion, Palatine Hill is the one many tourists overlook. You can have excellent view of Colosseum and rest of Rome from the hill and there are many ruins, palace on the hill as well.In order to reduce the distress many tourists suffered, I’d like to recommend following to Italian Tourism Ministry.1) Although Italy as a whole is very friendly and welcoming tourists, there are many websites posing as “official.” They overcharge entrance fees, tickets and worse, you cannot get actual tickets when you arrive. Another scam is they gave wrong information like you need entrance fee on everything although some sites are free. Since, one need to register even to use free wifi at airport in Italy and rest of Europe. So why don’t they take actions on those scammers giving a bad name to Italy.2) Need to punish “greedy” gladiators. Very well-known trip to target naïve tourists who did not do homework. Yes, those tourists should indeed blame themselves more for being idiots but gladiators should also be punished if they threaten to get like 100 euros. May be 10 euros should be like a maximum and once gladiators cross a line, tourists should be able to inform some policeman to take action.
HISTORY. This is the old Roman city.This had the market shops and temples.Its worth a visit.Its in the main tourist area and walking distance to the others.

A must when in Rome. This is a must on the to see list, we got in free with our Roma pass. Have to say it was much smaller than I expected I suppose I must have been influenced by what I seen in the movies rather than real life. All in all a good trip out. Id of struggled to spend more than an hour here though

A must in Rome . You can't go to Rome and not see this place! Very grand and really let's you imagine life in roman times. Lots of walking!!!Uneven ground and limited shade so bare this in mind when planning your trip

Worth a visit!. Definitely worth a visit. Amazing history and beautiful area to walk around and explore. Will take at least half a day - take your time and enjoy. We opted for the audio guide which I would recommend as a minimum so you understand what you're seeing. In hindsight a splurge on a guided tour would have been good - following an excellent guided your experience at the colosseum. Lovely in December - not too many people.
GREAT. This area has the best of old Rome.The great fights are held here.The old blood sport arena.The comfort for the fans and luxury for the rulers.
Rome Tours. Guides were excellent and well versed in Roman history and Vatican history. Great time of year to travel to Rome.
A must see when visiting Rome. One of Rome's most famous sites. Loved it! We were lucky to visit in December so pretty quiet. Easy to get around and had great views.

Thrilling. Thrilling to see the devastated Roman structures.
The structures they have built, the sculptures, carvings.. and much more.
Goose Bumps. Ny Latin Student must get goose bumps as they stand and walk in this ancient historic area !!! A Tour Guide added to the awareness & feel of the area !!!

Colosseum, Forum and Palletine Hill 2 day pass definitely worth it. If you are in Rome, get this pass as it covers you for 2 days. Fantastic examples of ancient Rome at it's best. I bought a book in the shop beforehand that gives information about these places as they were back in time, each picture has an overlap to show you what they looked like back in the day, a great thing to have while you're exploring the ruins as it helps to understand it all.

Historical!. I love historical attractions. And the roman history is legendary. The queue to get in colosseum is long, however there are people selling "fast-track" tickets, which also can get you in to Forum Romanum to a cheaper price and faster. This is where you have to be careful. There might be a goodlooking perfectly englishspeaking guy selling you the tickets, and when everything is settled, he shows you to your group -which could be a group of a guide who thinks he is funny, and simply ruins the whole trip, because he is moody and you simply dont understand a word he is saying. You just want to leave. However, if you want to get in forum romanum, you havr to stick to the group. What to do? Walk around by yourself, take your pictures, but keep limited distance from your guide, so you still can get in to the Forum. Otherwise, it really. Was interesting, despite the cheaters
What else?. How can anything 2000 years old with all we know about it be bad? Well, it would be if you are not on a paid tour. The lines are horrendous

Fascinating. Visiting Rome in December has the huge advantage of missing the crowds. However, I do suggest booking entrances on-line before you go, thus jumping the queues, and have an English-speaking guide or audio-guides everywhere if you want to get the most out of your visit. We had not booked a guide for the Palatine Hill and were therefore somewhat confused as to what was what. Ditto the Forum.

Historic. You cant miss seeing the Roman Forum and the Palantine Hill. If I had to do it again, I would more than likely skip doing the Palatine Hill and just visit the Forum again. It really is amazing to see the ruins that are still freestanding and envisioning all of the important buildings that were once still fully intact within the center of the city of Rome. With such amazing buildings you try and imagine what it would be like as a citizen back in time. Before traveling to Rome I would recommend buying a guidebook on Rome or spend the Euros and join a tour so you can get the complete experience.

Don't miss any of these sites. Get a good guide, even if you have to pay extra for one, to give you the incredible history of this wonderful area. Much to see, lots of walking. Bring water for the forum and Palatine Hill. Don't miss the newly opened Nero's Palace...its a wonderful view into the life of an emperor and his wife. Fascinating architecture.

A Must See Attraction!. This tour needs to be done with a guide to understand the history of a structure that was used to entertain and execute countless people and animals in Rome. The sheer amazement that such a barbaric society existed in Rome that had no respect for human life or animals is bind blowing.Seeing how the outer layers of walls removed over time due to decay adds a good visual in seeing how well and intricate this coliseum was built. What is amazing and moving is the huge Cross that stands on the main platform which brought down not only the pagan government of Rome, but was the force behind ending the evil threats against humans and beasts for entertainment purposes. A christian power that today stands as a testimony to the power and truth behind the Christian faith in Rome.
A must see. I know that those sites lost a little bit of their charm due to hordes of tourists, but they’re still completely mind-blowing and a must see places when you visit Rome

Take your time here. I recommend spending a bit of time to read about the ruins while you are there. We used the Rough Guide book. If you just look at stuff it looks like old ruins but if you read what they are it is much more fun. We didn't pay extra for the Augustine house tour but I wish we had. The tunnel is good as are the old walled garden bits. Great views from the top.

Pieces of History. If you are here during the busy season I would suggest buying your ticket somewhere other than the Colosseum as the lines can get quite large. When we were here in the beginning of December lines were very short.The tickets will cost you 12 Euro which is not bad to be able to view everything at a decent price.Make sure you have a good portion of your day free (at last 2 or 3 hours) so you can wonder around. Just be aware of the people out side of each location trying to sell you things.

Great places to visit. Of course you feel the aura of the ancient history, the awe of being in such an old place, the curiosity about what was like to live in those periods, marveling at what should have been like to be innovative....

Puts Human Nature into Perspective. Pomp? Spectacle? Show-offy riches and meglomania? These sites are proof that the times and places change, but human nature stays the same. If there is one historical site in Rome that is a must-see, this is it. We tromped around a long morning but still couldn't really take it all in. Bring a lot of energy, water, something to nibble (almost nothing to buy), and some kind of explanation to make sense of what you're seeing, like an audio guide. This site is too big and tiring for small children.

Not to be confused with Emperor Palpatine. My biggest regret about/Palatine Hill is that I wasn't able to really concentrate as much as I'd like and take it all in. I had done some reading in a Rick Steves Guide beforehand, which I'd also brought along - so I knew what some of the main points of interest were. However, I also had my toddler strapped to me and that interfered a little with the reading along. There was a lot here, more than I could take in! This place is best savored. By the time we got here, we were pretty tired out from the Colosseum and the Forum, so we didn't see the museum or all of the sites that were here.Of interest here are the ruins of the Imperial Palace (quite sobering to see site of the former throne - was once the seat of the most powerful Empire on earth and is now basically a field with wildflowers and some crumbling remains), a view of Circus Maximus. This hill is also the legendary site where Remus and Romulus supposedly washed up. If you don't do some homework beforehand (or get a good guide), you'll likely be a bit confused and wonder what's so important about all these old remains. Even now I'm finding out things that I missed and wish I'd paid more attention to!We forgot water bottles - it was October, so thankfully not as bad as it could have been, but still pretty rough. There are fountains throughout the place, but they are very hard to drink from without a bottle. Tickets to the Colosseum/Roman Forum include this site, so don't overlook it!
Ancient history. Ancient history up close. The pictures don't do it justice. Watch out for the gladiators! Unless you're happy to pay for the privilege.

Amazing. Walking through ancient Rome is a fascinating experience. One imagines life 2000 years ago. The site is huge, many features are well preserved. It's also worth going to the baths a little further south.

Must see. This is definitely a must see when in Roma. Spectacular structure. Be prepared for hundreds of people walking around. Go with sufficient time. Great photo opportunity.During my visit the front side was under maintenance.

Amazing History. Amazing place. Allow plenty of time to look around and well worth booking a full tour before you go (not off the people outside). Watch out for people selling selfie sticks and of course pick pockets if it's busy.
So much history!!!!. I really loved this place. It was very crowded but the staff managed to move people along. Once inside I was mesmerized by this amazing culture. Its a must see

Free Views from the Outside. Avoid the costly entrance fee and appreciate the majestic ruins whilst walking around the fenced area. As the forum is outdoors, all you're missing out on is looking at the textures in detail and the information boards on the grounds. Why not save yourself some money and download an audio guide (it's less conspicuous than holding a travel guide).

For the basic Rome experience. This place is probably on your list of must-sees, and if you can join a good tour group or if you're just into this sort of thing and will read up on the ruins preserved here, the Palatine Hill can be a pleasant and interesting way to spend 1-1.5 hours. If, on the other hand, you're just not so interested in Roman ruins, don't pressure yourself to be. To be honest, I was kind of bored here and only went because it was part of the basic Rome experience. And I like history.

Walking on Sacred Ground. This walk on cobbled, uneven ground is not easy for anyone who has difficulty with mobility, but it is a place to take your time, step easy, and soak in the fact that you are standing in the birthplace of democracy as we know it (in USA, at least). I highly recommend that you purchase one of the widely available books with plastic layovers, so that you can compare what you actually see with the view in ancient times. Otherwise, I would find a guided tour, because sometimes, you see a non-nondescript building or a pile of rocks, but you will appreciate it so much more if you know what was there long ago.
Go and behold history. One of the best preserved ruins in Rome and available tours electronic or personal reasonable entry fees.
Just amazing!!. I have no words to express my feelings during the visit and my only regret is that due to lack of time I could not get in to Colosseum. I do recommend you to book in advance the visit

A must see!. Wow, loved our afternoon visiting this ancient site. We took an English tour which we found to be very informative. The queues were not long in Dec and the site, although bustling, did not feel overly full. We were able to see all we wanted to and took some lovely pictures

Guided tour added so much. Really worth adding on the 5 euros for a guided tour - we were 2 in a group of just 4 with an archaeology professor who brought everything to life. The ticket also covers the Forum and Palatine Hill - the former is lovely to wander through, the latter is massive and needs more labelling!
Must get a guide. Just join a tour group there. Don't bother people booking. Plenty of guides selling their services. Would be hollow without the richness of historical knowledge to bring it to life.

Good day. Visited colosseum and palatine hill today, the colosseum was ok but walked over to the palatine hill to see what was what, had a pleasant surprise the veiws were stunning and you got a lot more information about Roman life and times, from the top of the hill you can see most of the city and even the colosseum from a different angle. There is a museum hiding up there as well, it's worth a visit.

Great way to look at the development of the city. We went in here first before the Colosseum because the queues were short, and we spent a good two hours, and would have spent longer if the weather had been better. The whole complex is vast, and not very well signposted as you go round, but there are some amazing structures, and there is a film on view in the Palatine Museum which gives a fascinating overview of the way the Plataine Hill palace complexes developed over the centuries. There is a lot of walking, and it is very easy to get lost. Well worth the effort, though.

Don't Miss It!!!. You can't go to Rome and miss this -- one word, Unbelievable! You can easily spend days touring these areas. But if you only have a day, it's doable. I've been to Rome three times and have visited these areas every time. It makes a history lesson come alive. Hire a guide if you can, I recommend Show Me Italy, they are fantastic.

Regal. Yes it is old, yes it only has a few bits of buildings left but this is Ancient Rome, it has lasted longer than most modern buildings, it is also the place where the Emperors lived, where the city held court and where the Vestal Virgins lived. An amazing piece of history which needs to be imagined as it once was, a fantastic place to visit, if walls could talk etc etc. It was the place that 'buzzed' all those years ago, the place where Nero had his statue. There are original pieces of road, which you can still walk along whilst gazing at Constantine's Arch, we took a guided tour with viator and the 3 hours was filled with so many details and information, I came away with a different view of Rome, a must see!

Fabulous, even in the rain. We didn't pick that best of days, but when you have to do Rome quickly, you get what you can. Umbrellas in hand, we spent a GREAT day in the area. We did the Rick Steves' Audio Tour and learned a lot (though the tour of the Forum had us coming and going, since landmarks weren't as clear as we needed them to be). At the end of our afternoon we headed to the Capitoline Museum dining room for what I was told would be one of the best views in Rome. While gray skies and mist obstructed the view, it was a delightful break from trekking around in the rain

Must see. If in Rome this place needs to be seen. It is stunning outside and amazing inside. The history painted inside is so interesting, you can picture the "games" taking place, imagine yourself as a spectator and look over the entire site in awe from the highest level. It is also an amazing experience to stand in the place that you have seen on tv, photos and books for years.

Nice Amount of History on One Ticket. Fairly inexpensive site, worth seeing. It would be good to catch either a tour or get an audioguide. Lots of history behind this area and a lot to learn. Only hard part is ticket allows one entrance and the whole thing takes time. Bring a snack if you are likely to get hungry.

Very good sight. I t was great to see such famous landmarks, would have been nicer if they were cheaper though. As we are newly graduates, and thus poor, so when your excited to see a sight, turn up and have to pay, its not great. But still lovely, and you can peak though fences :)
Great historic place. Great historic place. Great spot to take pictures. easy to access. Plenty of sightseeing and restaurant in the area.

Must go several times outside once inside. If you don't want to pay nor take a tour you really can get a great experience for free outside. Walk all the way sound look thru gates for free. Night and day both are a must. Sit on the wall and just take it all in. We did the paid your and it was ok good. Too much before history standing outside downstairs. But does give good info. The holes, the biggest info. The jokes are not age nor erosion. It was metal rebar styled support stolen by locals after its demise. They dug into the structure stealing the rods that supported it leaving holes and why the earthquake let one half fall. As well as, locals and POPES stole all marble, columns, riches to be reused thruout including the Vatican! Now you don't need the tour! Haha
So much to see!. Walk in history. If the ruins could talk... A very informative and good place to walk around for in hours. Wear good shoes!

Go early, skip the line. We were lucky to visit this amazing attraction in an early time slot. Practically saw the sun rise, and were well through it by the time the 'hordes' descended. As an older person and early riser coming early meant easier access in an area which is not exactly age friendly. If you need it, look for the special disabled elevator for both the aged and others. Keep in mind there are many obstacles on each floor. If you have an audio guide and it fails it is a long way back to change it however.
Rome does not disappoint. This was our second trip to Rome and we had a fantastic time again. This time we took or time and saw the sights at a leisurely pace and enjoyed ourselves.
Wow. This is a must see place. To imagine rome 2000 years ago, it must have been the most wonderous sight to behold. Simply amazing
Simply Brillant. Not a lot to say, the history and atmosphere speak for themselves, simply brilliant. Wonderful place but avoid the legionaire con artists.
Go early in the morning. We didn't opt for a tour but realised it is best to visit before the crowds take over. Much more interesting than expected.
Everything you expect. We thoroughly enjoyed our visit even though it was a very cold and rainy day. The ticket can be used over two days, which is great as there is a lot to see.

History!!. We went on November luckily on a day when it was sunny and not raining. After visiting the Colosseum we went straight to see Palatine Hills and Roman Forum. We started with Palatine Hills first which was a good idea since its uphill than starting at the Roman Forum first. Museum was small but it was nice. So much history to take in and definitely worth it!
It`s a must. it`s impressive, we liked everything. the only thing that can bother are lines and prices, but it`s normal for such a famous, interesting and popular attraction.

Following in the footsteps of Rome'as founders. This ancient structure is spectacular, used a guide who provided detailed history, v.interesting. Forum definitely worth a look. Went on to do a night tour of the area starting at column in front of forum, lots to see fountains, church of the apostles which has a prechristian pagen church under it in v.good condition. Ended tour across river in Jewish quarter. Bought a 4 course meal here for €13.
You MUST see these!. Buy a more detailed guide book or use a guide. There is so much to see and understand. Flat shoes are essential and take your time.

Buy ticket before visit. Buy your tickets before visit through the internet (coopculture.it). We arrived at the site and the line extended almost around the whole building. With the ticket in hand you can skip the line and go to the entry. The middle point at the entry was marked with a small sign marked rome visitor passes and advance tickets. We entered and went straight to the final gate and were waived in. We literally walked ahead of hundreds of people. The site is magnificent and a historic marvel. An audio guide (rent or download from internet) is a big help in understanding the site. Lots of walking, stairs, and rocky paths. The ticket is good for the Forum and Palintine Hill too. Plan on seeing these sites if there's enough energy left. Take your time, you want to see it all.

Dont get fleesed admiring this landmark. Amazing, but watch the pickpockets. The queue wasn't too bad for a beautiful Saturday morning despite not having pre-booked. Everyone trying to sell you queue jump tickets. Self guided was really good and much cheaper.
Amazing history. Everything around the roman forum was outstanding ! The place has so much history , I just couldn't believe how some of the architecture was built ! Mind blowing !

Splended. The place was wonderful to see and magnificent but beware of the lads dressed up as Gladiators and coming out with the chat and patter saying We take your photo with us dressed up - Thenthey borrow your camera, take a photo and then charge you 10 Euros for the priviledge of it and usingYOUR camera
Great sight. First Sunday in the month is free entry don't queue scan the bar code near the entrance and pay 1 euro and bypass the very long queues well worth it

A Must See!!. What an amazing place! Definitely a must see in Rome. To wander back into the past and see the places we read about in history books back in high school was unbelievable. Our only regret is that we didn't take a guided tour because there is so much to see and honestly, after awhile everything looks the same......old! It is beautiful but it can be a little overwhelming. So pay the extra money and take the tour, it will make everything come to life!

History. When in Rome you must visit these sights. Buy your tickets ahead of time and beat the crowds. We were there on a Sunday and because we had our tickets we walked right in. Get the tickets at the Palatine Hills entrance there is never a line.

So much history. You can't go to Rome and not visit this. (The Palatine Hill and Roman Forum were free on the 1st Sunday of the month and free entry with a ticket to the Coliseum). get there early to avoid the queues.

Historical Charm. What can I say that hasn't already been said, it is a wonder to step into a place that once held gladiators and emperors. So much history stored in the rocks and pillars and the marvelous vantage point overlooking the city of Rome. It was definitely worth the 12 euros. I'll be back since I wasn't able to see if everything since it was pouring out.

Awe inspiring, mammoth and unforgettable. Fascinating place to visit whether you're a history or architecture buff, or just like amazingly beautiful scenery. Great fun to explore and imagine the past, or just to daydream. Definitely a photographer's paradise.

Wonderful - especially if you're a history buff.. I studied Classics & Ancient History, so visiting the Forum and Palatine was like going to heaven! It's amazing to see all the places from the stories and imaging Julius Caesar stomping about ;-)Make sure you allow plenty of time - I would say at least three hours in total, but ideally more. The labelling and info onsite is very poor, so it's worth doing a bit of swotting up before you go - a lot of guidebooks (Lonely Planet) have a map with the key buildings marked. Look out for the temple of the vestals and the temple of Castor and Pollux - they look great in photos. Be careful not to miss the temple to Julius Caesar (only the inner section remains) and if you're looking for the Senate (Curia) it's the poorly marked big square building in the back right corner, past the Forum, as you enter from the Palatine.My favourite bit is the decorated pillar foot that marks the official centre of Rome (from where all distances were measured) that stands just to the right of the imposing pillars of the Temple of Saturn. Stand there and get geeky chills!

Amazing thing to go and visit. Definitely a must to visit! You can't go to Rome and not to go there!We went in november so it wasn't that crowded but I heard that in high season it is impossible. It is an attraction where you definitely need to read or go with a tour guide so you can understand more about it and appreciate more!

Incredible. Just back from a trip to Rome with my mum and this was one of the best things we did while we were there. We joined onto a guided tour outside the entrance which was a good choice, our guide was brilliant and so knowledgable. A must!
Breathing history. One of my most thriling outdoor experience, feeling 2000 years old history on every step. The resurection of old buildings, and other attractions makes this place a gem of Rome
Ancient Histroy Comes Alive. If you love history then is the place you should surely visit.. It brings back the History alive.. Ancient Architecture at its best...

SPQR. This is all that remains. As you walk among the strewn rubble and gaze at the few remaining pillars and columns, this is all that remains of the once mighty Roman empire that forever changed the course of human history.
Skip the queue. We paid to skip the queue. The people approach you as you near the site. You get a brief history inside. It is worth not waiting in line in the sun for an hour.
Ancient Rome at its best. ok its crumbling, but they are working hard to restore it. When you are there you can just feel the history of the place!

Disappointing. There was no queue when we arrived, so we sailed in. We took an audio-guide for eur5, and were very disappointed by it. Very little info, dry voiceover, not worth it really. With the 'normal' ticket (i.e. not with a guided tour), you can't go to the lower floors, the arena, etc. You go to the top level, where you have a nice viewpoint on the arena, also one on the Palatine hill (actually 10min of the hour-long audio-guide is about the Palatine hill). The audio-guide then directs you towards the souvenir shop! Then you're directed downstairs for a very short walk. And that's it. Extremely disappointing. As one lady already pointed out here, the toilets are pretty crap and disgusting. We took our baby in the buggy, and it was grand, as there's a lift to go to the top level. All in all, not worth the eur35 we paid for 2 tickets and 2 audio-guides. It's way nicer on the outside.

ONE OF THE MUST SEES?. Would have given it a miss - teeming with visitors and since large sections are not original, disappointing. Would have preferred to visit Sant Angelo close to the Vatican but ran out of time

Walking in the footsteps of Cicero - wow!. It brought back all my Latin lessons, Cicero, Scipio Africanus, Julius Caesar and more...I felt so privileged walking in the footsteps of the great Romans. I would go back again and again and again.

What happened to all the cats?. Rome is, or was, famous for their cats. On a prior visit over ten years ago the place was overrun with lazy cats sunning themselves among the ruins. We were in Rome for three days and did not see a single cat. Anyway this is it, the heart of the once mighty Roman empire. The authorities do an excellent job of preserving the ruins and preservation was ongoing even at the time of our visit. I could be wrong but there used not to be a fee to access the area. Now you must purchase either an individual ticket or a combination ticket with the Colosseum.
Book your tickets on line to avoid lines. Take a guide with u. Cost 150 euro but value for money. Guides combine this with the Vatican or other attractions

Take a Day to Walk Through History. While this is a tourist must do, it is worth it to take the time to really explore this area. The history is amazing and views and architecture are extraordinary. I recommend a guide to really appreciate the experience.

Better view in summer. Still worth a visit, less busy in the winter, reduced number of tours but you can probably get a better deal. Rome is always a great city to behold. Lots to see and learn about.

Great experience. What a great experience it was to relive the days of ancient Rome. We had a guided tour and would recommend this as you will not experience the true heritage and history on your own. A must see!

Good but under repair. Good but under repair and new metro station being built so huge wooden panels up everywhere. Also be aware that if you have photo taken with the Roman soldiers it costs 10 euro EACH person.
Ancient. 5 minutes walk from hostal. Great ararea with lot of history. Impressive and kept up pretty well. Benches near to relax. Beware of pickpockets and purse snatchers in the area

A lot to take in.... There are several options how to see this. You can walk through the archaeological site (there is a cost), or you can see a good deal of the important temples from the street. If you choose the first option, be prepared to walk a quite a ways. In either case, it is very impressive. Not just the ruins themselves, but the size of the area it covers as well.
First time travelers to Rome. even in late Nov the line was 30 min long. might try the "skip the line" if the price is somewhat the same. use the rental audio as the personel talk way too long.
History at it's best. Imagine those walking these same paths 2,000+ years ago. Plan an entire day to see it all. Fantastic!

Be Amazed what they built. How can they find something like this. Every little thing u see Someone else has been there before you. Eat mandarin from the tree? Not know if its allowed. Some people did that. All the rocks are nice and smooth

Amazing!!!. Simply Amazing!!! Great to walk around, eat, drink, also at night they project a film along the old structures
Pretty cool!
good place to visit. not really much to see, without an audio but nice to see after watch Ben hur and such films. Good opportunity to take pictures.

a lot to imagine!. A huge site that is now very run down. you could see where the old apartments were but you really need to imagine a lot in order to understand how everything was. There is a lot of walking involved, the ground is very uneven. try to get a ticket that will show you the Colosseum and Palatine Hill. The hill is very vast and green but there is little shade, so be sure to ake a hat as the sun can be quite strong. Unfortunately there aren't any sandwich bars or a cafe in sight so be prepared and take what you need with you, especially the water.i would recommend you visit it only because it is so close to the Colosseum and has a lot of historical influence in Ancient Rome.
A history buffs dream. I loved being able to see hte building and locations from the ancient past! The scaffolding scattered around for restoration work was a necessary evil.

Must Do. Go for the roma pass which will get you an effective and quick entrance and relief from all the long queues and moreover it will also grant you access to all the three places rather than buying separate tickets. Also if you are not going for the roma pass then make sure you book advance rather than leaning towards buying ticket at the place because it will only eat up a whole lot of time. But somehow you end up running out of these two options head to forum hill to buy ticket as the queue and crowd is lesser compared to other places. Be ready for a whole lot of walking and climbing. Stock in enough water and sun protections and prefer guided tours as there is no information around the place and you will only end up walking through bunch of ruins.

Amazing. The capital of the Roman Empire was an unforgettable experience.To walk on the original stone and cobble stone Roman roads where once the Romans tread and rode on horseback was a once in a lifetime experience and that too after having learned in history lessons.

Apt living in the beginning!. This is basically a big old apartment complex according to all the signs. It's where the old Romans would live and congregate. It's crazy to imagine and think about that when walking through the ruins. It's definitely worth doing, especially with the 2 for 1 ticket you can get with the Colosseum. It is A LOT of walking though, just be prepared.
NEED MORE MAINTANANCE. Though magnificent available lifts are not adequate ,old people found it very difficult to go to upper floor.A sound and light show can be arranged their.
A must see sight. This place is amazing. A good tip is to buy your tickets in advance to save your self a long queue. The closer you eat to the tourist attractions the more you will pay

When in Rome .... A truly amazing experience. Hard not to let your imagination take over when you walk the same paths as the romans did all those years ago. Buy your tickets at the Palatine Hill entrance rather than queuing at the Colosseum. Much quicker.

Worth spending the time at Palatine Hill especially. One ticket, best bought at the Forum end of things as the queues less than at the Colosseum.The forum is realtively short and easy to get around. Palatine Hill is massive and sprawling but repays your time in some fascinating surviving architecture. Feels amazing that so much as survived (though note that the Temple of Vesta has been 'restored' and isn't fully original.There should have been more of course, but some was destroyed in later centuries as people used the hill to build other structures.
Amazing. Incredible to see first hand what Romans were able to design and build so long ago. Beautiful site although quite overcrowded and rampant with street vendors
Must see. If u visit Rome u need to visit here. Did not like the outside sellers. December is a good time to visit, not crowded

The most magnificent view in the world. Every time I visit this magnificent place I see something new... There is so much to learn here. My very warm advice is to read a guide before you come and don't miss to buy at one of the chiosks one of the albums showing how were the sites in the antiquity and the actual situation. And also on a clear day take the elevator on top of Altare della Patria. It is the most magnificent view in the world!

Dream come true. Since I was a kid, I've dreamed of coming here and seeing everything I had learned in history. For non-history buffs, I believe this tour is still beautiful and you can imagine how these ancient people once lived.

Jaw dropping. Ever since I studied A level Latin at school, some 40 pls years ago, it has been the ambition of my life to see these places. They did not disappoint.The scale is staggering, the historical significance mind blowing and the whole experience just fantastic. Don't leave out the Palatine Hill, really important.Obviously watch out for touts, pickpockets, people trying to sell you things etc but fair dos to the Roman authorities, once you are inside the monument, these people are kept out and you are even told the toilets are free and staff are not expected to be tipped.

Good to see the building but nothing more. I think we had better expectations from it. We enjoyed.going around it. Place was full of people trying to sell you stuff you don't need. The tourist booked out so.we went around ourselves.

A must see!. We did not do any guided tours, we purchased the headset that gives you some background history. If I would have known ahead of time I would have liked to purchase tickets with a guided tour that tours the underground dungeons that recently opened. Tickets were sold out two months out. The ticket agent said they sometimes have a few available if you show up when they open (7 or 8am)? Either way a cool piece of Rome history to see and explore.
Amazing!. Great architecture! Do the under ground tour, great way to see what happened behind the fighting scenes. Go early or late in the day. Lots of tourists. Best when sunny. A must see!!

Amazing remnants of the empire . It was surreal walking through the forum on a cloudy November day. Just imagining what this place would have looked like in person at the height of the empire gives you goose bumps. I wish so much more of it was intact, but the standing remains are beautiful as is.
Amazing history. It is so great to see these ruins. Standing in the place where Caeser was killed, seeing the Temple of the Vestel Virgins, etc. Truly amazing.

This is Rome. In the Palatine Hill, ancient Rome had built. Breath taking place you will feel this breeze of history, power, culture and great civilization, the Palatine Hill extended to Capitoline Hill. One can buy a compound ticket to visit Colosseum, Palatine Hill and Roman Forum just for 12 euros.

Amazing beyond a photograph.. I love this area. It is worth paying the admission fee, but still enjoyable from the street. The renovations and excavations of the area are impressive and make it new every time I visit.

very interesting. We had fast track entry which was really good, but as we went in November, the queue wasn't that long anyway, the only thing I didn't like was the people constantly ramming selfie sticks under our noses trying to sell them! We had a tour guide taking us round which was good, found out lots more than we would have I think!
Interesting. Did a walking tour which included all of these. It was interesting especially the Michangelo piazza. Amazing to see it in real life.

Must see !!. This place took my breath away was absolutely amazing make sure you pre book tickets to here and otherwise the queues are massive when you get there on the day very easy to get to on the metro it's right across the road.
A must see. A must do... if you have kids you can have photos taken with a gladiator and also there are hundreds of people offering tours. beware of pick pockets.

a must see. Even if you don't book a tour, just walking around the remains is so atmospheric and beautiful. I suggest visiting early morning or near closing time to get a quieter period to really be able to enjoy the atmoshpere.

Neat experience. Enjoyed the experience, but would've been better to have a guided your or an individual that would be announcing the history. Plenty of space and they can utilize it more efficiently I think for people to get the most out of their visit.
Impressive. Amazing sites and good value for money since you get to go to the palatine hill, and roman forum as well!

Not with stroller. Difficult access with baby stroller no care to exit with the stroller through security point ,overpriced as most poins of interest closed to public, no personnel to provide assistance and/or information.....

Not to be missed. Even if you just stroll by, it is thrilling. I do recommend touring them but not during the heat of the day. My sister and I went to the Forum during a rain and had the place to ourselves.

Save your time and money. Save your time, save your money, there is nothing to see there. Excavations were 1861-1870 and all was recovered by earth or supposedly "reconstructed" with clay bricks without any access to sites. Only thing visible is Titus' Arch and this is not worth the visit. If the weather is fine it is a nice stroll, but that you can have anywhere.

Ancient history, marvelous heritage. Highly recommend a private tour guide if you are interested in getting to know the layers and layers of facts& figures about this ruins. One will get lost on your own, even in a group > 5. We (2 of us) had a enthusiastic tourguide, anthropologist& arthistorian! She brought this area to life! Rome will never be the same after this information.
Ancient Rome Sites. Three must see sights for any lover of ancient history. The Walks of Italy tour was so informative and enjoyable and had a perfect pace.

Very interesting. One tip above all else is wear suitable footwear as there is a lot of walking and all on quite uneven surfaces. The sights are amazing and the time we went was perfect. Only reason I say this as it was manic enough off peak so I can begin to imagine what it'll be like peak time.

Get a tour guide. Amazing to see in person. Definitely a must see when in Rome. Unless you really read up on it before, get a tour guide! We visited whilst doing a trip around Europe so didn't have time to read up properly. There's not much information around about what your looking at. So unless you know what exactly your looking at and what things used to be it's like looking at a pile of rubble. I really regret not getting a guide because I felt we had no idea what we were looking at and missed a piece of Rome history!I bought tickets through Coop-Culture and they last for 2 days which is great!

Truly Awesome. This attraction is awesome. We wandered amongst the ruins latching on to the occasional tour to catch a juicy tidbit of information we didnt know. There are no pamphlets or maps given to you - we did print something off the internet before we left home to give us some information on our own guided tour. The ruins are so enormous and beautiful that it took our breath away. To see how life was in Roman times and they built such vast and beautiful buildings. Lovely walk up the Palatine Hill, especially in the gorgeous weather we had. There is a drinking fountain where you can top up your drinking water. Dont buy bottled water from the various vendors around - they just get bottles from the bins and fill them up and sell them to the unsuspecting tourists - saw them doing this.

History. A large area to explorefilled with history. The archaeological ruins are simply a sight to behold. The story boards are in Italian nd English for those of us who don't speak or read Italian. Simply overwhelming historically.

I was expecting more.... We were kind of dissapointed. We expected more. In other of my reviews I have wrote that tv or videos doesnt make justice to an area or attraction this time I cant say it. I love the place and the tour but I had high expectations on this place. I thougth it will be huge or magistous and was not. Anyways is a must do visit and I strongly suggest you to visit the place to form your own opinion. We enjoyed the visit a lot. Dont misunderstand me We enjoyed and like the place the architecture and the history but In my mind for what I have seen on TV and videos I had higer expectations and I was prepared in my mind to get impressed thing that dont happened.

history speaks. great experience...not to be missed even if its d only thing u get to do in Rome....hop in early to avoid d long queue or book a trour but iu prefer to explore alone...audio guide also available but dont frget to take ur ID as it need submission

The highlight of Rome. We booked the underground tour with the upper ring. With this tour the ticket includes the tour and the surrounding sites. The tour was a great value and we saw places from a perspective that the people with a regular ticket did not see. The line for people without the tour was so long it was unbelievable. We walked past everyone and went to the tour meeting area and did not stand in any line. Great sites, great history, and unforgettable memories!

Must tour these locations!. Wow - imagine standing where the Roman leaders and people congregated centuries ago! Seeing the ruins and walking through them made history come alive for me, and helped me understand the Roman times much better. When you visit Rome, do not miss this tour!

Love it! Is beautiful! The only thing I will advise anyone is NOT TO PAY FOT A TOUR GUIDE you dont need to pay for. This... but if you happen to feel in the need of one right in front of the entrance you will be hassled for many of them... do not go with the first offer..push for a better price and do not pay more than 10 euros per person.

Ancient Ruins. This is the reason you travel to Rome. Lots of ruins in a few blocks, easy to walk around. Lots of cafes and trattorias to stop at. Taxi stands are run by thugs, so be careful, they will want $ before you can get into the next available taxi. Hawkers at Coliseum are rude, but just walk past them to the entrances. Don't miss the Museo Nationale, its behind the new buildings there.

Go at night to have the place to yourself. I had a walk in this area at night on a Monday in November, there were very few tourists, except ones taking some pictures. I had a feeling of traveling back to the times of the Romans.

Excellent choice for kids. My ten year old loved Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum. We took her twice because she wanted to do it again. Kids under 18 are free so the 12 Euro entrance fee for one adult is well worth it. She was not as impressed with the Colosseum which is very crowded. The Forum and Hill are a quiet respite with lots of interesting birds (parrots, seagulls etc).

What a sight. We wondered amongst the ruins which stood there proud. They were so enormous and beautiful that it took my breath away, to think that in the Roman times they built such vast and beautiful buildings. Lovely walk up the Palatine Hill, especially in the gorgeous weather we had

No words necessary. Get the Roma pass, to avoid the insane lines.
Palatine hill was rather confusing.... lots to see, not clear what we were looking at

What a place, you can imagine the atmosphere.. When you get inside this place and realize just how big it is, how old it is and how any people it used to seat the hairs will stand up on the back of your neck. We did a self guided tour and went around twice because it was so impressive.Your ticket also gets you access to the Forum and Palatine Hill so make sure to take the time to visit this too. The experience is slightly different but you get a real sense of what it must have been like when Rome was at its peak. Plus, if you walk to the end of the Palatine hill nearest the Colosseum you get the best view of the Colosseum without any crowds being in your way like you do at ground level, and for some reason most people don't seem to be bothered with making this very short walk so it's quieter too.

The reason for our Roma visit!. Yes, we went to see Rome because we had read so much about ancient Rome. We saw it and we loved it all the better! We could sit around and speculate on how life was 20 centuries back.it s worth it. We have done this twice already and will probably visit again.

Do the full tour. We visited in Nov, had prebooked a tour that included going down into the below ground level, and up to the third tier. Brilliant! Guide was entertaining and knowledgeable, and brought it to life. Great value, including the Roman Forum, that was excellent. We had an audio guide downloaded from the Internet, and it made it all so relevant. Found the place where Ceasar was cremated, and the Roman Senate, incredible.

Not as expected, Rough Area Aswell. Beware!. We were looking forward to seeing it, but it was a bit dissapointing... the building is gorgeous but surrounded in scaff holding and a met fence... you appreciate it is very old and now falling apart but its really not how it is made out to be.... the area is pretty rough. Not somewhere you want to be at night we were there about 8pm looking for a resturant and had young lads coming up asking us to buy drugs off them, lots of gangs on the streets drinking etc... in the day it is full of people trying to sell you things and scam you be very carefull... we will never return to Rome and il be glad when we finally leave.

Interesting. I enjoyed looking round here and seeing the ruins. It was particularly interesting to see where Ceasar was killed. It was good to get photos of the forum from the nearby museum which was higher up. It may be quite difficult for those with mobility problems.

Breathtaking!. You'll love it. You pictures will seem unrealistic. Be warned, you could lose each other. We lost our dad for about an hour with no way to contact each other. Come up with a plan if that occurs with your family!

So much history. This was such a great area to visit. There is so much history here to see and experience. I recommend having a knowledgeable guide as they bring so much to the experience. I would not recommend this area for the mobility impaired as there is a lot of walking and a lot of steps.

Very interesting. Gives an insight into ancient Rome pre-Christian times. Includes the famous Arch of Titus depicting the Emperor Vespasian's soldiers carrying the Menorah after destroying the 2nd temple in Jerusalem. Downloaded Rick Steve's audio guide which gave a great explanation of the whole area including why ancient Rome thrived and what caused it's decline.

Quiet getaway. Escape all the tourists. Pretty park with some interesting ruins. Quite a large area to walk around with views of Circus Maximus on one side and the Roman Forum on the other. You can get in with your Colosseum tickets.

Great building - shame about all the tour guide harassment. fantastic building with lots of atmosphere. The only thing that spoilt it was that you can't look at it in peace - there is always someone trying to get you to go on a guided tour, creepy men dressed as gladiators and always been asked if you want to buy cheap rubbish products. All these people should be stopped, so you can feel safe and secure.

The centre of Ancient Rome. A friend organised a small guided tour, and so glad they did. This was the ultimate history lesson on Ancient Rome. The Forum was essentially the heart and soul of Rome. Just about everything of any significance happened here & many of the most important buildings were located around here. It was such an interesting & informative few hours, and you could feel the history of the place as you walked around. Best to combine with the Colosseum if you can. Awesome!

colosseum. amazing place you can't go to rome with out visiting this glorious ruin of ancient rome, there may be a wait line to get in but once you are in it you can move around quite easily. anyone who has seen the movie Gladiator can relate to it it also has an elevator, restrooms and a book shop
Just unbelievable!. Wow, I liked seeing such a historic place. Walking the grounds was incredible! Knowing that I was in the place where I had only read about made history come alive for me.
Awesome. Just so amazing to see this. Queues were too long so didn't actually go in, but it was still an incredible experience just to be there!

Awe struck while touring Rome. My family and friends who came with us, hired a tour guide for a private tour of the Roman forum. There were seven of us, and it was great to get such personal attention. That is the way to go!! Anyways, to be walking where people walked many thousand years ago is awe inspiring. It really helped me get a grip as to how the people lived back then. Our tour guide Julia was very informative. She filed in the blanks on the Roman's traditions and food, clothing, where they shopped, etc. . She also filled us in on the "layers" of Rome. She said the oldest layers to the newest were piled like lasagna. She used that phrase a lot. You can see where the levels of Rome were built on top of each other. To see where Rome was founded, to see where Julius Caesar's body was supposedly burned was thought provoking. Unless you are a history professor ( or married to one), get a guide. It was worth the money we spent. We did not waste any time and saw most if not all of the Roman Forum. Being a history buff it really worked well for my group. There are many vendors in the area selling food, water, and drinks. There are also many restaurants within a couple block walk of this site. During our time there a policeman announced over a loud speaker that pickpockets were in the area. It was broadcast in about 3 or 4 languages. That was very much appreciated. Lastly our guide was able to direct us to a fabulous restaurant about 5 blocks away from the Forum. A guide is the way to go. They also provided transportation from our hotel and back.

Not to be missed. This is a triumph of architectural perfection! The ingenuity is outstanding! Purchase the Roma Pass (3-days) and you can easily spend 2 days at these extraordinary sites. Also don't forget to view the Trajan Markets and Circus Maximus. These wonders are not to be missed on your visit to Roma!
More impressive. Was huge and taller than I thought... A lot of pickpockets and purse snachers in area, so be on your a game... Hutslers, beggers and street entertainers everywhere...
very impressive. i thing that half of ancient romans history is written there. very impressive building. so close to palatino. nice park and very easy to find it. i liked it very much

Amazing. Amazing place and Bucket List stuff.....every corner was wow wow wow! The cost of a ticket is good value and gives a choice of 2 places to visit on two days. Felt very safe in the area and although usual street sellers they we're bare able.
Fantastic. I loved all of the sites and information. However I feel they did not have enough maps. My husband and I had to pay twice to see the full palatine.
Ancient History Alive and Well. Amazing sites but expect a lot of walking on uneven surfaces. Be prepared to fascinated and exhausted.

must see. The forum and Palatine Hill was amazing and all my interest was focused on the colosseum. I strongly suggest a tour with Real Rome Tours to get the full effect of this historical place - however you do have the option to go solo at your own pace! These are HIGH people traffic areas, and bring good shoes, water, and pack wet naps for the washrooms.

An absolute must. The amount of history in these three locations are enough to blow your socks off! There are so many tours doing these places in an all in one style which does make for a bit of walking but certainly worth it. If you only had 24 hours this would have to be on the list without question.

Book a tour and enjoy. Of course this is one of the main attractions in Rome. It's so obvious that is quite a cliché. However, there is more than only walking around or only a quick walk inside. I would recommend one of those tours that will bring you to the higher levels and to the underground (as long as it's not flooded). That is quite a good journey through the history of gladiators, executions, celebrations and death. And that would be a good advixe: check the forecast before going. It's not rare that they will close the place due rain.

History at its best. This was one of the best things we did. I was so glad we took a guided tour as the information given to us and the detail was eye opening. It also meant we did not have to que for ages for tickets. It involved a lot of walking on uneven ground so wear suitable shoes, also if it is warm make sure you have water and sunscreen. A must see.

prepare to queue!. It was truly amazing to walk around these historical monuments, something special about being in the place where so much has happened. Be prepared to queue for access to all these place though!
A must see. So much history and so much to see. We really enjoyed touring this area of Rome. I recommend the audio tour!
A 'must do'. Seen so often in books and on the screen but being there was awe inspiring. Being partly clad in scaffolding didn't detract from the overall spectacle.

Essential. It's incredible to walk on the streets that the ancient romans step 2000 years ago.
Be careful with the queues at Colosseum. Buy your ticket at Roman Forum and save time ;)

Lots to see. This is a great area to spend an afternoon in. Use a guide, though, since otherwise it's hard to tell where all the buildings were and what they were used for. Lots more interesting when you know what you're looking at/for.
Amazing!!. Great day visiting these historic places, my tip would be to visit the roman forum first and buy your tickets here to avoid the queues

Amazing!!!. It was surreal to be looking at and walking amongst these ruins! It was an incredible experience. I could have stayed there all day just looking at the buildings and columns and wondering what life was like so many years ago.

Amazing. I'm a bit of a history buff, and my first time to Rome was amazing. The scope and breadth of the treasures found here are difficult to describe. Imagine yourself walking through a period of history, complete with paintings, sculptures, architecture, and you can begin to comprehend Rome.
Need a day to do justice to the site. The Forum and Palatine Hill were much larger than I remembered and the various stages of Roman history were encompassed in the numerous monuments on the site
Unmissable. A completely unmissable sight when visiting Rome, a beautifully preserved piece of ancient history. Visit on a Sunday when the adjacent road is closed to traffic.
A must see in Rome. Buy your ticket at the Palatine Hill (must shorter line). The ticket is valid for both Colosseum, the Palatine Hill and Forum Roma.

Journey in time. A must see while in Rome. Have a stroll through the area and see old ruins and temples.If you´re interested in the story behind the stones you should get a audio guide, there are not much signs on the ruins itself.The entrance is 12€ and incl. the entrance to Palantine Hill and The Colloseum. To avoid the long que at the Colloseum come to Forum Romanum first and skip the line later at the Colloseum.

A must see in Rome. You can't miss this one. It's an amazing place, even more if you realize it used to have 90,000 people there watching gladiators and beasts fighting each other. If you go there at night, and want to have a pizza and wine, there is a small restaurant next to the Colosseo subway station. You can have your pizza, your wine, and see the monument just across the street.
When in Rome - cant be missed. You can book your tickets in advance to save waiting, the ticket also gets you into the forum for the same price

Worth a Visit. I've visited the Roman Forum twice on guided tours - admission is generally included with these guided tours. If you're visiting the Colosseum, it's worth a visit to see these ancient ruins. Be sure to have an umbrella, comfy shoes and water bottle on a hot day - there are not too many shady spots! The area is not overly crowded and you can wander around freely.

Roman Forum Light Show Experience. The Roman Forum is always a great attraction, but on our recent trip to Rome we went to an evening light show experience which was really fascinating. The lights re-created the Roman Forum as it was at it's inception. There were earphones in English that told the history of the Forum. Definitely worth experiencing.

Very impressive but difficult to understand. There is so much history buried here it is very difficult to understand what you are looking at sometimes. Don't try. Many areas hold many artifacts from different periods, lots of reused material and inconsequential later buildings. The Palatine ticket is also good for the Colosseum, so I suggest you visit the hill first (the lines to buy tickets at the Colosseum are looooonng).
Roman history at it's best. There is nothing to dislike. It is all wonderful. To walk through the history of the capital of the Roman Empire is just amazing.
Amazing. Strongly recommend to purchase your ticket online and print your voucher to avoid the long lines to enter. It's absolutely amazing place to visit even at night.

Justifies top billing. It is a must for any traveller. It takes your breath away as you wander round this huge site and unravel the sequence of buildings and history. Labelling is quite good and seems very honest about what they know and what is conjecture

Could be much better.. In Rome you are spoiled for ancient monuments. However, the Roman forum does not get the attention it deserves. There are hardly any signs, explanation or directions. It's a pitty really. I would skip this on my next visit.

Amazing.. If you decide to avoid the queue and sign up with a tour guide, have your best running shoes on. they rush you round.Best to endure the queue, then at least you can go at your own pace once you have entered .Good walking shoes are recommended if you decide to visit the Forum the same day.

Pretty Impressive Ruins. This is probably the best location in Rome to see and appreciate ruins. They're huge and diverse and comprehensive and artistic and yet without the story, they're just ruins. If you're planning to go. get on the internet and see some of the pictures of how it looked at the time. Read a little of what went on here and get a sense of the place. It will make the ruins seem that much more real and you will get a better appreciation of just what's going on here. Some organized tours have a guide that will supply this commentary and background and you may wish to consider this option. If doing your own walk around tour buy your combination ticket for the Colosseum area ahead of time on the internet and skip the lines.

Everything you expected!. These three places were absolutely incredible. It does take a great deal of time to get through them all by yourself. I had a guide that took us through the highlights of all three places and let us explore by ourselves afterwards. There is SO much to see, especially on Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum. You might want to start early, but it is definitely worth the time (and money depending if you go without guides or not).
Amazing views. there is no other way to get perspective on the lives of people in ancient Rome without being here ! Absolutely wonderful tours all around great photos everywhere you look
Amazing Building. You must go. Seeing is believing. I cannot adequately describe this amazing experience.Films like Gladiator and Ben Hur do it justice.

Incredible to see. It is incredible to see this ruin in the middle of city - across from a metro stop and incredible amounts of traffic! Give yourself plenty of time to wander the site, Palatine Hill and everything in the area. We went in the rain and still spent several hours and had a wonderful time.

Time travel. Whenever You visit in Rome, don't miss this combination: Colosseum/Palatine Hill/Roman Forum. You can get a ticket via internet, I strongly recommend to use this official website; http://www.coopculture.it. Ticket costs 14 euros and You can pass the ticket queue with it. Ticket is valid for two days. Best plan is to visit Colosseum first and after that navigate to Palatine Hill. When You walk down from the hill towards to Roman Forum, the views are unforgettable! It's magical experience and impossible to describe, it's one of those things You have to do at least once in a lifetime. I have visited there three times, and it's getting better and better every single time. There's so much to see and the atmosphere is just magical.

Ancient Rome. Where it all began. Having struggled through crowded The Colloseum, the mobbed Vatican and the glorious St Peters Basilica the wide open spaces, peace and tranquillity of The Palatine was a great relief. We were in Rome for three days and fell in love with Rome. To appreciate the history I would strongly advise you to pay for a guided tour. Our Palatine guide was extremely knowledgeable and very entertaining. Guides bring history to life.

What can u say!!! Fantastico. The historic sites in rome are amazing. This was my 6 th visits and it still wows me! They have uncovered more of the Roman forum , than ever. It's like a living movie set!!

Lot's of walking!. Lots and lots and lots of walking. Wear comfy shoes that you don't find getting dirty (my black shoes looked more grey by the end of the day). Get a map, I'm not sure where since would bought our tickets at the Colosseum, but try to get one. We had no clue where we were going, but that just made it more fun. :)We were there at the end of October, so the weather was great. But if you're there in the summer heat, I would recommend bringing a hat (or if you're crazy like me, a sun umbrella). I'm glad we visited on our own and just explored. Next visit, I think I would get a guide to learn more about the history.

Book in advance for a tour of third floor and basement level. We booked in advance for only 9 euro more than standard entry , we got a tour of basement plus third level, amazing amazing. Fantastic tour. Book this, highly recommend.

Eerily atmospheric. Loved the whole experience...don't miss it whether you like history or not! If you really like history, book the special guided tour that takes you down under the arena and up to the third tier....

Stepping into the past. The expanse of this whole area and the scale of the structures was extremely impressive....the Romans certainly didn't do anything by halves....The ruins of Augustus palace were particularly interesting.....A guide would definitely enhance the experience of this visit by bringing this whole area to life

sunny day and lots of time. long lines for the toilets - and not many toilets available so use them when they are free... there is an elevator for handicapped people and elderly - this is a must see for everyone - lots of videophones to rent or guides to help you along - these are across the street from each other
Just Wow!. Amazing, finally seeing the places I had only seen in pictures, imagining what it would have been like 2000 years ago.

Could do with a clearer interpretation.. This is a fascinating site to visit, as you would expect. The only problem that we found was in trying to understand what we were looking at. We overcame the problem by buying a book that had pictures of the current site, along with overlays of how they looked 2 millennia ago. It made it much easier to put places into context.Even tough it was November, the site was still busy, but it was the first Sunday of the month, when admission is free, so this was not surprising. Well worth seeing!

Better then the pictures. The site took my breath away. It is too big too imagine how it was ever constructed. Standing there imaging all the history that was part of this site takes my breath away. There was a demonstration taking place not far from here and it was an awesome experience standing in the past and witnessing the present.

Triple tour. You could easily spend the whole day at these three sites. A tour is the best option. Valuable information given and an insight to how these places were used in the day. Once the tour is over just sit back and take in the atmosphere .
Just a single day. These places will eat up lot of your time. All are nearby. You would need to walk a lot to see everything. By the end of this thing you could be dead tired
So much to see!!. The Roman Forum is very big and you need lots of time to explore the ruins. Well worth while and will not be disappointed.

History and stories before your eyes. The ruins don't mean much without being able to picture beforehand or afterward what they were when in use. An entire history book of happenings lies right before you. A guide book or person is mandatory to understand the scene and appreciate what it once was.
Don't forget to buy a reservation ticket on www.museumsrome.com, it's absolutely worth. If you decided to chose the reserved ticket for 11 o'clock, you can go in at 11.01h, not a minute earlier.

Important part of ancient Roman history.. We visited as part of a cruise excursion after a short walk from the Coliseum. It is an impressive site and an important part of Roman history. There is quite a bit to see, so allow plenty of time to tour the site.

Old Roman city in Rome. The Roman old city in Rome, the view and the historical architecture are stunning. Walking up the Palatine Hill, you can over view the city of Rome and see the Colosseum as well, It really worths you to take a walk here.
