Beautiful Roma!. Wonderful personal tour! We went at the best times to avoid as much of the crowds as possible. Knowledgeable, tour in English.

Amazing. What an amazing area of Rome. My husband and I and 6 cousins just walked and walked. It is amazing to see how the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill were built and to see the ruins. History is all around.

Walk thru history. Been to Rome a couple of times before but this was never on my tick list. Was a fabulous journey through time. Listened to Rick Steves free audio guide which made the tour even more interesting.
well worth a trip!!!. Wear a pair of good walking shoes as the ground is very uneven, perhaps a challenge for those with poor mobility. Great attraction, well worth a visit.
AMAZING!!!. This was our first trip to Rome and were overwhelmed by the architecture. Walking around the ruins gives you a true insight into the past. What an experience
Don't miss these!. Absolutely spectactular! A must see! Fabulous parts of History! There is so much detail and beauty! The views are breath taking! It's hard to believe they are still standing!
Amazing. This are very impressive places to visit. It's not hard to imagine the roman empire when you are looking at these magnificent samples of the old temples.

Another wow. We cheated on this one never paid the extra to go in as we took all the pictures we wanted and got a great overall picture from looking down on it. If you do go in make sure you get the dicta phones that will tell you everything. Be aware of the men dressed as centurions, they will charge for photos taken with them. Was told 5euros is enough for two photos.
Wonderful to see. Seeing such a historic building is just amazing. The enormous crowd of visitors tended to spoil the experience.

History everywhere. Spend a long time here. From a distance it appears to be a somewhat anonymous jumble, but don't miss it, for as you walk round, every step opens new wonders to view. In some ways though less obviously spectacular than other places in Rome, this was the most fascinating for us. Eavesdrop on the various guides and you will be almost overwhelmed by the history of this area

Really interesting. We actually explored these sites from the "outside" and avoided the entry fees and still feel like we saw a lot. We started up by the Victor Emmanuelle monument, Capitoline The Via Fori Imperiale was closed to auto traffic on the Sunday we were there. It was the first Sunday of the month, which entitled Rome citizens to free entry, so it was very crowded, but there was a very convivial, festive atmosphere with buskers, etc.

History at its awesome best. Easy to access, with excellent guides and advice and information. One would have to be completely without imagination not to pick up the atmosphere of what it must have been like 2000 years ago
awesome history, fabulous guide. Enjoyed the tour and the fabulous guide, we were there in July!! extremely busy and 35 degrees. Lots of opportunity to buy cold water. A very friendly morning

Incredible!!!!. Such a fantastic place, I cannot start to describe it!So much to see but buy a 'queue jump' ticket as the queues were terrible. We used the "hop on hop off' bus who supplied the tickets.The only reason I did not rate this as excellent was the poor standard of the toilets. Considering the numbers that visit this attraction day after day, the sanitary provision needs improving.

Just the bones are left. What you see has been stripped of all it's marble veneer. I think it would be nice to restore a small section to remind you of the grandeur of these places when they were new. It is still a must see but a little imagination is needed to see what it was intended to be.

Thoroughly enjoyed despite the cliche. Yes most heavily seen and photographed.We did it with a 7 and 4 year old.Did the guided tour. Definitely worth getting a guide. I will say if you have a choice then do it early or late to avoid the rush.
Book an English speaking guide. We did this to "beat the queue", it was fun and the guide was quite amusing comparing todays lifestyle with that of ancient Rome.
History at a glans. A wonderfull site. When walking around you can feel history all around you. This site is of major historic importance and therefor a wonderfull experience.
Great place. Right opposite to the Colosseum, an areas of ruined Roma city back a couple of thousand years, with original structures, feel like travelled back in time.

The most interesting history sight we have visited. The whole site is massive, and you get an instant impression of the layers of Rome, and the way of life for the ruling classes. The views are spectacular, looking over Rome and the Coliseum. There's a museum at the centre, with lots of artefacts, video walls and as with many museums in Rome, e foundations of Roman buildings incorporated. The fact that the occupants of houses built 2000 years ago can be identified is just incredible. The clarity of building details, and the preservation of the statues, is truly memorable.

so much history. The Forum is very beautiful and the weather was great the day we visited. There is a lot of walking and climbing so wear flat shoes or trainers. There is so much to take in so take your time and enjoy.

Roman Empire center. All Rome is an open air museum but Roman Forum is the core. History speak at each step, every stone has a story to say. Don't miss it! Walk truth the ancient place remembering the importance of this place for the entire world.

Skip the lines and pay for a private tour. As with all things - what was once free to do is now a charge to go everywhere. The first timers loved it while I remembered the times before all the people.
Must do tour. We booked a tour for this, and it was well worth it. We used Viator and the tour leader was very informative and spoke great English. It is overwhelming without a guide!
Excellent. Amazing history to learn here. I recommend having a guide to explain the layout and interesting facts of the area.

good combo. bought skip the line combo tickets online which were good value for money and great if you are time poor with a private driver (see pantheon review). if the first stop is at the top of the hill, looking down on the people wandering through the vast expanse below, it is inevitable to want to join them and get a closer look (which can be time consuming if you don't have tickets in hand as the queues can snake along for kilometres, depending on the time of year.

Easy to spend a lot of time. The Roman Forum and Palatine hill are great to wander around and soak up the ambience. We had a rick steve audio guide which was definately worth it to point out the major sights and set the scene. Incredible to believe what it pnce was. Definately worth the visit. With a guide of some sorts, you can soend hours here. With out it, the meaning of many things would be lost. Definately worth the time it takes to visit it completely!
Great historical sites.. Loved the history. Found it very moving. It was impressive as you walked around and imagined it in its heyday!
wow, built 2000 years ago, amazing. an architectural and engineering feat of construction! the only tourist item I view as valuable in Rome.
Go early, skip the crowds. Crowds get crazy busy around 11 am, try to get there before everyone else so you can move around, get pictures

Big. It's a must see since it is ancient but not the most awesome thing I saw in Rome by any means. To see the bottom portion you had to pay extra and it was a little limited as you can imagine there is a lot missing. Cool but not awesome.
Amazing!. Amazing to experience! Definitely book an underground tour ahead of arriving into Rome to void queues and learn in depth history during a guided tour.

Get a Guide. Really! Get a guide. A professional (mine had a doctorate in archeology and was very knowledgeable yet interesting) gives you so much insight and perspective about what you're experiencing, plus you get to skip the long lines to get in. It's all here, the origins of modern society plus the pagan foundations of Rome....almost too much to take in....and the progression of history found by the 'unearthing' of Rome is so powerful. But beware of pick-pockets. They are everywhere, especially small Roma children trained in the 'art'. Even in the midst of The Forum a loud siren blasted on, followed by an announcement that pick-pockets had been spotted in the ruins. Everyone walks around clutching purses, backpacks, etc. to their body....it's like a plague!

Being here was enough.... The memory of seeing this amazing area will always stay with me! Just standing amongst the ruins and knowing how significant this area was, was enough for me! I didn't have an audio guide and I suppose having one would make it all that more worthwhile, however with a guide book and having done much reading beforehand, I did not feel lost as I did in Pompeii for example. We waited for tickets and at this time of year it was only about 30mins.. The area is so big that even with thousands of people around it doesn't feel claustrophobic. No amenities in the forum though so make sure you have a toilet break before entering.... Definitely a highlight of my whole trip!

Best trip in Rome. We visited all the sights but this was my favourite. A guided tour can be got on the day at discount and is highly recommended. I learned more in 3hrs tour than I did in 11 years at school! Brilliant.

A must see!. The history is just amazing! coming from Australia we just do not having the buildings like that. We spent hours just looking at features, brought a book of Rome from the store and read about all the features and about the history of it, good way to do it without a guide. Shut at 15.30 however so plan on heading in way before then because the line at 2.30-3.00 was still big! And we did not get time to see the Roman Forum as that also shut at 15.30.
very interesting. Well worth seeing but quite busy. Book tickets in advance to avoid queues.Quite spread out so need to walk. Open top tour bus probably the best way to get there.
Very, Very impressive.. We took the underground tour and found it was well worth the 9 euros extra. We got a better appreciation of some of history being able to see these sites
skip the queue. Fab place, manic outside, make sure you have pre paid tickets and so straight in, ticket includes forum and palatine hill for 48hrs

A must to do. What an amazing experience. I was overawed by the magnitude of this archeological site. I always knew the colosseum would be amazing but was not aware of the extent of Palantine Hill or the Roman Forum, nor was I prepared for the impression they would have on me. My husband and I spent a long time exploring this site. It is a must for anyone visiting Rome for the first time. It was worth taking the recommendation of others to buy our ticket to Palentine Hill first as it gave us entry to all sites. This meant we avoided the huge queue at the colosseum.
overrated pile of stones. impressive buildings but hard to tell what is still left from the original building and what is being addedbuy a ticket online to avoid waiting in line.

The heart of ancient Rome.. The area is bursting with the most important sites in ancient Rome. It's amazing that so much is still preserved in the heart of a modern city. Sadly all the bronze and marble and most of the travertine cladding and mosaics have been removed and used by successive Popes to clad their buildings instead, but they're still mightily impressive.
Roman Forum and Palatine Hill. A must see when visiting Rome Stand in the Forum and use your imagination possibly many powerfull people met on the spot you are standing on now

Must Visit. Suggest you save time and enter via Palatine - site is well worth it - this is where history was made. Take refreshments with you as there is nowhere inside and loos are few and far between!
Save queue time. Very interesting but if you intend combining with Palatine and Forum enter via the Palatine and save heaps of time!

Amazing, amazing, amazing!. What more can I say? The experience was absolutely fabulous. I didn't bother with an audio guide, and I felt that just standing there I was able to get a sense of the sheer history of the site.Hot tip: go to the Roman Forum before you go to the Colosseum. The queues for tickets are a lot shorter, especially mid-afternoon.The only negative for me was that as soon as it got to 20 minutes before closing time they effectively threw us out, so expect that you will not be able to stay until the stated closing time.
Ok - nice view from the top. I was a bit over ruins by the time I went in but you can walk around and look at the nice views of the city and circus maximus.
Brilliant. Had a great time visiting, recommend the underground tour and 3rd tier, you go in small groups and explore.

Not just stone. We went on a sunny day- great for photos.We booked ahead so walked straight in. There is a lift for easy access ( if disabled/ have pushchair/ tired). Such an amazing place,lots of information on display too. Great place to visit...even before actually going inside there are great views from around. Be aware that nearby cafes charge silly amounts.
Fantastic !. Do the underground tour well worth the extra money. With limited numbers allowed each day booking in advance advisable. Definately a must see attraction.

Fabulous! What more can I say!. This is just an outstanding tour of the Colosseum and Palatine Hill! It is worth skipping the queues by booking a tour, however if you do not book a tour, you will queue for hours, but see so much more. When the Palatine Hill tour is over, you can discover the other wonders at your leisure. Wear comfortable foot wear due to the varied surfaces. Take plenty of water too, but be aware of the scarcity of toilets in both venues. It is breathtaking and somthing you will never forget.

Walking with the Gods. My wife and I booked the tour at the site , the tour guide was fantastic and gave a real insight into the history of this most important site . History oozes from every pillar and stone and it was one of the highlights from our trip to the eternal city . I was amazed to see the original water fountains still in use , ( well that's what the guide said ) he also pointed out the place where Romelus and Remus were born , and who the city of Rome was named after . A must visit ! .

Wonderful site for ancient history. Wonderful to walk around. Reaching there at 9am is good in avoiding crowds. Would be nice to gave a knowledgeable guide. Done friends got the audio guide which was not useful. We used our books and there are helpful information plaques.

Palatine Hill is mind blowing. The vast nature of this hill. Tucked away behind. The bustling streets, roads and crowds of the Eternal City, was just an amazing & pleasant surprise. I was awe struck with the visit into Emperor Augustus home and his wife's own house too, The House of Livia. For the latter, the uninspiring walk down the entrance stairs does not prepare you for the amazing audacious rooms and frescoes around the corner, truly an experience to have for yourself. The vast hill top and it's history was simply delightful. Our guide was full of great archaeological information and introduced us to the Museum with more to explore. Thank you for the blessing of being able to stroll through Palantine Hill.
large queues, chaos!!. large queues we waited fro more than one hour to get our tickets and after we bought them we couldnt move because they were people waiting!!

Good to see, but no Audio Guide!. This is a good site to see which is a stone throw's away from the Colosseum, with which the tickets are included.We get to see a lot of ancient ruins and sites with Roman architecture.However, it was disappointed to see the place wasn't very well managed or maintained. The maps given to us were quite confusing and not very well marked. It was also disappointing to see no Audio Guide included. Upon exit did we see the place to get the Audio Guide, but by then it was too late.Would suggest to get the audio guide from the entrance by turning left after the Colosseum, not going straight ahead.

Amazing - guided tour recommended. These ruins are amazing. But having the history and stories from a guided tour really enhanced my experience. All the sites like Viator and Dark Rome all use the same local vendors so don't spend too much time shopping around. If I knew this I would have booked directly with City Wonders (the local tour company).

Amazing ... A must see. We booked a guided tour, well worthwhile. This also included the Colosseum. Very informative ...also being such a huge site we could of easily gotten lost on our own. October was a great time to visit not too hot or crowed. The site itself is peaceful and overwhelming, a must see while in Rome.

A must see. It has all been said before. You just have to see these places first hand. There will be no sense of disappointment whatsoever, as long as you take steps to avoid the queues (and there are several options for doing this)

We couldn't get the most from our visit due to dreadful organisation. No one denies this is an amazing venue. No one would disagree with the guide books that say an audio guide is a must. So why cant the Roman authorities get their act together and provide sufficient guides? We arrived at 10.15 am and queued for 30 minutes. We got tickets no problem, but the audio guides were sold out!! We waited another 30 minutes to get two guides and set off on our tour. After 20 minutes, and a distance from the ticket office, both guides ran out of battery power and we had to walk all the way back to the entrance to change them - only there weren't any replacement ones and they wouldn't refund the extra we had paid for the guides. Absolutely hopeless.

Highlight of our trip to Rome. We walked from our hotel/boutique to this incredible place. My husband always had a dream of standing in front of the colliseum and we made that dream come true. Its more incredible and breath taking in person than any picture I've ever seen. Sooo much history and it's like standing back in time when you are actually there and the colliseum is right in front of you. Would highly recommend this to anyone visiting Rome.
A dream come true. Amazing, you just have to see it for yourself. Book a guided tour including underground a tier 3 for extra 9 euros. You will not be disappointed.
awesome. Make sure to get a guide for this, if you get a chance do the underground part of the tour. we didn;t and wish we had

3 historic sites in one visit. Three fascinating historic sites with well documented information throughout the museum sections. Pleased we too heed of other Trip Advisor tips to purchase ticket before we went to avoid the queues.
Great place!. Love history dimension of this place. So epic, strong and beautiful. I could imagine people fighting in there. Its great indicator of Roman Imperia strength!

Great day of history. My wife and I love the history. The tour guides were very infromative and we learned a lot. We felt we did not have enough time at the Roman Forum so we went back on our own and rented the audio units at the ticket counter. We learned even more and had time to explore much more than the tour offered. We went early and got lucky, the lines were not very long yet.

Colosseum Plus & Minus. If you want to see the basement or the top it costs extra. Vey good info boards around. Loos but entrance area only ? Aggressive Gladiators . Good that the one ticket will get into the ruins adjacent.
P. We spent a huge amount of time walking around the hill it's a old ruin a lot to see , took loads of photos it didn't feel like you are in city
Breathtaking. The history...just amazing. Buy the tour..you get to front of lines faster and it's well worth the low price.
Pretty neat!. This was pretty neat to read about as we walked through here. We were pretty tired so we rested in here as well but it was tricky to locate some of the areas described in our guide.
Turn back time. Beautiful historical place, just a little bit of imagination and history knowledge and stories of those famous and powerful people of the ancient Rome will come up.

Ancient Rome is fascinating. I came to Rome specifically to see these ancient places and relics. I am amazed at how well preserved some of these building are after so many centuries! so worth a visit, I envy those who can travel here more readily!
Visit All of these. It was wonderful to be in these places and imagine what life was like for the Roman people. Make sure to either take a tour, or an audiotape.

Give yourself several hours and take lunch. This is an extensive site, which on reflection I should have prepared better for by reading up on it, because all my preconceptions about where the Roman hierarchy lived and actual size of the buildings was just plain wrong. Some were immense. What I was amazed by was how they built their villas to overlook Circus Maximus, drink a wine and watch the races. Nothing's changed!Message for the curators : What I would have liked to see is a diagram at each point showing what the building looked like. The Baths of Carracella have a picture showing what it was like compared to what it is now, and are an excellent visual reference, which made the site come alive and more than another ruin. When so little remains of some buidings it would make it more enjoyable.Also, your toilets at the entrance need an urgent upgrade: flush buttons were so hard to push that I cannot describe here what I saw there. Appalling. There was also a queue. One should not have to wait!PS If anyone sees the busker playing classical guitar up the hill from the ticket office in the quiet lane on the way to the church, please buy his CD. I just got back yesterday and played it for the first time. I'd love to know how to get in touch to let him know how enjoyable it is to listen to.
Must see. The architectural and historical aspect's are amazing. It's definitely a must see and walking around the hill was gorgeous. It was a perfect day in a perfect setting
So much to see!. 12 euros is a great price to see so much history! October was beautiful weather, I couldn't imagine wanting to go in summer, the heat would be miserable.
A must see!. We enjoyed our visit. Just to be present in a place with such history is amazing. Even our 6yr put down his gadgets to look around and take it all in! A must see in Rome
wow. Please visit this place if you are even tiny bit interested un history. Prepare brain, camera and drop high heels. It is lot of walking but there is so much to ser.
visit at night. Visit this place at night when the crowds diminish. Just before dusk is when the light is great and the illumination on the monuments can be captured well with most cameras.
Iconic symbol of Rome!. It was worthwhile hiring a guide to explain all the history of this area! Truly an amazing place!!! It represents Rome at its grandest! The Romans were amazing engineers!

Unbelievable place. Breath taking wondering around the old rome which lay below the current street level. Trying to imagine the way the streets used to be is so hard and if it wasn't for our amazing guide i dont believe it would be possible to understand and take in so much of this amazing place.Pre-book for skip the lines and also take a guide with you to get the best out of the experience.

Easy to imagine what Rome used to be like. Another wonderful experience in Rome and a gorgeous autumn day of 21 degrees and not too crowded! I cant imagine walking around here in the middle of summer crowds in 40+ degrees though... Again I wont go on and on about the historical aspects, lots of other people are more qualified to do that. A couple of survival tips - you can spend hours here, so there are several water fountains throughout so dont worry that you will run out of water (very civilised - some other cities I could mention should be so courteous to their visitors instead of charging 2-3 euros for a bottle of water). I only found one set of toilets in the centre but they are there, so dont worry about rushing your visit. I took my lunch in with me and had a nice picnic and took my time through the ruins. Again buy your ticket online, only short queues here but just easier than having to line up and you can swipe yourself straight through the barrier. As many others have said - wear good walking shoes. This is not the day to try out your new stylish Italian heels!!! You will twist an ankle if you do - huge cobblestones everywhere and very dusty and uneven under foot.
A must see once!. It should be one everyone's bucket list! Liked the tour guide's knowledge and humour. The washrooms were inadequate for the number of visitors.

A treasure trove for the history lover. After visiting the Colosseum, we visited the Palatine Hill and Roman Forum. This place is just so full of history and to get the full effect, it is good to go with a guide who can take you through each step in time. An Amazing experience. Come with good walking shoes and a good camera, there is so much to take in and experience
Great Tour. Seeing this place and learning how these people once lived was amazing. The fact that these ruins are even standing is amazing. The tour was in great detail.

Great ancient ruins.. It was an abnormally hot day so we decided to simply walk through a small portion of the Forum and Palatine Hill.That's the the thing though.You can easily choose to see as much or as little and still experience this treasure.Incredible history, causing us to pause and imagine life of the times, how they created what they did and how they lived.On the way to the Coliseum, so convenient to combine in one day.

History Overload. A must see in Rome, coming from Australia the History was intense. Loved the guided tour an the information given, could not believe the physical size of the place and how they built it so many years ago for a place of sacrifice and death.

So much more to see here than we thought. Make sure that you get a good guide book, or take a guided tour. The ruins are incredible and the views are awesome. It can be very hot up there, so take plenty of water.
History. I loved that place. Is the same as the history books, well preserved and very busy. Destination of all tourists.

Beautiful Historical site. I had read about the Roman history before actually seeing the site. The site still has got a lot of character and one gets impressed and you cant yourself from thinking about the days when life was in full swing in this ruins..

Make sure you visit. Just the history and the size, It is impossible to imagine what it is like before you go in. You don't need a guide book. Try to book a skip the queue ticket to avoid a long wait.

Tour Guides. These two sites are within walking distance so you can get a tour guide who offers both for a better price then buying separate tours. There are many guides to choose from so take the time to shop price, personality, and ability to speak loud and clear in your language. Tour guides do have the ability to avoid the long lines you may encounter to enter the sites.

amazing history in this city. There is so much historical treasure in Italy, especially Rome that you get an overload after a while. There are over 50 cathedrals inside the walls of the city. I do wish they would maintain the grounds around these treasures better.

a walk through history. We feel the best approach is to start the day and enter and explore the Forum, before the heat of afternoon sun, then see the Palatine Hill (ticket included for both, and can skip the line w/ Roma pass). The hill is larger, and has more shady spots and can take bathroom/shade break inside the museum. Bring your own bottles of ice water, and can refill at the various running water spots. Bring a sun hat or wear a wetted bandana to stay cool. Wear good shoes, ground is rough, and/or dusty. Then take a break for late afternoon lunch nearby, and tour the Colosseum near sunset, for stunning photos and views in the golden light. Note: the Roma pass includes a Metro pass, so research before buying it. The Colosseum is a separate entry.
Amazing place were history was made. Love it all your imagination runs wild to picture how it once must of looked tiring on the feet but well worth a visit.

Great with small children. Visited with my boys, 10, 7 & 4 as well as my in-laws. There was something for everyone. Amazing photographic opportunities of the ruins and vistas of Rome with lots of space for the children to explore, run and catch lizards, while sneaking in some educational opportunities along the way.

Ancient Rome in front of you. This is the most important art of the Rome which you need to see. It shows the architectural and cultural way of life of the romans. It was the pulsating heart of Rome. Total awsome place

Beautiful and perserved well. Ive been a few times and its brilliant. I can see that the government has tried to protect it this time. They had a film showing while we were there about the history of the forum and that was brilliant.

A jumble of history. It is incredible to be walking where Caesar once walked!
I would recommend getting a guide for this - it can get pretty confusing. A good guide can bring the history to life.
Rome Italy. loved our knowledgeable tour guide, Sabrina. Walking tour was about 5 hours and about 4 miles, but well worth it.

First Time To Walk In The Forum. There is no describing walking around the Forum & trying to imagine what life was like in all its glory. Even in ruins, it is beautiful. The Colosseum, Palatine Hill & The Forum truly are Rome.

Excellent Tour. Beautiful restoration, excellent visit, but needs to have guided tours separated rather than all crowded up together! Most folks are not familiar with the majority of people they are touring with, so it is very hard with so many visitors and groups all crowded in together for folks to keep with their group. The umbrellas all look alike and are not always visible above the heads of the tour guides. Our tour guide did not speak clear English, so was hard to understand through the little speakers that were furnished even with ear pieces. The crowd was way too large for the spaces available and groups were all crowded together. Not a very safe environment let alone a healthy environment.
Very neat. Lots of tourists and pan handlers. That was annoying bc they kept trying to push cell phone holders on us.

Wonderful. The history and stories this area has seen is unbelievable. To think Romans at the beginning of AD were able to build structures which are still standing is unbelievable. We took a tour through Eyes of Rome (google the website) and had a Guide named Karin. She was wonderful and really made the entire place come to life.

I actually cried. So amazing, the first historical place we visited on our excursion and the most emotional. It's hard to put into words the sheer enormity of the Colosseum. So much better with a guide to take you round and be prepared for a good walk around.
Underground & 3rd Tier. Very informative tour which added to our enjoyment.Nice to have a guide to inform and answer questions. Got to see areas that are restricted to small groups.

Must see of Rome. If you are traveling Rome for the first time, these are must see sites, especially if you enjoy history. I highly recommend that you book a tour in advance to skip long lines. We used Walks of Italy which is one of a few that has a trip to the underground areas.

Awe-inspiring and a dose of reality in what the time of the Gladiators was all about!. We took a ship tour from the Royal Caribbean and feel we have checked off one of the important 1001 Places to see before you die! It was sobering, yet fascinating. Don't go on your own, because you will miss some of the important info and history. It's a bit crowded, but in October it was very manageable. I would never go during high tourist season. It would be miserable! Challenging walking especially on the 300 A.D. steps that are quite tall. But wear good shoes and go slow and you'll be fine. A must during your visit to Rome!

No audio numbers. We visited the Palatine Hill and took the audio guide but it was very difficult to find where to stand to listen to the various descriptions. We couldn't find any numbers on the site corresponding to the numbers on the machine. Interesting place though.

Helen, Christine and Liz birthday trip. Amazing very impressive long queues but it didnt take long to get
in and it was well worth it - spectaculat
Book online. Very crowded, with long lines, book and pay online to save some time. Basically what you have seen over the years on television.

Great. It was amazing to see the point of the best thing ever I want to go.
Remembering the old days of Rome and its so much fun in the world.

One of Rome's fascinating historical sites, a must see.. We visited the Forum as part of a walking tour of Ancient Rome. Unfortunately because of time restraints on the walking tour we only saw Palatine Hill from below, but we were so impressed, that we went back a second morning to visit Palatine Hill in detail on our own. Both visits were great. This is a fascinating place to visit. There is no better place or way to get a glimpse into ancient Rome. I strongly suggest, that if you can, that you visit this area with a good tour guide, as we did, as the guides can make ancient Rome come to life before your eyes. However, don't feel the need to buy the skip the line tours (especially the ones out on the streets) as the morning we went back to visit - in peak season and peak time of day - there was no line to skip, we just bought tickets and walked right in.
A Rome highlight. We spent a half day here and could have spent days! The Forum is spectacular but Palantine Hilll is even better. Make sure you have a guide book that explains the history.

Stunning. My best suggestion is getting the Rome Pass, you get to skip ALL the massive queue's which is the worst part about a lot of these landmarks. Also take the time to see these sights from as many different vantage points as possible, and take the time to see them at night. They are amazing testaments to how incredible the Roman Empire builders and architects were. Getting a chance to walk through these incredible historical monuments is priceless.
wonderful. Put on your walking shoes on and enjoy the scenery. This tour was amazing and filled with historical facts. A must see tour in Rome.

Wondeful place. Right next to the Colosseum. Purchased tickets with our Colosseum tickets, so great value! Its like a huge park in the middle of a bustling city..but this is a park with a difference. Roman ruins everywhere and a museum in the centre with lots of information about the site. You could spend hours here as the paths lead off in different areas. It was hot when we went and after walking for hours around Rome we cut short our visit. Hilly uneven walk and plenty of steps dotted about so wear good walking shoes. Lots of guided tours going on along the route. If we had had more time it would have been good to join one of these as there is so much to learn about the site. We took some interesting pictures though and got a real feel for what ancient Rome would have been like. My advice- take a sandwich and a cool drink. Relax under one of the beautiful trees and just take in the views for a while inbetween your trek. We kind of rushed round which is a shame as there was so much to see. If you aren't pushed for time join a guided tour. The ones we passed sounded very informative and interesting.

Impressive, even for a brand name site!. As first time visitors to Rome, my husband and I were thoroughly impressed with these sites! Make sure to do a tour if first timers like us or it is simply too much to take in! Do keep valuables very well hidden, even in low season we learned quickly there is no innocent bumps or touches.

A place you have to visit if you go to Rome. Human history is in this place, you feel how humanity has develop since the time this place was constructed and all the history that his walls keep for us. Before visiting it you have to read a little

Amazing. to stand in a place that is 2000 years old is just amazing. We had a great tour guide who is a archeologist during the cold season. He was wonderful and Able to tell us all kinds of facts and thoughts about what we were viewing. Just amazing
Overwhelmingly stunning. Simply stunning. Nothing much more to say. Also observed diggings going on across the street near Trajans column

Great archaeological sites but... go prepared. We arrived at the site entrance about 1PM and were told they were closing at 3 PM that day. As is typical… no one could tell us why and the official website I had checked that morning made no mention of it. Unfortunately, that’s just a part of touring that’s frustrating but to be expected. So anyway…great archaeological sites but DO all the common sense stuff …be prepared, bring water and wear comfortable shoes kuz its huge and your going to be there awhile.(+3 hrs)Also, unless you can read Italian (some signs have English… some not) or want to hire a tour guide (can be cheap or expensive), I recommend you download beforehand one of the many free (or nearly free) travel apps for your phone like Rick Steve’s travel site has some good one but there are many many others). I was never able to find just one app/site that had everything I wanted so I ended up with an assortment of apps depending on which site I was visiting. It you don’t have info ...you will just end up wandering around this huge site looking at piles of rocks and not really appreciate what it was.And remember the other “golden rule of travel” …if you pass a bathroom …use it :-)

What a place!!. As we walked in the lady at the gate said to be prepared with water and comfy shoes as you will be in here a while.... she was correct!! this place is massive!! my favourite part was towards to Palatine Hill, here there are complete buildings that have been uncovered, you can walk through them. its very surreal. My husband and I walked through this place for 2 hours and still didnt see everything. but after walking around the Colosseum for 1.5 hours we were pretty tired and decided to call it a day. but definitely worth it if you like the history.

WITH A GOOD GUIDE, IT'S ONE OF A KIND IN THE WORLD. I'm rarely moved by buildings or stones. But this is one exception. As a Jew living in Israel, I felt a connection to the period of the ancient Romans. I've seen Discovery Channel research on the Colosseum and that added another dimension to my ability to imagine it in its heyday.Our guide wanted to avoid a scene as we reached the Arch of the Triumph of Titus, knowing that some Jews refuse to visit it with it's glorification of the destruction of the Second Temple and the parade of its (and the Jewish People's) holiest and most treasured items. Not being religious, and being very interested in understanding the story of the times in that place, I asked that our guide take us and go into as much detail as possible.Upon seeing the Menorah from the temple in the arch, I uncontrollably broke down crying as if I'd just lost my entire family. I couldn't believe how it hit me! It took me nearly a half hour to calm down. But I continued to ask questions for more information. It's an astounding place.

Busy but worth it. Head here in the morning to avoid the crowds and wear flat comfortable shoes. This is a must do site in Rome, but plan to spend a whole morning in the area to get the best out of it and the site around the Colosseum

Great History, But Get a Guide. The history of Rome's earliest settlers from the Republic through the Empire is truly fascinating. The remnants of this civilization don't begin to give you a true impression of what was there, so a guide is needed to help you visualize what things were like from the 7th century BC through the decline of the Empire. The Colosseum is an interesting place, but the history of the Palatine Hill and Roman Forum seemed more important.

Include in your itinerary. We planned a visit first thing in the morning to the Roman Forum and Palantine Hill. We seemed to miss the big tour group crowds as they started in the Colosseum (we did that in the afternoon). It is cooler at that time and we skipped the line as part of the Archelogia pass. We wandered around the site by ourselves and found plenty of signs written in both English and Italian that explained each of the exhibits. There are fountains with fresh drinking and clean toilets. Don't forget to visit the museum on the far side of the site.

Fantastic. What a great experience!Such an iconic place to be in! Take your time to soak it all in.Buy your tickets early or at the entrance to the Palatine Hill/Roman Forum ticket office the waiting line will be way shorter.
Iconic landmarks. We took a tour with Walks of Italy and saw these notable landmarks. It was worth the expense to have faster entry into many of the sites and to get expert commentary on the history.
Rome ruins are fabulous. Wonderful to see all the ruins, but pack very comfortable shoes and water bottle and dress for the weather.

So Big. Get a map. Get your walking shoes on. The site is so big. You could easily lose your bearings. Make sure you have a map so it is clear what you are looking at. Otherwise it is hard to know what you seeing. The ticket says it is valid for 2 days. We miss read this and thought it meant we could go back in once we had left. Silly mistake maybe but one we made. It’s a must see but give yourself enough time as you cannot rush it.

Not clear.. We only visited for the final hour before closure so did not see the whole site. It was amazing to experience this most amazing and important place in History. However, it is very ruinous and leaves a lot to the imagination. We were ushered off the site despite there being 15 minutes before closure which was a shame.

Probably better with a guide. I have done my reading before going so I could make out most of it and was helped by the descriptions. Still probably and good guide could paint a more colorful picture. There are long lines and lots of tourists. And lot of sun and walking. Still is amazing to go and see what's left of such huge ancient buildings.

A "must see". Went there at 9:30 am.No line at the ticket office, which was very nice.An incredible experience. Buy tickets tothe Forum Romanum in the same office,and get one more fantastic experience.
history come to life!. The sheer scale of these Roman monuments is amazing! Try to see the garden of the Vestal Virgins with statues, flowers and ponds in the garden.
Amazing!. I love seeing all this places the only downside is since its a huge attraction you will do a lot of walking so wear comfortable shoes!

Ancient Rome. There's no point in visiting Rome without visiting what remains of ancient Rome. An impressive amount of the Roman city still exists and is worth exploring. If you visit all the available sites, it will take a long time, but you can pick & choose as you like. We've visited twice (several years apart). On our first visit, we saw the remains of a wonderful mosaic - you could imagine Julius Caesar or Augustus walking on it. It had been taken away by the time of our latest visit, but you still get the sense of history and the greatness of the Roman empire.

Must see when in Rome.... We've been to Rome before and saw these sites a long time ago. This time we hired a private guide and it was much better as we had a great description of each of the sites and the history. Be prepared to climb stairs and be around a lot of people. Do earlier in the day to avoid crowds and hire a guide to maximize your time and get a lot of information about each site.

A well preserved insight into roman life. The history and architecture still visible here makes for an interesting stroll around (not much shade from the sun though - bring some water with you if it's hot) definitely worth a visit if visiting this area of Rome.

Time to relax. Did this as part of the Colosseum tour and would definitely recommend it. We found it to be very interesting and peaceful after the crowds of the other major tourist attractions. It's the sort of place you could spend hours in with a picnic once you've covered off all the amazing historical elements.

Don't miss Palatine Hill. We went to Palatine Hill first because we were told the lines to get tickets would be shorter. A very fortunate happening. Palatine Hill was an amazing adventure, so much history and a must see in addition to the Colosseum.
GREAT CITY. We love the city of Rome so much to see great food just a fantastic city.so much history if thats your thing shopping is as good as it get,s.

A neighbourhood from Antiquity. After the Vaticani museum, this is the most beutiful place to visit in Rome. You should spend at least 4 hours in it, but totally worth it. It's a pity that it's not so well documented (not enough explanations for all the interesting things that they have in there).

Fabulous historic site. The Palatine Hill and Roman Forum are, to me, must see sites in Rome. The ruins of the historic heart of the empire and the emperor’s palace are incredible to see and to be able to wander down the Sacred Way and stand where emperors, senators, consuls, legionaries and ordinary romans walked was a highlight. There is a lot to see but don’t miss the Temple of the Vestals. There are some houses that you can enter, but these were closed during our visit – it seems odd but the authorities seem to delight in closing key sites during the height of the tourist season.Don’t bother with a guided tour as you can always “overhear” the guides talking to other groups. You should be able to get an audio guide but they seem to have too few to meet the demand.It can take a long time to walk round – we found it took 6 hours to see everything properly. There are toilets and water fountains with cool drinkable water, and you may find unofficial water sellers offering bottles of solid ice at a reasonable price – these slowly melt and are very welcome. Remember to take hats and sunscreen as it can be very hot and you will want to find shaded areas regularly. The streets and paths are uneven so not recommended if you are in a wheelchair or have walking difficulties. I did see one wheelchair user being really shaken about as she was pushed around by her carer.The big problem – as with many places in Rome - is the tour guides who have all adopted the practice of having coloured “flags” on top of high sticks which constantly get in the way when you are trying to admire a view or take a photo.Your ticket lasts for 2 days and also covers the Colosseum so its good value at about EUR 12. One note – you can only enter each site once on the ticket, which is a shame as it would have been better to be able to do half the Forum then come back again.Watch your map for the exits – just because you came in at a location doesn't mean you can also leave that way!If you love Roman history this should be high on your list to visit.

Breathtaking!. Just beautiful, even though it was busy we didn't feel crammed like some tourist places. The art of these buildings must have been gorgeous back in the day as it is breathtaking now. Lots of walking and well worth that money! We didn't do a tour guide just walked around looking. This place is not wheelchair friendly, sadly the pathways are brutal (tried to break my ankle). Wish there was some food carts inside but plenty of drinking water everywhere!

A "Can't miss" when visiting Rome. No matter how long yo are in Rome this is a must-see attraction. The history is amazing and rewarding to be able to see. Our kids 7 and 10 loved this area, as we spent one whole day exploring each site. If you are going in the summer bring a water bottle as it is very hot and you do a lot of walking. (The good news is that Rome is full of natural springs that feed fresh water through fountains.) I recommend you buy the Rome pass as it does offer faster entry in to some sites, and added value. Also many of the historic sites allow children and students under 18 in for free. So keep that mind when buying tickets in advance.
Great place to get back In history. We enjoyed to walking around early in the morning it was not at all crowded and we could take in what Rome would have been,likein the past!!
Could stay here all day. So much history to absorb, I can (and have) absorbed the history and mystery for days, always something interesting to discover
Wow!. Possibly better than the Roman Forum! Fascinating, monumental, evocative ruins. Tours of houses of Augustus and Livia also well worth seeing.

Walking Through History. Visiting the Roman Forum is incredibly exciting to me, realizing that you are walking the streets where so much history occurred. It is a trip back in time to an empire that once was the greatest in the world, and which so influenced our modern society. We were lucky to visit on the 1st Sunday of the month when entrance is free. I've been here before and I hopefully will come here again. It's all just great every time.

More than Expected. During our visit to Rome, my wife and I decided to visit the ancient city. We had no idea what to expect when we went in to the Palatine but found it to be far more than we ever imagined. I was amazed at just how big it was and at how many the different parts there were. There were descriptions at each port of call of the histories and excavations of each area. Admission included entrance to the Colloseum which we found to be rather overcrowded but the Palatine covered far too much ground to ever be overcrowded. It took about four hours to go round but could have taken longer. For me it was one of the star attractions of Rome.

Interesting Ruins. We enjoyed looking at all the ruins of the palaces here - but we really didn't know what we were looking at most of the time. The signage is not great, but if you had a guided tour, it would probably be very interesting. The museum was good & included with the ticket.

historical tour. With just 12 euros one can visit all 3 monuments within 2 days. The paths to visit Palatino are not well organised, so you may see the same things again during the tour.It is a lifetime experience!

Back in time. Loved learning about this amazing time but revolted by the sheer inhumanity of these 'civilised' people. In some ways they mirror our times but in others are quite alien. The buildings - without modern technology or machinery - were stunning, particularly the Flavian Amphitheatre itself.
everything i imagined!. cant really review these amazing sights! it was awesome! dont neglect Palatine Hill...it was a beautiful walk to the forum and to be honest I hadnt heard of it. Beautiful x

Fascinating history. We booked a guided tour which is the only way to get all the info you need about the history of these places. There is so much here to see and our guide from Through Eternity Tours had illustrations of what the places would have looked like in their glory days.
Oh to be able to Remote View by Time Travel. An impressive structure with incredible history - but crowded. Not suitable for people with ambulatory issues.
loved all the history. must have travel guide to learn about different temples and history. You can purchase ticket for all 3 areas.
Looking back in history.. What a experience seeing the ruins of ancient Rome. We spent a good hour walking around the main stretch of sites to see . A short distance from the Colosseum.

a lot to see. This is a large area with a lot to see. The Palatine Museum is small but very nicely thought out. There is a nice sort of high tech display that shows the history of the Roman hills from the earliest known settlements forward. It shows how the first dwellings were built and how the settlements expanded and evolved over time. The Palatine hill and the Roman Forum were interesting as well, even without a guide. There is a fair amount of work going on to restore those areas as well as the Colosseum, which was amazing as well.
Bella Roma. We like the arhitecture, the Churches and the Vatican MuseumsWe don't like the noise and the black people who sale bags on the street

Don't just look, feel the history. This place is not much to look at. Old pillars and old stone roads. But do realize the age of these structures and the historic figures that had walk on those stone roads, suddenly it really is worth your time for a visit.

Ancient!. Fascinating experience and mind-blowing (to me) to think how old all these buildings are. Entrance price is included with colosseum ticket (€12 total). I would buy the ticket at this entrance ( colosseum entrance is way longer!!)

You won't be disappointed!. Have been to Palatine Hill twice now and would not hesitate to go again. Each time we have seen something different. I reccomend that you make time to see the museum which will not take long as it is small plus see the Ancient Fresco's of Emperor Octavian Augustus. The Fresco's were such a treat and a glimpse into the homes of the Emperor's of Rome. Bring good shoes as you will be doing a lot of walking. The views from Palatine Hill are beautiful. When you have finished looking at Palatine Hill then walk down to The Roman Forum. Remember again to leave enough time to see it as there is so much to take in. Leave the Colosseum until last or see it on another day. You don't want to be too tired to see everything.

Awesome!. Awe inspiring and very big! Tremendous feeling of going back in time and breath taking as to what the Roman's achieved with so little resource...apart from the few thousand slaves of course! The Roman Forum & Palatine Hill offer a great perspective of what ancient Rome was like in all its glory. Take a guide, you won't regret it.

A little much. Site is huge. My favorite part (the Forum) you can see large portions of from the street for free. A fairly interesting museum on the Palatine Hill, but disappointing that the two buildings I was most interested in seeing (Casa Augusto and Livia) are special appointment visits only. Base ticket for Colosseum/Forum/Palatine Hill does not get you in. Also hard to navigate from one section to the next (you have to exit and reenter to get from Palatine/Forum to Colosseum). Good tip was to enter from Palatine Hill where there was no line. Also buy ticket online in advance.
So much history!. Second trip to the Forum and Palantine, don't miss the villas close to the Circus Maximus. Be prepared for a lot of walking.
Ancient Rome. History. Crowds are enormous. Get a private guide it is well worth it. The pantheon is amazing as are all of the sites.

Worth a visit!. I loved this place, it is worth spending a few hours walking around. We went later on in the afternoon and had plenty of time to see it all. There were guided tours which looked good however we didn't do one with it being later on. if you are thinking about seeing a few sites it is worth getting a Omnia pass it gets you into the Vatican, st peters Basilica with audio tours and skipping the ques, you get a 3 day bus card and metro card so can use these unlimited and the pass gets you into a number of other attractions it was worth it for us who went around a few different places in the day.

If you love History, this is a must see.. There's an entire area of Rome that's been excavated to reveal a ton of ruins. We had a guided tour which was awesome that took us to the Colosseum and then we walked a few blocks to the Roman Forum and the rest of the Ancient Rome tour. If you have an option to do something like this, I'd definitely recommend it. It was a great way to spend the afternoon. The site itself is about 10-15 feet lower than the current level of streets in Rome, due to thousands of years of dirt and sediment, so there's a slight downhill walk. Great place for history buffs to look around and get a sense of Ancient Rome.
Ancient building. Summer is very hot in Rome but these ancient buildings are worthy to visit. Many wonderful photos can be made here and the price is reasonable.
The Must See in Rome. We did this through City Wonders Tours. How amazing to walk in the foot steps of the ancients. The guides were excellent. Make sure you book to see the lower levels.
Back to the past. Visiting this part of Rome gives you the chance to bring history to reality. Set a least 3 hours to enjoy the visit with no hurry.

Something special. This was an excellent place to visit and one of the benefits of visiting here first then the coliseum is that you don't have to stand in the long que at the coliseum, this is a fantastic place and allows you to visualise how Rome would have looked in the past, what a history trip excellent

One of my favorite sites in Rome. This is a must do in Rome. The ruins are so rich with history, I would recommend doing a little research before going so you have an idea of what you are looking at. This is my second time here and we decided to get the audio guide. Here is a tip. If you get the audio guide ignore the numbers on the map. There are no numbers to coincide with them in the forum or Palatine. There are, however, signs that say what you are looking at and you can cross reference those with the map. Even then it's still really confusing. The information is great you just don't know what the audio guide is referring to half the time. I would go with what other people have said and download a podcast or just read the signs. Also, if you do get an audioguide you have to leave an ID. This place is HUGE with many exits so if you just wanted to exit where you are, let's say Palatine Hill, you can't. You have to walk all the way back to the beginning to return them. Bring water it can get hot and enjoy your afternoon walking through history!!

nothing special. To be honest, this is really nothing special, it's looks like a bunch of polls under construction. The good thing is, it literally beside the Colesseum, and it is included in the Colesseum ticket so you kill two birds with one stone.

A Walking History Lesson. My wife and I took the English speaking tour of the Coliseum and the historical information, mixed with the aesthetics of ancient Rome, were invaluable. After the Coliseum, the tour continued as we walked among a few of the seven hills of Rome, including the Palantine Hill. Our guide was wonderful and she was very knowledgeable and presented facts and historical nuances that left us so intrigued. We were so much more drawn to this locale than if we would have walked this without the tour experience.

Worth the trek. To just walk along and see the architecture and realize a world gone by is amazing. One minute you're looking at new and modern buildings and then, hey, look, the Colosseum. Such a worthwhile trip to walk around and take it all in.

get e-tickets and get there early or late. too many tourists, all the underground tours booked up millennia in advance, it is over-rated, there is so little left to see. make sure you get a reconstruction book for here and the forum or it will all mean nothing to you. the Imperial palaces are more stunning, better remains and mosaics visible. Caracalla's baths are better value in ll senses, do not miss the palazzo massimo museum, and START ON THE TOP FLOOR it is astounding, whole rooms from roman villas.

A must see!. I missed this on my first visit to Rome and now gutted I did as there is so much to see there and we only managed to cover about half of it.I would recommend giving a whole day to see Palentine Hill, Roman Forum and the Colosseum. Just incredible walking around and imagining the old life there.
Palatine Hill. This is an awesome place to visit! Can't believe how the upper crust lived back in those days. Very pretty and nice breeze up on the hill.

Center of Roman public life. It was for centuries the center of Roman public life: the site of triumphal ceremonies and elections were held where public speeches, criminal prosecutions, the clashes between gladiators, and the center of business affairs.

Standing on stones the ancients stood on!. This is why I wanted to go to Rome! To stand and walk on the actual roads that the Romans laid 2000 years ago. To walk through the ruins and think of the stories...to see where Julius Caesar was cremated...and absolute must-do!!

Careful what tour group you choose. We paid good money to avoid long queues and crowds. We got both - despite doing the tour in reverse order - which our guide told us was in order to avoid the crowds. Worst of all, we had to sit and wait for forty minutes while some of our group of twenty lined up for the one working toilet available on the Palatine Hill. Tour guides are supposed to steer you clear of such bottle-necks rather than "explain" that "this is Rome".So, avoid "City Wonders".

Amazing!. for any history buffs this is a real treat. You won't get a better feel for what Roman life was actually like than you do in this place. If you close your eyes and imagine then the place can come alive and the museum helps you to do that even more. We took ages to walk through here on our way to the Colloseum and had the fortune of a very knowledgeable friend with us who filled us in with all of the history. You will need water and a snack or stop off for an ice cream if it's hot. Price is reasonable and the ticket gets you into the Colloseum too. Well worth a visit.

Larger than expected!. A lot of ruins of what must have been once a fascinating and thriving place. A good account of Roman pre-Christ history. It is much larger than what I expected and took a long time to explore but was pleasant all the same. A nice relaxed walk around and definitely much less crowded than other places. A nice extension to the day at il colesseo.
Beautiful view!. Dont miss out on this! The view of the Roman Forum from the top of Palatine Hill is absolutely amazing! Not too much of a hike.

Immense, but very cool. The sheer size of this place will overwhelm you. It seems to go on forever. But every inch of this place is quite amazing to see with your own eyes. It really is amazing to see and experience. If you don't have a guide, make sure you read the signs and get some information about what you are looking at. You will learn some amazing things, I guarantee.

You simply must visit. Not sure of the occasion but it was a "special" day with 1. Euro entry (vs 12 normally) so big lines to enter and quite busy inside but no visit to Rome would be complete without a walk through history. It was warm so take water and wear a hat especially in Spring/Summer

Yet another pile of stones. Can't understand the fascination of other ppl for this. Maybe you need a guide to get useful information; without any additional material this personally gave me nothing. Just because it is well known doesn't make it worth visiting. Plus there is hardly any shelter from the sun.

Incredible. Book online to avoid the queue at the entrance. On the first level take the time to go through the exhibition of pieces found in the site. We bought there a book for our kids where you see Rome main sights how they looked before and how it looks now.There are also VIP tours that take you to 1 level higher.The visit needs to be completed by the visit of the Palatine Hill and Roman Forum which gives the overall picture.Visit with a guide makes sense (many of them are offering their services is many different languages just in from of the Colosseum entrance).

Disappointed.. Was so looking forward to seeing this piece of history... However it was covered in scaffolding. I understand renovation needs to take place but most of the landmarks in rome were when we visited. The Trevi fountain was even closed! So sad not to be able to take photos without all the building material in view!
Great archaeology. Recently uncovered archaeology next to the Coliseum. Well worth a visit, give yourself a few hours to see everything.

Walking in the Steps of Caesars. One of our favorite spots from 17 days in Italy. If you have any interest in history in general or Roman history specifically, you should not go anywhere near Rome without seeing this. Go early in the morning, when the ticket office first opens (8:30 when we were there). Buy your ticket at Palantine, not at the Coliseum (you can get tickets for both there, and do the Coliseum later without standing in line). We arrived at 8:30 and were literally second in line. We had the grounds almost to ourselves for a couple hours, which is enough to pretty well see it. It's also cooler in the morning. Take your camera. You will be walking from Caesar's house to his gardens, to the forum, complete with temples and government buildings. There is a delight at every turning. They have done a remarkable job of excavating, but not restoring or otherwise adding modern touches to these structures. It's a tremendous experience for a fraction of the admission price to most attractions in Rome. We enjoyed it even more than the Coliseum across the street. Don't miss it!

Peaceful park with impressive ruins and fantastic views. The Palatine Hill is mostly a peaceful garden with maritime pines, flowers and olive trees surrounding the impressive and massive ruins of the Roman emperors palaces.Views over the Forum and the city are truly fantastic. It is a unique oasis in the middle of the traffic and tourist frenzy of central Rome.
Must see. These were great ruins and arcgeoligical sites! I used Rick Steves podcast tours to immerse myself in the history. This is truely on of the top must see sites in all of rome

Must do. Big day out. Just fantastic. Worth paying for a tour so you get the right info. If you don't want to do this ensure you take a good guide.Take your time and just stroll around asking up the atmosphere. If you only have time for one my pick is Forum. It is just fascinating. Also great to look down from street level.There always seems to be free tours outside the Colosseum as well which are great.

Awesome. Amazing! Is recommend a tour to get a real idea of what went down at the forum 2000 years ago! The ruins are spectacular. And the palace was huge. It also gives you a fantastic view of the colosseum. Well with a day trip. Back a snack because you will be in the for ages! It's amazing!

Caesar the moment. The Foro Romano is big, the ancient paving stones are uneven, and the Palatine Hill is fairly steep. Moral: wear the most comfortable walking shoes you can get your feet into. Flip-flops or high heels simply won't cut it. There's much to see, but if you go on a sunny afternoon as we did, you'll want a hat with a brim and a bottle of water to carry with you.

The history.... We wandered over here after a tour of the coliseum. I would recommend either a tour or some other information source while walking through this. The history this place holds is tremendous. Wear good shoes as the ground is not level and the walking paths are very rough. There are a lot of elevation changes, I would not call this attraction accessible for the disabled. Also, bring water. There are fountains but they are widely scattered.

This is such an interesting place. Imagine walking around and seeing in your mind how everything grew. They say Rome wasn't built in a day but oh, however long it took it turned out fabulous. I appreciate the restorations I saw going on everywhere. It guarantees that this amazing place will be there for generations to come.
Awesome!. As the birthplace of a Rome this is a 'must see'. I would recommend finding a good guide to make sense of what you are seeing.

What a place!. We went straight into here from the colleseum, as it is included in the price of your ticket. We did not have a guide and I think that would have been helpful, as there is not much information displayed about what each area is. We did get a little amount if information by standing near other tour groups!! The whole area is massive and takes a long time to walk around, but it is fascinating, the history behind it all is very interesting.

Wear comfortable shoes!. This place is huge with lots of walking on stone and uneven walkways. So interesting and miracle that it instill standing and that everyday the excavation continues. Its a good idea to read about it before hand so that when you see it you understand the role and purpose of each of these buildings. Well worth the crowds and the price of the ticket.

Just a part of a wonderful historical site. This hill is home to a number of important structures, such as the large Temple of Apollo Palatinus, from where you can view the Circus Maximus, and the ancient "huts" which are considered to have been the home of Romus, the founder of Rome.It's quite a large area to walk and can take you couple of hours if you read and visit every bit of it. It's nice to visit here before heading to the Roman Forum downhill to the North, where one of the exits is located.

A must after the Colosseum!. This comes handily packaged under one ticket with the Colosseum. We would suggest reserving a whole day to this area. There's a lot of history to take in and read about. Bring some food with you as it could be a long visit. There are many places to get drinking water though.The area to the South of the entrance beside the Colosseum is absolutely huge and much bigger than we expected it to be. Its a good place to see the sheer size of the Circus Maximus to the South and a great view of the city from the West side of that area. See the "huts" of the founders of Rome, the oldest structures of the city.After that the rest of the area spanning from the Via Sacra to the Roman Forum, seems much smaller but is much more crammed with historical buildings, especially noteworthy being Caesar's Temple and the Temple and living area of the Vestal Virgins.

Change the Time. I can't tell here with the words, i feel like i changed the time. It was really worth to wait the long long que. You had to take an audioguide if you don't have a guide (actually you should araound all country), or probably you won't understand the whole area, there is not too much explanation. You can enter Paletino Hill and Roman Forum with Colloseo ticket. Save your whole day for these triple.

Just ok. I went to this using a Roma Pass but there was absolutely no queue anyway. Been before in May and queue was long. Out of the three (Palatine, Roman Forum and The Colosseum), this was my least favourite. although I don't tend to use audio guides so perhaps that was why I didn't enjoy it as much. The grounds were nice and some of the views were good but the signage was non existent so difficult to know exactly where you are. Areas where blocked off but you get the feel of the place.Certainly nice to get a break from the crowds but apart from that, I didn't feel there was much more to it really.If stuck for time, just do Colosseum and Forum.

Wow, very impressive!. You'll need a good full day to get through all of this. Thankfully you can get a ticket valid for two days that also gets you Into the Colosseum as well. Take the road from the colosseum to the Circus Maximus, there is a gated entrance half way down that has much smaller queues than the main entrance! Take your time and plenty of water in hot weather!
Walking through history. Right near the Colosseum, this is wonderful to walk through. It is very well preserved. It's easy to walk around by yourself, but wear comfy shoes.
Interesting history. I have seen the Roman Forum many times. There is just so much history to soak in. You learn something new every time you go. That is why I keep going back!

Amazing. What a wonderful place to visit. We were there in May and it was quite busy. A great place to walk around and take photos. Must has been an amazing place in all it's glory. It's right next to the Colosseum so only a short walk. We didn't do a tour, just wandered around ourselves. Lots of people visiting, especially children. There are people selling bottles of water which is great on a warm day.

Fab. There's very little shade and it's hot! Wear a hat and comfy shoes bring a water bottle to fill from the city's free drinking water supply. A guide book might help but there is plenty of information around this site. By entrance tickets on line and they will also give you free entrance to the gardens and roman villa over the road on Palatine Hill.

A walk through History. Great place to wander through after visiting the Colosseum and is every bit as impressive. Amazing history and there's plenty to read about it along the pathways. The ruins are very well preserved making it easier to picture what it once must have looked like. Wished I had given it more time.

If you want the ruins to come alive- get David Battaglino as your guide!. I had the most wonderful experience on 2 tours with David Battaglino (david-tours@live.com) as my tour guide. He speaks English fluently with a UK accent and he really knows his home town! As a tour guide he is outstanding making all the ruins come to life, a witty sense of humour and has really excellent tips on how to make the most out of a stay in Rome including how to avoid the queues at the popular attractions.I ended up on David's tour as I chose to spend 15 euros on a guided colosseum tour. That tour was not exciting but David collected our tour group after we exited the Colosseum for the 2nd half of our tour of the ruins. Best 15 euros I ever spent!The tour of the Palatine Hill was great although taking all those stairs on a hot day is not a good idea. If you are not fit or not confident on stairs- alert the tour guide as there is a ramp to the top of the hill. The forum was excellent although you don't get a paper map to help you work out which ruin is which.David also ran an evening walking tour (25 euros) where he took us under a church to really see Ancient Roman street level as well as visits to the River Tiber, the Jewish Ghetto, several fountains by Bernini and a look at the outside of the Pantheon. Both of his tours have an easy pace with plenty of opportunities to sit down in the location he is describing.website: www.roman-days.com

Worth the wait. We went on what we didn't realise was free entry Sunday. The que outside wasnt too bad but once inside at the ticket box it was crazy. No organisation no information, just about 100-150 people bunched in front of windows with ticket officers sitting talking to each other. After about 20 minutes and a few angry customers we were then informed that only 1,000 people were allowed in at any time and that was why we were waiting. I don't mind to wait but keep the customer informed...saves a lot of tension and disgruntled customers
So Much History. I love history and I am in awe how old this area is. This is what Europe is all about-preserving the past so others can enjoy it.

Rome Visit. Rome one big Museum we had a great time walking Rome for 4 days exploring every historical church ,museum,and ancient building we could get to. Must have walked 80 miles in those 4 days but it was well worth it. highly recommend a Rome visit

Journey through History. WOW!! This was my 3rd trip to Rome and its still a wonderful sight to see. One can never see the Colosseum too many times. I learned things I never know before. Take a guided tour if possible - especially through the Forum there is so much hidden history that you don't want to miss any of it.

WOW!!!!. These places are just amazing. To be standing in history is just surreal. This historical site is well worth a visit. We had a Roma Pass so entry was free but we then paid for a guide which was worth the extra euro 18 each. They explained the Amphitheatre, Palatine. Hill and the Roman Forum which bought it to life. this is a must see when in Rome. Wear comfortable shoes and take water.

BEAUTIFUL. You could walk round these gardens/ruins all day- perfect picnic destination! Absolutely beautiful! Lots of steps/hills could pose an issue for older tourists, however please don't exclude it from your trip- take your time to mosey round- stunning!

Best "attraction" ever. If you want to see how the Roman people lived then this is the place to go.You can see a variety of buildings and thanks to the information panels, you can read a lot of interesting information which leads you through the buildings in a nice atmosphere.When you buy this ticket, you can also visit the Colosseum with it and you don't have to wait in the line anymore.So visit the Roman Forum in the morning and go with the same ticket to the Colosseum in the after noon!

Up close and personal. While the Colosseum and surrounding areas are crowded in August, we very much enjoyed our afternoon wandering around Palatine Hill. There was so much to see and you are able to get up close to ancient history. Plenty of water fountains available, bring a water bottle to refill.
Amazing. The size of this place is amazing!! You felt like you were transported back in time with the audio guide.

Underwhelmed. Maybe my expectations were unrealistic but this was just fair. If you go, definitely go on some kind of guided tour. I am interested in roman history, especially Ancient Rome and figured this would have been one of the highlights of the trip. If was just fair.

explore the ruins with a guide. we explored the Roman ruins with our guide Anne Hogan and got a wonderful introduction to the life of ancient Rome. Anne showed us what the structures would have looked like 2000 years ago.

Better in real life. This is a place that you can spend hours walking around and never get board just the scale of it and the different parts of the culture that you can explore are so incredible this is defiantly a once in a life time place to visit and I carnt recommend it highly enough
Worth it!!!. Take the grand tour, really recommend the guided tour including third floor and underground. History at it best!

Wonderful. This was just as expected ,to stand there and imagine what it would have been like was in readable .We got a talking tour tape .which helped a lot and only cost 6 eur . Watch out for the hat seller out the front I was hot and went to buy a hat ,the police chased away the seller .. Disciplined me ,it is illegal .

Nice but not very exciting. Although this attraction is not one of my favourites, I would still recommend visiting it because it is one of Rome's main tourist sites. It's not very interesting inside so taking a look from the outside is enough.

A must see in Rome. Amazing history surrounds this building. We had a semi-private tour and skipped the long lines. Also, our guide gave us background information that allowed us to have a full experience of this magnificent structure.
A must visit. Probably the biggest landmark. Breathtaking. Take in a Pizza at the nearby resturants and admire the view.
History. This was awesome to see in person like so many other historical sites. I highly suggest a tour guide to get the most from your visit.
Good old days. The history that has been preserved is incredible. Being able to view this and reflect on the past only helps one appreciate our lives now.
Ancient Rome. A must see while in Rome!!! We did this in a day with Real Rome Tours. It was a great way to learn about what we were seeing. Our kids, ages 8 & 10 loved it as much as we did!
Outside view is good enough. no need to go inside.. For me it was just enough to see it and take some picture from the outside. unless you are a real history fanatic guy or you're in love with italy.

Amazing! What else can I say??!!.
