One of your best chances to see 2000 years old history with your own arts, one has to wonder what people coming to Rome from the provinces living in little shacks must have thought. Highly recommend to come early in the morning before the crowds arrive, but also late in evening when it's dark and certain areas are illuminated, it gives everything very cool atmosphere.

Great history. Anywhere you go in Rome there is 2000 year of history there! This is a place you have to go see! It's huge and amazing. I suggest buying your tickets online and print out your tickets and you get right in! Amazing place.

Must see in rome. Amazing and fascinating to see remains of roman civilization almost dating back to a century before Christ.
It makes sense to have a travelbook or guide as there is so much history in there that mere looking around will not be an enriching enough experience,

Roman forum wow. My trip to Rome was fantastic but one of my favourite bits was the roman forum just amazing the place the views the history .the gardens at the top of the forum are beautiful lime trees fountains .the forum it's self was great but the palatine hill I was a little broad at this point but please don't be put off by this because it's all worth the expairance.

nice walking there. Nice place to walk and talk. It takes you at least 4-5 hours to go around, so arrange you time. A suitable tour is 1 day for the Forum and Palatino, and the other day for Colosseo.

Numerous ruins set in a beautiful setting. A lot of walking is required.. It was historical, interesting and the area is beautiful. You are immediately aware of how long ago all of this took place and now you are part of history.

Magnificent Ruins!. It is hard to believe that the center of Roman life began here! use your imagination to take you back to ancient Roman civilization as you imagine the Palace, the government and the socializing that took place.
Amazing site. Edifice well preserved with an inside museum section.Palatine Hill was fairly large with multiple ruins throughout.
Forum. Loved walking around it was like a Living History Book. In fact all of Rome is like a Living History Book
Sheer Bliiss. Hard to find a cab, but otherwise it's just fantastic, could have spent more time just wandering around
Wow. It's amazing what they did back in 72A.D.! If you go in the summer, make sure you take a hat and plenty of water.

Amazing. It was everything I expected and more. I chose to take a guided tour so I could be sure not to miss any historical details. While the tour was good, I wish we had been allowed to wander around on our own once it was over instead of being led out when the tour was over. I did get some amazing pictures, though.

History as it is. What can be better than standing between all those ruins and imagine ancient Roma, and ancient Romans passing by? Very interesting, but it's better to do some additional readings before visit, just to understand what is it all about.

Amazing sights. Brilliant, we loved every minute - we used a tour guide but not that impressive, her knowledge was limited and she was thrown when asked questions that did not fit with her planned talk.
Magnificent. Get there early and make sure you have a Roma pass to avoid the queues ( which start early). Get an audio guide as it is well worth while. If in August take a hat and LOTS of water.
Truly Amazing. I love Rome, read a lot about it and it felt so good to actually see it. History came alive for me, like a trip back in time. No need for a guided tour
Sad2014. Great to see but we couldn't help thinking about the dreadful things that happened here in the name of "Sport"

Amazing. The size, the architecture, the thought of such a complex structure having been built almost 2000 years ago -!!. Easy access, reasonably priced entry, even with thousands visiting , can acommodate without crowding.

Amazing. That ancient buildings are impressive! The collumns of the pallatine, the stone walls of the Coliseum, the gardens, all of that make us think and almost live in the past. Its the most important site of Rome in fact!

First day in Rome -wow. So much bigger than we thought
A lot to see
Amazing
Allocate a lot of time to your visit
Wear good walking shoes
Be careful of gypsies/ pick pockets and hawkers
Amazing. Highlight of any trip to Rome. Well worth the admission cost. i would recommend purchasing these online, before your trip. Needs a guide to bring it to life.

Guided tour of underground. Buy tix ahead or you will wait in long lines. Underground tours are smaller so you can actually ask a question. Since 20,000 people visit daily, its nice to get a good guide who will tell you in your own language. But you don't see much down below, most of the tour is above ground. And it's not cheap.

Amazing !!!. Just love it and love Rome.
You can think about Gladiator if you want because it does feel like you could have been there.....
A great chance to get into history and belong.........
Enjoy enjoy enjoy....
Worth Seeing. Loved the grand scale and history. Ignore the people outside trying to sell tickets - we didn't have to line up at all. No need to take a guided tour.

Easy to get lost in. It was OK to look at. We wouldn't have gone if it didn't come with the Colosseum ticket. We got really lost in there and it was a hot day which was frustrating. The old palace was cool to look at, it's huge. There's lots of ruins all over this area of Rome so you don't need to go here to see some.

Awe inspiring..... This is most definitely the heart of the Roman Empire. Iconic monuments, Ceasar's grave, temples, the Curia...and so much more. Wear your walking shoes, there are uneven pavements and this is not the place to wear anything uncomfortable. Not ideal for strollers either. There are also fountains here to get water and fill your bottles. Bring your cameras, hats and be prepared to take in history. Its incredible.

Unreal!. Get your colosseum ticket and combine it with Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum. Palatine Hill is just breathtaking, there is a lot to see and ton of excavation still going on. The Emperor Augustus' home is there, along with Casa di Livia. The story of Romulus and Remus took place here as well. This is historical excellence. Bring your sneakers, water and hats and prepare to walk and enjoy!

Insight of antique Rome. These are must dos when one is visiting Rome! They are all in the vicinity of one another and you get to buy a single ticket which includes entrance to all of the 3 properties. Visit early in the morning as shady areas are limited. Places can be very crowded as they are all very popular.
Fab!. Book the tour for extra euro - it's worth it! Full of history and information, you would struggle to gain the knowledge without the guides
So impressive. Hard to take it all in, and the 3hr walk-around flew by! Could spend the whole day there and not be bored.
Under construction. Scaffolding covered the most part which was disappointing, but what we could actually see was pretty cool, I didn't go in though

No tour needed. If this was the Three Tenors, the Palantine Hill would be the third guy that no one knows his name. However, this is a travesty as the Palantine Hill is probably the best of all 3 attractions. The Colosseum is the big draw for the history but it was just a big oval (think of a basketball arena after the game is over).
Okay. Not what I expected! Way too crowded! The lines are long and it costs just to get inside to see and the crowds were pushy!
Gladiators and all that. Sheer size, the history and what it represents. Shows how advanced the Romans really were! 1 visit is not enough.

Book online!. How can you go to Rome and not visit here?
Speaks for itself really - an amazing experience.
Only tip would be to book your tickets on line, as we beat all of the queues! and this was so worth it!
Awesome. Awesome views even with the construction going on to fix the property, make sure you get water from the street vendors, long walk wear comfortable shows.

Well worth a visit.. Huge queue for colosseum. Don't go to that queue! Walk up a bit to Palatine Hill, queue a lot smaller there and the ticket gets you into the Colosseum also. A lot of walking in the Forum area so might be best to go here before the Colosseum. Take water also! No water sellers allowed in the area.

History at its best. This was the heart of the Roman Empire and you must see it. If you want to see it all it will take several hours. Take water, look out for water taps there are several and the water is good to drink. Wear good shoes as it's rugged in places. There are two exits so plan where you want to come out. One is back at the Colosseum and the other is by St Peters prison. This one is up a very steep set of steps so be aware if you have difficulties.

Fantastic City Wonders Tours. Our tour guide Alessandro was great! This is a three hour tour in the hot roman sun but Alessandro kept us entertained the entire time. The picture reconstructions of all of the ruins really helped to understand what the sites looked like in their heydays. Alessandro's passions for archeology really rubbed off on us and the mobile headsets really helped to hear and follow the tour.

Simply amazing. The whole area is just remarkable. Ruins everywhere and very interesting for a history enthusiast. You also see an interesting blend of modern living in between the historical monuments/infrastructure. A word of warning though, the area is very touristy and is swarming with pickpockets so be vigilant.

Simply a must - it lived up to it all!. Just go there, walk through Augustus Forum en route, if you can, past the huge Emmanuel II monument and you cannot avoid being amazed and impressed at the Coosseum.TIP: go buy your tickets at the Pallatine Hill just overlooking the Colosseum - it covers all three (i.e. including the Roman Forum too). Virtually no queue - Colosseum was packed with queue we could walk right past, brilliant:-)

Wow. History at its finest. Arguably one of Rome's most famous and iconic monuments,it is one of the Roman world's biggest amphitheatres and is one of the city's most visited attractions. We spent a day here. My highlight was julius caesar grave.
Roman forum. Fantastic go go the history of the place is amazing buy a fast track ticket you can just walk in no queuing

Lots of history!. We viewed the forum before the colosseum and it's worth viewing for sure. There are lots of ruins still visible as well as remains of marble sculptures. Get a map from the gate when you buy a ticket so you have more of an understanding of what your looking at.

Awesome. What a place....huge and ancient, and you get a real sense of what would have been happening there back in the day. Advice....definitely book online before you go, otherwise you'll be in a queue for quite a time!

Simply in awe. I had seen this before. My husband had not. I had completely forgotten how awesome it is.He convinced me to walk so we got the full view as it came at us from the distance.Normally I'd jump off at the outside train station Collisimo, take a photo and leave immediately!Not today. I was about to praise him for his decision making skills when the heavens opened and I ended up looking like a drenched rat! Never mind. Watch your pockets as the area is rife with pick pockets and beggars.Steeped in history the inside is well worth it if you've never seen it, but not when it's raining.Expect cheesy gladiators outside all looking to get a few quid off you to pose.I still can't stop humming the gladiator music whenever I see it. It's impressive, and continues to wow me each time I see it.

Pace yourself at Historic Sites. You should consider a guided tour. So much history and things to absorb. Buy your drinks before you get too far in the Forum. All three sites can be done in 3 hours but alot of walking (hot in summer).
A must visit place when you are in Rome. It's a great way to avoid long Queues in colosseum. This place is worth of visit, ensure you wear a comfortable shoes as you will do lots of walking.

What You Would Expect, But Still Should Do. First: Get a €36 Roma Pass at the train station, tourist info booths, or tabacci shops.We tried to buy our Roma pass at the Forum and then Palatine Hill.Neither location had them.(I don't know if they were out or never sell them.)If you're pressed for for time, skip Palatine Hill.

Rome at its best. If you came to Rome, you have to go to the Roman ruins. The tourism in the city is all about these places. It is a travel back into the past. Tip: go first to the Roman Forum. The lines are much smaller and the combined ticket will let in the Colisseum without having to wait hours in line.

lots to see and lots of walking. phew where do you start with all the history, we had a Roma Pass which got us in free to all of the above, and im sure we missed some of it even though we walked for hours, take a drink and some packed lunch if need be as restauarants can be expensive

Can't miss!. The sense of history thru many ages pervades these places, and they are organized well for tours. I would not recommend the Palatine Hill for anyone with trouble walking as there is much uphill on cobbled walks, many turns, and no places for bathroom visits except at the entry. There are fountains available here as throughout Rome where you can fill up your water bottle - carry them with you!

Amazing Amount of Ancient History. Dating to the 7th Century BC, the history packed into this site is overwhelming, from the House of the Vestal Virgins, where sacrificial fires were kept burning, to Temples to Ancient Gods, this site marks where Julius Caesar walked and was cremated after his assassination, and where, many years later, St. Paul walked and preached. Do not miss this site and take time to do some historic research prior to visiting. The history is overwhelming. While you can easily walk in and take some photos of the main area, which is compact, take time to explore the entire area, including the wooded hillside. It's amazing. There are many photo opportunities.
A must see sight in Rome. Take the guided tour of all three. --it is worth it! To avoid the Q take the tickets from Palatine Hill Ticket Office . Audio guides would be good too.

Well Managed. This was a site I was worried about due to tourist interest and traffic, but they blew me away with how organized, professional, and helpful they are.Unlike the rest of Rome, it is extremely well marked where to go, where to exit and how to get to each of the ruins, and what they stand for.Really enjoyed this walk, touring on our own. Beautifully organized and truly a fun afternoon spent.

ancient Rome at its best. We visited the Colosseum & the surrounding ruins on Palatine Hill in August. The site is outstanding & would definitely recommend. The Palatine Hill & the Roman Forum site is fairly extensive so be prepared for some walking over uneven rough paths. It is amazing that a site of such national importance is situated right in the middle of the city practibly opposite tourist hotels. A word of caution thou, be aware or the sellers trying to offer all the normal souvenirs, if you are interested barter & only pay what you think they are worth. also be careful with the Romans in their costumes outside offering to appear in your photographs, know your price & how many photos you can take before you start & stick to it. We were happy at 10 euro"s for as many photos as we liked with 2 legionnaires & stuck to it even after that then tried to squeeze us for a further 10.
So much to see. It's so centrally and conveniently located next to the Colosseum you can't miss it. There's also so many ruins and history behind it all, it's a must see.

SO BUSY. Skip Europe in August; it's miserable with the tourists and the peddlers. I love Italy, but the tourist attractions are unattractive while waiting in lines. Best bet is to go later in the afternoon when it's not so crowded. I love the Forum more, and Palatine Hill is definitely worth exploring. Bring a refillable water bottle and fill it up from the cisterns around; the water is good and it's cold. Just so incredibly busy in August...and hot.
Get a tour. You will not really understand what you are seeing unless you have a guide. The Roman Forum was a specific highlight for me because of all of the history.

A Must See. Worth going in and seeing. Amazing history and a must see for any traveler, history lover, or those interested in emercing themselves in anchient roman history. Beautiful on the outside, facenating on the inside.

History makes you feel small. You will be impressed. Standing there, with hundreds of other people, all around the world, smelling, touching one of history's biggest statement. Looking down, where the gladiators used to wait for the fight of their life. Walking around where the spectators would decide their faith.If you want to make your experience even better remember these two tips : there is drinkable water in the colloseum - look for the sign, leading you to a little fountain, dated in ancient times. You don't have to wait for hours in line. If you get the Roma Pass you can skip the line.Trust me, you'll be glad you did.
Amazing. You'll know everything you want to know about beginning of Rome. I've never seen anything like this amazing before.
loved it. Very organized tour. Very knowledgeable tour guide and helpful. Willing to answer random questions. Clean bathrooms.

Magnificent and awesome!. Unmissable and awe inspiring! The ticket queues were horrendous in August but booking on line will get you in quicker and costs only 2 Euros over the normal ticket price of 12 Euros for adults and my teenage daughter was free.The combined ticket also gives you access for a 48 hour period to the Palatine hill and Forum which are also a must see. Top tips would be to wear flat shoes and take your own water in with you due to cobbles and uneven ground. The colosseum itself is mind blowing!
As AMAZING as you'd expect. Amazing place. Audio guides good, but the whole place is so crowded that the listening points were often not easy to find.
Absolute outstanding. Great momument!all people must go there at least once!take the tour cause you will understand better the history of thta momument
Fantastic. This is great to see how the Romans could build this so many years ago. I highly recommend to have a guide to make the most out of the tour

Overwhelming. Avoid the queues by purchasing tickets on-line and collect from the Forum ticket office. A lovely quiet walk through this ancient part of town with fantastic views of the Colosseum. Water fountains available and very necessary in the heat of July.
Very Busy. A fascinating building - for best photos of the exterior, climb the mini hill to the right hand side of the entrance.

Amazing history. Get your tickets at Palantine Hill instead of going to the Colosseum for both the Forum and the colosseum. Will save you lining up for ages at the colosseum. Do the Forum first and then go across to the colosseum.
cool place. a good way to spend a few hours and try to imagine how it would be like in ancient roman times. lots of signs around too, so dont think you need the audio guide.
nice place. An interesting place, somewhat peaceful despite the crowds. Lots of poppies growing around too if you are interested in that. You can also see Emperor Augustus's house in here.
great view of history. Roman history in full view. This was a hightlight after seeing the Colosseum as this was my first time in Rome I was glad to have made the visit. A must see!!

Roman history. A wonderful place to soak up Roman history. A pleasant walk through the streets surrounded by remnants of the ancient era. If you love your history then this is a must see. Be prepared to spend a while here as there is so much to see and so much atmosphere to soak up. Do not buy bottles of water from outside venders, just take a bottle and fill it from the water fountain inside.
great day trip. I must say this was one of the highlights of the trip along with the collaseum. truly remarkable and a place that is must see if you are visiting rome for the first time.

Classic Western Civilization Heritage Site. Incredible site filled with identifiable and uncommon remnants of the empire. Italy could do so much more in terms of providing interpretation and deepening the visitor's understanding of this very large and invaluable site.

A must do. Probably not the most well known historical site to see in Rome but certainly worth a visit from vista point looking down on the Forum. A meeting place/market in the old days you can easily imagine what was going on here with a good knowledgable guide. A short stroll towards the Colesseum as it is not far at all.

Great Historical Site to Visit. There was almost no line when I went there and the ticket is good for the Colosseum as well, the line for that site is huge and you skip it if you have a ticket already. I did the audio guide tour but my wife knew alot of the history so I didn't really need it. If you like history, check it out.

Awe inspiring. Did you know....- The word 'palace' originated from 'palatine'?- Experts say people lived on Palatine Hill since 1000 BC- Roman mythology says this is where Romulus and Remus were found by the she wolf- The first ever emporer of Rome, Augustus, was most likely born hereThis is an absolutely amazing place to visit. The history is so rich you can almost smell it.Palatine Hill is full of old ruins that were home to Rome's elite. It's easy to imagine how opulent they once were.You're able to walk among many of the ruins and really get a feel for what it was once like as well as get a great view from the 40 metre high hill.I am surprised this site was so quiet when I visited. it seems as though many are missing out on this gem.Spending extra on a guide at Palatine Hill would also be well worth it.

Impressive. Ticket to this place is combined with Colloseo, so this is a must see place, and if you think that you can see everything without entering, you are wrong (I thought that first). It is so impressive, when You know from what times these remains are. And from this hill there is amazing View. There are places where you can drink cold water, and you need it there. Dont be on a hurry, better take more time, read information, it is worth to know about these places.

Incredible. Dedicate a day to this one folks - it's a biggy.There is so much history here that you can only take it in if you don't rush through. This is a living museum with so much ground to cover, it can be overwhelming. I would recommend getting there late morning and calmly strolling around Palatine Hill before descending into the lower area before the sun sets around closing time for some great photos.It's almost to much to take in that your walking amidst structures built thousands of years ago and sharing the walkways that were used by ancient civilisations.You may struggle to keep children entertained if you intend to see the whole thing.

Wow!. Just couldn't get over that I was really there! So much history! So much to try to take in. Had a tour guide at Palatine Hill and she was very good. But it took forever at some of our stops. Unfortunately we only had one day in Rome and wanted to go to other places. We felt that maybe we should have skipped the tour. But then you would miss out on all the details. There is just so much to see and try to understand and take in. Suggest you do Palatine Hill and the Forum and maybe another attraction in one day. Not try to see everything at once. It was our first time to Europe and we plan to go back to Rome and spend more quality time.

take a guide. From the outside an impressive ruinbut take a guide ( we had a very good one ) and this amzing place comes top life.
Allow at least 2 hours to take it all in and a water bottle is a must you will need to stop several times at the many water points during the summer heat.

Skip the queue for the Colosseum and you get the Roman Forum plus so much more.. We weren't going to 'waste' money on a skip the Q tkt for the Colosseum (which also included the Forum & Palatine Hill) , but the sun, the heat and the long line to get in quickly changed our minds. This also meant we had a guide to improve our knowledge and enhance our journey through both these impressive historical landmarks. Our guide for the Colosseum was good and we did learn quite a lot but when we got handed over to our guide for the forum things really stepped up a few notches. The guide, David Battagliano was not only extremely knowledgeable but the ease at which he imparted it made it so enjoyable and made the heat almost bearable. His sense of humour, wit and slight sarcastic slant on life was a welcome change to the usual tour guide, but most of all his tips and helpful hints about Rome were invaluable. He made such an impression on us that we actually went on a further 2 tours with him. One, an evening walking tour of Rome, which was brilliant but the best was the day trip to Ariccia where we went to Angelos Osteria and had a pasta making course and then ate what we had made (plus lots more) not to mention the wine. Our fabulous day ended with a visit to a lovely park overlooking Rome which was filled with orange trees, the smell of which was amazing. The whole experience is something that won't be forgotten in a hurry.

Amazing place to visit but complete lack of information. Amazing place to visit in Rome but a distinct lack of information available at the key locations within the ruins. Would need a guide or other information source as a visitor to get the full benefit of the visit.

You can really feel the history of this place. I absolutely loved the forum, perhaps even more than the colosseum. I just started wandering around and I got this feeling of how things must have been back there... I think the way the ruins are nowadays still shows a lot. The place certainly has a feeling of its own. I would recommend you not to skip it at all! And just sit somewhere to try to get the feeling

Great taste of old Rome. We visited here the day after visiting the Colosseum. The same ticket was valid for this attraction.Having tickets already meant we walked straight in, but this meant no opportunity to collect a map, audioguide or any other guide. Nonetheless, the Forum is an impressive location with many fascinating features, you can feel how the area used to look.Palatine Hill is a fair walk, especially in the August heat, luckily there are plentiful water fountains located around the main pathways. There are some excellent views of the Forum and the Colosseum also.Well worth a visit, especially if you have been to the Colosseum and have access anyway.

Terrible. Positive - The ruins and the excavations. The history of the place. The scale of the ruins. The majesty.Negative - The written descriptions are poor. The bathrooms are poorly maintained and smell horrible. There are no places to get water or food once inside. The water fountain water is not drinkable, although others out of desperation were filling up their water bottles with the water. On a hot day, the site is sweltering with very little shade. It can be a test of persons patience and resiliency. Often it is too crowded and the tour groups all compete with each other to see who can get to the bathrooms first. Expect to stand almost the whole time. Handicapped persons will have a very difficult, if not impossible, time getting around.
Tranquil History. Amazing place! I could have spent the day here. The ruins were incredible and wonderful to get up close and touch them. You can wander for hours. Fantastic views from up on the hill

Beautiful ruins . Lots of ruins from Ancient Rome and wonderful to see. Lots of walking involved. Bring water and hats as not much shade. You can't buy food in here but there are fountains to top up on water.

Excellent value!. It's free if you go on the first Monday of every month for some reason and there's so much history to take in that you could spend all day here.Fortunately once you are inside the gates you are also protected from the hoards of thieves and scam artists lurking around outside. Be very wary of the locals. They're thoroughly unpleasant at best and downright dishonest. Even the state will try to rob from you at every turn with fines for everything including the common scam on the trains. Fail to 'validate' your ticket at a second (usually hidden and always unsigned) machine in the station before you leave and you'll be hit with a minimum of €50 fine despite having the correct ticket with the dates and journey clearly stamped on it!!!! They caught 3 other groups in the same carriage as us and almost every tourist we spoke to had been hit with this. After a couple of days of having to queue twice at public transport hubs for this nonsense, fighting off the scam artists and thieves plus seeing the miserable, unhappy faces of the locals glowering at the very people who bring so much money into their failing state I'd tell anyone thinking of a trip to Rome to really think again and choose a more welcoming destination instead.

Ancient Rome. What a great educational experience in Ancient Rome. Six in our group with a private guide who gave us such wonderful information on this area. The Colosseum was beyond our expectations as we roamed through this great structure. The history outside in the surrounding areas of the Roman Forum were outstanding.

Great view. Although we did not fully see all of the Roman Forum, Palatine Hill was still great to look at. Prepare for quite a bit of walking as you are walking uphill and there are a few steep steps, but once you get to the top, it's completely worth it. The ruins are worth seeing and are fascinating to look at.Me and my boyfriend used our Roma Pass to get in for free, however if you don't have a Roma Pass you will have to pay (unsure of how much it actually costs). If you do buy a ticket, it will give you access to the Roman Forum, Palatine Hill and the Colosseum, whereas the Roma Pass does not also provide access for the Colosseum unless you still have attractions left on your pass to use.Make sure you get to the top of the hill to see a beautiful view of Rome!

Full of history. These impressive ruins are full of history. You can admire many monuments remains that were build on the Palatine Hill. This place will also provide you a nice view on a few sides of the place. I would recommend that you get a tour guide if you want to learn a lot about that place. You will walk a lot, but this is very interesting! Since some areas are very crowded, beware of pickpockets! The ticket you buy for coliseum also give you the entrance for this site. You can buy it online and skip line if you pay 2 euros fee for reservation.

History right in front of you.... I was really fascinated to see the remnants of the ancient city of Rome. I could not imagine that I was standing where a city had actually existed thousands of years ago, looking at structures dating back to the 5th century BC. What struck me most was seeing where Julius Caesar was killed. I was really in awe of this amazing glimpse into the past. This place is mystical and truly mind-blowing, putting history right in front of you.

Beautiful walk through ruins. If you enjoy and want to do a nice leisurely walk through ruins, this is worth doing. But you definitely need time. We visited the palatine hill after the colosseum and the roman forum and were exhausted! We started with the colosseum at 9 am, finished viewing the forum by 11 and then continued to the palatine hill. By then it was incredibly crowded and hot! It was busy and crowded but less so than the roman forum.

Nice view. It is located next to Piazza(means square) Vanezia. It depends how long time do you have to visit Rome but if you dont have much time U shouldnt get inside for a walk also You can see the place while you are walkin on the street :)But this year a big part of Historic places are under restoration. And I dont recommend you to visit Rome until the restoration will be end. You can not see the Love fountain Spagna and Collesso coz they are all under restoration.
Great learning and exploring history. It's best to get the ticket that includes the Colosseum visit as well. It's worth the visit for the whole day. Enhances and adds your history knowledge.

Took longer to see these than expected.. My family took a whole day to experience the Roman Forums, Palatine Hill and the Coliseum (we bought tickets online and are so glad we did, bypassed the queue and went straight in). Palatine Hill took much longer than I expected. It is much larger than I expected with paths going off in all directions. Don't miss the archway towards the old vineyard. At the top is a lovely view of the Coliseum and surrounding areas. We also queued to see Augustus' house (Cassa di Augustus), and although it was amazing to witnesses frescoes from over 2000 years ago, not sure I would queue again just to see 3 old rooms. It was very hot, and an uncomfortable slopped queue. Lots of walking, so make sure you are wearing comfortable walking shoes. I wore my flip flops, and what with all the uneven surfaces, stones, cobbles, dust, etc, in hindsight, my feet got a definite work out, and got very dirty. Also, once you are inside, there are no shops to purchase water, food or other refreshments, so make sure you take water and a few bits to munch on. There are a few water fountains to fill up your bottles, so you can stay hydrated at least. Enjoy!

Amazing history!. Fantastic, although we found the organization for ticket buying and info a bit confusing and not 100% efficient.Getting tix, aside, roaming the colessum and forum were helpful using Rick Steve's audio casts.

Enjoyed half day at this place!. I don't know if others have the same taste of mine or not, but me and my wife enjoyed half day walking around in this place. The nice weather helped off course, but we really enjoyed the place. For me, it is one of the best places I visited in Rome.

Must do - With a tour guide. Its a big area/garden with ruins and buildings I highly recommend doing this in a tour as without you would miss all of the history. If I hadn't done this in a tour I would have been bored and given it less stars.

Not to be missed. Helpful to read up on this area before visiting to see what it looked like in the beginning days of Rome. It is amazing that these structures are still standing after all of these years and this was a great history lesson for our teenager. Give yourself at least a few hours, it is hot in the summer but there are water fountains and shady areas located throughout Palatine Hill so keep a water bottle handy to refill. You can also see Circus Maximus from Palatine Hill.

Walk through ruins. If you like ancient Rome and history, i think this is one of the best places where you can see in one place the greatness and might of the Rome from the time of its glory.Also, one of the positive things about it is that there is not a lot of people.

Better Views than the Colosseum!. I am really glad I did this. These ruins are much more interesting than just one stadium. It used to be a commercial hub and has some great views. Don't miss this, especially if you're going to the Colosseum.

Huge chunk of history. The ruins of ancient Rome make for a great day.It's a very large park filled with ruins from the ancient times.We went in July so it was very hot outside, but luckily there are drinkable water fountains all around.The Stadium and the Mundus (the entrance to the underworld) were my favorite places.Take very comfortable shoes fitted for rugged terrain for more comfort.

Great place to start your Rome tour. This was our first stop when we visited Rome with our cruise ship. We managed to avoid the long queues for tickets by purchasing the tickets online .Tip: you can purchase entry tickets to this site from the nearby Palentine entry gate well. Less queues.We were able to cover the whole site with in less than one hour. Best to go early in the morning when the gates open that midday.The view from second floor is the best for photographs.

Very good. Its very good if you have an entertaining tour guide! I had a Chelsea fan escort us, his knowledge was amazing and entertaining… however his choice of football clubs left a lot to be desired. ;-)

really nice - take some time for it. we went here after visiting the colloseum. take time to go through the area. you will see amazing things and have great views over the city. highly recommended to have a guide. this part is included in the ticket for the colosseo.

Lots of history. This was quiet and beautiful to walk through, although many couples took the opportunity to show their amorous side and take up the pathways, so you will have to try to skirt around them. Signs are in Italian and English!

A nice walk through history. This is a great place to see Roman history. To make it even more interesting, use the free Rick Steve's app that gives you a guided tour. Give yourself at least a couple hours in this place.
Worth the time spent under the sun. It was a hot sunny day when we went but it was worth all of it, the place does give you a glimpse of the Romans life and their important part of the city.
Impressive ruins!. Good place to go for a walk And chill out picnic take In the views and sights! Lots of interesting artefacts in the museum enjoyed the sight!

beautiful. Thia massive complex is very imressive, and you will be overwhelmed by all the ruins and history there is to take in. Have some sort of guide (audio or book or person) on hand to explain what you're seeing, otherwise it's impossible. It takes a while to see everything and there is very little shade. There are, however, water fountains, so bring a water bottle

After Colosseum just Ok. Maybe if we visited this site before impressive Colosseum we would have better impressions but after it was a bit disappointing. History of Forum is interesting,but a lot of work going on across the site that blocks your way quite irritated and confused us. In general we didn't regret very much that attended this place, but if I knew whole picture in advance, I would better visit more bassillicas and churches.

An escape from the forum on a hot day: head for the hills. The Palatine Hills are elevated above the tourist bustle of the forum and a suitable viewpoint for pitying the queues waiting to get into the Colosseum, a place ito enjoy & savour on a hot summer's day. Shady trees, places to sit and exciting cool tunnels to negotiate May be missed by many package tourist seen clustering under the occasional tree below.You can even listen to some of the guides from the balcony above or pay a little extra to use an audioguide as you survey the ruins below. Don't miss the view of the sole surviving bronze Roman doors that remained buried for some many centuries, the view from above is the best place to appreciate the layout of the adjacent ruins below. Septimus Severus who I first found about in Libya many years ago built his Domus Severiana on the edge of the hill. Didn't he do well?

The impressive ruins. This is one of the major sites of Rome, which should go to feel the grandeur and scale of the ancient builders. Awesome atmosphere of antiquity, impressive size, the true History of of this world. In Rome, the book sold in all European languages ​​about the history of the city, in particular, about these ruins, from which you can see and understand how it all looked before. The only downside - a lot of people.

Do not miss!. I was amazed how uncrowded this was compared to the Forum. The ruins are just amazing and the setting is beautiful. It seems like everyone goes to the Forum and then skips the Palatine Hill. There is a ton to see here!

An all-encompassing experience. Thia massive complex is very imressive, and you will be overwhelmed by all the ruins and history there is to take in. Have some sort of guide (audio or book or person) on hand to explain what you're seeing, otherwise it's impossible. It takes a while to see everything and there is very little shade. There are, however, water fountains, so bring a water bottle!

Great History- Under Construction. This was our first trip to Rome so we did not know what to expect. The ruins were very crowded even during the beginning of the day. I recommend coming early in the day and reserving tickets to avoid the lines.
Definitely worth the time . One of the best attractions in Rome, you get a sense of the Roman greatness. How lagre the buildings actually were etc. Also great view and not THAT crowded.

A Must See. Visited Monday 7 July 2014 - Combined ticket with the Colosseum. Entrance to the Palatine Hill is past the Arch of Constantine, about 70m from the Colosseum. There is quite a climb up to the top of the Palatine, but it is worth it once there. The Palatine Hill takes up quite a large area and the preservation of the buildings is quite good (much better than the Forum). We managed to get into the House of Augustus and it is stunning. It really is a miracle that the painted walls have survived in such a good state for the best part of 2000 years. The views over Rome from the top of the Palatine are superb and well worth the climb. There is a path leading down into the Forum or vice versa if you started in the Forum. The Forum is not as well preserved as the Palatine Hill and it is largely just ruins now, however there are 2 Ceremonial Arch's and several columns still standing. Taking the Colosseum, Palatine Hill and the Forum altogether, the whole area is a must see and well worth the time and effort.

MUST SEE!. All of these sights are a must if you go to Rome. Head to Palatine Hill and the Forum first and buy your tickets there for all 3 sights. Take your time and don't rush through it all. If you are part of a tour group as we were, go a day earlier to see Palatine Hill and the Forum since both of those weren't on our itinerary. Watch for pick picketers! Got my wallet picked!

Walk back in time...... This is my favorite area of Rome and, even though we've been several times, it's still the first place I want to see when we go back. We always buy our ticket and go in the entrance at the Palatine (ticket is good for all 3, or used to be) because the line is generally not as long and then you can skip the line to get into the Colosseum and you go straight into the Forum from Palatine. We prefer wandering at our own pace so we are not fans of, or have ever done, a guided tour but know many people prefer them for the additional insights you may get from the guide. We do use phone apps that we've found or podcasts that I've downloaded as we walk through the sites.I think it would be impossible to walk through these sites and not wonder what life must have been like almost 2000 years ago when it was first built or how they even managed to build it at all. From the relics of old palaces on the Palatine, to the Forum, which was the commercial center of ancient Rome, to the majestic Colosseum, the history of ancient Rome comes alive and you find yourself immersed in thought, "what would it have been like?". Been to Rome several times around Thanksgiving and once in September and I much prefer the Thanksgiving time period. September was really hot and still very crowded - almost too hot to enjoy the city, with all the walking and outdoor places to see. Thanksgiving was less crowded (although I don't think there is really a time when there aren't a lot of people visiting) but, most of all, it was cooler. Temperatures around 55-60 during the day so doing all that walking and touring was much more enjoyable.Love Rome, one of my very favorite cities.....

Ancient history on view. The Roman forum is a worth while visit along with Palantine hill. One can get a sense of what it must have been like in ancient times,and the dilapidated temples to Romulus along with some other pagan deities is lovely. Great photo ops,and definitely take a walking tour,which will add to your knowledge of lesser known facts.
a must see. have seen it in the pictures but to see it in real life was incredible it must have looked fantastic in its time - went on conducted tour to avoid the queues would recomend

Amazing. Definitely a must see from the inside as well as outside. Pre-purchase tickets are available all over the internet and I highly recommend doing it. The lineup at midday was out to the street. We skipped all of it and had one person in front of us just because we'd purchased in advance. Fantastic piece of history.
Worth a visit. Definitely to be included if you're doing the Colosseum. Much less crowded. Be warned that the main museum is closed until September.

Lots of walking. I would suggest you do some kind of tour, tour guides can make the places come alive with all the information they have. Unless you do enough reading and researching ahead of time. There is so much history in Rome that it is more interesting when you know where it happened and what you are looking at. Beautiful, safe city.

Go guided. We did these sites on a "jump the queue" tour with a guide. The guide was amazing she was a archaeologist and loved the places, she made everywhere she took us come alive and would recommend these places as "must see" places in Rome, but well worth paying the extra and booking in advance to jump the queues as it does save a lot of time (sometimes hours).
walking walking. allot of walking in this place, allot of run down monuments so get a free guide from your app store otherwise you will be walking around aimlessly

Take a day to see all this.. There is a lot to see. Also a lot of restoration in progress. HINT: buy your tickets at the Forum/Palatine Hill ticket booth as the line is very short and the tickets are good for all three sites.

A nice stroll around and good view of Colosseum. I visited with my Roma pass or you can buy a 12 euro ticket for entry to the Colosseum, Roman Forum and Palatine Hill. Lots of ruins to look at as well as nice shady grassy areas to sit down for a rest.It was nice to walk around and there is a good view of the Colosseum from the far end.If you are short on time and wanting to see ruins, I would recommend visiting the Roman Forum over Palatine Hill.
The Roman Guy walking tour. This was an incredible way to absorb so much information. We were 4 adults, 2 eleven year olds so was very personalised, Brilliant guide

Palatine Hill Home of the Emperors. Between the Forum, Coliseum, and Palatine Hill, I would definitely say that sight on Palatine Hill is definitely the hidden gem. While the lines to enter the Coliseum are endless, and the are bustling crowds try to enter the Forum, Palatine Hill is less crowded which can make the sightseeing experience much more pleasurable even in the summer tourist season. There are great views from this vista and plenty of old palace ruins to explore. Though it can be hot in the summer heat, there are fountains available where one can get water for free to cool off. It is from her that one will be able to view the Circus Maximus in much the same way as Rome's distant Emperor's once did. There are also beautiful botanic gardens here (a legacy of from Rome's Emperor's) as well a views of the Forum below. I would recommend one first explore Palatine Hill before descending below into the Forum which will more than likely be packed with tourist and sometimes difficult to navigate if you want to take your time and soak it all in at a leisurely pace. Save the Coliseum for last as your ticket to get you into Palatine Hill will allow you to skip the long lines to enter the Coliseum.

Ancient Rome Walking Tour. Fantastic experience, a must do. The guide was really good and its easy to follow with the headsets etc.We loved it, there is a fair amount of walking, but not too strenuous

so cool!. There are quite crowded areas but your tickets last for two days so go at different times during the day! It's quite cool with the sun and you get different views. It's so interesting. Definitely get a guided tour if you can because it's much more interesting to know what you are looking at, and what the significance of it is.

Here is the Beginning!. There were some civilizations before Rome. Say China, India, Egypt, Babylon and more. None of them had anything even close to current states where people's opinion does count. Only in Athens for some time there was a practice of collective decision making. But the Rome, Great Rome, was the only ancient society where there was a certain structure, judicial system, society with rights, elected representative system, and the same time it was the state with most slaves. After the Rome, for many centuries the world did not come even close to the glory of Rome's culture, political structure and many other systems. Here was the beginning.

Goosebump alley. This place will blow your mind with so much history to take in please please get a guide , this will allow you to walk though a passage of ancient history. A good tip is go to the colosseum first then for a few euros extra pay a student guide making it a day never to forget , & you must have you photo taking with a gladiator ,take a bottle of water with you because it's a long walk .

Use your Imagination. Another place that take you back almost 2,000 years and further in parts to the beginning of Rome. Use your imagination to see what it would have looked like when at its prime, but great to see all the stuff in real life from the films, tv series and documentaries
Huge. Ancient history, but very hot. I recommend to visit historical places like this in Italy during autumn or spring months.
Rome. Great architecture and history, easy access and many viewing points. All in walking distance of each other
Great history!. Definitely worth the visit! We had a private tour guide who used an ipad and overlays to show us the ruins. We toured the area in 3 hours and definitely could have used more time!

Amazing!. Work your way around all the craziness of panhandlers and vendors , find a tour - usually they pick you out - definitely worth the money for a guided tour. We bypassed at least one hour worth of a line to get in. Better yet was the tour of Palatine Hill that was included . We paid 20 euros each - well worth it!

family vacay. Hired a private guide for our family which enabled us to hit all the high points of these sites in a reasonable period of time. While these places are must sees while in Rome would not recommend spending a lot of time as they are mostly crumbling ruins and ultimately not that interesting.

3-in-1. You MUST see thuis when you're in Rome! These three monoments are situated next to each order. Golden tip: buy a combination ticket in advance by the internet to skip waiting lines. Golden tip 2: enter the site by the Palatine Hill entrance, which is much more calmer. Enjoy.
History brought to life. Wonderful restoration work has taken place since our last visit. Fewer cats ..... It is sad that you must pay for a whole forum tour just to see the Arch of Titus

A palatial stroll. It is possible to imagine you were a well-off member of Roman society as you wander around the ruins of houses and palaces in this residential district of ancient Rome. One marvels at the sheer height of some of the buildings.

Value for money - included in Colosseum ticket. We were fortunate that it was unseasonally cool the day we had allocated for the Colosseum and Palatine. Not sure we would have visited the Palantine had entrance not been included in the ticket for the Colosseum. We visited the Colosseum first thing - then had a long coffee and headed from there to the Palantine - a short walk. We had no expectations. The amount of history contained within this area is fascinating. Excavations are ongoing meaning that the area is continuously evolving. There is a lot of walking over uneven ground - so not very suitable for disabled access. We would definitely return - next time we would do more homework about the significant historical characters involved in the development of this area way back when. Don't miss the view of the Circus Maximus and imagine watching the chariots! Our 14 year old really enjoyed this visit - I imagine that younger kids could get a bit bored - but to them it may feel like a visit to a park - would be a nice place for a picnic! Take sun hats and lots of water if it is summer!
Hill provides scenes like none other. One can enjoy several photo opportunities of the Colosseum, Tomb of the Unknown Soldier and surrounding grounds of the Palatine Hill. History is unmatched.
Use Viator for your tours. Viator will give you all the info about the sights and help you skip the queues. The sheer size of the Patatine Hill was not expected!!

Really Glad We Went Back For It. Truth be told, we only got the tickets for Palatine Hill because it came with the Colosseum. We almost didn't take the time for the walk through Palatine Hill, but man are we so glad we did! There's really a lot of history that they've uncovered there. And, even if you're not "up" on your Roman history, that's okay. The placards at the sites have all the info you need and it's really fascinating to just sort of step back and picture what it must have been like centuries ago.The nicest thing for us, though, was that it's really just a beautiful place. There's plenty of shade and even some garden areas. It was really a lot like just taking a stroll through the park. When you go, be sure to climb the steps to the top (I can't remember the name of the particular site feature), but that's where you're going to get yourself an awesome view over the city. It's really amazing and you won't be sorry!
Be sure to go up on the Palatine Hill. It is sometimes hard to see this as much more than a pile of rocks. This is a place where a good guidebook or guide is essential.
Awsome. Rome's history is worth the long flight from Australia, these 3 places are next to each other so are easily seen in less than 1 day

Underwhelmed. Not well maintained, weeds and over-growth was every where. Very difficult to understand and know what you are looking at. I thought there could have been more plaques and signs telling me what I was actually looking at. Most of what you did view was a column or a portion of what used to be there. In short, there was no sense of awe. It is not impressive.

Must visit place. Mind blowing place..Must visit, it takes you back to the roman era..Go for official guided tour and advance booking is not necessary. One can buy ticket from palantine hill as well..

Simply amazing.... To see and feel the ancient history in Rome is indescribable. We could have spent weeks there admiring all the history. WOW! Thats all I can say to describe it.....you truly have to visit to understand the depth of these ancient ruins.

Definitely the feel of Rome. Do not miss this otherwise this piece of Rome would be a true miss. If you want to skip all the people traffic buy a Roma Pass which you can read all about or ask your hotel. It will get you to the front of the line without any wait at all!
A must see. You can't do Rome without seeing these historic sites. Fantastic history. You don't necessarily need the audio guides just use your smart phone.

Awesome. Did a tour with Francesca as guide from Avventure Bellissime tours, so knowledgeable, and with the small group of 8 people plenty of time for questions. The knowledge and perspective she gave in 3 hours was fantastic and the models of how the ancient buildings actually looked. We really thought this was a highlight of our visit to Rome.

Huge amount of stuff to see. The best thing we did was get our tickets online ahead of time. Once we found where we needed to go to pick them up, the wait time was very small. Astounding views and history in these places. I really had no idea of the scale of the thing, even realizing that the tickets were good for 2 days. If we had had the time, we definitely would have split the visit over the 2 days. Too hard to fit it all into one and some of our group just got too tired to visit the Palantine Hill. The ruins are beautiful. The plants growing up through them making it even more poignant.

Layers and layers of Imperial architecture. Lots of climbing - be warned. Amazing insight into how a few of the Emperors lived and built. Bath complexes over bath complexes. Gardens to die for. Some mediaeval and beyond stuff confusing the picture, but well worth the visit. Be warned - the Palatine Museum is shut til September 2014.

Hot! . If you are going during the summer, bring an umbrella, sunscreen, and lots of water. You will also need comfortable shoes because the foundation is very rocky. It is an amazing experience to be able to walk through all that history. I would highly recommend checking it out. Entry is included with your colosseum ticket.

Building works and confusing routes. Be prepared to find extensive renovation/building works taking place, which seem to be taking place at many of the significant sites in Rome at the moment.My advise would be to take a tour as we found it a little awkward at times to find our way back to designated route.Very interesting and worth a visit, the minor difficulties prevent a higher score, maybe we visited at a bad time.
Wow!. Amazing to finally see it in person! Lots of history and interesting ruins. Definitely a must. Students and under 25's are also eligible for a discount.

Amazing to walk around.. A big area to cover but well worth it. The audio guide is also good to have. Amazing to think that you are walking around an area that people were walking around thousands of years ago. Loved it and will definitely be back.

Enormous site. To completely go round this site we needed half a day. Got an audioguide which sometimes was difficult to follow as certain areas are closed off for renovation and the audioguide still refers you to them and suggests following a route that is not viable. Furthermore it was sometimes difficult to guess whether the building you were looking at was the one referred to in the audio. Nevertheless it is definitely worth visiting. Ruins were good enough to keep our teenage kids interested throughout the visit.

Unforgettable. Conveniently situated within a walking distance from other major landmarks. The place is huge and the surface is rough and dusty so remember to take a lot of water along and quality shoes. In summer, don't ferget a good sunscreen and a hat. It is recommended to set aside at least half a day for the visit, yet if you like history you won't mind spending all day here or coming back. People who come here just because everybode else does might be disappointed as they usually expect something "more entertaining". That's why I'd recommend reading at least some basic ifnromation about the history and layout of this place before visiting. It will help to reconnect with the genius loci of this magnificent site. The feeling of old days is omnipresent and definitely worth experiencing! A combined entrance ticket is required - it covers the Colosseum, Forum and Palatine Hill area.
amazing. Well worth a visit. All the buildings are enormous its hard to believe they were built thousands of years ago. The museum though is closed for renovation.

Absolutely breathtaking - free on the 1st Sunday. Incredible place. The best part was that it was all free today because it was the 1st Sunday in the month. What a bonus; needless to say we had another great day in Rome!

Great with a Guide. Our travel group was lucky enough to have a guide for our walk through time and it made a huge difference. Instead of being stuck trying to tell the difference between the ruins our guide gave us a perfect vision of what the forum would have looked liked and how it functioned thousands of years ago. Make sure you stick together as a group as we lost someone for a few minutes.
History Lesson. Use a guide to get most benefit from this area. Lots of ruins to review and understand. Try to get there early in day as it can get pretty hot walking in ruins.

Traveling back in time!. Some of the worlds greatest ancient monuments you will ever see. Book online in advance so you are not waiting in line. Generally no line at the box office of Palatine Hill / Roman Forum. And the ticket is good for the Colosseum, Palatine Hill, Roman Forum. The ticket is good for 2 days from your first entry to visit all three sites. Single entry for each site. Palatine Hill and Roman Forum share the entry point, so you have to visit those two in one shot. Colosseum is separate. Usually long lines for tickets at the Colosseum. All these 3 places are within 5 min walking from each other.

A sprawling and confusing site. We visited this using the same admission ticket for the Colosseum and it was well worth it. We spent extra on an audio-guide and I don't think we would have got anything like as much out of it if we hadn't. The site is very large and sprawling and it can be very hard to imagine what most of the ruins would have looked like two thousand years ago. The audio-guide helped but there is quite a lot of work going on across the site that blocks the suggested route and no alternative directions have been created in the guide - understandable - or on the ground. It was quite difficult to get back on course on several occasions.The final annoyance was to reach the end of the tour and find that the site museum is closed throughout the summer.We enjoyed our visit but there were too many irritations for me to give it a higher score than "Average". Do make sure you have plenty to drink with you. There are no facilities within the site, except for a few potable water-taps, and little shade.

A walk through time. A must see if you're going to the Colosseum. You might want your closed toe walking shoes, as there are dirt paths and uneven stone walkways. Bring an empty water bottle as there are multiple places to fill up for free. If you go in the summer make sure you have your sunscreen and a hat! Wish they had more placards perhaps showing what they believe the ruins looked like originally; ended up buying a cool little book that did it for us instead. If you like history, you've got to see this place!
Amazing!. I only wish I had been able to take some photos, but my camera died on our way in! Will definitely return on our next trip to Rome.

Must see in Rome. We brought tickets for the Colosseum for 12 EURO which included entry to Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum. I don't know if you can by separate tickets for Palatine Hill and the forum, there were kiosks outside the entrance. If it is possible ques for just these attractions were very small but if you want to visit the Colosseum as well I recommend booking tickets online in advance. We arrived quite early and still queued for an hour and a half.I had not idea how big Palatine Hill was, we had driven past it the day before and had heard the views over the city were beautiful. We made our way up, but the site itself is stunning. Although "only" ruins remain of the huge palaces they still show the quality of the building work which leaves you stunned. Repeatedly heard "This is amazing" from other tourists on the site as well as ourselves. Leaves you feeling quite humbled and linked to ancient civilisations, apparently 2000 years isn't that long! There are old cobbles (I don't know if they are original but they look pretty old) they are quite uneven, also a lot of the paths are just dirt which gets very dry in the summer. I wore cheap sandals and was ok but my feet were filthy. Make sure you were smart shoes esp if you are unsteady on your feet. There are plenty of places to sit so although its a big site if you have problems walking you can take breaks. All the kids there seemed to be having lots of fun as well. Give yourself time to see the whole site along with the Roman Forum which is within the same site. The Colosseum provides much more shade than this area so I would recommend seeing the Colosseum first and then Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum in the late afternoon when the weather has cooled. We spent all day seeing just these three and I would have gladly spent longer. When you enter the site Palatine Hill is left of the first arch, if you visit this first you can walk back down and visit the forum. You can exit the forum and see the Altare della Patria which is just the most OTT building ever (some call it the 'typewritter' which it does look like!) Enjoy!

Lots of walking. Book your tickets ahead of travel. Lines are very long in the summer. A good pair of walking shoes, water and stamina is a must to do this area in the summer months. Amazing to be walking in these historic ruins. Recommend the self guided audio tour of the Colosseum.

Cool Ruins and a lot of walking. Neat half day adventure walking through the ruins of palaces and houses along side the palentine hill. Let me emphasize hill, a lot of stairs and it's very hot outside so bring water!

wonderful. This a absolut must for all! Just prpeare yourself with comfy shoes and sunblocker and water. This will take a few hours to explore! The waterposts are ok and water is safe. One minues: toilet signs were not correct! And very hard to find.
Have good walking shoes, a hat, and sunscreen. Unfortunately being there in June it was a bit crowded. However, that aside, it was incredible to see these ancient structures.

Pre-book. We pre-booked a tour on the official web site. Do remember to print your vouchers though. I think they're trying to keep in touch with ancient times but not accepting anything but a piece of paper for a ticket. Anyway.... The tour we had wasn't the best. It was a series of short speeches punctuated but walking in the sun. When it finished most people commented that they thought there would be more to it. The night visit, the tour of the top tier and the dungeons are all meant to be worthwhile. It's a pleasant place to sit out in the evening watching the hawkers trying to sell their wares. A top Rome tip - there are two places outside the Metro where you can get fresh drinking water. Save yourself from carrying big bottles and please save yourself from buying a bottle from a hawker (I have a feeling they use the free water and re-seal the bottles- not at all hygienic to re-use bottles). If you've got an iPhone there are apps that show the approx 2,500 fountains' location.

Perfect for History Buffs. We went as a couple and it was perfect for us! We truly enjoy marveling at history and spent several hours walking through and reading about everything. Our kids would have gotten bored quickly though because many of the ruins look similar. They are also still excavating, so it was interesting to see the scaffolding and the people at work unearthing more history. Do not miss it! And wear comfortable shoes. Bring a water bottle to fill up at the many fountains.

Typical Italian!. This place has been so badly kept up--in Germany, it would be much, much better. I was pushed and shoved, and I could see the heat eating away at this place. Stay away--there are better things to do in Rome.
Breath taking. Such a great, amazing historical site. However, we went mid-day time and it was really crowded and hot too. I recommend going later in the day, but for sure going.

Good History. Walking around the ruins of Rome, you are in awe of the sheer size of the buildings built by the Romans. A visit to Rome must involve an afternoon visiting these ruins as they are a wonder of the world. As well as one ticket covers all of them so great value for money.Just to be aware though walking around there are people dressed up as Romans and will charge for photographs after you have taken of around 10 euro per person.

Ruins, which are being ruined!. For me this was really interesting to see. Of course I have heard of Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum, during history at school and documentaries on TV. It was really good to get to see it.....What wasn't great though was the utter disrespected Italians have for their monuments. Building materials were just left scattered all around ruins, wet bags of cement were resting against the pillars, iron bars hidden in the thick weeds growing all around. Honestly this looked like the most slap dash renovation job I have ever seen! the sort of thing you see on TV when they expose dodgy builders!Albeit I went in January, the down season, the place was still full of paying tourists from all around the world. And to see some of the most important history of the world being ruined was utterly disheartening. Italy should be ashamed!

Hot hot hot!. Took a skip the line tour of this area and so glad we did. So much history, so many sights that take your breath away....no trip to rome would be compete without climbing to the top of the Palatine hill & soaking in the view! It was super hot and the free potable water fountains all over Rome were sooooo useful
Interesting. It was interesting to see and Im glad we went. Beware there is one major way In and one out so plan accordingly because they arent close. It was rough with a stroller!

Must see in Rome. This is the recommended first stop in Rome and I concur. Make sure you allocate sufficient time to visit all three sites. We followed other advice and started with Palatine hill, picket up an audio guide and started the visit with the Roman Forum. You need a guide (audio was very good and easy to follow) for both the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill. We finished with the colosseum (less crowded at the end of the day). The colosseum is impressive, we also use an audio guide but I don`t think it`s required for the colosseum.
Best place to walk thru and visit in Rome. I was on a tour of Rome city and had a chance to visit this place.This monumental ruins is one visited by all for its massive size and glorious history.
Amazing historic attraction. Truely a very famous place in downtown Rome in close proximity to the Collosseum.Walked thru this place during my Rome city tour and really enjoyed.

Larger than expected. This place is unexpectedly larger than I thought it was going to be. Take good walking shoes as the ground is uneven.
A guide is necessary to get the most out of your visit.

loved it. A beautiful place to walk around. I especially liked Palatine hill with its breezes and vistas. There are plenty of places to refill your water bottles. I would go back, it was very interesting

A Crowded Place of Pleasure & Pain!. A spectacular building-looking at the foundations with their 3 tiears of arches/galleries etc one wonders how did they build it without it first falling down & restarting-a real test to the strength of the Roman mind that they would not fail. One could just imagine above the clamour of the tour guides, the leering, jeering, the jangle of arms, feel the sweat of the fighting men, not knowing if they would be home for coffee after their combats! We didn't go in per se-we could see through some of the arches from the road behind-a powerful instrument of terror for the winning side. Nothing did we dislike in Rome-a real life thriving place. We were able to have some drinks & ice-creams but those Romans of 2000 years ago-I wonder what they had to keep cool. We were there out of season of course, so in July & August it must be at boiling pitch-a place to avoid-better to seek out those quiet alleys, gracious buildings, avoid the Tiber but enjoy the food in aircon restaurants.

Well preserved History. Must visit for a photo when visiting Italy. A well preserved History. The view of Colosseum from the Palentine Hill was awesome. We saw this on our golf cart tour. Worth a visit.

Allow plenty of time to visit. We visited here in June as part of our 12€ ticket to the Colloseum and Roman Forum. I wasn't expecting it to be in such a big area - it's huge!The gardens are well maintained, there are lots of information boards telling you about the ruins and buildings that are / were there. There are fantastic view if Rome, the Colloseum and Roman Forum. It really is a nice place to wander around. You can also walk down to the Roman Forum from this site.Be prepared for lots of walking and heat, we felt so hot and there was so much to see we came back the next day to finish our sightseeing. Luckily the ticket is valid for 2 days. There are also toilet facilities on site which I was no expecting. Unfortunately you only get a map of the sight if you have an audio guide, which we didn't have. Definitely another must see in Rome :-)
Awesome. There was little pockets of lawn to sit and rest and take in the cultural significance. The attraction was everything we had hoped for and more.

Et tu, Brute?. This was pretty amazing to see, especially with my love of the Shakespearean play about Caesar. Marc Antony did his speech here at Caesar's funeral, Caesar had a hand in creating this spot, Caesar's body was publicly burned here. It was incredible to see it all these years later.They have some statues for these historical figures too, which was interesting.Unfortunately, the tours were not happening, but next time, we'll go on one.

Scaffolding a disappointment. My third trip here so it was disappointing to be showing it off to my grandson only to see it largely covered with scaffolding. The Arch of Constantine was completely covered. In fact, most of Rome was being renovated which was bad news for photographers.
An organised tour is a must. We were fortunate to have a guide to take on a tour of the Forum which I recommend as there is so much to see. Without a guide they are just old ruins.

Spectacular and not to be missed. There were long, long queues or you paid a large amount to a guide company to skip the queues - but we found quite by accident that you needn't queue nor pay! Visit the adjacent Roman Forum, pay the 12 Euros for entry and the same ticket allows you to stroll right into the Colosseum, skipping all the queues and not paying again. Bargain.

you can breathe the ancient history here. You can really feel as a ancient roman, dive into 2000 years ago. But there are
many tourist groups - this worsens general attraction. I advice you to visit the Forum as early as possible, while there are a little tourists.
Massive - give yourself time. This place is enormous, we thought we could spend an hour there and then do something else but it is well worth the three hours we spent wandering around the site.

Masgestic. Get your combined ticket from the Forum to help you miss the queues. We didn't use a guide, it was baking hot and didn't fancy being in a large group, but there's plenty of info signs around to supplement your guide book. Watch your bags/pockets outside as it's a hotspot for pickpockets!
Historical site. Nice place to visit, good walking footwear advisable. Do you homework before you go to get the best out of the visit.

Magnificent sites but crowded. Rome was end of our trip. It was hot and crowded. So glad we had seen these sites a few years ago earlier in the year when one could take a leisurely stroll through the Forum.

Attractive site. It is a very big site to visit and you should prepare yourself with hat, umbrella, and water bottle if you visit there during summer. But you should know some historical knowledge about this site before entering, or else you will just see a big ancient ruins

we got lost. We were on a guided tour and suddenly a deluge of Biblical proportions descended upon us, this was in the middle of the day, yet the visibility was under 20 feet for over an hour. Umbrella and rain jackets did not help the bad guys in Noah's time. We were drenched, but warm and it was truly a magical place. In colder weather I would recommend a cold water immersion suit.

Speechless. Although in ruins, Palatine hill was one of my favourite things in Rome. Beautiful ruins with a lovely garden and the ‘foundations of Rome’ if stories are to be believed. The view over the to the forum and beyond are stunning. Spent so long looking round! Ticket prices are good and include the forum and the colosseum or you can get the archaeological cards that also include 6 other sites and lasts 7 days (well worth inverting in).

Lots of 'old' stuff. We 'did' this with only our guide book which was a bit 'lite' on information. There are however plenty of signs around telling you about the various sites. It might well be worth going on a guided tour here. You can buy a combined ticket for the Forum and the Colosseum which is really reasonable, but you can only use it once for each site.

Great scenery. Great historic scenery, with a lot of archaeological remains. Probably the most visual way of envisioning the everyday life of Romans during the first centuries.I can't wait for augmented reality tours.

Great, but a tour guide is a must. A great attraction, but a tour guide and sturdy walking shoes (lots of uneven ground) are a must. A good tour guide will throw light on the extensive history of this site. We left the tour half an hour early because we stupidly booked an earlier Vatican tour on the same day and were worn out!

The structure and history behind it is worth a visit. its still standing, still oozes the old world charm, still shows why the Romans were what they were, but if you cant walk, dont bother. if you are going in the peak summer, i would still give it a miss. but if you are fascinated by Rome, then yes you have to be here ones

Excellent tour. This entry fee is part of the Colloseum fee.lol but no one told us at the Colloseum.. We caught the last tour around 5 pm and the guide was very knowledgeable and interesting.l her English was good so we had no problem understanding.we were taken through the buildings and her description of each was so good... We would have taken an earlier guide if we had known if the dual entry.... It was well worth paying the few euros to do the guided tour...

Saturated History. We left the queues of the colosseum to wander up to the Forum (includes Palatine Hill)and found the queue here was only 12 people long whereas the other one looked like 1200 long. Tickets can be used at both. We also down-loaded a guided tour on our i-phones so had out ear pieces with us. It was raining and so we purchased colourful ponchos which was great that our phones sat in our front pockets and we didn't have the bulkiness of holding a headseat (TV remote size to our ears like some of the tourists). We also moved at our pace and were able to rewind or stop our tour as the rain and crowds slowed us up, or speed up as the case may be. The tour guides do provide interesting stories and tipbits that the commentaries do not, however this needs to be weighed up with budgets and timing.

Interesting, but should not be on the top of your list.. Certainly interesting to see, but should not be on the top of your list when in Rome. The remains are not very stunning (like the Colosseum), but interesting. Highly recommend a personal guided tour, as the headset tour is not very good.

Historical day trip. We purchased tickets that were good for the Roman Forum, Colosseum, and Palantine Hill in our recent trip to Rome, and we were not disappointed. The passes allowed us two days to explore all three areas. The Roman Forum was beautiful even though most of the rains were rubble. Walking aroundthere gave a great sense of history and you could imagine how grand it must have been during the full height of Rome's power. We didn't get a your guide, but we overheard a guides tour that was really interesting and informative. It might be helpful since there are only small signs indicating what you are looking at.
