Overall, we really loved the Roman Forum, if you are a history buff you probably too!

A walk through history. We met another couple while visiting Rome and toured the Forum together. The wife and I had an interesting political discussion while sitting in the Forum. We felt inspired by the history and knowing many political discussions were held there over the millennia

A must for a first time visit to Rome. Walking through the ruins.,we were traveling with a group and a tour guide which was very helpful to understand the incredible history and be amazed as to the the pillars still standing. Loved Rome!

Where it all began.... You must read beforehand some history of these areas and get a good guidebook/map to take with you as you stroll these areas. If you do not do this, what you see will appear to be a mumbo jumbo of rocks and ruins. It will make little sense. However, if you take the time to do a little research, Roma will come alive for you.You need time if you are truly interested in what you are about to experience. I prefer to research and visit on my own first - as I like to get the "feel" of it without having to hang on to the words of the guide - then, when I return, I will hire a guide. If you do not have this luxury, try hiring a private guide if you can, or, a small tour - if you go with a large tour - you might as well just read a book and go on your own. My opinion. there is a lot to see and learn and you will NOT do it in one visit. I have been to these areas many times and will always find out something new or see something new or there are new excavations (Domus Aurea area is one example - Nero's Golden House was huge and covered a great area). But by all means go, do not be intimidated, enjoy and bring a hat and water!

WHEN IN ROME, DO AS THE ROMANS DID. These sights are a must for first time visitors and even returning tourists, as there is always something you missed last time. Although conducted tours are fine, if you are prepared to do a bit of homework before you go, you'll get much more out of a visit, without the danger of overload when visiting so many sites in a short time. The Eyewitness Guide is very useful.The Roma pass is invaluable in ensuring prompt entry to these popular and crowded sites.

Amazing. Amazing, just amazing! Although it is mostly ruins (suggest you get an audio guide). It is full of culture and history and of course the ‘foundations of Rome’. Absolute must see for anyone and the views are amazing. We spent 7 hours there and 3 at the colosseum (we had the archaeological passes but the ticket is a joint ticket for all 3 points) well worth the money! Wear comfortable shoes and take water but there are plenty of places to sit and there are a few natural springs around to splash down with too!

Extraordinary Historical Artifacts. These central monuments -- as well as so many other archeological sites throughout the city -- simply overwhelm the visitor with the magnitude of achievement by the Roman Empire.

Get a guided tour. This is a phenomenal site which absolutely requires a tour guide to get anything out of it. We did the tour and at the end overheard comments from others who didn't use a guide and then realized how much more we got out of it. All the tidbits and stories from the guide really made the site come alive. It was worth every penny!

Like stepping back in time. You can easily spend 5 hours in the Forum if you're interested in history and want to read all the facts posted next to each landmark. The Forum covers such a large area, however, that it's wise to get a map beforehand if you want to see everything, so you can easily see where you are and what's left, as the path is not linear.Also, note that there are two main sections to the Forum - Palentine Hill is a different section, and a different direction, from the path in the Forum that takes you to Capitoline Hill.

historical monuments you just can`t miss out on when you are in Rome. Beautiful and historical, unbeliveble.. its so big, grand even after being partly ruins. The forum is great, to see, but recommend audio guide to get the most out of it.
Ancient wonder. Next door to the Colosseum this is another magnificent wonder worth seeing. Worth using a guide or reading up on it before you visit.

Interesting but could be much better. A good place to get an idea of what the ancient Rome could have been like. But they could make a lot more out of it. Information regarding the different buildings and places could be a lot better. But a great place to buy your tickets for the Colosseum and avoiding the cues.
This why you come to Rome!. One word, Inspiring! This is one of the many reasons that you go to Rome. Buy the Roma Pass online or at Kiosk and bypass the lines.

Highlight of my visit to Rome.. So many layers of history here - you could (and should) spend days here and not see it all. Unfortunately, I had only one day, but I really enjoyed it. A guide book is essential - a guided tour would be even better. I would love to go back.

Great place to explore ruins in the hot sun. Know that the place often closes at 6:15 though the ticket taker may tell you otherwise. Explore til your heart is content of ruins or until the hot sun gets the better of you. Benches are placed around in both sun and shade in case you need a rest. Bay leaf trees are abundant on the grounds, almost as abundant as the history in the area. It is a must-see when you come to Rome. Enjoy the architectural beauty and the vestal virgins and all of the monuments in between.

Very interesting. We went here because the Colosseum tickets we booked online included this too. I'm glad they did. It is a lot bigger than we thought. A lot of ruins to look at and a lot of history to read about. You get some good views from up the top including some good photo opportunities for the colosseum. You can pay at the gate for tickets that are just for this area however by booking in advance for all 3 combined we didn't have to queue at any of the sites.

One Day at Palatine Hill. This is really worthy one to spend some time to be coincided with the great Roman history.. I was really excited at the first footstep in the such glorious chapter of the history practically. Even I went there few times to have a better & clear understanding about the surroundings. Some must have a magnificent view over the pasat & present obviously

One of the reasons to come to Rome. Words actually fail to describe the remaining vestiges of history we all grow up with. You can get a two day ticket which allows you to see the Palatine, the Forum, and the Colosseum with a chance to soak it all in. I think a lot of people skip the Palatine, which would be a mistake. That's where the rich Romans lived, and chunks of their mansions, one with part of a marble floor intact, are still there. It is breezy even on a hot Roman day. The very earliest remains of the huts of Romulus are there as well. A huge athletic field is sunken behind what was one of the mansions. Go down hill to the Forum and you have another experience altogether. It is harder to imagine what it was like when intact- the multi story structures that once existed have been reduced in size. Archaeological digs were still ongoing when we visited . The Italians continue it make new discoveries.

Forum a Living History. This is by far the most excellent experience. I spent hours here totally immersed in awe at this walk through the history of Rome I found the best way to enjoy it was to solo it, that way you can stay longer and thus discover much more. TRIP HIGHLIGHT

Awesome. Well worth paying for a guided tour. Visit was peaceful, informative and just beautiful. Learnt about the vestal virgins, the senate, the temple of Saturn, the cremation site of Caesar etc etc and even the local naughty house!

Amazing Place. The most tourist place in Rome which you have to visit. No need to have tour guide for this one, only the book of this place is enough, you are going to see historical place, incredible of how they build them in the past.

Unbelievable. we are so thankful to have been able to come here and see it -- and to hear from our guide, about its history. We joined a small Englsh speaking tour and it was so worth it as it uncluded a ticket so we could just go right in instead of standing in line for tickets (which line was very long). It was very crowded with lots of VERY large groups that you had to manuer around. It was GREAT!!!! Nothing else can be said. COME!

Full of history. Rome had a heat wave when I was there and this attraction is a lot of walking with very little shade, but it is worth it. The arch you enter under was so beautiful and I get chills thinking of all the people who walked under it before me. I suggest a guided tour to appreciate what you are looking at. The forum itself is amazing and you can see the spot where Julius Caesar's body was cremated.

It was Okay…. It's pretty spectacular when you first walk in, not to mention absolutely HUGE! I think that we maybe didn't enjoy it as much because we didn't have any headphones or do any tours. It's cool to look at ruins, but after a while when you don't know what things are you don't really appreciate like you should!
Must see.. It, again, gives another view of the magnificence of the Roman Empire, but the crowds were almost smothering, and it is not even the peak. Fees and long lines.
awesome. great historical ruins, and wonderful way to spend a day in downtown Rome. Thoroughly loved walking around and seeing all that there was to see there.
Overrated. Didn't help that we had a hopeless tour guide! Could barely speak English and was so slow! Palatine hill walk is lovely and thoroughly recommend.

A must see. History at its best. Go early in the morning before the crowds start. Could get very busy later in the day. If you want more details then book a guided tour. If not reading about it before hand is just as good. Make sure you bring water because it can get very hot in June.

Brilliant. We were there for 4 hours what a amazing historical wonder we were stunned by the history and the ammount of relics preserved also all the archeological work going on its a huge site well worth a visit.

Lots of walking. This was spread out and the paths were uneven. However it was amazing to see such a wide range of ruins to look at from churches and gardens to artwork and sculptures. Try and avoid going when it's raining as it can get muddy

Must See. The Colosseum was the main reason for going to Rome and it didn't disappoint. Go early. Roman Forum was equally amazing. Palatine Hill is reasonably interesting unless you have kids who begin to melt in the summer heat and don't enjoy walking uphill. Nice bathrooms available about 2/3 of the way through the Roman Forum on the left. It's great to just wander through the Forum but if you want to know what you're looking at, you need to research ahead of time as there are not many signs.

Amazing. Bring a hat, water and sunscreen, because there is lots to see and the sun is strong in Rome! Hire a tour guide if you want to do some learning (we used DGS-fantastic). As a former Latin scholar, I was overjoyed to finally see where it all happened.

Take a water with you!. Don't overestimate this place- it's huge. If you want to see everything here, prepare for 6-7km of walking in heat. Take a bottle of water with you and fill it whether you can. And buy a ticket online.If this place could be renovated- would be absolutely EPIC.

Really amazing. We took a guided tour to find out as much about the history as we could. There is a lot of walking to see it all but it's worth it. The only fault is that they are still doing so much excavating so there are a lot of workers everywhere making getting around a little difficult.

Great walk in Ancient Rome. Great walk and peak into the life of Ancient Rome. We did not do a tour, but the placards were just as informative. Came here after touring the Colosseum. Wasn't too crowded and great photo opportunities.

Amazing. This trip was well worth it. Not very expensive and fantastic scenery of the ruins. Be aware of guys dressed in Roman authentic costume on way in to Colosseum. They take your pics and then want 10 Euros each person. Not a big deal. We did it and have cute photos but be aware.

Go with Get Your Guide. Excellent trip with this company and our guide Michaela was very knowledgeable. A skip the Queue tour is a must at this time of the year, more expensive but well worth it. A great way to see the ruins.

Great Views. Location: The forum and Palatine are right next to Piazza Venezia. You can get there on foot from the Centro in about 20 minutes. My suggestion is to visit the Colosseo, Palatine and the Foro on the same day, and end the afternoon with a visit to the Capitoline Museum. Personally, I opted to visit all three sites with a tour guide because I was interested in the historical aspects behind them. These three sites were definitely in my favorite top 10 - they are all remarkably well-preserved and just bloody awesome! If you're a photographer like me, then you will find plenty of photo opps here. DO remember to go to Palatine Hill - it's beautiful up there and there are plenty of ruins to check out. Palatine is quite a large area so make sure you're wearing comfortable shoes. I wore my Birks because I just could bring myself to wear runners in the intense heat, but be warned - you're much likelier to sprain an ankle wearing sandals than you are wearing runners! Anyway, I really enjoyed visiting this site - there are many ruins scattered throughout, and you will find one of the best views of the Colosso from one very specific vantage point (be sure to keep an eye out for it as you start walking up). You will also find great views of the Forum as well as Circo Massimo.

Have a look, despite our experience. We took this tour as part of a combined Colosseum/Forum ticket. After seeing the Colosseum we decided to have a wander around. Sadly however, on that Sunday (15th June) the heavens opened...and how! By the time we got through the entrance there were many people huddling under trees. My wife had a brolly, I had a very light jacket. We persevered, only to find more sightseers huddled under what cover there was (there isn't much). More thunder and lightning, very, very close, one bolt went off just above my head! Impressive! Being a Scot, I'm used to rain, even heavy rain, but this was something else! I decided enough was enough...Ok, so our experience wasn't get, and somewhat curtailed. What we saw was interesting, but I was so miserable I didn't really take it in. Please don't let our experience put you off. I've given this review as high a rating as I can. Should we return to Rome we will go back and I'm sure we will enjoy...

Must see. Definitely worth a visit. We had the combined ticket for colosseum, Fort, and palatine Hill and at first we were only bothered with the colosseum. So glad we decided to go into palatine Hill. Ruins are very interesting and the views are stunning.

They didn't tell me there was an elevator!. Went there on a rainy day so hours of walking on uneven services of 2000 year old cobblestones, uphill and muddy. Found out next day from a fellow tourist there is an elevator. With a bad knee (been repaired) this was painful.

Centre of Roman Empire. Remains of religious and political buildings from the Roman Republic and Empire. To visit both sites, you will surely spent at least half a day inside, but it is not a punishment at all. Buy tickets online to avoid long waiting times outside (in combination with the Colosseum and valid for two days) But watch out: don't exit the Forum or Palatine to return later (to have lunch for example) as the ticket is not valid anymore: the 2-day validity has to do with entry of the Colosseum and the Forum/Palatine (which is considered one site). I was lucky to find understanding personel, which let me in to finish my visit in de Palatine.

We especially loved Palatine Hill...... but, all 3 were straight out of the History books. Please make sure you do a quick review of your Roman History to enhance your viewing here even more. It will come alive!

Too much scaffolding and ground works spoil the experience. OK,this is a fantastic piece of history,which luckily we have visited previously.Unfortunately there was a strike on which meant the Palatine and Forum were closed.Also the construction work of Linea C,the metro means that the scaffolding,supports,have a detrimental effect on the experience.

Must see. Take a deep breath, and just look at the structures, the architecture, the layout, everything about this. This is a must see while in Rome. It is hard to imagine the life and time when this was built. We opted for the hand held wand as our 'tour guide', and this was cumbersome. The map layout was not very well done, and it was hard to figure out where you were, and sync this with the wand. So I would recommend a guided tour. They are not that expensive and you will get more out of the event.
Rome: one big archealogical site!. Give yourself time to wander around these sites and take in the history. Just amazing. The forum is very exposed though so take a hat and water on a hot day.

Fab. Don't miss walking up La Palatine Hill. We saw many tourists just walk straight from the Colosseum to the Roman Forum instead of talking a left at the impressive arch. A short walk and imagination puts you into the heart of Ancient Rome.

Best place in Rome. Absolutely loved it here. This is the main attraction of ancient Rome. Mesmerizing, beautiful, magnificent, overwhelming, just wonderful. It's amazing to see the sheer size of all these ruins, and you can't help but imagine what this place would've looked like all those centuries ago. I could have easily spent the whole day here, it was that amazing. Only negative about it is there is not much information boards explaining what the ruins are. There are some, but with others, I was left wondering what I was looking at. Either do your research before you go or book a guide.

Bring a bottle of water with you. In hot days, this trip can end not so well. Bring water with you and fill it whenever you can. After you reach this point, you can see a magnificent view of an old and new Rome. Worth visiting.

A Must See When In Rome!. Such history and beauty, probably the best thing about Rome. I highly recommended a guided tour, otherwise you miss out on all of the history lessons to be had. Simply wonderful!!! If you don't go with a guided tour, purchase your tickets in advance or get a Roma pass and you can skip the lines.

A must see - but don't listen.... I went with friends to the Palentine Hill. It's an amazing place to visit. The history just on this 'little' hill in the heart of Rome is wonderful. Just one tip, don't bother on the audio guide, it's really disappointing, and you just get sidetracked, use the map and Guide book, and you will be fine...

Go with Richard!!!!. We did this tour with a company called "Italy with us". They were touting for custom on the road and believe me some are better than others! We were taken to the office to pay and asked to join the group at 12.00 for the tour. We were led by Richard, and what he doesn't know about the ancient Romans couldn't fill the back of a stamp! Brilliantly informative, wry humour, and gory tales of the mad, bad and dangerous to know Roman Emperors. We were stood on the top of the Palatine Hill in another thunderstorm, (every day we were there!). Richard kept going, asking if we were all okay, even though he was dripping wet and shivering. This man is a gem, and if you are interested in ancient Roman history, please seek him out. The office is next to The Shamrock Irish pub 100 yards from the main road opposite the forum. If you don't do anything else while you are there - make sure you visit the ancient heart of Rome - and do it with Richard. You won't be disappointed!

When in Rome - this is "sight seeing ground zero". You can't visit Rome without visiting the Colosseum (go early - HUGE crowds), and the magnificent Roman Forum - Palantine Hill. Go all the way through the Forum to the top of the hill and you'll be rewarded with fantastic views from the site that was, literally, the center of the civilized world. If you visit nothing else - visit these three spots.

Go early morning. We arrived early morning, after a bit of confusion we found the correct line and made our way in. The longest was for the tour groups, the normal ticket entrance was surprisingly short. The line moved very fast, maybe 15 minute wait. We paid only 12€ for our entrance to the colosseum, Palatine Hill & forum. If you know much (or enough a little) about Roman history you prob don't need a tour. From what we heard from other tourists, "the guides talk a lot & you don't get long to soak something in before being moved on". We stumbled across Rain Nymphaeum which was a nice surprise. You get some lovely view from the top of the hill, as well as some uninterrupted photo ops looking back towards the colosseum.
Epic in size. reqires a lil imagination to transport yourself bak and imagine Roman life and bear in mind the age and what was achieved here

Essential Rome. If you can try to filter out the thousands of other tourists and faux gladiators you can have a wonderful visit to this essential sight. We visited the Palatine Hill and found it less crowded and more atmospheric. A combined ticket allowed us to visit the Colosseum without queuing which was a real bonus.
Must go to the house of Augustus. Go to Palatine Hill and find the house of Augustus. It is under restoration and excavation. The frescos in situ are magnificent.

great example of ancient rome. when i was in Rome, it was an excellent day to walk around, this is a perfect way to spend a day like this. it is full of ruins and a lot of descriptions of each building that make you wonder what it was like 2000 years ago in that very spot. this and the Colosseum together make a wonderful day in ancient rome

A must to visit. This location is actually fairly expanse and provides historical insight into ancient Roman life and construction. The hill provides a magnificent overview of the area and you can get amazing pictures. Walking through the ruins you can actually feel the history and past that was once Rome.

tip buy your ticket at the forum. buy your ticket at the “forum” (@12 euros each adults)its quieter at the forum less “queues”this ticket also allows you to get into the colosseum so you can walk past all the queuing lines ! and straight in !!

Great experience. Don't buy a tour. We had long queues. About an hour, but you don't have to stand in the sun. The prices at the ticket office are good value. If you are between 18 and 24 and a EU resident you get in for half price. You need ID. It might be worth checking the queues at the Roman Forum or Palatine Hill as the Ticket includes all 3. Great interesting trip

Perfect addition to Colosseum. Reserve some time to take a walk among the remains of Roman power or take a short break to sit in the shade of the past eras. I was a little bit disappointed that the remains were in such a bad shape but at least the spot is not so crowded as the Colosseum.

Thrilling!. The whole thing was just mind blowing .... so much culture in such a small space. I just couldn't quite get my mind around the fact some of these structures were 2,000 years old. They look so modern.

The story of our past. Even though it was hot and sunny and I was wilting, it was an experience I couldn't miss you can imagine the stories you have heard or seen in movies about gladiators, Christians and lions come to life, think of the forum when it was the center of a thriving civilization and stand in awe of those who built it before modern technology. The Roma pass got us in even faster than the guided tours as well as getting us all over town for three days for one price. It's a great deal if you use public transportation.
One of the Must go places in Rome!. Shocking stories. Make sure you go with a guide, otherwise all you see is just some old destroyed walls and stones.

Fantastic place. Wondering around here in a fashionable capital like Rome is extraordinary. It is so impressive to be viewing one after the other sites and buildings whilst having the vibrant city of Rome in the background.The site itself covers a lot ground. Unfortunately we found that a number of the places were shut off and that the information of the various sites and buildings could have been more useful. It does not spoil the overall impression of the place though.Note: combined ticket with Colosseum is advisable (the cheapest).

Nice, if we have had a guided tour. That is a remarkable site, but also a lot to walk and see. We visited it at noon, when it very hot outside. In this case an umbrella helps a lot. Seeing so many ruins is far more valuable with a guide, which we didn't have and I wish I did. Consider that your ticket is valid for one entrance only, and that includes the Forum and the Palatine Hill - so you must do them in the same day, one after the other.

A great package. I think you can do all of them in one day but the tickets are for 2 entries and I am sure that its for a reason. Once you go there, if you want to travel through history and listen or read about it, you will definitely need 2 days and I think this is something you can think about while planning you trip. Personally, although Roman Forum is of great historical value, but not much remains.
A Must See. History, how could you ever visit Rome without seeing this!! May is great as the crowds aren't so bad and the weather usually great.

must see when in rome. a guide is essential to anyone who is interested in really understanding the place. Or else it is a pile of bricks. History comes alive with a guide. Plenty can be found outside the coloseum and they give a combined tour with tickets at a reasonable rate.
OMG!!!!!!. Cant tell you how beautiful Palatine Hill is and the ruins are stunning. As you walk through you just start to imagine all the romans walking the same steps you are.
Amazing Ancient Rome. words cannot express how a bunch of ruins can make you in awe. i was totally speechless knowing philosophers and emperors once walked on the same paths. it was totally surreal.
Amazing. Such an amazing place, so much history. Best bet BUY THE TICKETS ONLINE!! They charge an extra 4£ but you don't want on any lines.

Don't miss this. This was amazing!!! Anyone who is in Italy should not miss a chance to visit this ancient site. To be in the same area where the Romans conducted their day to day activities was truly a treat. This is such a great way to see the history that you learned about in school. Some of the buildings are in such good shape you can really get a great view of ancient times. Please don't miss this. The ticket I purchased was cheap and it included a visit to the Colosseum.
Love the Hill and the Forum. Get lost walking around in the Palatine Hill. Some of the best sights of Rome. At some point you could think that you are in the middle of the country side.

Very nice, and tiring. If you plan to do this and the nearby Colosseum in 1 day, don't plan to do much else. You can easily spend 2h on each of the Colosseum, the hill, and the forums. Nevertheless, the forums and the hills are something out of this world. Absolutely stunning. Buy the combo ticket for the Colosseum and the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill. Also, if you can, find a guided tour of the hill as there is much to learn.

Lots to see. Block off a couple of hours and wear good shoes. Bring a water bottle - there are water fountains around with cold refreshing water to refill your bottle. Bring an umbrella for shade if you have trouble with the sun. Lots to see, great history, great views. We did not take a guided tour, but it might be a good idea as there are not many placards around telling you what you are seeing.

Great experience. This is a must see. Hard to believe we walked on these ancient grounds. It was a very large area and you need several hours to complete the walk. If you like history, this is a place not to be missed.

A tour skips the line!. We showed up within an hour of opening and the line was ridiculous! We were trying to decide what to do when a young woman approached us about a tour. They had room for two people on a tour that was just leaving to go inside. We paid $35 euro each and walked right in with our small group. The tour was OK and they included a walking tour of the Roman Forum afterwards which was really great! As we were leaving and seeing the even longer line waiting, we were very glad we had skipped the line and taken the tour!

Long Walk. Part of the ticket that gets you into the Colosseum, Buy the ticket from here as there is no queue compared to that outside the Colosseum.Bring a drink and be ready to get lost in all the ups, downs and backways to different parts of the forum. There were boards up around the outside when we went so finding the entrance was a bit difficult, but if you go by metro to Colosseo just take a right outside and keep following the road towards the Vittoriale. Once inside if you go right its the shortest part, if you go straight you'll get to a path that takes you to a huge back section that you wouldnt believe, and left takes you towards the exit which comes out by the arch of Constantine and the Colosseum.

Worth it. You can't come to Rome and not visit. It really is amazing all the history and seeing the ruins makes it all so real. We took the skip the line tour which is worth it. Just be very careful of the men dressed as Romans outside. They will talk to you and ask if you want to take a picture & then want or really demand you pay them 10 euros each. Just ignore them.

Bring a drink, it's a long walk!. It's lovely to get into this place for free (if you buy Colosseum tickets you get free entry here and it's valid for 2 days!). It's a beautiful place to visit but quite big, make sure you take a drink. There are loads of tours going on but you can easily navigate your way round!Worth a visit.
Ancient Rome. The Forum is worth the entire visit to Rome. If you are over 65 and from EU entry is free!- but you need proof (passport etc)
Average.. For Palatine Hill and Roman Forum.... since a major part has been destroyed or with the minimal remains of the place a large part is left to your imagination.

Nice tour of Palatine Hill. Booked through travel bound. The company was dark horse tours, I think.The tour guide was great and didn't spend to much time on things that weren't important. The groups was about 15 people and didn't feel to big. She was very knowledgeable and the tour also included the Colosseum. The price for the tour was reasonable as well. Plan to walk a lot!Overall, great tour and would recommend.

Huge. Visit the Colosseum first and buy the joint ticket for this saves money and avoids queuing again. These ruins are a marvel to walk around you get the feel of the history of life as it was. Allow plenty of time to walk around its far bigger than first impressions. Take water as gets very hot roaming around. There is a water fountain where you can refill your bottle near the entrance.

Allow 3 hours and take some water! . It's hard to explain the scale of the forum and surrounding areas. Lots of hidden sections and dead ends will at times amaze and frustrate in equal measure. The scale of the buildings, columns and ruins are something else. We visited in the early afternoon, stupidly in full heat, however this didn't stop our enjoyment and exploration. Just make sure you take some water in with you as unless you fancy drinking from a fountain, there isn't really any other option (unless you count the opportunists of course selling water). It's also quite dusty, so keep that in mind if that's a problem for you.

Dedicate some time . Be prepared to spend a couple of hours as there is plenty to see and you can enjoy the views. A little tip, start with the musei capitolini, fori imperiali etc as these parts are the first one to be closed (and they only annouce it 5min before closing them down). The rest of the parc is open until one hour before dusk

Essential when in Rome!. Great to see this. Queue was long to get in and a fair number of people would jump the queue but once inside - fabulous! My mum got in for nothing as she is over 65 and teachers can get in free if they have proof. I sadly did not think to take my NUT card with me:-(. Palatine is great for views of the city and was a cool place to have a rest. Buses erratic on way back - we waited about an hour!

Avoid long queues, book a tour!. I visited her in May, arrived at about 10:30am to find that the entrance queue already had over two hours to wait. I found a tour guide outside the colosseum who was offering a place on a guided tour (12 people), with entrance to both the colosseum and the forum for €30. The tour was excellent, and the best part was beating the queue!
Great history. Go in the morning before the hot Italian sun, and spend about 3 to 4 hours, you will see amazing history and treasures..We did the solo tour without guides and we had good time

Great views and lots of history. Really interesting tour with a company called Through Eternity - our guide Katia was so knowledgeable and really brought the ancient ruins to life for us. Would recommend this company for the tour.
Historical!. It was like stepping in to the past. Lots to see, do, and it was quite pleasant to just sit in the sunshine for a bit on Palatine Hill. Comfortable shoes a must!

Interesting. Go early, and by early I only mean 9am or 10am. Around 12pm all the tourists from the Colosseum start showing up. It was interesting to walk around but the Roman Forum seemed more interesting if you could only pick one of the two which was our situation.
A must do. As the saying goes when in Rome. Fantastic grounds & well maintained. Great views to be had. Quiet a bit of walking in hot temperatures but well worth it.

Hidden gems round every corner. It is hard to describe the magnificence of this site.You really must go and see it for yourself and experience the grandeur of the buildings that were once Ancient Rome. There is so much to see that I would recommend a guided tour. The site is large, the terrain cobbled in part and uneven and offers little shade from the sun.Entry is included in the Colosseum ticket price and you should give yourself time to do your visit justice.

Wish we had more time. I hate taking tours. I would have liked to wonder around, but we were at the mercy of a tour group. I kept inking we were in the middle of one of he busiest cities in the world and there all these ruins around us. The Romans have just build up around these ruins and hey are apart of their daily life. Really impressive!

walking through history. you feel like you are on a film set. Just amazing to look at all the history and to just try to imagine what life was like back in the day. just an amazing time. less busy in the mornings but amazing no matter when you go.

Ancient Rome's birthplace and Civic Center - A Must See. Most people combine a visit here before or after they tour the Colosseum. A combo ticket includes the Colosseum and Palatine Hill. This is the ground between Rome's famous seven hills.One could argue that this is the most important piece of real estate in Western Civilization since just about anything important that happened in ancient Rome happened here.The site is large, much of the footing is cobblestones or dirt, and there are a lot of stairs on the Capitoline Hill side.There is much to see and I would recommend hiring a local guide or getting a well laid out walking tour.Hard to image visiting Rome without seeing this site.If this review is helpful then please indicate so below.

Senate House still closed. I do not know why the magnificent Senate House has been closed for so long, but again that was very disappointing. If you do not have a good guide book, it is strongly recommended you rent the audio guide. There is signposting in English, but it does not begin to give you the history of the Forum.The museum on Palatine Hill was also closed when we were there in May. We have been to Palatine Hill many times but this is the first time we "discovered" the frescoes in the house of Emperor Augustus. We followed a school group who knew where they were going, then we realized there frescoes which have been on view since 2008. You can only look in the door at the frescoes because they are fragile and they only allow a handful of people to enter at one time. It is well worth the wait. The frescoes are vibrantly colored and beautiful.I would suggest visiting the Forum and Palatine Hill before the Colosseum since the same ticket allows entry in to the Colosseum and you can skip the queue if you already have your ticket. The line to purchase a ticket for the Colosseum can be well over an hour long wait.

Well maintained ruins, I would say.. Amazingly well maintained, considering the number of years of the history. Worth a visit, but not with the kids. Its really a long walk if you want to cover the entire area. Keep a solid half a day on hand if you want to visit here. Make sure you get some eatables since inside you get nothing expect those fountains for water. But if you are interested in histories, then this is a excellent walking tour. Usually, the crowds are much less here compared to the colloseum, so get the tickets here which is valid for both forum and Colloseum.

A Must See!. This is, I believe, usually included in the Colosseum ticket. It was so fascinating to walk around and see these ancient ruins. We were there in May, so not too crowded. Lovely to walk up on Palatine Hill. So much to see!!!

A bunch of rubble, hard to imagine what it was, better things to see. Hi,The Forum was part of a tour that we took with the Colosseum. Even with an excellent tour guide it was really hard to imagine what the place looked like originally. It was not well preserved. There are so many wonderful sights to see in Rome that I wouldn't waste your time on this one. Not impressed!

Running through the ruins. Seeing the ruins helps get a picture of what the city might have looked like. People lived in the area; business happened; life occurred. It's hard to grasp that some buildings are older then our country.

Amazing. Wow! The history is amazing from these ruins. The gardens and what remains of the Temple of the Vestal Virgins, Temple of Antoninus and Faustina AD141 you can feel the history!! The cobblestones on the road, you can nearly hear the horses thundering down them!A must see!! The ticket is included in the price of the Colosseum great value

so much to see..... We visited the colosseum first on a tour which also included the forum and palatine hill. We then had time to explore our selves. The scale of these ruins is amazing, take your time and explore thoroughly there are hidden gems round every corner and up every set of steps, with some amazing views over Rome.

Lots of Walking. The place has ruins of several ancient buildings at the center of the city of Rome. It is next to the Colosseum. Please note that Colosseum tickets includes the Roman Forum-Palantine ruin entrance. There will be lots of walking to see all of the ruins. At the back exit is the Piazza de Venezia where the National Monument to Victor Emmanuel II is.
This is a must see. You need to allot enough time to see this remarkable site, if you let your imagination rome you can see yourself walking among the historic Romans that called this place home

Very interesting sites.. There was a lot of history and some fantastic sites throughout this area. We took a Walks of Italy tour, that included the Colosseum, and were glad we did as, otherwise, we would have missed a lot of the significance of what we saw. Though not as preserved as Pompeii there are many interesting, and beautiful, structures to see.

Just wish there was more of it still standing!. This place is worth a visit definitely, but what is left does not do justice to what it must have been like when it was all intact. Huge columns, arches etc are all so immense, these Romans really were great builders! Palatine Hill is not so great, but worth the climb to see the colosseum from the top. The ticket includes the colosseum so no queueing!
Excellent. worth a visit. absolutly excellent. wehen in Rome you must visit. Go to Palatine Hill to get aware from the crowds who favour the forum

Historical Entertainment for the History Buffs. I'm not really into Roman history, so I didnt really feel the buzz which I'm pretty certain others mustve felt. Having said that, it is so wonderful to see all the ruins of ancient times, and I can imagine how it was like during those days. Get a guide, or go for the audio self-guide. That would make it more interesting and make you appreciate the place more.

VERY Educational!. Get a audio guide and pre-book tickets on-line to save queuing. To get an audio guide you need to had over some id which is returned when you drop the audio guide off (standard practice in Rome). Without the audio guide you wouldn't really know what you are looking at. It can become information overload as there is so much history on the site, but totally worth the time and effort. learnt so much.
Great Views. The views over the Roman Forum and the other ruins are great. Really worth a visit, especially on a sunny evening with the sun setting.

History Overload. Wow, talk about the cradle of civilization. Thankfully we hired a guide and he made it all much more clear that the written guides that we had. Beautiful day, lots of walking and way too much to absorb in a few short hours.

Plenty of history. The entire site is huge so be prepared to spend quite a bit of time if you want to see all of the sights. We made the mistake of not renting an audio guide and were left wondering half our time in the area. That said, there are some information panels around the various sites explaining the history and significance of the various ruins and we found that very useful. The hills also offer an excellent view of Rome. One thing to note is that there are multiple entrance/exits to the area so you can choose to exit straight into the city.

You can almost feel the history in the air. Great place for people interested in ancient history and not only. Palatine hill offers great panoramic view of entire Rome and it's all for only 7 euros for students, including ticket to the Colosseum.

Wonderful site and ruins.. While these ruins are always crowded (we were there off season), the experience and monumental grandeur are wonderful. Bring your hiking shoes, because there is so much to see.

Maybe I needed a guide?. This was my least favourite of the three (Palatine, Roman Forum and The Colosseum), however it was the only one I did without a guide so perhaps that was why I didn't enjoy it as much.The grounds were nice and some of the views were stunning but I didn't feel there was much more to it than that.

Great sites!. Palatine Hill is with a visit. Do it with a guide and you'll get all the history. Tickets include the Coliseum and the Roman Forum. Lots of walking and lots to take in but it's all worth it.

Why are these treasures so poorly run?. The Roman Forum is one of the world's most important sites. Tragically, it seems that Rome does not know how to manage it. The audio guides are in a word: terrible. Useless. A waste of time. Unfortunately it seems that to visit this properly one must hire a good person as a guide. It should not be this way. Perhaps the audio guides are deliberately lame in order to diminish competition with the live guides.
Not one of my Favourite.. Visited since we're there,but it's not one of my favourite. But still a must see whilst in Rome, not worth spending too much time there if you're short of time in Rome.

Roman history. This attraction, together with the Colosseum, is a must if you are interested in ancient history. When we visited the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill is was not too crowdy so we had a very nice walk back to the Middle Ages.

Dont be late. This is obviously a must see whilst in Rome, unfortunately you have to do it in times everybody else is....don't go too late as you will not get a guided or audio tour. However even if you miss these, the descriptions on each monument are really good and give you a sense of the place. The Palatine is worth visiting but not for long, we found the Arches and their history the most interesting. Some of the temples are still in good shape so well worth a bit of time.

Best to visit with a tour guide.. Lots of history is located within this site. I would recommend visiting this site with a guide to learn and understand what is behind this historic site. Definitely worth visiting and spending time here!

Nirvana for history buffs. The Palatine Hill gives you an idea of what Rome was like, at least for the top of the ladder. If you are a history lover, it's a thrill to be in its midst. And it is such a large site and visually uninterrupted by the modern ( except the museum, which tries to blend and does a reasonably good job at it ), that it adds to the feeling.Unfortunately, it was late when we started the Palatine Hill and we wanted to see the Colosseum before it closed, so that all we saw of the Forum was from the Palatine Hill, itself. What we could see looked great and made us sad as we knew we wouldn't get to see it, as we were leaving Rome the next day. It was just one of many places on the itinerary we had to excise due to time constraints. I used to get upset when we wouldn't see everything I planned. Maybe I'm getting older or just realistic, but this time I took it in stride. Besides it's easier to accept when what you do see is so spectacular that you are in a perpetual state of awe.

Not to be missed in Rome!. We visited the Forum and Palatine Hill as part of the Nero's Rome tour booked with Through Eternity. Our private guide Cinzia was fantastic and made the history of these extraordinary places come alive with her knowledge and expertise. The views of the Colloseo are also very good from the Hill.
Awsome!. This experience was even better than the Coloseum. Is fantastic all the story that can have one place. I recommend it 100% if you like history, archeology and art.

You have to feel it. Maybe it is only me, but I really enjoyed being in and around this place. It seemed to me as if I could feel the energy of people residing here in ancient times and those with vivid imagination like me can see images of people walking or sitting in this place thousands of years ago. Amazing!
The Glory of Rome. I cannot recommend this enough. You can explore on your own but I did it with a guide. The sense of history is all pervasive. After all, you're in Rome. Go & be entranced.
fantastic experience. What a great experience. Strolling through the ancient ruins was sl surreal. The history is amazing and I learned so many interesting things.

AMAZING. Words really can't describe this historical place. Yes there are crowds but once you start walking around you understand why, all the history books and photographs can not duplicate the REAL thing...Best advise, go early in the morning and with a small tour group. Charge up your phone, camera and wear good walking shoes.

Combine Palatine, Roman forum and Colosseum...Go here first. This is my second trip to Rome and once again I enjoyed visiting this triple combination. If you by Roma Pass, this and Castel d'Angelo are a great combination to use your free entrances on. If you do not buy a Roma Pass, buy your combo ticket at Palatine Hill. The line is very short; it allows you to bypass the lines at the forum and Colosseum, which is always very long. The entrance is just up the hill from the Colosseum entrance. I enjoy Palatine Hill because it is a quiet, tranquil area in the midst of the usually overcrowded forum and Colosseum area. It is full of gardens and ruins. A peaceful, relaxed walk through the Palatine Hill area prepares you for you entrance into the crowd at the Roman Forum, which can be entered directly from Palatine Hill and then the Colosseum entrance is just across the street from the exit from the Roman Forum area. As you walk past the very long line waiting to buy tickets at the Colosseum, you will be very glad you have your ticket and can walk straight into the Colosseum.

Couldn't miss this. This was fascinating and interesting and, at the same time, a bit unbelievable to be there with the remains of buildings/structures from so long ago. We didn't have a guide but wandered by ourselves at our own pace and didn't feel as though we had missed out. The signs are in Italian and English and contain information about major points of interest. Be sure to wear good walking shoes and have a hat and water. Around these popular areas, food is very expensive and if you think you might just "pop in"somewhere for a coffee, forget it. You'll be given a surly look and no service. On the streets beware of the crazy drivers- even if you are crossing with the lights that is all irrelevant. Just remember to say your prayers as you brave the traffic.

Don't miss it. Buy a combination ticket with the Colosseum and give yourself plenty of time to see this place. Bear in mind that with the combo ticket, once you have visited one part you have 48 hours left on the ticket. The magnitude is immense but worth taking the time to explore. Take food and water and wear good walking shoes. Don't miss it!
A must. It's in ruins but when you realise that you're walking on the same soil Romans discussed and spent their time 2000 years ago you end up in awe. So incredible.

Massive, but don't miss it!!!. This place is very impressive!!! I never realised what is actually there, i wish we had given ourselves a full day at least!!! There is so much stuff to see, this was my favourite place in Rome.Take good walking boots, sun protection or rain. Take your own water and food. Once you get in through the line up you won't want to leave and come back.Buy a full Roma pass from the info centre if your not doing tour guides, it supplies trains all entries and 3 free museums for three days. Saving in the long run!!!I rate it over the Vatican and The Colosseum, its unreal to see how much of the city was abandoned and buried by floods and now is all unveiled again.

This is it!. This is the place you've heard about in all the stories - the real center of ancient Rome. You've got to be there to see it, to feel it, to "get" it. If you can, hire a licensed guide so it all has context, but just be prepared to feel - a lot. the combination of eras, influences, ideas and peoples. It's all there.

Overwhelming. The sight is a lot larger than I anticipated. We spent a fantastic afternoon there. I would try to go when it is not too hot as there is a lot to see and not much of a breeze. Also a good idea to get a map and possibly an information book so you have a good idea of what you are looking at. I thought I knew enough about the sight, years of art history, but will take a really good guide book next time. It leaves you in awe.

Worth to Visit the Hill and Forum. Again there is big line for entry but not much compared to Colosseum. Either buy a pass in advance to skip the line or don't go in the morning hours. Once you enter the palatine hill there is beautiful gardens, monuments and ruins unearthed from the old roman era all reminds us the history. It is worth spending 2-3 hours moving around the area. It is better to have a good guide to know what is what in the Hill and Forum. Those who don't have any knowledge or not visited earlier in these places without a guide can just move around and enjoy the beauty of the garden. To know about the historical structures, ruins one should have a guide or accompany with someone who know these places.

Imagine as it was then. Just walk through and imagine you are in ancient Rome thousands of years ago... If you buy Colosseum ticket it is included and it is right next to it, so go there right after Colosseum
Good value. Included within 12 Euro admission to the Colosseum. Spent a good couple of hours here, could have spent more. Just look out for uneven pavings which are not to be unexpected. Enjoy it

Probably should have gotten a guide. What the title says. A very beautiful landmark that I suppose we would have enjoyed even more, had we bothered with a guide. Mom still loved it. Also, someone mentioned it previously: go early when it opens (8.30; you can be there at 9) and since the ticket covers both the Forum and Colosseum, start with the Forum, there's no queue there and we got in in minutes. You'll avoid the lllooong queue at the Colosseum if you have a pre-purchased ticket. Another option is to just buy it online in advance, but they require you to have it printed out (as opposed to just showing it on your smartphone, which works well enough in Estonia), so it's not as handy as a last minute resort.

An amazing location. There are ruins, partial buildings, and a few intact buildings dating back over 2,000 years. Go with a tour, otherwise you'll get tired of looking at old buildings without an appreciation of what they were and how they came to be.

lot to see. Well worth a visit to the forum and palatine hill. Loads to see and amazing to think what it would have been like. We should have got some more guide info but our app to show what it was like was good.
Interesting tour. Chose a guided tour for the forum, glad i did so i knew what i was looking at. many ruins to see , well worth a visit

Used a Tour Guide - skipped the line and worth it!. There were long queues to enter the Hill & gardens so when Brent (A US guy acting as a guide)offered a tour at just 3 euro's more than the entrance fee and 'skip the line' decided it was a good bet!Had a bit of a wait whilst others joined the tour but wasn't too long. Had a guided tour throught the Hill & gardens which was very informative, whilst it was a little quick at the end then had the option to re-trace your steps and generally explore the place. Again saw some examples of how Roman features became buried over time then excavated and this was evident at the Mansion House built for Mussolini where the base of the house is quite elevated.Ideal to browse on a fine day with the sun out!! For the mobility impaired some of the paths are quite steep so may be a challenge! Equally for children quite an effort but may lead to a peaceful night!

Impressive ancient Rome experience. Really amazing to see what the Romans were capable of building centuries ago. The "castle" on Palatine Hill must have been really impressive. Besides, the views from this hill are amazing as well.

Don't miss it!. According to our tour guide, the majority of people who come to Rome, don't visit the ancient forum, which is sad because the have missed an opportunity to walk in the footsteps of history. We had a tour guide, who explained the buildings and their purpose. And the walk to the top of palatine hill was worth it. Only thing I would say is some areas did not have signage so we were clueless as to what we were looking at.

Start here if you want to see Forum and Colosseum. Took a tip from Rick Steeves and bought our ticket for the Forum and Colosseum at the entrance to the Palatine Hill. The Palatine hill was a great visit, not crowded, but lots to see. Then moved to the Forum which took up the rest of the day. Since the ticket was a 2 day ticket we went back to the Colosseum and went right in without waiting on line.

Walk with the Ancient Romans. Fascinating to walk in the footsteps of the Ancient Romans. I loved the Temple of Romulus and was entranced by the Temple of Vesta and the House of the Vestal Virgins. What a life of privilege they led? And if they fell by the wayside they were buried alive...harsh! The Arch of Titus was impressive. The Palatine Hill and museum stretch the visit into several hours. Sadly Livia's House was closed to visitors and several areas other areas were undergoing renovation. It all takes a long time as there's so much to see.I wouldn't recommend the audio guide. There are numbers to press at all the points of interest but no corresponding numbers on signs and signposting is generally poor so we resorted to guessing where we were a lot of the time. We got it wrong several times!!It's hot (even in April) so make sure you have water. There's nowhere inside to buy drinks and the street sellers will rob you blind for a drink outside. Good walking shoes essential. The uneven stones will have your ankles twisted if you're not careful.
Ancient ruins. went there after the Colosseum in a rainy day of March.the structures and remains were really stunning.it helps you imagine the living area of Romans.

The history!. A very large precinct showcasing many aspects of Roman life. The crowds were mind blowing in parts but walk 300m off to a different section and they are all but gone. Depending on your thirst for historical knowledge you can spend anywhere from one to four hours here. Don't forget your hat, water and be prepared to deal with huge crowds in parts. We even had to queue for 20 minutes to get out through the exit turnstile!

Step back to Roman Times. Well worth a visit to really understand the treasures of ancient Rome. Not very busy at all compared to the Colosseum and the Vatican. I could not really understand why it was not busy given that these were the ancient relics of Rome.

Superb Remains - go early!. The place is quite superb. Lots of the original parts of Imperial and Republican Rome of the 1st c. BC to 4th c. AD. The quiet of the Palatine is a relief from the buzz of the crowds in the Forum.Good interpretation on the audio tour and you can plug a second headset into the unit so you do not have to rent individual units... 1 between 2 is fine :)We thought the museum (small) was well displayed and interpreted (Italian and English).Get a ROMA PASS to get in without the long queue, and use the Palatine entrance as it is the quietest.... the free local bus/tram transportation with the Pass is also worthwhile.

Impressive view and nice gardens. This was a lovely place to spend our afternoon after a tour of the Colosseum and Roman Forum. When you reconstruct the history of this place, it's an amazing place to be. Also, it has great views out over the city, and lovely gardens to enjoy on a sunny day.

Another Must See. So much history and archeologicy.... Don't miss this part of the old city. It's a very big place with a lot to see, and don't forget this is where it all began for Rome....Important tips: 1. at the entrance of the Roman Forum buy the combined ticket (Forum + Palatine Hill + Colosseum).2. Wear comfortable shoes.3. Bring a few bottles of water.

Gardens were a real surprise. There were some great exhibitions including a virtual tour through the sewer system. 3d mapping of the site ensures these monuments will live on at least digitally. Overall a sense of wonder mixed with sadness these amazing buildings have been allowed to fall into such decay. The highlight has to be the climb up to the gardens where you get a perspective on the site below. Spent a magical 3 hours there.

Beware of scammers. Huge place, you could spend a day touring this and the colosseum. Some map would be helpful to navigate around this place.Do beware of people wearing gladiator costume outside it, they will walk up to you offering to help you take photos and such, afterwards they will ask you for money, so do know what you are walking into. The management should do something about it.

Do this first before the Colosseum..... This is easly to get into. NOTE Also as your ticket is combined with entry to the Colosseum purchase here. You can then bypass all queues at the second venue as the queues here are enormous. The scale is amazing, this is living breathing ancient Rome and considering the age it is incredible how many building still stand. There is shade and Palentine Hill provides great views across the city. Even 2 lots of toilets!

When you think of ancient Rome, this is what you imagine!. Probably one of our favorite spots in Rome! It contains all of the ruins from the iconic historical Rome. Columns still stand, the bottoms of the buildings are still intact. Although, admittedly, they are "ruins", your eyes almost transform the ruins into what they were hundreds of years ago. Plus, it is just a really fun place to walk around. Great picture opportunites, too.

Needs some imagination. It's a great place to stroll around although got incredibly busy by lunchtime with coachloads of school children. Tickets from the colloseum that cost 12 Euros get you in for free. It does require a lot of imagination to think of it how it once was but is still definitely worth a visit.

Beautiful!. Beautiful place to spend an entire day. I only wish there were more informative displays that described what you are looking at. If you need a wheelchair, walker, cane, etc., it would be pretty difficult to navigate as the stones are loose and not even..

A lot to take in. You could walk around the site for two days and still not have seen it all. The signage on the site isn't very good at explaining the various ruins and their history so make sure you take a guidebook or a guide. Bring your walking shoes, a packed lunch, and take your time taking it all in.
Half a day - not enough. Should take a full day to explore and feel this streets, secret gardens, hidden places and much more.What a majestic place it use to be!Love it!

Need to go back. We spent half a day here and there is much more to discover. A lot of walking is involved and as you go you begin to grasp the beauty and scale of the construction of ancient Rome and its magnificence. It was much more detailed, opulent and extensive than I had expected.
Interesting. Nice sightseeing but you've better have a tour guide with you because there's so much to see. November was a nice period of visiting with lots of sunshine.
A great through roman history. A fantastic walk through Roman History .The experience can be greater while walking there in a sunny day . Its a great journey of Roman ancient history

I LOVE Roman History!!. My husband and I visited in January (his first time) and I was so excited to show him the Roman Forum. I learned all about it in a course in college and I was like a kid in a candy store. Thank you Rome for spending the money and time to continue excavating! 10 years from my first visit and the Forum was completely different (in a good way). I was beyond thrilled to enter the senate house. My first visit it was closed and it just made all my dreams come true to be able to go in there. I can't wait to visit 10, 15, 20 years from now and see how much has changed then! Such a treat!

Would like to have stayed longer!. Visited Palatine Hill today, the entry fee used as part of the 2 free entries you get with the Roma Pass we purchased (well worth the money). We found it extremely interesting and awe inspiring and there was a great deal to see. One thing I would mention though is that it would be difficult to get around with a pushchair/buggy or in a wheelchair or if you are not too good on your legs or don't like climbing slopes, as the whole area is very uneven and on a number of levels. We wanted to see the Palatine Museum too but unfortunately it closed at around 12.30 because Barack Obama was visiting the Colosseum next to it and all areas around the site were closed for security purposes( I've never seen so many police in one place, let alone armed police with helicopters circling overhead!!) I would loved to have been able to spend a couple more hours here and if it wasn't our last day in Rome today I would go back tomorrow to see what I missed but I suppose it gives me the excuse to visit Rome again but if I do I must remember to consult with Mr Obama's diary to make sure our sightseeing trips don't clash again!

Very interesting. Get a tour!. We got a tour of the hill and forum as part of the Colosseum tour. The guide gave us a lesson on the history of Rome and the Hill, and showed us around where the palace once was and the Forum. Definitely check it out if doing the Colosseum tour, and the ruins of the Circus on the hill are quite good too. Interesting to see that any marble left behind 'wasn't good enough for use' in Renaissance works, but are still works of art on the site. Definitely get a tour though!

Palatine Hill. Really cool to see the authentic roman buildings and ruins but the whole view was scaffolding. Understandable if they are making sure what's left lasts but not so panoramic. Good gardens and nice to walk around though.

Great day. we split these tours in two and did colosseum 1 day and Palatine Hill and Forum 2 days later as we had to fit Rugby in-between it was great and our guide David whos mother was English and father Italian was brilliant with a great sense of humour

A chance to visit the hill from where the world was managed for almost 800 years. it's a chance to see a part of history + the view from Capitoli & Palatino hill is amazing. It's a good place to start your day as it is the city center & you can go from there to any part of me easily

Wonderful Experience. Took a walking tour in this area. Just to be able to experience the history of it all is remarkable. The guide was very knowledgeable in all the history of the area. So much to take in, but worth it.

Awesome!. This is an awesome destination in so many respects!You feel the weight of the centuries in this place.We spent around 3 hours there and had two knowledgeable tour guides; one who guided us in the Colosseum and one who guided us through Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum.We hadn't pre- booked and were approached by them at the Colosseum and it was good value for money.Don't do this place without a tour guide. Its just not worth it.I wish I had spent more time there.Beware of the pick pockets though, while you walk from the Colosseum to Palatine Hill.
So grand. Much bigger than I expected. Staying nearby helped us to enjoy it at night also. The whole area makes history come alive.

Undersold unbelievable Historic Site. I would have given this 5 if I had been rating on the historic Forum and Palatine hill itself but I'm afraid the upkeep, signage and management is appalling. Firstly without Trip Advisor city guide we would never have found the entrance. Secondly there are only 2 ticket offices creating I would suppose monumental ( excuse the pun) queues in the peak season. Secondly you need ID to get an audio guide, being a Brit I don't have this unless I carry my passport not a good idea in an area renowned for pick pockets. One post said the audio guide was useless anyway. Thirdly there are no other guide books or maps to buy or any free maps given out. Fourthly there is no obvious way round so it's easy to miss the items of interest, and the signage which is up is wordy. What is so obviously needed are some drawings of how the buildings used to look. All the guides have these little books to show their flocks of tourists my top tip would be to buy your own before you go. The ruins themselves are amazing and some are intact like the senate building which is tucked away and we could have easily missed. This could be a spectacular attraction if managed properly they might take a tip from whoever is running Edinburgh Castle which we visited only a few weeks ago, here we were just handed the audio guides which were excellent for a very reasonable sum.

Wonderful day. Don't come to Rome without a visit to Colosseum and Palatine hill.Take a tour but wait till you are inside it is cheaper. You buy a ticket for €12 and extra €5 for the guide. The tour is around 45 mins and very informative. Then you get time to wander around the Roman forum and up to palatine hill.

Ancient Rome- A Must See. Took a private tour- a must do when in Rome. This area is breathtaking and the history is unforgettable. A private tour was the best way to see everything. You can spend many hours on this tour

In awe walking in the same steps.... All that history...It was fantastic to be there and be in a place that had such long standing effects throughout the world. Personally, I don't think you need a tour. We just walked around and explored on our own, finding little areas worth noting. It can get hot, so bring a bottle so you can refill it readily. Bring sunscreen and a hat too if you can.

I didnt take the guided tour they seemed to rushed for my liking. Palatine hill is the most outstanding place i have ever visited just outstanding! the old ruins give your mind so much to play with your imagination runs wild when you see the grandeur of these great ruins... this is a must when visiting Rome. you need to spend a full day so start early and wear some comfortable walking shoes.... I DIDN'T TAKE THE GUIDED TOUR, take your time you will see so much more and ENJOY X :) (dont forget your camera on this visit!)
rome trip. we did a guided tour and it was well worth the money ,you were told more history than you would by doing it on your own

Really interesting archaelogical site, but few signs to explain what you're looking at.. I am not a fan of guided tours, but in the case of Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum, I would actually recommend doing some sort of tour. Unless you have researched extensively, it's hard to tell exactly what you're looking at. Don't get me wrong, the sites are impressive, and there are some parts in particular that are pretty well preserved. For instance, there was one spot where I was walking through a covered passageway and there was an amazing carved ceiling overhead. Look all around, because not many of these things are called out specifically if you don't know they're there! There are a number of signs at the top of the hill where the Flavia Palace is, and that is a must-see if you are in this area. My ticket purchased at the Colosseum also covered admission to the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill, so for 12 or 13 EUR, you could spend a half day or more seeing all there is to see in this part of Rome.

Fantastic. We enjoyed a wonderful day here using the Rick Steves app that we downloaded onto our iPhones before leaving the US. It sure made what we were seeing come to life. Be sure to wear comfortable, sturdy shores!

Get an audio guide. Absolutely brilliant, but you do need something to tell you what you are looking at. We got an audio guide - 6Euro, but be aware that you have to leave some ID - we left a credit card as that was all we had. We got it around 11.30am and it had to be back by 3pm, which we did, just. If you love ancient things you could wander round here all day.

More signs, please. It is quite difficult to find your way round the ruins - more signs would help. Be sure to look for the long passage way, Cryptoporticus, built by Nero to connect his Golden House with other imperial palaces on Palatine Hill. At some places it is possible to see the remains of the elaborate wall and ceiling decorations.

Worth a trip. You can buy a ticket here (or online / print) valid for this and the Colliseum, over 2 days.It's a bit wild and badly signed, but it's raw history and you're right in it. Good views from the hill, but some parts are closed.

Skip the Augustus house line. There were several places within the area, that without a guidebook, we would have missed or skipped on. Well worht reading about, or getting a guide to know what to look for. Same issue as everywhere else in Rome, if there is a guided tour going on, don't plan on seeing what they are looking at, or read what's on the information card. We waited in line to go see what the House of Augustus was all about, three rooms with frescoes in tact, wasn't worth the 30 minute wait it took to see it. Look through the windows at the top and you can see what it is.

Interesting but not enough info and staff were rude. The ruins look very impressive and there is a real atmosphere to the place. However after a long queue when we got to the front the rude staff refuses an audio guide because we didn't have an ID which isn't referenced at any point in the queue they didn't give any information or a map and we were left to our own devices. There are not many signs and things are not very clear. If we went again I would be sure to get a tour guide.

Definitely top attraction of Rome. I purchased the ticket directly to the ticket office located at the Colosseum, for € 12 ticket you have access to the inner area of the amphitheater, the Imperial Forums and the Palatine Hill. A sensational experience no doubt for those like me who is a lover of Roman history. For complete detail all the way through that part of the hill from the Colosseum and the forum I think that the entire journey would take more or less than 5-6 hours, but I think to visit every corner of this beautiful piece of history it takes half a day, there is a endless supply of things to see. I think if you wanna get a good knowledge of all the notions is appropriate to hire a guide that will explains everything you need to know from the single altar to the ruins or building. In short, I personally I place this as the top attraction in Rome.
A real step back in time. We really enjoyed this. The location was pretty much the old Roman town centre. You can almost small and feel the old markets that would have been set up around the forum.
Simply awesome!. Though we only spent few hours here, the experience is totally great! Seeing the remains and treasures of the old Rome is amazing. You must not leve Rome without seeing this place!

simply in awe. we spent 5 days there and I was immersed into her intriguing treasures of Roman remains and art collections, Wandering through all of that, you felt that you are in a deep dialogue with something dated more than 2000 years old, you are listening to an old man at 2000 years old to tell you his story and his glorious days, specially when dimming sun lights blanket over the remains from the sunsetting, you felt a sense of history with past glory and great success, but all you can see is the remains, falling marble stones and the only thing is still standing is the lonely columns pointing to the sky and refuse to fall down! I paid my respect with awe to them!
Amazing.. To see the remians of the former Roman city centre was amazing. Just stop and take a moment to picture the hustle and bustle of the centre of the empire at it's pomp.

Almost frozen in time!. I can't think of anywhere else where it is so easy to imagine how it must have been! So many wonderful buildings, views, and fascinating stories! I particularly enjoyed wandering round the orange gardens to take it all in! I can't say anything new - just go!

a must do. again another MUST SEE - great to wander around and take pics. the area is huge and so much to see - palatine hill a good place to take some further back pics of maybe colosseum and rome. again if you buy your ticket at the colosseum or in advance it usually includes the Forum and Palatine Hills so well worth it
Very hard to find the way to get in !. No one knew the way to get in. Very confusung. Can see as much from a distance and it would be for free.

Fabulous. Rome has a few must-see sites and this is one of them. It is absolutely worth the time to see this fabulous site. It is impossible to overstate the historical significance of what is seen here. Each item is explained nicely by the guide and it allows the possibility of transporting your imagination back two millennia to have an understanding of the life at that time. Definitely put this on your itinerary.

A must but only after the Colosseum first. Take a trip through the ancient forum but remember, your ticket from the Colosseum also gives you access to the forum so don't pay again. If you really want to see parts of the Palatine Hill Emperors' palace walk the Circus Maximus as it faces the back which you can't access from the top.
Thought provoking. We had Palatine hill as part of a package we'd purchased through the coliseum and it is just over the way. It was apparently were the first of their time shopping area was too

Ancient Rome at its best. Visited this as part of a segway tour. It is hard to see all you want to see in Rome especially on foot and when the weather is so hot. The Hill part suggests its uphill so the Segway was a blessing. You have to see this. Old Rome being eaten away by time and full of history and stories. No glam and glitter- no paintings by famous artists - just rely on your imagination to take you back to the place this used to be. Amazing. There is only so much a tour guide can tell you so try to research it beforehand if you can. Try to bring it to life and you will enjoy the experience even more :-)
very interesting IF and only if your are into such things. I really liked it, but i think that one must like this kind of activities.there is a lot to see there.

So much to see. This whole area has so much to see its almost too much. A huge area especially when you include the Palatine Hill. History takes true form here but dress comfortably cause you'll be walking for a long time to cover the area.
A must do. My favourite place that I visited whilst staying in Rome. Very quiet compared to the other must see attractions.

A top highlight of our visit in Italy.. My husband and I visited via a Walks of Italy tour that combined it with the Roman Forum and Colosseum, so our entrance fee was already covered and the tour allowed us to skip any lines (the tour was the best tour we've ever had, so I highly recommend it as well). It's an incredible experience to visit and feel the presence of another time. And with so much open space, it's not crowded, so very relaxing to take everything in and take amazing photos of the area and city beyond. In our opinion, visiting is a must.

Rome. Now this isn't inexpensive. But this after all why you are here. This is really two parks combined; and the Palatine is really the best. Go on a bad day and have it to yourself. Or go on a good day, and spend your day there. Go when the Servian terraces are open. Though I have never been able to fiquire out exactly when this is. Like so much of Rome; it is just a matter of circumstance and luck.

Very interesting and beautiful setting. We had a fantastic tour here. There was so much to see and take in, I would really recommend paying for a tour as I find that I get so much more out of it. I'm glad we were child free, whilst we found it very interesting, my children would not have appreciated it. If you have children that are interested in history I would say ages 14 upwards to really get something out of it.

BEAUTIFUL!. I would defiantly recommend a tour through this. There is just soooo much history behind all of this that alone I would have never even imagined any of it. Defiantly get a tour guide and get some information behind all of this!

Welcome Home Senator. The Palatine was the home of many of the most famous figures of ancient Rome and as such it is hard to stand on any part of the hill and not feel awestruck by your insignificance in the vast scheme of history.
