You could easily spend a day walking around enjoying the marvellous views of the city of Rome, at one moment you are struck by a view of the dome of Saint Peter's in the distance and then you find yourself looking down to find the ruins of the Forum laid out below you like the pillars and blocks of a child's building set that someone has forgotten to tidy away at the end of playtime. It is a great place for a picnic. It is a confusing site there is no doubt and a good tour guide is probably necessary if you really want to get under the skin of the site. Even without a guide it is possible to feel the very essence of ancient Rome all around you. Augustus and Livia lived here as did Cicero and Mark Anthony and it is even believed that the twins Romulus and Remus were reared here by a wolf. Do not miss the Palatine Antiquarium Museum which is housed in a large building on the site. It is full of artefacts including busts, statues and artwork actually found on the hill and some of these are absolutely stunning.

Get lost in the heart of Ancient Rome. Could have spent hours walking around Palantine Hill, there is so much history here, it's overwhelming. As with many of the places I visited in Rome, I felt there wasn't enough information given to tourists about the history of the site, which is a shame, so I would suggest maybe looking into a guided tour, just so you can fully appreciate the surroundings. Spent a good few hours here, looking at every nook and cranny, touching everything possible (gently of course) that wasn't roped off, but also, just standing, breathing in the air and imagining life in Ancient Rome. Considering what is left, Palantine Hill is very authentic and makes you able to do so. The buildings are very impressive and makes you appreciate just how creative we are as a species and for how many thousands of years that humans have been able to design and build such beautiful, complex buildings. This could potentially be boring for younger kids, who may be irritable with the lack of shade, so consider in summer going in the afternoon. Also, don't be surprised if your teenage kids don't appreciate it as much as you thought they would; unless they are into culture, then they're more than likely they were on a beach in zante, or some other 'cool' party place. All in all, a great experience and I would have loved to have learnt more about it as I walked around, but luckily, thanks to my free wifi at the hotel I was able to find out evrything I wanted to know about it, when I got home.Don't give this place a miss, and remember, it is included in the collosseo ticket alongside the roman forum

Stunning site. Palatine Hill is an impressive site. The expansive ruins help illustrate how huge the ancient settlement of Roma was, and how creative and inventive the Romans were. The towering walls, extensive current archeological activity, lush gardens and sites of leisure activities are all of interest to those keen to understand the beginnings of this great city. The views across Rome from many vantage points are excellent, especially of the Colosseum and you can see the relationship between different key sites. I had planned to visit the Forum but found Palatine Hill of much greater interest.

Must see in Rome !!. This is a great place to visit and don't forget the Colosseo too. You need to walk a bit but so much you can see and experience. With Colosseo you can really see the Roam history here. It is too hot to walk around in the middle of the summer but spring and autumn are probably the best time to visit. You can spend good half day here!!

We had an awesome tour guide arrange by the guide who traveled with us that provided many insights into what we may h. We had an awesome tour with a local guide arrange by the guide who traveled with our group that provided many insights into what may have been missed. Not to be missed. Wear comfortable walking shoes, and carry water.

History and Scenery. Did palantine hill as part of a guided tour with viator.com which also included the colloseum and the roman forum (GREAT TOUR) . Loved palatine Hill. Great views , great for pictures. I highly reccomend doing a tour for things like this in Rome, you won't regret it and you will learn more about the history. Check it out.

Beautiful place!. Visit at first the giant Colosseum, then the fabulous Forum Romanum and lastly have a nice stay and enjoy the silence under the Palatine trees! Take off your shoes, lay down on the earth and try to imagine, how many people was there before you...

Plan for a long visit. You need at least 3 hours to visit all the items on the map here, so plan ahead. The site closes on sunset, so in winter they start evacuating people around 4-4:30.
There is a lot of walking involved, with steps and hills, so not for you if you have a stroller or get around slower.

Don't bother with the audio guide. What an interesting and imagination-provoking place! We had a great wander around the forum and Palatine hill for about 3 hours and would highly recommend it. It's incredible to walk on the grounds of such an ancient place. One piece of advice though would be to leave the audio guide. Perhaps it's just because we've been to a LOT of museums in the last month but we felt there was too much information - a bit heavy on weird random histories that didn't seem to have that much to do with what we were looking at. Also we were to we had to return it by 2pm and the place shuts at 4:30 which isn't great.

So much history / manage your time. It is an amazing place. So much history in such little space.If you plan your visit for the late afternoon, have in mind that they push out the tourist at the very end of the working time. So do not count on some additional time after that.

Beautiful, historic remains*****. - Beautiful place to escape the busy centre of the city- Could stare for hours at the ruins, very calming- Fantastic atmosphere, a true trip back in time- From the top of Palatine Hill, the view is inspiring, definitely worth a visit.

Make sure not to miss parts. I first visited here in November 2011, however, returning in February 2013 I realized that I had missed missed out part of the attractions on the Palatine Hill including the museum - so be careful. Walking around the area with its pine trees, you imagine exactly what a Roman saw.12 Euros for the Colosseum, Forum and Palatine........what a bargain!

Get a guide!. Ancient Rome - just close your eyes and you can imagine how impressive it must have been in ancient times! If you are a history buff, it'd be good to invest in a tour or at least an audio guide else you wont know which building you're looking at.

Take a guided tour if you want a great experience. Sure you can do this on your own but you won't know what the building were and the true feeling of the place. This is an archeologist dream and some of the most amazing architecture that you'll ever see. The only problems is that this place is full of tourist and can get crowded so that is why an experienced tour guide would be my recommendation. You should spend the entire day exploring the Roman ruins and the Colosseum. Wear comfy shoes.
Ancient Rome. This was great to walk around and to see the old civilisation and ruins. For a first time visit would recommend this as well as the coliseum.
The best place to see and feel Old Rome. We went on a very hot day - but there is spigot water available everywhere - you really get lost in the history - a magnificent place
Not what I expected. We had never even heard of this place until we attended today and even though we had a pram which was difficult - this was just an amazing experience

As in the history books.... Helped by the experience of our guide, this part of Rome has been absolutely the most interesting. You can feel yourself in the middle of history, between senators and emperors.

Center of Ancient Rome. The Roman Forum and Palatine Hill have a lot of history behind them as it was the center of the Roman Empire. You've read about it, heard about, now see it. Even if you don't pay the entrance fee to get inside, you still get an impressive display of the ruins from outside and all around. Well worth the time.

It Was Awe Inspiring!. This by far was the highlight of my two week trip to Italy. Walking in the steps of so much history, imagining what life was like! This is definitely a must see for anyone visiting Rome. I would suggest that you familiarize yourself with Rome's history before doing so, it will make the visit that much more enjoyable. My wife and I took probably close to 50 pictures during our visit to the forum.

A must see place. If you're going to Rome in August this place can get very hot. Either you can visit it early in the morning or later in the afternoon. Despite all the heat this is a fantastic place that must be seen if you're going to Rome. When I arrived, I got lucky because the queue was not very long. Definitely one of my favorite attractions in Rome.

A lot of history. Make sure to give yourself plenty of time here. My husband and I ddn't allow enough and it closed before we were finished. I'd say a few hours is enough if you're taking a leisurely pace. We didn't get a tour guide but passed one and wished we had. They were sharing some pretty interesting facts. This is right beside the Colosseum and their tickets cover both places.

Wear comfortable shoes and prepare for photo's galore!. The queue for tickets for this place was only about 10 minutes long and you can buy a ticket with the Colosseum included (which you can visit the next day) so don't queue for hours at the Colosseum!We didn't visit all of the places inside as we were very tired from walking on the small steps so I would advise you to wear comfortable shoes, but what we did see made for some amazing photo's and beautiful views.Look at the map for the few toilet sites they have there as I waited over 25 minutes for the one toilet in the museum and then found a totally empty toilet facility close by! They really need to advertise the different 'shortcuts' around the tourist parts of Rome!

Great views from Palatine Hill. We had great views from Palatine Hill of the ruins of Rome. You get a good photo opportunity of the Colosseum with the ruins in the foreground. Palatine Hill is probably the most impressive of the seven hills of Rome. There is an amazing amount of history contained in the small area between the Colosseum and Palatine Hill.

Can't believe this isn't rated higher. My husband and I spent an entire day wandering around the incredible ruins in this site. If you have any interest in history or archaeology this is a must-see. One tip - the entry for the forum / colusseum is the same ticket - go here first and you'll be able to walk straight into the colosseum without queueing!

#1 tip - hire a guide. i know that others have advised not to bother with a guide but if you have any inkling to get a true sense of the history of this area i strongly disagree. sure, you can stumble through and snap pictures willy nilly, ooh and aah at the architecture and splendour of just being there but i assure you that you will have no idea of the *true* magnitude of the history of this place if you don't hire a guide. take a bit of time before you go to rome to look online for a solid third party private tour guide who for around 100 euro will provide you with endless amounts of amazing insight and all the little tidbits the other tourists just waltz past unaware while randomly clicking away on their cameras or ipads.i don't usually advise a guide to see sites (you can read my other reviews... louvre, no guide, pont du garde, don't need a guide...) but in the case of palatine hill and the colosseum i still attest that it was money well spent. if you are going to come here from abroad to see it why waste your time flipping madly through a guide book for a few sporadic notes and risk missing out on a truly great historically/culturally enriching experience? others who visit this spot may leave with amazing pictures of the columns, and the *cool* roman ruins to show friends and family when they return home but you will actually be able to tell people about why it why it was so gosh darn important for you to go there to take photos in the first place.visited in may 2012

Photographers Dream. This is my third visit to the palatine and it was still just as enjoyable. Plenty has been written on TZ about the sense of history and the great views, but I would also like to add that it is an awesome place to enjoy taking photos. The ruins are beautiful in themselves, but the vistas between them make for some magic snaps. The Colosseum is impressive, but pretty one dimensional compared to this part of the area.

Brilliant!!!. Again did this venue with a fab english speaking guide...who was able to explain the improtance of what we were seeing...it was great to be walking in the same place as the Ancient Romans..obviously not quite the same...but this history, is breathing & you can touch it...again miss at your peril!!! lol
Takes time to see it all, but worth it. Take the Rick Steves audio and it will help with understanding it all. Lots of history. We visited Palantine Hill as well so there's lots of uphill as well.

Great view from Palatine Hill. A lot of history is compacted in a small area having a large amount of ruins, statues and gardens. It is impressive standing on Palatine Hill overlooking the Roman Forum with the Colosseum in the background. We were part of a private guided tour which was helpful in having a greater understanding of the sites we were seeing. This is an important place to visit to understand Roman history. It is the main hill containing a large collection of archaeological sites.
Download the TripAdvisor app. Download the app so you can have a tour at your fingertips. Very interesting history. Lots of walking so make sure to wear comfortable shoes and the weather is good.

Why isn't Palatine Hill in the guidebooks?. We spent 3 hours in the Coliseum, thought we'd do a quick tour of the Hill, and were pleasantly surprised that there was soooo much to see up there. The Emperors' Palace and gardens were amazing, the view, breathtaking. We ended up spending another two or three hours there. We actually liked it better than the forum. Don't short yourself by skipping this or only leaving a short time for this. The museum was interesting and the expansive ruins take time to walk through.

Absoutely the place to vist for ancient Rome. Not only did Mussolini allegedly make the trains run on time, he certainly was instrumental in saving this area of ancient Rome that preserves so much in buildings, government, living, worship and scenery. Be sure to visit this with a trained guide or you will miss a lot.If I were to visit three places in ancient Rome, it would be this, the Pantheon, and the Colosseum. We took a tour that covered ancient Rome in the AM (Colosseum and Palatine) and modern Rome in the PM (Spanish steps, Pantheon and Trevi fountain.)

Rome, Siena, Florence. go... do not miss anything. we started in Rome, and headed north. We visited lots of churches and ruins. and each one was more spectacular than the next. People were friendly and helpful everywhere.

Almost better than the colosseum. Can get in with your colosseum ticket, right across the street. You walk through the ruins and collumes. It is truly something. You can imagine yourself in those times. And visit the church.

History!!. So much history here worth a visit but wear flat shoes as the stones or pebbles you walk on can be a pain on your feet!! Only drawback was that it was not very well sign posted inside and you can walk for ages to try and get out.

Best Place to Buy Colosseum Tickets. One ticket gets you into three attractions; Palatine Hill, the Roman Forum, and the Colosseum; and you can easily see all three in a day. Skip the long ticket line at the Colosseum and go to the Palatine Hill ticket office on Via San Gregorio, just a short walk south of the Colosseum.Palatine Hill is less crowded, and more peaceful, then either the Forum or the Colosseum. Start here and wander through the ruins. The Stadio is worth a look and there are several good viewpoints from the top of the hill.When you come back down the hill walk past the ticket office (but DO NOT exit) and enter the Forum. Save the Colosseum for last and go directly to the entrance with your ticket. Do not get in the ticket line by mistake!
Amazing!. What an amazing historical place! very large but I really loved it. History is everywhere (yes it is in all Rome) but this place has something different. A must go!

Take a tour. My experience here was not great, but it was probably influenced by the heat which made it hard to walk around this barren area of rocks and put in the effort to discover what everything once was. I think to appreciate this area you need to read up on it in advance or take a guided tour. Without that it is hard to see more than rocks.

If you are in Rome, this is a must see. I love history! I've been fortunate to have had the opportunity to spend a considerable amount of time in Rome. I really loved the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill! It's a large area! History is everywhere for you to explore, touch, marvel at! You wont want to miss this if you are in Rome! They are still making new discoveries, which is cool to see. History buffs, visit this, please!I also recommend that you visit Ostia Antica, the old harbor of Rome. It is an absolutely fantastic preserved location. It will offer you different historical things to see that you wont see at the forum.

For history buffs. The historic importance of this place is unique in the world, but to most, it's only a field of old stones with nice carvings. The different stages of archeologic digs have left their trace. Do your homework before you fly and gather information before you fly to Rome to make sure you have a reasonable knowledge of the place you'll see and their significant importance. For history buffs, like I am, a very moving visit to the heart of western civilization, not to be missed and to enjoy to the fullest. If you stay in Rome for at least 3 days, use the Roma Pass and get entrance to the nearby Colosseum and Palatine Hill, skipping queues at each.

ANOTHER GORGEOUS PLACE. We visited this by accident but spent hour upon hour looking around this .We found this small church and spent an hour just there looking at the intricate carvings and ornate finishes on the ceiling.A must see on your visit to Rome

Take the guided tour. Definitely worth taking the guided tour- much more efficient and informative that way and avoids aimless wandering . Our tour guide was knowledgeable , her English was charmingly cute and she had a book which showed us what things must have looked like so many years ago.

Interesting but not mind blowing. I loved it and really liked it but it was not mind blowing. Sometimes it is really hard to imagine what it was like thousands of years ago. Some pictures would have help to imagine what it was like, Yes there was plenty of information but not pictures. Pictures do say more than 1000 words. It was not too crowded and the area is a nice break from the hectic world around it.

Amazing place. One of those places you just have to see to believe. I'm not all into history, but I was just in awe of this place. So serene and I can just imagine the hustle and bustle in its heyday. For 12 euro, you can see the Roman Forum, Palatine Hill and Colosseum. It wasn't busy at all when we came at around 1:30. Made me want to learn more about the people who built it, why and how long it took. Couldn't even think of a place in the US that could even compare. Definitely recommend.

Use a tour guide!. This was such an incredible thing to see. Walking passed it is not the same as walking through with a tour guide. I learned so much that I never would've known had I just walked through alone. Our tour guide made me interested in the history of Rome so I highly suggest getting a tour guide.

Great History. This is a great place to go and see some real Ancient Roman ruins, and statues. We took our time strolling around here and took plenty of pictures to bore our friends and family with. I couldn't get over how well maintained these were, and would recommend anyone with an interest in the Ancient Romans to take a look, as I'm sure you could fill a day strolling around here.
Must visit. Book ot together with the Colosseum. Suggest to do a bit of research before as there are no big explanations. Audioguide is tecommendable but must be returned at the same entrance.

Ancient Ruins, unique experience. We went on a Sunday with the roads around closed and it was atmospheric and beautiful. A must see but take your time, bring a good guide book and try and take it all in.

Plan ahead to enjoy your visit - Worth it!. Loved this place and cannot get enough of the spectacular views and incredible history. It is just breathtaking and if you love history, you will not be disappointed. I cannot describe the feeling of being in a place like this. It is a unique experience that I wouldn't trade for anything. It is a a ruin, so not everything is perfectly preserved. However, it seems that every time I come here, a new section of Palantine HillI or the Forum is being conserved or renovated. It is also an archaeological site that frequently has new sections opened up or discovered. So each time I visit, I see a new part that I did not see before. I looked at a lot of the reviews that complained about not getting a map - maps are available with Roma Pass purchase, online, and with many guide books such as Rick Steve's. Rome is not a place to go and just "wing it". It is very old and can be confusing. With taking the time to thoroughly check out places we wanted to visit, reserving tickets, and properly planning our time, my husband and I never got lost and came away happy. YES, you do need to keep your belongings close. Pick pockets are a problem. My husband keeps our IDs, money and credit cards in a zippered pouch that he wears around his neck and buttoned inside his shirt.
Struck by the history. The Forum was expansive and full of historical significance. To see the rocks where Cesear's body was creamated brought to mind the scope of history present here.

The best of Rome. I found these ancient ruins, preserved more by luck than good management down through the centuries, profoundly moving and fascinating. Because they represent a large enclave of Ancient Rome the walking around gives a wonderful feeling of time and space. I would say if you only had a day in Rome you would have to do these ancient ruins. We actually did a sort of ancient walk starting at the Pantheon and ambling along the river until we found ourselves there.

a new experience for me. had a few hours between meetings and I strolled up the hill. excellent,. i didnot go in to the paying area but walk up along side as time was tight. Came upon a lovely church,

Imperial Rome. It does not matter how many times I visit Rome, coming here is mandatory.From my childhood fascination with the wonderment of the Roman Empire..coming here permits me to ponder how incredibly brilliant, indulgent, cruel, hedonistic, political and the list goes on..One cannot say they 'have to Rome' without wandering for a few hours around this precinct of Rome.It is Rome in all it splendour and glory!Tip: Good walking shoes and for the female tourists NO heels!

Disappointing. Of the numerous ancient sights I've visited this was the most underwhelming sights I,ve visited.Not worth paying to get in but you can view most of ot from the streets, so don't bother paying. Particularly poor was Palatine Hill the Forum was better

Worth the visit. Did not disappoint,. The Palatine Hills ruins was so much better, less crowd, more space, more to see, more to imagine. Much better than the Colloseum. Go there at late afternoon, around 3 pm and as you walk, the setting sun really gives a great photo op background around the ruins' temples.Colloseum was crowded and has long lines, as part of the tour, Palatine Hills was a great respite.

Great ruins. This place is so beautiful no matter where you look. Try to imagine it as it was when in use. Come back at night and walk around to see the buildings lit up. If you want to understand the area and what you're looking at, use a guide or buy a book.TIP: Rick Steves has a great free walking tour of the area. Download before you go and put on phone or ipod or download the app and install the tour.

Well worth the time but have a guide!. These ancient grounds were pretty amazing to say the least. We were fortunate enough to have a private guide who explained everything there was to know about it. Without that knowledge being passed on to us it would still be worth the time but invest in a guide to get the full flavor of the site.

Guided tour worth the cost. We used the Context Rome Tours for Palatine and Forum. They have small groups which was great....................... be sure to see the museum on the Palatine. Have done the same tour twice a few years ago.

Walk back in time....... Great historical area, bringing to life the Roman times. You get a great view from the rear of the Vittorio Emmanuel II Monument where you can get some great photos opportunities.

A little more relaxed than the Colosseum. Another part of ancient Roma, and enjoyable just to wander. As with the Forum and the Colosseum, don't feel the need for guides. You don't need a history lesson, just wander the grounds and you can imagine and feel what it must have been like to be in ancient Rome. A good location for a photo of the Colosseum from a different viewpoint as well. Far less crowded and more relaxed than the Forum or Colosseum, which you will appreciate if it is the last of those three places you visit together.

Extraordinary ruins are jaw-dropping. This historic site contains so much history and deserves most of a day to take it in, which is what I did with my one day in Rome. Located next to the Colosseum, this site was buried for a long time under 20 meters of material and remains only partially excavated. What is exposed is amazing. Tours and guidebooks add so much color, as the history is rich. There is a lot of preservation work ongoing.

The glow of an era gone by. Despite being in ruins, every fragment, every stone, every broken pillar tells a stunning story. This was the throbbing heart of Roman republic and early Roman empire. One of the most important public places, at least in the western world. This was the place that saw innumerable dramatic events unfolding, tug of war between Marius and Sulla, the formation of first triumvirate, Cicero's oratory skills, fights between gangs of Clodius & Milo, the civil war between factions of Julius Caesar and Pompey, Caesar's cremation and the beginning of Roman emperor-ship under Octavian (Augustus Caesar). No other place except, may be Athens, influenced the western civilization like this one. Just standing here and imagining the past was enough to give the goose-bumps.

Amazing ruins totally worth a visit. If you go, make sure you go to both the Roman Forum and the Palatine Hill which are adjacent to one another. In fact, some of the best views of the Forum are from the Palatine Hill. It's amazing to walk through the ruins and you are really transported to another time. Don't miss this amazing history lesson.

Walking guided tour is the way to go!. We had limited time to see as much as we could, so getting onto a guided walking tour was the way to go! Not only were we taken around by a knowledgeable guide, but it also made the history of the place really come alive and made for a truly interesting afternoon - the 3+ hours seeing the Forum, Palatine hill and Colosseo was definitely well worth it!
Spectacular Setting and Incredible Historic Site. This is an incredible historic site that must be on everyone's travel agenda in Rome. Be sure to allow enough time to take it all in.

Well worth the time and effort. It's unfortunate that prior generations didn't preserve this site, but what is left is amazing. However, make sure to either hire a guide or prepare by reading alot about the site.

Say Hello to Julius. A city within a city...thats what it was. A place for gathering and markets alike. You can see the mix of roman architecture and influence of the church in the structures that lived and those that didn't. What was interesting was the guide showing us the reality of the place with a book that shows you the structures that were re-traced as they were.And eerily, you can also say hello to Julius who is beleived to be buried here.

excellent if you love Roman history. If you love Roman history, you will love visiting the Palatine. A prime spot for Roman aristocrats to live for centuries, it became primarily the location for emperors to live starting with Augustus. He lived here for over 40 years in the same modest place he first had when he became emperor. Granted it was more lavishly decorated then the average Roman's, but compared to the emperors who followed him, it was modest indeed. Later a palace was built by Domitian in around 81 AD. Presently there are the extensive remains of later modifications and additions to this area. There is a small museum on the top of the hill that is worth about 30 minutes to go through. For me the highlight of the Palatine is the House of Augustus. You get to view four rooms of the man who had total control of the western world for 45 years. Absolutely check the hours this is open. I was told all day and arrived about 2:00 to find it closed. It appears at present it's only open until 1:30, but only on certain days. The House of Livia (his wife) is closed to the public. There are also some remains they have discovered that date to about 850 BC that support Rome's legends of having been founded in 753 BC. It seems the Colosseum and The Forum get all the press (which they deserve) but do not overlook this fabulous area.

Easy to spend a hour or two enjoying the sites and views. Went to Palatine Hill - Forum after sitting waiting in the ticket line at the Colloseum. You use the same ticket to go to both so waited in the much shorter (5 mins) line for Palatine Hill. It's a huge expanse in the center of Rome. Lots of ruins. Nothing particularly breathtaking, but the feeling of history and the views to the rest of the Rome made it one of my favorite places to visit. You picture in your mind how spectacular this place once was and now what it's become. Makes you think about how people will look back at the artifacts of our civilization two millennia hence.

Fantastic piece of history. Incredible place, to walk on the same stones as the caesars and see how advanced their building skills were 2000 years ago. Some attractions inside the Forum are not open every day, e.g. the House of Augustus was not open on Fridays. There is a small sign of this just before the ticket office, which was a very nice (NOT) surprise after having stood in the queue for an hour to get a ticket. (We decided to go to Colosseum instead and come back the next day because this was one of the things I definitely wanted to see.)There are couple of places where you can fill your water bottle, up on the Palatine next to the garden and down on the Forum behind Basilica Giulia.

Walking the beautiful ruins. This is a great way to get into the colosseum and avoid the lines there. Lines not as bad at all. Loved wandering the ruins and using our imagination, peering into rooms and gasping at some leftover surviving wonder like a curved ornate ceiling in what seemed like a crumbling cave. Enjoyed the fact that there was some oddball art at one end, glass box of heads like pompeiian mummies. Good place to visit on a nice day. So fun to feel almost alone, just the two of us, in ancient Rome.

Beautiful Place Full of History. This is right across the street from the Colosseum. Your ticket to the Colosseum will get you into the Forum and Palatine Hill. So you might as well go. As to those who expressed, "just more ruins," seeing much of Europe is seeing and feeling history. If you are too ignorant to appreciate where you are standing or what you are seeing, might I suggest that you visit McDonnalds and tell all your friends about how you ate a hamburger in Rome. For those of you who appreciate history and culture, I need not say more.
Rome, my favorite city. Such a rich environment of culture for all of your senses.....by far the most romantic, and cultured city I have ever been to.

If you like ancient history. A worth visit for you are who like to become little historians. Ruins of many ancient buildings. But coming with children perhaps is not the best for them, unless you explain to them. The most excavated area even is Trajan forum, across the street which unexpectedly very few people visit it.

Best place for heat hiding. Rome is quite hot in summer and autumn. The best place to enjoy Rome in the middle of the day is Palatine Hill, a green and nice place for a picnic to enjoy your lunch with family. Also if you are tired of walking and standing.

check details before paying and get ticket!. We did the combined tour and was told that the ticket lasted for 2 days. aqbnd could do it at our leasure. We were not given a ticket and when I asked I was told that the tour guide would give them to us. One of our party felt unwell and we were going to leave the Palatine and Forum till the following day but when we asked for the tickets he did not have any and my husband could see that the tickets the guide was using were dated the day before our tour. So he was obviously using someone elses tickets from the day before hence the reason why he could not give us any. Just check and get your tickets before you start. Dont let this put you off, it is an amazing experience! I would recommend a tour guide but just be careful

Nice but get a guided tour and befor eyou get into gates.. Amazing ruins but confusing without a guided. Could not figure out how to si up for tour. Then once inside could not get audio guide. Once you are in you cannot leave forum (to get tour guide or audio guide) and come back in - that very disappointingRecommend Roma pass if doing a bit in Rome for the 3 days

Fascinating but blurs after a while. Huge, sprawling site.Definitely worth a look but to be honest it starts to all blur in to one after a while.There was a beautiful rose garden & the ruins in the forum section were quite majestic.

Centre of an empire, don't miss the senate house. Make sure you include this in your Rome itinerary, as many other reviewers have indicated there are a lot of similar ruins and temples but for me the total highlight was the relatively plain square building at the bottom end which turned out to be the house of the senate with the original Marble floor that 2000 years ago was where the senators of Rome debated.Made the hairs on the back of my neck stand up with the sheer weight of history.

Once in a life time trip. We did Rome in a couple of days. It was tiring but well worth it. We bought the Omnia Rome & Vatican Pass which included Roma Pass & map plus fasttrac ticket to a couple of different attractions prior to the trip. Between the hop on hop off bus which has audio guide & our own foot power. We did the Coliseum, walked to the Forum/Palantine Hill, threw coin in Trevi Fountain, across the Tiber river to visit the Vatican City. Walked to the Panteon, stood on the Spanish steps, walked to Campo di Fiore, visited Castle St. Angelo, rode the bus passed the Capitol, saw Piazza Navonna. It's a lot of walking but it can be done. I do not recommend renting a car in Rome. Parking is a bear & traffic is beyond believe. We were surprised that we did not see one traffic accident. Although, we've heard a lots of siren goes by. It's a busy place but interesting. One sad note, there are graffitis every where. I guess it's typical of big city.

Unbeatable Value. We took a chance and just found our own way around the Forum and Palatine hill. At just €12 each it was amazing! It has been a real dream for many years to be able to explore the whole area and get a feel for what is perhaps the great centre of history anywhere on earth.

history comes alive. this time we didn't enter the palantine hill. we toured it from the outside. you can see alot of the ruins without entering. all 3 sights are very exciting. you can realy imagine life there 2000 year ago.

Ruins and nothing else. The grounds are very wide and there is lots to see, but after a while they all look the same - ruins, ruins, and ruins. The Colosseum is much more interesting. Would recommend travellers to come here first before going to the Colosseum, as a way to manage expectations.

Worth seeing at least once. It is a piece of history like non other. So make sure you do not skip this one. But do not give in tourist traps that makes you spend tons to get a "personal tour" You don't need a guide, you can read and experience it yourself.

History lovers rejoice!. We thought we would be in and out quickly but spent an entire afternoon there. The grounds are massive and there is so much to see! I would recommend carving out an afternoon to properly see everything the grounds have to offer. I would also recommend a tour guide to really help bring the ruins to life. We really enjoyed being able to walk through sites with so much history. Definitely a must see while in Rome!

Step back in time. This is a must see. Take a full day and visit this attraction, it's well worth it. It really has an amazing feel that helps you step back in time to see and understand what it was like way back when. It is a full day to see round both of these and the long walk at times can take it's toll, but if like me, seeing the next point of interest put a wee hop back into my step.....Go see it for yourself!!

Back in time!. This was part of our guided tour (Colosseum, Roman Forum and Palatine Hill) and so worth it. It is great to wander by yourself, but bonus when you get inside scoops from great guides. We booked our tour with Dark Rome.

At Last!. We didn't have time to visit the Forum on our first trip so we were thrilled to finally visit on this trip. We bought the 12 Euro ticket at the Coliseum and used that for our entry here.We considered hiring a guide, but I've done a lot of reading...travel books and Roman history....so we decided to go it alone. It worked out just fine. I actually carried Rick Steve's Rome book so I had a quick reference to fall back upon when needed.There is so much to see here and so much to "feel"....soaking in the sights...thinking of who walked these streets 2000 years ago....and just trying to get deep into the ancient Roman experience.There is much much much to see and take in here. I really don't suggest trying to walk it and just look. Either study up or go with a tour that uses headsets so you can clearly hear the guide.However you do it, I think your visit to Rome isn't complete without a visit to the Forum.

Very interesting. A tour guide is absolutely necessary here. Otherwise you won't probably understand what exactly you're looking at since you don't have much information on spot.We bought a tour for the Colosseum and Roman Forum and it was a fantastic and funny experience. The guides were absolutely amazing, we've learned so much! And we also skipped the queue.

Nice extension to a colosseum trip. An ancient part of the city, with many ruins and gardens. There is some signage explaining what you're seeing. Great views of the colosseum and city from the top. I wish I'd had a guide for this part of our trip. Even without a guide to explain everything, its worth the hour or so to walk around, especially if the weather is nice.

Get the tour. This area was in conjunction with a tour of the Coliseum and the guide will make the difference. We had a fantastic enthusiatic guide that made all the typically boring ruins really come to life. And we had the headsets so even though we were out in the open- everyone could clearly hear the guide. FYI we booked our Italy adventures/tours at the Walks of Italy website.

Give yourself hours to wander. We spent three hours and still did not see everything in the forum and on Palentine Hill. The Hill is very peaceful and I would seriously recommend taking a picnic and sitting under some of the lovely trees at the top to soak up the atmosphere.

Archaeological site with lots of walking. Don't go in August, too hot. Lots of walking around and the maps were not helpful. A lot of the signs would tell you to a direction and you couldn't go that way. It would be nice to have a guide as you don't always know what you are looking at.

You could spend hours at this place. Had visited this attraction as part of a group tour. Unfortunately the hour that we spent there was not nearly enough I thought.Wonderful area with so many ruins that are still standing and are in very good condition.As I am someone who is fascinated by the Ancient Romans I found it really interesting place to visit.The only thing is that you really should dedicate at least 3 hours to see it, 1 hour was just not enough for me I thought.But what I got to see in the hour or so was fascinating. A definite item on any trip to Rome.

No tour, no information. I went without joining a tour so we have no idea of what we are looking at, other than rock n stones. However we did overhear some tour guides doing the story telling, which makes a lot more sense. My advice is do your homework or join a tour.

nice atmosphere. It is very close to coliseum , you can get entrance ticket for both palatine and coliseum by 12 Euro , but better to pay 17 euro and you will have a guide tour for the palatine hills , and was really interesting and you can understand what is going around you , I recommend it , with this ticket you don’t have to wait for a long time in a row of ticket it is a fast pass ticket

Lots of walking but fantastic!. Again, we had a licensed guide which was set up in advance. I had been to Palatine Hill before but it meant nothing until I heard the history of the property. It's very hilly, rocky with no respite from the heat. There is one fountain to get water from so bring your own water bottle!

Spendor in the ruins!. All of Rome is a must see! The hills, the history, the hallowed grounds are moving. Lots of walking, but very interesting and a completely different experience from anything in the states.

Take These 2 in Along with the Colosseum. You can buy a combo pass for the Colosseum, Forum, and Palatine Hill - definitely do it. The lines at Palatine Hill are much shorter than the Colosseum, so buy it there.This area is fascinating, so much rich history. Hire a tour guide, or download Rick Steves' podcasts to help enrich the experience. It's so spread out it would be hard to imagine there's a bad time of day to go for fear of crowds. But bring a hat b/c there's not a lot of shade.

Step back in time. Visit the Forum first and the ticket you purchase will allow you access to the Colosseum which means you will not have to stand in line for ages.You really do walk back in time - lots to see with exhibits all over the place.We had a tour with Walks of Italy and the guide was really helpful and know a great deal about Roman history - it was a great help talking with someone who knew so much
Go with a guide. Beautiful ruins, but go with a guide so that you get a full understanding of what the area was used for, what it looked line in ancient times and the history surrounding it.
Book Direct. As title, forget £50 packages and book direct online inc guide and basement and upper tiers tour for about £17Great spooky place

Rome-2013. Already rated the Colosseum. Don't know what an Aperitif is, other than a cocktail, and don't think that's what is being referred to here. Palatine Hill, one of the seven hills of Rome is beautiful. The gardens and ruins are very impressive but would have been a big mystery without a guide to walk you through and give you the pastoral and mythical backgrounds. The Forum was great..one can almost feel the Senate meeting there and conferring...probably gives foundation to some of our political system.

Wonderful visit. Just to be able to wander around freely and acknowledge the wonder of the ruins is mind blowing. At every turn you expect history to come alive and for a past civilisation to step forward and greet you. There are many guides offering tours and as l have taken one before l was able to enjoy my own thoughts this time.

Breathtaking diggings and antiqities. It is difficult to take in the scale of the development at Palatine. Everywhere one looks there are ancient ruins of significant size and importance. Not to be missed

Forum Romanum. This was the commercial,religious, political and legal center of the city and dates back to the 7th Century BC! When you walk on these streets you can picture how they lived-you can imagine people like Julius Caesar, Mark Anthony countless saints and martyrs...The Arch of Titus.built after they defeated the Israelite's. The large Corinthian columns The Temple of Romelus the statues of past Emperors that are still standing-just so much to take in...Well worth the visit!

Emperors lived here!. The Palantine represents the birthplace of Rome..And is supposed to date back to approximately 754 BC..There is also evidence of the bronze age..Most of the Emperors lived on the Palantine.. Fascinating to see.Incorporate this with a visit to the Forum and the Colosseum.

The type of day you want to spend in Rome. The colosseum is everything grandeur Rome was. Palatine Hill and Roman Forum are where the transformation of Rome from its Etruscan beginnings, to its current form, takes place. And once your feet are beaten to a pulp, and your spirit has been lifted immersed in history... you deserve an aperitif! TO ROME! CinCin!

Spend the day!. A wonderful day spent looking at the ruins. They are extensive, beautiful and wonderful to look at. Bring water as the fountains are somewhat hard to come by. Bring a lunch and sit on one of the benches or better yet take a seista under a tree after eating a sandwich.... It's a great day long experince.

A must see. Beautiful, no other words, just simply beautiful. Make sure you drink from the fountains, I was a bit scared but the water was crystal clear. It was hot and a lot of walking, but absolutely well worth it.
Great history. It was worth the time and effort, but it is a lot of walking both up and down. Definitely don't miss it as it is a good way to start a Rome tour. AirForceColonel

Incredible. Loved everything about this area and could just imagine how life must have been for the people of Rome. This is the 3rd time to Rome and certainly not the last. What we did not like was the liter and foreigners selling "made in China".

Go before the Colosseum. In my opinion this was far more interesting than the Colosseum. Of course, may be is not as spectacular (architecture) as the Colosseum, but there are meny things to see and learn here.If you don't have booked a tour or if you didn't reserve your tickets in advance, buy a combined ticket for the Forum and the Colosseum here. It is about 12 EUR, and you won't have to queue for hours.But for sure, a guided tour is the way to go here, there is just to much to see, so it is better if you listen all the info from an expert.
loves it. You must go in to get a good look, as you can only see a small section from the outside, (from afar). Explore palentine hill gives a good view overlooking the colloseum, love it.

Worth a look with a guide. This was part of the Dark Rome (Triposo viator) half day walking tour along with the Colosseum and it was excellent. Straight to the front and in, well worth doing a guided tour as you would miss so much without expert knowledge. Our tour finished here so afterwards we had plenty of time to wander and take everything in.
excellent place to walk around. We walked around the outside of the forum, no need to pay to go in as you can see everything from above with just a greater view.

Globus Best of Italy. I was recently on Globus tours Best of Italy (Sept 2013) and was pick pocketed in this very area. I would suggest for those on tours to leave all belongings, wallets, backpacks on the locked tour bus while visiting in these areas. This happened on the first full day of my trip. You can never be too careful.

So much history. Make sure you have sensible shoes as you will do lots of walking around these sites!
Saturns temple plus many more. Give at least a couple of hours to walk around these sites. Roma pass will skip the queues at the colosseum

a walk thru time. nothing bad to say about this walk. Ancient historyall around. Stories of Pagan temples converted to Roman temples converted to Catholic churches. Walk where the galdiators walked, sit where emperors sat and just soak in the history.

Well worth the price of 12 euros. The best parts are the Palantine Hill which has wonderful views of Rome. The stadium is really impressive. However the house of Livia seemed to be closed so couldn't see any mosaics as described in the guidebooks. The Forum is sadly mostly disjointed ruins but still very interesting with at least one building largely intact.

Lots to absorb.. Get a guide book or better still, a guide, if you want to make the best of the visit because there is just so much to take in, but even if you don't and are just looking at the information boards it's still well worth it to see and be in the place where it all happened over 2000 years ago. To avoid queuing buy your combined ticket at the entrance to the Forum (the other end from the Colosseum) where queues are light or non-existent. When you get to the Colosseum you can then walk past the queues (they are queuing for tickets) and walk straight into the amphitheatre then let your imagination run free and enjoy.

Lots to see. There is so much to see here so make sure you plan to spend a good few hours there so you don't miss out. Best value entry is to get a combined ticket with the Colosseum. There are some brilliant views out across the rest of Rome and some interesting ruins. The only annoyance was a lack of toilets - there were several closed toilet blocks with no explanation as to why or to where the nearest open toilets were.

Cool to see out audio sucked. This place is visually amazing but the audio tour was very confusing. I would recommend getting a book with the transperancy that shows the before and after and just read about it.

First time we spent enough time. Spent most of a whole day here, on our own! We were wary because the guidebooks say that it's not well marked and too confusing to do without a guide or at least the audio guide, but when we got there early one day, they had no more audio guides and we didn't want the video guide. So we wandered off on our own with a good guide book and had an absolutely wonderful time. (Note: we felt the same way about the Capitoline Museum, the maps were clear and we did very well). This is a stunning place!

Awesome guide made it come alive!. We did this tour as part of the walking tour that we did of the Colosseum. We had Rory as our guide and he was fantastic. The ruins are amazing by themselves but his commentary made the whole area come alive for us, as his historical knowledge was delivered clearly and with a dry sense of humour. I fully recommend that you take a tour if you can, as it adds another dimension to a trip to Rome. A "not to be missed" part of Rome!

A pile of rubble. Ok I know! There are far better roman sites than this in just about very country in Europe. Given that this is the heart of the Roman Empire and indeed Rome, I can't help but feel disappointed. The site is steeped in history but it's a mess. It fails to deliver any sense of the majesty that once existed. Pity.

A Must See. This is another site in Rome that is best seen in a private tour. The history, glory and downfall is best heard from an educated historian. This is the center of ancient Roman politics. It is a not to be missed site. Right next to the Colosseum so see both in the same visit.

Well worth a half day. Well worth using one of your free entries on your Roma ticket, if you visit the Colosseum and the Forum it only counts as one ticket, excellent value and beat the queues!
The excavations enable you to imagine what it was like 2000 years ago.

Historical. This is a time consuming exercise! If you're interested in history this is a must. It will take a good few hours and a lot of walking, so have your walking shoes ready. There are on-going excavations, very interesting. And a lovely rose garden for a bit of light relief!

Amazing. You have to have a bit of imagination or a guide book to picture it as it should have been but it's certainly inspiring. It was as usua; very busy and difficult to navigate at times the signs are amazing and informative but if you have the opportunity to pick up an audio guide or take a mini guide book with you, I would. It would certainly add value.

A piece of history. A piece of history of Great Roman Empire. Nice atmosphere around. It is possible to see the most from outside walls. A "must see" when travelling to Rome. Was there in November 2008.

Very interesting . Very interesting ruins. I suggest taking one of the tours to learn some of the history. It's worth the money in my opinion. On terms of location everything in Rome seems walkable to me so take a few days to wander around and enjoy!

Retracing history. This is why you go to Rome. Use a podcast or take one of the many fantastic tours available. The walk is fantastic, the history undeniable. It was a highlight of Rome for us. It's free with any Colesseum admission. Romans and their conquests were an amazing people. Put your running shoes on and explore.

Not to be missed. Even though we have visited this site before we thoroughly enjoyed viewing them again. It is just so astonishing to think that the Romans built such magnificient buildings. You must visit all 3 sites in the same day but we found this to be fine.

Friends, Romans and Countrymen. To be able to visit a place that has been described as The Cradle Of Democracy and Centre of The ancient Roman Empire was a humbling experience. To walk in the steps of so many great leaders of ancient times, what was not to like? We couldn't possibly see it all in the short time we had. Never the less, it is an absolute must if you are visiting Rome you cannot miss visiting this amazing piece of History.

It's the start of Rome. A must see. How can you go to Rome and not walk where Cesar and the ancients have tread? Make sure you take a tour book with you so you can get more insight and appreciate exactly what you are seeing. It is free with the fee for the Colisium.

Must go!. One of my favorite places in Rome. A real travel in time, totally worth the ticket price. You must be prepare to spend a few hours and some shoes to see all. The place is huge, but extremaly beautiful.

Beautifull hill and amazing giant ruins. When I crossed the gate coming from Constantine's Arch I made a turn on the left and passed under a giant roman aqueduct, then I advise you to go see the enormous retaining walls that allowed a building extension to the palatine hill (for imperial palaces mostly), they are indeed impressive you can't miss them! Them I went to the inner gardens of the palatine called Stadio Palatino,a big rectangular and green open space, lovely! it had once a two-story portico all around! there were many houses(domus augustana, domus severiana) all of this in massive proportions, the walls and roofs, amazing! Well they are the Imperial Palaces!! Wen I reached the top, the palaces were less impressive, but wen I got to the other end of the hill, I was prized with a stunning overlooking view of the roman forum!!The palatine hill was something I wasn't expecting, and impressed me a lot!

Imperial treasures. It is hard to believe the brilliance of the Romans who were ingenious enough to conceive and build these structures. The acquaducts from natural springs are still In use today after originally being built by ancient Romans. To see such buildings and beautiful architecture still standing is truly inspirational.

Enormous tour of Ancient Rome.. The history books come alive in this place. See where Caesar lived and walk on the same Via Sacra. 2000 years of restoration and it continues still with archeologists working throughout the place. Incredible
Great as a Walking Tour. I toured the trio as part of a walking tour. The history and discriptions combined with my imagination made this a tour I will never forget. One of my favorite tours.

Definitely worth the stroll. Palatine Hill is connected to the Forum and the Colosseum is close by. Give yourself a few hours to visit all three. We downloaded Rick Steve's audio guides and also had his guidebook to help us understand what we were seeing. Let yourself walk through history and the glory days of ancient Rome. Use your Roma Pass to make it quite a deal.

Loophole?. We went to buy tickets to explore the Roman forum and palatino at around 11am. There was no line (at the entrance to the forum). Much to our delight, we were able to also purchase tickets to enter the Coliseum! This allowed us to skip the ridiculous line outside of that! For all three, I believe it costed ?12. Worth every bit of it, but bring walking shoes!

Surprisingly enjoyable for a load of old ruins!. Take the opportunity to explore the full grounds, and not just those nearest the Colosseum - some great photo opportunities. Wear sensible shoes, the cobble stones are ankle-snapping! In my opinion, these were worth the money for the joint ticket including the Colosseum (which I found much less enjoyable). Kept seeing signs for toilets - never actually discovered them!

Tour trip through ancient times. We took the Walks of Italy tour that was a good portion of the day, although it was supposed to be 3.50 hours. It was a fine tour with MariaGracia, our amiable hostess who had so much information and was so informative. It was my second time there, and I had routed my large family through this tour, and they loved it.

Go with a guide. This is the amazing historical center of ancient Rome, very impressive.I would highly recommend you go with a group tour or hire a private guide - especially one that has pictures or images of what the buildings used to look like would be great, since they are completely in ruins now. We went on our own thinking that we could follow along on the audio guide but it was pretty bad. First off, you cannot actually follow the audio guide's route due to construction near the senate building. Secondly, the descriptions were not very helpful and were long-winded and boring. I do NOT recommend getting the audio guide - go with a real guide! You really need it in order to understand anything about the site, since nothing is labeled and if you don't get an audio guide they don't give you a map. Otherwise you will just be wandering through some piles of stones and have no idea what you are actually seeing.

Interesting ruins. These ruins have the Colosseum for sight-seeing competition as both are located next to each other. If you are short for time and want to narrow down the sites, I'd visit the Colosseum. If you have the time, Palatine Hill, Roman Forum and the surrounding sites are an interesting walk about...moreso if you have a guide to give you some background information. If you want to see everything, you will need a few hours as there are a lot of ruins spread out over a wide area.

Outstanding!. Unbelievable! To be immersed in history this old! Just to walk among remains this old and see how they built these buildings, etc. without any of the conveniences we now have. We bought a book in the gift shop afterwards (wish we had it before!) it has overlays of how it is believed it all looked at that time. This really puts it all into perspective and you know what you were actually seeing.
Great. Need to go see it is full of history here make sure you take a hat and good shoes uneven ground and very hot in sun not much shade
Amazing. This place was great, there was lots to see and lots of walking on uneven ground but cold drinking water fountains
Wow. This is a must see, lots of walking on uneven ground, they have cold water drinking fountains which was great with the heat.

Best spot in Central Rome. I was not sure what to expect at the forum but I was not disappointed! There is so much to see and so much history attached you can easily spend a day here. Highlight for me was Augustice palace and gardens. Well recommended location to visit while in Rome.
Historic Wonder. Loved it all!! As a Roman history fan it was great to see where it all took place. Lots a walking though so wear comfortable shoes and bring water.

Great area to spend a few hours. These buildings are amazing to walk around and experience what it must have been like all those years ago. There are many trattorias in the area to have a nice afternoon lunch or drink to recover from all your walking. Thoroughly recommend.

An Ideal Day in Rome - a Visitors Perspective. As a tourist visiting a country that I have heard and read about for years, this full day of Roman experiences did not disappoint. The scale of everything is huge and almost hard to take in. So much history and so many stories being told everywhere we turn. Fascinating and educational.

Incredible!. I'm a Roman and Latin lover so this to me is just fantastic but to many might be a load of old ruins. I took a whole day just on Palatine and am saving the Forum and Colosseum or future trips. You need a good guide book recommend Rick Stevens for his tours of Palatine and the forum and you can get them for Kindle so not heavy to carry round. From these we found spots like the exact position of the emperors throne, which even the guided tours just by-passed. Amazing to be standing there and picturing how it might have looked and felt. Recommend a guide or good guidebook or you really can't appreciate what you're looking at ans miss so much.
Amazing and interesting. So much history and culture to absorb. The tour guide made the history of the ruins very interesting. Plenty of photo opportunities

Worth seeing. If you cannot get tickets on line before you go then get them at the Palatine. When we went there there was no queue. Don't do the colosseum and the palatine in the same day, it nearly killed us! The palatine is hard walking up and down hills and stairs on cobbles.

Allow plenty of time to explore and enjoy. We really enjoyed walking around structures that go back so far. some of them are in remarkably good condition. The ticket that you buy for 12 Euros give access to the forum, Palatine hill and also the Colosseum and is really good value. We bought our ticket at the entrance to the Forum nearest to Piazza Venezzia and there was no big queue there.
Quite simply amazing. Struggled to find the entrance, but once in we wandered for hours. Some incredible ruins to stroll amongst.
Definitely worth visiting, fascinating to see. Amazing to think what used to happen here, well maintained but disappointing to see the 'shopping centre' inside the upper levels!

A must see with the colloseum. After I visited the Colloseum, I wandered around palantine hill and then the roman forum. Although I was not on a tour, just wandering the grounds and seeing all the history in front of you was great to see. I believe it complements the whole Colloseum experience

Amazing Tour Through History. Wonderful historical site, the ancient heart of Rome. This is a strenuous site to visit, with steep stairs and pathways up and down hills. Highly recommend using a tour guide, she was able to give so much of the history of what we were looking at that it made so much more sense of what took place here. She also was able to show us what the various structures looked like back then, it really added to our experience. Tour groups and Roma Pass users also bypass the long lines to get in. Do not miss it.

Amazing. Get there early in the morning to avoid the queues, otherwise you will spend 1-2 hours queuing.There is little information posted around the site, so to really appreciate it you should either join one of the group tours or, alternatively, you can read up about the site in advance and then walk around at your own speed to enjoy.Take your own refreshments as there is little, if anything, on site and also a comfortable footwear as there is a lot of walking.

Use a tour guide. We entered the Ancient Rome site via Palantine Hill entrance, guide books say this has the shortest queue times. I guess get there early ,or pre-buy your tickets as it took us 1/2hour . The queue staff asked if we wished to have an official tour guide for €5 extra. Our guide gave a group of us a 45minute tour of Palentine Hill including images of what it used to look like, very informative.Lovely views over Rome from the top too!Afterwards you can head down to the Forum, & onto the Coliseum. Allow a morning to enjoy the whole site!

Great other than finding it.. Was amazing to take in - the old architecture, the ruins, the displays. Got lost TWICE(!) on the way in. Follow the signs for the r healigical site. It will seem wrong, but it's right.

Avoid paying too much by an archeological ticket. The entrance to all these attractions is included in the archeolocial ticket available at museums. These attractions involve a lot of walking so take plenty of water, a sun hat and take your time!!!

Worth strolling through. Our Colosseum tickets allowed us free entry into the ruins, so we decided to visit the day after. It could be a little boring if you don't like history, but we appreciated what we saw and the conversations it sparked about Roman history. We didn't have to wait in line because we had the Colosseum tickets, so there was no delay getting in. The bathrooms leave much to be desired, so make sure you 'go' before you get there.

Walking on the 2000 year old stones where famous Romans walked. The old stones of 2000 years ago are rounded and worn and I cant imagine driving a carriage over them. The guided tour of the Palatine Hill take 1 hour very fast pace. To see it all you need all day. Take a backpack lunch and stop and rest and eat. There is water available from the local spring just bring your container. There are a lot of places to rest and reflect on what you are seeing and experiencing. Take a guided tour and then plan on taking a long walking tour yourself since they don't cover the ruins. Wear solid walking shoes. It is dusty and uneven walking. It is good to go early in the day. The metro train station is just across the street as well as some restaurants. do some research before you go so you know what you are seeing.
Great experience. This is the place to go when you are in Rome - loads of history and fantastic location. The Palatine hill is a great place to walk and relax as well
weekend in Rome. What a great city full of real history and the birthplace of so much of our western culture. Lots of tourist (like us) but a really nice, friendly feel and so much to do!

Ancient History. How can you not like all the history this area has. I would recommend getting a tour guide or download audio tours while exploring this area. The Triposo app for the iPhone was a good way to read about the history of this area.

worth the walk. What an expirence to witness and feel like you were a part of history.We were a part of a tour group run by The Dark Side and we had the most passionate and informative guide. It turned out to be 4hour plus tour with a lot of walking but it is a must to do when in Rome. Forget the crowds and soak up the atmosphere, most of us will only do it once.
Outstanding. The history lesion was amazing. Be sure to get the guided tour and prepare to walk a long way. I can not say enough about this. Just amazing history.
Ancient Rome. It was wonderful to walk around "Ancient" Rome along the cobbled stone streets admiring the magnificent ruins all with that wow factor.Loved our time here.

The core of the Roman Empire. Well worth seeing if you've been to Rome and see the Colosseum.. The forum was the centre of Roman power. The Colosseum was an entertainment complex, but on the Palatine hill there are a series of emperors' palaces and pleasure gardens, the Palatine Museum, some amazing frescoed Roman houses, and then drop down into the valley as there are temples and triumphant arches - and the Senate, which is still intact today - a huge building which is unfortunately generally not open to the public. With seeing if you are here or have any interest in Roman history.

Picturesque!. You can spend hours and hours here. A pair of good walking shoes is a must! Personally, I found it a little difficult to follow the map shown at the entrance, make sure to take a picture of it when you enter. It will be useful once you are inside. Be mindful of the closing times, guards are pretty strict and you will not be allowed to enter.

Excellent and a must see. We got tickets for these with the Colosseum tickets - the views are awesome too. Don't buy the water - there are plenty of drinking fountains. This really is well worth a visit.

Start here before the Colosseum. Buy your ticket here (the ticket booth is right between these 2 places) as the ticket includes entrance to all 3 places valid for 2 days. Then start with the Roman Forum, then Palatine Hill and finally the Colosseum. By the time you have reached the Colosseum, you'll just have to walk straight into the line for those with tickets, scan your ticket and enter. If you are one who loves architecture, old buildings and spends hours in just one place, you might want to separate this trip into 2 days. If not, you can just visit these 3 places in one day.

Take a Guide. This is my second visit. The first time I went alone and pondered over what I was looking at. This time we had a private guide who gave information, answered questions, guided us in a logical way and generally cared for us along the way. The Palatine Hill and Colloseum were also included. Take a small bottle of water as there are regular places to fill your bottles with free fresh water.

The Forum and Palatine Hill. Our entrance ticket to the Colosseum also included entry to these sites, and both are worth visiting in their own right. The Palatine Hill was the home to a number of palaces of Roman Emperors, and to a number of other rich and influential Romans - the site of Rome's power, in fact. There are the remains of a number of significant buildings, and fine views over the Forum and surrounding area. At the bottom of the hill under the Flavian Palace is the Forum, where ancient Rome's main business was carried out ranging from government buildings and law courts to market traders.
Rome city break. what a place, shame that the city elders have run out of money to clean it all, but the grime of thousands of years does not detract from the awesomeness of this place

Best Guide ever for the Ancient Ruins!. The day after we arrived in Rome, we took a private tour of the Flavian Amphitheatre, also known as the Coliseum, The Roman Forum and Palatine Hill. The tour guide, Chiara was the best guide we have ever had. We arranged the tour through Emma Villas. I highly recommend having a private tour as we were able to hear and see exactly what she was showing us. She had so much knowledge of the Ancient Ruins, my children are actually still recalling the information we learned from her. She intertwined history with the artifacts and a timeline of how and why things happened when they did. We were able to take the information we learned from her to the next tour at The Vatican City. We had a horrible, group tour there. If I had known better, I would have hired Chiara to do that tour as well. Because it was a private tour, we were able to move quickly and see more of what the ruins had to offer. It was definitely the best tour we have ever taken. In hind sight, I would book Chiara through Emma Villas for one tour- a private tour, and then contact her personally (they give you her cell#) to see if she can take you to other places. 5 starts out of 5!!

Essential to see- Even Better with a guide. These sites are astonishing for anyone with an interest in Rome the city and Rome the ancient civilization. The Roman skills at design, architecture, construction, social organization,and politics, are on ample display and one is in awe of these achievements of two millennia ago!I recommend a private guide to save time and to learn more. It is worth every penny unless you are a roman scholar or professor. Bring cold water and wear good shoes for a trip of a lifetime.

Peaceful and decent views. Taking a stroll through here was a pleasant way to spend a couple of hours. Despite it being peak tourist season, the area didn't feel busy and you can easily walk around at your own pace. I wouldn't say there's anything here that will take your breath away but it is certainly interesting and has good views of the city. The ticket price includes access to the Colosseum so I'd recommend coming here first to then jump the Colosseum queue afterwards.
wear comfortable shoes. Make sure to wear comfortable shoes cause there is a lot of walking and steps. It is a must see wonderful old sites
Amazing. Look for a tour and get in, this is a magical place frozen in time. You can imaging people from 2000 years ago still going around.

Long but worth it!. Good thing that I prebooked a tour with Viator. It was extremely busy and extremely hot. Our Guide Davide was very knowledgeable. If you are travelling to Rome, these places are a must see. It is quite tiring and long, especially for the kids, so pace yourself and carry lots of water.
see rome and die :). just like a dream come true, walk and imagine how it was 2000 years ago, must see when in rome. only words coming to my mind , amazing, great, fenomenal

Quite a walk!. A lot of walking to get around it all but some breath taking photo's. Amazing so much is still standing and in such good condition. Found everything fascinating, history comes to life walking around. Avoid buying anything around the sites as its really expensive.

Amazing but... watch out for rip off merchants. Great if you can manoevre it properly, but of you go without doing any research first you could end up being shunted onto one of their last minute organized tours (with 50 people on each) just to avoid the lines... only to find out you will wait just as long for them to get a big enough group together. Read up on the layout and what tour companies are worth going with first.

Money, money, money. Roman Money.. We spent an afternoon exploring the Palatine Hill. We did not get an audioguide, and was the poorer for it, but still got an idea from the information stands and the map. One palace stood out for us, the complex that was built by Septimius Severius, who was Roman Emperor around the year 200. The Flavian Palace overlooks the Circus Maximus, and one can only marvel at the scale of undertakings that was done here. If you finish your visit of the Palatine Hill here, and have about two hours of your afternoon left, it is only a ten minute walk down the Via Terme di Caracalla, to visit the baths of Caracalla. Also begun by Septimius Severus, and finished by his son Caracalla in AD 217, it is a marvellous example of Roman ingenuity and engineering.
Must -see sights. A wonderful experience, quite a lot of the monuments preserved and free to roam around at your own pace.

The Roman Spirit. Return back many years ago, to the roman empire with its elegance & charm... this Great Monument is worth a visit while you are in rome, you will feel how the Roman people were look like from many eras ago especially when you use the stairs to get to the Amphitheatre.

Take a walk with the past. Walk into the roman past, surrounded by buildings of Augustus and Hadrian etc, see where current digs are taking place. Good information boards displayed all around. If you have a good imagination, reconstruct the ruins to see imperial Rome at its most majestic. The only thing which spoiled it for me was the inappropriate and jarring incongruity of several pieces of modern Italian art... Place it anywhere except here please!

A walk through history, amazing.. If you are interested in history then this is an absolute must. Walking down a road where Julius Caesar once walked, seeing the remains of once vast temples and getting a feel for life in ancient Rome is fascinating.Okay so the buildings are really just ruins and some people have described it as stones and rubble but if you become aware of the history then it does come to life. So don't just wander round, you need to be guided. This could be by a tour guide, a book or as I would advise an MP3 recorded tour guide on your phone or MP3 player. We used a tour by Rick Steves. This meant we got a full explanation of what we were seeing and a real feel for the events that happened exactly where we were standing. It also meant we could go at our own pace, as it was a sunny 35 degree day and I am Scottish (I get moon burn :) I like to move from shade to shade and having my own tour allowed me to do this.We loved the whole experience, thinking about Roman legions riding down these roads in victorious return to the city gave me Goosebumps.A visit to Rome would simply not be complete without a tour of the Forum.

Interesting, but a tiring walk. Historically this was a very interesting place to visit, and there are a few exhibits to look at within the Forum as well as the ruins of the Roman market place. As history graduates we enjoyed perusing the sights, however the walk up the Palatine Hill was a bit much after a long day of sightseeing in the high heat, so if you are planning on visiting here, make sure you have a lot of water and haven't tired yourself out too much elsewhere beforehand, as it did spoil it for me slightly that I was exhausted.

Visit to Colosseum, Palentine Hill and Forum. We went in August and yes it's very hot but we planned to spend the whole day looking at the 3 sites of Palentine Hill, the Forum and the Colosseum so took our time. Someone recommended we go to Palentine Hill and Forum first as there were no queues as most people head to Colosseum first. We got in very quickly and purchased the audio guide. It was a bit frustrating to follow as not very clear where you are supposed to stand for each location and could do with a numbered sign so we knew we were in the right place. As a consequence we ended up repeating each bit several times and took a lot longer than it should have. I would recommend printing a guided tour from the many you can find on-line to take with you to make more sense of it. Even so it's quite an amazing site and well worth a visit. We spent all morning there and had a long break for food and drink in the shade before heading to the Colosseum mid afternoon and walked straight in ahead of those queuing to purchase tickets. Again the audio guide is a bit disappointing with not enough information. A good guide book to accompany audio guide would be recommended. Also the queue to pick up audio guide is same as the drop off queue and as they keep a credit card or passport to make sure you return handset, there was a long wait to give audio guide back. Not very well organised. But All in all an awe inspiring day!
