Went crazy here. If you like ruins, I whole day might not be enough. Get lost here. Pay attention to the details, enter small spots, enjoy all the greatness.

Beautiful Attractions/Mediocre museum. Unless you do a guided tour or get an audio headset you won't be able to learn much about the areas. The signs aren't in important places (which is good to preserve the view) but do not really teach you about the history of the sites. A lot of museums in other countries include the audio guide with the price of your tour so I think it's slightly annoying that you need to pay extra for it. I have heard of audio guides you can download as mp3s and listen to on your mp3 player while you walk around for free, so that might be an option. Other than that these areas are beautiful and it is a good deal that the various attractions are bundled for one price.

Terrible! No Map will be provided if you do not rent the audio guide!. Seriously do not understand why we need to pay so much to see ruins, half pillars and broken pieces and rocks/ bricks...... The staffs at the counter were rude! No map is provided at the ticket counter!! I saw all those people who rented the audio guide have a map. So, I've asked for one from the staff at the audio guide counter. But she just said no maps, only audio guide! I'm so annoyed! I have paid 12 euro for the entrance fee and am not even entitled to a map?!!! I felt that visitors are being forced to rent the audio guide as there are no sign, no map and no proper guide. It cost you 5.50 to rent the audio guide and you need to queue up again after buying the ticket. Again, another long queue. Although the ticket is valid for 2 days but you are only allowed to enter each of the attraction once! You cannot re-enter the same site for the second time within the same day or the next day after you have exited! As such, the 2 days validity period is not very helpful at all.

Colossol Threesome. We used a Roma pass, as all three were counted as one visit. We didn't realise how huge the Forum & Palatine Hill would be. Maybe don't go around quite as slow as us taking pictures of almost everything at different angles. We actually ran out of time & didn't get to see all of Palatine Hill. This is a truly vast & amazing place.

Excellent Tour Stop with Stephania. Guide was an archeologist who was very knowledgeable. I am a history guy so I really enjoyed it. Did not like the overbearing presence of pushy foreign vendors! mama mia!

gREAT TRIP. This is an important tour for someone coming to Rome. Palatine Hill consists of a series of ruins that explain the significants of the old Roman society. Tour guide is a must for this excursion! Take a camera because these sights are a once in a life experience to capture.
Step back into time. Amazing info. What did happen Here?? I realised this place was built and occupied so long ago , with so many stories ,I could have listened for another few hours AMAZING !

Simply fabulous. It's unite a walk but then it's amazing to see how well things have been preserved here. The palatine hill is a maze with history in every nook and corner. You walk to the Roma Forum from there and there is plenty to see nd admire the sheer engineering skills that were used by the ancient Romans!!

history / history / history!. We picked up an english-speaking tour outside and worried about being ripped off but fears were false and tour was excellent and entertaining. Included an afternoon tour of Forum that turned out to be really excellent (if really hot) so at the end we felt we had real value-for-money.
The place is steeped in history!

Wonderful historic site. It is a huge site absolutely full of historic roman ruins. Well worth the admission, which also gave entry to the colosseum but avoiding the huge queue for tickets. It took a few hours to properly walk the site. There's a lot there. The views and photo opportunities are also good. My only snag was the poor signposting to the exit when we wanted to leave c

History before your eyes. My husband loves everything about roman history and made this a must on our trip. We bought a Roma pass each and this entitles you into this attraction free, as well as the colosseum and forum and helped to avoid the ticket queues.To be honest it is breath taking and the history is amazing but there is a lot of walking in the heat, not much shade and lots of hills and steps. In the end I let my husband do a lot of this on his own and I took a shaded spot under a tree watched the world go by and enjoyed the breathtaking views. To walk the streets where Caesar trod was amazing and if you love roman history then this is the place to see it.

I loved every minute spent in these places. It's a must when visiting Rome! You feel the history on every corner and every step moves you back in time :) I guess it is even better with an audio guide, but it's still great without it (yet some background knowledge seems necessary)

First Time to Rome. We were able to walk to these sites and greatly enjoy multiple sites in one day. Whether historic or a current buildings, the sites were amazing and so beautiful. They are located closely, but you need to be able to walk for longer distances if you decide to walk this this part of Rome.
Awesome. As you stand and look at all of the architecture it's hard to fathom how old everything is and what it's been through. You can see pictures but nothing is like seeing it in person.

Few tips. I visited this great attraction on the 11th of August 2013. Here are some tips: It was very hot and you have to go there early in the morning. Get an audioguide but first get a glimpse of it from Google Earth to know where would you be and get a quick idea about the huge and sprawling place. The ticket costs 12 euros per person and it also gets you in the Colosseum. This helps you avoid the long lines waiting to get entrance to the Colosseum, The other good thing is This ticket would stay valid for two day, and that is good as you will very exhausted after the first day in the Palatine Hills and the Forum Romanum. Get yourself a bottle of water, then you can refill from a lot of places inside, try to wear comfortable shoes, sunglasses, sunblock, and a hat.

Queues horrendous. Very disappointing after Vatican - street traders, beggers, queues, no organisation, dire. Yes the building would have been fantastic when it was previously covered in marble - Rome are just living on their history and ruins - not putting any money back into the buildings to preserve, covered in scaffolding to stop people going through.

Great Tour - A must do. It is what it is!We took the English guided tour and it was well worth it. Alovely woman showed us around and explained the history and layout. It was a very very hot day when we went so we took it slow and steady around. It would be advisable to maybe read up a little before going to appreciate some of it a little more. But its an amazing feat of architecture as is most things in Rome. Or as someone else did - the semi private tour - that sounded excellent!

HOT, FIND SHADE, BRING WATER! :). After a late morning at the Colosseum our tour continued to Palatine Hill. I can't imagine seeing this without the informative guide telling us the story of the beginning of Rome. Magical history coming to life! As we wandered afterwards and my husband stopped for many scenic pictures I have to admit I got very Hangry (hot-hungry and angry!). There are few trees and endless sun in August. Lots of hills as well.We had already gone through several litres of water between the colosseum and the tour and it was difficult to find shade. If I could do it again I would take an Air Conditioned restaurant break between the Colosseum and Palatine Hill/Roman Forum to fully appreciate it! Cost is included in Colosseum ticket cost.

How Rome was built. Pre-booked semi private tour, fantastic guide small group very attentive, a must visit in Rome. Lots of walking and a bit hilly, not suitable for those unable to move around. Excellent views from the top and you gain a good understanding of the history of Rome.

It is considered one site - Roma pass issues. We visited colleseum, roman forum and palatine hill and had an issue with it when we got the Roma pass so be careful. If you buy Roma pass the sites colleseum, palatine hill and roman forum are included. But make sure you visit palatine hill and roman forum at the same time - dont get out from palatine hill to go to roman forum as you will not be allowed in with same pass. There is a way to go into roman forum from palatine hill and vice s versa.
Excellent. If you enjoy walking around ruins then this is a must. Very hot and badly sign posted so quite a challenge at times to navigate your way around. Get a two day pass with colosseum .
Recommend. Loads of history and really good tour guides. Need another day to do the forum again as not enough time in the day.

Very Interesting. The Roman Forum and Palatine Hill is characterised by rich history which will, at times, take your breath away. It is the ideal place for a historian. Apart from its rich history, the place, as a whole, is very scenic and quite beautiful. I suggest you a invest in a guided tour of this place to learn about the history of this beautiful place. Only then you will fully appreciate it. It is definitely recommended that you walk with comfortable shoes, drinking water and probably an umbrella or hat because this place is like an oven during the day and you will need at least 3 hours to have the entire place fully covered.

Walk through the past.. Must visit before or after seeing the Colosseum. A walk through the ancient streets of stone, and the perception of the grandeur of Roman buildings remaining is incredible. Lacking good signage for tourists, bins and toilets. But nevertheless are striking images that will generate great photos.

You cannot skip this - Wonderful. I came here with my family and friends (group of 11 people) and there was no disadvantage, not even the long queues that were moving so fast. Don't believe some guides when they tell you that they will save you 1-2 hours of waiting with the fast pass with which you will skip the queue.You have to visit Colosseum, Palatine Hill where all the history of Rome started and Forum Romanum which was the old city center of the ancient Rome.

A must see!. Tourists are able to walk the sites by themselves or appropriate a tour guide at the sites. The history located here is impressive. Try to arrive early with summer heat and purchase tickets for all three places at one price most easily at The Forum.

Bring water and walk like hell. Must see. I do agree with some other reviews that it could be a torture walking in the frying pan. But hey, when you are in Italy, you got to be here at least once in your lifetime.We went to Coliseum first, then Palatine Hill and then Roman Forum. We then exit the Roman Forum at the Capitoline museum exit. For Coliseum and Palatine Hill, please see my other reviews.Get a tour guide or an app, bring lots of water and try to go there early to avoid the heat.

Try to go there early in the morning after Coliseum. Again, a must see in Italy.Another few pointers:1) Try to go there early, or else you will become a sun-dried tomato with the summer heat.2) Just bring lots of water and some snacks. Even though they are heavy, you definitely need it as it is a huge place to walk.3) You probably want a guided tour (or download Rick Steve's app) as it would just be a pile of rocks if you walk there yourself.4) There is a Palatine Museum in the middle (http://www.historvius.com/the-palatine-museum-735/) but there is no air conditioning. They do have a bathroom.5) Do not buy bottle water from guys standing besides the staircase toward the top of the hill (near Stadium of Domitian's Palace). I suspect they fill the bottle water with the water fountain near by.6) Best value to get bottle water was from the newspaper hut outside the Colosseo metro station (turn right after you exit the station). 2 Euro for 1L bottle water.
Have to see when in Rome. Crowded, try to see Rome in off-peak season. Same applies to Vatican and Venice. Can't really enjoy anything when you have to watch you toes all the time.

Roman Holiday. The italians are a sumptuous lot. Very kind and loving.The trevi fountain is a must see in Rome.Just walk toward it.A most colorful experience awaits you.You will be surprised and very pleasantly so.

A must see in Rome. Brilliant place. Highly recommend "Rome Pass" card as there is a separate waiting line for card holders, also you can use it as one of the two free museums including in the card deal.
Palatino. Extraordinary! Amzing view, it's fantastic.. but be prepeared, it's hot so don't forget to bring water and a cap with you! ;):P

TAKE YOUR TIME TO VISIT. Gives you a very good idea of what Rome looked like during the Roman era . You pay 12 € full price to visit this AND Colosseum , and you have the day of purchase of the ticket and the next day to do so. Very impressive , take your time to absorb what you see it is unique in the world. You can take your pic-nic inside , only some water taps and toilet facilities inside , no bar or restaurant.

Zero shade, terrible map, terrible audioguide, terrible queues. In the summer PASS.Out of the 1000000000000 other tourists there was not a single person looking remotely interested/happy. Everyone is miserable and wishing they hadn't spent $50 for walking around a heating pan. I don't know who these people giving it 5* rating are- probably some crazy palaeontology/rock historians types from Hong Kong who don't mind the heat. I like history more than the average person but this was pure torture. Without a real guide, the map and audio-guide are incomprehensible. The map black and white and the size of a post stamp.There are so many things to do in Rome... don't waste precious time. Don't do this to yourself, let alone your kids.
Flavian Amphitheatre. This place is amazing. Worth paying for a guided tour to skip the long ques and get some real insight.
Boring. If you are really not into Rome history, pass on this. There is nothing, but half pillars and broken pieces on the ground. I was so bored...

Where it all began!. Nothing can prepare you for what is the centre of Roma, the place where a Republic was birthed and an Empire was run from. The Palatine is a special place, though can be difficult to navigate around in just one day...so we took two! If you're not familiar with this archaeology then get yourself booked onto a tour, that will help a lot. If you go in high summer then make sure you take sun tan lotion and plenty to drink as the sun will suck the energy from you in no time at all. There are toilets available and there are running taps where you can refill your water bottles. The water from these taps is totally safe to drink too.Be prepared for long hot days in the central area.

wow. you're walking along normal streets in rome and then there it is just like that the colosseum. Its amazin and you can really get into the idea o what happened there - i you have a teenage daughter into the hunger games then link it - me and my daughter even hubby were ready to watch this afterwards as we could visualise so many things linked. Its an amazing place. Its hot and there are pies to fill your water bttles from - eep an eye out for the lizards i you into nature and have children who like thi sort of thing. Apparently we found out at a later time there is an option of getting gladiator training dressing up in the full gear and having a fight - would have done that if we'd known.Palatine needs more imagination - we had been to pompeii a couple of days earlier so dont feel its a fair review from my part but probably spent too much time in this area - disappointed in the museum. Forum - very magical get a map if you not havving a guide as its confusing and the history is well worth it could really grasp the ancient city would revisit this in the future in cooler weather for more extensive disccovery. Loved it.

With a little imagination, it's like stepping back in time. I must stress that you need a map here. We used the map and guide in the lonely planet Rome guidebook, which served its purpose perfectly well. (One thing though, if you use this then when it says to turn right at the Arc, it means turn left!!)Without a map you will have no idea what you are looking at as there are no signs here. Take your time. Once you’ve got your bearings and have wandered back and forth a few times, identified what building is (or was!) where, you will start to appreciate the ruins for what they are – or were. Certainly worth a look, especially as entry is included with your colosseum ticket.

Unlike anywhere else in Europe. It is incredible to walk around the ruins and imagine ancient Rome as it once stood. But what is more spectacular is the vastness of the site. Rome have done a great job in preserving these ruins and making them available to the public. Do not worry about the heat in the summer either, as there are plenty of water fountains for you to drink from all over the site. We went when it was 36 degrees so were a little lethargic by the end, but you should take your time in going around whatever the weather.

Great historic place. If you like History, it is highly recommanded to visit. For the palantine hill, you need to know a bit before going there (audio guid was disappointed) and to avoid warm and sunny weather. The colosseum is spectacular. It is also very nice to see it from outside at night.

Think about ancient times. Like the Agora in Athens, the main political and social center of Rome.Walk around and try to imagine what life was like then, stroll around and think about what life must have been like way back when.

Lived up to our expectations. This was our first visit to Rome and these places lived up to our expectations. They were very easy to get around and we spent 2 days walking the area, visiting the sites.

Poor information. This sight could be so much better if there were good signs with valuable information. Now there are just a lot of fallen stones and poor information. Maybe it is better with a guide, we do not know. Tip: buy your ticket here and you can enter the colosseum on the same or the next day so you can skip the line there.

Full of surprises. Well worth a visit but is much bigger than expected it will take a few hours to get round. The audio tour is a bit hit & miss and could be better numbered. I also think it would benefit from more information on boards with illustrations it seems a bit take it as you find it ! Be warned there is nowhere to buy food or drink once inside however there is free water from the drinking fountains.

Day in Rome. We only had one day in Rome and a must see is Palatine Hill, The Forum and the Colosseum. We got in about 12 noon and started our tour of the Ruins it was beyond amazing. a must on any bucket list

Comfortable shoes, light fabrics.. I enjoyed the actual colosseum much better than the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill. When you go, make sure you wear very comfortable shoes and light fabrics if it's hot out. We went in mid July and it was HOT! I don't recommend making a whole day trip out of this. I feel like anything over 3 hours would be a waste of time.
Sublime. What can I say - whether you are into Roman history or not this is just wonderful and not to be missed, if only for the great views across the city. Great value.
Lots of history. Great location and perfect to combine with a trip to the Colosseum which is a mere 2 minutes away, typical of what you expect from the Romans and plenty of photo opportunities.
back to old rome. Wandering arround these gardens, buildings and ruines, give you the feeling you are back in old rome. Feel, smell en experience. TIP, drink enough in the summer.

Fantastic!. Great walking tour. Loved the ruins and the historical surroundings. Don't forget to bring your water if it's a hot day! Great experience for young and old alike. Take your time and enjoy!

So Much to See, Don't Miss It. There is so much to see here that you can spend an entire morning walking the ruins. There is so much history so I recommend a guide. When we went, there was work being done on the sidewalks, which created a bit of a pedestrian traffic funnel.

absolutely in love with the ruins. You have to visit them.. these ruins are absolutely captivating. Even though they are ruins, they are the most beautiful ruins i've ever seen. I am so amazed by the history behind these ruins. Rome is really beautiful.

With such a stunning view you don't need anymore. Terrible service, very high prices, average quality (when not poor), but I'm always coming back here, at least just for a coffe, to enjoy the gogeous view!! It absolutely worth the visit!!!

Absolutely amazing. This is an absolutely must see when visiting Rome. Seeing the architecture and structures that are still standing after thousands of years is amazing. The whole place is steeped in so much history it's humbling to walk through and see what was achieved with the resources available in that era. When buying your ticket for this add on the Colosseum as this will allow you to miss the very long queue to buy a ticket actually at the Colosseum, if you don't be prepared for a very long wait! Stunning - what more can I say?

Union Mentality. We had 2 hours left on our ticket. They stopped letting people in because of a strike! But they wouldn't give us our money back. Told us to come back tomorrow. Told them we couldn't since our flight leaves tomorrow. Could she please make an exception. NOPE. Dumb attitude to the tourists that pay your salary lady. That's why Italy's economy is not recovering. Left a lasting negative impression on all of us there!

Picnic in the Forum/Palatine Hill. Take your walking shoes! Is is a beautiful walk to go through the Forum and Palatine hill there is a lot to see and learn. If possible go with a guide. I went without one and would listen to some of the guides as they passed and there is a lot of amazing history to learn. It would be great to spend half a day to a whole day. Take some food or snack because there are beautiful area's to have a picnic. There are a lot of water fountains around so take a water bottle and you can fill it up. Also take an umbrella if you can because there are some area's that do not have a lot of shade.

Incredible Ruins. We walked to Palatine Hill and seeing the incredible ruins sent shivers down the spine. We did not pay to tour but walked all around the area. It is a long walk to go all around but worth every step. The stories of the ancient Romans and their construction of the cities could be imagined in the ruins.
Wonderful. Very nice area to visit. Beautiful history and defiantly worth a visit, we took a tour to here and the coliseum it was excellent

Good Historic Overview of Ancient Rome. This is worth seeing but only if you are on a tour or have a good audio guide, perhaps a free Podcast from Rick Steves. It would also help to have an Ipad or picture book to see what the ruins looked like as the current condition leaves lots to the imagination. Worth seeing.

Still impressive today. I can't imagine what this must have looked like during Caesars time. It's still impressive today. Our guide took us up above it so we could look down onto the entire area. Wow. It's also the place where Julius Caesar was cremated.

Worth it but subway construction makes finding entrance a challenge. You can enter this on the same ticket/pass as the colosseum (use Roma Pass to bypass long lines - see my review of colosseum for info). However when I was there the last week in June, finding the entrance to the forum was a huge challenge for not only me but many others, as there are many paths that appear to go to an entrance but instead end up at fences; I finally asked a policeman and got directions. There was no signage and it turned out I had to go back up along the main road and away from the colosseum to the traffic light (to what was previously just an exit) to enter; this is due to the extension of the metro that is being built right there. For information and a walking tour for the site I downloaded Rick Steve's free podcast which gave me a very information walking tour and I didn't feel I needed anything more re info. If there had been good signage/entrance would have given 5 stars but so much walking and back tracking which also caused me to miss Palatine Hill due to time constraints so only 4 stars (but this is a must not miss attraction).

Excellent Value For Money !. The Roman Forum and Palatine Hill is excellent vale for money this is a historical place surrounded by the ruins of several government buildings and include some iconic and impressive pillars. Please note if you visit The Coliseum first then you get in here for free . So I would suggest to do the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill first then go to visit The Coliseum as then you will skip the queue for The Colisseum ! The ticket price is 12 euro for The Colisseum and The Roman Forum and Palatine Hill .

Beautiful place with great history. I would recommend getting the Roma pass to enjoy the Palatine Hill with the Colosseum. The best way to learn Roman history is to visit this marvellous site with a competent guide and join the guided tour. If you are visiting during summer, you must bring a bottle with you so that you can keep filling it up with the cold and refreshing spring water from the many fountains in Palatine Hill. Do wear a pair of comfortable walking shoes as you will be doing a lot of walking. Visited July 2013

Beautiful views of the city. We wandered in here after visiting the Colosseum thinking we could quickly check off another site since we were right by it. We ended up walking around for nearly two hours and could have stayed longer if we weren't so worn out.The whole site is beautiful and there are some areas where you get beautiful views of the city. Other than paying $5 to take the elevator up to the top of Vittoriano, these were the best views we found.It is a lot of walking, but it was a nice break after the crowds of the Colosseum.

Fantastic ruins. We went as a group with a tour guide who can fill you in on any questions you have and give you a great history lesson as well. Fantastic afternoon photo opportunities here also. Great historical sites, but that's why you are most likely here. Do not miss it!
Very fun especially with a guide. Our guide really made it pop out and come to life I do recommend this or else it is kind of pointless really. It was beautiful and fun!
Must see. A lot of ancient monuments, near each other. Must make time to visit them, because they are impressive and full of stories.

Should be better organised. The place is full of history, but they should have more explanatory signs, so the visitor could make a flashback in the city's history. On the hill there are some nice gardens. At summer, plan your visit early, beacause there's not enough shadow. Maybe you shouldn't visit the place the same day with Colosseum, because you'll get exhausted after waiting so long in the queue. An alternative is to enter first here and then in Colosseum with the same ticket, or book online.

PERFECTO!!! :D. We spent a nice time over there, after a few hours breathing the Colosseum atmosphere, we just crossed the street to star our journey to the past, I strongly recommend you guys to save a time to have a really nice picnic at the top of the hill and enjoy the view!!

History, history, history!. Amazing to walk around 2000+ year old ruins, trying to imagine what the area was like in its heyday - so much to see.I would like to see the grounds up-keep improved a little - it is quite overgrown in places. For such an important archaeological site a bit more signage and information would improve the experience.

Very long tour. Lots of walking and since it's Rome/Italy, lots of hills, but very informative and beautiful. We did this at the same time we toured the Coliseum and it was a four hour tour, not for the weak or easily bored.

lovely views. The long walk in the heat of summer may put a few people off but we managed it with two kids (one 5 year old). The guided tour ensured many shaded stops. I don't think one should visit this marvel without a competent guide as you wouldn't know what to look for. The guide really brought the place to life. Beautiful views of the other attractions made this worthwhile. Take water with you in summer.

Amazing history, but....... We recently visited the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill with our family (including a child with a passionate interest in the Roman gods/mythology. Clearly this is a site of historical significance and there is so much that COULD be learned. This site however did not live up to its potential, it would be so easy to put up some signage, artist representations of its former glory and some of the myths / legends and history. Unfortunately the remains are crumbling and exposed to the elements. I would not return again without a guide.

Amazing history you must visit. You must visit, and do it with a local guide to hear all of the stories and facts. Definitely bring your camera there is so much to see, its mind-boggling to think how long these buildings have stood here

Unbelievable!!. We visited here in may and got a guided tour, which costs a little more, around here and the colleseum (recommended as the ladies that took us round were excellent!) We thought this place was unbelievable and as impressive as the colleseum!

Incredible. Just so fascinating and incredible. Five of us, four adults and one child, took a guided tour of Rome we purchased from our cruise. We were all just amazed and loved every second walking through the ancient ruins. You just feel like you can't soak it all in fast enough. So well worth the time...just imagining the history you are seeing firsthand is outstanding...even overwhelming. We all loved it. I recommend it and truly hope that someday I will get to go again!

So-So. The Palatine Hill and Roman Forum would have been better if we have a tour, since we didn't know enough about each area since most of it is rubble. Also, look at the weather forecast before going out. My husband and I were caught in a horrible thunder and lightening storm in the midst of the Forum and were soaked for the rest of the night. Tip: Bring an umbrella everywhere.

Easy way to lose half a day. As with most places in Rome, the history that is slowly being discovered here is absolutely fascinating to observe. You could easily spend most of the day wandering around and soaking in the sights

Pausing for Palatine. I think this was one of my favorite spots. My 11 year-old grandson and I explored the whole area in spite of the summer heat. There were lovely shaded areas with a breeze that allowed us opportunities to contemplate the trmendous history of this area. I wish we had been there in a cooler part of the year when we could have explored in more detail but I would return in a heartbeat.
Incredible sights and history. Wow! It's surreal to walk through all these ancient ruins and just imagine all the history. I've never experienced anything like it.

Beatiful. Beautiful place to learn some Roman history. Many things on the site, but you will need a map or a guide to understand what is where and since when. A combi ticket with The Collosseum is adviced. Very hot during the summer days, but there is a toilet and water to drink up in the Palatines and they are both very clean. Perfect to freshen up. We even caught a guide from another group and stood there to steal information :). Don't miss it in Rome!

Lovely afternoon spent here!. Used the omnia Roma pass to get in which provided queue jumping benefits.  once in we wondered around on our own looking at the sights. There was limited written boards to inform what we were looking at so would advise to have a guided tour.  the ground at times were very uneven and it is a big asda that you cover so its advisable that you were comfy footwear, i word flip flops which wasn't my greatest idea!your feet get really dusty too.  the ruins are so interesting and it definitely worth the money because you will be there for hours! and no street sellers inside woohoo!

Wow. Give yourself plenty of time for this site,it's huge, we had a 2 day pass from doing our tour of the colosseum, we only used one day of the pass but in hindsight should have used the other day too. The day we went it was hot so in no time we were really struggling, so my advice is to get there early in the morning. Loved the history. A tour would have been good to understand more about the place but they do have plaques along the way explaining some of the ruins. It really is a must see

Pay to Take a Tour. We went in with Roma Pass and were honestly underwhelmed. Nothing was very clearly marked, so it was difficult to see the history which we knew was there. I'm sure if we had gone with a tour we would've had a better experience.

Amazing. I went with a tour guide, and I have to say its the ONLY way to go and see the forum and hill, cause theres so much you wouldn't know if you were wandering by yourself. Its just amazing to be standing on the same grounds as where an old roman civilization used to stand. It's really a wonder to behold and see the existing architecture that still remains. Avoid going in summer too, SO HOT

Pretty and Relaxing. This is the ideal attraction to come to if you want a slower-paced walk around. You can see the forum and Palatine Hill at your leisure, and there's plenty of places to stop and rest with strategically placed water fountains to drink from. Both the history and the views from the top of the hill are things you should come here for, but this attraction seems less crowded than the Colosseum can get anyway. I was a little disappointed with the Romulus Huts as I'd climbed up the whole hill only to find the "huts" were just holes in the ground filled with rocks, but the feel of the rest of the place connected me much better to ancient Rome. Leave a bit of time to explore this area as you won't want to rush up the hill, especially in the heat, and leave buggies behind- I lost count of the amount of people I saw struggling with buggies on the ancient cobblestones.
Go with a guide. The ruins are truly impressive and a must see if you're in Rome. But there's honestly so little left to the ruins that you should go with a guide to help you understand what's what.

Historically fascinating but not for the young ones. Long, hot and fascinating with tremendous views. Ruined palaces, baths and a variety of buildings with regular sign posts with text about what you are looking at. We didn't take audio so found these signs very useful but stopping to read them, I suspect, takes longer than listening to the audios. Bought 12 euro ticket on spec covering Palatine Hill, Roman Form and Colosseum. We're advised to do them in this order to reduce waiting but did queue for an hour to get tickets at entrance to Palatine Hill. I suspect younger ones or those with little interest in history might find this dull as it will take over an hour and closer to two hours to get round this.

Great views. This is a very large area so you will need plenty of time to truly appreciate it. There are so many ancient ruins and artifacts that it gets to be a bit overwhelming. This is especially true when you combine it with the Roman Forum which is very nearby. I really enjoyed the great view looking down on the Colosseum and Forum. You get a great panoramic view ,from the southeast corner of the hill, of the Forum, Arch of Constantine and Colosseum when looking from left to right. There are a few fountains scattered around the area and ruins that offer crystal clear, ice cold water that is necessary on a hot day. There isn't a lot of shaded areas and facilities are scarce so keep that in mind prior to starting up the hill.

Ancient Rome. Walk the same roads as the ancient Romans.! There are so many buildings remaining to really give you the feel of what the ancient Romans must have experienced as they walked through their civic center.

Pretty but unspectacular. Sandwiched between the Colosseum and the Roman Forum, Palatine Hill felt a little underwhelming. It is very pretty and was an ideal place to have a picnic after the Colosseum but we didn't feel that there was too much to look at (perhaps that's because we didn't have the audio guide). As the price is included in the ticket for the Colosseum and the Roman Forum it is definitely worth having a wander around but I wouldn't expect it to take up too much of your time compared to the other two

Do not pay into this!. We used our Roma pass to get into this attraction but don't make the same mistake! You can pretty much see the best bits if you just walk round the outside which is free.. or for 7 euro take a trip up the elevator of the national monument of Victor Emanuel II which gives you an amazing view over the complex and over Rome.

History at its best!. I have been a history buff since I was very young, but trust me, you don't have to be one to enjoy this magnificent place. To be amongst these ruins and only metres from the Colesseum, is absolutely breathtaking. A must see when in Rome!

Just take your time and enjoy this one. I am not the traveler who goes to massive archeological sites to skim by the ancient walls. I stand, I stare, I marvel at the people that made these great places possible. My husband and I took an entire day to see the Colosseum and the Pantheon because we kept having to pause to take it all in. Plus, hubby is an ancient history buff, so he was telling me all about the people who lived in the Pantheon, and the politics of ancient Greece. It made for a lovely time, but the site is packed with monuments and by the end of the day I felt like I deserved an 'A' in the crash course of Greek history I'd just been through.

YES!. Roman Ruins Rock! Get a guided tour. We love Walks of Italy. Makes me sad we have shrunk to our measley existences 2000 years later. They were such great minds- flawed but no more than we are now.

Bring a bottle of water and a snack. I just loved this. There is so much to see here, I was here for hours. There are toilets but no other amenities so bring some water and a snack, there are plenty of gorgeous scenes to sit down and drink in the serenity. There were a lot of tour groups, however as the area is so large easy to avoid the, and come back to things you want to see.

Find David Battanglino For A Tour You Won't 4get. The Only Thing That Outsurpasses His EntertaNing Knowledge Of Rome Is His Passion For His City. History Comes To Life With Stories You Will TelL To Your Friends. The History Of The Palatine Came To Life Through David

Allow plenty of time, take water bottles, skip the audio. We underestimated the amount of time it would take to walk Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum. Even after a few hours we felt a little rushed to get in to the Colosseum, however, it turned out to be perfect timing, as there were few people left at the Colosseum by the time we got there (after 5pm). Expect to walk, a lot. Palatine Hill is vast, with hills, walkways and lots of stairs, but it is fascinating and is so big, you won't feel crowded like many other Roman sites. Skip the audio tour--we tried it, but nothing is marked, so it's very difficult to figure out where you are on the audio. If they fix the signage issue, it might be worth it. In addition to the expense, the units don't work well, and we had to return one. We saw many people doing the same thing. You also have to wait in a separate line to get one, and you have to leave an ID with the desk, which also means you can't exit from the Forum and go on to the Colosseum without first returning it. Take in your water bottles; there are fountains with potable water you can refill them--and you'll probably need to. There are bathrooms in the white museum about midway. Buying a combo ticket gets you into the Colosseum the same day and you get the benefit of skip the line without the extra expense. It's the most economical way to see both.

Buy your combo ticket here!. Best advice ever was to buy the combo ticket for Palatine Hill, Forum, and Colosseum here. We also bypassed the short line that was there by paying a few euros for a guided tour. Kids under 18 are free. Be sure to bring water. The ubiquitous water fountains of Rome are not found here.

Please don't miss this experience!. We loved our visit to the Roman Forum and Palantine Hill. We bought our tickets before we left home, along with the Colosseum which is included. There's nothing like seeing these old ruins and pondering on the history of what actually went on there. We did not do any type of tour. We like to explore on our own, but, probably didn't know what alot of the buildings we were seeing actually were. You can often overhear the other tours, so, it's easy to figure out anyway. There is so much too see here. It's very hot and wear very good walking shoes, as with everywhere else in Rome. There's not alot of shade, and so much walking on uneven cobblestone. Don't miss this while in Rome!!

A good walk if you want the history. We took others advise and went here first before going to the Colosseum as the queue is smaller and then we can just go in the fast lane into the Colosseum. Walking around gives you a great idea of ancient Rome. there were toilets available. not much shade so take it easy in the sun.
Rome in a Day. Easy to get around by foot We had a day and a half in Rome , we walked everywhere and found it very easy to find the main attractions . A highlight for us was Castle Saint Angelo

TERRIBLE MAP/DIRECTIONS PROVIDED. We were looking forward to this....arrived early to beat crowds and heat and soon discovered that with all the 'renovations/repairs' etc in progress (but knowone actually working!), the map provided with audio was short of being useless ....together with absolutely NO signs or hint of directions to assist visitors, we gave up out of sheer frustration.....other visitors were walking round saying 'where do we go/where are we'.....SURELY it's not too much to ask when this is a major tourist attraction to have proper signs.....one large 'house' near a garden/fountain had no sign/label as to what it was......but had heaps of information about the garden that used to be the!!!!!!!! Very very disappointing....we didn't say anything to staff as we got the distinct impression they couldn't care!!
HUGE. This site can be walked but it will take a great effort. It can also be seen from above if walking is an issue. A must see for its extensive view of the history of Rome.

Not to be missed. Any trip to Rome, particularly for the first time visitor, must include time wandering the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill. The entry fee is low, and I was able to get a ticket immediately about mid-morning in June. The crowds were not huge, and there are plenty of spots where one can just sit and ponder the past. Take your walk slowly, but don't feel that you have to stop and minutely examine every piece of rubble and debris. If you want to skip an official tour, get a small guidebook or one of the numerous walking tour guides for free on the Web (no tour guides are required). Some of the areas are blocked off, as archaeological digs are ongoing, but you can stop and watch a dig in progress as long as you don't bother the workers. Definitely head up the Palatine Hill and see the Cardinal's Gardens - there's a lovely view of Rome from high atop the hill. Note also the wildlife in the area, particularly the gulls, which can be raucous.

A Shadow of what was once the center of the known world. We regularly return to Rome for weekends away and always find time to have a picnic on the Palatine under the pines. Steeped in history, whether your a scholar of ancient Rome or an enthusiastic tourist, you can not help but be touched by this shadow of history. A must.

So much to see. What's your interest? Ancient ruins? Gardens? Churches? Contemporary Art in an ancient setting? It's all here, really something for everyone. The ticket here is combined with the Colosseum, so hang onto it. A great deal for both at 12 Euros. If you have a Roma Pass you can use it to skip the line as long as it's one of your first two entries. Wear sunscreen, there's not a lot of shade!

not to be missed, need a guide. Unless you are an expert in Roman history and archeology a guide is a must for this site. The ruins are confusing and not well labeled. We started with an overall view of the area, went in the quick line to the coloseum for holders of the Roma Pass. After the colloseum we continued in the area of the Roman Forum. After our 3 hour organzed tour I wandered around on my own; had a had time finding my way out of the Palatine Hill.

triumph of the ceasars. Loved the history having seen numerous films featuring rome. We needed much longer than we had time for, but seeing the arches and senate house and the house of the vestal virgins is a start.

Wear good walking shoes!. You'll need them. There is a LOT of area to cover, and the stones can be slippery when wet.If you have children, it will be well worth it to buy one of the picture books sold at many of the tourist stands - the ones that show what the buildings and areas looked like back then. It'll really bring it to life for kids.
A must. It took three days to realise that this is really the heart of rome. I would recommend to go on a guided tour, otherwise it is just rocks.

Awesome ruins in the middle of the city. These ruins are beautiful and worth the time to look around. Lots of walking on uneven surfaces but amazing when you think about their history. Definitely worth the time, purchase the combo colosseum and forum ticket!!

Experiencing the ancient time. The Three day Roma pass allowed us instant entry without waiting in the long queue. The ruins, Temple , Forum, Museum all work as time machine, taking us back to the ancient time.One need to walk a lot, good walking shoes are advised.Close access to the metro and bus stop connects the place well to the city.

Walk walk walk. If youre not careful you'll be disappointed, as i was. Take the time to plan your visit and be prepared to see antient ruins and stones without proper explanation, picture or model building. Wear light shoes, take your water and study well before you ho there. Its a part of the ticket for colosseum and must see attraction.

lovely bit of history. we saw this on our second to last day of our trip, and we were getting pretty bored of ruins, however it was a nice visit, good bit of history and we used it on our roma cards so reduced entry

A must see. Despite the disappointment of some closed buildings and ruins, the Forum and Palatine Hill are must sees to get a sense of Ancient Rome public and private life. Wear a hat and bring a refillable water bottle - it's surprisingly fun to use the fountains there and in Rome.

Fantastic. For a small fee you can walk where Julius Caesar walked, see the Curia (Senate House), intact after 2000 years!! See where Julius Caesar was cremated and people still place flowers there. See where the Roman Emperors lived on the Palatine Hill. I was totally blown away by this place, so remarkable in the middle of the City of Rome. In this place, decisions were made which has affected western civilisation right to the present day.

Worth the entrance fee. Great to just wander around and imagine times past. Colosseum entrance fee includes this part too. We went with a very large group which spoilt things slightly - recommend you see it on your own.

Skip it. We came because we did not want to waste the combined Colosseo/Foro/Palatino ticket which was valid for 2 days. Besides, there was a recommended walk in the Roman Forum that we wanted to try. Our mistake was veering off course and following the signs to the Palatine right after the Arch of Titus. We ended up wasting an hour staring at piles of bricks that were better looked up in the internet rather than explored on foot. There was a crowd gathered at Stadio Palatino probably because it was recognizable and had a marker with description. Here we found a big Colosseo/Forum/Palatino location map that identified other points of interest as well as drinking fountain, washroom and entrance/exit locations. A copy of this map should have been given free with admission! We followed the signs to Casa di Augusto and were sorely disappointed when we got there. It was behind closed gates with some work underway, there was nothing to see. We went to Museo Palatino just to use the washrooms. The Palatine Hill has a viewing deck but the view is nothing compared to those you can see from the Gianicolo, St Peter’s cupola or Il Vittoriano’s terrazze. There was hardly anything worth taking pics at this site. It has a lot of history but sadly we did not find it interesting. It might help if management (Soprintendenza Archeologica di Roma?) provided free maps and put up markers with descriptions as well as reconstructed drawings at every significant rubble to serve as visual reference. Until then I say visit the Forum but skip Palatine Hill.
Palatine Hill. some amazing views of the whole of Rome from here,so worth the climb, quite peaceful in some places too,

Beautiful Quiet Spot after the Colosseum. Short walk after the Colosseum to a beautiful tranquil place with wonderful views . Easy walk down to the Forum . Tickets to Colloseum include this and the Forum , purchasing in advance was well worth doing around 12 euro ( kids and over 65 EU free but 1.50 each reservation fee if booking online) . There are no guides so take your book and bottle of water . There are clean toilets on the site. We went to Colloseum first , then here , down to the Forum and then back to Centro Storico ... it worked well for us :)
Very nice!. Very extensive and part of your entry fee/ticket for the colosseum, be ready to do a lot of walking and wear comfortable shoes.
Very nice!. It's very nice and very extensive, part of your entry ticket/fee for the colosseum that you can combine with the Roman Forum as well.
Alot to see... At first I didn't really want to go, but when I got their it was pretty good. I saw a lot and had great views of the city. They have a great garden of flowers and plenty more.

Be careful to the 2 days ticket. I have booked a 2 days ticket which included Colosseo, Palatino and Fori Imperiali. I wanted to visit the Colosseo and Palatino on the 1st day and Fori on the 2nd day. However, I realized that Fori and Palatino have only one entrance and if you get in for one of the two attractions you cannot get in anymore on the 2nd day because the ticket is valid for one entrance only. Of course this was not mentioned in the web when I bought the ticket. I was not very happy because the lady at the entrance clearly told me that going out on that moment, I would have missed the entrance to the Fori on the next day. Please mention that on the web so that people could be aware of that.

Needs a guide. You need a guide to explain what the ruins are. Unfortunately the official audio guide is poor - it's detailed (but dry) but difficult to work out where you are meant to be for each description. Also some pathways were closed for no obvious reason when I visited, making it harder to follow the guided route.If you get there early there's no queue and the ticket also gets you into the Colosseum (skipping the queue).
Beautiful Museum. Gorgeous museum and it close to Metro and buses going to the city centre. So busy when I went that that cuz a lot of different tours in the same day.

Still awesome to visit, but will see it again in off-season.. We were able to see the beautiful trees and flowers this time around. We do all of our European travel off-season and traveled here in Fall/Winter 2004 and wasn't able to enjoy the spring like this May. However, it was way too crowded. There were doing construction/cleaning so some of Palantine Hill was closed, as well.

A waste of time . . . and money.. No guide. No staff to inquire of. No maps, No brochures. No site signage describing anything (in Italian, let alone English). Entry fee for 2 of us: 25 euros.At the end of the day, unless you immerse yourself in learning about the site beforehand, you’re just looking at a pile of bricks. For $35 bucks.A complete waste of time & money. (And, having visited the Forum . . . also not so great with explanations . . . we would advise either spending the money for a guide, or skipping the ancient sites altogether.)

Nice on a sunny day. This attraction is quite large and spread out. It is nice to walk and wander around on a sunny day, looking at what is left of these old structures and trying to imagine what it must have been like in its day. I cant say it was the most inspiring of the sites we seen however it is still very much part of Romes wonderful history.

Don't miss it at night. Having a bit less gruesome history than the nearby Colosseum, this is a highly interesting but somewhat confusing site. The ruins span nearly 1000 years. We had downloaded audio tours, which helped. Also, which helps, is to view recreations of the forum (you can find them on YouTube). To bypass the very long lines, buy a Roma Pass - it is well worth it. However, you can see much of the site from the adjacent streets and this is where you should view it after dark. the lighting adds an etherial quality.

Great place to visit and great views. I was very impressed with Palatine HillIt is a short walk to the top where you’re met by the ruins of some palaces and the stadium.There are some great views of the Roman Forum and Rome itself from the hill.The botanical gardens were picturesque but they were hard to appreciate as it was raining during our visit.

Superb place to visit. The site is huge and there are lot’s of interesting Roman ruins and monuments to admire.I was particularly impressed with the gates and temple ruins. It was astonishing to think about all the history that occurred on this site.I would recommend that anyone who visits wear appropriate footwear as the entire site is cobbled.The only suggestion I would make is that facilities like toilets should be more clearly marked as signposts often lead you to exits.

Iconic Rome. Seen many times on TV but far more interesting to wander around it yourselves. I printed off the Walking Tour 1 and map of "Rome of the Caesars" from frommers.com/destinations/rome website which made it possible to wander around ourselves and make sense of the site. We didn't bother with the second half of the tour as we had spent 4/5 hours on the first part! So much to see and think about, putting it into historical context.
If you see nothing else, see this. There is an incredible sense of history in this spot. Get a good guide ( I downloaded Rick Steve's audio guide app) and pay attention because a lot happened here!

The best thing about Rome. We loved Rome - absolutely everything - the food, the wine, the metro, all of the well known sites. But the Roman Forum was outstanding. Don't bother with a guide. Get there early and buy a guide book from one of the stalls at Colosseo metro station. It will give you all the information you need at a fraction of the price. It was like walking back through time, with multiple eras surrounding you from BC through the most important periods of Roman history. Worth every centime of the entrance price.

Beautiful historic place - nice for a chilled walk. When in rome - you have to go there and see it. It's a nice combination between a relaxed walk in the gardens and a very very interesting historic sides of rome. See the sculptures and the signs on the stones. Very impressive.You have a nice few from the top of the gardens over colosseo and a the old part of rome city.Smelled extremelly nice after a short rainshower. It' so big, that the counts of tourists doesn't matter.
roman ruins. I didn't like this as much as the colosseum,you need imagination to see rome as it was in the past,can skip if you are there for only a couple of days

Ruins worth visiting to dream of how Emperors lived. Great views and tranquil too.. The final piece of the triumvirate that includes the Colosseum and the Roman Forum. I would recommend seeing this last, after the Forum, as they are linked. One 12 euro ticket covers them all. Outstanding value. This is the most tranquil of the three, situated high on a hill, there are fewer tourists, and some great views of surrounding Rome to be had. Though much of what must have been opulent palaces has been reduced to rubble, it’s still possible to imagine what life must have been like for Roman high society and the Emperors. The site is massive, and some parts of it are still very impressive indeed. I was surprised just how integrated and close it was to the Forum. It’s a real pity so little of it survives, this place would have been a real wonder, but even as it is, the site is still definitely worth visiting. Bring a vivid imagination!

Historic, peaceful, thought-provoking. At one level, there isn't much to see on Palatine Hill--ruins of former palaces interspersed with trees and views of the city beyond. At a different level, the quiet of Palatine Hill the early morning we were there was both therapeutic and thought-provoking. After the hoards in the Vatican Museum at at the Papal Audience, we were pleased and soothed to find we had the paths and venues almost to ourselves on several occasions. Finally, it is not a new insight, but it is useful to think about how the palaces of the rich and powerful are all gone. It reminds me--in my humble life--to understand the transitory nature of power and to try to invest in things that last. Highly recommended.

Omg but wear good walking shoes. This was a really exciting experience. Be warned rocky uneven walk ways (Ceasar walked there) no real handicapped help. Not for weak or not able bodied. Sorry it's true. Otherwise bring some water and your Rick Steve's app and ear phones or rent. I'll never forget it
Fascinating site. But not without an audio guide!! No signage at all. Rick Steves has an excellent free downloadable MP3 audio tour! Centuries of history in a small place.

Don't stay in the queue for AUDIOBOOK: TIP&TRICK. If you want to take the audiobook, don't stay in the same line with everyone else. Go directly at the front of the queue where it splits up. You will be able to buy audiobook and tickets from that "special" desk.I would not recommend the audiobook since the way it presents the forum is really messy. Too many facts and you don't distinguish the ruins from what it says. No Clear picture and not good overall. Just get a decent book.Only reason you would rent one would be to get over the queue.Hope this will help others and will not do the same mistake as us. Oh and get a hat!

Great for history lovers, take some kind of guide and arrive early. We arrived early in the morning (9 AM) and there was no line whatsoever, we just walked up and got the tickets that later that day got us into the colosseum without waiting in line there at all. I am a history lover and read a lot about ancient Rome before our visit but still needed a guide, because the place is mostly ruins and it's very hard to imagine what it must have looked like back in the day. We took Rick Steve's audio guide that is included in his mobile application and it was pretty good. It also let us walk around at our own pace which was nice.

You should go!!. As words as i write,it is very little for the beaty and the size of these monuments.Suddenly when you are inside these monuments you feel that you are in another era,it is really a time machine.It does not matter if i propose you to go,if you go to Rome,you have been there already!!

Over-priced, and something of nothing. We had visited the Palatine Hill some years ago when we first took a stroll round the Roman forum, but decided this time to go in directly using the entrance in Via di S. Gregorio. It says at the entrance if I've hit 60 I can get in for free, and I have reached the sublime state of earning a bus pass. Good show! Otherwise it will set me back Euro 12. The kiosk girl responded to my request for a free-bee with a massive yawn - not even a hand to the mouth. I have a reasonable knowledge of Italian, but she did not know this, and my explanation that I was English received a barrage of hostile Italian that translated roughly as 'get lost'. Unless you opt to carry your passport (not advisable) or birth certificate everywhere, forget it. We paid Euro 24.The Palatine gardens are these days scruffy and weed infested. We came across one loo, mixed gender, no signs of any shape or form, and a little boys-and-girls room that you would definitely prefer to forget. If the Rome archaeological authorities want to keep attracting visitors they need to improve their act. I know Italy is in recession but it is not sufficient justification to soak tourists at every opportunity, and one or two could do with a refresher course at charm school.If you want nice, relaxing gardens in Rome, the Borghese Gardens that you get to via Flaminio on the Metro are prettier, they won't cost you, and you may not even get yawned at.

wonderful views but a rip off. 12 euros to get in even if you dont want to visit the Collosseum.
There was not an option on tickets. remember your passport if you are over 65 you have a reduction.

A combined attraction with the Forum Romanum. A very nice and calm area in the centre of Rome. The trees and plants are lovely and it gives you a good impression of the life in ancient Rome. The attraction is directly linked to the Forum Romanum. Tip: Since buying a ticket at the Colloseum will allow you to enter at the Forum Romanum and Palatine Hill. It might be an option to buy your ticket at the Palatine Hill and skip the line at the Colloseum, since this latter line is way longer.

A very interesting historic site. You don't need a tour guide if you have a decent guide book and a lot of the information stands have an English translation so you can work out what things used to be. :) You can get some amazing views of Rome from the top of the hill as well.

Huge!. Entrance is included in the ticket to the Colosseo. The place is huge. I could only imagine what it must have been like during the peak of the Roman Empire. Well woth the visit and whilst there are large ruins keep an eye out for some of the amazing details.

Awesome site, wish we had a guide!. This site was unbelievable. We took pictures for hours, just stunned. We wished we had a tour guide because signage is limited and in a lot of cases, we had no idea what we were looking at. Every square inch of this place is an uneven walking surface, so if you have balance problems, stay away.

A break from the hustle.. Palatine Hill is one of my favourite places in Rome as it offers a cooling break from the maddening crowd below while being interesting in its own right. The hill offers great views of Rome, great archeological sites and tree cooled paths on which to slowly stroll along. Tip: visit Palatine first before the Forum as you can gain entry to the Forum easily, at no extra cost and will likely help you to avoid the very lengthy entrance lines to the Forum at its main entrance.

A good contrast after the Forum (and included in the price).. This suffers from the same lack of interpretation as the Forum, and the large areas fenced off without any sign of activity, but it is much less crowded and there is plenty of scope to cool off and explore. There are good views over the Forum.

An archeological junkyard?. That is certainly how it might seem if you have not done your homework or hired a guide. The queues can be very long, so a Roma pass could be handy. It's a pity that those responsible seem to have little idea about conservation and how to aid interpretation. Also large areas are roped off without any evident signs of activity. You can gain a good impression without entering the Forum at all, both from the Via Imperiali and Via della Consolazione.
Incredible Past. Beautiful views, you can imagine what WAS there, such an enigma. The lives of the affluent, Nero, and the vital portion of the Roman Empire tht occurred at this world landmark.

Nice, but can waste a lot of your time if you let it.... This was nice initially, but you're essentially let loose in an area of ruins with no map, no guidance, and difficulty even finding a way out. There are certainly gems to find within here, but before long, you gasp in more amazement at a bathroom with soap than you do the endless landscape of nearly-identical ruins.It's definitely worth doing, especially after the crowds at the Colosseum, but I would recommend approaching this with a very determined attitude, because if not, you'll look back and think you spent too much time on it. Of the two attached attractions (Colosseum being the other), I could have probably gone without this.

the text books do no justice.... You don't want to miss this mysterious beauty!...it's not everyday you get a chance to be up close and in person with a part of history itself. My husband and I decided to tour France and Italy for our 3 week honeymoon in late August. One word describes my honeymoon...Amazing!!! There is so much culture, history and breathtaking art to take in...3 weeks just wasn't enough time..so we're planning another trip back! Sightseeing throughout Rome takes a bit of walking around by foot, so start your days early and make sure you wear very comfy shoes and DO NOT forget your camera and your bottle of chilled water,...bring an umbrella if you go during the warmer months...the sun's a killer.
Not that great. I wasn't very impressed with it. There was a lovely garden there tho. I thought it will be much more interesting.
So many ruins. It is interesting, but also confusing, you can't tell what is old and what has been repaired. They kept rebuilding and remodeling. You almost need your own carbon date tester.

great stroll.. This place is just full of history. Visit this before the Colloseo! Why? Lines are not that long here and the ticket that you'll purchase here would also be valid in Colloseo and Palatine Hill. Overall, its one great experience!

OK for history but not much to see for the effort. Filled with history but not much left to see but recollected rubble. It is part of the glory that was Rome and pays tribute to murdering emperors, but has little left to spark the imagination. Only the excavated portion of the Vestal Virgins headquarters gives much of an impression. A lot of walking and climbing involved. There are better ways to see it than by climbing through it.

The most magnificent site in all of Europe. This is possibly the most amazing site in Europe, most of the architecture of classical antiquity remains only in small, isolated fragments (barring a few notable exceptions) but I can't think of any with as much closely packed in them as this. A huge area full of temples, buildings, statues and columns that will make you feel as if you're truly wandering around the ancient republic itself. It stands as a stark and refreshing contrast to the Catholic dominated cultural attractions of Rome and should be on anyone's list for a visit.

Not Much Left But Still Worth Seeing. The buildings are crumbling and there is a lot of wear and tear but the area still tells thousands of amazing stories. We did a walking tour which I would recommend as the guide can explain what each structures purpose and what it once looked like.
Great historic site.. We walked where the roman legions marched in triumph. Visited the colosseum and imagined the lions being freed to fight with humans... very powerful.

Feel the history. We went there after colloseo as its nearby and the ticket to colloseo includes roman forum,there wasn't a line and we went inside without difficulties.looking at the pictures you see nothing special but you have to go to understand the atmosphere.its a spectacular place.i got a little sunburnt there so prepair sun protection- everything will be useful as sun in Italy is a real evil.after visiting it combing upstairs you will see the symbol of rome - the wolverine.so don't forget to take a picture.
beautiul. beautiful rome, nice to take a walk around the roman forum, lots of history and beautiful scenary for photo opportunities :)

Amazing. This is a wonderful place. There is so much to see and it is fascinating. There are also good views from the higher parts of Palatine. You could easily spend many hours walking around as there are so many things to look at.One ticket price of12 euros covers getting into The Palatine, The Roman forum (which is at the same place) and the Colosseum, which is next to them.The down side was the queue. We'd seen on Trip Advisor that it was quicker to queue at The Palatine and get our tickets there rather than at the Colosseum. That might be correct, but the queue at The Palatine was horrendous. It wasn't that long, but at times it didn't move at all for about 10 minutes. I can't understand why it took so long. They really need to do something about this. Why it should take so long to take money off someone and give them a ticket is beyond me. My husband queued for well over an hour for tickets. If you are in Rome for a few days, I would recommend getting a Roma Pass as you simply walk straight in, without having to queue.

Not much to see. Although ancient history is in front of your eyes there are not many to see. Almost everything is ruined except from the Arch of Septimius Severus. Great view from the Capitoline Hill

Why not since you are in Colosseo. This place is huge. It is part of the admission ticket to Colosseo (which is right next to it). Uphill and downhill. Be ready to walk! Wear comfortable shoes. Pavement are all rocky uneven surfaces. Totally drained us out by the end of it. Have fun!

So much to see!. So many great ruins in such a small space, you could easily spend hours here alone! Favourite spot was the Necropolis just up the hill. Make sure you wear enclosed shoes as the ground is very dusty. Fantastic place to visit for lovers of ancient Roman history.

Great to Explore. We didn't do the tour, although I'm sure it would help explain much of what we were seeing. We had already done many tours in Rome and were happy to simply explore the ruins and read the signs when we came upon them. The area is huge, so be ready to walk. We couldn't have been happier to just explore some old Roman ruins. Definitely recommend it.

I really recommend visiting as a tour. We visited this as part of a tour and due to the historical knowledge of our guide she really brought the whole place to life.I'm not sure if this would have been the case without her as there is so much history within that area

Do the guided tour!. It's packed with history. Unless you know your Romans inside out I would book a guided tour. We booked an English tour at the box office. There are a lot of people selling 'official' tours around the sites but do your homework and compare the prices and access before you set out to visit the sites. Our tour guide was fantastic. Knowledgeable. professional and projected her voice (a must given that there are so many school trips/ guided tours to block out!). Finish off your tour by walking to the top of the hill in the forum where rocks and rubble are replaced with lush greenery and flowers.

an absolute must if you have an interest in ancient rome. we got the English tour. ..was excellent. ..this tour matched up how and why of the collesium and led our history lesson through to the middle ages and then the vatican. .

A long day but well worth it.. It's hard to take it all in but well worth the visit, take plenty of fluids, it gets very hot on that hill, I'd also take a bite to eat as we were drained by the time we left. The walk ways could have done with a little maintanance as very uneven in places, good flat shoes a must. Not wheelchair or pushchair friendly, also very few and poor toilets. Still a great day.

History buffs paradise. You can't go wrong by visiting the Palatine hill and seeing the imperial palace. If you don't like crowds and are not a huge history buff, go late in the day...around 5:30. There are very few people there, albeit some of the attractions are closed for the day....like the house of Augustus and Livia and the view of the Circus Maximus. If you are a big history buff, also go late in the day, but return the next day since your ticket is good for two days...and see the sites that may have been closed previously. The museum is small but I enjoyed it. If you like history you will enjoy it. If this is the first museum you've seen on your Rome visit you will enjoy it. If you have seen the Vatican museum, Capitoline museums, or National Museum of Rome already, then skip this as it is sculpture and bust overload. The house of Augustus is very cool. However if you're not overly enthusiastic about the Roman empire skip it as there is generally a half hour long line. If you are looking for the throne room, it seems its no longer accessible. Also as of April 2013, the Romulus and Remus huts that guidebooks tell you to visit are also no longer accessible.

Lots to see!. I enjoyed walking round the ancient ruins and trying to get a feel for what it used to be like, but I would have liked a little bit more information - a map, some more information as to what each building perhaps was or points of interest. We had a guide book so we could make sense of it all, but otherwise there was no way of knowing what each ruin was. Almost everything is outside, so visit when it isn't raining. You can also buy a ticket for the colosseum and the price of the ruins is included in that, worth bearing in mind. Great to see the history though!

Such a Salvage Yard You Need a Real Guide!. We hit a travel wall this day during a whirlwind tour and our imaginations were quite spent. The audio tour here was so overly verbose!!!! We truly needed an enthusiastic, knowledgeable, honest guide to excite us over the rubble. The audio guide and map seemed torturous to follow, much more confusing than the winding streets of rome itself! My mother infromed me, after the trip of course, that she had purchased an overlay book which allowed her to view what the rubble actually was prior to the dismantling of it. Wow! We would have loved that!

Hours Of Enjoyment. This is a must see attraction, don't just visit the Colloseum. It is situated right next door to its more famous neighbour, but has so much to offer. We spent literally hours wandering around the ruins, but you need to wear sensible footwear as the surfaces are often very uneven and difficult to negotiate. We bought our tickets as a combined entry with the Colloseum prior to travelling, and I feel this is the best way to do so to avoid lengthy queues.

Well worth it. Another beautiful place full of history but also relatively quiet and green, a nice place to go on a hot, busy day - equally good for checking out the sights or lazing under a tree with a book.

In love with the ancient Roma. Truely amazing place. No need to pre-book the tickets: I arrived early at 9am and get straight in from the Palatine Hill entrance (halfway down the road south of Arch of Constantain). Do get the audioguide (bring an earphone so you can share one between 2!) as it explains a lot of history. It is very crowded with lots of tour groups and especiall school group. I wil recommand spending a good half to a whole day here if you have the time to spare: the tickets include Colosseum for 2 days. Bring your own lunch though, there's no restaurant (at least I didn't find any) inside. A pinic in the Palatine Hill garden or the Venus and Rome temple is amazing though.

Gigantic collection of Roman Ruins. I was amazed at all the different buildings, and how the reconstruction is done. You can wander throughout the area, sit around on some of the ancient stones and drink in history. We took a 3-in-one tour, which included the Coliseum, Forum and Paletine Hill with a local guide. It was 30 Euros per person - but worth it to scoot in past the long lines, and give you some of the history. I don't know what the regular fee is for getting in to these places, but it was included in our 30E. Anyway - the columns are spectacular...and the archwork everywhere has stood the test of time. Simply amazing.

Great place to visit but they could have made it easier to get tickets and go inside. This is a great place - i visited it few years ago when visiting Rome with friends. Went to Rome in March this year and really wanted to take wife there, but there was such a big queue for the tickets which was moving SO SLOWLY - we stood there so long my wife felt suddenly ill and we ended up not going in. So disappointed. They charge tourists so much, could they not provide a better service at least? Maybe put some seatings to sit while waiting.Also, there is a small "shop-on-wheels" nearby selling sandwiches and snacks - DO NOT ever buy from them as i bought a sandwich for my wife from them while waiting and she got sick from that..

Awesome. You can do this on a tour to get all the history or visit yourself. It's only 12 euro's each and includes entrance to the coliseum as well. Take good walking shoes as the paths are original from centuries ago and there is so much too see some of which is uphill. If you take your time you can spend 3-4 hours here taking photo's and reading up on the history. A great place and you can quite literally touch history. Best value and the highlight of the trip along side the Coliseum.

Fantastic. We went here before the colosseum so as to get our joint ticket and avoid the queue at the colosseum. We waited 10 minutes and were in. We went up to the Palantine first and wandered around trying to imagine what it must have been like over the years. We had a guide book to help us understand what things were and I would say that this was important. A few hours was needed really. No food for sale inside.

One of my favorite parts of Rome. I loved just wandering the site, particularly Palatine Hill area, which is not only amazing historic but also staggeringly beautiful. Almost perfect.Staff at the entry was very helpful with the Roma Pass.We listened to the Rick Steves podcast while we walked the site which heightened the experience.

A lot to see. It's all most too much to take in in such a small space and time, but much of it is amazing. This was probably the least helpful audio guide in Rome, and about halfway through the day we stopped using it for the most part. Make sure you leave enough time to get up to the top and see Palatine hill.

Get up to the top. I wasted too much time wandering the gardens as the base of the hill. After you tour the forum head straight up to the museum (the bathroom there was closed for our visit) at the top of the hill and start your Palatine tour from there.

Dream come true. The Italian capital and former Roman capital has two sides...the new and the ruins. These ruins open up your mind to the wonders of ancient Rome. The engineering feats, precision blocks of stone and the fact.that a lot of it is still standing. Amazing
Fascinating. This was really good to wander around, it was amazing to think how old it is and how they built everything

Beautiful area, needed a map!. My husband and I walked through the Roman Forum and surrounding garden (Palatino, I believe) in April 2013 and it was a lovely morning.
