We entered through the south side - there was no line, it wasn't crowded, and I think we got the better end of the deal (at the end of the walk we exited on the NE side and it was very crowded and touristy). I wish they had given us a map of the grounds, however, as the southern side is beautiful and open but with a few dead ends. There were signs throughout the park indicating what the different sites and ruins were, so that was helpful and informative. Great views of the city and the Colloseum!

Impressive. I was not expecting to see such beatiful place. Although I did not go inside, if you walk on the surroundings and on the sidewalks, you are able to have amazing landscapes. And there are the rodes near that you are able to visualize everything in a general overview. It is indeed one of the most pretty views, in my opinion. So, if you are not willing to pay to be able to get inside, you will still be able to have the experience of this play. In the pictures you can see that it really is a place worth of your time.

David Battaglino is one of the best tour guides for Rome. My cousins and I went to Rome a week ago and it was an amazing experience. Part of this was attributed to David's tours - informative, funny and some of the best tips for touring Roma. If you want a guide to the eternal city, look no further.

we suggest a guide. did not expect to love this like we did. coupled with the forum, this is a powerful experience, not to be missed. if you can afford to spring for an arranged tour with a guide, do so. otherwise, pick up a copy of a book like "reconstructed rome" or something like that via amazon before you go, so you'll know what you're seeing. even if you had no idea what you were looking at, it would still be a great experience.
One of Rome's seven hills.. Palatine Hill is in the same area as the Colosseum and Forum. The same ticket will get you into all three. Ancient Rome at it's finest.

Wonderful place to visit. So impressed with the Roman remains but having done the Colessum and Palatine Hill couldn't belive there was no food or drink available in any of the sites. Takes many hours to visit all three sites on the combined ticket but had to cut visit short as it was three in the afternoon and we had to have something to drink. Would have helped if we had known this in advance and could have gone prepared.

palatine hill and coloseum. We have bought ticket on place.It was definitely worth of seeing. We have spend nearly 4hours of walking and taking pictures as there was much to see. After we went to see Coloseum. Was handy to get tickets in advance as we could skip the queue.must recomend to see.

Could use more information. I would recommend getting a guide book or a actual tour of Palatine Hill. I expected a lot more information signs within the ruins, however there were very few (especially at the beginning). I wish I had done more research on the ruins before heading into them and I recommend you do the same. It is quite frustrating walking through and not knowing what exactly you are looking at.

Impressive sites but do get a guide !. Set aside a whole day to explore these impressive sites and preferably do not do it on your own as it will all end up as piles of rubbles as there are hardly any signboard explaining the significance of the particular place. Either try to get a guided tour or an audio guide. The audio guide cost approximately 7€ for all 3 sites. Anyhow despite the lack of guidance, we still found the place pretty impressive and definitely a must visit when in Rome. Another suggestion would be to get the Roma Pass as it really helps with the long queues and wear comfortable walking shoes as there will be a lot of walking!

Fascinating and Great for a Curious Kid. As an adult, this is a must-see, but my 8-year old inquisitive daughter was thoroughly fascinated and asked to go back again. She loved it so much, that we bought a book (in English) with facts about the ruins. The ticket for this will also get you into the Colloseum and it is better to buy it at the Forum for shorter lines.

ancient but brilliant. we travelled to rome in august not the best month as it was very hot (no wonder the romans leave the city) but the benefit of this that english students studying in rome give "free tours of the forumguide books are good but they can't tell the true stories behind the buildings our guide told us all the stories behind the stone where caesar was killed where mark anti=ony gave his famous "friends romans speech" why romans still mark caesars death with flowers to this dayhe then sat us down and told us all the gory details of the caesars through the years and for a family group of 9 including 5 teenagers the gorier the better!!!although the tour was free we were so impressed with his story telling we of course had a whip round for him well worth every every euro

Fascinating stuff. I'm not into History by any means, and didn't book a tour guide to take us round, but I thoroughly enjoyed the spectacle of the remnants of the forum, and imagining exactly what it must have been like in Ancient Rome all those years ago. Wish I'd read the top tip below about the "Reimagining Rome" book aimed at kids, because my 42yr old self would have enjoyed that immensely! Well worth a visit on your way to the Colosseum.

Not to be missed.... Definitely pencil in a few hours to properly take it all in.We were on a tight schedule and had lost time queuing at the Colosseum which meant we had to rush around the Forum. My mate wasn't too interested in visiting until we were in there and exploring, and we both agreed we'd of rather spent the majority of time here, instead of the Colosseum. It's a big site with lots to see (or rather, imagine seeing) as obviously the majority of the buildings are ruins, usually just a few columns left. Just from the remains though it's clear to see the sheer scale of proceedings back then.A few people mention the lack of information on site, personally, this a plus, I feel it allows you to immerse yourself within the setting and makes you feel like you're truly exploring,

Lots of imagination needed. I'm a Roman history buff but even I struggled with figuring out this place. This was the centre of the Roman Empire and indeed the centre of the civilised world. A few more labels and maps wouldn't go amiss. I would visit again, however, with a tour guide.

What can you say?!? The history rings out!. 'Friends. Romans and countymen' was uttered here. And Julius Ceaser stabbed to death. These tales which have been recounted and played out in so many productions actually happened where you can stand with your own two feet. It's very old and very worn. With most of the buildings, bar a few pillars, a giant arch and a church which doesn't actually look connected, being little more than a few bricks high. But the many, many tales are so thick in the air... like the Vessel Virgins, who's temple is there; if they were found to have had relations with a man, they were buried alive with only a lamp and a piece of bread! The history of the place is amazing!

A great place of history but a big climb and less than down below.. The Palatine hill is above the Forum and where the emperors and wealthy of ancient rome lived. From it we get the word palace. My mother found the climb up taxing and, after starting down below in the forum where 'friends, Roman's and counrymen' rings through time the remains on the Palatine Hill did not seem as impressive. This said there is an excellent view from the top, a plesant garden and the private ampitheatre of the rich worth a look. Take a drink! It's a good walk up.

My favourite. The Palatine Hill is included in the price of the Colosseum and the forum. It is the homes of several emperors and you get a lot for your money including a museum. (Don't forget ID for under-25s as they get a discount.) It's incredible to think how old it all is. There are also some great views of Rome. Good walking shoes recommended.

Nice Walk & Views!. Beautiful walk and just a stones throw away from the Colosseum.We went at the end of April and the weather was pleasant, quite a lot of walking involved but well worth it for the views. Great photo opportunities and if you are visiting the Colosseum keep your ticket as this covers both the Palatine Hill & the Roman Forum.

Amazing History!. Watching movies over the years about Roman history and standing in the very spot Roman soldiers once walked, felt unbelievable. We visited the Roman Forum after our underground colosseum tour. It was a pleasant sunny day, and we spent about 4 hours walking around the Forum and Palantine Hill. So much history and what is astounding is the detail in the ruins built so many many years ago. A very interesting day, and it will be difficult to pick which pictures to print. Definitely a must if visiting Rome!

A delight. Right next to the Colosseum, it is included in the ticket price for that. Definitely can spend half a day around this, we had to rush a bit towards the end as our guided tour was at 1pm and we got in here at 10am. Easily could spend 5+ hours wandering!

Go early and do not go audio guided. In total contrast to the Colosseum, the audio guide was terrible. It kept on slipping into Italian and even offered me Russian at one point! This was despite taking it back halfway through our visit. There are no audio guide listening points marked along the route nor are there any numbers marked on the signs which one can relate to the numbers on the official map. A number of the main attractions were closed - the Curia, Livia's House, Aula Isiaca etc. It was a very unsatisfactory visit indeed. The best thing was getting there at 8.30am and having the place almost to ourselves for the first hour or so.

Be careful you don't go round in circles.... We spent most of the day here, partly because it was so absorbing, but also because the signs pointing to the exits were a bit confusing. Mind you, if we hadn't taken a wrong turn we wouldn't have seen the very place where Gaius Julius Caesar was stabbed...people have been leaving flowers and tributes there nearly 2000 years later! Testimony to the great man.Caesar Augustus' house was also very inspiring as he seemed to live very simply despite being the first of the Julio Claudian emperors. I loved his 'wallpaper'!It's so central in Rome you won't have trouble finding it. They sell tickets that last 3 days so that you can visit the Colosseum and forum at leisure. Once again, take good wlking shoes or your feet will let you know. It can also be very steep in places.

Very Pretty & Great Views Over Forum. This is really worth a visit and if you are going to go to the Colosseum then your ticket covers you for entry to the Forum and and the Palatine Hill. It's the 2nd largest of the hills in Rome and it's a lovely place to walk through in the right weather. The history is fantastic of the place and you get a real sense of how lavish some of these Rich romans were when you see the size and scope of the palace at the top.

Bit lost. On a nice day visiting the ruins is great, problem is you wander around not knowing what you are looking at and you can get lost.There needs to be a map you can follow, more information about the ruins you are looking at. A little history here and there.I felt we just walked around and looked at one ruin after another not really knowing what it was, the history behind it etc.If the ruins were not so impressive and vast this would have been even more disappointing.

Wander at will. Amazing to think that you are walking among 2000 year old ruins. It would have good to have a little more information about what we were looking at and a few more directions would have helped but overall an interesting place to visit.
great. We went for a tour into palitine hills, and enjoyed the scenery. The views were exceptional, and the history was everywhere.
Relived my childhood dreams!. Absolutely magical to take a look at the ruins where once, the great Roman empire used to live. Worth one whole day on these grounds.

Impressive but no signs- just directions. This is an impressive site but you need something to explain what everything is or a guide book. Inside of the small church is worth looking at - some original wall paintings still there. Just a small map with the ticket would be a massive help Rome

Large area to visit- some impressive views of Rome. Included in the colloseum, forum ticket for €12 this was an enormous site with a small museum, beautiful views of Rome and the circus maximo.
Well signposted at the top for direction but not many signs explaining what anything is- in any language.

Impressive size. This is probably 5 KM in circumference and the scale is vast and impressive. Full of Roman ruins and the occasional catholic structure. From the hill you get excellent views of Rome. I'd give it 2-3 hours to explore. Go early there isn't much shade.

Breathtaking place - but disappointing information. To see an amazing place that we have been aware of all our lives was fantastic. We started at the entrance by the Palatine Hill and used an audio guide. The numbered map provided to use with the audio guide was totally inadequate and, unlike the excellent audio guide at the colosseum, there were no indicators at the site to help with which number to key on the audio device. Also, because we entered at the Palatine Hill entrance and not the Forum entrance on Via del Fori Imperial -THE NUMBERS ON THE MAP NEED TO BE FOLLOWED IN REVERSE. This is probably sounding like gibberish unless you have been and tried to follow the guide. In a lot of places - most particularly on Palatine Hill, we struggled to relate the map,guide and site together and hoped that everything would fall into place at some point, but it remained difficult and frustrating to follow. It was clearer when we reached the forum area, but still inadequate as some parts that the guide tells you to walk through were closed.This is an incredible historic place that once affected the history of a vast area of the world but we feel as though we have missed out on a lot of information. It could be organised much better - a few scale models of what it was like in it's glory days would have been so helpful and valuable - there is certainly the space there for this without impeding on any of the site. An absolute MUST has got to be maps and audio devices that correspond to the Palatine Hill entrance. We came away with a plan to buy a DVD/Book to go through and tally-up details with what we can remember. NB. The whole area is totally unsuitable for disabled guests due to the rough terrain.

Good views over the Roman Forum. Palatine Hill shares an entrance with the Roman Forum, and brings you up to higher ground where you can see, amongst other things, Augustus' palace and several other interesting sites (such as a little garden maze) and ruins. The hill also offers some nice views looking out over Rome and provides some good photo opportunities. Worth spending an afternoon in together with the forum!

Bring your own guide book. Visually stunning, but very limited signs or description of what you are seeing. Buy a guidebook to take in with you that describes all the areas and what they would have looked like.

The real deal. There is so much that happened here over the course of Roman history and of course the remnants nowadays are a mix of different historical time periods from the Republic through the Empire. However you cannot visit it without a humbling sense of its importance to modern civilization, for all the murder and mayhem that happened here as well as momentous decisions made within a few meters that determined the futures of Britain, Spain, France and of course Carthage.

Take a guided tour. There is so much history to see but not much explanation, to really understand the this great landmark take the tour, It was not very expensive and well worth it. Also the entrance ticket provides access to the Colosseum & Palentine, you have 2 days to see the three sites.

Step back in Time. Allow yourselves enough time here as plenty to see if you manage to cover the whole site. A guided tour is well worth the extra money as this really brings the whole place to life. a amust do in Rome and suggest reading up on as much of the sites history before you go as really adds to the whole experience.

Excellent view of the Colliseum and the rest of the city.. I totally recomend this place if you want to make lovely photos of the different buildings of Rome. The place is surrounded by old roman ruins. You must go in a sunny day, otherwise you wont appreciate the magnific view of the city.

Needs more information . Amazing amount of ruins and history just a pity not enough signs explaining what your looking at.
If it was in the uk there would be pictures and descriptions to go with everything.
we found ourselves looking wondering "well its pretty but what is or was it....."

CITY OF ROME. So much history, to visit and marvel at. Feel inspired and be grateful for so much beauty in one city. Four day's not really long enough, really tired feet at the end of each day, but the need to be out the next day you forget just how tired you feel. The best site for me, The Pantheon, what history, what a Monument.

Combined with entry to the colosseum. Probably like most reviewers I would describe as simply awesome. It is a free entry if you go see the colosseum so very good value.The ruins literally take your breath away - the realisation that such an advanced civilisation existed 2,000 years ago is awesome. the architecture that remains is interesting and often so vast that you can't believe it was ever made.Managed to wander around in around two hours and build up a little appetite for more ruins!

Wow, Ancient Rome. Just being able to see any of the old ancient ruins is special, there are awesome remains of lots of old statues, archs, temples and is such an interesting place to walk around with signs telling you all about it.Must See when in Rome.We had the Roma Pass which helps alot.

Not to be Missed. There is alot of walking to do here but plenty of good views along the way.If you buy the Vatican/Roma Pass you get to use it here and any places in Rome.Good Idea to pay one of the students who speaks english to give a guided tour and explain alot if you dont know too much.

Walk through. We went here on our last day. It was sunny so a great day to explore. There are signs posted that tell you what you are looking at. Very interesting and unique. It is a little confusing when you first walk in because the path splits multiple ways. It is very peace full to just walk around. There are lots of birds here. They are even still diging in parts that was interesting to see. Please stay on the paths and keep your kids on the paths there are people tryinging to enjoy the view or get pictures.

Stunning views. Palatine Hill is connected to the forum - and I believe is where they think Rome started. There are some fabulous ruins on the hill and plenty of things to see. Make sure you take a picture of the map at the entrance and go and see everything! The high places give some brilliant views of the colosseum, the forum and the arches. Also the circus maximo from the rear of the complex! Very well kept, lovely and green. Annoyingly there were some conservation works happening while we were there but needs must! Combined ticket with forum and colosseum!

Breath-taking. To see how much has been preserved from Ancient Rome is absolutely breath-taking. Most of it would be around 2000 years old! There are remains of houses, palaces, arches, temples and of course, the forum itself. A must see, and if you buy a ticket for the forum (or vice versa) you can also get in the colosseum with the same ticket! Bargain!

Excellent views, an essential companion to the Forum. The Palatine hill was where the Roman elite mainly had their homes and palaces from the earliest history of Rome right through to the later Emperors. Indeed our word for 'palace' derives, I believe, from the word Palatine. It was here that Romulus and Remus was supposed to have lived, and where figures such as Cicero, Mark Anthony, Emperor Augustus, Nero and Domitian had their palaces. Indeed it is worth remembering that what you see today are the ruined remains of perhaps 1,000 years of building activity which transformed the original shape of the hill. The large brick structures which you see from the Forum are merely the supporting structures for the great marble palaces that would once have stood on top.Here are the main things that I have discovered on my visits to the Palatine Hill:1. Do consider getting a Roma pass for 30 euro before going to Rome. You can buy them on the net beforehand and pick them up when you arrive. I picked mine up at the airport at a tourist information desk - it was very quick and easy. The Roma pass gives you free access to your first 2 attractions and then half price to many more, for a period of 3 days. It also allows you free transport on the metro and by bus for 3 days. The Forum and the Palatine Hill count as one attraction when you use the Roma pass. The Roma pass also allows you to skip the ticket queue at attractions which can be a real boon. Note that one place where you cannot use the Roma pass is the Vatican - for that you need a special ticket which can be booked in advance on the Vatican website. Note also that the Vatican museum is one of the few Roman museums to be open on a Monday so it may make sense to visit it then if you can. 2. The metro in Rome is very easy to use as it only has two lines which cross Rome in an X shape with the intersection at Termini main train station. One arm of the X comes from the direction of the Vatican and goes down towards south-east Rome and the other arm comes up from south-west Rome, past the Colosseum and on up to north-east Rome. The Colosseo stop is probably the closest stop to the Palatine Hill. If you have a Roma card you can simply walk up to the ticket barriers, hold your Roma pass up to it and they will open for you. The buses are also easy to use and cover more of Rome than the metro. With a Roma pass you can simply jump on whichever bus you want without needing to buy any additional ticket.3. The Forum is joined to the Palatine Hill so it makes sense to do the two together. It is basically one big space. There are no ticket barriers or anything separating the two.4. The Palatine Hill is grouped close by a number of fascinating things to see which you can visit in conjunction with it. There is the Forum, which is joined to the Palatine Hill, the Colosseum which is very close (maybe 200 metres), Basilica San Clemente (which has a fascinating piece of Roman housing in the basement), Trajans Markets, the Baths of Caracalla and much more. You can certainly quite comfortable do the Colosseum, the Forum and the Palatine Hill in one day and that would be a sensible group of things to see. If you don't have a Roma pass, you can get one ticket which covers the Colosseum, the Forum and the Palatine and it costs 12 euro each.5. Do bear in mind that both the Forum and the Palatine Hill are basically open air, so come prepared for the weather. And I don't think that there is anywhere to get food or drink, so you might want to pack a picnic. Toilet facilities are limited too. There is a museum on the Palatine Hill and there are toilet facilities there. It also takes a good few hours walking on sometimes uneven paths to see both the Palatine and the Forum. I don't think that most of either the Forum or the Palatine Hill is going to be very accessible to those with walking difficulties. If you have such difficulties you will need to look into access to these sites beforehand.6. You can get some great views of Rome from the hill - for example looking down into the Forum and from the other side of the hill, directly down on to the Circus Maximus, the great chariot racing circuit of Rome which is, to this day, the largest sporting venue ever constructed. The hill is also pleasantly covered in trees and it can be a wonderful place to stroll on a sunny day.7. The hill is not well sign-posted at all and is a rather confusing jumble of remains. Do bring a map and do a little reading beforehand to make sure that you see the main sights.8. The main sights on the hill are probably the Houses of Augustus and Livia. Augustus was the first emperor of Rome and Livia was his wife. Their houses are remarkably well-preserved although they tend to be shut somewhat randomly! The Palatine museum is also worth a look, as are the rambling jumble of palace remains which cover the whole site. There is also a tunnel which I believe linked two palaces belonging to Nero which I found quite interesting.9. I have not yet chosen to get either a guide or an audio-guide, preferring simply to wander at my own pace. One type of guide which I have found useful, and which you can buy widely in Rome, is a special type of guidebook which has modern-day photos of key sites together with transparent slides which you can overlay to see what the sites once looked like. This can be very useful. I have certainly seen these for the Forum, but am not sure if they cover the Palatine Hill in detail as well. You will see them advertised as many small newsagents, newspaper stands and small shops.
Amazing. The place is just amazing,the views over the Forum...fantastic..so much history.We used the Roma Pass 30euros and were able to avoid the line

Hire a tour. Do yourself a favor and get a guide. It's the only way to truly understand where you are standing. I didn't, so I ended up reading the few available signs and imagining what the ruins and buildings could've been. In any case, it's a great experience and a must-see after visiting the Colosseum. You do sense that you're walking where great men and women used to.

Pace yourself.. We chose to do this and the roman forum using an audio guide for 7 euros. Would chose a tour in the future. You have to follow a map and press the appropriate number when you reach a certain location. Unlike the vatican audio tour, there are no number markers to guide you. Waste of money. Pay more for a tour. It is a lot to take in, and after a couple of hours you can lose interest if there is no one helping to bring the ruins alive. Beautiful view from the top though.

Don't bother with audio guide!. I would definitely recommend the tour as opposed to audio guide. The audio guide tries to cover too much referring to ruins on your left and right etc, but not making it very clear what ruin you are looking at. We listened in on the tours, and they were a lot more informative and bought the ruins 'alive' with stories and pictures.
Another Must See in Rome. Amazing to see the seat of democracy. This attraction is surrounded by shops and other buildings. Rome is truly an amazing city!

Excellent, not to be missed. Truly an experience not to be missed. You can do Colosseum, Palatine Hill and the Roman Forum all in a day, but be warned, there is a lot of walking. It is all worth it ! Enjoy

Stunning. A lovely place to walk around in the sunshine. Lots to see and not too busy so can walk around freely without feeling squashed or rushed. Definitely worth going it alone rather then being rushed around by a tour guide.

Very interesting. Why pay for a tour when you can closely follow one and listen for free :D we caught snippets of information from different tour groups going around but had the freedom to explore the way we wanted. Lots to see and some amazing views. You can't tell just how much there is to see from the road. There is a fee to pay to get in but this also allows entry to the Colosseum. A lovely place to visit in the sunshine.

An unexpected highlight. It may have helped that we had a tour guide, but the Palatine Hill was really wonderful. When you know the context of what you're seeing, it is amazing. You get wonderful views of Rome too, and you will probably stumble across the convent that is still on the site. The ticket price is included in the Colosseum ticket, so no excuse, really! :)
Best bit of Rome. This is the Rome you come for; so much to see, so evocative and photogenic. Yes, it is full of tourists and you may have to queue; and don't expect photos without people!
Historic. We walked around the forum after visiting the Colosseum. It was very hot and there was little shade. Other than that, it was an excellent experience.

Underwhelming. While we enjoyed walking, there were a lot of places closed off and undergoing refurbishment. It wasn't easy to navigate, and we got lost a few times trying to follow signs. Regardless, it was nice to wander about. I'd recommend going in the house of Augustus, but be prepared for a line. The frescoes are worth the wait! Bring a water bottle and fill it up using the fountains. And grab an orange if you can!

Historic!. I will preface and say that I wish I had studied a little more before our visit OR had a guide. While we definitely enjoyed wandering, I didn't know as much about the history of what I was seeing. Remember that your colosseum ticket works for the forum as well!

How to see Rome from one place. If you wish to see Rome from one place, this is it. Palatine Hill oversees the Colosseum and the Forum as well as Circus Maximus, the Vatican and St Peters are in the distance across the Tiber but are clearly visible. If there is one place to visit to get the feeling of Ancient Rome then you have to go here.

Worth a wander. You can enter the hill as part of your ticket that lets you into the Colosseum and the Roman Forum.It's worth a wander, it's calm and on a nice day there are good views of Rome. It's still blighted by large areas taped and fenced off but with nobody working on them. I'd recommend going to the Forum first, then to the hill then walking down to the Colosseum taking in the views of it as you go.
Should not miss. History at your feet, this is a must do if you visit Rome. Hire a headset and budget a couple of hours for this visit. Its a stunning location and a step back into history.

Building site. An incredible place where you can walk amongst history, and metal fencing, and taped off areas and transit vans.This should be one of the best attractions in Rome, it isn't it's a bit of a mess.I think it may be that the Romans have, in this day and age, just got too much "stuff" and are overwhelmed by it. Areas are cordoned off but nobody was working in them. Flat bed Transit lorries were parked amongst the columns but nobody attended them. Miles and miles of fences and tarpaulins but protecting what?Very disappointing.

Book Tour Outside to save €€. Loved it, we had a fantastic guide! Born in New York to Italian parents, she was so enthusiastic about the history and culture!! We also saved time and money by booking a tour of the Forum and Colosseum together through a guide who was outside the Colosseum, they give a great rate and you beat the hour(s) of queueing outside as they can take guided groups straight in!! :)

Nice but not special compared to Forum. We visited the Palatine Hill and Roman Forum on the same day. We had trouble with the audioguide which I have explained in my Roman Forum Review and won't repeat here. The reason we wanted to see the Palatine Hill was because of the panoramic view that was advertised there. When we got there we were disappointed to find that the viewing spot is closed but there was no mention of that anywhere. Because so many areas were closed the map was very confusing and we couldn't find our way around. We obviously understand there's restoration work going on and that;s ok but someone should at least warn tourists where it is.It's nice to see how the Romans used to live but actually compared to the Forum the Palatine Hill is really not that special so I'd recommedn spending a couple of hours in the Roman Forum and just walking through the Palatine Hill .You get a ticket for all three attractions anyway (incl. Colosseum) so you might as well see it as it's good value for money,

A definite must- see but organisational problems. This is definitely a must- see, especially if you're interested in Ancient History. The ruins are amazing and you can see and discover so much of ancient Roman life here. We spent two hours here and it felt like not enough time to appreciate it all.A few comments: it doesn't make sense to visit without a proper guide or map or without reading up about it properly. You'll end up walking around, not knowing what's what, it's pointless. They don't give you a map unless you buy the audioguide.We had a big glitch with the audioguide: we bought it for both palatine hill and roman forum (7 Euro instead of 5) at the entrance and found we had to leave an id as deposit which was very impractical as we wanted to leave through the other entrance, closer to the colosseum. Never mind that. They gave us the audioguide and told us to walk to point number 1 which was about a 10 minute walk away from where we were. When we got there one of the audioguides wasn't working but we were close to another entrance so I went to exchange it (they had the same audioguides available) only to be told that they can't exchange it and I should go to the entrance I came through- 10 minute walk away! After arguing with them for a while and saying there is no way we are possibly walking back they agreed to exchange it but they made it very clear to me they were not happy about it. After that we walked around and it was great although the amount of information could be overwhelming at times. Gorgeous place though and could spend hours there but someone needs to talk to staff and make sure they know who the paying visitors are!

Spend a few days.... And you still wont get enough of this place
A civilization 2000 yrs old and very well preserved amidst all the efforts of different people trying to capitalise on its beauty. A lil sad that modern rome has eaten so much of old rome.....

Amazing area but you need a guide or map.. We did not allow enough time and without a guide or map we didn't know what we were looking at. It wasn't clear to us where to go or how to get more info. Some other reviews have good information we should have read first. However we could see how amazing these ruins were without the guidance.

Such historical places don't need advertizing. We were here in November 2010. The day was raining and in spite of being cold and wet we got a lot of pleasure from visiting it. I didn't even want to leave. The place is wonderful also for people who don't know history a lot. One can simply walk and feel this atmosphere

Must see. You cannot go to Roma and not see this grandeur of days gone by. Standing at the point where you can see the Temple and the Pillars at the same time we made a video of the before (Marquee in front of you) and then the now video. Looked amazing when we showed folks back home.

Amazing. there is nothing to dislike about the roman forum an amazing piece of history a well worth trip we booked a tour guide which was great as without one you would not understand anything that you are looking at

Plan ahead weatherwise. We think the Forum visit could've been fantastic but unfortunately it was a disaster. We bought our 2 day tix to Forum/Palatine/Colisseum at the Forum entrance on Via del Fori Imperiale. The weather: January 2013, 40-ish with heavy rain the whole 3 hours that we trekked through mud and puddles. The ticket agents at the entrance were not helpful and didn't even provide a basic map with our admission. There were no guided tours available. Using Rick Steve's and Fodor's guides were impossible in the downpour plus they are not very clear if you don't have a point of reference when you enter. The signage at the Forum is awful. Unless you really know what you are looking at, don't go without a personal guide. We don't know how good the audio guide is because we're not audio guide people. Other visitors wandered about aimlessly like us and we all had the same complaints: Not knowing what we were looking at. Re Palatine Museum - nothing memorable. The best thing about the Palatine Hill was the view of the Circus Maximus. We had the feeling in advance that the Palatine and the Forum were separate but they're not. The Palatine is a section of the Forum, just up a hill.

Get Lost!. You can get really lost here wandering around the ruins of the old gardens, palazzos and villas. A top tip is stout walking shoes as the cobbled streets and paths hurt your feet after a while. A lot of it is still being unearthed by the archeologists but there is still lots to see and do.Orange trees line the structured garden which is an idel vantage spot to take some awseome photos of the surrounding area.
Briiliant view. The view is amazing and the aquaduct is a prime example of mastercraft engineering. You can really imagine what it was like to live in those times

Feel the history. Take your time to explore to get a fascinating insight into the culture of ancient Rome. The site is larger than I anticipated so there wasn't time to see everything. It's also exposed to the elements so dress accordingly. There are many steps and uneven cobblestones which are hazardous on a wet day so a degree of care is necessary. There are toilets at the entrance gates. There's a wonderful panoramic view over the city from the terrace at the top of the hill.There are several entry and exit gates (some are exit only). I used the Roman Forum entrance and there was virtually no waiting time to buy tickets. Combined tickets are available, for 12 euros, for entry to the Forum, Palatine Hill and Colosseum. The Forum and Palatine Hill are part of the same site but you have to exit and re-enter to gain access to the Colosseum which is a completely separate site. There's a combined audio guide to the Forum and Palatine Hill - you have a choice of paying 5 euros if you intend to return it within 2 hours, or 7 euros if you return it within 3 hours. If you exceed the time limit you will have to pay an extra 5 euros for each additional hour when you return it. You have to leave your passport at the entry gate as security. This of course means that you have to return to the same gate to return the guide and retrieve your passport when you're ready to leave. As it's a large site this is somewhat inconvenient. The audio guide doesn't include the Colosseum - I believe you can buy a separate one at the Colosseum entrance if you so wish. Tickets only permit one entry to each site.I'm not convinced of the usefulness of the audio guide. There are plenty of information boards that you can read as you walk around, and having a time limit on the audio guide is very inconvenient. Being prepared by reading a guidebook beforehand is a good idea.

Use your imagination. The hill is in ruins but it's cool to use your imagination to think of how Rome's elite once lived and ran the empire. Very cool, just wish they had more signs and explanations there so you know what you're looking at. Before going, either plan to get a personal guide, or do your own research and bring it with you while you walk around. It's part of the pass that let's you get admission to the Colosseum, the Forum, and the Palatine Hill. Totally worth the money. It's not expensive and you get to enjoy the whole day. Bring water bottles because they have fountains with the city water which is safe to drink as it can get pretty hot in the sun all day. Wear comfy shoes! And definitely bring your camera.

Experience the Rome of the aristocrats.. I love the Palatine perhaps more than any other place in Rome. I feel instantly relaxed and at peace up there. It is where Romulus famously established the foundations of Rome after killing his brother Remus. The sense of history up there is overwhelming and intense and yet there is is a peacefulness at the top and a great view over the modern city of Rome. There is also an amazing view over the forum from the Farnese Gardens.It can be very hot and unforgiving in the high summer so best to visit in spring I think. Take a picnic and find somewhere to eat amongst the ruins and enjoy a leisurely day drinking deep from 2700 years of history. Visit the museum and absolutely try to go on a day when the Casa di Livia is open as this is stunning with amazing frescoes.I always start my day with a visit to the Coliseum, then the Palatine, the Forum and then a wander up to the Trevi Fountain in the twilight to round off the day. A long and tiring day, but amazing!

Botanical gardens and upper sections . We got there late and got a video guide, we ran around for about 2 hours with the video guide then managed to go back to the gate at 1530 and return the guide then go back inside and see the rest of the place. I think it must have been about 1630 when they kick everyone out. Must see the view from the orchard/botanical gardens and the Maximiluis Basilica.

Where the Roman Elite Lived. Although in ruins, just the thought of walking about where the most famous Romans of ancient times lived and strolled is awesome. Livia's (Augustus' wife) house and the hut where Romulus and Remus first founded Rome are here. The Farnese Gardens are also impressive.

imagine yourself being back in Roman history. get yourself time traveled back in ancient Rome ...Palatine Hill is part of the Colesseum and Roman Forum pass ticketenjoy and see buildings and landmarks from ancient rome....not much remains but there are some that are still standing and survived due to preservation of these ancient landmarkshere you will see space occupied by the Roman empire.... their building and their way of life...the hills hike is nice and enjoyable....and get to see city view of modern Romemust stop and enjoy history at your footsteps

Take it all in. It rained while we were here so we did not linger excessively long. However, its nice for just a browse. Like some other persons said some form of guide whether its audio or personal tour guide would be helpful.

Nice to browse. I agree with the other travellers that you realy need to do your research on this beforehand because there is not a lot of signage identifying what you are seeing. Perhaps one of the guided tours may be useful. However, it was great to walk around. One thing I would like to know is how do the guys selling umbrellas get in? There was a sign at the entrance saying no selling or soliciting. Yet as soon as the rain started to fall, out runs this man out of what seemed like no where to sell us and the other tourists umbrellas or ponchos...I found this whole thing rather hilarious because all during our trip we were marveling at how these guys just seems to be everywhere trying to sell you something or the other but whenever it rains the other nit nats they have seem to disappear and they have dozens of umbrellas on sale.

Amazing. Beware of the queues! Better take a Roma Pass if you're visiting the city for a couple of days and you can skip the queues. The Aventine Hill, the center of the Roman Empire, is absolutely amazing, beautiful to see such structures and to see how the emperors and nobility of Rome lived in the old days. Much if not all is now ruins but it still gives you a pretty good idea of how they used to live there. And from the Palatine Hill you can walk straightly to the ancient Forum, the political center of the city.In my opinion this is a better visit than the Colosseum.

Tranquil gardens to avoid the crowds. You can easily spend a whole day here at your leisure, walking the whole garden.Prebook your ticket online, or enter on Via di San Gregorio for a relatively shorter queue. Definitely get the audio guide, so you can wander around at your own pace and not be forced on a tour guide's schedule.Climb the hill to take some magnificent photos of the Arch of Constantine and the Colosseum.There are plenty of historically significant ruins, little nooks and crannies for you to discover. There's even a museum in these grounds, if you aren't museumed out already.Definitely a highlight of our trip in Rome.

Tour guide not audio guide to maximise the experience. We visited Palatine Hill & the Forum the day after with our Colosseum ticket. We had an awesome tour at the Colosseum and decided to get an audio guide for the Paltine Hill & Forum but it was possibly the worst audio guide we've had on our Europe trip. (I admit I had high expectations of this part of Rome & wish to have learnt more.) My recommendation is to just read the signage posted at various locations or get a tour guide if you really want to get a lot from it. A must see! It's incredible!

A Pleasant Surprise. The Palatine Hill was much more extensive than I had anticipated. We enjoyed the opportunity to walk through and experience what must have been the heart of ancient Rome. We had purchased the ticket the day before so didn't want to stand in line again to get an audio guide. It would've been helpful to have been able to rent them at a separate location and not at the ticket line because I believe we would've benefited from hearing more about both the Palatine and Roman Forum, which we visited immediately afterwards.
Fantastico. It takes you back to Roman days of old with so much to see and to enjoy. The views of Rome are good from here and loads of picture opportunities

Palatine Hill. I visited the Palatine Hill with family in April. We did not take a guided tour and chose to visit by ourselves. As I had been to the Palatine Hill on a previous holiday and re-read a lot of information before this visit, I did not feel that I missed out by not having a guide. Indeed it allowed the freedom to sightsee at your own pace and you can easily find your way around with a good guidebook that includes a map and some information about the Palatine Hill so you know what you are seeing. You can take photographs everywhere and make sure to take a hat / bottle of water in hot weather as there is not much shade. Do not miss the fantastic view over the Roman Forum from the gardens. A little tip ... if you visit during Culture Week (as we did) the entry is free. A must see in Rome!
Best visit in Rome. This really is a fascinating place and well worth a good half or full days visit, many cares and bars around to watch the world go by, really great time.

Vast history. The hole area around the Palatine, Aventine Hills, Roman Forum, Colosseum is awash with epic history. Well worth getting a guided tour as there aren't many signs so it's hard to get an appreciation of what everything is otherwise. Views from the top of the hill are magnificent.

History comes alive. We toured this site with "Through Eternity" tour group. You can tour this solo or you can get the self audio-guide; due to the enormity of the site I would recommend a tour group or at the least the audio-guide. It really was amazing to walk down the same cobbled streets that the ancient romans walked down or held their triumphs. There are ruins of ancient buildings EVERYWHERE, and our guide filled our minds with a ton of information. We saw ancient temples, churches, the home of the celestial virgins etc...Included in the fee is access to Palatine Hill, which includes the home of Emperor Augustus, Nero's Palace and great views; ending at the Colosseum. The Forum and Palatine Hill are a must do for any person interested in Roman History.
important to visit. The atmosphere is amazing. a must if you visit rome. you must be there with a guided tour. if not you will not understand the importance of this place. one of the highlights !!

Dont forget the map!. If u're planning to come here, please dont forget to take the map because it's quite big and u might probably go in a circle, they dont hve the map at the entrance, so u hve to take it from the colosseo

Fascinating. A terrific site to see the history, art and architecture of the early Roman Empire. Great for archeology and history buffs! If possible, take the time to do the lower level and/or upper level tours. We visited in the morning and the crowd was small. In the afternoon we went to the Coliseum which was much less crowded than when we passed in the morning on the way to the Roman Forum.

Fantastic way to learn about ancient Roman. I visited Palatine Hill or the Ruins in Dec 2012 and spent more than four hours walking and visiting every corner. I prefer this site compared to the Colosseum. It is a huge area and will blow your mind in terms of the architectural marvel that the Romans were able to do more than 2000 years ago. It also provides fantastic location to take the Colosseum photos as well as the view of Rome city because it is on a hill. So pro:1) huge area that has well preserved buildings2) provides fantastic location to take photos of the Colosseum as well as Rome city3) has several small museums that provides more context4) the ticket for this site also covers entrance fee for the ColosseumIf there is one thing that I regret was not renting the audio guide. This will provide me with more context and better understanding. All in all, one of a must see if you are in Rome.

interesting sight. this is a interesting place to visit. entrance is free if you already paid to see the Colosseum. the architecture is amazing. there is still much detail in the marble carvings, which is amazing considering they are exposed to the elements. its pretty much a set path through the forum, so you wont miss anything as long as you pay attention. the crowed is much smaller compared to other sights in rome. and there are plenty of natural fountains to refresh yourself on hot days. this is not an easy attraction for those who are handicapped or have difficulty walking, it is hilly and mostly dirt paths.

Watch Out for Romulus. Topped with the iconic umbrella trees, and a tranquil respite from the chaos of Rome, Palatine Hill is an interesting place to visit. If for no other reason than to get a great view of the nearby ancient sites, and tickets to the Colosseum without the queues.We visited as part of a 3 hour Carrani walking tour through ancient Rome, that included the Arch of Constantine, the Roman Forum and the Colosseum. Unfortunately, we’d been on another gruelling walking tour that morning, and we were exhausted for our march up the Hill. Our guide was full of heaps of information about the site, including the palaces. But regretably it went in one ear and out the other. However, what did remain was that according to legend, Palatine Hill was the place where the she-wolf first found Romulus and Remus in a cave and raised them as her own. Romulus then went on to kill his brother and found the city of Rome there. If nothing else, it makes for a good story.The line for admission is very reasonable, and as the tickets purchased there also get you into the Colosseum, it’s a great way to skip the queue at the latter. And there’s also the odd stall out the front, where you can buy an overpriced snack or a cold drink.It is worth a visit. But just make sure you’ve got the enthusiasm for it.

Continuation of Colosseum visit. Just like the colosseum, a visit here will send the imigination spinning. How many people have stood in this spot discussing politics or religion or haggling over the price of a pigeon. How many grand parades passed through the arches and gates? How many stories could these stones tell, if only they could speak? Wow, just wow... A large place, with lots of walking... Somewhere stroller friendly, but a bit bumpy in places (That's what you get with 1,000 year old coblestone streets.) It's a big place, so plan to spend some time walking around, taking it all in.

A testament that weather and time cannot be beaten. This is an amazing attraction and one absolutely not to be missed. It is very interesting, especially if you have even a rudimentary knowledge of Roman history and are familiar with just how important Ancient Rome was to our current civilisation and institutions. It is also levelling to see that nothing and nobody can stand the forces of time ad weather. A crumbling once great city is testament to this. It makes to feel your insignificance but equally makes you jubilant about human kinds ability to grow and develop. Wear good comfortable shoes, take a good camera and be ready for a few solid hours of exploring.......and deep thinking if you are so inclined.

A Spot to Relax in Amongst a Busy City. Palatine Hill was an absolutely gorgeous spot, and proved a good place to spend a some what more relaxing couple of hours after some time in Rome city. This place was no where near as busy and hectic as most other attractions, with amazing history and great views over Rome. Be sure to take a camera and a jacket/warm hat as even on warm days it can get a little chilly! The weather was lovely the day we went and yet the big puddles in the shade were frozen. We used our Roma pass to visit here and the Colosseum.

Tranquil a welcome break.. We got into the Roman forum and Palatine Hills with our Colosseum ticket, not many people seem to take advantage of this as there were not many people here at all.It was a welcome break far from the madding crowd, lovely green open space to wander round, with views out to the Colosseum and the mountains beyond Rome. Parakeets flew over head, and chirped nosily and pigeons munched on fallen olives from the fragrant olive trees, sounds like a slice of heaven!Loved just sitting here, lovely space and smells, probably one of my favourite spots in all of Rome.Don't go into the loo's as you get in they are beyond gross, but the ones half way round the Forum are lovely, hot water and everything!

It's huge. We spent about 2 hours exploring this area. We had not realised how big the actual area was. We had a map listing each particular spot about 40 or so from memory, but declined on the audio guide as the one for the Colosseum was crap. Entrance was included in our ticket when we purchased our ticket for Colosseum. We entered after the Roman Forum and noticed that the number of visitors quickly drizzled out. I don't think many tour groups include much of this area into their tours. It is easy to do by yourself and worth the time if you can afford it.

It was a amazing view but a guide wouls be best. This place was a really amazing site but the downside of it there arent any signs telling you the history of the place or what each building or ruins were. I had to keep looking at my wikapedia to check what everything was. If you are going here and want to know the history then i would look into getting a guide, but if you are just wanting to site see then dont get a guide , and make sure you get a guide that you can understand a lot of the guides i heard around us i couldnt understand and they were speaking english.

A must!. Like stepping back in time. These ruins date back in time around the 7th Century and was the hub of economic and commerical activities. A good tip I can offer is to buy a book called Rome Past and present, which is sold by street vendors near by. This book will give you images of what the ruins looked like back in the 7th century. A must when you visit Rome.

Rome's birthplace. The construction sites keep moving around blocking off routes which makes it frustrating to walk the grounds.But be sure to visit Palatine Hill, museum and newly excavated areas. Especially the good frescoes in Augustus house even tho there will be lines to get in. The number of W.C.s have increased! Refill your water bottle at the Forum's public fountains. FascinatingBe aware that weekend student demonstrations seem to start near Forum and caused a large police presence and nearby streets to be block to traffic--including public transportation.

Needs to improve the tourist support. The place is really a treasure that everybody in Rome should see. But there is not enough people or signs to help the tourists, so a lot can be missed. My biggest complain is about the audio guide directions. The lack os signs related to the audioguide made it almost useless. How difficult is to put a sign saying the correspondent number in each construction or sign the right order to walk using the audioguide? Well, better go there with a real guide!

wonderful views... Its splendid views on ancient and nowadays Rome are fascinating.
A must-see while in Rome.
Tickets to the Colisseum include it + Forum (when booking ask for the price combined since it's cheaper)

Amazing views and spot. Emperor Domitian certainly appreciated "location, location, location" long before telly estate agents............... Well worth a visit both for the views and the architectural scale of the palace as well as an elevated view of the Forum. There are a few steps to get there.

Unmissable. Lots of vey impressive buildings/ruins etc. Hadn't realised Rome/Italy has no overarching authority for managing the sights (unlike, for instance Egypt) hence the VG rating. Italy/Rome needs to get that sorted so those who are not guided have some information to help.

Whaow. Just incredible to discover so many roman history in such a little place... you really feel out-of your century walking around, imaging life during Roman time.... just walk around and lost yourself in such beautiful historic landscape, it's magic.....
A lot of walking. Beautiful views of Rome, it overlooks the Forum. Several Ceasars lived there and even Musselini but a summer home at the Pallantine

More history than the mind can cope with. Brilliant place to visit, but very hot and crowded. So much history in such a small space. Make sure you see the spot where Julius Caesar was murdered, and where he was cremated.
Steeped in history. Go on a hot day and take lots of water. Most tourists don't go there in the heat, so you have a quiet visit through history in the centre of Rome.

I think you need a guide or guide book.. I think you need a guide or a guide book to put it into perspective. Otherwise you are looking at ruins without an understanding of what you might be looking at. It costs 12 Euros per person but that also includes entrance to palantine hill and the coliseum right next door. We walked through it rather fast but you could probably spend a couple hours here.

Walking in history. This is so amazing, walking in ancient Rome. The old buildings and relics, this is probably one of my favorite spots in the World. You can see the ruins of some of the most amazing buildings of the ancient times. You can feel history all around you, with every step that you take.

Disappointing. We were somewhat disappointed that so much of the museum was barricaded with repairs and and restorations. We visited in November and paths were blocked and the museum had rooms closed. Signage was very poor and we had difficulty even finding the exit. Paths were very rough.

Give yourself a lot of time!. You can spend the better part of a day wandering the sites. If you purchase your tickets from the Colosseum which is just down the street), it includes the forum entrance. Give yourself plenty of time to visit and enjoy

Must see attraction; only with a guide. For visits to this attraction do not go without a guide. It is very poorly marked where to go and it took us half an hour to find the entrance. Guides who work there and at the Coliseum are not exactly the kindest when asking for directions. And with very many people who come to visit this real piece of history, you will hardly enjoy without expert gude.

Looked very cool, but..... I will reiterate what others have said on here.....get a tour guide for this area. If you go without an audio guide or tour guide, it could be disappointing. The structures are grand and impressive, but without knowing what you're looking at will make it all a bit dull. I had a guide book and it still wasn't as interesting as one of the tour guides that we passed along the way. If you have the combi ticket or Roma Pass, you get to pass up the ticket line on the left and go to the right side to scan your ticket and go on through.

Bring a guidebook to make the most of it. Seeing these ancient ruins is a must-do in Rome. It is a good idea to book tickets online in advance as the queues can be quite long (you can get a ticket which includes the Forum, Palatine Hill & the Colosseum). We rented the audioguide which was almost useful but a lot of the walkways were under renovation or had been moved so the guide did not match the walking path. Without a useful guide, it is not possible to fully appreciate the ruins.

get the audioguide or take a guidebook. This was a bit of a disappointment. It was a huge and sprawling and I am sure it would have been very interesting if I had a clue what it was about, but there was little information to tell you what you were looking at. As a site to just wonder around cluelessly it is impressive and there is a lot to look at, but it could have been so much more interesting if I knew what was around me and why. I think that it would be well worth investing in an audioguide when you visit here, as you will get much more out of the site, if I returned I would definitely do this. To save joining the giant queue at the Colosseum buy your ticket for the 3 sites (Colosseum, Roman forum, Palatine hill) here.
Great views great history. If you like roman history it is amazing to think of the famous romans that probably walked on the same ground as you are on when you visit this place.

Majestic ruins. Ok its in ruins but still the sheer massive bulk of the structures that remain is fairly impressive - and there are lovely views various viewpoints on the hill over much of Rome - a lovely place for a leisurely stroll amongst the Umbrella Pines. There is a small museum but not much worth seeing inside.

An oasis from the hustle and bustle of Rome. This is a beautiful oasis away from the hustle and bustle of Rome. The ruins are set mainly in lovely gardens - the birds flock to the trees above you and the views over the city are perfect. The ruins really give you a feel for how the city must have looked all those years ago. Although, I can't wait for holo technology to catch up to the demand for experiencing the area in all its glory. You can get a two day combination ticket to visit this area as well as the Coloseum, which saves money and is well worth doing. Rome is a magnificent city, but it's not for the naive - be wary of the many characters who will try and rip you off. But here on the Palatine Hill, you can truly experience the Eternal City.

Could be interesting. We didn't have a book or guide and fairly little time to explore so I'm sure one can get more from this if they put in the effort. There is a small museum which presents a different aspect of the Roman Empire from the militaristic side usually focussed on in books/tv, which was quite interesting. The ruins themselves are reasonably impressive but there is a distinct lack of information provided.
only with guided tour. there are no writen signs anywhere... If you don't have guide book, ther no reasen to go.My suggest take guided tour, or don't go

Not to miss. The large majority of my reviews for Rome are four and five stars and thats for one simple reason, Rome IS amazing. Its not every day, you get to walk around and be able to see and touch architecture thats over 1000 years old. It was rather quiet here, this could be due to the vast landscape and how easy it is to spread out, whilst I didn't get a guided tour in hindsight I would recommend one, its a shame that I didn't get to completely understand the history behind the ruins. But, I had a fantastic time regardless of not having a tour. I would recommend having plenty of water on you, as it was extremely hot and got extremely thirsty very quickly. This isn't one to miss.

Get a Guided Tour or you will miss out on this experience. Beautiful, not a lot of tourists, and so much history to see. You really need a guided tour however or you will miss out on what you are looking at all together. It is really "ruins" and you need an imagination to see what you are looking at. An amazing piece of land, beautiful gardens, and great views on the city....I see why emperors from the beginning of Rome to Mussolini all built homes on this hill. It is quite grand and a nice break from the bustling city around you. Plus it has shade and fresh air around you. Worth the walk through the grounds but be prepared to spend at least 2 hours there if you want to see everything it has to offer.
So much history. As you walk through these ruins you have to us your imagination to transport you back in time to a much different place. Everywhere you turn there are hidden jems

Worth it.. We toured this site right after the Colosseum. We scanned the same printed tickets and walked right in. We used our Rick Steve's audio guide we had downloaded (free) to our phones. We were able to slow down or hurry up, depending on crowds and energy levels.

GREAT EXPERIENCE. My reviews on the Roman attractions might all sound the same, all 5 stars and all worth seeing. What else can I say? You get to walk around and see where western civilization began and see how the Romans 2,000 years ago shaped our society today. Do a guided tour if you go to the Hill, you will get so much more out of it. We did and were there for about 90 minutes and learned so much. we loved it.

Ancient ruins of a marvelous city. First off, the line is long so do yourself a favor and GET THE ROMA PASS! You can skip the line and get in for free. That pass is worth every penny. Seriously.There are beautiful examples of what ancient Rome used to be here. You can walk freely on the grounds and even see current excavations.There is little or no signage in the park, so you really don't know what you're looking at unless you hire one of the guides hanging out near the entrance. The immensity and beauty of the structures back then (what is left of them) is amazing and is worth the visit.

A glimse of the greate republic and empire. Always imposing. Now there are added two exebitions critical of historic misrepresentations. Critical the church stress on martyrdom and the missing focus on roman humanism and statecraft. And of the corresponding fascist misuse of roman policy and symbols. Very good! Take your time!
Very nice. Quite interesting walk. You can feel the ancient history here. Be sure to have comfortable shoes and a lot of water. The entrance is free with Roma pass

Very cool. We only decided to do the Palatine Hill as it was close to the Colosseum and you could get a combo ticket. We were told the queues were less if you did the Palatine first. There was no queue at all. However, we were very impressed by what we saw. It was an amazing site and much much larger than I thought it would be. Its worthwhile to take your time and just go through the ruins and see the sights. It is a very cool place. Definitely worth a visit!

The oldest ruins in Rome. The Palatine Hill is known as the place where Romulus and Remus founded Rome. The place is filled with old ruins and the entrance is combined with Collosseum and Roman Forum (12 Euros).
very interesting. Quite interesting to visit the roman forum, we had a great guide, I think the best way to see the ruins is with a guide, otherwise you would'nt really get a lot out of going here.

More to see in Rome than this. Unless you are part of a tour group, not a very exciting site to visit. It is very big, and you can do a lot of walking. And if you do not know what you are looking at then you can waste an hour or hours here.
big but very interesting. you need a gide or an audio guide to know what your looking at so get there about an hour and a half before it closes !

Very pleasant afternoon.. Like all of the places I have been in Rome it can be somewhat disorganise. We have a good guide book so we knew where we were going. Even with this however I found the wall difficult because they random closed walkways were closed. It is beautiful and interesting and considering you have to get a ticket if you go to the coliseum it is really worth a look. Just to advise, however, if you are coming to Rome, or really any city in Europe, perhaps purchase a guide before you get here. Some have complained that there is not enough information but I feel, in Britain, we are a bit spoilt and the lack of info is standard in most continental cities. Either that it hire a guide, which is pricey. The choice is yours spend £5 on a book or £30 on a guide it do neither and then moan.

What the Barbarians Didn't Destroy . . .. "What the barbarians didn't destroy, the Barberini did." It's a shame. There's not much left of this heart of ancient Rome, and what is left is not well presented or explained. Little is restored, but perhaps it shouldn't be. But there is so much! The site is huge, and the forum is so historically significant, it is a must see. The Palatine Hill is still somewhat intact; the museum and other structures on top are interesting, and the views are great. Your ticket will be good for two days and includes entrance to the Colosseum.

Where Rome began. We were pleasantly surprised by the tour of Palatine Hill. This was part of our group tour ticket to the Colosseum, and we had an excellent guide who made the area come to life. This is where Rome began, and I am embarrassed to say I was not familiar with the history of the area before the tour. There are interesting architectural landmarks, an impressive stadium, homes, gardens and views of the forum. Well worth seeing if you have the time.

Interesting visit.. This is a very interesting attraction, a little confusing at times, particularly with the audio guide, some things are not clearly marked. Overall we really enjoyed it , it took us around four hours to complete it, wish we had remembered to take in a drink as there is nowhere inside to get one. It's quite tiring so be prepared! Make sure you get the joint ticket for the coliseum as there was virtually no wait at the palatine entrance.

Just as I expected. This is something only for people who like ruins and the history behind it.I loved it but it got exhausting after an hour of walking around in the sandy road under the heat of the sun. So I suggest bringing an umbrella or so to prect yourself from the sun, or go there on a not so sunny day.

Nice stroll through history. There was not much in the way of crowds here which was nice. there is a lot of walking but i enjoyed it very much. there are great views and some worth while ruins to see Definately worht checking out

Tons of history. History is all around you. I downloaded Rick Steves audoi tour as i travel alone and it was great. if you dont have this down loaded i would suggest a tour or a good guide book to learn about it. I carried a bottle of water becuase it was so hot but dont throw away your bottle because they have fountains where you can refill your water bottle. dont forget to check out Julius ceasars spot where he was cremated. people still bring flowers to this spot.

Magnificent. Go with a guide and let them bring this site to life for you. I have read much about Rome over the years but this visit really brought the city to life for me - the enormity of the buildings and the narrowness of the streets.

I could have stayed all day. Fascinating place, so much to look at, so much to learn! The history of the world is here - The bronze doors of the Temple of Romulus are beautiful - and they are locked with their original 1700 year old key! There's a lovely little glass museum there too.
The center of ancient Rome. There's no shortage of things to see here, and the chance to feel the ebb and flow of history. This is highly recommended for republic/empire buffs.

The summit experience of visiting Rome. I loved this more than anything else in Italy, because it's one of the few as-is reminders of the Days of the Imperium. To imagine what transpired here is to be diminished by history, and how influential this city was to world history.

A fascinating journey back in time.. You have to have time to make the most of a visit to Palatine Hill. It covers a large area, lovely to do in October - probably too hot to do in the summer. But on a pleasantly warm October day it makes for a very interesting meander through time. As with a lot of Italian Historical Monuments they could do with more signage mroe reasonably priced guides.

Living History!. It is so awesome to see and be able to step where the early Romans once were. This was one of our favorite sites in Rome. I highly recommend a guided tour via What a Life tours...ask for Thomas! We felt like we were seeing the Forum with a friend. He opened our eyes to early Roman life and made the experience more enjoyable. We saw the Coleseum as well which is equally awesome! Do not miss this historical adventure while in Rome!!

Ancient Rome. I'd never heard of Palatine Hill before reaching Rome. Possibly would have missed it completely if it wasn't included in our entrance ticket for the Coliseum and Roman Forum. We'd just come from the Coliseum, and, not knowing what to expect, we thought we would give it a few minutes before heading to the main event: the forum.Well; expect the unexpected. This place just blew us away completely. It's a big, sprawling complex of ruins in very good condition that just seems to go on and on. There are surprises around every corner: like the sunken arena set between the two ancient villas. And a sunken garden behind one old residence. I was amazed at just how tall, and deep, these structures were. And I overheard a local guide explaining to his group that the building were twice as high when built than than are now. The early Romans were certainly not scared of heights.We ended up spending almost 3 hours here. We'd decide to just go so far, but then a new sight would draw us in further and further into the ruins. There were plenty of areas that were fenced off and just a jumble of old building stones, making you realize just how vast this place must have been in its prime. The parts that were excavated and accessible, from towering ruins to underground roads, held our interest for hours, and it was only reluctantly that we turned back to allow us sufficient (albeit shorter) time to explore the forum.I would rate this place above both the Coliseum and the old forum, and you don't have the crowds to contend with. Later we visited what's left of Circus Maximus, and from there you get a fantastic view of the Palatine Hill ruins.

Great ancient Roman site. Just next door to the Colosseum this was a fascinating place to relive ancient Roman history. We only used a guide book to explore. See the spot where Julius Caesar was cremated. People still leave flowers there. You can really get a feel from Roman life at this place. If you are a fan of ruins don't miss this but be prepared to walk a lot. The water fountains have wonderful cold water you can refill your bottles with. Also where sturdy shoes to navigate the old pathways where Caesar walked.

Amazing "It's lying all over the ground". To quote an old Monty Python line was so accurate of what we saw in the Forum. Yes there is so much history that is being preserved as we toured but there is so many other pieces of ruins lying all over the ground. Our guide told us to come back in 5 years & it will still look the same, there is no rush in restoration. But well worth the trip
Palentine Hill. There is a lot to see, so be prepared to walk and take water. A breathtaking view on the other side. So much history - just incredible.
Such history!. To stand where the roman senate stood - incredible! It is quite a walk - but worth it! It is amazing to think of the history around it!
Wow. I am a history buff and this place was so nostalgic for me, we got a guided tour package (included the Coloseum) from Walks of Italy and it was awesome!

Age of Empires. Amazing and much bigger than I expected! A little confusing to navigate and we struggled to find the exit haha. Remnants of buildings lie scattered on the ground and you look up to see a 21st century Rome passing you by - shows how far we've come with technology and architecture, I highly recommend visiting this forum.

So Much History!. A must see on your 1st visit to Rome. We did the Forum after the Colesseum and Palantine Hill. Wear good walking shoes, water and next time I'd bring a hand fan. There is very little shade and it can get quite warm. Our Roma passes allowed us to get into these 3 attractions. We had our guide book but would recommend getting a guided tour next time.

Another must see. Palatine Hill was such an awe inspiring place. The ruins were amazing and the views couldn't be beat. We strolled the grounds for a couple of hours - there was that much to see. Wear good walking shoes and be sure to bring your camera.
Excellent. This is a very impressive sight, but it is not easy to imagine the look of the buildings in former years. It is very helpful to buy the guide with the overlay-pictures.

AMAZING HISTORY. 2nd visit now and there is always something else to discover. It brings to life all those films we have all watched. Continue upto Augustus forum and look into Augustus house - opens at 11am. Amazing frescoes - considering they are almost 2050 years old the colours are still strong. They are still digging and still finding lost treasures. By a flip book that shows you how it looks now and flip over and how it looked then. Buy it from a bookshop its cheaper
:). This was just as amazing as the colosseum. Beautiful amazing grounds its so hard to get anyone to realise just how beautiful Rome is unless you go see it yourselves. Another must visit
Nice to see. A must-see when visiting rome. Enter by palatine hill, which is a nice start, especially the views! The tickets you buy are also valid for the colloseum(and the lines shorter).
Tour Guide Necessary!. This is an amazing place especially if you're just there to take photos but you do need a guide to understand what the ruins are all about.

Use your imagination. Visualizing what the forum was and looked like and what went on there and for how long and how long ago - wow. Approcahing it by climbing the long steps next to the Victor Emmanuel monument you suddenly are right there, overlooking it. I would love to be able to wander there and just touch the ruins. Old Rome must have been amazing. then think of the even older places to visit.....

Hill of a view. Some of the best views of Rome and some seriously awe-inspiring monuments can be seen from here amongst the tall tropical trees including the famed Colloseum in the distance. A lot of time can be spent walking through the vast area. Have good shoes on for this visit & a devent camera with you!

amazing trip back in time. Always crowded but as it's open air there's still plenty of space. I'd recommend a guided tour or else reading up plenty before you visit so you get the most value out of it.Buying a Roma pass ticket gets you the best value access combined with Palatine Hill and Colosseum.

Stunning, impressive, make sure you have a guide. I totally recommend you visiting the Palatine Hill. Most people seem to visit the Colosseum and the Forum but don't venture up to the Palatine Hill which is a shame.It is much quieter as a result but for me it is the more impressive part of the ancient ruins.
