It is the part which gives you a feel for the huge magnificence and staggering scale of the Roman civilisation.The Palatine is included in a single integrated ticket with the Colosseum and he Forum and altogether you can spend 4-5 hours exploring the area.You need a guide - but we didn't use an audioguide or a tour guide - we don't like those, they take you where they want and you can only spend the time at each spot that they want you to spend. Instead we got a guide book that had the information and the maps and then spent the day exploring on our own.On the Palatine Hill you get to explore the ruins of several emperors' palaces, get great views out of the forum, the city and the Circus Maximus and enjoy a lovely walk through the gardens and ruins.Don't miss this.

THE must-see amazing experience of Rome. This is amazing. The biggest must-see of Rome.The best thing to do is a full day (and a long day) with the Colosseum, the forum and the palatine hill all in one go. You get a single combined ticket and then you spend a whole day exploring the ancient capital of the Roman Empire. Getting to understand, be amazed and stunned by the mighty civilisation that they were.This is walking through history - and we spent 4-5 hours exploring the whole site.You need a guide - but we didn't use an audioguide or a tour guide - we don't like those, they take you where they want and you can only spend the time at each spot that they want you to spend. Instead we got a guide book that had the information and the maps and then spent the day exploring on our own.The forum itself is the ruins of the main buildings of the Roman Forum - temples, baths, palaces, etc all laid out for you to explore.But don't stick to the Forum (in the valley) - to really get a feel for ancient Rome you have to go up to the Palatine Hill as well. Its much quieter on the Palatine Hill indicating that most people (and most tour guides) don't venture up the hill. And that's their loss.On the Palatine Hill you really get to explore the ruins of the Emperor's Palace and understand the scale of the civilisation and building exploits. Don't miss it.

Awesome. Heaven for history buffs. Walk in the very streets and roads where Romans walked 2 millinea ago. Those Romans had strong legs and stamina to walk in these hilly cobblestone (make sure you have comfortable shoes). You can spend days exploring these well preserved areas and still not see everything.

Palatine hills and forum. Truly beautiful it's a must see. If buying ticket for collegium then keep ticket as it gets you entry to palatine hill and saves queuing . Also vie from hill of Colleseum is incredible.
Nice ramble on a sunny day. A lovely place to ramble and explore on a sunny day but be prepared that it is not very well labelled, so make sure to have your guidebook with you!
Nice but take a guide!. The audioguide and map are not at all clear! Maybe with the videoguide would have been better, or with a conventional tour. Otherwise you miss much of the stuff.

Very Impressive. We visited Palatine hill as part of the Forum/colosseum tour and enjoyed the site and the views. A shame that the area that overlooks Circus Maximus is closed.Worth looking around and taking some time over the site to imagine what it once was. Tour guide was helpful in understanding what was going on when the Palace was built.

History. We saw the Roman Forum after the Colosseum. Entry into the Forum and Palatine Hill is included with the Roma Pass as part of admission with the Colosseum. We did not get an audio guide but we sure were glad that we had Rick Steves' book. We spent hours here.

Walk where the Romans Walked. It is incredible to see the ruins and walk through the forum and palatine hill. It is also nice that your tickets for here are also for the colosseum. So to avoid the long lines at the colosseum you can come here first and get the ticket for both. There are so many great places for pictures, plan on bringing an extra memory card.
great. was nice looking around the ruins and soaked up the atmosphere that rome had to offer we got this included in the coloseaum tickets so i was almost free

Try to imagine yourself in ancient Rome. There is so much history here you will probably miss half of it. The aesthetics are incredible too. Photo opportunity at every step. There is a little temple on the right where they screen videos of Rome in it's prime from various movies, worth a brief look.

Amazing but overwhelming. Another "must see" but a lot of walking if you are seeing the Forum and Colosseum, also. The audio guide for this was not at all marked out, so it took a lot of map-searching ( and guessing) to match the audio with the locations....be sue to have water and good shoes....there is so much to see that it might be better in a couple visits. The audio guide had interesting info...just a bit frustrating

Impressive to say the least. We are history buffs. This is the main place to visit if you are similarly inclined. We especially liked just walking on the sidewalks and looking down at the recent excavations. Ancient Rome is still being "unveiled."

A lovely walk, beautiful views!. One of the most ancient areas of the city. Just the place if you'd like to 'get out of the city' for a while without actually leaving. You can watch the hustle and bustle all around you from the hills. :) I highly recommend purchasing your tickets at Palantine Hill - not nearly as crowded as the lines at the offices around the Colosseum and you can use your ticket for entry to both.

Beautiful, but confusing. This is a lovely site to visit, but don't count on being able to figure out what you're seeing! There are some informational signs, but if you are bound and determined to know each and every historical detail about every ruin - good luck. The Rick Steeves Rome guidebook gives the illusion that you can follow his tour, but here's the news: it's not possible. Don't even bother try to get a view of the Circus Massimus from here - it's blocked off, and even if you could see it - it's just a grassy, gravel field. MUCH better is the view of the Palatine structures from the Circus Massimus if you are walking in that direction anyway (near Santa Maria in Cosmedin, for example). From the view point on the far side of the Circus Massimus, you can really appreciate just how huge the structures on the Palatine really are, something that is elusive when you are walking among the ruins. When visiting the Palatine, I'd suggest just wandering around, getting the overall picture from the (few) informational signs and your guidbook, but enjoy the atmosphere, the views, and gardens.

very good. quite a large area to cover and look at, all ruins but very nice. We went via the Paletino area which takes you up a large hill around some lovely ruins etc and then on to the forum view point and then down to the forum itself.

Interesting history. Got in using the Roma pass as the 1st sight, so we didn't need to wait in the long queue. Visited in early September and the weather was hot hot hot. You won't get shady areas in the Forum so bring an umbrella/cap and your sunglasses. Wear sun block too. Bring lots of water too. A drinking fountain available near the restroom near the exit. Audio guide is dry and boring, but gave very detailed explanations. Get a good guide if you can and wear comfortable walking shoes. There's a lot of walking involved.

Rating by my visit. I am sure if I had used a Rick Steeves audioguide for this I would have appreciated both Palatine Hill and the forum much more than I did. I had read before going that if I didn't take a tour or have the explanations I would feel a bit loss in this maze of historical relics. This is exactly what happened. Thankfully my husband had read up a bit and knew some key points, but there are no explanations for the tourists at all. No signs or indications of what we are looking at. Someone should definitly remedy this situation considering the amount of people who visit each day.

use a guide. well worth booking tickets in advance on the web, locally guides are available as you enter, well worth using there services.Can get very hot so take water and try to go early.Allow a couple of hours at least.
History. You must wear comfortable shoes and avoid Summer time or simply a hot day. Take water and a camera and look anything around. Ancient history infront of your eyes.

Ancient place - one of the few preserved in the site. It was raining and the place was under construction of some kind. But we could have noticed its age and architecture from outside. One of the few structures left standing from early age. Don't miss.

Jam packed with history. Take a guided tour of Palatine Hill if you can. Even with the best guide book, you may get lost as it is vast. Skip the audio guide- although detailed, it is very dry and the sights in Palatine hill aren't marked, making it hard to figure it out. You also need to leave your passport if you rent an audio guide. This could be a bother if you choose to exit at the Forum exit, then you need to make your way back to pick up your passport. Make sure you wear a good pair of walking shoes and bring an umbrella/wear a cap for a hot sunny day. Not many shady areas as you are walking within the area. Water fountain to refill bottles are available. You'll get a good view of the Forum.

Amazing for history. Wear comfy shoes! The ancient heart of Rome is just wonderful to wander around, but there is no information on the way round. Didnt realise you could get an audio guide and we asked at the entrance about any guided tour of the Forum and Palatine Hill. The girl told us there was no tours of any kind and then we saw right after the entrance 'Meeting Point for guided tour'!! Didnt see anyone there though so assumed there wasnt a tour starting anytime soon so just had to make our own way around. You could easily spend hours here.
beautiful outdoors. this is a good place to get a little bit away from the fuzz but still see the history of the old centre of rome. you can get really nice photos from this place

amazing but less info. the place is ofcourse a history on the palm! cant imagine how many emperors walked there! take comfortable shoes, it needs time to walk around and the ground is paved! the only drawback is that there r very few informations on display, either take a guide or just walk around wondering who built the column infront of u...

ruins, gardens, great views. if u r covering coliseum forum and palatine hill in one day, my advice either start with it, either go to coliseum then to it, as it is the most demanding attraction from the 3! many stairs and climbs, but its beautiful with nice gardens where u can have a sit and a nice view over the forum...there is also a garden where u can see what vegetables, fruits and plants used to be cultivated by the ancient romans!! very fascinating!!

Not to be missed.... This is one of thé must-see places in Rome. The entrance fee is included in your Colosseum-ticket. The place does get crowded though so try to get there early... The Palatine & Roman Forum are actually all located at the same place - there's hardly any information out there (on boards or something) so it does get a bit confusing. There's no café on the site - I couldn't even see a drinks-stall so stock up before you go in. Best bet is to buy your ticket online in advance so you can skip the queues.

History in the middle of a green oasis. You can visit the Palatine Hill with the same ticket for the Colosseum & Roman Forum. It is a great place, steeped in history but a bit of a maze. I didn't take a guide but just wandered around soaking in the atmosphere & taking picture after picture...The place is often forgotten by tourists but for me it is not to be missed.The atmosphere is different to that of the Forum Romanum: the large gardens make it a nice and yet awe-inspiring place to spend some time in.As far as I could see there are no drinks for sale so stock up before you go in. Best is to buy your tickets in advance online to avoid the queues...

Fascinating history - guide is a must.... Weather was not great, but the scenery was... One downfall is that the current excavations mean that some parts are closed - but there were still more than enough fascinating sights to see in one visit. A guide or audioguide is an essential - otherwise you're just looking at a pile of stones, but the explanations on audio guide from the ticket office were very good. The downside is that they give you a tiny map to follow, and at times it can be hard to locate the right place to stand (and this is made more difficult because parts of the audiotour route are currently closed as already mentioned). However, with a little patience, and a boyscout badge in map-reading the audiotour provides for a full and rich day of sightseeing in both the forum and paletine. If in doubt try a tourguide - but be warned, last time we visited Rome the guide was in training for The Olympics and rushed us on at too fast a pace. The audioguide enabled us to go at our own pace.Other reviews comment on carrying water - and this is a good idea, but there are a number of places where the Roman Springwater can be used to fill your bottle. Be warned though, once filled with water - there are precious few places to visit where one can become comfortable! We tried to use one of two toilets on The Paletine, which was temporarily closed for cleaning. When we tried to wait, an overzealous cleaner told us firmly to go away and find another toilet!A thoroughly enjoyable day - even in the rain - made better by the excellent commentary of the audioguide. For 7 Euros it was very good value.

Steeped in history, overlooking Rome. The Palatinus is a hill alongside Forum Romanum and Colosseum, the most famous of the historical attractions in Rome, and one can buy a combined ticket to all three. According to our experience of many discussions with people visiting Rome, Palatinus is often omitted of the three. Don't make that mistake, since in the end this is the one that will leave the most impressive and deep-felt image and one where you will want to visit again. It is enough to visit the Colosseum and Forum Romanum once, and you will see them anyway many times during your visit, if you move around that part of Rome. But you can really spend time on the Palatinus Hill, both engaging with the history and finding tranquility in the arboretum. What's more, there are several places where you can get a good view of the city.There's a historical museum that offers interesting insights into the ancient habitation on the hill, but it is a bit old-fashioned so perhaps not so engaging to some. The main historical attractions are the ruins, however, among which my favourites are the racing arena and the banquet hall.Whenever we visit the Palatinus, we bring our own stuffed panini sandwiches with us and dine in the arboretum, one of my favourite places to rest in Rome. Just don't litter!

Simply amazing..... It's huge but just amazing to look around 'the lost city'. I just could not describe how wonderful it was in any words......But there was not cafe or a place to buy food within the site. Do take a proper break before you enter and have a water bottle (water fountains were avaialble). It took us about 4 hours to look around.

Allow plenty of time for this. We unfortunately visited on a very hot day, after going to the Colosseum, so feel we didn't get to see as much as we would have liked.There's a lot of walking involved and I didn't think the signposting was good so sometimes it was hard to work out where we were.That aside it's well worth a visit; just allow plenty of time to get the most out of it.

Fantastic historical experience. The kids loved the Roman forum,,, Its great to see the ruins. Worth a visit. Take your time. Walking through from beginning to end gives a real sense of this ancient area. Take a hat and a drink on a hot day.

Incredible. Like walking in history, and all the more remarkable since the ruins that are left are mostly the skeletons of what was there originally, the white marble clothing having been 'repurposed' for other buildings, mostly early churches, from the Dark Ages to almost the present day.

Too hot, too big a queue - but there are ways of getting good views without going in. We aimed to take in the Palatine Hill and Roman Forum sites as the last stop on our weekend of exploring Rome last week (21st September 2012).Having walked down from our hotel near the Spanish Steps and then spent 2+ hours in the Colosseum, all in 30 C heat, we got to the Palatine Hill entrance to be greeted by another queue. With no shade and the 100 metre queue seemingly not going anywhere quick, we decided to skip it.Instead, we walked around the Perimeter (past the Circo Massimo - which is a bit of a mess), up via san del theodoro (there's a good bar for a quick drink there called 0.75) and then climb up the zigzag of Via del Tre Pile. At the top of this road you can look down into the entire Palatine Hill site and take some good pictures.From here you walk straight into the beautiful square by Il Vittoriano.

Disastro. Its an insult to this important historical place, how inreadible bad the organisation of this place is.Don t visit this place without a good guide or beeing well prepared with the history!Than you will see only old stones and monuments without any information or not even numbers on the most important spots.The map you get with the audioguide is completly inuseless (the map you get at the coloseum is much better and usefull for orientation).No one is able to use the audioguide, because you will not find the numbers printed at the map on any ruin...And there is only one toilet for all the mass of tourist...You will not find any usefull sign.... The sign for WC will guide you in the Coloseum, but you are not allowed to reentry in Forum Romanum or PalatinoSo be well well prepared or use a guide, than it s amazingOtherwise its a "disastro"

Ruins, ruins, ruins. It was so awe inspiring to walk through the ruins. There are statues and a few walls and spires still standing including a large arch that is still intact. To think, how old these ruins are and you are walking where the ancient Romans tread!! Where else on earth?!

Top of the city. An excellent get away from the chaos in the centre of Rome. It's up high so be ready for plenty steps, access isn't great if you are infirm in any way. Views are amazing and worth the trip - ideal for panoramic photos of the sites below. You can get access to the Hill with your colloseum ticket which saves on the Q's. It is still an active archaeological site so work is still being done. Discounts for Children from the EU but not from outwith.

The best site in Rome. I returned to this site after a 7 year gap and I was still blown away. I purposefully stayed in accomodation one road away so that I could gaze upon this site daily. The best view is from the Capitoline Hill and I highly recommend going there at dusk or dawn, as the viewing spot is packed during the day and nothing beats standing there at 11pm with no one else there and just gazing out over a remarkable piece of history. Remarkable considering it had become a cow field in the latter par of the last thousand years with most of the lower standing monuments only unearthed in last hundred years or so.  If you are a fan of Roman history you will be in your element here - it is a must go to place. I highly recommend purchasing the 3D souvenir photo book from the tourist bookshop, as it has reconstructed images of what this and other important Roman sites looked like in their hey day and you can switch between the now and then photo/image in astonishment. Sadly the audio guide was extremely confusing and very short narratives about different sections (if you do take this option remember to take ID e.g passport otherwise they won't rent to you). I didn't take a tour but listened in here and there on passing tours and I would say the more personal tour you can take the better, as we could never hear what the guides were saying clearly and the groups were 15+. Purchase your tickets online in advance to avoid the queues you can print tickets from home and bring them with you. I highly recommend this destination.

Ok. Let me preface this rating by saying we did this at the end of a very hot day and were exhausted and moving very quick through it so we didn't get to truly appreciate everything. The architecture is pretty amazing but I would recommend getting a tour group for this one. My wife and I did it on our own and were pretty lost. I'd still recommend visiting.I'd recommend getting the Roma Pass prior to visiting Rome. It gets you into two landmarks for free (Forum and Colosseum) while passing by the large lines. You also get discounts on all other landmarks/museums and transportation is also free!

One of our favorites. We loved touring around Palatine Hill. At first I wasnt even sure it was something that I wanted to do but in the end Im so glad we did. There was a lot to see and I found it wasn't over packed so you really got to enjoy it. In the end we went back again a second day

Add this to your day.. It turns out that our colosseum tickets included Palatine Hill. It was my first time and we loved it. The overwhelming scape of work and labor is mind boggling. And the Age. This is the heart of the ancient Romans.
bring your sunscreen. Fantastic, very historical, it was a great thing to see and learn about, plus it was nice to see trees in the middle of the city.

Incredible to See Ruins being Unearthed. The ruins that are uncovered are incredible to view. However, toward the end we found an area where they are curently excavating more ruins. This held my interest more than anything else at the Palatino as I found it interesting that no matter how many ruins you see in Rome, there appears to always be more history to uncover.

Advice. Arrived in Roma, what a panorama of ancient history. But pls take an attention your wallet. When we were arrived in Roma, so many ppl advice us take good care your wallet. Because so many pickpocket over there.
Great History. Make sure you have your walking shoes and some water. Plan to take your time and spend most of the day

Palatine Hill. It was lovely and gave me the opportunity to rest and take some photos. I wish I had taken a tour as I don't know the history behind the hill or many of the complexes. Without the knowledge it was more like a park with ancient ruins strewn around it but it was still worth a visit

Well Worth It, but Take a Tour. The views of the city of Rome from this hill is really great. Definitely try to get a tour of this area, if not, you won't know what you're looking at. Tried to do it with just a book, it really didn't do it justice.
Just Average. I didn't enjoyed this place. I guess a guide is needed to explain the meaning. If not all you see is ruins, ruins and more ruins without knowing the meaning.
Real Rome. Lots of great ruins (if your into that kind of stuff) helps to have some knowledge about what you are seeing or i would suggest a tour.

Real Rome.. This is the place to come if you are really interested in the history of Rome and its empire. Although mostly just ruins you can still get the idea of the magnificence of the former empire and just how far ahead of their time they were.

Really cool. This place was really cool. This is a massive collection of ruins front the Roman Empire. We did a Dark Rome tour through it which was really informative ( you basically won't get anything from this unless you do a guided tour). Definitely worth a visit.

Buy your combnation tickets here for Palatine Hill and colleseum. Buy your combnation tickets here for Palatine Hill and colosseum. This will save you some much time at the colosseum.The whole family enjoyed wandering through the sights, we ate our picnic here before going straight to the front of the colosseum queue, you just need to show your pass and your waved through.

Magnificent history. A brilliant awe inspiring place. Surrounded by history that led to the world I live in today. I so enjoyed the images in my head asa did my kids. It is just worth doing cause of what it was

Well preserved historical site. Extremely well preserved. We particularly liked the chariot wheel tracks in the pavement. My daughter, age 6, really liked seeing archaeology in action as there was a dig on whilst we were there and some of their finds were on display.

Don't miss this when you're at the Roman forum . The gardens are very nice and full of interesting ruins and beautiful views of Rome. I'd recommend not to miss two things: the stadium and the tunnel (called Nero's necroporta-something).
Good sight!. Not very much to see. However, when you consider the history it is worth going to at least once. You can walk around and see other ruins or just walk down a side street and go to a cafe.
Just ruins. If you do not like ruins, do not go there. Unfortunately, all the buildings are unrecongnizable. If you have just one day or two in Rome, this is an attrection you can skip.
Impressive. Great to see. Guide showed the party pictures of how the scene would have looked in Roman times and it was amazing to see it had not changed very much at all.

Amazingly huge Roman complex. As this was right next to the Colloseum, and we had one more free visit on our Roma Pass to use, we tried this atrraction. With no preconceptions of particular knowledge of this place, my daughter and I were trully astounded by the size and complexity of it. The scale of it when at it's prime must have been, yet another, marvel of the Roman world. Overlooking Circus Maximus and the Colloseum and the Forum, it is a remarkable site.
So nice!. It's great to visit it during a sunny day! It's tiring, but definitely worth the visit. You can get some panoramic views of Rome, too, from the Platine Hill :)

A nice walk. Palatine hill has some great views of The Colosseum and Rome and there are various ruins that are very interesting to see but keep going to the Roman Forum for something that little bit more amazing.
Walking in the ancient. A must see in Roma. A pity that for commercial reasons it is also very crowdy and at a high price...

Book a guide for the best experience. Queues can be enormous so better to prebook a tour to bypass them. Not really suitable for children, and can take quite a while to get round as the area is vast compared with the few pictures in the adverts, but if interested in a fascinating part of history this cant be beaten. Particularly if you have a good guide!

possibly my favorite place in Roma.. I didn't really want to go here originally, but I followed my wife. I ended up loving the Palatine gardens and the forum. It was so peaceful, and there were so many interesting structures and ruins to see. I wish we had brought lunch to have a picnic there. I will definitely put this near the top of Rome's sights.

Interesting - if you know what you're looking at!. Immensely interesting and important area of Rome - but consult your guidebook or all you'll see is a series of ruined buildings. There are good information boards, but these don't replace a bit of research.Buy tickets the evening before you go - they cost 12 Euros for the Palatine, Forum and Colosseum inclusive, and are valid for 2 days. This must be one of the lowest priced tourist sites in the world, given what you get access to for your cash!Best to use the Via San Gregorio entrance, halfway between the Circus Maximus and Colosseum. Way less people than at the Fori Imperiali entrance. Walk through the Palatine ruins, from which you have direct access to the Forum. Head for the Temple of Saturn on the opposite side of the Forum from the Colosseum, then out onto the road to see Trajan's Forum, Column and Markets. From there you can walk down Via Dei Fori Imperiali to the Colosseum.There are Metro stations at Colosseo and Circo Massimo. All is within easy walking distance.

So much history. I found it amazing to see where the romans used to walk and do business. Amazing to see the remains of the temples and some remaining basalt stones that they used to actually walk on, surreal in a way and a definite must do since you are in rome.

Attached to forum. We went to see it since it was easily accessible from roman forum and it is across the street from coloseum. Unless you have a tour guide looks like a bunch of old roman buildings, some nice areas with flowers but we were mainly there for the forum.

Must see with Historian Tour guide.. If you are going to do this trip you must do what a tour guide. It is rich in history and you need to pay for a Private tour guide with degree in History. Without a historian you will be looking at just ruins and saying ok that was nice..But you must see the vision of what was there and the events that happened daily
Just another ruins. Many sites you can visits but this one is not as impressive as others. But go and enjoy yourself, something to see and learn.

Follow the footsteps of Emporer's. An amazing look at where some of European history began, the fantastic Roman engineers show us how they contructed buildings and simply built over ruins and natural disaster ruins.I would reccommend taking a guided tour as you have some fantastic views from here and so much history, if you enter without prior knowledge i feel the area would be underappreciated, read up on it or take a tour to fullly grasp the history of this great place!

A magnificent site!. Walking around in the ruins takes you back thousands of years, and it is hard to find words to describe it. You just have to experience it. Be careful NOT to try to enter the forum up the Via Sacra (the street). We, like many others continued up that hill all the way up, just to hit a dead end at the very top, having to go down again.

Not really impressioned.. Yes there is some very old buldings underground, that are dated to 300s years BJ. But for me it was just a parc to walk, nothing else special. The entrance is with tickets and if you buy a ticket to Coloseum for 14 euros you can enter to forums for free with that ticket.
Hot, long walk. Well worth the effort but try to time it so you do the walking in the cooler part of the day. However, there are areas of shade and places to sit and recover.
Wonderful. I loved every piece of land there. Pure history. It is amazing tour to understand the humanity history. You can see differents ages of the Romain Empire.

Tragic and disappointing.. Oh dear! No directions and no information. Very difficult to gain any idea what this former nerve centre of the Roman Empire once looked like. It costs as well which is wrong. You will stumble around struggling to decipher what you are looking at and it really is not a destination worthy of the hype. Resist the temptation and move on.

Fascinating!. An amazing place that you could easily spend an entire day exploring. There is a lot to see and on hot days can be very tiring. Take water! It was very dusty when we visited and the ground is rock and uneven so make sure you have sturdy shoes/sandals. So many ruins amazingly preserved from floor mosacis to wall decorations - don't by pass this - it is just as amazing as the Colosseo!
It was ok. Nothing more, nothing less - it was ok. I would really have appreciated a map to make it easier to identify what each of the buildings were.

Inform yourself and set priorities. There is so much to see here that it is virtually impossible to take everthing in. Reading about this place beforehand gives you a chance to decide what you really want to see. Good footwear and a water bottle have been mentioned elsewhere. The water fountains are actually indicated on all the site plans around the Forum but we usually found the places by the groups of people standing around them.Walking up the hill or up the steps to the Palatine hill. There is always a shady corner up there for a rest or even a picnic and some wonderful views across Rome. Don't miss the gardens overlooking the Forum.The one set of toilets that aren't marked on the site plan - and accordingly didn't have a queue - are near the Arch of Titus in the building adjoining the Temple of Venus and Rome. They actually belong to the archaeological offices situated there but none of the staff seemed to mind an odd tourist making use of their facilities.Buying our combined ticket here first and then going to the Colosseum immediately afterwards meant we could avoid the lengthy queues at the second site and walk straight in. Visiting both sites on different days is also possible as the ticket is valid for two consecutive days.

Take your time here. You really need to take your time here and experience the ruins. Don't just look, feel the history here. Imagine what took place at this site when it was highly active. Follow the path to the Colosseum and check that out right after.

This is a must see, but use common sense!. This is magnificent, but it can be a lot of rough walking and climbing, especially in hot weather. Wear very, very comfortable shoes, and don't take a lot to carry. Takes quite awhile to see it all, so allow for that. Take a water bottle, and fill it up at the free fountains. Rome has the coldest water I've ever seen! Feels like it just came out of the refrigerator - for real! The ground is rough (of course) but I actually saw people fighting baby strollers - wow -- what a mistake! And my most important thing I took on my trip to Europe was my umbrella! In the heat, that little bit of shade can make a world of difference!
Its like Roman Legoland half finished. An extraordinary site, cant believe so much is still standing, this is really quite a large area to look at from several angles

A must!. This is a must as it is the foundation of Rome. Rome was founded on this hill and is rich in history. Even the mythology of the founders of Rome is fascinating. Download a audio guide for the forum and the colosseum. I used Rick Steve, it was free!

Imagination Needed!. Whilst it is a wonderful attraction how hard wouldn't be for the authorities to give a little more insight as to what we are looking at and a clearly defined route around the area. Too many times we ended up at something unsure if it was the right place or not. Despite this lack of information I really enjoyed the views.

it will blow you away!. the history that is here in this place is amazing. Every stone tells a different story. buying your ticket here first also gets you the queue jumper into the colluseum. handy tip as the queue there is sometimes around the building! make use of the many drinking fountains dotted around the forum especially in the height of the summer. there are clean toilets in the forum too which are a must! take the path up to the palatine and see the remains of the house of Agustas and livia and be sure and look up at the vaulted painted ceiling too. Gardens are beautiful in summer.
Beautiful!. This was so beautiful! I was not very excited to go here but it ended up being my favorite place in Rome. This one is a must for any photographer.
Entry included with Coloseum ticket. Probably the best sight in Rome.Allow 2 hours to see.Bring a water bottle and sunscreen.A guide book is a must.

Part of the Roman Forum. This is actually part of the Roman Forum so you would hardly realise you were on it until you're exiting. It's basically a grassy hill. On entering the Forum you can go left to the hill or right to the Forum. We went to the Forum but ended up coming back via the hill.

Hard work on a hot day. It was boiling the day we visited. My daughter who is studying Classics was fascinated so we spent quite a few hours here. The path is large stones and is very heavy on the feet when you're walking as it's very uneven. It's a large site. Buy a guide book before you go as it's hard to know what's what in here. I must say we visited straight after the Colosseum and I found it very tiring. In the end I sat down and let my daughter off to study the monuments. Definitely worth seeing. I think a hot day is not the best one for this site. There is a fountain with cold drinkable water however.

Palatine Hill, Farnese Garden, and Roman Forum. The Palatine Hill, Farnese garden, and Roman Forum are included in the Roma Pass. Admission (all 3) can be purchased at the gate. The entry gate is for both Palatine Hill (up the path) and the ancient forum (turn right and down the path).Modern Romans posing as Roman soldiers for photographs have a wide variety of prices. NEGOTIATE THE PRICE BEFOREHAND. We noted prices from €5 to €20.The Palatine Hill was the site where Roman emperors lived. It is now mostly tumbled down ruins or excavated walls with a couple of fountain ruins. The information signs are absolutely essential to understanding what any particular ruin is. A tour guide adds much useful information. At the far end of the hill is a remnant of the Farnese garden (build in 1550) promoted in the tourist literature. The garden has only a single entry/exit but the views are grand.The Roman Forum is easier to interpret. It is probably a quarter to half mile long with ruins, arches, and temples throughout. It provides a better "feel" for what ancient Rome must have been like. These sites would be difficult for individuals requiring walking assistance or wheelchairs

Great tour filled with roman history..it's rise and fall,plus more. Take this trip with a good tour guide as our bought it all to life with great knowledge and humourThe story is an amazing one you will learn loads as I didWorth the time out after seeing local sitesGo for itComfortable shoes are best as its paved...
Included in the Colosseo ticket. The main reason we visited was to get the combo ticket for the Colosseo to avoid the lines. While it isn't the most stimulating, it is a beautiful and calm place.

Must Appreciate Ruins-If So, GO!!!!. What a collection of ruins for the eye to behold!! The Roman people were not admirable in all ways but they could certainly build an impressive array of structures that have at least partially endured the ravages of time. My favorite view was looking out of the large windows of the adjacent museum and looking down on the entire site--wow!! We happened to have a personal guide who explained the structures and added to our understanding of the functions of each building. **Try not to go on the hottest day, however--there is not much shade and there is plenty to see--or take some water bottles with you and take occasional rests to avoid overheating. I would go see this again (and again). The books with plastic overlays could add to your understanding and appreciation of the place. Small kids might not relish the particular history but could work off some energy having a bit of space to run around in and stretch their legs!

Nice views of Rome once you reach the top!. Wear comfortable shoes as the hill and Roman Forum is rubble and you do get dust on your feet and all over your toes if you wear open toe sandals or shoes. The buildings are mostly ruin but you can imagine how impressive they would have been in their time. Carry a water bottle as in Rome there are lots of cold water fountains dotted about where you can drink and top your bottle up! We spend about an hour but you could easily spend longer if you take your time and enjoy the gardens. We got a little bored and hungry.
History at its best. To walk among the ruins, see where the Vestal Virgins once resided, visit Mussolini's summer residence - so much history in one place.
Interesting. Many ruins in time for repair to finish. I believe that for archeologist is a lot of fun for visitors a little less but its incredible dimension like egyptian pyramid

Palatine Hill. This place is amazing (I seem to say that about everything Roman). -I would definitely do some sort of tour here (either a group or an audio tour). It will help because there are so many ruins and unless you've already stuided all this, you will not be able to tell what is what.-Give yourself at least half the day. (Did the Colosseum during the other half- read the Colosseum review). -There is a lot to see and lot to walk. There is also lots of dirt and sand. Make sure you wear walking shoes to get dirty. -Bring sunscreen if you're going in the summer.-Always pack an umbrella or a pancho (it might rain).have fun!
Nice place to view. Very old ruins. In the midst of repairs, which kind of defeats the purpose of calling them ruins...

Such an amazing place. We spent hours wandering around here (and in the excruciating heat no less). It was awesome. Of course we like seeing old ruins. If you don't then you probably shouldn't visit this attraction.
We didn't use the audio guides but I think if we ever come back we would benefit from them.
It's an amazing place full of such culture.

Wow! What a sight! our 3 boys loved roaming through this place!. You could spend hours here imagining what it used to look like. Our boys (8,11 & 14) enjoyed this tremendously. They especially liked the athletic stadium. It was a great was to get a feeling for the vastness of the rulers lifestyle in ancient Rome. We were there for about 1.5 hours and for our guys that was good.
sooo cool. We did this as part of the Forum and Palatino hill tour. Wear some good walking shoes! but we loved it!!

Another reason to visit Rome. Palatine Hill and the Forum were the highlight of our visit to Rome. It's fascinating to walk through 2000 years of history, although as other reviewers have noted you need to use your imagination.

Interesting and great views of ancient Rome. We bought a 7 day archaeology card through "Select Italy" that gave us admittance to several sites. This was one that we visited and because we had the seven day pass, we didn't feel like we had to race through everything. Really enjoyed th history of this place and it was not extremely crowded.
Even walk pass you will get Roman Feel. What even you just walk pass or take a half day tour here you will feel how is Roman empire in the last century

Use your imagination. There is little left to see on the Palatine Hill, the ruins are provide little, if any indication of the former residences. A good tour guide is suggested in order to assist your imagination. This is mythical birthplace of Romulus and Remus.

Great Day!. We went to all three locations today. We started out at Palatine HIll and waited in line for about 10 minutes around 0915. THe rest of the day we didn't have to wait in line because we already had the tickets. The sites were beautiful and a breath of fresh air after having to crowd through the Vatican Museums and St Peter's Basilica. I would recommend these locations to anyone. Note: If you have a stroller, the Roman Forum is a pain due to the cobbled road.
Excellent archeological site for those who love roman history... The whole place is surrounded by great buildings and achitecture. It is a paradise for those who like history.
Good. Impressive and a must if you are goinf to Rome! Bigger than expected. A big pluss is that it is water fountains to drink from everywhere:)

Still an active archeological dig....... They are finding things every day from these digs. The ancient and the modern right next to each other......what a contrast. It was so amazing to see the archetectural wonders combining the past with the present......great job!

Really a don't miss. This is what people come to Rome to see: history. We did it on our own, but I suspect that hiring a local guide would have made it come more alive. The audio guide was positively the worst we've ever hired, so don't waste your money. They didn't work, and after we paid for them they told us to follow the map because there were no #'s at the site locations. Even the map didn't jive with the audio. One of them broke halfway through. Hire a private guide instead. If it's hot, bring an umbrella to provide you with moveable shade. There are fountains in several places with very cold water to drink and re-fill bottles from. Perfectly fine drinking water.

Worth the Hiking. The Palatine Hill is fascinating. While it's a bit of a hike to get to the top of the hill, once you're on top, the walks are very easy and the ruins are worth a leisurely stroll. There aren't any concession stands on the property, so bring your own water. There are also few sitting areas, but there are many shady spots where you can relax. Many people were picknicking on these shady grassy areas when I visited. So if you are a non-athletic traveller or simply would like to take it easy, the Palatine Hill can accomodate that after you get to the top.If you don't need a leisurely day and want to take-on the hill without breaks, you should be able to see everything in 1.5 hours. Just be sure to bring a map since the ticket office doesn't hand out any, at least not to me or anyone else that I saw. And the direction signs on the property simply are WRONG! They will point you to the Forum entrance and you will find yourself elsewhere, repeatedly. So, it's easy to get lost; however, if you come without a map, there are plenty of visual landmarks to guide you, chiefly being the stadium.The stadium is a must see. Supposedly St. Sebastian was martyred at the stadium and there's a big bloom of beautiful purple flowers growing in the area, at least in May/June. Also a must-see is Livia's house where you can see a great deal of the villa's layout. At the end of the house, down the hill a little is a FANTASTIC view of Rome with the Temple of Hercules to your left and St. Peter's Dome straight ahead. This is one of the best photo-ops of the city. But the star attraction of the hill, to me, were the tunnels, called the Cryptoporticus. The Cryptoporticus is a series of tunnels that the emperors would use to get around the city without being seen or exposing themselves to the threat of crowds. Despite the safety purpose of the Cryptoporticus, in one of these tunnels, Emperor Caligula was assassinated. I was a little hesitant to walk through these tunnels--fear of the potential creepiness, cave-ins, and claustrophia, but the land around the tunnels has been dug up, so there's a reassuring blast of sunlight at the end of each tunnel. Also the tunnels are amazingly sturdy and preserved; you can even find some great ancient reliefs and carvings inside them. These are definitely worth seeing!If you plan on seeing the Colosseum, Palatine Hill & Forum in one day, I'd advise that you visit in the order listed. After seeing the Colosseum, you'll exit behind the Arch of Constatine. Don't go back to the Via dei Fori Imperiali, which you'd likely take to access the Colosseum. Instead, take the road to the left of the Colosseum exit (Via San Gregorio) and go upwards to the lesser known entrance of the Palatine Hill. There should be either no line there or a very tiny one. When you are finished with the Palatine Hill, you can enter the Forum directly without reentering any lines outside. Go down the ankle-twisting original stone path carfeully! You'll be facing in the direction of the Colosseum on this path and enter the Forum by the Arch of Titus.I booked my online reservations through OmniTicket before my trip: the Colosseum, Forum, and Palatine Hill three-in-one ticket. It cost 13.50 Euro per ticket for all three sites and no wait in line. There's no signs or separate entry area for the three-in-one ticket, so just go to the area designated for the Roma Pass, raise up your printed-out ticket, and the guards will let you in.

Treat as a stroll in a park!. The ruins here are in such a poor state that it is almost impossible to imagine what was here before (even armed with guide books and photographic overlays of what places would have looked like). As a consequence of not knowing this, our expectations were far too high and the Palatine Hill was rather disappointing. My children (14,12,10) actually hated it unfortunately!The views from here across to the Colosseum and the Forum are lovely however and it is a great 'breathing space' after the crowds of the former. If you treat this as a stroll in a park and a quiet spot in the coolness of the shade of the mature trees it's worthwhile, maybe even for teenagers!

Just walk around and see the ruins. Would suggest just walk around the site, or get an pay for the ROMA Bus tour to see in pain the roman sites, decide to get off and walk around the bits you want to see etcNot very well sign posted, so take a guide with you while walking

Skippable. It might be that we visited the colosseum before this and had seen something grand but this turned out to be a damp squib. It was difficult to follow the ruins, the signage wasn't very good and there were a lot of areas which were blocked off. If you have lots of time at your hand then you can visit this after the colosseum otherwise I would recommend skipping this.

A must. There is a place where you can stand above the site having walked down from the hill before walking aound the Forum to get a better perspective, I also read about it first as there is a lot to see, doing all this I understood it better as well as the background and the different emperors, suprising that these monuments have lasted so long.
First Visit. Loved walking through the ruins, like travelling back in time!

It's great _ but don't get the audio guide. It's an interesting place, but the audio guide is a total waste. None of the sights are marked, the map on the ground does not coincide. Not worth it.But by tickets here rather than at colosseum and save a Q

Palatine hills give you a feel for the real Rome. After the coliseum this is a must see, the palatine hills is stunning the architecture is amazing. You need a full day for the sights. Buy food elsewhere the food vans are very pricey but take your camera
Nice monument. I visited Palatine Hill along with Roman Forum. The audio guide was very useful and gave a neat idea of what each part stood for.

Big, Really Big!. Although my companion was not impressed with old stuff that used to be buildings I found the forum amazing. The fact that such structures were built by hands is just fascinating to me. Rome is a fascinating city and historically, a treasure to be savored in every way. The forum is what you make it and I loved it. I could visualize it in its glory...but it is not for every one.

Interesting site, poorly signposted. I have been to the forum before on previous visits to Rome, but this is the first time I have visited since it has been fenced off and charges admission. Given this additional revenue stream I would have expected a much better visitor experience throughout the venue, with very informative plaques and maps located at key sites to help visitors understand what they are seeing, however with the exception of one or two non-descriptive maps and a basic plaque there was nothing to identify the ruins or describe their function. Additionally, the signposts were terrible, the new entrance is located at the back of beyond and we spent 20 minutes following incorrect signs trying to find the exit once inside.All in all, its a very interesting place if you know a little about the history (I've had tours on previous visits) but I don't know how first time visitors gain much from the experience without having to pay for the audio guide or a tour. I expected better.

Lots of photo opportunities but no walking amongst the ruins.. Take lots of photos and admire the view. The whole experience is fabulous and the views are only ever seen in secondary school text books. The real thing is fabulous. Ignore the street sellers! They annoy most peiople and even move in when you are taking photographs!
Incrédulos how romans were excepcional engineers.. Every thing and buildings are great to see. You must go.

Best view of ancient Rome. This elevated hilly area above the city of Rome which was once the neighborhood of roman emperors is a needed respite from the heat of the city. The most beautiful panoramic views of the ancient city are found here as well as the occasional cooling breeze. I was actually shocked at how well preserved some of the ruins are and how huge they are. There is a viewing platform that overlooks the forum. The view here is absolutely breathtaking!

The Forum itself: amazing. The official Audio Guide: an amateur rip-off!!!. The Roman Forum and Palatine Hill are a glorious testimony of the illustrious Roman past, but to truly appreciate the significance of the ruins around you need a bit of imagination and, most importantly, adequate guidance. We are here to warn you that the scandalous Audio Guide sold at the entrance to the site is one to avoid as an overpriced and inadequate service that does not actually reflect what you see on the ground.Crucially, with an audio guide you should be able to clearly understand what you’re looking at. But the Roman Forum audio guide is not grounded on the map, and consequently two reasonably intelligent persons with some experience reading maps got quite lost in the details.The main complaints are these:1. The official site map is outdated, inaccurate and misleading! The site’s layout has clearly changed: some paths are off-limits, some roads are closed, and some ruins are simply not accessible. None of these changes are reflected on the map. Regrettably, the audio guide tracks correspond to this map, and now the audio guide walks you through places that are inaccessible on the ground!2. This would have been OK if there was some way to re-orient yourself when the map and the guide mismatch, but no. There are hardly any signs in the site, and none of them use the numbering system of the map and audio guide.3. The audio guide is nicely divided to tracks (you click a number to play the relevant track depending on where you are) but the commentary is continuous from previous tracks. You can’t always make out the historical context if you just click a track in mid way.4. The audio directions for navigating around the site are also relative, not absolute e.g. “look to your right” or “continue the guide when you pass the temple of Castor and Pollux (remember there are no signs on the ground corresponding to the map...) Therefore it’s hopeless to re-orient yourself if the road was closed or if you took the wrong turn.5. The commentary is uneven. Some tracks are very basic for the un-initiated tourist, while others assume a deep background.

Worth a visit. The forum is included with your tickets to the Coliseum and Petrin Hill so worth visiting, but we preferred the other two due to the views of the hill, and atmosphere of the Colosseo. Had we paid separately for it we would have felt a bit let down as there was a lot of scaffolding / restoratino, which takes something away from the artifacts, although must be necessary - A shame, as the ruins are clearly amazing, and I would not suggest at all that this is avoided, but if anything they are more interesting from a distance than up close.

Only tranquil place in central Rome. This place is enormous and enchanting. It's much quieter and more tranquil than its better known neighbours. It brings a real sense of Ancient Rome and how the people here lived.
Don't Miss This. Well worth the time to see this part of Rome. We love it. Seeing something built 'B.C.' was amazing. The prison that held St. Peter and Paul still stands nearby - how crazy is that?

A great build up for a historical day. We came here before the Colosseum on a gloriously sunny day, and had a great time exploring and viewing the fantastic ruins. No queues and a very relaxed atmosphere - a highlight of the day and our whole visit.

Part of the Forum near Colosseum. This attraction is located at at the back of the Forum. You have to gain entrance to the Forum to be able to access it. Some nice temples and a very nice place to casually stroll about without the hustle of crowds. You really need a good few hours to be able to do both the Forum and Palatine Hill. I really recommend the guide option!
A nice break from the crowds. After being at the Colosseum it was lovely to stroll around Palatine Hill.

Go with a guide. We did Palatine Hill as part of a guided group tour that included the Colosseum and the Forum. If not for the tour I probably wouldn´t have bothered walking the steps up the hill, as without the background it doesn´t really mean very much... just more ruins like at the Forum. It was becomes interesting when you realize that this whole area was actually one building. It was in fact the city before the Forum was built, and all lived within its walls.
Brilliant. Worth the money you at to get in, a good few hours f exploring nd another must visit, spectacular view of the ity from the top

Your best day in Rome - but don't go unprepared!. Ok, I'm going to nail my colours to the mast here and say this is where it's at - the best site in all of Rome to visit. It doesn't have the opulence or grandness of St Peters, the richness depth of the Vatican, or the beauty of the Sistine Chapel, or the steps of the er...Spanish Steps.The Roman Forum and Palatine Hill is the beating heart of Imperial Rome. You can walk where not just emperors and Senators roamed, but where the millions of ordinary Romans saw the seat of their empire. The senate. The Temples. The sacred flame. The law courts. The triumphant arches. The palaces...so some of them are just ruins, but that's what you get guidebooks for. That and your imagination to fill in the gaps. For a mere 12 Euros (at time of writing)!So here are my helpful tips:(1) Rome isn't just about the place where the gladiators fought. But if you just want to visit the Colosseum and you have very limited time, just pop to the Forum or Palatine Hill entrances, buy your ticket there and walk back.. Enter via the group entry signs and skip the horrendous queues.(2) Take plenty of water.(3) The Houses of Augustus and Livia have limited opening to preserve the archaeology. Head there first and early to avoid queueing or disappointment.(4) For your own sake go to the loo before hand and use them when you see them. Facilities are few and far between on these sites. They haven't quite mastered catering to the tourist masses just yet, surprisingly.(5) Take water.(6) Dress appropriately. That mean sun block, hats, good shoes (it is uneven underfoot and not fully pavement for the stupid unprepared tourist in high heels)(6) Take plenty of water (and food). There are no cafes etc on site at all. If you leave the site, you cant go back in. Don't say I didn't warn you.(7) Beware the guided tour groups! These numpties plug themselves into their headsets blithely following round some tour guide carrying a coloured flag or brolly and barking into mikes, and they have literally no regard to what's going on around them. Women, children the infirm...watch out for the invading hordes!!! The problem with these groups are they are so interested in the audio track and keeping up with their guide they lose all perspective of what goes on around them and they pile through anything. No wonder pickpockets thrive at tourists sites!(8) Take a guide book. You'll notice in Rome the locals aren't great in labelling anything, so you have to self identify a lot from the books. When they do out a sign up its usually just in the mother language (of the monuments that is).(8) Take plenty of water, head wear and good shoes. If I hadn't mentioned that already.And after all this you can leave one exit and pop into the Colosseum without queueing. What a grand way to end you day.

A walk back into history. We visited last year whilst on a family holiday in Italy with our 3 children. We visited after we had been to the Colesseum. We booked a tour guide for when we arrived. We had not really done much research on the different tour guides, but the one we had, Felicity, was very good and enthusiastic and she really brought the whole history of the area to life.The guided tour was about 1 hour long and we went through and looked at the various different temples, archs and buildings. Felicity gave a brief history of each of the buildings. You had great views of the City, and you could really imagine the hustle and bustle of the city in Roman times, when this small area would have been the centre of the huge Roman Empire stretching across Europe. With Julius Caesar and Nero striding through the streets.Once the main tour had finisged we were free to wander around some of the other sites and take in the view.The fact that over 2,000 years ago the Roman Emperors and generals had the confidence in the future to build the various temples and that these have mainly survived all the tribulations of history and passage of time is truly inspiring.As with many monuments in Rome, you are walking in the footsteps of history.

bring good walking shoes and go to the bathroom before. beautiful 2+ hour walk of the hill... Augustus' quarters not worth the line though... sort of a maze at the end - - making it hard to find the exit - - bring a map with you - and either an audio guide or guide book to decipher what you are viewing.

get a guide or audio tour.... very confusing to know what you are looking at without them - - since they are all ruins and remnants of buildings... more meaningful with some sort of tour guide or book...
very good. Get lost here and you'll discover nooks and crannies of amazing quiet. Really wonderful.

Worth every penny. Palatine Hill and Roman Forum is a must see. Unless you are a history teacher, you definitely need a guide. This is not just a bunch of stones and you would feel so sorry not to learn/hear the full story of those epic ruins...

Beautiful Place...but badly ran. Of course Palatine Hill was beautiful! To think your amongst ruins from hundreds and thousands of years ago is inspiring....but the place and tour options are extremely bad!!The price was good, 22 euros each (being under 24 and in the EU) and includes the Roman Forum and Colosseum but the option for audio guide was 7 euros and only covered the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill, you would have to pay extra for the Colosseum. This we were okay with...the thing that really angered us was the fact that the audio guide was not beneficial unless you started at the Roman Forum... we had entered at Palatine Hill so were not pleased we had to trek through Palatine Hill to begin properly looking at Roman Forum especially in 30 degree heat, would have been better if the woman on the desk had told us this. Another thing, with the audio guide, you did not know where to look, there was no signpost of interest so we were listening based on guess work....due to the fact we'd been given an old map!!! So although it is a beautiful place...I'd advise going through a tour group or at least enter through Roman Forum...least then you stand a chance of knowing what to look at.

A Step Back into History. This is a fascinating and overwhelming site. I would not recommend the audio tour. It is not well organized and very difficult to follow. Also, try to avoid the heat of the day as there is very little shade so can be unpleasant. Be sure and read up on this site before you visit.
Gave me goosebumps. To think that we were actually touching,standing and seeing the ruins from the original Rome built in 700BC was surreal. Wonderful views of modern Rome also from that vantage.

A guide is a must!. You need a guide book or private tour to really appreciate what you are seeing. There is currently a wonderful temporary exhibit on the history of glass for art and pottery there right now until 2013.

Go high for the views and then circle around!. Tour guides will start yumoffmhgh for a reason - the magnificent view but once you take it in - round out your photo opps with some flower photos amongst the ruins and some the more unique shots! The post card sales folks are more determined here so make your deals remembering its almost $2 us to send them to the states! Better yet, photo them in your photos to remember the major sights as you visit them. The books on the historical sights of Rome in 'layers' sold here are the best in Rome!

What can I say but History History History!!!!!!. Anytime of the year this place is a great place to visit!!!!!Remember this place was around 4 century BC!!!!!So when in Roman go back in time and you will think you in the 4 century BC

Great Old Rome!!. We didn't really go in & walked through it, as my friends & I had limited time to explore Rome, but it's definitely worth it, only if you're into history .. If not, you can google about it to know the story ..

tour guide-a gem!. We were waiting for our Gladiator tour guide for the second half of our tour (palatine hills) who never showed up. We were on time and at the correct spot. Our Gladiator Tour coloured stickers on our shirts were noticed by an ex-pat British woman who came over and asked if we were ok. Elaine Adams graciously added us to her tour, at no cost. She expressed embarrassement at the lack of professionalism by another tour guide . (Greg) Her knowledge and enthusiasm was outstanding. She knew the most intimate of details of Roman history and culture.She was entertaining, and sincerely interested in imparting as much of her knowlege as she could give us in the allotted time.. Her love of Rome and it's history was wonderful. Elaine Adams is truly a gem. Her love and respect for this amazing city was our gain.

Great old Roman City!!!. We stumbled into this place 5 yrs ago, it was totally open and great place to walk though after the Coliseum. But this time, this Old Roman city is fenced and there is entrance fee to get in. Good time to go to Italy to visit all museums is when culture week there. All entrances are free. Except for churches, churches are always free

Lovely scenery provokes the imagination. This along with the nearby Colosseum really gives you an appreciation of the grandness and power of ancient Rome. Use your imagination, walk through and picture the bustling beautiful forum around you. The surrounding area with newer buildings is lovely as well.

As expected, mostly.. My only complaint about this place is the signage. (I also don't like that me and my partner nearly gave ourselves twisted ankles tripping over uneven cobblestones, but these are, probably, the original flat stones, so I can't really complain about that!)The signage. So, I knew where one toilet was - at an entrance - but despite having a map and there being signs, the "toilets" labeled on the signs were not where the signs pointed to and I ended up never finding them. I also never did find the "Romulus Huts" which I really wanted to see, unless it was next to the House of Augustus - I don't know, the signs pointed here and there but if we did actually see them, we wouldn't have known it because it wasn't labeled. Many places DID have adequate signs and even short descriptions and history. Very good, English translation mistakes aside. (Doesn't matter if you know your Roman history).** Speaking of languages, the signs, etc are bilingual in Italian and mostly-correct-English. If you read neither of these, you will need a guidebook in your language.Tips for travellers:- Bring water and lots of it (or refill in an antique wall-water-spout fountain if you're feeling brave). Even at 70F and partly cloudy you are walking (and even hiking) a lot and you will get thirsty.- Bring a snack or have a big meal before going. There are random places to eat overpriced food OUTSIDE the forum but if you're still viewing the huge grounds and feeling hungry you probably can't leave and come back without paying again. I had a granola bar just in case but didn't need it because I had a good-sized breakfast. - Wear sunscreen - you will be out in the open for hours. I wore SPF30 and still got a little color (I burn easily).- Wear hiking shoes or cross-trainers. You will be traversing uneven flat stones, rough and uneven cobblestones, gravel, and steep slopes and steps.
A must see. Bring a guide book or an audio guide. Go early before it gets too hot.... and take lots of pictures of this fantastic site.

Included in the Colloseum ticket. One of the nicest places with ruins in Rome which literallely breaths history. The nices view is if you go around the caitol hill as there is a road which is working like a balkony and allows you to shoot perfect pictures and see the full size of the area.

Included in Colloseum ticket. A magical place full of ruins. The ticket for Coloseum is valid as well here an it gives you very nice view of the town and idea of the antient Rome. Aldo the best veiw is from circo maximo and worth to make this short walk around this place.

See it at night!. Astonishing and haunting at night. We loved it so much we went twice at night and were surprised both times by the few number of people visiting this locale after sunset. The lighting at night casts an eerie and dramatic glow on the columns. Fantastic ambiance. Unfortunately our cameras could not really capture this essence. There are a couple of terrases around the area offering different vantage points. All are worthwhile.
Stepping into History. There is so much to see! This is an absolute must-see! I highly recommend getting a guide to tell you about everything, since there is so much. It is a great site to visit.

Overrated. This is one of those places that you are told you have to visit when in Rome. i must have a limited imagination because many hours spent walking among fallen masonry is just a long and awkward walk. The area is probably meaningfull to archeologists but without a detailed guide and a deal of hard work it is difficult to picture it as a working city;The April drizzle did not help either.

memory lane. i was amazed at what was still standing and recognizable from what i had read before going . i was led to believe there were just a lot of piles of bricks and stones from what use to be there.

Emperors. Its where the big guys lived. Is it as impressive as the coloseum? No. So use a little imagination, close your eyes and pretend that you are living 2000 years ago in the world of ancient Donald Trumps, Warren Buffets et al. They controlled the world as they knew it with the most sophisticated army and infrastructure the world had ever known. Created everything that still has influence on us today. Once you realize that it blows you away. Sit in the gardens. Have a drink, suck in the history that perished 2 millenia ago yet still lives. Awesome. I will go back and probably stay for quite some time.

A look at history in ruins. Located a short walk from colloseum this is as the name says on a hill. From here you can view ruins of times past. The garden here are wonderful and this park like setting gets you out of a hustle and bustle. Entrance is included in colloseum fee or you can purchase separate. Great to take photos overlooking Rome

History. Part of the Palatine Gardens and close to Colosseum ; this area is ancient Rome and well worth a visit. Take walking shoes and just enjoy the experience. The Columns and carving on the arches is amazing.

Be aware Augustus and Livia Houses closed most of the day. The guidebooks say these are the must sees on this site but when we reached them they were both closed up with tiny signs saying the last entrance was at 1.30 p.m. Not helpful or publicised - unfortunately poorly managed as are many major sites in Rome. Other than that not a great deal of note but pleasant surroundings.

Not just a pile of old stones.. Great to wander round, even without a guide book in hand. Great views from here.ater fountains are dotted around the site which is handy to fill up water bottles for free.

Green Rome. Views of the Colosseum from here are a must & it is all so green with gardens, trees etc, not what I expected at all. Do go it is worth it with the combined ticket for the three attractions.
It's a ruin.... Basically another ruin with some interesting history... see it, take a picture, move on...

Hundreds of years of history. Spend some extra time here, get an audioguide and listen to the fantasic history when you stroll arund looking at all amazing historic sites in just a small areaGo here before you go to Coloseum, then you can use the line for ticketsholders that is much shorter !!

Amazing history!!. Please take one of the tours when you go to Palatine Hill. You need to hear a detailed explanation of the scale and history to truly appreciate what life must have been like for those who lived in this palace.
Try it with a guide. I recommend experiencing this attraction with a guide because despite its attractiveness, you will understand it better with some background.

A nice walk, but nothing more.. Well, after walking through the Forum, we spent another 30 minutes or so walking up (and down) the Palatine hill.
While it IS a lovely walk, there's almost nothing exciting to see, other than passing by the arch of Titus.
If you went through the Forum, feel free to skip this hill.

Roman times bought to life!. An audio/tour guide is essential to really appreciate this place, or it could just look like a pile of ruins. We had the free Rick Steve podcast & map (I do keep mentioning him in my reviews, but he really did bring the place alive for us). It's a very large area and there is so much to see and learn here, I thought it was more interesting than the Colosseum, and you could really imagine how it was in the past. A must-do in Rome. Tip - buy some water outside and take it in with you, you'll be enjoying your visit for a long while and I didn't see anywhere inside to buy it.

Hot and crowded, but loved it!. I was in Rome in March 2012. The weather was excellent (ok, hot) and the site wasn't exactly deserted, but totally not as full as during summer. We sent about 4 hours within the Forum but haven't seen all there is to see. I recommend to start the visit in the morning ! Wear good walking shoes and bring water!The site is impressive but lacks descriptions.
Great Place to visit. A fantastic place to visit you can feel the history of the place. I had goose bumps, a really exciting place to have visited

Incredible place. We were on a guided tour which I believe is the best way to get the most out of the visit. The site is huge with lots of uneven surfaces so be careful walking but the history is incredible. You cannot miss this place if you go to Rome !!

This is the Shakespeare stuff!. Booked this experience with the Colosseum as it is only across the road but I found it far more interesting than the Colosseum itself. I would definitely recommend going with a tour guide as it is basically ruins and it is interesting to know what your surroundings are or would have been in Ancient Roman times.
Palatine Hill. This site carries you back to the height of the roman era . It is full of archealogical treasures and lets your imagination wander back to the Forum and other well known sites

My favorite spot in Rome.. I loved this place for the history, the views and something exceptionally rare in Rome: a lack of tourists. Get lost here and you'll discover nooks and crannies of amazing quiet. Really wonderful.
Lack of information. We don't know what we were seeing where we were going. No description, so we saw everything for us are left over historical items.... I think.
Take a walk through...fascinating. This is a great look into construction techniques. Make sure to take a walk through.

It was ok.. Before visiting Palatine Hill we had visited the Colosseum and Forum already so my feet were aching and I was tired. After visitng two magnificent sites the Palatine Hill fell short for me. I didn't really know what I was looking at so it was just a bunch of rocks. I wish Rick Steves' offered a audio tour on the site. Since admission was free with our colosseum ticket Palatine Hill was worth seeing, but it wasn't anything special to me.

Worth checking out. Definitely worth checking out if you have time. Some decent photo opportunities but a little pointless if you don't know the history of it and the organisers/staff are stupid enough to not have enough audio guides charged. You wouldn't have that service elsewhere!

Poor organisation. This visit was ruined mainly due to the extremely poor organisation of those running this. The staff simply did not care about people pushing into queues as there was not enough staff to control it. 2 people working at the ticket desk when there is a queue of hundreds of people. Then to make it worse, we were told that none of the audio guides were available because they are currently charging. Instead they recommended we went to the Colosseum to obtain one from there - which would result in joining an even bigger queue to then go all the way back again. I don't think so! Sort it out please, it's terrible. To be honest with you I found this level of service at quite a number of places around Rome, which I find unacceptable.
don't miss. No trip to Rome is complete without an understanding of it's history and legends - go with a guide/group for all the details.

A must while in Rome. This is an absolute must see when visiting Rome. Plan on spending at least half-a-day there, better yet an entire day if time allows, because it's totally amazing and fascinating - every piece of ruin is worth attention if you are into such stuff. Wear the most comfortable shoes you have because there is a lot of walking required. Also, bring water and some snacks when going for a few hours because I don't remember any beeing sold there. Don't forget sunscreen if going during May-September because there is not a lot of shade. The ticket includes admission inside of the Colosseum.

Read the history.... with your kids and enjoy the visit! This is an amazing historical site of great relevance. We had a great time when we entered via the Hill of Palpatine and made our way down to the Forum then up to the Colosseum. A wonderful, rich day!

Make sure you have a guide. It's just piles of neatly piled bricks unless someone can point out the significance, function and period. With that it really gives you a glimpse of how different the world would be if the Roman empire hadn't fallen

Really interesting. Amazing place and it's even more impressive if you realize that this area at some point was one of the most important places of the Roman empire. Make sure you come early, it's much more relaxing without masses of people around.

Use your imagination. See what remains of one of the world's great empires. You'll probably never miss the answer agora for Roman market place in your next crossword puzzle. Ancient history comes alive here.

Not to be missed in Rome. This is a bit off the beaten track but worth every minute. Entrance is just past the Coliseum. On ticket gets you into the Colisseum, Forum and Palatine. The museum is wonderful. Wandering the paths is splendid. Flowers, wisteria everywhere. And view from 200 ft. above the Roman Forum are breathtaking. The Palatine Hill was the first of the seven hills to be settled. There was an iron age settlement here. It's thought to be the spot where Romulus and Remus were suckled by the she-wolf.

Nice walk around ruins but don't bother with the audio guide!. This is obviously a beautiful and historically important site, but (as another reviewer has mentioned), the general organisation and signposting turned out to be really frustrating. I don't usually go for an audio guide but the place seemed so vast that we felt it would help us get a better grasp of it all.
