The problem is that it is virtually impossible to work out which number corresponds to which site so we couldn't find the correct commentary, and then we realised that the information on the little maps we'd been given was not the same as the large maps around the site! Then my audio guide stopped working altogether and when I asked for my money back, the girl on the desk was a complete cow about it (I'm used to rudeness in big touristy cities but she was reeeeally bad). This may all sound petty but we quickly became tired and irritated and by the end of it we couldn't have cared less about the stupid ruins, we just wanted to get out of there and find wine and pizza. Shame!

Amazing!. Buy tickets online first as lines are very long...WELL worth the extra few euro to avoid the line! Great place for adults and kids... Ours were enthralled by the Ruins and had space to run around when bored. A brief history of the place makes it come alive for them! Palatine Hill was fantastic, but we looked at it first and were a bit tired and hungry when we got down into the actual forum area! I could have spent days in this area alone!

A walk back in time. The great Roman Empire really does come to life as you walk between the ruins of temples etc. A guide is a good idea for this tour as it is hard to tell just which building is which. It can be a little hard on the feet but well worth some pain.
Bring comfy shoes, its massive!. Daughter loved it, spent most of the day exploring every stone in the place. Saw lizards too!

Important site but useless signposting. We found this a frustrating visit, even with the help of a hired audio guide. It is an impressive historical site but the lack of signposting and poor written descriptions make it very difficult to appreciate it properly. Whoever was responsible for this aspect of the site should be replaced by someone competent!
Awesome. Loved the ruins, and the gardens are beautiful. Highly recommend. Part of the Roman Forum complex, so its included with that ticket.
Cool ruins. Another must see in Rome. We enjoyed using Rick Steve's free podcast on this site so we could get a fuller understanding of what everything was as most of it is (obviously) ruins.
Amazing. While there is still a lot of construction-remember to not wear your good shoes or cloths because the dust is everywhere. You can tell those that were at the site by their shoes. lol.
Very Interesting. Get an audio guide tells you eveything about the old city. Long queues and not told that by getting a guide skips the queue. Amazing insight into how the Romans lived.

Makd sure u go there early. There is always a huge q so make sure u go there early in the morning to avoid it.take with u an audi or tour guide as there no explanations and if there are some they are in italian

Rome in two days!. We arrived in Rome, dropped our bags at the hotel for safe keeping and headed off to see the sights. We purchased a two day pass at the forum which included next day entry into the Colosseum. Best decision we made while in Rome! Spent the first day roaming around the Forum and Palatine Hill. It was great with the exception that we forgot to bring a container for water. Free, great tasting water is readily available from faucets several places in this venue, but you must bring your own container. Thought we were going to pass out from thirst. Next time, we will bring a water bottle. This area is very dusty, so wear comfy shoes that you don't mind getting dirty. Next day, we were the first to visit the Colosseum at 9 a.m. - we already had our tickets!
Too overwhelming!. Like the ruins at Pompeii, a guide would have been a great investment. The audioguide was almost useless as it was impossible to figure out the numbers to match up to the sites.
when in Rome.... just one of the top attractions that you should not miss, if you combine with Colosseum you have discount ticket and the full visit of the two takes the whole day.
It is one of my favorites places. This ruins are magnificent. I just love to stroll along them and in different times of the day. There is sooo much history here !

Amazing architecture. by husband and I visited the forum after the colosseum we suggest you arrive about eight in the morning to avoid the crowds,which is very worthwhile also you don't want to be stuck in the forum during midday as there is no shade and it gets,extremely hot. The views of circus de Maximus are astounding if you love history you will love it here. Be warned there are men dressed as guards offering photos with them this isn't for free and they will expect paying for the privileges but they are not pushy and can be very humourous one offered a snap shot of him killing my husband lol with his sword his words
be prepared, it is a ruin. Bring a guide book to explain everything, i would walk up the public road from the collosseum and look in as its not worth paying
Tour included with Colloseum. We took a tour of this with the collosseum and palatine hill, well worth it and very interesting.
Take a tour guide. We took a tour of this and the Roman Forum with David and it was excellent and entertaining. Without the tour it would have looked like a bunch of bricks and mean nothing.
A must see - wear walking shoes. Be sure to catch the glass and textile museum at the end.

History, history...if they only had some signs. Unless you're really well read, have some great guide books, or have audio tours for your iPod (I did), I'd suggest a tour to get the most of this awesome place. Its amazing to walk through, but difficult to understand what you're seeing. They don't have many signs, maps, etc., like American historical sites would normally have. I LOVED this place, and my audio podcast tours made a huge difference. Do your homework before you go, and you'll love it.
Brilliant!. Great sense of history to this place. Would recommend spending a few hours here. Sensible shoes a must. One of the many excellent historic sights in Rome.
to be combined with forum/colosseum. Great piece of rome ancient history. A guide would be a plus to understand better the ruins. Nice overview from the top of the hill over the antique forum.

Forget the audioguide. Worth seeing on any trip to Rome ESPECIALLY the Museum but forget hiring an audioguide. Either take a good guide book or pay for one of the tours. The audioguide is linked to a map that is supplied with about 40 sites of interest all numbered and linked to the audioguide. HOWEVER none of the sites in the forum is marked with a number, The buildings on the map are not orientated correctly on the map and if you want to find a toilet forget it! The map must have never been updated and previous entries for toilets do not exist or have altered.Overall the site is very interesting but you need a good imagination to envisage most of the sites within it. Hence the need for a good book or guided tour

Another gem in Rome. The Palatine Hill came across as a pleasant surprise after coming in from the Forum...there is so much green and you get to see the amazing brickwork which dominates the building in the Palatine Hill.There are lots of buildings dominating the hill so be prepared to walk and ideally with a good guide book. Its a very extensive place so take your time and dont feel compelled to cut your visit short. You get to see how the wealthy live in ancient Roman times and it does give a sense of perspective especially with the Colosseum within sight and how the gladiators would fight for the entertainment of the wealthy living in this hill.Nevertheless, the buildings here are architectural masterpieces.
Amazing. This place is BIG...the history, the structures, it is amazing what has been uncovered thus far....must see

must go then watch HBO series Rome to put everything into perspective. Really enjoyed this visit but you must understand Roman history to enjoy this. Think of the days when Caesar rode his chariot through the streets. Impactful to still see these ruin and buildings still standing.

Excellent, but best with a tour of some kind. I really didn't think I would find much interesting about the Forum. And I probably wouldn't have found it interesting without the audiotour we played on our MP3 player. When we knew what was going on the forum became alive for us. For example when we knew that the place where there are 3 arches (forgot the name) was only part of the church building it became much more amazing how big this place was. Really enjoyed the little glass mini museum that was inside of one ofe the buildings.

Not to be missed while touring Rome. We toured this site with our guide, Silvia. She was so helpful and informative in the way she educated us concerning each stop as we walked through the Acient Ruins of the Forum. This site is breath-taking as you begin to visualize the city as it was in old Rome time periods. Highly Recommend on your tour stops.

Ah, peace and countryside in the middle of ancient Rome.. Need a break from the art overload of Rome?Spend several hours wandering around the Palatine Hill. Ruins, of course, but lovely gardens and quiet places.

Amazing site to see. So much history to see and hear about. Make sure to take a guided tour so you know what you are looking at and the history behind it. We used Roman Candle Tours and highly recommend them.

A Peaceful Hiatus from the Colosseum. After the obligatory visit to the colosseum as part of the combination ticket we visited the Forum but went up the hill instead of staying to the right and discovered a delightful, peaceful stroll through flowering bushes, archeological digs, and a small museum. We loved it. Much more than the man-made monuments. Coop

No shade and poorly signposted.. We felt this attraction should have been better - as there is undoubtably so much history here. Maybe we should have taken an audioguide - but you could be in the forum all day if you wanted to cover everything. Even though we went in March, it was scorching heat and there is no shade and few seats, so it made for a gruelling tour. Also, the ground is really uneven so it is difficult to walk on. Very few information boards or signs, so difficult to navigate.

Be ready to walk. prepare to spend the entire day there walking up and down and just imaging what it had to have been like. Look closely and you are walking on mosaics still. It is overrun with ferile cats you can smell it and birds.

Roman Empire. I've been to Rome four times. I can't seem to take in the city for there is just to much, Porta Portese Flea Market, Catacombs, Castel Saint Angelo, la Chiesas di Roma, piazzas di Roma and so much more. Just will have to go again, forsure
Worth it. I love all things history so this was part of the can't-miss sights including coliseum and forum. Get ready to walk, that whole area is bigger than you think it may be.

eh... i wasnt as blown away. to be honest, everything is under restoration or renovation or whatever when i went. it was a hot hot day, not as hot as summer, but there are lots of steps and slopey roads with uneven stone surfaces, so make sure your sneakers are comfortable!!! i didnt find roman forum as intriguing, and i was one of those tourists that were there to just be there ot see it. i wasnt particularly into this history stuff so i didnt get a guide. if you are really into this i would probably recommend doing a tour with a company otherwise you have no idea where you are going and what you are there for. a tour can last half a day to almsot a full day so just be careful with your timing. there are plenty of tours that do roman forum, palatine hill, and colloseum all together on one day but they do not include admission tickets! so be aware! if you think you can research and learn about the facts yourself then walk around yourself without a guide! its quite expesnive!the ticket combo if you purchase yourself is about 12 euro. its a combination ticket which includes admissionto colloseum, roman forum and palatine hill. i recommend coming here FIRST before the colloseum as the lines there are extremely long even before summer season.

Interesting, but you need a guide. We chose not to get a guided tour for this place and that was a mistake. The ruins are confusing, even with the Rick Steves podcast. I think a guide could have added a lot to the experience.

Phenomenal. I remember studying these spots at high school and seeing them for myself was just phenomenal. Do a combined tour including the Roman Forum and the Colosseum. Guides hawk their tours outside each landmark and most are genuinely knowlegable. If you're with a tour group you also bypass the lengthy queues.

Jaw dropping. This place and Palatine Hill just amazed me. I remember studying these spots at high school and seeing them for myself was just phenomenal. Do a combined tour with Palatine Hill and the Colosseum. Guides hawk their tours outside each landmark and most are genuinely knowlegable. If you're with a tour group you also bypass the lengthy queues.

Pace yourself. Give it 4 hours, bring a picnic and buy the 'Rome Reconstructed' book in the gift shop before going in. Then all the ruins will spring to life and your hunger/thirst won't get in the way of the second act (palatine).
Disappointing. Fabulous site but there was a distinct lack of information for tourists unless you have the audio guide.

Walking through the heart of ancient Rome.. Get yourself a map, get information about the ruins of the monuments, or get a guide, and walk through the Foro imagining you are a Rome citizen 2000 years ago. Some of the monuments are very poorly conserved, but other ones give an idea to you of how magnificient they were (such as the Basilica of Maxentius), or still keep original parts (such as the original bronze door in Romulus Temple).Don't go without having any information about what you are going to see, or you will only see a bunch of rocks and spoil the visit.
Wow. So much history to see and imagine. Would recommend buying a book to take along and read while wandering through the site.
More organized. On my two prior trips there was no entry fee. This time I was with a tour and that may have made a difference but area seemed more organized that prior trips.
Very enjoyable stroll. A wonderful stroll through many ruins with a great view of the Colloseum from afar.

massive. We took the walking tour and had a great guide who gave in depth explanations to most of the ruins.Fascinating area to wander around and really get a feel for the magnificence of Ancient Rome.

Worth a walk. Be sure to download the Rick Steves audio tour and bring your ipod or MP3 player. The Capitoline museum is a must see after you complete your walk from South entrance (near Coloseo) and venturing North.

Do not let the "hill" discourage your visit. Our family enjoyed the less tourist laden Palatine Hill immensely. The admission is included in the ticket for the Forum, but many people appear to skip the hill (perhaps intimidated to climb) which isn't difficult and is rewarding. After visiting many other sites, the open and spacious paths and gardens were much appreciated as our small children could be free. The ruins are quite amazing (stadium, palace, etc.), but it takes some imagination for the children to grasp the concept and stay engaged. Also, great views of the forum below.

Great Look into Anchient Palace. This is a great site where you can see some of the great buildings of ancient Rome. It gives you a good sense of how the very rich lived in ancient Rome. There are some nice small gardens to walk through, and some great views of the Colosseum and the Forum.
What a lovely place to be. It was a lovely place to go to. The views all around were spectacular

a walk in history. I'm the kind of person who likes to walk among historical building/ruins etc. quite freely and it's very possible there. No rush, no crowds, you can just walk around the fascinating building and ruins. Awesome experience.
Living history. A quite extraordinary location, with ruins from more than 2000 years ago. Unmissable.

Huge and impressive. Incredible place, how must have life been 2000 years ago,
at least for the upper class, amaizing
must see. Rome backbone is the best touristic venue in anice sunny roman day. Relaxing but beware of not taking out any stones
Many parts closed. Great views and a sense of what it might have been like to live up there. Many sites (Houses of Augustus and Livia, eg) were closed.
Beautiful experience, but no oranges for me!. The only thing I disliked was my inability to pick the oranges! Otherwise, lovely site!
Amazing place, especially at night time!. It is one of the most fascinating places in Rome and we got to see it at night during our food tour.

Use a guide or study first. We had a private guide without whom we would have just been looking at old stuff. Knowing what you are looking at makes all the difference in the experience. If you don't want to pay a guide, study up on the internet or a book before going.
ancient site. We loved our visit to the Palatine Hill. It was busy but we still got a sense of the history that was around us. Definitely woth a visit.
Needed placards with descriptions. You have to have an audio tour or a good guidebook with you.

If history is your thing, then its great.. I did sense I was walking through two thousand years of history, and made a good effort to get in the mood, But I was more interested in getting through it to come out for the colosseum. Maybe if I had took more time I may have enjoyed it more. But I found with all Rome, theres no information anywhere, theres not even any traffic signs if your driving. There are better touristy things to see than this in Rome. ..................7/10
loved it. It is an amazing feeling walking through the historical cultural heart of this ancient city. It has a serene atmosphere and I highly recommend staying here for a few hours

Very little left there. Saw it from a distance while on a walking guided tour. Mainly tiny ruins, looked a bit like an excavation site. At the same time it's worth a visit due to it's significance to Rome's history.

Home of the rich & ruling class in ancient Rome. Palatine Hill is a great place to get an idea of the sheer scale of wealth that was Ancient Rome. Unfortunately it is not clearly signposted and when we visited quite a lot was closed off so we couldn't visit. There's almost too much history in one place, so it's hard to decipher what you're seeing at times. That said, it's a wonderful place that deserves to be visited. The ticket is great value at €12 which includes the Forum, Palatine Hill & Colosseo.
Forum. Breathtaking. Very impressed with sensitively active restoration in the placed that had clearly been falling away.

One of the most historical world sites. Take your time as the place is much bigger than you may expect. Notice that there are several entries. Take the stairs and walk in the gardens. You will find several restored buildings there. It's not all ruins.

An amazing area of Roman remains.. This is such a large area you could easily spend a whole day. In summer take a water bottle to drink and refill it at the water points . Much of this is still in mid excavation so have a good look at the ongoing archaeological digs. The house of Livia is open to visit and worth seeing if you can. Be prepared to queue. There are guided tours in English and Italian several times a day. Also take a torch. It is useful for ferreting round dark ruins if you like that sort of thing.

Back to the Ancient Roman. Great experience to imagine if all the structure were still there!! Walk around the remnants of Roman structures, it's worth for the ticket and wandering inside this massive complex. Start visiting to the Palatine Hill on the left side after the entrance and you will end up at the gate towards the Arch of Constantine... Beware of "Gladiators" who want to take pictures with you. They will charge a very expensive tips for taking pictures with them.

Walking in the steps of the Roman Empire. Experience the ruins from the Roman Empire by taking a walk through these fascinating pieces of what is still left from ancient time.Standing next to the Arch of Septimius Severus is the main highlight.

Stroll the grounds where Emperors lived. The spralling ruins of what is left of the home of the Roman Emperors is very impressive. Even more impressive when you realize it was all built two thousand years ago by hand. Definately worh a visit while in the Coloseum/Forum/Circus Maximus area.
Ruins, but hints at former grandeure.. With a little imagination, you can picture the Roman senators strolling down the same paths you are walking today...

Fantastic. Stand where the ancient Romans stood, it's impossible to imagine the history that this place contains. It is immense, it is just so significant to our lives and in how our world developed. One of these places that has so much importanc but is so accessbile. You have to visit there and as often as possible.

Not much to see but with a good tour guide still excellent. Obviously the place is pretty much just ruins but if you go see it, book a tour. Their knowledge of the place and ability to explain things makes it come alive and become more than just ruins
Incredible Ruins. A very large area with the remains of numerous buildings. I would recommend bringing a guidebook to help identify and provide backgound to the various structures.

Worth getting a guide. Despite my simple-minded contempt for organized tours & my questionable status as a history geek, this is one of the few times I would strongly recommend taking an organized tour. Given the impact of this half-empty field on world history and western culture, it requires too much imagination and research to gain its full benefit from a solitary glimpse. A knowledgeable guide can fill you in on the intricate detail and back-story of every crumbling foundation and plot, bringing to life the amazing stories behind these ruins. I weaseled my way into the end of a nearby tour and it was a totally different experience. This is one time it really pays to be part of an organized tour.
Rocks.... One of the less exciting things to see. Just a bunch of ruins
Full of history and interest. The Roman forum was vast and interesting. Take some literature with so that you understand what your looking at becuase its intrigiuing.
Hard to image what it must have been like.. Again this is a must see sight but it is hard to imagine what it was like when it was the center of the civilized world.

wow - enjoy the taste of the ancient roman center. Great to be in the center of old Rome. You can walk into Augustus original house, walk on original roman streets and visit the ruins of old temples, houses, and market places.

Rainy Day, but Still Great!. We got rained on during our visit, but it was still wonderful. We had a guided tour from Walks of Italy. You really need to take your time in here and learn about each section. I can see that it can be easy for someone to breeze through here quickly, but don't. There are highly significant stories to learn about in every corner.
Breathtaking!!. It is amazing to be able to admire the ruins. There is so much history there!!!
Needs more signs. Although it was great to see the ancient ruins it got a little confusing what was what so more signage would be good!
Somewhere to spend a few hours. So easy to spend a good 3 hours there just wondering around. Very easy to get lost as there isn't many signs!
Not really interesting. There's not much to see here to be honest. Just ruins, when much of the rest of Ancient Rome is still standing.

A Must See!!. This is a site in Rome that cannot be missed!! We spent hours just roaming around taking it all in. It is so full of history and beauty. It's all outdoors, so make sure the weather will be pleasant while roaming through. Enjoy!! I know we will return some day!
Need a good imagination!. Some very impressive areas but a lot of empty spaces and areas where you need a good imagination to believe what is said used to be there

Wow..... I didn't really have any preconceived ideas when I came to Rome and happened upon this purely by accident when at the Colloseum - WOW! You will be blown away by this area - reasonably pried and you can combine it with a tour of the Colloseum as well. Step back in time to the Roman Empire as you see these original columns and watch the archeologists unearth more....
Beautiful. A beautiful place. Its historical importance is huge but I liked it for the peace, quiet and the stark beauty of the old columns.
The Views Were Fantastic. I wouldn't say you MUST go here, but if you buy a ticket to the Colosseum, it includes the Palentine, so you may as well take advantage. It is really beautiful.
Trajic. You have to visit this, but it is such a crime how this got destroyed by the romans themselves after the fall of the empire, they stripped everything bare.

Fantastic views!. I didn't really expect much from the Palatine Hill but I really enjoyed my visit here. It was nice to take a leisurely walk around the park and there were some wonderful views of the Colosseum and the Forum. Plus, it's included in your ticket to the Forum and Colosseum. Worth it!
Nothing grand. Not such so much worth a visit. It is mainly a place were locals take their dogs for a walk.

Wonderful history. I have to admit- I just liked stretching my legs and doing some walking up a hill, in the fresh air- and the place itself is, of course, fantastic. A must see after a trip to the Colosseum.
historical centre. a large area of ruins some impressive, others not so, the tunnel on top gets you cool and the main drag from the arches lets you imagine the roman era
Amazing!. Loved the fact that you could wander around at your own pace and leisure. Nothing to dislike (-:

Overwhelming. You see why "all roads led to Rome"
I include Palatine hill, esp. domus augustana.
Take good shoes!

A walk into history. A must when you go to Rome! Be sure to have enough time to sit and take it all in, and if you have the chance, join one of the guided tours, a good guide will make the place come alive in ways you can't get by just reading a guide book. ( I listened in on a guide from the company "SPQR", and he was excellent! I will go with them next time!) Once you are there, it is also very nice to walk up to thePalatine hights. It gives even a better impression of how life must have been at the time of the old Romans. I arrived from the Circo Massimo side, and must admit I had a hard time finding the main entrance (all around, and at the other side ...) - very few signs indicate where to go.

A Tremendous Historic Site, The Audioguide was Poor. The history of this site is astounding. It might have been better with a tour guide as the Audioguide for this site was dissapointing. It seemed out dated and the guide markers were gone or not clearly visible. The Neronian Cryptoportico was quite fascinating. There must have been some kind of special celebration of Nero when we were there are there were special programs at various sites that we were unaware of.
Bus tour. If travelling out of season you can see more from the open top bus tour than walking as not all sights are open.
Excellent views. It is a good thing I have a digital camera to capture mass quantities of photographic treasures here.

One can just imagine what ancient Rome was like.... Unforgettable experience - to walk through the ancient city, centuries after the great empire had fallen. Shame about the scaffolding here and there, would've been utter magic without it.

Amazing Ruins, another must see when in Rome.. Be prepared to spend a day walking around here and Palantine Hill. Bring plenty of water and snacks as there are no cafes or shops once inside the complex. Worth the visit as there are so many ruins in the one area.
Historians heaven. Try to avoid going during the summer months as the entire area is a suntrap. Instead enjoy in autumn or spring, fabulous outing for families
A lot of walking. One can really imagine the political intrigues and plots being hatched at that place. The debates, it is really a marketplace.
Lots of walking on rough ground. Interesting but too much walking for limited benefit.

This place is a part of our history. Right across the street from Colosseum, this place must be visited. Imagine a acheological site in the open! This is exactly what this place is: a part of ancient rome open to our eyes.
fantastic. A lot of walking around, take sandals! everything here is worth a look, always go for the guided tours if you can afford it.

What little is left..... You have to be very imaginative here but buy a book from one of the street vendors which shows the before and after pictures. My favourite part here was the burial place of Julius Caesars ashes. After Rome win a football game, it's a tradition for the fans to bring flowers to place here!
Absolutely brilliant.. Just be prepared to do a lot of walking and hope for good weather! There are, however, plenty of places to sit down and have a rest.

Very large & not worth walking through. We went by it and took pictures but did not go inside because it is so big & my kids would be too exhausted. wesaw it all from top of hill with a private driver. That was enough.
Very interesting. My partner and I spent a long time wandering around the ancient ruins and thoroughly enjoyed ourselves. It was wonderful trying to imagine what things once were..
The heart of Rome. All of the temples are her, and the Senate. You can steel feel the power of the Empire. Very interesting
Mind-blowing.. We used the Rick Steeves' podcast to walk us through it. It is simply mind-blowing and almost incomprehensible to fully intake all of the history contained in this place.
Enchanting ruins!. Buy a flip book cheap from a vendor and see what the ruins looked like before! It really enhances your sightseeing!

Romantical, historical, cultural, wonderful.. Don't arrive with a limited amount of time. This isn't an area you want to rush through. So much to see. It's SO neat to be there and even be able to walk through and touch the old remains. Don't skip anything here, one area might look the same from a distance but every time you turn a corner you find something new and unique.I recommend having a picnic on the grounds!Don't forget your camera.
Worth a quick visit.. Right next to the Colosseum, you will find old ruins from the Roman Empire.

VERY HOT!!. Loved this place! it feels like walking around a film set, and never quite sinks in that you're walking through a piece of ancient history.. take lots of pictures! It's a huge open area so wear a hat and cover up at the hottest times as shade is hard to find!

so many things to learn. I must honestly say I have not remembered much of historical data we were bombarded with. There is so much history in this place, you should stay for years to learn the meaning of every stone. However, it is impressive to hear that every building, pillar, drawing has its story. There are drinking water fountains around when you get tired, especially if you combine this visit with the previous visit to the Colloseum. But, it is worth it.

Must do when in Rome. My fiancé and I went to the ruins after the Colosseum, and I absolutely loved it. We went there two days in a row. We spent the entire day walking around. Next time we go I plan to have a little picnic and spend the day there. It was one of the best things I did in Rome. I can't wait to go back.
History!. Not to be missed. Be sure you have a travel book so you know all the history you're experiencing.

Worth visiting. A little disappointed, as there are better ruins in places like Jordan, England, and Libya, but certainly worth a visit. Recommend a guided tour to understand history as it relates to the ruins. Avoid midday during summer as it is blazing hot and exposed.

WORTH A VISIT AFTER THE COLLESEUM. Followed with a tour after the colleseum and it was worth it. I would not have enjoyed if we wandered on our own. You need the guide to explain what everything is. Worth the trip while you are in the area. Interesting info and learnt alot from our very passionate tour guide. Thumbs up for this one.
Historically important. Basilicas and the house of the senat are impressive
Amazing History. I thought it was cool to walk down the same streets that once were strolled by Roman Senators.
If you love (or even like) ancient history you must visit!!!. Absolutely surreal experience to see the remains of an ancient empire. Walk, ponder, enjoy!

All day project. I stayed there for six hours just because I loved it so much. Sit down and relax in the sun, surrounded by history but before you go, read about it so that you know what you are looking at. Many buildings are just ruins today. The view is staggering, and don't forget to see the gardens.
Self tour a little confusing. We didn't book a tour - thought self tour would be okay. You need a tour guide to gain history of individual items - even tour book and audio system was confusing.
Historical. We enjoyed seeing the ruins and architecture of the area. It is amazing to go a few blocks and see the old city still unearthed around a sprawling metropolis.
Forum. Very interesting/informative, took the guided tour
Roman glory. Remains of the past roman glory. You definatelly need a book- advisor because of the history hided behind the structures. I was impressed by their nice condition.

Rome's rubble is living history. Less busy than the Colusseum. Worth a leisurely two hour visit in summertime, walking slowly through the ruins watching for delicate stone carvings, columns and paved roads. A great place to read your guide book and identify where you are resting up reading your 3 dimensional map of ancient rome.

Rome's top monument. This is an archeological site that is and has been open to the public for centuries really. It is the most important of the Roman building sites left. You can take a tour or just wander on your own but it is difficult to cover it all in one day because it is so large. So several trips are needed. If possible try to go in the off season as it is very hard to see with huge crowds or in extreme heat. So much is left one really can imagine an active living rome as long as you have a good guide book telling you about each part. Read up on it and take a map and as well as the guid book and you will not be dissappointed.
nice. Great bit of sightseeing if you like crumbly ruins! nice bit of history. beware of the sun though, as there is no shelter, lots of walking to do too!
Bring plenty of water!. Must see in Rome, be prepared to do lots of walking, multiple small museums inside. I would reccomend a guided tour, if you are at all interested in the history.

Unbelievable!. A must do after visiting the Colosseum. It's a long walk, but well worth it. Visit Augusta house and the museum up on Palpatine Hill. Make sure u have guide because the history is vast.

"A funny thing happened on the way to the Forum". Except for being charged now, I suppose the money goes towards the up keep in that case thats fine.Mind you, as a consequence of this, we saw The Palatine Hill this time because they charged (you go in that way) and that was very nice so it turned out ok in the end!!
Roman hike ! lol. Loved all the history here couldn't get enough! Make sure you have a water bottle handy, but there is plenty of drinking water available.
Outside, enjoy it with nice weather, use Roma pass. It's outside, use the forum entrance and buy Roma pass, shor t line - 5 people or so. Great outdoor adventure, great view to other diections.

Ancient Rome bought to life. I'm a history buff so for me this was amazing. To walk in the footsteps of the ancient Romans was incredible and at times I could almost picture them.We had a great guide who bought it all to life and helped to put things into historial perspective. My friend isn't such a history nut as me and the guide really helped her to get the best out of the visit.As you walk around the ruins you can imagine how this must have looked back in Ancient Rome.Our guide showed us the place where Julius Ceasar was murdered and there are still flowers here to this day. That's the power that Ancient Rome still has and you can really feel it here.

Great Preservation. I think that Americans are unaccustomed to having parts of old (REALLY old!) buildings standing around in areas where newer buildings exist as well. We usually tear them down. Fortunately for us all, somebody had the good sense to save much of the ruins of the Forum for posterity. Very impressive.
Awe Inspiring. Truly one of the most amazing walks through history available in the world. Even 11 year olds can't help but feel the power of the ruins and appreciate the wherewithal of ancient Rome.
Ruims all the way. It is a huge place full of ruins !! Recommended an audio guide cause there is no explanation to anything
Essential Roman history. Wonderful history. Much beauty, even if some in ruins. Impressive. Good explanations. Rough walking surfaces.
history. the site is extraodinary,, could have spent days discovering it better.
Great. You can use the same ticket fron the Colosseo.It's really nice to walk it in a sunny day!!

nice views. You do have to walk up this hill not a difficult walk but I would wear comfy shoes. Beautiful views over parts of Rome and of the colesseum. A nice place to sit and relax especially if you have already done a lot of walking around the forum. The water fountains are safe to drink from you will see them around the Vatican as well. Worth a walk up if you are already visiting the forum.

great views. If visiting this and the colosseum go here first as the queues are less. The audio tour for this was informative but to be honest I got a little bored after a while not sure if it was because it was so hot or just because there is so much to listen to. When getting the handset you have to leave ID which means you have to walk all the way back which you may say is not far but when you have spent hours walking around in the heat it seems like an age, we ended up taking our tour back early as did not want to walk round Palatine hill as well with it, which can be included on the audio tour. Parts of the ruins can be seen from the road in most can be but it is still nice to walk around other parts and from palatine hill you do get a great view of the forum and the colosseum. Worth going in for these views.
Travel Back in Time. Step where once Emperors and peasants alike once stepped. Magnificent to see those structures and churches around there.

History well preserved. Romans(italians) care for their history, and they do their best to preserve it well. it will be evident from this site. This place is worth at least half a day of your trip. If you are serious obout historic sites, then be prepared before visiting any attraction in Rome. It has so much to offer. If you do not have a guide, you can download audio guide by Rick steves which has interesting insights. if not, lonely planet book can be handy. Remember, this is one of the places, where julius caeser lived and walked.

Pretty cool. The ruins are pretty awe inspiring when you know the history. Make sure you know the histiry or it will all just look like a bunch of old stuff to you. A tour guide might enrich your experience here.Colosseo tickets cover this site and vice versa.

Piece of history. This is a piece of history worth visiting while in Rome. Do either get a guide or download and use the Rick Steves free audio guide to learn the deep history behind these majestic pillars and structures. Definitely a must!

Its history.... If I didn't have a guide that showed me how it looked like and what each building was for I would have hate it.
It would benefit a lot by a better signals... so bring your guide with you!

Lots to see. Great place to visit, helpful hint download on ITunes the Podcasts for Italy Audio Tours. They are free and will tell you everything about the sites without having to spend the extra money on the headsets. Ticket comes with the Colosseo ticket. Probably our favorite site to visit, wonder around on the hillside, most people stayed on the ground level.
A lot of bits and pieces around. You should see a picture of what it looked like originally so you can appreciate this more. There isn't a lot left standing - understandably
The Centre of the World 2000 years ago. Wander around the government buildings of the Roman Empire bewildered at the sheer size!
Great History. This was a really cool thing to see. After you're there for an hour or so it becomes same ol same ol though. But great thing to see after you have seen the Coloseum.
Bring Your Imagination. Although it looks like a bunch of rubble and marble, imagine what once stood there. The history, emperors, battles, gatherings, etc.

amazing site poor signage. allow plenty of time maps and signage very poor as on different
levels so can be confusing if hire audio guide must return to
entrance cannot use other exits near the main site
excellent. excellent history and artifacts. lots of well preserved pieces of rock. plan to spend at least 3 hours between forum and colloseum if not more

If you're touring Rome in 3 days. We toured Rome on foot over a 3 day period, and we went here after visiting The Coliseum. We had an English speaking tour guide for the Palatine Hill (he came as part of the tour guide service from the Coliseum). He gave us a cursory overview of the Forum while touring the Palatine Hill ruins.
Ancient Rome. Certainly there must be thousands of reviews of this remarkable place which is right in the middle of a major European capital city. Just go!
Where the Roman emperors lived. Like Hadrian's villa the Palatine is very poorly maintained.
History. An essential part of the history of modern Man. The engineering and architecture is amazing, if you consider that all this was carried out several centuries back.

History before your eyes. This place tells the story of ancient Rome like few others. Be advised: it's huge, hilly and a lot of strenuous walking, but it really shows how the original city was laid out.

You can't just look at it. You have to explore it.. It's an amazing feeling to think about all the history under your feet here and to imagine the people who walked here and the things that happened. If you don't really have much interest in the history, it's not lost on you. The architecture and views here are truly magical, particularly on sunny days. It makes for awesome photos! Don't miss this experience for sure.

get a guide.. Its packed full of 2000 year old bulidings which made up the city centre back in the day. Its a must do if your in Rome. However I would strongly advise going on a group tour, its pretty cheap and gives you much needed information as there is no signs inside the forum and is not self explanatory like the collosium.
A vast area of antqities in central rome. Easy to get to in central Rome. It is a vast site and not well marked so difficult to understand. Would not be very accessible for everyone.

So tiring. If you have a tour guide it might be more interesting, but if you don't, you just end up walking for hours to get through it. It is neat in some areas, but it is so spread out and just has a lot of crumbled rock and pathways - it would have been more beneficial to have a tour guide to draw my interest. But it may have taken even longer to get through in the dead heat without any shade. Bring water.
Must See. Children were amazed by viewing a dig so closely.

Get a guide!. The Roman Forum and Palentine Hill are worth visiting but do get a registered guide or an audio guide. There is too much to take in and wandering at will through a maze of ruins can be bewildering. I did have an introductory booklet but even that didn't do justice to the sites. Go first thing in the morning. You need a good amount of time to make the most of this visit
Good. Price included in your Colosseum and an interesting place to visit, like a big park with roman ruins

worth a look. even though this is a very historical and important site in rome it hasn't got the "wow" factor like alot of it make sure you get the head set otherwise you wont know what you are looking at ! but still a must see of rome

Just a few more signs & details please..... Its a fascinating place but many locations in it are not signed or the signs are confusing, others, oddly are really well explained....Take a good guidebook & map
a must. and you should do this with Walks of Italy---small group ( 8 )---great guide and pace perfect!
Impressive. Astonishing vistas! Impressive places! Great atmosphere! Will come again!
worth the visit. made all the more inteersting with the use of a private guide who explained the ins and outs of the ruins and columns we saw and painted a picture for us

Use a guide. With a guide - a fascinating walk along the sacred way and day in the life aof ancient Rome.
Without a guide - piles of rocks with a few pillars in between of which you will make no worthwhile sense unless your are a history scholar.
I reccommend Roam-around tours for a guide, you won't be dissapointed.
History. Go to see and understand what Rome must of felt like. Most of it is in ruins, but use your imagination. Buy a phamplet(guide) to understand the historic markers..
Awsome ancient ruin.. Simply awesome but tiring. If you attempt this on a hot day, take plenty of water. Ruin after ruin can get a bit too much, but it is something you cannot miss.
Ancient Rome. So interesting to see these remains. Would be helpful to have more information and guidance on how it all was, but its amazing to be here.
Historical ruins. It was wonderful to be able to travel through ancient relics - put on a good pair of walking shoes!

Great for ancient history lovers. if you love ancient history (just like me) you will relish at what the forum has to offer. although some may consider it to be 'just a pile of ruins' (as one person in our tour group expressed), if you love your ancient history it is hard not to get carried away with envisioning all the buildings that would have stood in the Forum
very interesting. great to see the temple of the vestal virgins. Impeccably taken care. at the same site you can also visit the Romolo temple inside part of a catholic church.

Huge area that will take all day. Give yourself enough time to see this as there are 100's of ruins, buildings, etc. to wonder at. I had no idea of the scope of this area and recommend a day just for it alone.
Another most see in Rome. It never fails to amaze me on all my visits to Rome and I have leave without visiting
Don't pay to go in - just look from the gardens. Don't pay to go in - just look from the gardens. Nice for a wonder around but go at night for a different view altogether.
Alot of history.. Walking within the ruins is always amazing. Very clean and so much history. Close to Colusseum.

Study before heading there. We spend almost 3 hours in these place, like the rest of Rome this place is full of history, but I think you will enjoy the place better if you study it before going there and have tons of imagination, because the place is a ruin, unless you know what you are looking at, otherwise it's just a lots of broken rocks. But if you have guide or study the place a bit, then it become a important place for history.
So much history. What a great place, so much history. Download the tour from Rick Steve's on your iPod. It's free and there is so much info. Loved this place
Walk in Their Steps. I loved the ideas of being at the same level as the "original" Rome. This area allow the imagination to take you back. It's a must do for me.

See this-make the walk-no regrets.. The place from which the Romans ran the whole Empire. TIP: get a replica of what it looked like before the wreckage. You'll get any idea of it's greatness. Walk it with the Caesars, then get
a great overall view from behind the Campodoglio.

Recommend a tour to see this. It is no doubt impressive in terms of history and world dominance at the time, however today it is a bunch of ruins. I did a tour with Walks of Italy that helped to bring the ruins alive and I could visualise life in those days. Well worth the cost of the tour to enhance the experience.

Get a Guide!. We had only the map that came with our Colosseum audio tour, which gave us place names, but no details. I knew that cool things had happened in the Forum, and I know I must have walked past some of them, but I have no idea where they were. Even then, though, it was worth it to know that we were in an area where so much history had happened. Without a guide (person or book), though, the kids were rather bored of walking around looking at things that didn't have a whole lot of meaning for them.

Like the Collsseum a must see location. This is a 'must see' for anyone going to Rome. I would suggest you purchase a Roma pass to get around the long ticket line. Admission is included in the Roma pass as well as access to one other site (we used it fo the Forum) and all puiblic transportation.
Wonderful. History, history, history!!! So interesting. A lot of walking but well worth it.

Incredible site, I'd highly recommend some kind of guide/audioguide. Due to scant information available from signage, I think to have a more meaningful visit and to appreciate the historical significance of each part of the Forum it would be advisable to get either a tour guide or audio guide.We downloaded the free Rick Steves mp3 guide onto my iPhone - it was actually of fantastic quality, easy to follow and made the experience a lot more meaningful - http://www.ricksteves.com/news/travelnews/0602/rome_downloads.htm if you're interested. It was lucky we had that, as to borrow an audio guide at the gates you required official ID (eg. Passport) which we didn't have. It may also be worthwhile to visit the Pantheon first, to give you an idea of what Roman buildings looked like (as it apparently looks more or less the same as it did back then), before you try and imagine the grandeur of some of the ruined buildings in the Forum. Enjoy - it was really amazing!
Interesting. Visited on a beautiful sunny day and spent an hour walking amongst the ruins imagining how it would have looked 2,000 years ago.
So much to see. THe history here is mind boggling! We could have gone back again and again as it was hard to see everything there was to see.
A bit disappointing. We were a little disappointed as a lot of the sites were closed off so couldn't see everything

Walking amid a remarkable history.. So much happened in this place that it beggars the imagination. We spent three hours here and only scratched the surface. I wish I had done more research so I could have appreciated it more.
That's where the old Romans lived.. And partially that's what you came to Rome for to see. So an absolute must, especially the two triumph arches.
By a Guide. A fascinating place, but the placquards are not the most informative so take a good guide book
november in Rome. Ticket for here 12 euro and gets you into the Collosium - good value

Beautiful place to spend some time. This is a beautiful place to take some time to relax and wander about. There are great views of the city and the forum. If you are a photographer or artist, this is heaven. This is also the place to buy your ticket for admission to the Colosseum and the Forum because the line is always short. You can then bypass the long line at the Colosseum and walk right in.

This is why I came to Rome. If you have any interest in the history of ancient Rome, this is where to soak in it. The forum is saturated with sites of significant historical interest. Do a little research before coming to really appreciate what is here.

Well worth the time and money. I visited this along with a Colosseum and Palantine Hill on a combined ticket, which is well worth the money. Plus the ticket is valid for 2 days! There is so much to see as this is a vast area of buildings, gardens, monuments and exhibitions. There is so much to see and do and there is an amazing view of Rome from the highest points of the gardens. The scale of area is only really apparent when you're at the lowest point of the area, surrounded by the huge buildings and arches. Amazing.

Walking around the Palantine area. Much of this area is under construction this month, but it is still interesting to walk through. Very steep and pretty rugged trails in some spots, but gorgeous views.
Excellent. Spent hours wandering around and so much to see. Well worth seeing and spending time there. Forget rushed tours that only take you to the main bits, do the rest too.

An essential if you go to Rome. The ruins of the ancient city centre situated between the Colosseum and the Victor Emmanuel monument. Ruins are ruins - there's little more to be said - but they are well worth a visit. To overlook and get the best photo go up to the Campidoglio, behind Victor Emmanuel, bear right and then left between the buildings, under a little bridge and you will find a splendid vantage point.
Beautiful and I wish I would have allowed more time. If you like to wander around beautiful scenic places, please donàt rush yourself. Allow a few hours here.
Allow enough time to fully appreciate the extent. A large open space with many Roman remains. Allow plenty of time (a full day) to be able to explore the whole area. Bring water and a picnic.

So old!. You can't fail to be impressed when you realise just how old and historically significant this place is. It's a shame there isn't any information within the site, so you know what you're looking at. You must do your homework before or after your visit.

The Forum & Palatine Hill- Where civilization moved to a higher level from primal status. To walk through the forum and palaces on the palatine hill brings alive all the ancient history that was the center of the empire and center of the known world

A not to be missed sight. It is one of the not to be missed sights of Rome, however, if you visit the Colosseo first, you will probably be very tired with the uneven walkway around the forum. Take sun block if it hot as you will be out in the open with no shade for quite some time. If you have the energy to walk to the garden above, you can get some cracking photos.

equal to Coloseum. Allow lots of time, there is so much to see! Also provides good views of city. Take a good guide book or get the (audio)guide as otherwise there's not much info on display. Beware of the closing time, the officious wardens will literally whistle you out like herding sheep....

Better when it was free.. Alas you now have to pay to walk through the Forum. I haven't been back to walk thought it since charges were brought in. Its an interesting place to visit and you can't help feeling you're stepping back a couple of thousand years in time
I have goose bumps (remembering being there).. So much history! Take your time and bring your imagination and go with a local guide if you can. All roads lead to Rome.
When in Rome ..... Lots to see and wander in and out of the ruins. A bit more in the way of signs and information would have been helpful
To touch and see and feel the past. Who stood where I did? What was discussed here. Italy surely has their hands full trying to restore their past.

interesting site with lots to see.. Try to get a good tour guide to walk this site. There is a lot of history and a good guide will bring it to life. Definetly worth a visit. A fair amount of walking required with a hill at the start.
wonderful. Another historic site I studied in school. It must have been quite a site thousands of years ago...I could image chariots and people on the stone street

Take maps, do the work. This will mean nothing unless you find some very good maps and read thoroughly before you go; Amanda Claridge's Oxford Archaeological Guide-Rome -will help; there are also some very good downloadable 3D depictions on YouTube; a good idea is to use the vantage points around, especially the newly [re]opened observation platform on the Vittorio Emmanuale monument- the white typewriter at the northern end

Great place to run your imaginations. Walking this sight is a little energy consuming (lot of ground to cover), but it is a great place to use your imagination (little more than in colosseum) and imagine how things were way back when.

history comes to life. you seen it in books in school now you can relive the history. the entrance is near to the colliseum. the area of this site is huge so good walking shoes is required. also a camera to relive the area when you get home

A must do tour. We followed along Rick Steve's free tour app. It was perfect. Not too long or short. The history is just amazing to see and hear. I thought it was better then the colosseum but that's just me.
Very cool!. Saw this on a tour. Too much history to do it without a guided tour. A great place for photos.
Make sure you have your walking shoes on.. Fascinating site, that was only spoilt by the amount of areas currently being renovated.
Breathtaking!. U will be really greatly impressed by the beauty of the Roman Forum next to the Collosseum!!!!!

The Palatine hill shouldn't always be last. As Romulus killed his brother and defined the "Pomerio", the physical limit to define Rome, the first Romans lived up on the Hill of the Palatine. Augustus created his palace then Domitian filled it with earth and built on top of it his own even larger palace and Nero his Domus Transitorio. Different tiers of history. Archeology would seem to be about defining the different periods, firstly from the layers. The great thing about archeology is nothing is for sure, all the great ones will give you at least three stories for each subject. Also you have to use your your imagination, eliminate certain parts, to imagine what it was like in this or that period, fascinating! It actually made me depressed at one point to realize what tremedous wealth the Flavian Emperors had and how even with all there power, how Rome fell in the end... if you buy your ticket for the Palatine just do the Palatine, take a sandwich up there with you and stay all day.

Take your time and see it all.. Study in advance of the trip or find a guide, this is hard to figure out without help. The ruins aren't really labeled so you have to work at understanding what you are looking at.

imagine how the lived.... it´s a place where everyone should go. it shows how roman politicians lived, you can see walls full of original paintings, there are lots of conserved pavements, and things are still being discovered. it´s full of trees. but you will take at least half a day to see everything.

Ancient history today. I loved that there is so much to see, and that you can just wander between the ruins and imagine what it was like. The only downside is the lack of signage, so you don't know what things are, so take a guidebook with you. I suppose in many ways it makes it more natural not to have signs. You get a real sense of history there, it's really thought-provoking

historic. i liked walking around and seeing everything, i feel that if you're up for it a guide might be a good fit because he'd explain everything, however, if you like walking around by yourself do it, it's also very much fun.
A must see in Rome!. Amazing history here!! I did a tour with Rome Walks and they provided a wonderful commentary with detailed history.
history brilliant. long walk again but steeped in history well worth it

Take a 2000 year walk..... First of all, you can see it without paying a dime because it is located in an open space and lots of people just take pictures from all around without entering.But i firmly recommend getting inside. I really felt that an ancient Roman would come by and say hello to me! These ruins seem so fresh and modern as the flowers that people leave on the place where Ceasar died!!
Putting your walking shoes on.. Another site that needs time and lots of walking. It is to take a lot of photos.
Rome of the history books. All the history of Rome I'd done at school came to life here. Wish I'd visited before I had to learn it.

Forum. We saw the forum along with our visit to the colosseum both places were great to see. The size and the thought that these places have been there so long is amazing and are something to see. I wonder if the Italian people realize that they are really living in such an historic place!

Wear sturdy shoes!. visiting Rome always means a considerable amount of walking but the Palantine Hill particulalrly so. Its a wonderful place with exceptional views and a wealth of things to see - don't miss the Emperor Augustus house which you may have to queue to see but is just stunning inside.We loved the space just to walk as so many of Romes attractions can get very busy but the Palantine - even with the ubiquitous tour groups never felt packed.
Could take it in from afar. Walked the outside perimeter but did not go in. Would probably appreciate it more if guided inside as it is a massive area with probably lots of details to take in

Oh, wow!. This area is the archaeological dream come true of Italy! Digging here has revealed a historical roads, columns, courtyards, etc. You're time in ancient Rome need not be purely in your imagination. This area is both fascinating and beautiful. As you climb the hill, you travel through ages of Rome's history. Atop the hill are splendid views of Rome. If you have kids who like the assassins creed video games, lure them here by telling them that they'll be in the game! An amazing sight to see.
Feel the history!. This was a truly awesome trip back in time. Could feel the history of this place & picture Julius Caesar walking the streets of the forum.

Massive. Its a massive place, right next to Colosseum. I bought a combined ticket for roman forum and Colosseum. There is an option to buy the ticket online, you can beat a 5 km long queue by paying couple Euros extra...!!
Wonderful! Do in combination with the Colosseum. Full of history and culture, this literally is the birthplace of western civilisation. It's a must do!
WOW. Excellent, again i was speechless. Its great, gives you a lot of thinking about the Romans and how they could do it.For poeple who are in love with history-excellent
Interesting Ancient Ruins. Mostly ruins with a few columns standing. Would have been helpful to have signs up telling you what they were, but I guess they want you to buy the audio guide!
Interesting chaos. A very interesting place, although somewhat chaotic. I'd always assumed the senators met in a circular room (as portrayed in most films), when as I learnt it was rectangular.

huge. At first we thought there would not be much too the ruins but when you get inside it is huge. There are lots of buildings that have walls. You need some background with audio tape or tour to really appreciate what you are seeing.

Some much to see. Leave time to see it all. Suggest you allow 90 minute and take one of the Rome books that are sold in the city to compare what it looks like today with what it looked like 2000 years ago.
Some Assembling Required. Its really interesting to see the columns on the ground - just laying there - some that you can sit on... the ones standing are beautiful and... majestic

This is Ancient Rome. Obviiously very ruined, so an interest in rome's Classical period makes it 5* for me, whereas it might be 3 or 4* otherwise. Still, there's the Senate building and the (not very well marked) funerrl pyre of Julius Caesar (really just a pile of bricks, so not interesting to everyone). Some kind of guide would help.

Time travel. I liked everything of this site, it is just perfect. Actually I visited it twice in a week. The first time I had a superficial visit and I didn't really understand the matter of it. I bought a book and I studied the Forum and ancient roman life, not deeply but with a bit of passion.When I went back there the world opened an I was there 2000 years ago, vividly imagining what was going on there. I was amazed by myself and by the place, please do not be superficial, enjoy time travelling

A MUST VISIT - WHILE IN ROME. The rich history and architeture is mind blowing. Take the time and go with a tourguide because you will miss a lot of stuff. Like Cesar's tomb, which doesnt look like a tomb at all. Magnificent works of art, while in decay, still beautiful. We went in Oct, 2010 as part of a Globus Tour. NOTE: Uneven surfaces, not for people in wheelchairs. A lot of walking.
Amazing!. A truly amazing site to visit, but to get the most out of it book with a tour guide. Our guided tour included the Colosseum.
History. I could almost hear Julius Caesar speak! But watch out for the people dressed up who con you into having photos taken with them!
Great place. Buy a Roma Pass and visit this and the Collesium counts as one entry and gets you past the queue!

A great flash back with the Romans. Don't go during the day ! if it's hot you will die and people are everywhere.We went around 4pm, the crowd is less present and the light from the sun was just perfect for the pictures.It was really nice to walk around and imagine ourselves in the old times.Trick: The line to buy your ticket is little and it gives you access to the Colosseo, where you will skip the looong line !
A lot of walking but worth it. Since the last time I was there they have done much more excavation. A one of a kind place for history. What a culture!
great ruins. if you like ruins these are the ones to see, and they were right out our hotel room window!
So much to see. Needs time and a good, detailed guide book and map in order to work out what each bit is and where.
The live history. The signs and map is not clear. Water source is difficult to find.

Great but not buggy friendly!. Very good site to walk around and take in the sheer size of the monuments etc. On a nice day has great views of the city below too. We enjoyed our afternoon here despite having to carry the buggy over a lot of the ground - would definitely recommend a carrier if taking baby along for this one!

TIMES ARE A CHANGING. You once were able to wander in here free of charge and pick up a guide for a few Euro/dollars. No more which is such a pity. However this is the cradle of Rome and you should get a full guided tour to understand the importance of this site.

Fantastic Forum steeps you in history. The Forum is a great place to visit whether you love history or not. If you're an ancient history buff, you could spend several hours here. If not, this is still worth the visit to see the stunning ancient ruins. The Garden of the Vestal Virgins within the Forum is a great place to rest amidst this somewhat hot and dusty setting. While we were there, students were conducting archelogical digs on the perimeter of the Forum and it was interesteing to watch them as they worked.

Wow - Amazing History. Great attractions! Highly recommend. We bought a combination ticket at Palatine Hill. At the same time we also purchased the audio headset which I would not recommend since it is difficult to follow. If you purchase your ticket at Palatine Hill the line is much shorter than at the Colosseum.
Walking through the Roman empire. You feel you could just fill in the pieces with your mind and be transported to Ancient Rome. Beware of the sun in summer!

Use your imagination!. There is much to see in this place, so take your time and plan at least a half day to take in most of it. We were short on time and it was hot, so we focused on Palantine Hill and to make the overlook of the old forum. Lots of walking, lots of ruins, but if you take the time to read up on what is there, and use your imagination, you can start to get a tiny feel of what ancient Rome was about. A guide would be good here if you want to learn more.

Must do in Rome. After our day in the Colosseum we learn our ticket was good the next day to tour the Forum. What a remarkable place it was. Be sure to explore all the areas and get the amazing pictures from the top of Pallentine hill.
Fantastic place to wander. We stayed very close to the forum and really enjoyed the walk all around it. We got a tour of it as part of the Colosseum tour. I found it very informative and interesting.

Don't miss this. Amazing that you could walk and sit among the ruins. We went shortly before closing and there were no crowds. Allow yourself enough time to explore it thoroughly. Wear the proper footwear, it is easy to trip and fall.
When I saw it first time, I felt like in the Roman Empire.. A truly architectural masterpiece with a strong place in history. This combination makes the sight a wonder.

ambiance spoiled by all the construction and fences. We have been here twice before and are glad we got to enjoy it without all the 'construction.' No one actually working, but fences, etc. spoiling the views and spirit of the site.
Footsore. It was okay. Probably getting a little overkill on ruins by the time we visited. Could have done with somewhere to sit down and have a nice cold drink.
Fantastic History. Brush up on the history and ensure you have a map and /or audio guide.This will greatly enhance the trip.
Beautiful views from Monument Vittorio Emmanuelle Bldg. Was closed the day we were there but went up to the top of the Monument bldg and saw magnificient views of city, Vatican, and forum.
A slice of History. Download Rick Steve's free mp3 tour to really enjoy this pile of rocks.

Awe inspiring. This was an amazing site, with so many ruins. Allow plenty of time to browse, not much shade and it gets very warm in the sunshine. the site would have benefitted with some information signs about the various remains, even a small sign giving the name of the building would have helped interpret the site more. A map is essential to understand it. The floor is very uneven and hilly, sensible footwear a must.

Breathtaking. It was extraordinary to see this site. It just took our breath away. There is so much history in Rome and to see that this site has been preserved throughout all of it is a marvel in itself. Get off the tour bus and just walk around to take it in. Truly amazing.
Walk Forever. From either up above on the surrounding walls or down below among the ruins, this historic site is not only a must see but it's a haunting and wondrous treasure.

History in front of your eyes!. It is worth reading up on what you are looking at here. Only then do you really appreciate how incredible it actually is that we are able to experience it. You get an amazing sense of the remarkable history of the place. A real privilege.

Takes You Back in the Time of Historic Rome. Alot of interesting artifacts and architecture. You can imaging a thousand 'swords & sandals' epics featuring this place. Needs a morning at least to explore but it gets busy and is not great for those with walking difficulties.

Fantastic. This site is still being exgavated but the area is so full of history you can feel it all around you as you walk through all the ruins. Very well layed out for visitors, but do wear some strong shoes as you will be doing a lot of walking.
great walk through history. make sure you have a tour guide with audio headsets.
loved it. this was the coolest part of Rome to me, with all you've seen in movies, etc, it really is neat
A must visit. A must visit to appreciate just how things were done back then. Your imagination is required. Try to put yourself back in time,
Go Armed with Information. The placards are few and far between. Take your own information along so you know what you're looking at.
not where Chuck Heston played!. This is not worth the walk. It's an open field, undeveloped and an insult to its history.

Lots of history, but not much to do without a tour. Neat place, but you need to do a tour of it to get context. We did Dark Rome and it was worth the money of the 3-hr tour. Be aware of the horrible bathroom, steer clear if you can.

take your time. There's a lot to see. As recommended, we went early in the morning before seeing the Colosseum, avoiding ticket lines. There's also drinkable water fountain inside, so no need to bring lots of water.
You can see everything without going in.. Don't waste your money, just take a stroll around the perimeter and take your photos.

Bring your imagination. A baking hot autumn day and a detailed audio guide, but out brains were cooked and we had difficulty reconstructing the full picture from the words, unfortunately. Avoid hot weather, and perhaps read up a little before entering to fully enjoy.

Walking shoes required.. Take a guidebook here and make plenty of time. You shouldn't rush this one. It is truly a step back in time into a world long gone. One tip: there's a public toilet at the northeast exit, but you have to know how to find it--it's tucked around the corner at the back of the gatehouse. There's drinking water there too and like all the rest in Rome it's cold, fresh, safe, and welcome.
Very Impressive - Very Much To Take In. Well worth a day for the whole thing. We got a guide from Through Eternity - well worth it, because there is so much you can't take it all in without help.

Very interesting but need time and map reading skills. come in the main entrance and definitly start at point 1 we came in the the other entrance and started at the Palatino and it was a bit confusing. Take water and good walking shoea and enjoy.

Very Important. The Forum and Palatine Hill audio guide is very important because you'll see ruins that need to understand what kind of buildings were erected there and understand how impressive it must be all. The points where you should listen to the audio guide are not very well marked so much and look out for is better to start the visit from the entrance to the site for the Via de Fori Imperiali. One of the most beautiful views of Rome from the Palatine Hill is on the forum with the Colosseum in the background.

Skip the line, see it all, and surprisingly entertaining.... Roberto was our guide. Like a Russian Ace Ventura. Very funny guy and had a rapport with the group of roughly 20 people with in minutes. He knew his information inside out. Presented it well and answered any questions with ease.Added bonus is skipping the main line which wasn't huge. Regardless worth it just for the extra information and the opportunity to ask questions.Palatine Hill was great as well. Different guide, very different vibe. Super knowledgable and some great sites, views, actual factuals and well worth it.

Great views of the Co and Forum, but it can eat a lot of time.. Overall I was glad we visited the Palatino. It did provide several excellent photo opportunities, especially the views of the Coliseum and the Forum, but if I did it over again, I would race to the views and spend less time with the rest of the ruins.

A Quiet Escape from the Crowds. Visit the coloseum first. Go early in the morning, then walk a short distance up the hil past the arch to the entrance to palatine hill. You will instantly leave the crowds behind. Visitors flock to the coloseum and the rroman forman but seem to shy away from palatine hill which is full of interesting ruins and quaint gardens. Pick up the handy map at the entrance and map a path that will let you exit into the roman forum. In the midst of the maddness of the crowds in downtown rome, this area is quiet, isolated and almost unpopulated. My grandson and I enjoyed the solitude and the interesting ruins and gardens. We stopped for our midday picnic lunch. Take your time because there are a lot of nooks and crannies to explore. They have excavated the ruins of some of the old houses and restored some of the ancient gardens. Be sure and visit the overlook just beyond the gardens. It is a great view of the forum below. A great picture site and you can see every building below. When you are ready to re-enter the crowds, follow the path to the entrance to the roman forum. Walk down the steps and you are in the forum near the entrance across from the coloseum where the crowds enter, so you won't miss anything. Remember that the palatine hill is include in the combo ticket for the coloseum and the forum.

Audio Guide. I was astonished when the clerk required that I leave as security either my passport or a credit card. She would not accept a cash deposit. With all the talk of identity theft these days of course I refused. We had no such trouble at any of the Museums in Paris.I struck the same thing at Herculaneum, and the Vatican Museum. No doubt the Colosseum would have been the same but the queues were too long, and as we had been there before we moved on.My advice is download mp3 guides, many of which are available free.

The Aeneid comes to life!. We to the Palatine Hill after the Colluseum. We had our packed lunch in the shade of the Arch di Constantin. Palatine Hill was quiet compared to the Colosseum, the entrance is small but quick if you already have your tickets (entrance to the Colosseum allows you to enter the Palatine Hill and Roman Forum as well - and visa versa - currently €12). If you're a pensioner take a copy of your passport for FREE entry, students take your ID for 50% off.There is so much to see, and all of it such a window into the world of Ancient Rome: the House of Livia, the House of Augustus, the Temple of Apollo, the Palace of the Flavii, the Domus Augusta and the amazing Circus of Domitian.There is a small but very informative (free) museum and a fresh water spring to drink from and toilets but otherwise no facilities.The photo opportunities are fabulous and then (after a couple of hours) to wander down to the Forum is just an amazing day out in Rome.

Interesting and evocative... but take a picnic or eat first!. Palatine Hill is a very interesting site and a peaceful and delightful place to wander after the bustle of the Colosseum and other Rome sights. Due to lack of planning on my part, however, we went straight from the Colosseum, wrongly expecting to be able to buy a drink and snack while there. There are no facilities at all and a strict no re-entry policy. Be prepared!

Ruins near the Colosseum. We walked through the Palatine hill after being to the colosseum. Ok to have been there, but not fantastic. A lot of ruins. The maps and signs in the park was informative. We were a bit tired when we was there - after walking all day. Maybe that had something to do with it that we weren`t very impressed.

Some words about management of the site and the audio-guide service. It's a very bad idea to take the tourists' credit cards as deposit for the audio-guide. I did not understand that my card was taken by the cashier and thought that it was either lost or stolen when I was coming away from the cashier's window with the tikets. I got stressed very much and have to call the bank (international call!) to emergently block the card. Maybe, the cashier warned me, but it was impossible to hear her perfectly, because of the plastic glass wall. By the way, the other cashier at nearby window used the loud-speaker. Was my window not equipped with it? Furthermore, after I had found the card absent I asked the officer to check at the cashiers if I had left my card there forgetting to take it after the paying. The officer kindly did it replying that "no, there was no card left at the cashiers". Couldn't he guess I was asking right about the card taken as the deposit?!
