Such situation would be impossible in my native country, Russia, because a credit card is considered to be personalized finansial document, and it cannot be asked or withheld as a deposit by anyone at anycase (because a misusage by other person is possible). Is it OK with it in Italy? So, I regreted very much that I took the audio-guide, further more the sound quality was very bad, it creaked steadily while speaking

Amazing - one of the highlights of Rome. Included in your ticket for the colosseum, is also entrance to the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill. The Colosseum is chaos, the Roman Forum is busy but for some reason the Palatine, is fairly empty....if you dont visit you really are missing out!The one let down for me was the lack of signage, or anything telling you what the area was used for and why it is important. I would therefore recommend taking a good guide book with you, or doing some serious reading beforehand, just to ensure that you get the sense of occasion of the site.There is so much to cover in this area, that you could easily spend a couple of hours here, if not more. Plus if the weather is not too hot, it is a lovely spot to sit and watch Rome from the top of the hill and you get some great views.Some areas worth mentioning are Domitian's Palace built in AD 81, Augustus' house built in AD 1, the Temple of Cybele the Farnese Gardens (great views over Rome from here) and there are numerous others.I would highly recommend this as a historic spot, without the tourists. I felt I really understood ancient Rome when viewing the ruins, which made it a very memorable visit.

Be Transported Back to Ancient Rome. The ruins are incredibly interesting but I would suggest joining a tour group so you have a guide who can take you through and explain what you are looking at. I booked through Dark Rome tours and was incredibly happy with the guide and the information she provided.

A journey in history. A beautiful place where you can get a good picture of ancient Rome. Took a guided tour of the Palatine Hill and had a really great and funny guide named David.Our guide really made it really interesting and made the history come alive.I can highly recommend a guided tour of the Palatine Hill as well as the Roman Forum and Colosseum.
Worth a visit. The Colosseum ticket also includes the Forum and the Palatine Hill.The palatine Hill was worth a visit especially August's house to see the frescoes.

ancient rome as it has been. The Roman Forum (close to the Colosseo) is also a must visit when your in RomeWe suggest to visit the Forum before you visit the Colosseo and buy a 'combi ticket'so you avoid waiting at the Colosseo. The Forum is a very impressive area giving youa perfect idea of the wealthiness and richiness of Ancient Rome. We visited a lot of siteselsewhere (Turkey, Greece, Cyprus....)but according to us none of them can competewith the sites offered in Ancient Rome.

The size of it is huge. One has to be there to see it. its definitely a huge area to visit and please take the time to visit. browsing through quickly just doesn't justify it. tip: get the ticket here for Foro Romano and the colosso, you'd skip the line at the colosseum hehe

Waited for one hour to enter under strong sunbeam. Our family of six arrived at around noon and had to be in the long line under very strong ray from the shining sun, no shade, full one hour. Then we paid EURO 12 multiplied by six including four children, because we are not EU citizen. This is a MUST visit place in Rome, but we should have been much smarter with children 10 and under.The ticket can be used both for Colosseo and foro romano for two days. The better way was visit either place in the late afternoon when it is not so crowded, and visit the rest on the following day, because if you have a ticket, you do not wait in the queue.Another idea is to buy the Roma Pass at 25 EURO which is valid for three days and includes these tickets and metro.

You need a guide. Unless you have a guide this site is not well organised. I know its old but it could be better run, and we hated the Roman Soldiers and people trying to sell tours, even the official guides tried to sell tours.

just ruins. unless you know what you are looking at, book a tour with a guide. The attraction offers a combined ticket with the palatine hill and an audioguide. We did that and it didn't work, we coudn't find our way around [ the map is very confusing]. The second time we went with a guide and we could finally see how it was before and understand the life on the forum. It also helps to buy a book before and after rome on the guys outside the coloseum { haggle on the price, we got ours for 10€ intead of 15€ ).
Historic ruins. It helps to like both history & ruins.. Go in the evening before the sun sets. It is much cooler then.

An Open Air Museum. The Palatine Hill is one of the seven hills of Rome. It was the place where the rich and the famous chose to build their homes. There are nice views of the Roman Forum on one side and the Circus Maximus on the other. Much of the place is in a state of ruins but the Farnese Gardens at the top of the hill are beautiful. Don't miss the Palatine Museum which is covered in your entry ticket. For more details visit my webpage at :http://sites.google.com/site/niluanu/sitemap/travelogue---a-trip-to-italy---ii

very good. you must visit this place it gives you a real insight to what it must have been like in roman days be prepared to do a lot of walking and it is steep in places and very uneven take plenty of water but well worth the visit
History at its best. entrance is at the far left of Constantine Arch, exit at the Titus Arch; download and use free podcast audio guide and map of Rick Srteve.

An interesting stop while in the area.. I visited the Palatine Hill after the Colosseum and the Roman forum; the entry fee is included in the Colosseum ticket. I had the Rick Steve's Rome Guidebook which had a helpful Palatine Hill tour section. The area is very interesting as it gives you an idea of how the emperors lived, the views of the Forum, Colosseum, and Rome as a whole are just amazing, really shows why they decided to live there. Wear very comfortable shoes, there is a lot of climbing and walking around the hill, the experience is very calming as it is not as crowded as the other sites.

Get a ROMA Pass and prepare to walk!. Amazing ruins. You can walk up to the top for a great view below of the ruins. Best way to get in is with a Roma Pass that can be purchased as most Tabacchis to skip the long line. Prepare to walk around so bring good shoes and a hat. Make sure this is one of the few things you do in a day or you will be tired. We never booked a tour but would have liked a tour book or guide. Still, very interesting and surreal.

Globus--The Best Tour of Italy but.... This previous review was very thorough but I would strongly suggest doing a little background research for knowledge before doing such a trip. The Pantheon might have offered light on the gods 1900 years ago but today the Pantheon is a Roman Catholic Church. Though it does not resemble a church because of it's architectural design, it is indeed a church as signified by the large crucifix. Therefore, there are no images of "gods" in the Pantheon. A stunning piece of architecture!

A must see when in Rome. Ticket is 12 euros, which also includes the Colosseum. As I am an EU teacher I got in for the reduced rate of 7.50 euros (EU children are free) so spent 5 euros on the audio guide, with an extra 2 euros to include the Palatine Hill (the birth place of Rome) that you should include as it takes longer to explore than the ruins themselves..There is little information inside so I think having some kind of guide, be it audio or written is worth it. This audio guide is one where you hold it up to your ear rather than having headphones. I did therefore have some tricky moments holding it, along with my umbrella (essential sun shade) and the map. There are no audio guide numbers anywhere within the sie so you have to identify your location on the map and then type in the number. This does present some difficulties such as when the narrator says "look at the column on your left" and you, not having a particular point of reference, can see columns in all directions. It is hot so bring water bottles - there are several fountains within the site from which you can refill bottles or cool yourself down. It can also be very dusty. I had the the audio guide for 3 hours and had to leave to return it as my time was up - it was a rush to get around in this time and I could have stayed longer.

Touristy, hot, lacking information - but interesting!. Very much looked forward to visiting these places and was a little disappointed. Roma Pass was useful for skipping the ques, and we avoided the touts (guide, ear phones - but with 40 others!!) and opted for audio guide (which was fantastic in Pompeii) - very disappointed. Unlike Pompeii there were no highlighted spots on site, only on map to know where to stop and listen. this made it very hard to know what they were talking about - or referring to, even when you thought you were in the right place. Map was poor too especially when some ruins were blocked of and you had to work out how to get to the next number on the other side of the blocked off one. I really recommend a guide with a small personal group if you can manage it - i really feel i would have got more out of the trip that i initially looked forward too. Go late in day to Colosseum for less crowds... E12 for the lot - good value.
HUGE. there is a lot of ground to cover here so give yourself plenty of time. there isn't a lot of information about it so do your research before visiting.

Don't miss it when visiting the colosseum and Roman Forum. As others have said, it's included in your colosseum and Roman forum ticket.We used the Roma Pass (25 euro) which got us into this site (along with the others on this ticket) for FREE. Tickets normally 15 euro. Then got free entry one other museum and discounts everywhere after and free metro and bus rides.You do not need to pay a guide hundreds of euros to take you around this site. It is actually more well labeled than the forum was (we thought) and we had a guidebook (DK EYEWITNESS) which did a phenominal job explaining the layers of history.You are looking at ruins not just from 1 time period and trying to do this site on your own can be confusing. But there is no need to pay someone to tell you what you can read for free online and bring with you (or just get a guidebook like we did). If you don't want to carry the heavy pages with you, then just copy the ones of the palatine hill and bring those.While we enjoyed the roman forum better (we had the free rick steves tour on his iPhone app for that) and enjoyed the history there more... the palatine was still worth it and had some amazing views over rome and the forum! Don't miss it!

Not that special.... It is very big and there is no information available...Most of the time you really don't know what you're looking at.But is is big and impressing.If do think Pompei and Ercolano are much more interesting and pretty

Beat The Crowds. We purchased a ticket on-line which gave you access to The Forum, Palatine Hill and museum, and The Coliseum. We were able to print the ticket at home and skip by the line. Believe me, it's worth it. Why spend an hour or two waiting in line when you don't have to.We took the metro from Termini station and when you come up at the Coliseum metro stop you're smack dab in front of the coliseum. Naturally the hordes of tourist all head straight for that. Don't do it! Head straight to the forum. We arrived when they were just opening and the forum was deserted. It was nice to walk around for about an hour in the forum before the first groups started to arrive (we call them herds of cattle) and then we headed up to Palatine and the museum and again, no crowds. We spent a little over an hour in the forum listening to Rick Steves podcast which is free on I-tunes. I suggest having some sort of a book/audio guide otherwise you won't know what you're looking at. Palatine Hill is really very beautiful and the views of the forum and the coliseum are incredible. We also liked the museum which was nearly deserted. We spent about two hours walking through Palatine hill and we could probably have spent two more.So don't forget... buy your ticket on-line and go to the forum first. It's an incredible feeling walking around in all this history with only a handful of people.

Included in your Colosseum ticket. We left the Colosseum and went to Palatine Hill via the Arch di Constantin. The road between the Colosseum and Palatine Hill was very busy and there were lots of people trying to sell you stuff, just keep your head down and keep moving and they’ll soon move to someone else. Palatine Hill was vey quite compared to the Colosseum, the entrance here is very small so it became a bit chaotic but as we already had tickets (your entrance to the Colosseum allows you to enter the Palatine Hill and Roman Forum as well for no extra cost), we skipped through pretty quickly. We then went to the Forum, again it was so quiet, I think there were 5 or 6 people there which was surprising as the views you get back to the Colosseum are very good. I would recommend visiting the Forum and getting photos of the Colosseum. We were mostly here on our own.

Should not be missed - visit it as part of a trip to the Forum. The Palatine Hill is right next to the Forum and I have found it useful to visit the two together. The Palatine Hill provides some wonderful views of Rome and the Forum and itself has beautiful gardens and extensive remains of Roman palaces. The hill was where many of Romes rich and powerful had their palaces over the centuries and it is fascinating to walk through the remains of their homes.Like the Forum it is not an easy place to visit at all if you have walking difficulties - it's a long walk, quite steep in places and uneven.I do not recall there being much in the way of facilities, signage or explanatory material on the Palatine Hill so make sure that you have some water with you, a guide book and a coat if the weather looks suspect. I got in to the Forum / Palatine Hill very quickly and for free using a 'Roma Pass' which I had purchased before going to Italy.

Roman history you can see and feel. While the Colosseum is more impressive, Palatine Hill and the Forum are more interesting. It's a large area to cover, but there's just so much to see. Whether walking around the Forum or climbing to Palatine Hill, it's history everywhere you look. Much work is being carried out on preserving what's there and unearthing more ruins so it's a little like a construction site too. The crowds gets bigger as the day goes on, so again, get there early if you want to move around more freely. We didn't have a tour guide, but were able to eavesdrop in many places to pick up on what we were looking at. We could easily have overlooked Caesar's resting place if it weren't for being next to a guided tour. While we spent an hour at the Colosseum, we spent several hours wandering the Forum and Palatine Hill. Tip: wear good walking shoes and be careful if it's raining as the pathways get slippery. Overall, this is a must-see place when in Rome .. come to think of it, EVERYTHING in Rome is a must-see!

Incredible Walk Through Time. I have no idea what I was walking through and also no idea if there was a fee to get in? No one asked so I assume it was free? Which is scandalous. This place is far too impressive to be free!! Even a cheapo like me would pay a few Euros. Anyway soak up the history. Better value than the Colisseum. We went up the steps of the nearby (much derided) Vittorio Emmanuelle beforehand and got a different perspective. Combining that and the Forum together make for a nice relaxing aftenoon's walk. You can then undo all that good work by grabbing a pizza and bottle of wine for dinner!!Just one thing though. Rome; please look after your sites a bit better. The tourist is helping your economy no end and yet you seem like you don't care about these attractions!

Even better than Colosseum.. I am an archeology geek, and this is absolutely fabulous. This feels much more authentic than the Colosseum, amazing as it is. It is simply amazing how much of the area is still intact, almost as if the ancient Romans simply packed up and left yesterday, perhaps for a nice little raiding trip in the British isles. The remains of Julius Ceasar especially gave me the chills. I would recommend getting an autoguide or guide, so you can truly get the scope of the history here. Don't miss this spot!!!

Step back in time for a couple hours. Small and manageable as long as there aren't twenty tour groups crowding the grounds this is a must do while in Rome. Included in the admission of the Colosseum this is best visited in the late afternoon since there isn't much shade and slightly less crowds. To walk through ancient Roman ruins is indescribable.

Equal parts history and beauty. Nothing is more enjoyable than walking through Palatine Hill on a sunny September day. The price of the Colosseum includes Palatine Hill and the Forum. One could easily spend a whole afternoon here exploring the ancient Roman ruins, gazing down at the Circus Maximus, lounging in the gardens or just enjoying the stunning views of the city from the top of the hill. Just watch those seriously annoying street vendors upon exiting the Colusseum and walking down Via di San Gregorio. They don't take "no!" for an answer.

check ticket and Livia and Augustus house open times. We might be the only ones to make this mistake, but we weren't careful enough about what the combined Colosseum/Palatine/Forum ticket offered. When we finished visiting the Colosseum we went straight to the Palatine/Forum site. We hadn't even finished visiting the Palatine when it was lunch time. It was very disappointing to find that there is no 'pass out'. We had no choice but to leave and then buy another 12 Euro ticket to get back in to finish the Palatine and see the Forum. Also, the House of Livia and the House of Augustus are highlights of the visit but they are not open every day and they are not necessarily both open on the same day. It is hard to get information on opening times on the internet, so if you are keen to see one or both houses it would be best to check at the ticket office before you buy the ticket.

Walk In The Foot Steps Of The Ceasar. This place is fascinating. Arrive early, book a spot on a guided tour through a reputable guide agency (I recommend Through Eternity) and plan to stay a good long time. Bring one of those guide books you can purchase almost anywhere in Rome and indeed in Canada where you can fold transparencies over the photos of the sights and see what the place used to look like. The wealth of really significant important sights here is stagering. You can see the curia (the Senate), the Temple of Jupiter, the Rostrum, the triumphal arches of Titus and Septimumius Severus, the location of the cremation of Julius Ceasar, the Basilica of Constantine, the Basilica of Aemilia (where you can see the remnants of the sacking of Rome by the Goths - look for the green stains in the rock, they are the melted coins), and so much more. You will walk on the Via Sacra and touch the stones touched by the ancients. The richness of history here is palpable. Take your time and enjoy it. Remember though, you have to go over a few blocks to the Largo Argentina to see where Julius Ceasar was assassinated (a place that is shockingly unexploited and relatively inaccessible). Even so, this is a terrific place to visit and is likely one of my top three places to visit in Rome.

Interesting site. The Colosseum ticket includes visits to Palatine Hill and The Forum - visit both as they are very interesting and provides a lot more information on Roman times that just visiting the Colosseum. Take a guide to get the most out of the time on Palatine Hill - ours, Mark Anthony from Ohio, was very knowledgable certainly enhanced our trip. Wear comfortable shoes as there is much walking involved.

Great companion to the Colosseum. Our tour of the Colosseum with "Discover Rome" included a tour of Palatine Hill, something we didn't originally plan on but thoroughly enjoyed. While the Colosseum is more impressive, the tour of Palatine Hill was actually more interesting. I definitely recommend going with a guide though - by itself, it's largely just ruins; however, with a guide Palatine Hill offers an excellent insight into ancient Rome. This area includes the Forum as well as several ancient temples and palaces spanning many emperors' reigns. Each ruin has an interesting story behind it, from the location of Julius Caesar's funeral procession to the the Arch where emperor Caracalla had his brother Geta's name erased after killing him.

Seriously the best and most impressive thing in rome.. I do not know how this isnt the Number 1 place to visit in rome. I was barely aware of it on my visit. This park of history is unreal. It is like entering a roman city. I cant imagine even people who are bored with ruins and history not being impressed hear. This is the most incredible place i have ever visited. DO NOT MISS THIS. Its right across from the colloseum. I suggest taking a tour as there is almost an inifinte amount of things in this park.

Get lost in the midst of time. Amble around the amazing remnants of a glorious Empire from the time when Britains were sitting in a wooden hut with a straw roof trying to light a sodden fire.The sheer scale of the Roman (or should it be slaves) achievements is awe inspiring. How did they built such wonderful structures with nothing but wooden scaffolds and ropes?Allow at least 2 hours to meander through this wonderful area and take advantage of the crystal clear water fonts.

Gorgeous hands-on historical experience!!!!!. I spent a day walking around and poking through the ruins here. I could have spent several!! There is more than enough to keep the Roman history enthusiast interested for a very long time. Not a good place for the disabled though; much walking along rough terrain is required for much of it and the area is quite spread out.

Palatine Hill. We walked up the hill to see a great view of the Roman Forum but did not go into the museum because there are much better museum to spend your time. A good tip is to by the combo ticket for the Colosseum and the Roman Forum, Palatine Hill will be included. Also if you buy the ticket at Palatine Hill you will avoid the lines at the Colosseum.

A walk through history. We took a guided tour on the palatine hill and think it was very interessting. Our guide, Gregory, was very informative and managed to make the tour fun at the same time. On the hill there are mostly ruins so having a guided tour or some kind of audioguide is very useful to get the most out of the hill. On the top of the hill you get a good view over the Roman Forum, Circus Maximus and a distant view over the Colosseum.Be sure to bring lots of water on the hot days summer days in Rome.

“DON’T miss it!!! ... with a guide :P. Just like the Vatican City those Rome Symbols don’t need any kind of description but “DON’T miss it!!!” When I was there I get a guide for both the colosseum and the Forum and it was the best thing I did. I spend 22 euros for the ticket plus the guided tour. I think it’s different to have a real guide despite usually the audio guides work very well. This time I get really lucky and the guy that did the Forum tour was simply a colossal story teller so the visit was very interesting and amused.

A trek through ancient Rome. Incredible doesn't come close to describing it. Spectacle from lost ages on all sides, whist treading upon the ancient roadways constructed by the slaves of the Roman Empire. Starting at the Colosseum, winding up hill on the ancient stones of Via Sacra, (the road depicted in movies with the Roman Legions marching down it and the crowds standing on the sides of the road cheering), passing Caligula's Palace, the Basilica of Emperor Constantine, and through the archway of the Roman Senate. Smack in the heart of Rome, surrounded by the modern ways of a modern city with the Roman Coliseum to the South, lies the ruins and the history of the former greatness of Rome. Easy to get to off of Metro line A, (Colosseo stop), or by taking bus number 60 to the Coliseum, Via Sacra wanders up the hill through the columns and arches of the Empire. The cost is relatively inexpensive for the experience, 11 euros, (around 17 USD), for entry into the Coliseum and Palatine Hill. Private guides are also available for an additional charge. Palatine Hill encompasses the funeral spot of Julius Caesar, the Roman Senate House, temples, forums, and everything you've ever seen in a gladiator movie. On your left after your entry from the south are the remains of Caligula's Palace, (Emperor from A.D. 37 to 41, and the guy who gave all Emperors a bad name), and immediately on your right is the Basilica of Emperor Constantine. The Circus Maximus lies just to the west, (home of the chariot race, a.k.a. demolition derby with horses), and the Pantheon is about a mile or so north. At the end of the Via Sacra is the legendary Roman Forum. Guide book vendors adorn the entry and surround the Coliseum, and the purchase of one, or the acquirement of a guide I highly suggest. Knowing what you're looking at makes the experience of Palatine Hill come alive, and the experience should not be shortchanged. It's the birthplace of the Roman Empire, and a must see destination on any trip to Rome. Magnificent doesn't describe this incredible Roman day trip. It's an easy 5 stars.

Wasted opportunity. This is surely one of the greatest historic sites in the world. For most people however the experience is a huge let-down: You face surly staff, random pricing (we were charged an additional 3 euros for a temporary exhibition of which we saw no trace), and random closures (Domus Livia was closed with no explanation / many direction signs led to a fence with the ubiquitous legend 'Lavore in corso'). I'm certain this is a brilliant place for anyone to visit if they have a historian in their rucksack, but without a guide it's almost meaningless.There is a huge upside: On the same ticket you gain access to the Forum Romana, which - even without interpretative information - is truly spectacular!

walk through ruins but very hot. This is a walk through ruins which in summer will be in very hot weather. The area is littered with ruins. Entrance is through the gate in Via San Gregorio or through the Foro romano. Combined ticket is valid for both. We bought the Archaeologica card for 28 euros which entitles you to other various places and we jumped the queue because we already had the tickets. Unfortunately without a guide the area is a guess the ruins walk, but otherwise it is marvellous. Take a bottle with you to fill with water from the various springs there since it is very hot. The museum is small with many finds from the area. Of interest is the stadium, house of Augustus. However, the Forum is a much more interesting place to visit.

An essential stop through Roman history. In March, the only lines were for the WC in the modern museum building. Use your Roma pass for entry here and to the Forum. I recommend seeing the Colosseum, then Palatine, and ending with the Forum. Start early in the morning. Everything on Palatine Hill is a ruin and unfortunately, there are not enough descriptions of what you are looking at, so consider a guidebook or a guide. It would be wise to spend some time reading about imperial Rome first, including Caesar Agustus, before coming here. The area is quite large, and it is not entirely clear where one structure ends and another begins. Still, there is still considerable brickwork remaining, as well as arches and doorways, and hallways that disappear into darkness. There are also very good views of Rome in all directions. St. Peter's is clearly visible, as well as the Colosseum and the Forum. It is worth nothing that the views of the Forum are wonderful, as you are looking down onto the Forum and can see the entire area. Be sure to bring water any time of year. Be aware that much of the ground is uneven and good shoes are necessary. It would be easy to spend 3 hours here.

LOVED it!! Get a guide outside of the Colosseum. Outside of the Colesseum you will find people asking if you need a guide. I had already known about this, so when an English one asked, we said sure!! First off.... with the guide, you SKIP the line at the Colesseum! On our day it was over 2 hours long. Second, they were awesome... so much great info. There are no signs in the Colosseum or Palatine Hill... so the guide made it worthwhile. For a total of 10 Euros a person that included both tours, it was SO worth it. Heck, we would have paid it to skip the lines!! But the guides were great.

Takes you back in time. I recommend before you go to download Rick Steve's audio guide and map. If you bring your ipod with you you can have your own audio tour. There is a lot more to see here than Palatine Hill and the stories are rich with history. Make sure you have about 45 minutes to see and walk everywhere. When I went you couldn't enter down the main entrance (La Sacre), you have to enter through Palatine Hill.

Disappointing. So I listened to the Rick Steves audioguide and memorized his map of the hill. Basically it is ruins. I learned more from the audioguide and map than I could understand from actually being there and seeing it. It is mostly ruins...and I mean ruins so there is really nothing to see at all. Circus Maximus is just a grassy knoll and the only things you can really make out are the fountain and the stadium...I think if you are short on time I would just cut through to the forum.

A must see for visitors. I visited a friend in Italy for a week (which was definitely not enough time!) The Roman Forum is a must see. It's beautiful and awe inspiring. My friend gave me a minor history lesson while there and I have been reading that it's helpful to have a guide to understand the significance of the site. I did ok without one, but I suppose I had my own "guide" of sorts. It was a memorable and educational experience. A must see for visitors.

Great, audio guide not so good.. We bought our Roma passes here and it was well worth it because we planned to visit other historical sites. This pass saves you money and means not waiting in the long queues at the Colosseum! The area is a sprawling site and very interesting but the audio guide was very confusing. Still we had a guide book and various leaflets so we worked it out. This place is definitely worth a visit!

Get a guide!. I would advice visitors to get some form of a guide (audio guide, join a tour, or a really good Rome reconstructed book) before entering this attraction. My sisters and I, unfortunately did not have this foresight so we did not get to fully appreciate the significance of the forum remains. We were walking aimlessly in the forum and Palatine Hill, and the mid-day May heat did not help either :(

See it with a guide. I used Through Eternity Cultural Association as a guide. It would be difficult to make sense of this place without a guide. It is unbelievable how the emperors lived!!! The indoor riding stadium, the banqueting rooms (where you lie down to eat), even the wall decorations which looked very modern. The view of the forum and Diocletian baths is stunning. The original aqueduct that supplied homes on the hill is still intact. Some of the ruins are so sparse that you will have to have a guide to put it in perspective. This attraction is underrated.

Awesome ruins. It took about two hours to explore all of the ruins and was very educational. But folks please please do not crawl or climb up on the ruins that have been around since 500 B.C. It was a little embarrassing to see American tourists being so disrespectful for the sake of the a picture and the security guards will escort you out.

You have to walk through..... We head to the Metro for Circo Maximo stop on Line B, with a switch at Termini from Line A to B. We walk up Via San Gregorio and get online for the Palatine/Roman Forum entrance. We wait about 45 minutes and buy our ticket for the combined entrance to Palatine/Roman Forum and the Colosseum.We enter and start walking around toward Casa di Augustus (Augustus House) and stop at interesting ruins and vistas along the way. As it turns out, only 5 people at a time are allowed into Augustus, so we skip it. We walk more and see that the Palatine overlooks the Roman Forums. We walk through the Palatine and come through the entrance to the Roman Forum. It was a lovely day, but make sure to wear sneakers (or closed footware) or you will get dust all over you.Listen in on a tour group, if you can and receive a mini-history lesson. There is not too much to see here as the Roman Forum and Colosseum are right in front of you and included in your ticket.

Fascinating for history buffs. We started our Ancient Rome touring day at the Palatine, where we bought our combined Palatine/Forum/Colosseum ticket for 11 €. This was a trick from Rick Steves that worked great, since there was no line at all at the Palatine, and we wanted to see it anyway. We didn't get a map with our ticket, so if self-touring like we did, I suggest taking copies of maps and/or tour itineraries. The best guide I found for the Palatine was in the “Blue Guide Rome”. The Palatine was fascinating. There is a lot left of the giant Imperial palaces, so you can easily imagine how the emperors lived. Domitian's private stadium is largely intact. There are also older ruins on the site, going all the way back to Etruscan times, and the views from Palatine hill are superb. Well worth a visit, especially for those interested in Roman history.

Actually better than billed. The Palatine usually plays second fiddle to the Forum and the Capitoline, and wasn't marked as a 'must see' in our guide.In many ways though it was actually better than the Forum. Not as historically significant I'm sure - but there's actually quite a bit left of the various emperors' palaces.You get a good idea how lavish the lifesyle of the rulers must have lived - and the hill itself is like a little oasis of greenery and calm in the midst of the bustle of Rome.

Watch the entrance. The entrance by the Arch of Constantine is now marked "exit only". I would suggest trying an entrance to the right, down the street. We went left and ended up by the Palatine Hill. It meant we spent most of our time here searching FOR the Forum instead of exploring it.

Terrific views from the Hill, and other bits to see. We bought the combo ticket for Palatine Hill and the Colosseum and visited the Hill first. We enjoyed the Hill as it had loads of ancient ruins lying around for us to look through and under and around. As usual, bring your own guidebook 'cause there's nothing there to tell you what's what. There are: a grotto, a garden, great views of the surrounds (the Forum, the Colosseum, and Circus Maximus) and the city (you can see St. Peter's Basilica in the distance). There are marble bits lying around, so you can take a rest on a marble column if you're tired. There's a small museum with more interesting bits on show (statues, wall paintings) and it's a great place to cool off from the hot sun. (It's also got a lavatory.) Behind that is the Circus Maximus which is now mostly a grassy area bounded by parked cars. We liked Palatine Hill, mostly because there's lots of open spaces for kids to run around in, lots of trees, and because of terrific views of Rome around you. In reality, there's actually more to see at Palatine Hill than the Colosseum -- don't miss it!

Worth to see this than Coloseum. I like this place coz it didn't disappoint me. I queued for half n hour just for buying tickets to go in, and of coz everyone queuing here just wants to buy tickets faster, then they can go to the coloseum without queuing again. But this place is really worth to see than the coloseum...

Great guide for Ancient Rome. We scheduled a private walking tour of Ancient Rome with Through Eternity tours for September of 2006. We booked this tour with them online at . Our guide was Andrew, a young , fun and knowledgeable fellow from Ireland. He met us at our hotel in the morning and we took a cab together over to Palatine Hill. We got our tickets at the Palatine Hill entrance, which is key because the line is so much shorter there than at the Colosseum. Andrew then quickly immersed us into the Ancient Roman world with an accurate and entertaining history lesson that continued throughout the entire tour. Our tour included the Palatine Hill, the Colosseum and the Forum. At first I thought that we could tour the ruins on our own, but about a week before the trip we decided that we wanted a guide to help us make the best use of our time. I am so glad that we decided to hire a private tour guide. As we traveled I saw large groups struggling to keep together and listening to their leader with headsets. It was nice to be able to chat with Andrew and ask him questions at any time. He allowed us to linger where we wanted to and I am sure he was able to tailor our tour to us based on our reactions and interests. I would definitely recommend Through Eternity Tours-and ask for Andrew!

Ruins of a really BIG residence. Another surprise hit, as I was unclear on what exactly Palentine Hill was until we got up here. These are the remains of the royal families' residences--and you can see why 'Palentine' is the origin of the word 'Palace'. The place must have been immense: vast rooms on multiple levels. Check out the 'rec room' and the room with the fountain in particular. Use your imagination along with a guide or a guidebook (we used Rick Steves) as there are no markers to tell you what you are looking at.The museum (the only 'modern' building) has some very nifty stuff ie models of the original huts on the hill, and an amazing piece of mosaic from the palace is mounted on a wall. As others have said, there's a bathroom here, so take advantage!

Enjoyed Patatine Hill. Visited Rome from June 24-30, 2005. Your ticket to the Colisseum includes the Palatine Hill (across the street). We found it interesting but we had a private tour guide that explained everything to us. Great view of St. Peter's from here. Also, if you need to use the toilets, use them here, practically no wait unlike at the Colisseum.

Visit it with a guide. Excellent, amazing, incredible, WOW!!!But all other Tripadvisor users are right when saying that it is confusing ecc.Indeed you'll be pretty disappointed when going there alone. I'm usuually no tour person, but here you NEED a guide, otherwiuse it is better not to visit this place at all. Invest your money on a good guifde. Two nice options (we tried sweveral ones, as we visited Ropme 9 times) are: Icontours (for good grouptours, ask for Naomi or Mike) or still better, but obviously a little more expensive: Roberto Miglio, a great private guide, -----------------------, ask for his handsome looking son!!! :-)

Attention Rome Seekers: Use a Guide!. This site is absolutely incredible if you know what you're looking at. And it's not the place where you would want to see a bunch of signs standing everywhere to tell you what you're looking at, it would take the magic away! And a sign could never tell you the story like a guide could. So, head for the forum manned with your guide book or a trustworthy guide and go back in time to Ancient Rome!

Good, but no explanations. Interesting place - the where the powerful lived including emperors. Unfortunately there are no signs to tell you about what was there, except in the small musuem. A good guidebook would be very beneficial to bring. It's included in the Colosseum admission so take advantage of it.Unfortunately the intact house that is supposed to be impressive was closed when I was there.

Fascinating, but get a book or tour. Lots of interesting things here but since all there is to tell you are some title signs you have to have a book or take a guided tour. Even those didn't seem to take in everything - I only found out about the tomb of Romulus because a professor told his companion about it when I was standing there!A shame they don't make a better effort. But it is a must see. I went several times. (It's free.)

Nice but.... Nice ruins but there are no signs or informational guides to let you know what you are looking at. The stones are very uneven so be careful when walking. Still...amazing to see still standing after so many hundreds of years.

a worthwhile addition to your itinerary. Take an extra hour during your visit to the Forum to visit the Palantine Hill. The entrance fee includes entry to the Coloseum and is good for 24 hours, so be sure to hold on to your ticket. This is a pretty big area with the ruins of ancient palaces so you might want to read up on it and study a map before going. Pay a short visit to the small museum - there are some great statues and mosaics - all the interpretive material is in Italian. Nero's Palace is here - it's mostly underground and has a separate entry fee.
